BC-Sports-Motorcycling-Grand Prix-Doohan
Doohan calls for upgrade to 1000cc bikes
SYDNEY, Australia (AP) _ Four-time world 500cc motorcycling champion Mick Doohan has called for the establishment of a new 1000cc class, featuring four-stroke engines, to replace the existing machines. Doohan, who was second behind Spanish teammate Alex Criville in Sunday's 500cc French Grand Prix, believes a move to 1000cc four-stroke machines would attract new manufacturers such as BMW, Ferrari and Ford to grand prix racing as engine builders and suppliers. The 500cc class is the top division for motorcycle racing, but Doohan said the two-stroke V4 machines raced by Japanese manufacturers Honda, Yamaha and Suzuki for the past 15 years faced a limited future. ``It seems to me the two strokes are reaching the end of their era because the 500 V4s have been doing the same lap times for the past five years,'' Doohan said Monday. ``We're not making leaps and bounds forward anymore, the bikes never really change, and people lose interest. There's been talk about switching to four-stroke grand prix bikes and I think it would be awesome to go to a 1000cc prototype.'' Doohan said changing up to 1000cc bikes with light, small engines would make the sport more interesting, and more fun for the riders. ``Going to four-stroke prototypes would take the sport to the next level and open up racing to other manufacturers like BMW, or even Ford and Ferrari to build engines,'' Doohan said. ``Yamaha made Formula One engines even though they don't build cars so it could work the other way around.'' Doohan, who has won 48 grand prix races from 126 starts in the 500cc class since 1989, said a move to 1000cc four-stroke machines would be expensive, but the benefits would justify the costs. ``Racing four-strokes would cost more, but the manufacturers aren't afraid to spend if it will do them good,'' Doohan said. ``It's no use trying to keep it cheap because this isn't club racing. If some people can't afford to run four-stroke grand prix bikes there's plenty of other championships for them to race in.'' (tjh)

BC-Sports-Baseball-AL Roundup,0729
Red Sox beat Yankees 13-7, Mariners defeat Devil Rays 11-6
Eds: RECAPS pvs
NEW YORK (AP) _ The Boston Red Sox scored 11 runs in the third Sunday, then had to rely on a sensational stop by rookie second baseman Lou Merloni to beat the Yankees 13-7 Sunday. Boston sent 16 batters to the plate in the inning, combining nine hits and three walks _ plus three poor fielding decisions _ against Andy Pettitte (6-5) and Darren Holmes. Nomar Garciaparra and Jason Varitek each had a double and single in the majors' biggest inning this season. Pedro Martinez (6-1) turned over an 11-4 lead to the bullpen with two outs in the sixth. The Yankees scored three times in the seventh to make it 11-7 and had the bases loaded before second baseman Merloni made a diving stop of a grounder to rob Jorge Posada of a two-run single and start an inning-ending double play. Mariners 11, Devil Rays 6 In St. Petersburg, Florida, the Seattle Mariners went the equivalent of nearly three games without a home run, then hit six, including Ken Griffey Jr.'s 19th. Rob Ducey ended a 26 2-3 inning drought with a homer leading off the fourth against Rick White (0-1). Joey Cora, Edgar Martinez, Russ Davis and David Segui also homered before Griffey finished the power surge with a solo shot in the eighth off Albie Lopez. Bill Swift (4-3), pitching a day ahead of schedule because Jeff Fassero had a stomach virus, held the Devil Rays to three runs on four hits in 5 2-3 innings. Rangers 9, Orioles 5 In Baltimore, Juan Gonzalez hit his seventh career grand slam and added a solo shot for his second straight two-homer game, to lead Texas. The five RBIs gave Gonzalez nine in two games and an AL-best 71 in just 54 games. Gonzalez's grand slam came in the third inning off Scott Erickson (5-6) and gave the Rangers a 5-1 lead. Kevin Elster also homered for the Rangers, who gained a split of the four-game series. Darren Oliver (3-5) allowed three runs and seven hits in five innings, and Tim Patterson got four outs for his first save. White Sox 8, Tigers 2 In Detroit, Jim Parque pitched 6 1-3 shutout innings in his second major league start and Chicago hit three home runs for the win. Wil Cordero, Mike Caruso and Frank Thomas homered for the White Sox, who gained a split of the four-game series with just their fourth win in 10 games. Parque (1-0), a left-hander who a year ago was pitching for UCLA in the College World Series, allowed four hits and three walks. Detroit's Damion Easley went 0-for-4, ending his AL season-best hitting streak at 19 games. Frank Castillo (2-3) took the loss. Indians 8, Blue Jays 3 In Toronto, Cleveland scored four runs off Pat Hentgen in the fourth inning and Charles Nagy (7-2) pitched 6 1-3 solid innings for his fourth straight win. Jim Thome and Mark Whiten hit solo homers and David Bell and Omar Vizquel had RBI singles in the fourth off Hentgen (7-4). Carlos Delgado put the Blue Jays up 2-0 in the first with a 433-foot (132-meter) home run to right center. Jose Mesa pitched the final two innings for his first save. Angels 6, Twins 5 In Minneapolis, Jason Dickson, an All-Star starter last season, allowed two hits in 4 1-3 innings of relief before Gary DiSarcina's sacrifice fly in the ninth lifted Anaheim. Dickson (4-4), a 13-game winner in 1997, is now 2-0 with a 1.42 ERA in five relief appearances since being demoted from the rotation on May 5. Troy Percival got his 14th save. Justin Baughman tripled off Greg Swindell (0-2) leading off the ninth and DiSarcina followed with his sacrifice fly to right field. Angels starter Jack McDowell allowed 10 hits and five runs in just 3 2-3 innings in his second start since coming off the disabled list. Royals 10, Athletics 4 In Kansas City, Missouri, Dean Palmer homered and Terry Pendleton and Mike Sweeney each had two hits in a seven-run seventh inning for the Royals. The Royals had a season-high 16 hits, including eight against five pitchers in the seventh when they turned a 4-2 deficit into a 9-4 lead. Jeff King and Johnny Damon added solo homers for Kansas City to make a winner out of starter Tim Belcher (4-6). The loss went to T.J. Mathews (3-4), who walked the only batter he faced in the game.

Successor of scandal-scarred president tied in presidential race quote and ADDS that Serpa resigned as interior minister last year.
Eds: UPDATES with Sanin winning three largest cities, with Serpa AP Photos BOG101-6 By FRANK BAJAK Associated Press Writer
BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) _ Despite widespread disillusion with the scandal-tainted administration in which he was a key player, Horacio Serpa was headed Sunday for a runoff with a Conservative Party challenger who painted himself the candidate of change. With 97 percent or 10.6 million votes counted, Serpa of the governing Liberal Party had 34.6 percent against 34.3 percent for the Conservatives' Andres Pastrana, a former Bogota mayor in his second straight run for the presidency. Noemi Sanin, a former foreign minister who had hoped to break the traditional parties' century-old monopoly on power, had 27 percent, official results showed. Sanin's independent campaign had surged in recent days and she won in Colombia's three biggest cities _ Bogota, Medellin and Cali, splitting the protest vote amid a record voter turnout. Both the Sanin and Pastrana candidacies were spurred by rejection of the four-year presidency of Ernesto Samper, in which Serpa was interior minister until stepping down last year to launch his candidacy. ``Today Colombians defeated indifference but, more than anything else, we defeated business as usual,'' Pastrana told supporters. But Serpa, a populist who appeals to the poor and billed himself as the best chance for peace with leftist rebels, benefited from a well-greased political machine that dominates Congress and has held presidency for the past 12 years, trading patronage for voter support. ``The people are always wise,'' Serpa declared, promising that peace would bring true change. ``The machinery, 8th graf pvs

BC-Malaysia-Economy
Finance minister: Bad stats won't change growth forecast
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) _ Malaysia will not change its projection of 2.5 percent growth for this year, despite new figures that show the economy is in worse shape than previously thought, the finance minister said Monday. The Central Bank's announcement Saturday that Gross Domestic Product shrank by 1.8 percent in the first quarter this year was the worst sign yet of the country's economic problems, said Anwar Ibrahim. But Anwar said the news would not prompt the government to change its forecast for this year, citing positive growth in April. Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, is forecasting that exports would grow, boosting the economy, even though regional currencies have dropped dramatically in value since the onset of the Asian financial crisis. Anwar also said Malaysia would continue to allow market forces determine interest rates. ``I have asked Bank Negara to give an explanation on the interest rate policy today,'' he said. He denied that there was a conflict between Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and the central bank on the issue of interest rates. Over the weekend Mahathir had said the government was considering lowering interest rates, currently at about 15 percent. The central bank, however, was committed to maintaining rates that were comparatively high by recent standards in Malaysia. Mahathir and his closest economic adviser, Daim Zainuddin, have both warned that a tough monetary policy could derail Malaysia's recovery efforts.

BC-Japan-Politics
Japan's governing coalition breaks up four-year alliance
AP Photo TOK101
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's three governing coalition parties officially broke up their alliance Monday, bringing to an end four years of legislative cooperation ahead of parliamentary elections this summer. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, meeting with Takako Doi, head of the Social Democratic Party, and Masayoshi Takemura, chairman of New Party Sakigake, accepted the two parties' departure from the ruling bloc. The breakup, however, was seen as unlikely to have much impact on Hashimoto's administration as his ruling Liberal Democratic Party dominates Parliament's powerful lower house and should have little trouble gaining support from other parties when needed. ``Over the past year, the coalition was mainly driven at the LDP's pace and that left it in bad shape,'' Takemura said. The one-time finance minister also said that Sakigake will remake itself as a party focusing on environmental issues as its most important political issue. Doi's party decided Saturday to end its alliance with the LDP, citing disagreement with Hashimoto's party on two key issues, including political ethics and Japan-U.S. defense ties. Hashimoto said in a nationally televised interview Monday that his party will continuously respect ``a history of working together,'' indicating that the LDP will continue to seek cooperation from the former partners on some issues. The pro-business LDP has 261 seats in the powerful 500-member lower house. But with 118 seats in the less powerful upper house it still needs support from the 21-member Social Democratic Party and three-member Sakigake to gain a majority in the 252-member body. Half of the upper house seats will be at stake in elections slated for sometime in July. (km)

BC-Vietnam-Loans
Khai allocates preferential loans
HANOI, Vietnam (AP) _ Prime Minister Phan Van Khai has decided to allocate 1.5 trillion dong (dlrs 120 million) in preferential bank loans for several key industries, the Dau Tu (Investment) newspaper reported Monday. The government originally set aside 6.6 trillion dong (dlrs 510 million) in preferential bank loans for priority projects, but the garment, textile, footwear and machinery industries were not on the list. The interest rate will be 0.81 percent per month for loans in dong and 8.5 percent per year for loans in U.S. dollars, with a maximum payback period of 10 years. Longer-term loans must seek approval from the prime minister. Khai recently told government agencies to cut back inefficient investment projects in sugar processing, breweries and hotels and increase funding for projects which can find markets such as bicycles, garments, textiles and footwear.

BC-China-Dissidents
Chinese dissidents call on public to pressure government
BEIJING (AP) _ Their previous attempts to seek government redress having failed, Chinese dissidents have urged citizens nationwide to press for democratic reforms, a rights group reported Monday. In a bold open letter, the former secretary to one of China's leading reformers and 11 other democracy campaigners appealed to the public's growing sense of rights and lingering outrage over the military's bloody quelling of the Tiananmen Square democracy demonstrations. The ninth anniversary of the June 4, 1989, crackdown falls on Thursday and police have stepped up detentions and surveillance of dissidents to prevent any challenges to Communist Party rule. By one Hong Kong-based monitoring group's count, police have arrested or detained more than 20 dissidents to prevent public commemorations. Chinese leaders have refused to provide a full accounting of the military's armed sweep through central Beijing. The death toll, believed to number in the hundreds if not thousands, has never been divulged. In their open letter, the 12 democracy campaigners noted that ordinary citizens and the families of victims have repeatedly asked the government for a reassessment of the crackdown. ``These legally reasonable appeals have never obtained a well-intentioned response. To the contrary they have been met with ceaseless suppression and some people who have issued appeals have been sent to labor camps,'' said a copy of the open letter dated Sunday and released Monday by New York-based Human Rights in China. Chinese leaders' unwillingness to adopt democratic and legal reforms have allowed official corruption _ a key concern of the 1989 student-led movement _ to worsen, the letter said. ``This is an evil consequence produced by the suppression of the `89 democratic movement and the obstruction of democratization,'' the letter said. The dissidents called on the people to push Chinese leaders to re-examine the 1989 crackdown, join ``the worldwide wave of democracy,'' protect civil liberties and adopt legal reforms. The appeal was led by Lin Mu, once the secretary to Communist Party General Secretary Hu Yaobang. Hu was ousted by party elders in 1987 for having failed to stop an earlier wave of student-led protests. His death in April 1989 sparked student demonstrations that eventually brought more than a million people to Tiananmen Square.

BC-Australia-Pakistan-Nuclear, 1st Ld-Writethru
Foreign minister again denounces nuclear tests
Eds: RECASTS; UPDATES with new denunciation of nuclear tests
CANBERRA, Australia (AP) _ Australia does not accept that a nuclear arms race is the way to solve the problems of South Asia, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said Monday. Australia has called for a special session at the U.N. Disarmament Conference in Geneva to discuss the detonation of 11 nuclear devices in India and Pakistan in the past few weeks, Downer told Parliament. The special session Tuesday will allow the international community to express its abhorrence of nuclear testing and the desire for India and Pakistan to join the global non-proliferation regime, he said. ``I met the Australian High Commissioner to Pakistan, Geoff Allen, this morning and discussed the government's handling of the serious security implications of Pakistan and India's actions,'' Downer said. ``Australia has long accepted that South Asia presents particular security challenges, but we resolutely do not accept that a nuclear arms race is the way to address these challenges. ``Once again Australia calls on India and Pakistan to immediately sign and ratify the comprehensive nuclear ban treaty,'' Downer said.

BC-Japan-Autos
Japan's automobile sales down 8 percent in May
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's sales of new cars, trucks and buses fell in May for the 14th straight month as the sluggish domestic economy continued to keep consumers out of dealer showrooms. Sales fell 8 percent in May from the year-earlier month to 294,211 units, the Japan Automobile Dealers' Association said Monday. The sales are measures by new registrations. Sales dropped 2.8 percent compared with April. The sale of passenger cars was up slightly, 0.1 percent to 294,211, compared with the year before. Truck sales, however, plunged 23.9 percent to 82,614 sold the year before. Sales of buses were also down, falling 1.1 percent to 784. While demand for Japanese cars remains robust in North America, domestic Japanese consumption has lagged since a sales tax increase last year. Exports to Asia have also fallen because the financial crisis there sent local currencies into a tailspin. (dj-et)

BC-Afghanistan-Quake, 1st Ld-Writethru,0735
Aid supplies begin to reach quake-stricken area in Afghanistan site, more quotes from head of U.N. humanitarian office
Eds: UPDATES with international aid workers trying to get aid to AP Photos LON108-109 By PHIL GOODWIN Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ Aircraft laden with emergency aid flew Monday to northern Afghanistan to help the victims of a weekend earthquake that buried as many as 3,000 people, many still struggling from a temblor that struck the region three months before. The powerful magnitude-6.9 quake wiped out entire villages, sliced mountains and triggered landslides. While initial estimates are putting the death toll at 3,000, aid workers and local officials in the area believe it could rise to 5,000. There are thousands of people still missing and thousands more homeless. ``This is a mountainous region and the force of the earthquake sent houses crashing down the hillsides toward the valleys below,'' said Alfredo Witschi-Cestari, head of the U.N. humanitarian aid office in neighboring Pakistan. ``We saw a couple of villages that had been completely flattened, but there were probably more,'' he said after visiting the site on Sunday. Cargo aircraft packed with emergency supplies in neighboring Pakistan were expected to reach the region Monday, aid workers said. Tons of food, blankets, tents and plastic sheeting were to be loaded onto cargo helicopters Monday in the Pakistani capital of Islamabad and were to be sent to the mountain capital of Faisabad. From there, the supplies will be forwarded to the areas that suffered the greatest damage. When Saturday's quake hit, many of the people affected were living in tents, not having had the time, money or materials to rebuild their homes that were destroyed in February's earthquake. Among those killed were 140 school children in Rostaq, the site of a Feb. 4 earthquake that killed as many as 2,300 people and left another 8,000 homeless. Witschi-Cestari said this quake was more devastating. While the first struck a region with about 30,000 people, the second hit a hilly, rugged area that is home to about twice that population. The area's sun-baked mud homes, already weakened by the February temblor, crumbled like dry dust in Saturday's violent shaking. The homes had been made more vulnerable by the relentless rain that battered the region in recent days. ``We need help desperately. Thousands of people are dead,'' a spokesman for a northern alliance fighting Afghanistan's Taliban government said from the stricken area, near the border with Tajikistan. Opposition soldiers already had recovered 1,650 bodies, Shamshul Haq Arianfar said. Witschi-Cestari's helicopter swooped in low over several villages Sunday, opening a view onto horrific scenes. Hundreds of homes were shattered and completely flattened. U.N. officials said 4,100 houses were destroyed. U.N. officials flew over some of the most desolate and hardest-hit regions Sunday, setting down briefly near the quake's epicenter in Shari Basurkh, about 50 kilometers (30 miles) from Faisabad, capital of the Badakhshan province. They delivered tents and plastic sheeting as well as materials for an emergency clinic to be set up in Shari Basurkh for the many wounded. Aid organization officials in neighboring Tajikistan were told by the Afghan ambassador that 5,000 people were killed. The Red Cross said it was not able to confirm the figure. According to the report, the dead included 3,000 killed in Shari Basurkh, almost 1,900 in a settlement on the outskirts of Faisabad, the 140 children in Rostaq and 124 people in Chaib, on the Tajikistan border. Arianfar, spokesman of the anti-Taliban alliance, described images of utter devastation. Eight villages simply disintegrated, he said in the town of Chaib. The French Foreign Ministry plans to send on 35 tons of humanitarian aid to Duchambe, Tajikistan, where it will be transported to the disaster area by a non-governmental organization. The International Red Cross got one plane into Faisabad on Sunday and was preparing to set up a clinic in the area. The United Nations still has about dlrs 1.2 million in its emergency fund left over from a massive response to the appeal after February's earthquake.

BC-India-Budget,0409
India's government faces budgetary woes
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India's business press fretted Monday over how the government's new budget would cope with anti-nuclear sanctions, a widening deficit, rising inflation and a failing rupee. Finance Minister Yashwant Sinha was to present the budget to Parliament in a speech Monday evening. His government has promised to revive India's economic growth, which faltered to 5 percent in the fiscal year 1997-98, the lowest rate in the last five years. To do that, experts say, Sinha will have to spend on infrastructure and encourage investment. His revenue options have been reduced since the United States, Australia, Japan and other nations cut off loans and all but humanitarian aid to punish India for conducting five nuclear tests May 11-13. ``Investors are likely to think twice before they commit their hard-earned money here,'' The Economic Times said in an editorial Monday. The Financial Express, saying Sinha's budget was shadowed by ``nuclear clouds,'' speculated he would hike taxes and speed up the sale to private investors of state-owned industry to raise funds _ some of which might be spent on a bigger defense allotment ``in wake of the deteriorating security environment in the region.'' The Bharatiya Janata Party-led government's first budget ``comes at a time when the country is reeling under a prolonged low growth phase and has to stand up to international criticism,'' said The Business Standard. The government's pre-budget economic assessment, presented to Parliament last week, was bleak. In addition to the falling growth, it said the deficit rose to 6.1 percent of gross domestic product, the total value of goods and services produced by the economy, exceeding the target of 4.5 percent. A 6.35 percent inflation rate was reported Sunday, up from 5 percent during 1997-1998. The full impact of the nuclear sanctions was not yet clear, but they were already having a chilling effect. The rupee slid last week when Standard and Poor's financial rating agency revised its India rating outlook to negative from stable. A few days later, the World Bank postponed consideration of more than dlrs 800 million in development loans to India because of its nuclear tests, prompting a further slide in the rupee. The rupee opened Monday at 41.74 to the U.S. dollar; it was 39.73 at the beginning of May.

BC-Cambodia-Election
Deposed co-premier registers to vote in Cambodia's elections
KOMPONG CHAM, Cambodia (AP) _ Prince Norodom Ranariddh registered to vote Monday in upcoming elections, backing off threats to boycott if the polls are unlikely to be free and fair. But Ranariddh, deposed as co-prime minister last year in a bloody coup, said that his FUNCINPEC party may push to postpone the July 26 vote to reduce the advantage held by his archrival, strongman Hun Sen. ``We should not talk about a boycott,'' Ranariddh told reporters after receiving his voter registration card. ``But we should talk about the possibility of postponing the election.'' The opposition has accused Hun Sen of stacking the electoral process in his favor to win the polls, which he hopes will restore international legitimacy and aid lost due to his violent takeover 11 months ago. As many as 90 of the prince's supporters were killed after the coup and no one has ever been arrested. The opposition accuses Hun Sen of intimidating opposition workers and coercing voters into pledging support for his Cambodian People's Party. Ranariddh said that if fewer than 80 percent of the 5.5 million eligible voters register _ down from 90 percent who cast ballots in the U.N.-brokered 1993 elections _ FUNCINPEC should ask to extend the month-long registration process, now set to end June 15. The prince reiterated concern about the opposition's limited access to Hun Sen-controlled radio and television, calling a present plan to allocate each political party only five minutes a day to broadcast messages ``unacceptable.'' ``People must be informed about each of the parties' ... political programs and platforms,'' Ranariddh said. Last month, a coalition of opposition parties, including FUNCINPEC, said it would boycott the elections unless conditions were put in place to ensure the polls were credible and the election date was pushed back. The threat was largely intended to lure the international community into helping pressure Hun Sen to comply with a minimal criteria for fair elections. But foreign diplomats, who have shown decreasing sympathy for the opposition or its demands, have brushed the threat off as a gimmick.

Malaysia criticizes nuclear adventurism in Asia
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) _ With three nuclear powers now in the region, Asian nations must halt moves toward nuclear adventurism, Malaysia's deputy prime minister said Monday. ``We must oppose opportunistic politicians who fan the flames of jingoism, be it in the name of religion or state,'' Anwar Ibrahim said in an speech at a regional meeting on confidence building and conflict reduction. Anwar's comments reflected the growing concern over Indian and Pakistani nuclear tests among Asian nations that do not have huge armies or nuclear programs. Malaysia has opposed the tests and urged India and Pakistan to refrain from entering into a regional nuclear arms race. India conducted five nuclear tests last month and Pakistan, its archenemy to the West, last week replied with five tests of its own. ``We must constantly remind ourselves that in any conflict it is always the people, not the state, who pay the price,'' he was quoted as saying by the national news agency, Bernama. Anwar said although Asia had three nuclear powers now, the region that is home to half of the world's population remained mired in poverty and destitution. Diplomacy in Asia must go beyond conventional confidence building measures to finding remedies to remove suspicion and distrust and heal the wounds of history, he said. ``Confidence building has not worked precisely because we have not probed into the roots of suspicions and distrust between states,'' Anwar said. Asia's economic crisis was in part a result of a mismatch between the old-fashioned national systems and the global system in an information age, he said. Asian minds were still trapped in the second industrial revolution which was the age of automobiles and airplanes, he said. ``Thus, we have become T-Rex, trying to live beyond the Jurassic Age.''

Finance Chief: Recession unlikely this year
By JONATHAN DRAKE Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Singapore's economy is unlikely to slip into a recession this year despite a trend toward negative growth in Southeast Asia, Singapore's finance minister told Parliament on Monday. ``The overall picture of the Singapore economy is one of uncertainty,'' Finance Minister Richard Hu said. But he stood by an earlier government forecast of 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent in economic growth this year. Some private analysts and economists have begun predicting that Singapore's economy would contract this year, and have projected GDP at 1.5 percent. Hu said off-budget measures to stimulate the economy would be decided on in late June or July. ``As the Singapore economy is fairly well diversified, we are unlikely to slip into negative growth this year as our growth will be supported by the relatively healthy performance in the U.S. and EU economies,'' Hu said. But Hu indicated that downward growth might necessitate special economic measures ``sooner rather than later.'' ``We will not wait for GDP growth to go negative before we do something,'' he said. ``If the trend is clearly going to head in that direction we will try to do something.'' Hu said that by mid-June the government would have a clear picture of second-quarter economic developments and could react with tax cuts or rebates. The finance minister also said trade figures in the second quarter would show a 6 percent year-on-year decline. Three international investment houses, J.P. Morgan, Credit Lyonnais Securities and Santander Investment Research, have predicted a Singapore recession, with the economy shrinking up to 0.3 percent for 1998. Economic consultants firm I.D.E.A. has forecast zero growth. Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said that Singapore is still offering up to dlrs 5 billion in financing of Indonesian trade through Singapore, despite the abrupt change in government in Jakarta. Lee told Parliament that the money, which is supplemental to a rescue plan put together by the International Monetary Fund, wouldn't be released until IMF funding for the embattled country is reinstated. ``Singapore believes that the trade financing scheme can play a significant catalytic role to unlock private funding (for Indonesia),'' Lee said. The offer was made several months ago, but there has been little progress on implementing it.

BC-Japan-Food Production
Reports: Japan to abandon food self-sufficiency target
TOKYO (AP) _ The government has decided not to set a food self-sufficiency target when it revises agricultural guidelines next year, despite fears of overdependence on imports, news reports said Monday. Japan produces only 42 percent of the food it consumes, down from 52 percent self-sufficiency in 1985 and 79 percent in 1960. The country is self-sufficient in rice, however, its traditional staple. The decline has sparked fears that dependence on imports could make Japan vulnerable to food shortages if bad weather, war or blockage of trade lines should cut off supplies. But the changing Japanese diet has made it difficult for officials to impose restrictions on agricultural imports or compel consumers to eat domestically grown produce, the Mainichi newpaper reported, citing Agriculture Ministry sources. Per capita rice consumption is dropping. Japan is also under pressure from trading partners to dismantle government subsidies for agriculture, which critics say inflate food prices and keep cheaper foreign products out. The ministry is planning to revise the basic guidelines for agricultural policy next year for the first time since 1961, and there has been speculation that it would impose a self-sufficiency target. Shirara Shiokawa, of the Agriculture Ministry's planning division, said the government does not have a target in place now and has not decided whether to implement one. However, he said a government forecast shows food self-sufficiency rising over the next few years to reach between 44 percent and 46 percent by 2005. In a bid to fend off overseas pressure on Japan to further open its agricultural market, the government may set an item-by-item target for self-sufficiency in staple foods, such as rice and wheat, instead of an overall food target, Kyodo News quoted government sources as saying. Kyodo News reported Monday that the government also plans to lift a ban preventing companies under stock ownership from acquiring farmland, in a bid to make farming corporations more competitive through stock ownership.

BC-FEA-China-Since Tiananmen,0888
Life in China freer 9 years after Tiananmen, but limits remain
AP Photo NY109
EDITOR'S NOTE _ Tiananmen Square, where U.S. President Bill Clinton is expected to be formally welcomed by Chinese leaders during his visit this month, remains a symbol of the Communist Party's steely determination to rule alone. Still, the reins on Chinese society have loosened since the army's bloody assault on democracy protesters on June 4, 1989. An Associated Press correspondent looks at changes in the lives of China's people. ___ By RENEE SCHOOF Associated Press Writer BEIJING (AP) _ Nine years after it crushed the democracy movement at Tiananmen Square, China's government still wields a heavy hand to silence dissent. But these days it also is allowing ordinary people more personal freedom. To see the changes, it's necessary to look beyond Tiananmen, the heavily guarded concrete expanse in the heart of Beijing that demonstrators were vanquished from by troops who shot their way through the city nearly a decade ago. Although the government continues to slap down any broad challenge to its rule, it interferes less in the daily life of the vast majority of people who avoid political opposition. Economic growth also has brought more choices in how people live. Democracy activist Xu Wenli, who was imprisoned from 1981 to 1993, mostly in solitary confinement, sees an increased understanding of basic rights and a new willingness to speak up about them. ``Security guards at supermarkets often unreasonably accuse shoppers of stealing and treat them rudely,'' Xu said. ``In the past, people would be scared of anybody in a security uniform. Now they say, `You're violating my human rights!''' Police still follow Xu and occasionally detain him for interrogation. ``People around me who don't have the slightest connection to politics say, `They're violating your rights,''' Xu said with a chuckle. ``In the past, they didn't dare show sympathy, much less use those words.'' People speak more freely these days in part because the government is less involved in their lives now than it has been since the Communists took power in 1949. Urban workers used to depend on government offices and factories for jobs, housing, medical care and services and even had to request their employers' permission to marry or travel abroad. In 1989, work units still distributed the prized tickets that allowed workers to buy meat, eggs and rice at subsidized prices, and markets in winter sold little more than cabbage and shriveled apples. Today, grocery stores and markets brim with foreign and Chinese foods of all kinds. Today, with economic reforms eliminating many state jobs, and most cradle-to-grave benefits, the rapidly growing private sector is providing the work. Many decisions are being made by the market rather than by government officials. ``Now the market basically controls more than 90 percent of people's lives, and that's a very big change. I feel that now it's much freer,'' said Jia Qingguo, a professor in the School of International Studies at Beijing University. The development of a legal system, crucial for the growth of the economy, has enabled Chinese to hire lawyers and file lawsuits to seek protection of their rights. The most pervasive changes are the most visible. In 1989, glossy shopping malls were virtually nonexistent; now they're everywhere, along with boutiques like Romance Deluxe New York. Restaurants used to close early, and the only nightclubs were in hotels for foreigners. Now bars, discos, bowling alleys and cafes are filled with Chinese customers. The average per-capita income in cities increased from the equivalent of (US dlrs) 150 in 1989 to (US dlrs) 625 in 1997. ``Of course life has changed in 10 years. People have money now,'' said a middle-aged woman out for an afternoon of shopping at an outdoor market near the American Embassy. ``Everybody has a lot more choice in what to eat,'' said the shopper, who gave her name as Mrs. Wang. ``And look around at how well people dress these days. Some are even starting to buy cars.'' Video compact disc players are common equipment in ordinary homes, bringing access to movies from around the world. Government-run bookstores sell books like ``Crossed Swords,'' which calls for freer thinking that would allow for political reforms. Chinese-language e-mail has become a tool for business and dissidents alike. Xu said dissidents now have a ``Democracy Wall of the air,'' a reference to the movement he joined in the late 1970s centered on a wall covered with posters in Beijing. Political dissent, on the other hand, hasn't seen any loosening. While Chinese can and do ridicule their political leaders in private settings, public dissent remains dangerous. Police detained at least four dissidents last week and warned others not to travel or try to commemorate the Tiananmen anniversary on Thursday. Several dissidents have been sent to labor camps without trial in recent months after writing open letters to the government. Another recently was imprisoned for meeting with Wang Bingzhang, an exiled dissident who visited China to try to build an opposition but was deported.

BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ An advertising agency has apologized for using images of Adolf Hitler to sell potato chips in television commercials and posters targeting Thai teen-agers. Leo Burnett Bangkok, the Thai branch of the global ad agency, issued a statement of regret Sunday after Israeli diplomats said they found the advertising campaign disgusting and insensitive. The statement said the agency ``wishes to apologize to any persons who may be offended by a recent television commercial for a potato crisp that uses images of Adolf Hitler.'' The commercial was produced only for Thailand on behalf of a Thai client, Food Processing Co. Ltd., for a brand of potato chip called X. It shows Hitler giving a Nazi salute and cuts to a woman whom Leo Burnett said ``clearly wants to change his evil ways by casting a voodoo spell over him as he eats the crisps.'' A Nazi swastika turns into the product logo as the transformation is completed. ``The commercial is targeted to Thai teen-agers and is designed to communicate that the world would be a better place if happiness ruled. It was never intended to offend and the agency apologizes to anyone who finds it sensitive,'' the statement said. The poster version, displayed on many of the motorized three-wheeled taxis plying Bangkok, suggests that eating the chips would transform Hitler into a fun-loving Charlie Chaplin character. The agency said it ``acknowledges Hitler as one of history's most despicable dictators and would never do anything to suggest otherwise.'' Israeli Embassy and company officials were not immediately available for further comment. Hitler fanned fanatical nationalism in Germany and unleashed World War II in Europe, wreaking death across the continent. Six million Jews and millions of other civilians he viewed as subhuman were murdered.

Student protests against local officials erupting across Indonesia
With BC-Indonesia Eds: Many Indonesians use one name By ANDY JATMIKO Associated Press Writer
UJUNGPANDANG, Indonesia (AP) _ More than 800 students demanding the resignation of a provincial governor on Sulawesi island faced off Monday with 200 members of a Muslim youth group who support him. Despite relative calm in the capital of Jakarta, demonstrations targeting allegedly corrupt local leaders continued to erupt across Indonesia in recent days. Student protests helped force then President Suharto to step down after 32 years of iron-fisted rule on May 21. But governors and other local administrators appointed by Suharto are still in place. Soldiers and police quickly positioned themselves between the opposing groups in South Sulawesi province. The demonstrators lined up about ten paces apart and traded shouts and epithets on the grounds of the local legislature buildings in the provincial capital of Ujungpandang. Monday was the fourth day the students had occupied the buildings. They have vowed not to leave until Gov. Palaguna, whom they accuse of corruption and nepotism, steps down. The students carried banners calling for reform. Their opponents, members of the youth wing of Indonesia's largest Muslim organization, Nadhlatul Ulama, wore green camouflage t-shirts and held posters saying ``Reform Is Already Underway.'' The Indonesian capital of Jakarta has remained generally quiet since May 22 when soldiers evicted 2,000 students from Parliament without bloodshed. After helping to force Suharto's ouster, the students demanded the resignation of new President B.J. Habibie. The president has called for elections in 1999 and many of Indonesia's 202 million people appear willing to grant him a grace period as long as he follows through on political and economic reforms he has pledged. However, protests against local leaders have been breaking out like brush fires in several cities across the archipelago during the past week. Several hundred students have taken over the local legislature in the eastern Javanese city of Surabaya demanding the local governor resign. The Jakarta Post reported Monday that nine soldiers have been disciplined with two weeks of detention for using excessive force in dealing with the students. More than a hundred students have also entered their fifth day occupying the local legislature in the city of Jambi in central Sumatra, the official Antara news agency reported Monday. The students, from the Sultan Thaha Saifuddin Institute for Islamic studies, have accused local officials of allowing gambling to flourish in the district, and say they won't leave until all slot machines are burned down. Last week, a riot broke out in the northern Sumatran city of Tanjungbalai, when the local governor walked out of a meeting with demonstrators who accused him of corruption and insisted he usher in reforms. At least 20 people were arrested and dozens of shops, homes and automobiles burned in the ensuing violence.

MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Mexico's government seized the nation's largest airline on Monday after 1,033 unionized flight attendants walked off the job. Members of the Unionized Association of Flight Attendants went on strike at midnight, saying Aeromexico was unwilling to negotiate better working conditions and benefits. The government, saying national security was at state, temporarily seized Aviacion de Mexico, which runs Mexico's largest airline, and appointed an acting general administrator for the duration of the strike. ``This action was necessary to guarantee that people have transportation, and also because many areas of our economy depend on air transportation and we would have huge economic losses'' if the flights were all grounded, an official at the transportation secretariat said on customary condition of anonymity. Under Mexico's constitution, the government can temporarily seize companies considered vital to the nation's economy or security so that they can continue to operate during emergencies. Thousands of passengers were left in limbo, as the secretariat official conceded that most of Aeromexico's 300 daily flights wouldn't leave the ground. The government planned to fly as many planes as possible with Aeromexico's 300 non-unionized flight attendants, and said 12 airlines that have agreements with Aeromexico would reschedule some of the passengers. If the strike drags on, he said, the government will train new flight attendants. The union said Aeromexico wasn't negotiating in good faith. ``The company doesn't want to continue negotiating,'' said Lizette Clavel, press secretary for the union. ``We're treated as third-class workers.'' Aeromexico accused the flight attendants of making unreasonable demands, calling them ``out of the range of other airlines'' and saying meeting them would cripple the airline. ``This would prevent us from having the capital we need to buy planes and to expand,'' said General Director Alfonso Pasquel Barcenas. ``We can't put into risk our viability as a profitable company.'' The difference over salaries was small: Flight attendants said they want a 19 percent raise while Aeromexico said it was offering 18 percent. The real conflict was over benefits and working conditions. Aeromexico wants to increase each shift, which range from eight to 14 hours, by two hours. It also wants to reduce by two hours the time between shifts, which range from 12 to 36 hours. The flight attendants want a pension plan, which they don't currently have, better health benefits and guarantees that flight crews will be complete. The union says many Aeromexico flights take off with fewer than the normal number of flight attendants.

Nelson Easy Winner in Pittsburgh Senior Classic
BELL ACRES, Pennsylvania (AP) _ Even after consecutive record-tying rounds of 65, Larry Nelson was worried. ``It was a little more difficult than I thought it would be,'' Nelson said after a 2-over-par 74 on Sunday, giving him a five-stroke victory in the Pittsburgh Senior Classic with a 204 total. ``It was kind of an uneventful day,'' Nelson said. ``I just wanted to not embarrass myself.'' It helped that Nelson blistered the tournament with consecutive 65s over the Sewickley Heights Golf Club. Following an opening-hole bogey on Friday, Nelson played 40 straight bogey-free holes, finally running into trouble Sunday at the par-4, No. 6 as the wind gusted to 35 mph (56 kph) and his red-hot putter began to cool. His second shot landed on the green about 25 feet (7.5 meters) from the hole, but Nelson three-putted. Nelson also bogeyed back-to-back holes on the back nine, but followed those with a 15-foot (4.6-meter) birdie putt at the par-5 No. 15. He played even-par the rest of the way, never letting runnerup Bob Duval get closer than the final five-stroke margin of victory. ``It was a pretty good tournament, except for one person,'' said Duval, who was followed by Jay Sigel at 72-210 and Al Geiberger, who was another stroke back after a 72. Seven other players were tied at 212, including Gary Player and Ray Floyd. The tournament was never close, thanks to Nelson's blazing start on Friday and Saturday, twice tying the course record that stood unmatched since 1977. When Nelson finished the front nine on Sunday, he still led by eight strokes. ``He could have stumbled into the clubhouse and he still would have won,'' said Duval, who finished second in the Pittsburgh Senior Classic for the second straight year. Last year, Duval lost to Hugh Baiocchi in a playoff. Nelson, who joined the Senior Tour last September, won for the second time, matching the wire-to-wire victory he posted at the American Express Invitational in Sarasota, Florida, in February. He has now finished in the top 10 in 10 of the 16 Senior Tour events he has played. The first-place check for dlrs 165,000 was the second-largest Nelson has collected in his career, and it pushed him over the dlrs 1 million mark for Senior Tour earnings. Nelson also scored his second professional win at a Pittsburgh area course. One of Nelson's most memorable days as a golfer came nearby, at Oakmont Country Club, where his 62-foot (19-meter) birdie putt at the 16th hole sealed his dramatic 1-stroke win over Tom Watson in the 1983 U.S. Open.

LONDON (AP) _ Paul Gascoigne's socializing, erratic play on and off the soccer field, and lack of fitness finally caught up with him. In one of the biggest World Cup-related stories in the country since 1966 _ when England won its lone World Cup _ the 31-year-old Gascoigne was left of this year's World Cup team named Sunday by coach Glenn Hoddle. As well as Gascoigne, Hoddle also dropped five other players _ Tottenham goalkeeper Ian Walker, Manchester United's Phil Neville and Nicky Butt, Coventry's Dion Dublin and Everton's Andy Hinchcliffe _ to get down to the final 22-man team. Gascoigne, a key figure when England reached the World Cup semifinals in 1990 in Italy, returned to England after the shock announcement at the La Manga resort in southeastern Spain where the team is training prior to the World Cup, which opens June 10 in Paris. ``I can't believe this has happened. This is the worst thing that has ever happened to me,'' The Sun newspaper quoted Gascoigne as saying. The Sun said Gascoigne _ rated as one of the country's best-ever at midfield _ broke down in tears when Hoddle told him Sunday that he was not going to France and that, after a flare up with Hoddle, Gascoigne fled the team's training camp, leaving his luggage behind. Hoddle made his announcement a day early when a tabloid newspaper got wind of Gascoigne's absence. Hoddle, who is reported to have warned Gascoigne about his lack of fitness and slack training habits, was scheduled to hold a press conference in Spain at 1130 GMT Monday to explain his decision. The unexpected gamble by Hoddle, the No. 1 news item Monday across England, was surprisingly supported by more than 75 percent of callers to a popular London morning radio show. The story dwarfed news that Geri Halliwell was leaving the English all-girls pop group the Spice Girls. Gascoigne, who has played for Newcastle, Tottenham, Lazio, Glasgow Rangers and Middlesbrough, seems to have lost the ability to win games with his magical passing and dribbling. He has also suffered numerous injuries and attracted the wrong kind of publicity off the field. Ankle and groin injuries sidelined him for much of last season and, although he played 90 minutes of England's 0-0 tie with Saudi Arabia and the 1-0 victory over Morocco on Wednesday, he managed only half of the game against Belgium and limped off with a leg injury. In those three matches he looked ineffective, a shadow of the creative player that made him a one-of-a-kind on previous English sides. Some of the tabloids newspaper have been gunning for Gascoigne, accusing him of late night drinking with his showbiz friends and castigating him for smoking 20 cigarettes a day. Although Gascoigne was reported ruled out for his lack of fitness, Hoddle kept the faith with Les Ferdinand and Darren Anderton, two Tottenham players who have been short on fitness and form this season. BC-Sports-Hockey-NHL Playoff Roundup,0583
Red Wings 3, Stars 2 AP Sports Writer
Eds: RECAPS pvs By HARRY ATKINS
DETROIT (AP) _ The Dallas Stars gambled and lost. Now the Detroit Red Wings are just one win away from a repeat trip to the Stanley Cup Finals. Vyacheslav Kozlov broke a tie at 11:30 of the third period to lift the Red Wings to a 3-2 victory over Dallas on Sunday in Game 4 of the Western Conference finals. Kirk Maltby and Steve Yzerman also scored for the Red Wings, who took a 3-1 lead in the best-of-7 series. Pat Verbeek and Sergei Zubov scored for the Stars. ``We're scoring important goals at the right time,'' Detroit forward Darren McCarty said. ``We're hoping that continues. Now we've got to win one more hockey game in Dallas.'' The Stars, who are 1-16-2 at Joe Louis Arena since the franchise moved from Minneapolis, will host Game 5 on Wednesday night in Dallas. If a sixth game is necessary, it will be played Friday night in Detroit. Fourteen teams have come back from a 3-1 deficit to win a best-of-7 series, most recently the Edmonton Oilers over the Colorado Avalanche in the first round of this year's playoffs. ``I think we all realize our situation,'' Dallas forward Mike Modano said. ``We're not yet in those record books. We have something to strive for and play for. We have two days to regroup and rally around what we have to do for Wednesday.'' The Stars battled back from a 2-0 deficit to tie the game on Zubov's power-play goal 55 seconds into the third period. But Yzerman set up the winning goal, grabbing a loose puck and weaving his way across two lines. Yzerman turned at the top of the left circle and fed the puck to Larry Murphy. Dallas goalie Ed Belfour had almost no chance as Kozlov, camped at the left side of the net, deflected Murphy's shot from the top of the slot over the goaltender's right shoulder at 11:30 of the third period. ``Even at 2-0 down, we thought we could still win the game, and at 2-2, we thought we would,'' Dallas coach Ken Hitchcock said. ``But they got a great goal from three skill players. ``We gambled, going for a 2-on-0 at the net, but instead, they got a 4-on-2 going the other way.'' The rest was up to Detroit goalie Chris Osgood. The Stars, who outshot Detroit 30-23, peppered Osgood the rest of the way but couldn't put the puck in the net. Dallas pulled Belfour for an extra attacker with 1:18 remaining and put tremendous pressure on Osgood. A hard shot by Zubov, which Osgood caught in his glove, almost flipped over the Detroit goaltender. ``He came up big at the end on Zubov's shot,'' Verbeek said. ``I don't know how he saw it, because it was by my chin and I didn't see it, either.'' Osgood admitted the final minute was tense. ``They were shooting the puck every chance they got,'' said Osgood. ``I had about three guys in front of me. They were really coming after us at the end. They were pretty desperate.'' The Stars went into the game 0-for-17 on the power play during the series and their woes continued in the early periods. Maltby scored the game's first goal at 7:02 of the first period while the Red Wings were shorthanded. Yzerman gave Detroit a 2-0 lead at 12:10 of the first while Jere Lehtinen was serving a tripping penalty for Belfour. Verbeek made it 2-1 with an unassisted goal at 14:31 of the second, coming from behind the net and jamming the puck between Osgood and the post.

BC-Singapore-Economy, 1st Ld-Writethru
Finance Chief: Recession unlikely this year drop, further quotes
Eds: UPDATES with union chief predicting record layoffs, market By JONATHAN DRAKE Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Singapore's economy is unlikely to slip into a recession this year despite a trend toward negative growth in Southeast Asia, Finance Minister Richard Hu told Parliament on Monday, but the market was unconvinced. Meanwhile, the government minister who heads the national trade unions said layoffs this year would exceed the 20,000 who lost their jobs during the 1985-86 recessions. ``The overall picture of the Singapore economy is one of uncertainty,'' Hu told Parliament. But he stood by an earlier government forecast of 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent in economic growth this year. Some private analysts and economists have begun predicting Singapore's economy would contract this year with a GDP of no more than 1.5 percent. Three major international investment houses have predicted recession. Singapore's already bearish market fell on recession jitters, with property stocks fueling the sell-off after the government said it would do nothing drastic to stimulate construction or cushion the tax and interest bite for those with undeveloped land and untenanted units. The benchmark Straits Times Industrials Index fell 1.3 percent by midday. ``Because we do a lot of trade with our neighbors, demand drops, and I think if the second half of this year is worse, some companies will have to trim costs by cutting down the work force,'' said Lim Boon Heng, who is secretary-general of the National Trade Unions Congress and also a minister without portfolio in the government. He said the number of layoffs could exceed the 20,000 record. Finance Minister Hu said off-budget measures to stimulate the economy would be decided on in late June or July. ``As the Singapore economy is fairly well diversified, we are unlikely to slip into negative growth this year as our growth will be supported by the relatively healthy performance in the U.S. and (European Union) economies,'' Hu said. But Hu indicated that downward growth might necessitate special economic measures ``sooner rather than later.'' ``We will not wait for GDP growth to go negative before we do something,'' he said. ``If the trend is clearly going to head in that direction we will try to do something.'' Hu said that by mid-June the government would have a clear picture of second-quarter economic developments and could react with tax cuts or rebates. The finance minister also said trade figures in the second quarter would show a 6 percent year-on-year decline. Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said that Singapore is still offering up to dlrs 5 billion in financing of Indonesian trade through Singapore, despite the abrupt change in government in Jakarta. Lee told Parliament that the money, which is supplemental to a rescue plan put together by the International Monetary Fund, wouldn't be released until IMF funding is reinstated.

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Gascoigne Out, 1st Ld-Writethru
Gascoigne's erratic play on and off pitch costs him World Cup spot conference beginning at 1130 GMT
Eds: ADDS Steven quote; WILL be updated after Hoddle news
LONDON (AP) _ Paul Gascoigne's socializing, erratic play on and off the soccer field, and lack of fitness finally caught up with him. In one of the biggest World Cup-related stories in the country since 1966 _ when England won its lone World Cup _ the 31-year-old Gascoigne was left of this year's World Cup team named Sunday by coach Glenn Hoddle. As well as Gascoigne, Hoddle also dropped five other players _ Tottenham goalkeeper Ian Walker, Manchester United's Phil Neville and Nicky Butt, Coventry's Dion Dublin and Everton's Andy Hinchcliffe _ to get down to the final 22-man team. Gascoigne, a key figure when England reached the World Cup semifinals in 1990 in Italy, returned to England after the shock announcement at the La Manga resort in southeastern Spain where the team is training prior to the World Cup, which opens June 10 in Paris. ``I can't believe this has happened. This is the worst thing that has ever happened to me,'' The Sun newspaper quoted Gascoigne as saying. The Sun said Gascoigne _ rated as one of the country's best-ever at midfield _ broke down in tears when Hoddle told him Sunday that he was not going to France and that, after a flare up with Hoddle, Gascoigne fled the team's training camp, leaving his luggage behind. Hoddle made his announcement a day early when a tabloid newspaper got wind of Gascoigne's absence. Hoddle, who is reported to have warned Gascoigne about his lack of fitness and slack training habits, was scheduled to hold a press conference in Spain at 1130 GMT Monday to explain his decision. The unexpected gamble by Hoddle, the No. 1 news item Monday across England, was surprisingly supported by more than 75 percent of callers to a popular London morning radio show. The story dwarfed news that Geri Halliwell was leaving the English all-girls pop group the Spice Girls. Gascoigne, who has played for Newcastle, Tottenham, Lazio, Glasgow Rangers and Middlesbrough, seems to have lost the ability to win games with his magical passing and dribbling. He has also suffered numerous injuries and attracted the wrong kind of publicity off the field. Ankle and groin injuries sidelined him for much of last season and, although he played 90 minutes of England's 0-0 tie with Saudi Arabia and the 1-0 victory over Morocco on Wednesday, he managed only half of the game against Belgium and limped off with a leg injury. In those three matches he looked ineffective, a shadow of the creative player that made him a one-of-a-kind on previous English sides. Some of the tabloids newspaper have been gunning for Gascoigne, accusing him of late night drinking with his showbiz friends and castigating him for smoking 20 cigarettes a day. Although Gascoigne was reported ruled out for his lack of fitness, Hoddle kept the faith with Les Ferdinand and Darren Anderton, two Tottenham players who have been short on fitness and form this season. The move leaves England without a player with World Cup experience. The club failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup in the United States and reached the semifinals in 1990 in Italy. Trevor Steven, a former England teammate, criticized Hoddle's decision. ``There's still two and a half weeks before kick off. Paul has something that nobody else can offer the team and I would have just given him that time. ``As an England fan I would have loved to have seen him do well. But the decision has been made and I think our squad is poorer for the lack of Paul Gascoigne.'' Gascoigne's manager at Middlesbrough, Bryan Robson, was also critical. ``I'm surprised,'' admitted Robson. ``When Gazza's fit, he's the one who can do it at the highest level. He was all right when he was with us at Middlesbrough. He helped us win important games and could do that for England.'' Facing uncertain future, Indonesians return to nationalist roots
By GEOFF SPENCER By Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ As Indonesians ponder how to reconstruct their political system, many staged low-key ceremonies Monday to celebrate the birth of the national philosophy on which it was founded. New President B.J. Habibie has promised to hold elections sometime in 1999 and says that free political parties will be allowed to form as long as they follow the philosophy, Pancasila. The five-point creed mandates a belief in God and respect for the tenets of humanity, national unity, democracy and social justice. Dozens of new political parties, representing a wide range of competing interests, are expected to be formed in the lead up to the elections. Under the old system controlled by Suharto, only three loyalist parties were allowed to operate and their activities were strictly scrutinized by the government. Pancasila was drafted by Sukarno, the founding president of Indonesia at independence in 1945. But critics say the former regime of President Suharto, who resigned on May 21, misused it to suppress democracy. ``Pancasila is Indonesia's basic philosophy,'' said Megawati Sukarnoputri, Sukarno's daughter and a prominent opposition leader. ``But it has been manipulated for a long time.'' Meanwhile a leading opposition figure has called on ex-President Suharto to donate the bulk of his wealth, estimated in the billions of dollars, back to the country. Amien Rais, a prominent Muslim leader, said that with the money Indonesia would not have to beg for assistance from international agencies to prop up the economy, which is in its worst crisis in 30 years. Rais said that if Suharto did that ``the Indonesian people could find it in their hearts to pardon him.'' Rais and other critics blame nepotism, corruption and cronyism for much of Indonesia's economic woes. He has also called for a travel ban on the ex-president and his family amid growing calls for an inquiry into their wealth. In another development more than 800 students demanding the resignation of a provincial governor on Sulawesi island faced off Monday with 200 members of a Muslim youth group who support him. Despite relative calm in the capital of Jakarta, demonstrations targeting allegedly corrupt local leaders continued to erupt across Indonesia in recent days. Soldiers and police quickly positioned themselves between the opposing groups in South Sulawesi province. The demonstrators lined up about ten paces apart and traded shouts and epithets on the grounds of the local legislature buildings in the provincial capital of Ujungpandang. Monday was the fourth day the students had occupied the buildings. They have vowed not to leave until Gov. Palaguna, whom they accuse of corruption and nepotism, steps down.

Mayor, business magnate headed for runoff in Ecuador presidential race
AP Photos By MONTE HAYES Associated Press Writer
QUITO, Ecuador (AP) _ The Harvard-trained mayor of Quito and Ecuador's wealthiest man will square off in a runoff to determine the new president of the Andean nation, which is racked by instability. Quito Mayor Jamil Mahuad collected 35.4 percent of the votes Sunday while business magnate Alvaro Noboa, who boasts of owning 105 companies ranging from banana plantations to banks, won 26.8 percent, according to an exit poll sponsored by seven television stations. Ecuadoreans, fed up with corrupt and ineffective governments, were hoping the elections would produce a leader who can end the country's political and economic instability. Mahuad, who has a master's degree in public administration from Harvard University, predicted that in the second round he would receive the support of ``people who are against corruption, who are against what Bucaram and Noboa represent.'' ``We have defeated the biggest fortune in Ecuador,'' he said. ``We have won despite slanderous attacks.'' Responding to Noboa's denunciation last week that his campaign was financed by drug traffickers, Mahuad said: ``Noboa has taken off his mask. He has sold his soul to Bucaram.'' Mahuad, a 48-year-old centrist, is boosted by his reputation as an effective, honest mayor. He has pledged to improve health services and education and to combat rising crime. ``He's honest and he has kept his promises to Quito. The 47-year-Noboa is running as an independent. But despite his wealth he has the backing of Bucaram's Roldosista party, which dubs itself ``the force of the poor.'' Resorting to Bucaram's populist style, he promised to create 1 million jobs and build 200,000 homes for the poor.

AP Photos Eds: RECASTS and UPDATES throughout with celebrations, Djukanovic By ALISON SMALE Associated Press Writer
PODGORICA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Wild gunfire erupted in downtown Monday as revelers celebrated the victory in Montenegro's parliamentary elections of the biggest challenger to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. With 72 percent of the vote counted, the Election Commission in the smaller of Yugoslavia's two republics said Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic's coalition had captured 50.4 percent of the ballots compared to 34.3 percent for Milosevic protege Momir Bulatovic. Djukanovic's triumph was a new blow to Milosevic's 11-year rule, already dented by a virtual war in the Serbian province of Kosovo in which ethnic Albanian militants are gaining ground against police. Djukanovic addressed several hundred wildly cheering supporters, some of them firing guns in the air, and all singing patriotic songs. ''Montenegro has again shown that it has the wisdom, courage and resolve to resist those who decided to enslave Montenegro,'' Djukanovic said. ``This is not our final victory,'' he added. ``Our final victory will be when democracy wins throughout Yugoslavia.'' Milosevic took command of Serbia in 1987 and set a nationalist, autocratic course, spurring wars that helped unraveled the former Yugoslav federation. Djukanovic, 36, is the first man with executive power to challenge him. ``This is a major victory for democracy _ and light at the end of the tunnel,'' said Novak Kilibarda, leader of one of the parties making up Djukanovic's ``For a Better Life'' coalition. Serbia and Montenegro are the two remaining republics in Yugoslavia. Despite widespread fears that Milosevic's supporters would not recognize the results, the camp of his protege Bulatovic said they would abide by the outcome, and called the elections free and fair. Only three parties _ Djukanovic's coalition, Bulatovic's and the Montenegrin separatist Liberal Party _ made it into the 78-seat republican parliament. Among those who surprisingly missed the 3 percent barrier was Serbia's ultranationalist Radical Party. Its leader Vojislav Seselj, a partner of Milosevic in Serbia's government, expressed surprise at the margin of Djukanovic's triumph. If the trend shown by partial results is confirmed, Djukanovic's coalition should be able to form Montenegro's government without partners. More importantly, Djukanovic could name the bulk of Montenegro's deputies to the federal Yugoslav Parliament, which elects and can unseat the Yugoslav president. If those deputies teamed up with lawmakers from Serbia's opposition, they could vote Milosevic out of office. For that reason, Sunday's election was keenly contested _ with Milosevic's camp denouncing Djukanovic as a criminal and suggesting it would not accept a win for the Montenegrin rebel. The 54-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe dispatched some 120 monitors to Sunday's election, and was to declare Monday whether it considered the vote free and fair. Djukanovic has won strong support from the United States and western Europe for his defiance of Milosevic, his pro-Western reformist policies and inclusion of minority ethnic Albanians in his previous government. Both he and Bulatovic rose in the late 1980s under the patronage of Milosevic. But Djukanovic turned against his former mentor during massive anti-Milosevic protests in the winter of 1996-97. Montenegro, a republic of 630,000 people, has a tradition of settling scores with the weapons that many keep at home. Hospital officials said four people were wounded during gunfire late Sunday. Tensions between the rival camps soared as polls closed when riot police loyal to Djukanovic were deployed to block off Bulatovic's party headquarters. Police sources said they had acted to prevent planned violence by Bulatovic supporters. Hours earlier, Bulatovic threatened to shoot at police outside the apartment house where he and Djukanovic still are neighbors, local independent media said. Bulatovic later issued a statement saying he became angry because the police had harassed his wife and children. (ds/as)

BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Globalization is turning the world into a more dangerous place for children to be exploited for sex, making clean government and uncorrupt officials ever more necessary to protect them, a former Thai prime minister said Monday. ``It has become easier for the traffic in children by means of abduction, tricks and enticements both within countries and across borders,'' said Anand Panyarachun, opening a Asia-Pacific conference on human resources development for youths. The week-long conference, hosted by the United Nations' Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, was told an estimated 10 million children worldwide were working as prostitutes, with some 1 million being added every year. Meanwhile, the Internet has put a tool into the hands of pornographers to spread thousands of sexual pictures of children around the world at ``the push of a button,'' Anand said. ``Children are dealt with as commodities, traded and exchanged as part of an increasingly borderless world,'' said Anand, who led reformist governments in 1991 and 1992 in a country notorious for child prostitution. Currently the United Nations Children's Fund ambassador to Thailand, Anand said that trafficking was abetted by governments that allow corruption enabling law enforcement officials to turn a blind eye to _ or help for profit _ gangs exploiting children. Government transparency and enforcement of what Anand called ``child-friendly laws'' would go a long way toward cleaning up an environment that allows the ``dark forces'' of corrupt police and criminals exploiting children to thrive. Anand suggested a series of measures to promote child rights and good governance, including improved screening and training of law enforcement personnel, more support and incentives for good law enforcement and greater penalties for corruption. Poverty breeds abuse and exploitation, Anand said, while lack of access to education renders children more vulnerable to the sex market. Family disintegration, migration and negative traditional practices are also factors.

AP Photos planned By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ After running smoothly for months, Mir's main computer has turned skittish and was out of order for a third day Monday, threatening to postpone the Russian space station's last rendezvous with a U.S. shuttle. U.S. space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to lift off Tuesday and dock with the station on Friday to pick up astronaut Andrew Thomas, the seventh and last American to live on the Russian outpost. But that trip to the Mir is now in doubt since the shuttle can only dock with the station when its computer-controlled steering system properly aligns it for the docking. ``We hope that the crew will finally resolve the problem later today,'' said Valery Lyndin, a spokesman for Russian Mission Control. He said space officials have not yet determined why Mir's computer broke down on Saturday. Russian cosmonauts Talgat Musabayev and Nikolai Budarin replaced it with another unit, but the new unit failed on Sunday when they tried to switch it on. ``They still have a lot of spares to fix the problem,'' Lyndin told The Associated Press. He said the crew will resume attempts to restart the computer later on Monday when the station moves into a position that will permit it to relay the necessary data to ground controllers. During a chat with ground controllers, Musabayev said the situation on board ``isn't bad'' but added that he was concerned about the problem on the eve of the shuttle's launch, the ITAR-Tass news agency reported. Mir's computer repeatedly failed last year, prompting Russian space officials to send up a replacement on a shuttle ferry flight in January. That unit failed on Saturday after five months of trouble-free operation. The station's crew has replaced it with a back-up computer brought up by a Russian cargo ship. Mir's main computer operates the station's motion control system, and when it fails, the station's energy supply is threatened because it can't keep its solar panels in optimum alignment with the sun. Depending on how much energy was lost, it can take from one to three days to get the orientation system fully on-line. Fortunately, when the latest trouble occurred, the station was on the so-called solar orbit, which puts it in direct sunlight round the clock. As a result, the Mir's solar panels have remained in full sunlight. The crew also shut down some systems to save energy, and as a result Mir's batteries were full on Monday, which will make it easier for the crew to restore the orientation system, Lyndin said. MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia's nervous markets sank farther in early trading Monday despite U.S. promises to support new loans by international lenders. Nonetheless, by midday the stock market was down an additional 4.5 percent, although traders said there was little panic selling. ``We are seeing a manageable fall,'' said Robert Devane, head of fixed-income trading at Moscow's Troika-Dialog brokerage. ``We are not yet at a critical point like last week.'' Russian leaders have been working to stabilize the financial markets after a wave of panic selling last week caused the stock market to plummet and threatened a run on the national currency, the ruble. The ruble was weaker in trading early Monday, but had fallen only a few cents on the dollar. Before the crisis, Russia's economic prospects had been looking somewhat brighter, having kept a lid on inflation and recording its first economic growth since the Soviet collapse. But the government has been unable to solve a years-long payments crisis, caused by its inability to collect taxes and therefore to pay wages to state workers. Many workers and pensioners have been unpaid for months on end. Russia's new tax chief, Boris Fyodorov, said in an interview Monday that the country's 35 percent tax rate must be lowered but enforcement strengthened. ``The rate should be 20 percent, but then those who do not pay must in effect be put into prison,'' he told the NTV network. He also said Russians must get used to the idea of paying taxes. Only a small percent of Russians file income tax. ``Individual taxes constitute the lion's share of the taxation base in any normal country...'' he said. ``Where there are incomes, there are taxes.'' Russian leaders have said that the crisis was triggered by a combination of forces, including a sharp fall in world prices for gas and oil, the financial crisis in southeast Asia, and social unrest including a recent wave of coal miners' strikes. Russia has said it is not seeking a bailout package, but it is eager to get the latest installments of a dlrs 10 billion loan from the IMF.
