Wild gunfire greets victory by Milosevic foe quotes, Bulatovic accepts results, updated results.
AP Photos Eds: RECASTS and UPDATES throughout with celebrations, Djukanovic By ALISON SMALE Associated Press Writer
PODGORICA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Wild gunfire erupted Monday as revelers celebrated the victory in Montenegro's parliamentary elections of the biggest challenger to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. With 72 percent of the vote counted, the Election Commission in the smaller of Yugoslavia's two republics said Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic's coalition had captured 50.4 percent of the ballots compared to 34.3 percent for Milosevic protege Momir Bulatovic. Djukanovic's triumph was a new blow to Milosevic's 11-year rule, already dented by a virtual war in the Serbian province of Kosovo in which ethnic Albanian militants are gaining ground against police. Djukanovic addressed several hundred wildly cheering supporters, some of them firing guns in the air, and all singing patriotic songs. ``Montenegro has again shown that it has the wisdom, courage and resolve to resist those who decided to enslave Montenegro,'' Djukanovic said. ``This is not our final victory,'' he added. ``Our final victory will be when democracy wins throughout Yugoslavia.'' Milosevic took command of Serbia in 1987 and set a nationalist, autocratic course, spurring wars that helped unraveled the former Yugoslav federation. Djukanovic, 36, is the first man with executive power to challenge him. ``This is a major victory for democracy _ and light at the end of the tunnel,'' said Novak Kilibarda, leader of one of the parties making up Djukanovic's ``For a Better Life'' coalition. Serbia and Montenegro are the two remaining republics in Yugoslavia. Despite widespread fears that Milosevic's supporters would not recognize the results, the camp of his protege Bulatovic said they would abide by the outcome, and called the elections free and fair. Only three parties _ Djukanovic's coalition, Bulatovic's and the Montenegrin separatist Liberal Party _ made it into the 78-seat republican parliament. Among those who surprisingly missed the 3 percent barrier was Serbia's ultranationalist Radical Party. Its leader Vojislav Seselj, a partner of Milosevic in Serbia's government, expressed surprise at the margin of Djukanovic's triumph. If the trend shown by partial results is confirmed, Djukanovic's coalition should be able to form Montenegro's government without partners. More important, Djukanovic could name the bulk of Montenegro's deputies to the federal Yugoslav Parliament, which elects and can unseat the Yugoslav president. If those deputies teamed up with lawmakers from Serbia's opposition, they could vote Milosevic out of office. For that reason, Sunday's election was keenly contested _ with Milosevic's camp denouncing Djukanovic as a criminal and suggesting it would not accept a win for the Montenegrin rebel. The 54-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe dispatched some 120 monitors to Sunday's election, and was to declare Monday whether it considered the vote free and fair. Djukanovic has won strong support from the United States and western Europe for his defiance of Milosevic, his pro-Western reformist policies and inclusion of minority ethnic Albanians in his previous government. Both he and Bulatovic rose in the late 1980s under the patronage of Milosevic. But Djukanovic turned against his former mentor during massive anti-Milosevic protests in the winter of 1996-97. Montenegro, a republic of 630,000 people, has a tradition of settling scores with the weapons that many keep at home. Hospital officials said four people were wounded during gunfire late Sunday. Tensions between the rival camps soared as polls closed when riot police loyal to Djukanovic were deployed to block off Bulatovic's party headquarters. Police sources said they had acted to prevent planned violence by Bulatovic supporters. Hours earlier, Bulatovic threatened to shoot at police outside the apartment house where he and Djukanovic still are neighbors, local independent media said. Bulatovic later issued a statement saying he became angry because the police had harassed his wife and children.

By BETH DUFF-BROWN Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Pacific rim countries could sign an agreement this week that would simplify certification of communication equipment and allow foreign manufacturers greater access to Asia, a U.S. official said Monday. Communications equipment such as cellular phones and modems currently must meet technological standards and be certified in each of the countries where they'll be used. The Mutual Recognition Agreement would allow manufacturers to get their equipment certified by agencies in their own countries, lowering the cost to consumers and getting the products to market faster, said Larry Irving, assistant secretary of communications and information at the U.S. Department of Commerce. The United States and the European Union already have a similar agreement. ``It'll make things easier. If you make a handset in one market, it won't be as difficult to jump over hurdles to have that handset used in other markets,'' Irving said. Irving was attending a meeting of ministers of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation to discuss liberalizing the telecommunications business across borders and oceans. The MRA agreement could go into effect by July 1999. Irving told reporters that the U.S. was still ``bullish'' on the Asian market, despite the regional economic crisis that has led many investors to flee. ``While people may be stretching out investment, and that's real, you're not seeing anyone saying they're going to halt investment,'' he said. APEC ministers were also to discuss the expansion of the Asia-Pacific Information Infrastructure and Internet ``domains,'' the three-letter address endings such as .com. In conjunction with the APEC meeting, the latest telephone, computer and broadcast gadgets and systems went on display at the CommunicAsia/NetworkAsia conference. ``Governments are very concerned about what it means to be giving away to the private sector ownership and management of broadcasting,'' said Derek Nicholas, a consultant for the CommunicASia/NetworkAsia conference. ``This may well act as a retarding effect on using all this super technology we've seen.'' Nicholas spoke at the opening press conference of the conference and exhibition which covers 22,490 square meters over two sites and is Singapore's second largest trade fair. Displays at the booths for NetworkAsia, CommunicAsia, BroadcastAsia, CableSat98 and MobileCommAsia show how the different communications sectors are increasingly interrelated. The exhibition, in its 12th year, is attended by 1,800 companies from 46 countries. For the first time at a international trade fair, the three different high definition television systems, developed separately by the United States, Japan and Europe, are on display at the same show, said Stephen Tan, managing director of Singapore Exhibition Services. ``Many countries, including Singapore, are in the process of deciding which (of the HDTV systems) to adopt,'' Tan said. Japan and Australia have said they will put HDTV into operation for national broadcasting by 2000-2001.

Japan's governing coalition breaks up after four year alliance
Eds: RECASTS; Updates throughout with background; ADDS byline. AP Photo TOK101 By CHESTER DAWSON Associated Press Writer
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's governing coalition officially broke up Monday ahead of parliamentary elections this summer, bringing an end to a four-year alliance between formerly bitter rivals. In a widely expected move, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto accepted the decision of the Social Democratic Party and New Party Sakigake to withdraw from the government, allowing his Liberal Democratic Party to formally reclaim its position as sole ruling party. It ended an oddball marriage between the conservative LDP and left-leaning Social Democrats, formerly Japan's socialist party. Previous to linking up in June of 1996, the two parties had been political enemies for most of the post-World War II era. The coalition's demise was seen as unlikely to have much impact on Hashimoto's administration. The Liberal Democratic Party has already assumed all Cabinet posts and enjoys a majority in the more powerful of Japan's two legislative chambers. ``Over the past year, the coalition was mainly driven at the LDP's pace and that left it in bad shape,'' said Masayoshi Takemura, chairman of New Party Sakigake. Social Democrat head Takako Doi said her party decided to end its alliance with the LDP over disagreements with Hashimoto's party on key legislative issues such as more stringent political ethics and the strengthening of U.S.-Japan defense ties. But the withdrawal was also viewed as a tactical move before elections slated for sometime in July. Half of the seats in the upper house of parliament will be up for grabs. The pro-business Liberal Democratic Party has 261 seats in the powerful 500-member lower house. With 118 seats in the less powerful upper house, it still needs support from the 21-member Social Democratic Party and three-member Sakigake to gain a majority in the 252-member body. The Social Democrats and Sakigake party were expected to continue to vote with the LDP on a case-by-case basis. And the Social Democrats have pledged to support Hashimoto's administration if opposition parties submit a no-confidence vote against the government. Hashimoto said in a nationally televised interview Monday that his party will respect the ``history of working together'' with the two parties, indicating he will seek cooperation from them on some issues. Still, Hashimoto may need to court additional support from independent lawmakers and non-aligned parties such as a lay Buddhist political group which once had close ties to the LDP. In June of 1996, the LDP joined hands with the Social Democrats in what was dubbed an ``unholy alliance,'' producing Japan's first socialist prime minister in 46 years. While the two parties had long been rivals, they buried their enmity in a bid to keep from power a reformist coalition made up of political renegades from both parties. The LDP was toppled from power by this reformist coalition in July of 1993 after four decades as Japan's sole ruling party. (cd-km)

The Central Bank's announcement Saturday that Gross Domestic Product shrank by 1.8 percent in the first quarter this year was the worst sign yet of the country's economic problems, said Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim. But Anwar, who is also Malaysia's deputy prime minister, said the news would not prompt the government to change its forecast for this year, citing positive growth in April. Deposed co-premier registers to vote in Cambodia's elections conquered, grafs 4-6
Eds: UPDATES with Ranariddh fearing opposition will be divided,
KOMPONG CHAM, Cambodia (AP) _ Prince Norodom Ranariddh registered to vote Monday in upcoming elections, backing off threats to boycott if the polls are unlikely to be free and fair. But Ranariddh, deposed as co-prime minister last year in a bloody coup, said that his FUNCINPEC party may push to postpone the July 26 vote to reduce the advantage held by his archrival, strongman Hun Sen. ``We should not talk about a boycott,'' Ranariddh told reporters after receiving his voter registration card. ``But we should talk about the possibility of postponing the election.'' Ranariddh expressed fears that the opposition vote would be badly divided and ballots cast for his chief opposition rival, Sam Rainsy, would ultimately benefit Hun Sen's powerful Cambodian People's Party. ``When the CPP wins, they will form a government with Sam Rainsy, leaving us as an opposition party,'' Ranariddh said. Sam Rainsy, once a leading light in FUNCINPEC who now heads his own party, has voiced similar fears about Ranariddh, pointing up the deep division and mistrust in the opposition to Hun Sen. The opposition has accused Hun Sen of stacking the electoral process in his favor to win the polls, which he hopes will restore international legitimacy and aid lost due to his violent takeover 11 months ago. As many as 90 of the prince's supporters were killed after the coup and no one has ever been arrested. The opposition accuses Hun Sen of intimidating opposition workers and coercing voters into pledging support for his Cambodian People's Party. Ranariddh said that if fewer than 80 percent of the 5.5 million eligible voters register _ down from 90 percent who cast ballots in the U.N.-brokered 1993 elections _ FUNCINPEC should ask to extend the month-long registration process, now set to end June 15. The prince reiterated concern about the opposition's limited access to Hun Sen-controlled radio and television, calling a present plan to allocate each political party only five minutes a day to broadcast messages ``unacceptable.'' ``People must be informed about each of the parties' ... political programs and platforms,'' Ranariddh said. Last month, a coalition of opposition parties, including FUNCINPEC, said it would boycott the elections unless conditions were put in place to ensure the polls were credible and the election date was pushed back. The threat was largely intended to lure the international community into helping pressure Hun Sen to comply with a minimal criteria for fair elections. But foreign diplomats, who have shown decreasing sympathy for the opposition or its demands, have brushed the threat off as a gimmick.

Hezbollah threatens attacks, Israeli warns of harsh response
BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP) _ Hezbollah guerrillas have threatened retaliation for an Israeli missile strike that hit civilians in south Lebanon, while Israel warned of a tough response if shells fall in Israeli territory. The twin warnings raised fears in Lebanon of a new round or cross-border fighting in which far more Lebanese die than Israelis. In Israel, newspapers reported Monday that residents of northern Israel spent the night in shelters in fear of a possible Hezbollah attack. ``The resistance ... cannot keep quiet in light of what has happened,'' Sheik Nabil Kaouk, Hezbollah commander in the south, told reporters Sunday night after weekend Israeli rocket attacks killed a Lebanese shepherd and wounded his brother and another man. In Israel, radio reports quoted the Israeli army's northern command as warning it will respond ``harshly'' if rockets fall on northern Israel. The Israeli army also suggested Monday that the harm to civilians was unintentional. ``Israel has no interest in attacking citizens,'' an army statement said, adding the targeted area ``is an open space and anyone in it is suspected of being a terrorist or protecting terrorists.'' Cross-border guerrilla rocket attacks triggered major fighting in 1996 in which at least 175 people, mostly Lebanese civilians, were killed. Since then, Hezbollah has targeted the occupied zone and occasionally Israeli positions along the international border for retaliation. On Sunday, Israeli troops fired a missile near a village in southern Lebanon, killing a Lebanese shepherd and wounding his brother, security officials said. On Saturday night, an Israeli rocket attack injured a guerrilla near another village. The Lebanese security officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, originally said two brothers were killed in the rocket attack Sunday. But they later said one of the brothers had only been wounded and was hospitalized. Both targets hit by Israel are in a guerrilla mountain stronghold on the edge of the Israeli-occupied border zone in the south. Hezbollah is leading the fight to oust some 1,500 Israeli troops and 2,500 Lebanese militia allies from the occupied zone. Israel or its allies have controlled the zone for over 20 years, maintaining the occupation is needed to guard against cross-border guerrilla raids. sfg-zk-jer-ggl

Lonely heart Japanese seek mates with love beeper
By CHISAKI WATANABE Associated Press Writer
TOKYO (AP) _ Lonely hearts are prowling the streets of Japan, armed not with romantic haiku poems or long sultry looks, but with the ultimate matchmaking tool of the electronic age. The love beeper. While the real name of the gadget _ ``Lovegety'' _ might not be so fetching, the toy's makers _ and the 400,000 souls who have bought one already _ are hoping it'll open the door to romance. The Lovegety _ a rather straightforward mix of ``love'' and ``get'' _ is an oval disc that fits in your hand. It's carried on forays into crowded places and sends out different signals, depending on the setting. When someone of the opposite sex carrying a Lovegety comes into range, the two machines beep or flash. Then it's up to the would-be lovers to seek each other out _ or run the other way. The device, which came out in February, has three settings for favorite activities: ``karaoke'' for romantic crooners, ``chat'' for those who want to talk, and ``friends'' for something, well, more intimate. ``This ... gives you a way to start a chat,'' said Takeya Takafuji, executive planning director for the manufacturer, Erfolg. ``It's just one way to meet people.'' Erfolg, a small company that makes modems, said there a backlog for more than 200,000 units, and the company is boosting production this month. Sales to Singapore and Hong Kong are planned, and the company expects the boom will increase annual revenues sevenfold to dlrs 15 million. The beeper, which retails for 2,980 yen (dlrs 22), can pick up signals from 5 meters (yards) away. A flashing green light means a match in interests, while red means there's a Lovegety next to you, but you've got the wrong setting. The settings can be changed any time, and the timid can keep the beeper off so only the lights will flash. Encouraged by brisk sales, the company plans to introduce an upgraded version in August with more choices, such as ``movie,'' ``drink'' and ``dinner.'' The new version will also pick up signals from 100-meters (yards) way. What if the person at the other end of the signal isn't The One? ``If this middle-aged man isn't your type or you think there is no way you want to talk to him, then you just walk away,'' said Takafuji. ``He'll never notice.''

MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ Philippine stocks fell for a seventh straight session Monday, with regional uncertainties and a lack of positive domestic news discouraging buyers, traders said. The 30-share Philippine Stock Exchange Index fell 15.40 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,996.05 after slipping 2.78 points Friday. The index now has lost 152.56 points, or 7 percent, since May 22. ``Foreign investors aren't in the market and in most of the region since there's really no reason to invest,'' said Noel Reyes, vice president for research at Anscor-Hagedorn Securities Inc. Reyes expects the market's lethargic trading, due to the absence of foreign investors, to continue for at least six months. Traders said the Dow Jones Industrial Average's 70.25-point drop to 8,899.95 Friday added to the market's selling mode, with local investors cashing in their blue chips. The poor, but largely expected, first-quarter economic growth figures released last Friday were discounted by the market days before their announcement, traders said. However, they continued to cast a shadow over market sentiment. ``The latest data raise concerns that the government won't even meet its gross national product growth target for the year,'' said Reyes. He said the government's optimism may be a ``state of denial.'' GNP growth was 2.5 percent in the first quarter. The government is targeting GNP growth at 3 percent to 4 percent for the full year. Losers trampled gainers, 67 to 13, while 46 issues closed unchanged. In currency trading, the peso closed slightly higher against the dollar, with slack demand for the U.S. currency helping to buffer the peso from the weaker regional currency trend. ROME (AP) _ Leaders of the center-right opposition headed by media mogul Silvio Berlusconi have rebuffed calls to put off a key parliamentary vote on political reform, state radio reported Monday. Premier Romano Prodi's center-left coalition has made the reforms a major goal of the two-year-old government, and some parliamentary leaders last week raised the prospect of early elections if 17 months of legislative efforts to change the system yield nothing. RAI radio said Gianfranco Fini, a right-wing leader and Berlusconi's main ally in the opposition Freedom Alliance, turned down a proposal from Franco Marini, an ex-Christian Democrat within the alliance, to postpone the vote, which is set for Tuesday in the Camera of Deputies. Marini had suggested putting off the vote for a while so politicians could search for a compromise. The process stalled over a demand by Berlusconi, a former conservative premier, that the figure of the president be granted power to dissolve Parliament at any time, not just when the premier resigns. Under the draft of proposals presented to Parliament by a 70-member multiparty committee, the president would be directly elected instead of chosen by Parliament, as is the case now. Italy's leftist parties strongly oppose increased presidential powers. After the downfall of Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini, writers of the new constitution purposely created a weak central executive. The reform committee also drew up plans to reshape the legislature, grant more regional autonomy and create a greater division between judges and prosecutors. (fd)

Militant labor group likely to cancel nationwide strike consultative body, CORRECTS president's visit to June 6-14
EDs: UPDATES with mainstream labor group's decision to join By KYONG-HWA SEOK Associated Press Writer
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ Bowing to public pressure, South Korea's militant workers appeared ready Monday to withdraw their strike threats and negotiate their differences with the government. Reversing its previous stance, the Federation of Korean Trade Unions said it will join a government-proposed consultative committee to discuss ways to salvage South Korea's battered economy. The federation claims 1.5 million members in white-collar and small-business jobs. Meanwhile, the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions, a smaller but more militant labor group, indicated it may call off a nationwide strike scheduled for next week during President Kim Dae-jung's visit to the United States. The confederation, which claims a membership of 500,000 in auto, shipbuilding and other heavy industries, had planned to cap a recent series of labor strikes and protests with a large-scale strike on June 10 to protest growing layoffs. ``A much feared government-labor confrontation may be averted,'' the all-news cable television network, Yonhap TV, reported. The government has been trying to lure union leaders into a consultative body of representatives from the government, labor and management to resolve labor problems through dialogue. A similar body, formed in January, succeeded in adopting a pact that made layoffs easier, a major concession by workers accustomed to lifetime employment during South Korea's boom years. But labor leaders later accused the government and management of laying off workers en masse while dragging their feet on implementing promised benefits to the unions. Critics warned that a new strike could hurt efforts by President Kim to attract foreign investment during his June 6-14 visit to the United States. ``We intend to fully cooperate (with the government) so that President Kim Dae-jung's state visit to the United States will be successful,'' a statement from the confederation said. The confederation said it already has formed a high-ranking negotiating team and urged the government to ``appear at the negotiation table and make serious efforts to resolve pending problems.'' A confederation official, requesting anonymity, said it was possible that the strike could be canceled or delayed, depending on ``the attitude of the government.'' Officials at the Labor Ministry refused to discuss details but acknowledged that both sides have been meeting to break the stalemate. State KBS-TV reported that the government has made fresh promises to minimize layoffs, significantly increase unemployment benefits and accelerate restructuring of South Korea's bloated, family-oriented conglomerates, or chaebol _ key demands of labor unions. Thousands of workers clashed with riot police on May Day, resulting in dozens of people injured. Protest rallies and street demonstrations have since become almost a daily event. Prosecutors are pushing criminal charges against more than 100 labor leaders for alleged involvement in a two-day strike by autoworkers and other laborers last week. Government figures show that the number of jobless people has doubled to nearly 1.5 million and may top 2 million by the end of this year.

BC-Russia-Mir, 1st Ld-Writethru
Mir computer failure threatens U.S. shuttle launch successfully running first tests, UPGRADES attribution.
Eds: UPDATES with crew trying again to restart computer, AP Photos planned By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ After running smoothly for months, Mir's skittish central computer was out of order for a third day Monday, threatening to postpone the Russian space station's last rendezvous with a U.S. shuttle. U.S. space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to lift off Tuesday and dock with the station on Friday to pick up astronaut Andrew Thomas, the seventh and last American to live on the Russian outpost. But that trip to the Mir is now in doubt since the shuttle can only dock if the station's computer-controlled steering system properly aligns it for the docking. ``We hope that the crew will finally resolve the problem later today,'' said Valery Lyndin, a spokesman for Russian Mission Control. He said space officials have not yet determined why Mir's computer broke down on Saturday. Russian cosmonauts Talgat Musabayev and Nikolai Budarin replaced it with another unit, but the new unit failed on Sunday when they tried to switch it on. ``They still have a lot of spares to fix the problem,'' Lyndin told The Associated Press. The crew resumed attempts to restart the computer later on Monday and were running the first tests successfully. They will try to put it back on line in the next few hours, Lyndin said. During a chat with ground controllers, Musabayev said the situation on board ``isn't bad'' but added that he was concerned that it occurred on the eve of the shuttle's launch. ``I'm worried not for myself, but for the flight program,'' he said. Mir's computer repeatedly failed last year, prompting Russian space officials to send up a replacement on a shuttle ferry flight in January. That unit failed on Saturday after five months of trouble-free operation. The station's crew has replaced it with a back-up computer brought up by a Russian cargo ship. Mir's main computer operates the station's motion control system, and when it fails, the station's energy supply is threatened because it can't keep its solar panels in optimum alignment with the sun. Depending on how much energy was lost, it can take from one to three days to get the orientation system fully on-line. Fortunately, when the latest trouble occurred, the station was on the so-called solar orbit, which puts it in direct sunlight round the clock. As a result, the Mir's solar panels have remained in full sunlight. The crew also shut down some systems to save energy, and as a result Mir's batteries were full on Monday, which will make it easier for the crew to restore the orientation system, Lyndin said. BC-Taiwan-China-Military
Taiwan spy chief warns of Chinese invasion capability
TAIPEI, Taiwan (AP) _ Redeployment and renewal have made China's forces capable of invading Taiwan, and its military is devoted to training for the task, Taiwan's spy chief said Monday. New weapons and advances in electronic warfare have vastly increased the threat to Taiwan from China's military, Yin Tsung-wen, director of the National Security Bureau, said in a rare public appearance. Meanwhile, the reduction of other defense concerns has allowed the People's Liberation Army to train exclusively for an invasion of Taiwan, Yin told an audience of university students in a pitch for new recruits. Yin's comments reflect the seriousness with which Taiwan's leaders view the military threat from China, and their determination to keep the public focused on defense. Two years of military service are required of all Taiwanese males, but the services have difficulty recruiting professional soldiers. The government also has difficulty persuading the public to remain vigilant. Business clamors for closer economic links with China. China claims sovereignty over Taiwan, and threatens to invade if the island declares formal independence. Taiwan was ruled for 50 years as a Japanese colony until 1945, and split from China again in 1949 at the end of the Chinese civil war. Most foreign observers discount China's ability to launch a full-blown invasion, citing deficiencies in its air and sea lift capacities. Taiwan also has its own formidable defenses. But officials here refer to the Chinese threat in dire terms. A Defense Ministry white paper issued in March warned China is now capable of at least a partial blockade of Taiwan, and said China's missiles could cripple its military and civil institutions. Yin said a Chinese invasion would begin with an electronic assault on Taiwan's communications and financial networks, followed by missile attacks, a fight for control of airspace and coastal seas, and finally a ground invasion. The Soviet Union's breakup allowed China to move forces stationed on its northern border into coastal provinces opposite Taiwan, Yin said. Missile tests and war games held near Taiwan in 1995-96 were examples of the PLA's single-minded devotion to an invasion, Yin said. China staged those exercises, which included firing missiles just 35 kilometers (21 miles) from Taiwan's coast, in an attempt to intimidate those advocating the island's independence. Yin said the major intelligence threat to Taiwan came not from Beijing's spies here, who he said number less than 100, but from Taiwanese who visit China. His bureau has stepped up surveillance of Taiwanese suspected of funneling military and technological secrets to China, he said.

BC-SKorea-Trade
South Korean exports decrease for first time in four months
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ Exports, the engine of South Korea's economy, decreased slightly in May for the first time in four months, dimming hopes for a fast economic recovery. Exports in May dropped by 2.6 percent to dlrs 11.4 billion from the same month last year, the first monthly drop since January, the Ministry of Industry and Energy said Monday. Imports in May also fell 37.5 percent to dlrs 7.7 billion from a year ago, mainly because of depressed domestic consumption and facility investment and falling oil prices. That created a dlrs 3.7 billion trade surplus in May, the seventh straight monthly gain, and pushed South Korea's total trade surplus so far this year to dlrs 16.1 billion. But analysts said the continuing trade surplus is unhealthy because it results from sharply decreasing imports rather than increased exports, which have led the country's economic expansion. Officials attributed the decreased May exports to the financial difficulties in Asia, where many currencies were sharply devaluated in recent months. Asian countries have traditionally consumed about half of South Korean exports. But Korean exports to the region fell by 10 percent between January and April. ``I believe the incentives of the weak Korean won, or price competitiveness of Korean products by currency devaluation, are already gone,'' said Lee Pil-sang, an economics professor at Korea University. The Korean won has lost nearly half of its value since late 1996. But other Asian currencies were also devaluated, ranging between 16 percent for Japan and 80 percent for Indonesia. The weak currencies, especially the Japanese yen, hurt Korean exports in the international markets as the nation's key exports such as semiconductor, steel, ships, and home appliances compete with Japanese exports. Lee also said that the decreasing South Korean imports of raw materials could affect future South Korean exports. ``Fewer imports of raw materials now means fewer exports in the future. The impact has been little so far, but it will be bigger and bigger,'' Lee said. ``Considering all, the prospect for our exports in coming months is quite gloomy.'' South Korea began to post trade surpluses in November when the surplus reached dlrs 120 million. It reported a record trade surplus of dlrs 3.91 billion in April. The nation recorded a trade deficit of dlrs 528 million in May, last year. The total 1997 trade deficit reached dlrs 8.5 billion. South Korea called in the International Monetary Fund in December to bail out an economy on the verge of collapse under the weight of over dlrs 150 billion in foreign debts.

Cabinet meeting ends without decision on West Bank withdrawal
By DINA KRAFT Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Despite growing U.S. pressure on Israel to make a decision, Israel's Cabinet on Monday again failed to reach agreement on the the scope of a West Bank troop withdrawal. Israel's continued indecision is likely to further strain ties with the United States which reportedly has demanded an Israeli answer within several days to its proposal for a pullback from 13 percent of the West Bank. However, U.S. ultimatums to Israel have come and gone in the past month without repercussions for Israel, and it appeared Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was more concerned about the survival of his government than about possible U.S. censure. We were assured by the prime minister that there would be no troop redeployment that will hurt the settlements.'' The Jewish Settlers' Council on Monday launched a campaign to turn Israeli public opinion against a 13 percent troop pullback. Recent polls have suggested that a large majority in Israel want Netanyahu to forge ahead with the peace negotiations and agree to a troop withdrawal. In the settlers' campaign, brochures were mailed to 1 million homes in Israel, with maps illustrating the settlers' arguments that a pullback would endanger water resources, Israeli security and control over Jewish holy sites. U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has been trying for months to break the deadlock between Israel and the Palestinians on the pullback. The Palestinians have accepted the U.S. proposal for an immediate 13 percent pullback, to be followed by another significant withdrawal whose scope has not been determined. Israel radio and the Maariv daily reported Monday that Netanyahu was considering a 15 percent pullback in three stages. Netanyahu's adviser, David Bar-Illan, was not immediately available for comment, but the radio said Netanyahu denied the report. On Monday morning, Netanyahu first met with Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai and Infrastructures Minister Ariel Sharon, and the three failed to reach agreement on a troop pullback, Israel radio said. Sharon, a former defense minister, insists that handing over more than 9 percent would endanger Israel's security. Mordechai told the daily the Yediot Ahronot daily before the meetingt that ``the time has come to make decisions on everything connected to the peace talks and the Palestinians.'' After consulting with his ``kitchen Cabinet,'' Netanyahu convened all of the ministers to discuss the pullback. The two-and-a-half hour meeting produced no result. kl

Finance chief: recession unlikely this year exports.
Eds: RECASTS throughout with updates, quotes; UPDATES with market figures and reaction; CORRECTS figure in graf 14 is for May non-oil By JONATHAN DRAKE Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Singapore's economy is unlikely to slip into a recession this year despite a trend toward negative growth in Southeast Asia, Finance Minister Richard Hu told Parliament on Monday, but the markets were unconvinced. ``The overall picture of the Singapore economy is one of uncertainty,'' Hu told Parliament. But he stood by an earlier government forecast of 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent in economic growth this year. Meanwhile, the government minister who heads the national trade unions said layoffs this year would exceed the peak of 20,000 who lost their jobs during the 1985-86 recession. Some private analysts and economists have forecast Singapore's economy slowing this year to about 1.5 percent GDP growth. Three major international investment houses have predicted recession. Singapore's already bearish market fell on the recession jitters, with the benchmark Straits Times Industrial Index falling 1.6 percent to close at 1,234.57 points. Also, Singapore's currency fell against the U.S. dollar to 1.69 in late trading. Dealers said Hu's assurances that Singapore won't slip into a recession this year run counter to growing pessimism among some private economists and fears of recession elsewhere in the region. He failed to calm market nerves. ``Because we do a lot of trade with our neighbors, demand drops, and I think if the second half of this year is worse, some companies will have to trim costs by cutting down the work force,'' Lim Boon Heng, who is secretary-general of the National Trade Unions Congress and also a minister without portfolio in the government, said Sunday. he predicted record unemployment by the end of the year. Finance Minister Hu said off-budget measures to stimulate the economy would be decided on in late June or July. ``As the Singapore economy is fairly well diversified, we are unlikely to slip into negative growth this year as our growth will be supported by the relatively healthy performance in the U.S. and (European Union) economies,'' Hu said. But he indicated that signs of a contraction might necessitate special economic measures ``sooner rather than later.'' ``We will not wait for GDP growth to go negative before we do something,'' Hu said. ``If the trend is clearly going to head in that direction we will try to do something.'' Hu said that once the May figures are available in mid-June, the government would have a clearer picture of second-quarter economic developments and could react with tax cuts or rebates. ``We would like to look at the May figures before we react,'' Hu said in response to questions from members of parliament over whether the government was responding quickly enough. ``Certainly its not too long to wait for a few weeks.'' The finance minister also warned preliminary data showed non-oil domestic exports dropping by 6 percent in May. Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said that Singapore is still offering up to dlrs 5 billion in financing of Indonesian trade through Singapore, despite the abrupt change in government in Jakarta. Lee told Parliament that the money, which is supplemental to a rescue plan put together by the International Monetary Fund, wouldn't be released until IMF funding is reinstated.

PARIS (AP) _ Passengers were stranded Monday at airports across France after Air France pilots began a strike that threatened to disrupt travel plans during the World Cup soccer games. Monitors at Paris' main airports offered a bleak sight for passengers: ``annule,'' _ canceled _ written in red next to almost all international and domestic flights. The strike began at midnight after Air France failed to reach an agreement with pilots seeking to block wage cuts. Air France set up special telephone lines for passengers seeking information on flights. There was no immediate indication of how many flights were canceled or which routes were most affected. Most of the company's aircraft _ many of them decorated with players representing the 32 World Cup teams _ remained grounded Monday. Air France is the official carrier for the World Cup. The World Cup, held every four years, will attract an estimated one million people to France. The tournament kicks off June 10. A combined audience of 40 billion is expected to view the four-week soccer bonanza. Air France expects to cancel 90 percent of long-haul flights for the coming week. About 25 percent of short- and medium-haul flights out of Paris' Charles de Gaulle airport are likely to fly as planned, the company has said, as are about 20 percent leaving from Orly airport. The spokesman for the leading union in the strike, the SNPL, apologized to customers. ``We have no other choice,'' Christian Paris said on France Info radio on Sunday. Transport Minister Jean-Claude Gayssot, speaking on French television, urged both sides to ``take up the path of discussion.'' Fearful that France's image could be tarnished when the soccer matches begin, one leftist lawmaker, Georges Sarre, denounced the pilots as ``the damned of the Earth.'' Sarre, speaking Sunday on French television, said the pilots were ``practicing blackmail on the company.'' The SNPL union has called a 15-day renewable strike starting Monday. Three smaller unions called for a strike from Monday to Thursday. Most of the state-run carrier's 3,200 pilots were likely to take part. The pilots are asking the carrier to abandon a plan to save dlrs 83 million a year by cutting into their salaries, currently among the highest in their field in the world. The cost-saving measure also calls for pilots hired after June 1997 to begin at a lower salary than their predecessors did. Air France President Jean-Cyril Spinetta sees the plan as critical to keeping the airline profitable. Air France reported strong 1997 earnings after years of crippling debts. (scw)

Germany's Klaus Kinkel and Iran's Kamal Kharrazi also had a ``detailed'' telephone conversation late Sunday on bilateral relations, the ministry said, declining to provide details. KINSHASA, Congo (AP) _ As many as 500 ethnic Mai-Mai rebels have surrendered in northeastern Congo after a series of government military operations against their bases, the Ministry of Defense confirmed Monday. The mass surrender follows a series of government military operations to clear out the Mai-Mai rebels and their allies from the area around the town of Goma, near the Rwandan border. ``We launched these operations along the border between the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda,'' said Maj. Ande Kanou, a commander with Kabila's forces in Goma. ``The results you will see are the young Mai-Mai who came out.'' After toppling the late dictator Mobutu Sese-Seko and coming to power a year ago this month, Kabila has been struggling to quell growing unrest among the Mai-Mai rebel forces in eastern Congo _ formerly Zaire. State-run television over the weekend said the Mai-Mai had been used for cover by military operatives from Rwanda, but did not elaborate. The Mai-Mai reportedly draw strength from the former Rwandan Armed Forces along with support from militia groups elsewhere in Rwanda and neighboring Uganda. The Mai-Mai, whose name in Swahili means `magic water,' are made up of fighters from tribes in eastern Congo who joined the Kabila rebel alliance that ousted Mobutu. They subsequently turned against Kabila, mainly in protest against the presence of ethnic Tutsis from neighboring Rwanda and eastern Congo in the new army and local administration. Tutsi fighters from Rwanda played an important role in Kabila's rebel war last year, but also stand accused of widespread massacres against Rwandan Hutu refugees in Congo. Kanou said Congolese forces had launched several attacks on camps in North Kivu province used by the Mai-Mai and their allies along the border with Rwanda. Few details of the operations were made available. Security in eastern Congo has been steadily deteriorating with reports of Mai-Mai fighters joining other disgruntled groups in staging sporadic attacks against road convoys and populated areas. BC-Afghanistan-Quake, 2nd Ld-Writethru,0589
Aid supplies begin to reach quake-stricken area in Afghanistan
Eds: EDITS throughout to trim. AP Photos LON108-109 By PHIL GOODWIN Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ Aircraft loaded with emergency aid left Pakistan on Monday for remote northern Afghanistan, where soldiers dug through the rubble of villages leveled by a powerful earthquake in search of buried victims. The quake, which hit Saturday with a preliminary magnitude of 6.9, flattened entire villages, sliced mountains and triggered landslides. Thousands are feared dead. ``We saw a couple of villages that had been completely flattened, but there were probably more,'' said Alfredo Witschi-Cestari, head of the U.N. humanitarian aid office in neighboring Pakistan. ``This is a mountainous region and the force of the earthquake sent houses crashing down the hillsides toward the valleys below,'' he said after visiting the site Sunday. While initial estimates are putting the death toll at 3,000, aid workers and local officials in the area expect it may rise to 5,000. Among those killed were 140 schoolchildren in Rostaq, the site of a Feb. 4 earthquake that killed as many as 2,300 people and left another 8,000 homeless. Many of the people affected were living in tents because they lost their homes in the February quake. Cargo aircraft in neighboring Pakistan, packed with emergency supplies, were expected to reach the region later in the day, aid workers said. Tons of food, blankets, tents and plastic sheeting also were to be loaded onto cargo helicopters Monday in the Pakistani capital of Islamabad to be sent to Faisabad. From there, the supplies will be forwarded to the areas that suffered the greatest damage. The French Foreign Ministry also plans to send about 35 tons of humanitarian aid to Dushanbe, Tajikistan, where it will be transported to the disaster area. The international Red Cross got one plane into Faisabad on Sunday and was preparing to set up a clinic in the area. ``We need help desperately. Thousands of people are dead,'' a spokesman for a northern alliance fighting Afghanistan's Taliban government said from the stricken area, near the border with Tajikistan. Opposition soldiers already had recovered 1,650 bodies, Shamshul Haq Arianfar said. Speaking from Chaib, the alliance spokesman said eight villages simply disintegrated. U.N. officials flew over some of the most desolate and hardest-hit regions Sunday, setting down briefly near the quake's epicenter in Shari Basurkh, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) from the Badakhshan provincial capital of Faisabad. They delivered tents, plastic sheeting, and materials for an emergency clinic to be set up in Shari Basurkh for the many wounded. The officials said 4,100 houses were destroyed. The area's sun-baked mud homes, already weakened by the February temblor, crumbled like dry dust in Saturday's violent shaking. The homes were more vulnerable by the relentless rain that battered the region in recent days. Aid organization officials in neighboring Tajikistan were told by the Afghan ambassador that 5,000 people were killed. The Red Cross said it was not able to confirm the figure. According to the report, the dead included 3,000 killed in Shari Basurkh, almost 1,900 in a settlement on the outskirts of Faisabad, the 140 schoolchildren in Rostaq and 124 people in Chaib, on Afghanistan's border with Tajikistan.

Globalization worsens child sexual abuse; clean governments needed
Eds: Notes Anand spoke in keynote address in 4th graf; ADDS quotes from other speakers in grafs 10-16; name Ofelia is cq in 10th graf By GRANT PECK Associated Press Writer
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Globalization is turning the world into a more dangerous place for children to be exploited for sex, making clean government and uncorrupt officials ever more necessary to protect them, a former Thai prime minister said Monday. ``It has become easier for the traffic in children by means of abduction, tricks and enticements both within countries and across borders,'' said Anand Panyarachun, opening a Asia-Pacific conference on human resources development for youths. The week-long conference, hosted by the United Nations' Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, was told an estimated 10 million children worldwide were working as prostitutes, with some 1 million being added every year. Meanwhile, the Internet has put a tool into the hands of pornographers to spread thousands of sexual pictures of children around the world at ``the push of a button,'' Anand said in a keynote address. ``Children are dealt with as commodities, traded and exchanged as part of an increasingly borderless world,'' said Anand, who led reformist governments in 1991 and 1992 in a country notorious for child prostitution. Currently the United Nations Children's Fund ambassador to Thailand, Anand said that trafficking was abetted by governments that allow corruption enabling law enforcement officials to turn a blind eye to _ or help for profit _ gangs exploiting children. Government transparency and enforcement of what Anand called ``child-friendly laws'' would go a long way toward cleaning up an environment that allows the ``dark forces'' of corrupt police and criminals exploiting children to thrive. Anand suggested a series of measures to promote child rights and good governance, including improved screening and training of law enforcement personnel, more support and incentives for good law enforcement and greater penalties for corruption. Poverty breeds abuse and exploitation, Anand said, while lack of access to education renders children more vulnerable to the sex market. Family disintegration, migration and negative traditional practices are also factors. ``We cannot be forever insensitive to the cries for help of these children,'' Ofelia Calceta-Santos of the Philippines, a special U.N. investigator into the sale of children said at a panel discussion. To tackle the problem, she said, ``We need a wedding to have good children, a wedding between governments and non-governmental organizations.'' The head of a private multinational organization against child sex abuse said there were perhaps as many as 1 million children under the age of 16 held in virtual slavery in brothels in Asia. ``Many of the children in brothels die quite young, of AIDS, drugs, suicide,'' said Ron O'Grady, chairman of ECPAT _ End Child Prostitution, Child Pornography and Trafficking. O'Grady also warned that child pornography on the Internet is widespread, easy to find, and cruel and insidious in its effects. He said that foreign sex tourists often take videos of photos of themselves abusing children, and can post them around the world on the Internet within 24 hours. ``The internet goes beyond national boundaries, breaking down national laws,'' he said. ``In the 21st century national laws and boundaries will become increasingly irrelevant.''

Associated Press Writer
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Arab leaders are holding intensive talks on a proposed summit meeting aimed at reviving the Middle East peace process, but the leaders are reported to differ widely over what direction the summit should take. Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah held talks on a summit with Syrian President Hafez Assad on Sunday and will meet Monday with Jordan's King Hussein. Arab foreign ministers were expected to discuss the issue Tuesday in Beirut at a meeting on Arab ties to Europe. The summit would be a follow-up to a convening of Arab leaders in 1996, shortly after Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's election, that warned of a harsh reaction if Netanyahu failed to fulfill pledges in peace pacts. Holding a summit now is being pushed by Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat who has urged the Arabs to take a tougher stance toward Netanyahu since peace talks have reached a complete stalemate. Talaat Hamid, spokesman for the 22-member Arab League, said Monday that the proposed meeting would try to forge a unified Arab position ``against the obstacles Israel erects in the face of peace.'' He told The Associated Press that consultations are under way over the time and place for the summit, but he gave no details. Osama el-Baz, a senior adviser to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, was quoted Monday in Cairo newspapers as saying the leaders also were trying to agree on who should attend and the meeting's agenda. Last week, Arafat said the conference should work out a unified Arab strategy to ``confront Israeli arrogance.'' He made visits to Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states to convince their leaders to attend such a gathering. The move reflects his frustration with U.S. mediation, which has failed to convince Netanyahu to accept a compromise of a further 13 percent pullback in the West Bank to restart talks. Arafat, who wanted 30 percent, has accepted. Arab diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Jordan's King Hussein is reluctant to attend a conference in Syria where he expects Assad to push for a hardline stance against Israel. Syria has been calling to activate a resolution by the 1996 Arab summit to suspend ties with the Jewish state if progress was not made toward peace. Jordan's foreign minister, Jawad Anani, told The Associated Press that Jordan supports holding a summit ``as long as it produces the right results.'' He did not elaborate. But Jordan, the strongest advocate of peace with Israel, would likely oppose any more to express outright hostility. Another hurdle to the summit is who to invite. Most Gulf states still oppose asking Iraqi President Saddam Hussein because of his 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Syria says Iraq's presence is needed for a united stance against Israel. Several Arab countries also are unwilling to attend a summit on the Palestinian issue while the United States still is mediating. Once Washington announces its efforts have failed, Arafat would likely meet less resistance. On Monday, the London-based Saudi daily Asharq al-Awsat derided suggestions for holding a summit now, saying it would only show how divided the Arabs remain. ``Arabs love meeting,'' it said. ``The outcome of the meeting doesn't matter; the important thing is to meet. This is proof of the size of the gap that separates Arab countries, so much that a mere rendezvous has become a hope and a dream.'' sn-ggl

BC-Kenya-Politics
Moi leads Kenya in celebrating independence
AP Photos NAI101-102 By GEORGE MWANGI Associated Press Writer
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) _ President Daniel arap Moi, celebrating steps toward independence 35 years ago, Monday called on Kenyans to work together to find solutions to problems including corruption, poverty and unemployment. ``Among the many challenges we face, the most critical are poverty and unemployment,'' Moi said. ``The war on poverty has yet to be won.'' Moi addressed a crowd of thousands which gathered for Madaraka Day, the 35th anniversary of when Kenya gained the right to self-government from British colonialists. Kenya became fully independent on Dec. 12, 1963. For the national holiday, the capital was decorated in the black, red and green of the Kenyan flag. At an open-air ceremony in Uhuru (Freedom) Park, troops marched past Moi, politicians and diplomats, church choirs sang, and traditional dancers performed. Last Madaraka Day, Moi dismissed opposition demands for constitutional reforms ahead of elections, while police confined opposition leaders to their homes to prevent them from disrupting Moi's speech. Donor countries subsequently forced Moi to make some compromises before the election in December, which he won for a fifth, five-year term. On Monday, Moi, 74, expressed thanks to those parties which are cooperating with the ruling Kenya African National Union, whose leadership he vowed to retain even after he retires from the presidency. ``I do hope that other political parties will see the need to join hands ... peace and unity for the development and prosperity for this nation.'' Opposition leader Mwai Kibaki, who was in the audience, condemned Moi's remark, asking ``How can we cooperate with a government which send people with bows and arrows to disrupt our meeting?'' Last weekend, one man was killed and 20 injured when thugs disrupted an opposition meeting in rural Kitale. To fight the country's economic problems, Moi said he would try to bring down ``excessively high interest rates,'' now at 27.97 percent. Also, he promised to strengthen Kenya's tax collection system and crack down on ``unpatriotic Kenyans who deny the government revenue.'' Moi condemned corruption, saying it has undermined the efficiency and effectiveness of public sector operations. Many donor countries have blamed Moi for allowing corruption to thrive in Kenya. Shifting to Swahili, Moi, sounding a familiar theme, condemned foreigners who ``come here to tell us how to live. We know ourselves that if we don't unify the future will be difficult.'' (kjd)

Travelers Group takes 25 percent stake in top Japanese brokerage
Eds: RECASTS; UPDATES throughout with details of tie-up; ADDS comment from Travelers chairman in 4th graf.
TOKYO (AP) _ Travelers Group Inc. said Monday it will take a one-quarter stake in Nikko Securities Co., Japan's third-largest brokerage house, in one of the most aggressive moves to date in the Japanese market by an American financial powerhouse. The New York-based company will become Nikko's biggest shareholder, taking over from top Japanese lender Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. Nikko will buy a smaller stake in Travelers Group to solidify the broad-based tie-up. Travelers' announcement comes less than a month after it unveiled an dlrs 82 billion merger with Citicorp to create the world's largest financial services company. ``Our creating a partnership with Nikko will allow us to be more productive not only in this marketplace but all around the world,'' said Sanford Weill, chairman and chief executive officer of Travelers Group, speaking at a press conference in Tokyo. The deal marks the latest move by a major Wall Street firm to strengthen its position in Japan in the midst of a major effort to liberalize the Japanese financial industry by 2001. The reforms, dubbed the ``Big Bang,'' are expected to open up a pool of personal financial assets worth an estimated dlrs 9 trillion. A number of other big names on Wall Street have also expanded in Japan. In February, Merrill Lynch and Co. hired 2,100 former employees of the failed Yamaichi Securities Co. to staff 33 retail outlets nationwide. Fidelity Investments Co. has announced similar plans. As part of their strategic alliance, Travelers and Nikko plan to link their world-wide securities sales and trading businesses. They will also set up a jointly-owned Tokyo-based securities company with working capital of more than 140 billion yen (dlrs 1 billion). The Japanese venture, to be called Nikko Salomon Smith Barney Ltd., will incorporate the investment banking, consumer product and research operations of Nikko Securities, one of Japan's ``Big Three'' brokers. It will be headed by Yuji Shirakawa, currently president of Nikko Research Center. Toshiharu Kojima, chief executive of Salomon Smith Barney in Japan, will become co-chief executive of the venture, along with a Nikko Securities official. Separately, the Tokyo Stock Exchange launched an investigation Monday over possible insider trading involving Nikko shares after the price of its stock jumped Friday, an exchange official said. Nikko shares closed at 436 yen (dlrs 3.16) Friday, up 20 yen (dlrs 14 cents) from Thursday's close, after rising by as much as 10 percent. A total of 8.59 million Nikko shares were traded on Friday, about 5.9 times the amount traded on Thursday. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, refused to provide other details. BC-Israel-Palestinians,0425
Cabinet meeting ends without decision on West Bank withdrawal
By DINA KRAFT Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Despite growing U.S. pressure on Israel to make a decision, Israel's Cabinet on Monday again failed to reach agreement on the the scope of a West Bank troop withdrawal. Israel's continued indecision is likely to further strain ties with the United States, which reportedly has demanded an Israeli answer within several days to its proposal for a pullback from 13 percent. However, U.S. ultimatums have come and gone in the past month without repercussions for Israel. It appeared Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was more concerned about the survival of his government than about possible U.S. censure. A U.S. official said Monday that he did not expect the Clinton administration to make good on veiled threats to announce the failure of the U.S. peace initiative and blame Israel. Instead, Washington will give Israel more time to reach a decision, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Far-right Cabinet ministers have threatened to topple the government if Netanyahu agreed to a 13 percent pullback. ``A 13 percent withdrawal would be a disaster for Jewish settlements,'' Transport Minister Shaul Yahalom from the National Religious Party told Israel radio Monday. ``We cannot agree. We were assured by the prime minister that there would be no troop redeployment that will hurt the settlements.'' Recent polls have suggested that a large majority in Israel want Netanyahu to forge ahead with the peace negotiations and agree to a troop withdrawal. The Jewish Settlers' Council on Monday launched a campaign to turn Israeli public opinion against a 13 percent troop pullback. It mailed brochures to 1 million homes in Israel, with maps illustrating the settlers' arguments that a pullback would endanger water resources, Israeli security and control over Jewish holy sites. U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has been trying for months to break the deadlock between Israel and the Palestinians. The Palestinians have accepted the U.S. proposal for an immediate 13 percent pullback, to be followed by another significant withdrawal whose scope has not been determined. Israel radio and the Maariv daily reported Monday that Netanyahu was considering a 15 percent pullback in three stages. Netanyahu's adviser, David Bar-Illan, was not immediately available for comment, but the radio said Netanyahu denied the report.

BC-Russia-Impeachment
Russian hard-liners to push impeachment motion
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russian hard-liners will try to get an impeachment motion against President Boris Yeltsin put on parliament's agenda during a scheduling session next week, a prominent hard-liner said Monday. Nikolai Kharitonov, leader of the hard-line Agrarian faction, said Yeltsin opponents will ask members of the agenda-setting Duma Council on June 9 to formally file the motion and set up a committee to study the proposal. His comments were reported by the Interfax news agency. Impeachment proceedings are long and complex, and it would likely take months before the motion is actually debated by parliament's lower house, the State Duma. Communists and their allies, including the Agrarians, launched the latest impeachment campaign last month, gathering 205 signatures in the 450-seat Duma. They have accused Yeltsin of a range of transgressions, including instigating the Soviet collapse, launching the botched war in Chechnya and ruining the country's economy. Their frustrations intensified in April during a long test of wills with Yeltsin, who threatened to disband the legislature unless lawmakers approved his candidate for prime minister. Several previous impeachment drives have fizzled, in part because Russia's Constitution gives the president the upper hand in confrontations with parliament. (mr)

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open, 1st Ld-Writethru,
in Kournikova-Novotna match American women thrive in Paris
Eds: UPDATES with Majoli defeating Martinez, explains controversy By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ The American men may have bombed out at this year's French Open, but the women are doing just fine, thank you. With Venus Williams, Lindsay Davenport and Monica Seles all advancing Sunday, more U.S. women have reached the quarterfinals than in any French Open since 1986. They were almost joined by the other Williams sister, Serena. But she folded in the second set of a contentious match against Aranxta Sanchez Vicario after coming within two points of victory. ``I'm only 16, my first Roland Garros,'' Serena said after the match. ``Everything is a learning experience for me.'' That may be the one thing Sanchez Vicario agreed with. ``I taught her a lesson,'' the fourth-seeded Spaniard said angrily after the match. It was a lesson that featured glares across the net, an unusual dress change by the Spaniard, and a slam by Williams that nearly beheaded her opponent. Williams accused Sanchez Vicario of changing from a black outfit to a white one midway through the second set as a strategic move. Sanchez Vicario, for her part, was upset at Williams' attitude after a controversial point in the first set. ``I just think she doesn't have respect. She cannot go in with that attitude,'' said Sanchez Vicario. ``You know, I'm glad I beat her.'' So Serena will have to watch her sister in the quarters, and it should be one of the most intriguing matches of the tournament. Venus Williams will play top-seeded Martina Hingis, another match in a rivalry quickly becoming one of the best in women's sports. The elder Williams advanced Sunday with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Henrieta Nagyova of Slovakia in which she slammed seven aces _ two at 116 mph. Hingis was a 6-1, 6-2 winner over Anna Smashnova of Israel in a match between former French Open junior champions. Venus Williams, the No. 8 seed, has lost just 13 games in her four matches at the French Open. Hingis has lost 14 games. Hingis holds a 5-2 record against Williams, but they are 2-2 this year. Sanchez Vicario will face Patty Schnyder in the quarterfinals. No. 2 Davenport and No. 6 Seles also advanced to the quarters. Davenport will face defending champion Iva Majoli, the 10th seed, who ousted No. 7 Conchita Martinez 7-6 (7-1), 6-7 (3-7), 6-3 in a match completed Monday. Majoli and Martinez were tied at a set apiece when darkness halted play Sunday night. Martinez jumped out to a quick 3-1 lead in the third set, then lost the last five games. Seles will face No. 3 Jana Novotna or No. 13 Anna Kournikova. Novotna led 7-6 (7-2) 3-6, 4-2 when play was halted Sunday night at Novotna's request. That left Kournikova in tears because she had made the same request a game earlier, but was denied. According to international tennis rules, a match can be halted due to darkness only on an even-number game in a set. Seles, a three-time champion who never has lost before the quarterfinals in Paris, won 6-1, 6-4 over Chanda Rubin. As the second week of the tournament gets started, the women's side appears to have a bit of everything. There's star quality in Kournikova, power and attitude in Venus Williams, the world's No. 1 player in Hingis, and a touching story in Seles, who is playing only two weeks after losing her coach and father. What's left on the men's side? Certainly not many of the world's top players. With 12 men left in the draw, only No. 3 seed Marcelo Rios remains of the top 10. The next seed left is No. 12 Carlos Moya. Then there's No. 14 Alex Corretja, No. 15 Felix Mantilla and No. 16 Alberto Berasategui. Also remaining are the world's 45th-ranked player, the 69th and the 116th. No U.S. man made it through the third round, the worst showing in a Grand Slam event in at least 30 years. Gone are the reigning champions of the other three Grand Slams: top-seeded Pete Sampras (Wimbledon), No. 2 Petr Korda (Australian Open) and No. 4 Pat Rafter (U.S. Open). Also gone are some of the more charismatic players, such as American Andre Agassi and last year's surprise champion, Gustavo Kuerten of Brazil. The remaining marquee player, Rios, has a huge following in Chile, and his fans bring gigantic Chilean flags to his matches. But in the rest of the world, he is well known for a cold and haughty attitude. There is one exciting story on the men's side being written by Marat Safin, the 18-year-old Russian qualifier ranked 116th in the world, who's beaten Agassi and Kuerten here. Safin powered his way through the first three rounds much like Williams, with brawn and with aces. He's attracted Kournikova-like attention with his athletic good looks. And his post-match news conferences resemble those of Hingis: smiles and jokes.

BC Arabs-Summit,0524
Arab leaders confer on planned summit, differ on meeting's goal BY SALAH NASRAWI
Associated Press Writer
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Arab leaders are holding intensive talks on a proposed summit aimed at reviving the Middle East peace process, but they reportedly disagree over what direction the summit should take and whom to invite. Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah held talks on a summit with Syrian President Hafez Assad on Sunday and will meet Monday with Jordan's King Hussein. Arab foreign ministers were expected to discuss the issue Tuesday in Beirut at a meeting on Arab ties to Europe. The summit would be a follow-up to a convening of Arab leaders in 1996, shortly after Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's election, that warned of a harsh reaction if Netanyahu failed to fulfill pledges in peace pacts. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, who has been pushing for the summit, has urged the Arabs to take a tougher stance toward Netanyahu since peace talks have deadlocked. Talaat Hamid, spokesman for the 22-member Arab League, said Monday that the proposed meeting would try to forge a unified Arab position ``against the obstacles Israel erects in the face of peace.'' He told The Associated Press that consultations are under way over the time and place for the summit, but he gave no details. Osama el-Baz, a senior adviser to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, was quoted Monday in Cairo newspapers as saying the leaders also were trying to agree on who should attend and the meeting's agenda. Last week, Arafat said the conference should work out a unified Arab strategy to ``confront Israeli arrogance.'' He made visits to Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states to convince their leaders to attend such a gathering. The move reflects his frustration with U.S. mediation, which has failed to convince Netanyahu to accept a compromise of a further 13 percent pullback in the West Bank to restart talks. Arafat, who wanted 30 percent, has accepted. Arab diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Jordan's King Hussein is reluctant to attend a conference in Syria, where he expects Assad to push for a hard-line stance against Israel. Syria has been calling to activate a resolution by the 1996 Arab summit to suspend ties with the Jewish state if progress was not made toward peace. Jordan's foreign minister, Jawad Anani, told The Associated Press that Jordan supports holding a summit ``as long as it produces the right results.'' He did not elaborate. But Jordan, the strongest advocate of peace with Israel, would likely oppose any more to express outright hostility. Another hurdle to the summit is who to invite. Most Gulf states still oppose asking Iraqi President Saddam Hussein because of his 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Syria says Iraq's presence is needed for a united stance against Israel. Several Arab countries also are unwilling to attend a summit on the Palestinian issue while the United States still is mediating. Once Washington announces its efforts have failed, Arafat would likely meet less resistance.

TOKYO (AP) _ Sony Corp. will acquire a 6.7 percent stake in Justsystem Corp., a major Japanese software maker suffering a slump in sales, a spokeswoman for the software maker said on Monday. Sony hopes to take advantage of Justsystem's software development skills to stengthen its position in the market for digital consumer appliances _ electronic gadgets that incorporate computer functions _ a Sony employee said. Under a basic agreement between the two companies, Sony will buy the entire block _ 2 million shares worth 1.27 billion yen (dlrs 9.16 million) _ of a new stock issuance by Justsystem scheduled for July, said Kyoko Kamata, spokeswoman of Justsystem. It was the first time that the company posted a loss since its foundation in 1981. Justsystem is popularly known for its ``Ichitaro'' Japanese-language word-processing program, but its sales suffered last year because of the slumping domestic economy and Microsoft Corp.'s penetration into the Japanese market. The Japan Securities Dealers' Association said it suspended trade of Justsystem shares Monday as officials needed time to verify a newspaper report on the planned tie-up with Sony. (km)

BC-Zambia-Kaunda, 2nd Ld
Kaunda freed as state withdraws coup allegations prosecution'' procedure that can have case reopened
Eds: UPDATES with Kaunda quotes, reaction, color, more on ``no By ANGUS SHAW Associated Press Writer
LUSAKA, Zambia (AP) _ Former President Kenneth Kaunda was freed by a court Monday after spending five months under house arrest for allegedly knowing about plans for coup last year by junior military officers. Kaunda, 74, waved to supporters on the steps of the Lusaka High Court after state prosecutors dropped the case against him, apparently on lack of evidence. ``I feel great,'' said Kaunda, wearing a thick white beard he has grown since his arrest on Christmas day. Supporters waved two-finger victory salutes and cheered. Jubilant supporter Christopher Malama described Kaunda's release as a triumph for their opposition party. ``Our father is out. We are very happy today,'' he said. Also freed by Judge Japhet Banda was Moyce Kaulungombe, Kaunda's bodyguard. Both men were charged with concealing prior knowledge of an Oct. 28, 1997, coup attempt by junior military officers that was quickly crushed by loyal troops. Attorney General Bonaventure Mutale told Banda the state entered a plea of ``nolle prosequi,'' the legal term for ``no prosecution,'' a procedure normally used when the state lacks sufficient evidence or does not wish to proceed with a case that can be reopened later. ``This means the state doesn't wish to proceed further. You are discharged so you are free men,'' Banda told Kaunda and Kaulungombe. But Kaunda was defiant, saying he was not satisfied with the case being dropped. ``I want a complete acquittal. I am very clean,'' he told reporters. Kaunda dismissed reports that President Nelson Mandela of South Africa asked President Frederick Chiluba for his release in return for Kaunda retiring from politics. ``I am going to listen to the people who have been discussing this, then I'll decide,'' Kaunda said. Kaunda drove through downtown Lusaka, waving his trademark white handkerchief, and was scheduled to meet with supporters and colleagues at the headquarters of his United National Independence Party, the main opposition group. The drama came on the first day of the trials of 81 suspects _ most of them soldiers _ who were arrested after junior officers stormed the state broadcast center and claimed to have overthrown Chiluba's government. Somali gunmen kill four bus passengers in Mogadishu
MOGADISHU, Somalia (AP) _ Gunmen killed four people and wounded five others in an attack Monday on a bus in south Mogadishu, witnesses said. An armed guard on the bus returned fire, they said. The bus driver and conductor were seriously wounded, and were taken to a nearby hospital. The attack may have been in retaliation for the robbery of another bus last week by subclansmen of the owner of the bus that was hit Monday, witnesses said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Somali has not had central government since the 1991 overthrow of dictator Mohamed Siad Barre. The country is divided up into clan-based fiefdoms and kidnappings are a common way of extorting money. BC-Russia-Japan
Russia and Japan plan joint naval exercise
AP Photo MOSB101
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia and Japan will hold a joint naval exercise for the first time in the Pacific Ocean in July, the chief of the Russian General Staff said Monday. Gen. Anatoly Kvashnin met with his Japanese counterpart, Admiral Kazuya Natsukawa, to discuss upgrading military contacts between Russia and Japan as part of an effort to conclude a peace treaty by 2000. Five decades after World War II, the two nations have yet to sign a treaty, mainly because of a territorial dispute over four tiny islands in the southern Kuril chain that Soviet troops seized from Japan in the closing days of the war. Kvashnin said no deadline has been set for demilitarizing the islands as part of military reforms that envisage cutting Russia's armed forces from 1.8 million servicemen to 1.2 million by 1999, the ITAR-Tass news agency reported. ``The deadlines depend on political agreements, but there are no specific documents on this issue,'' he said. The naval exercise will involve two Russian and three Japanese warships in a simulated sea rescue, Kvashnin said. He said he would visit Japan next October or November at Natsukawa's invitation as part of the program to improve military ties initiated by President Boris Yeltsin during an April summit in Tokyo with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto.
