BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open, 2nd Ld-Writethru,
quotes American women thrive in Paris
Eds: UPDATES with Novotna defeating Kournikova, ADDS Kournikova By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ The American men may have bombed out at this year's French Open, but the women are doing just fine, thank you. With Venus Williams, Lindsay Davenport and Monica Seles all advancing Sunday, more U.S. women have reached the quarterfinals than in any French Open since 1986. They were almost joined by the other Williams sister, Serena. But she folded in the second set of a contentious match against Aranxta Sanchez Vicario after coming within two points of victory. ``I'm only 16, my first Roland Garros,'' Serena said after the match. ``Everything is a learning experience for me.'' That may be the one thing Sanchez Vicario agreed with. ``I taught her a lesson,'' the fourth-seeded Spaniard said angrily after the match. It was a lesson that featured glares across the net, an unusual dress change by the Spaniard, and a slam by Williams that nearly beheaded her opponent. Williams accused Sanchez Vicario of changing from a black outfit to a white one midway through the second set as a strategic move. Sanchez Vicario, for her part, was upset at Williams' attitude after a controversial point in the first set. ``I just think she doesn't have respect. She cannot go in with that attitude,'' said Sanchez Vicario. ``You know, I'm glad I beat her.'' So Serena will have to watch her sister in the quarters, and it should be one of the most intriguing matches of the tournament. Venus Williams will play top-seeded Martina Hingis, another match in a rivalry quickly becoming one of the best in women's sports. The elder Williams advanced Sunday with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Henrieta Nagyova of Slovakia in which she slammed seven aces _ two at 116 mph. Hingis was a 6-1, 6-2 winner over Anna Smashnova of Israel in a match between former French Open junior champions. Venus Williams, the No. 8 seed, has lost just 13 games in her four matches at the French Open. Hingis has lost 14 games. Hingis holds a 5-2 record against Williams, but they are 2-2 this year. Sanchez Vicario will face Patty Schnyder in the quarterfinals. No. 2 Davenport and No. 6 Seles also advanced to the quarters. Davenport will face defending champion Iva Majoli, the 10th seed, who ousted No. 7 Conchita Martinez 7-6 (7-1), 6-7 (3-7), 6-3 in a match completed today. Majoli and Martinez were tied at a set apiece when darkness halted play Sunday night. Martinez jumped out to a quick 3-1 lead in the third set, then lost the last five games. Seles will face No. 3 Jana Novotna, who defeated No. 13 Anna Kournikova 7-6 (7-2), 3-6, 6-3 in another match halted Sunday night. The match was stopped with Novotna leading 4-2 in the final set. It took Novotna just 12 minutes to finish off the match Monday. Play was halted Sunday night at Novotna's request, which left Kournikova in tears because she had made the same request a game earlier, but was denied. According to international tennis rules, a match can be halted due to darkness only on an even-number game in a set. ``It was very difficult for me to play the match over two days,'' Kournikova said. ``It was a new experience for me.'' Seles, a three-time champion who never has lost before the quarterfinals in Paris, won 6-1, 6-4 over Chanda Rubin. As the second week of the tournament gets started, the women's side appears to have a bit of everything. There's power and attitude in Venus Williams, the world's No. 1 player in Hingis, and a touching story in Seles, who is playing only two weeks after losing her coach and father. What's left on the men's side? Certainly not many of the world's top players. With 12 men left in the draw, only No. 3 seed Marcelo Rios remains of the top 10. The next seed left is No. 12 Carlos Moya. Then there's No. 14 Alex Corretja, No. 15 Felix Mantilla and No. 16 Alberto Berasategui. Also remaining are the world's 45th-ranked player, the 69th and the 116th. No U.S. man made it through the third round, the worst showing in a Grand Slam event in at least 30 years. Gone are the reigning champions of the other three Grand Slams: top-seeded Pete Sampras (Wimbledon), No. 2 Petr Korda (Australian Open) and No. 4 Pat Rafter (U.S. Open). Also gone are some of the more charismatic players, such as American Andre Agassi and last year's surprise champion, Gustavo Kuerten of Brazil. The remaining marquee player, Rios, has a huge following in Chile, and his fans bring gigantic Chilean flags to his matches. But in the rest of the world, he is well known for a cold and haughty attitude. There is one exciting story on the men's side being written by Marat Safin, the 18-year-old Russian qualifier ranked 116th in the world, who's beaten Agassi and Kuerten here. Safin powered his way through the first three rounds much like Williams, with brawn and with aces. He's attracted Kournikova-like attention with his athletic good looks. And his post-match news conferences resemble those of Hingis: smiles and jokes.

Collapsed Yamaichi Securities debts even more than claimed
TOKYO (AP) _ Collapsed Yamaichi Securities Co. said Monday its liabilities exceeded assets by 22.51 billion yen (dlrs 162 million) as of March 31, suggesting the broker doesn't have enough money to repay all its debts. The report contradicted a claim by the Finance Ministry which said after Yamaichi collapsed last November that the broker had enough capital to meet all its liabilities. Yamaichi collapsed under the weight of more than 274 billion yen (dlrs 1.97 million) in the off-the-book losses _ Japan's biggest corporate failure ever. In Yamaichi's earnings report for the term ended March 31, Yamaichi suffered a net loss of 460.33 billion yen (dlrs 3.3 billion) as it wrote off 410.9 billion yen (dlrs 2.96 billion) as special losses following the collapse. Yamaichi's income including trade commission fell by 30 percent from a year earlier to 147.488 billion yen (dlrs 1.061 billion), but expenditures for business operations were 201.080 billion yen (dlrs 1.446 billion). Yamaichi's balance sheet as of March 31 showed that the overall liabilities totaled 600.227 billion yen (dlrs 4.318 billion), including 43 billion yen (dlrs 309 million) in subordinated loans, against overall assets of 577.721 billion yen (dlrs 4.156 billion). A Yamaichi official said Yamaichi is negotiating with the life and casualty insurers which made the subordinated loans because Yamaichi is unable to repay nearly half of what it owes them. Yamaichi, one of Japan's ``Big Four'' brokerages, failed after trying for years to juggle trading losses stemming from the collapse of real estate and stock markets earlier in the decade. It closed the last of its branches on March 31, lowering the curtain on 101 years of businesses. (sk)

BC-Sports-Swimming-Mexico-Cuba,0219
Australian swims from Mexico to Cuba
HAVANA, Cuba (AP) _ Australian Susie Maroney was believed to have become the first person to swim from Mexico to Cuba when her latest long-distance epic ended early Tuesday. Maroney, 23, touched Cuban soil at 5:03 a.m. (0903 GMT) after swimming approximately 197 kilometers (122 miles) from Isle Mujere, Mexico in 38 hours and 33 minutes. Her support team reported she was in fair condition but being treated for dehydration. Maroney walked onto land in a remote part of Cuba after being pointed towards a lighthouse by the coast guard. The distance was less than the 233 kilometers (145 miles) Maroney had been aiming for, which would have given her an absolute world record for the farthest any one has ever swum in the ocean. According to the Maroney team, the 197 kilometers (122 miles) is the farthest any person has swum in the ocean without the aid of flippers and she will claim it as a new ``honest distance'' world record. After being treated by the team physician, Maroney was expected to be taken by boat to Havana, where Cubans who have followed her latest swim were to welcome her. Last year Maroney became the first person to swim from Cuba to Florida.

BC-Egypt-Libya
Gadhafi to visit Egypt for talks on trade, investment
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi is making a nine-day visit to Egypt starting Tuesday that will focus on trade relations with Egypt and likely will touch on Libya's feud with the West over the 1988 bombing of an American airliner. Gadhafi's visit to Egypt, the second in two years, can be expected to upset the United States which has sought to isolate Libya because of the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed 270 people. Banned from international flights under U.N. sanctions, Gadhafi is expected to travel by land over the Libyan-Egyptian border to the town of Saloum and then go on to Cairo. He will be arriving with an entourage including nine ministers and a team of businessmen. The team will discuss potential Libyan investments in Egypt, especially in the vast Toshka irrigation project in southern Egypt. The two countries are to sign seven trade, investment and manufacturing agreements, according to Egyptian news reports. The Libyans want to boost trade with Egypt, which now officially totals 492 million Egyptian pounds (dlrs 144 million) annually. Despite U.S. complaints, Egypt has sought to maintain good relations with its oil-rich neighbor. Gadhafi is likely to raise the Lockerbie issue in talks scheduled with President Hosni Mubarak on Tuesday. Lockerbie will also be on his agenda with Arab League Secretary General Esmet Abdel-Meguid, who is to meet with British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook on June 14. Both the United States and England have sought to isolate Libya because of Gadhafi's failure to turn over for trial two Libyans charged with the Lockerbie bombing. Gadhafi says they cannot get a fair trial in either country and wants them tried in a neutral state. In an effort to force Libya to turn over the suspects, the U.N. Security Council imposed sanctions in March 1992 that ban international air travel, refuse arms sales to Libya and call for limiting diplomatic contacts with the country. mae-ggl

BC-Northern Ireland
Sinn Fein stands up Prince Charles _ saving some British blushes
BELFAST, Northern Ireland (AP) _ In a double-edged snub, leaders of the IRA-allied Sinn Fein party have turned down an invitation to a royal garden party because Prince Charles will be there. The announcement Sunday saved the host, Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary Mo Mowlam, from some awkward maneuvering. Now, she won't have to worry about keeping the Sinn Fein leaders away from Charles _ whose much-loved great-uncle Lord Mountbatten was assassinated by the Irish Republican Army in 1979 _ when guests mingle Wednesday in the grounds of her Hillsborough Castle residence. Sinn Fein said that leaders Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness will boycott the party because Charles holds the ceremonial position of colonel-in-chief of the Parachute Regiment whose members were involved in Bloody Sunday in 1972. Thirteen Catholic marchers were shot dead in the British army's worst shooting in this province. Adams, Sinn Fein's president, and McGuinness, the party's chief negotiator in the peace talks, won't show up ``due to unresolved circumstances surrounding the murders,'' party chairman Mitchel McLaughlin said. After a long campaign by relatives of the victims, British Prime Minister Tony Blair this year authorized a new investigation into Bloody Sunday, which is being carried out by an international panel of judges. Leaders of pro-British Protestant parties accused Mowlam of blundering and insensitivity by inviting Sinn Fein to the party, being held to mark the 50th anniversary of the state-funded National Health Service in Northern Ireland. Before Sinn Fein said it wouldn't be going, Mowlam promised to make sure Charles didn't meet Adams and McGuinness, who hold two of the 18 Northern Ireland seats in the 659-member British House of Commons. ``That won't happen. I can guarantee that,'' Mowlam said of the possibility. ``It will be I who will escort the royal round, and I will make very sure who he meets,'' she added in a BBC television interview. David Trimble, leader of the largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, said Mowlam ``must be mightily relieved that her grave error of judgment has not led to worse consequences.'' Charles' office made no comment. But Blair's press spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said Charles' staff knew Adams and McGuinness were being invited. (mj-kg)

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Gascoigne Out, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Hoddle says he dropped Gascoigne solely for lack of fitness
Eds: LEADS with Hoddle press conference, quotes PVS: London
LA MANGA, Spain (AP) _ England coach Glenn Hoddle said Monday he dropped controversial midfielder Paul Gascoigne from the final 22-man World Cup team solely because he wasn't fit. On Sunday, Hoddle stunned England with his decision not to include the 31-year-old Gascoigne, rated by some as the best midfielder in English history. The story was one of the biggest soccer items to hit England since the team won its sole World Cup in 1966. As well as Gascoigne, Hoddle also dropped five other players _ Tottenham goalkeeper Ian Walker, Manchester United's Phil Neville and Nicky Butt, Coventry's Dion Dublin and Everton's Andy Hinchcliffe _ to get down to the final 22-man team. But all attention Monday focused on Gascoigne, a highly skilled, creative player who has filled the tabloid press in recent years with reports of his fast-paced, hard-drinking life off the pitch. ``He (Gascoigne) was not selected on his fitness levels and his form over the last two or three months,'' said Hoddle, speaking at a news conference in this southeastern Spanish resort where England has been training. ``We have run out of time getting him to the (fitness) levels I needed,'' Hoddle added. ``I am as disappointed as Paul that he is not with us but I have had to make a very tough decision. It was a difficult one for me to call.'' ``It's a great pity that Paul has not got himself fit. It's a pity he has so many injuries over the last months and the injuries kept coming.'' Hoddle, looking composed in the face of a decision that could backfire, recounted that Gascoigne cried after he told him the news. ``We had a chat for two or three minutes that lasted no longer than that,'' Hoddle said. ``At the end of the day I think there were some tears in his eyes.'' ``He went into his room. I think some of his friends went into his room to console him. Paul acted as I would have expected him to react.'' Gascoigne, a key figure when England reached the World Cup semifinals in 1990 in Italy, returned to England after the shock announcement and was reported staying with his estranged wife. ``I can't believe this has happened. This is the worst thing that has ever happened to me,'' The Sun newspaper quoted Gascoigne as saying. The unexpected gamble by Hoddle, the No. 1 news item Monday across England, was surprisingly supported by more than 75 percent of callers to a popular London morning radio show. The story dwarfed news that Geri Halliwell was leaving the English all-girls pop group the Spice Girls. Gascoigne, who has played for Newcastle, Tottenham, Lazio, Glasgow Rangers and Middlesbrough, seems to have lost the ability to win games with his magical passing and dribbling. He has also suffered numerous injuries and attracted the wrong kind of publicity off the field. Ankle and groin injuries sidelined him for much of last season and, although he played 90 minutes of England's 0-0 tie with Saudi Arabia and the 1-0 victory over Morocco on Wednesday, he managed only half of the game against Belgium and limped off with a leg injury. In those three matches he looked ineffective, a shadow of the creative player that made him a one-of-a-kind on previous English sides. Although Hoddle said he dropped Gascoigne over his lack of fitness, he kept the faith with Les Ferdinand and Darren Anderton, two Tottenham players who have been short on fitness and form this season. The move leaves England without a player with World Cup experience. The club failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup in the United States and reached the semifinals in 1990 in Italy. Trevor Steven, Gascoigne's former England teammate, criticized Hoddle's decision. ``There's still two and a half weeks before kick off. Paul has something that nobody else can offer the team and I would have just given him that time. ``As an England fan I would have loved to have seen him do well. But the decision has been made and I think our squad is poorer for the lack of Paul Gascoigne.'' New editor of Al-Hayat promises no change in paper's policies
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ The new editor-in-chief of the leading Arabic daily Al-Hayat on Monday promised to continue its policy of independent and fair journalism. George Semaan, who assumed his post Sunday, wrote in today's issue that the Saudi-owned paper will stay true to its policy of ``objectivity in news coverage and analysis.'' His statement came amid speculation that the paper's publisher, Prince Khalid bin Sultan, was reorganizing the paper to promote a more pro-Saudi stance. Semaan said ``we will stick to our fixed principles of independence and fairness'' in reporting. Semaan, a journalist with Al-Hayat before the promotion, was named as editor in March by the paper's publisher, Prince Khalid bin Sultan. He takes over from Jihad al-Khazin, who edited the prestigious daily for a decade. Although the paper is owned by Saudis, most of its journalists hail from other Arab countries _ mainly Lebanon. Two Lebanese journalists were appointed as deputies to Semaan. Former editor Al-Khazin will work as information adviser to Al-Hayat's publishing company and will continue to write his daily column in the paper. Al-Hayat, first issued in Beirut in 1946, was forced to close after its owner, Kamil Mroue, was assassinated in 1966. The paper began publishing again from London in 1988. sn-tt-ggl

BC-Italy-Nicholas Green
Italian appeals trial begins for slaying of American boy
CATANZARO, Italy (AP) _ Prosecutors are trying a second time to convict two Italian men of the 1994 highway slaying of a 7-year-old American boy whose parents then donated his organs, inspiring a country where donation rates are low. The appeals trial began in this southern city Monday for the men acquitted in January 1997 of slaying Nicholas Green during a robbery attempt as he and his California family drove down a Calabrian highway while on vacation. The lower court jury had ruled there was no evidence to convict Francesco Mesiano, 23, and Michele Iannello, 28, of murder, attempted murder and armed robbery, but Italian law allows the acquitted to be retried by an appeals court for the same crime. Prosecutor Salvatore Murone told the court that since the first trial a pistol was found in the house of Iannello's mother, and that the discovery questioned the credibility of the defendant, who had earlier testified he had no other weapons, the Italian news agency AGI reported. As Nicholas' father, Reginald Green, drove faster to try to break away from the highway bandits, the boy, sleeping in the back seat, was shot in the head and was declared brain-dead. His parents donated his organs in an act that saved seven other lives and inspired a temporary surge of organ donations in a country where many relatives of accident victims, especially of children, refuse to allow removal of organs. Italy has one of the lowest donor rates in Europe. Reginald Green testified in the first trial that he could not identify the masked assailants. Mesiano and Iannello had denied involvement in the death, even though Iannello admitted to four gangland murders. The prosecution said statements recorded by telephone taps implicated the pair, but the defense disputed the meaning of the conversations in dialect. The appeals trial is expected to take about a week. (fd)

BC-Russia-Human Rights
Amnesty International says Russian human rights violations persist
MOSCOW (AP) _ Serious human rights violations persist in Russia despite President Boris Yeltsin's declaration of 1998 as Russia's Year of Human Rights, Amnesty International said Monday. Derek G. Evans, deputy secretary general of the human rights group, said in a statement that torture of prisoners continues, the death penalty has not been abolished and there is still no alternative military service for conscientious objectors. ``Amnesty International remains seriously concerned at the deep gap emerging between the president's declared intentions and the practical measures being put in place,'' Evans said after meeting with Russian media. Although Russia promised to abolish capital punishment when it joined the Council of Europe in 1996, Justice Minister Pavel Krashennikov said last week it would be premature to do away with the death penalty. Evans said the Russian government was keeping the death penalty because it did not want the expense of providing for life imprisonment for about 1,000 people. ``In other words, it is cheaper to kill,'' he said. Another concern for Amnesty International is conscientious objection to military service. ``While the Russian Federation's Constitution guarantees this right, no legislation has been enacted to create an alternative civilian service of non-punitive length,'' Evans said. He also said that civilian prisoners in pre-trial detention were kept in conditions ``so severe as to constitute torture.'' Evans said Amnesty International has provided the government with a preliminary analysis of the human rights situation in Russia and some 51 proposals for meeting international standards. (jai/mr)

MADRID, Spain (AP) _ Spain on Monday extradited fugitive Mexican banker Angel Rodriguez Saez, who fled his home country in 1994 after allegedly swindling banks out of dlrs 4 million. Spanish police handed Rodriguez Saez over to their Mexican counterparts at Madrid's Barajas airport where he boarded a midday flight to Mexico City, said National Police spokesman Antonio Nevada. Rodriguez Saez, a flashy businessman known as ``El Divino'' _ The Divine One _ built a banking empire during the privatization of the industry in Mexico in the early 1990s. His Banpais entity, however, was taken over by regulatory authorities in 1995 after they discovered capital shortfalls and ``irregularities'' in the bank's bookkeeping. His extradition will make him the first major player in Mexico's 1994 banking and political scandals to be returned to his home country. Mexican officials have failed to win extradition of former Assistant Attorney General Mario Ruiz Massieu from the United States, while financier Carlos Cabal Peniche _ the most important figure in the 1994 banking scandals _ is still at large. Rodriguez Saez was arrested July 29, 1996, after he attempted to flee Spanish police by diving off his yacht while sailing near the Spanish Mediterranean island of Ibiza. Despite successive appeals, Spanish judicial authorities agreed to his extradition on February 22, 1998. On April 20, Rodriguez Saez dropped his objections to the ruling. The conservative Spanish government of Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar finally approved the extradition on May 22. (cg)

SOFIA, Bulgaria (AP) _ Police arrested a dozen people and impounded as many luxury vehicles in a crackdown on a ring suspected of smuggling cars stolen in Canada, officials announced Monday. ``All the cars, brand new and at an average price of dlrs 60,000, have been stolen from car dealers or parking lots in Quebec province,'' said Kiril Radev, head of a special police unit dealing with organized crime. Bulgarian police began the arrests last week, and still are seeking the man believed to have masterminded the ring, 41-year-old Hristo Ivanov Iliev. He is a Bulgarian who emigrated to Canada and now has Canadian citizenship, Radev said. Iliev is thought to be hiding somewhere in Bulgaria. BC-Singapore-Death Penalty
Singapore gives death penalty for `ice' trafficking
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Parliament imposed the death penalty on Monday for trafficking in methamphetamine, and introduced corporal punishment and long jail terms for repeat drug offenders. When the amendments to the Misuse of Drugs Act are published in a week or so, anyone convicted of dealing in more than 250 grams (8.75 ounces) of methamphetamine, a designer drug known as ``ice,'' will go to the gallows. Traffickers in 167-250 grams (5.85-8.75 ounces) of ``ice'' face life in prison and 15 strokes of the cane, while lesser amounts are punishable by up to 20 years in prison. Singapore law automatically considers anyone possessing large amounts of drugs as a trafficker. Under existing law, adults caught with more than 15 grams (0.5 ounce) of heroin, 30 grams (1 ounce) of morphine, half a kilo (1.1 pounds) of cannabis, or 1.2 kilograms (2.6 pounds) of opium face the death penalty. Also under the new law, users and dealers convicted a third time will be imprisoned five to seven years and face three to six strokes of the cane. Those found guilty of a further offense will be jailed seven to 13 years and receive six to 12 strokes. The tougher punishment ``is for these people who just simply refuse to change,'' Home Affairs Minister Wong Kan Seng argued in Parliament. ``We have decided that the only way to treat these addicts is to imprison them for a long time.'' The previous law dictated sentences of less than two years in drug rehabilitation centers for repeat offenders. The small Southeast Asian island republic has some of the world's strictest drug laws. More than 180 people have been hanged for drug trafficking since 1975, when the mandatory death penalty was imposed. Singapore no longer makes public the number of people hanged.

New budget addresses economic woes pickup.
Eds: UPDATES with Sinha introducing budget. ADDS byline. No By ASHOK SHARMA Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India's finance minister, who promised firm action to deal with anti-nuclear sanctions that have battered an already weak economy, introduced a budget Monday that included increased spending in the infrastructure and nuclear energy sectors. The Bharatiya Janata Party-led government's commitment to ``swadeshi,'' which the BJP has defined as ``economic nationalism'' had worried foreign investors. But Finance Minister Yashwant Sinha said ``swadeshi does not mean isolation, swadeshi means making India strong and self-reliant.'' Sinha said he believed the nuclear sanctions ``will not have any significant impact on our economic development,'' in part because he believed countries like the United States, Australia and Japan who cut loans and all but humanitarian aid in the wake of India's five nuclear tests last month would ``moderate'' their opposition in time. ``On our part, our policies have to be clearly directed and firm,'' he said. Sinha's government, presenting its first budget, has promised to revive India's economic growth, which faltered to 5 percent in the fiscal year 1997-98, the lowest rate in the last five years. Experts say that requires spending on infrastructure and encouraging investment. His revenue options have been reduced by the sanctions. Sinha announced a 35 percent increase in spending on what he called the key infrastructure areas of energy, transportation and communications, and a 16 percent increase in allocations to the Rural Infrastructure Development Fund, under which, among other measures, farmers can obtain loans for expanding their enterprises. The exact spending levels, and his plans for raising revenue, were to be outlined later Monday. Spending on developing nuclear energy _ an area that also has defense ramifications _ was increased 68 percent, and for the space department _ which has an important role in developing missiles that could carry nuclear weapons _ 62 percent. Minor concessions, likely to include tax breaks, were offered to get Indians living abroad to invest in their homeland He also promised a ``hassle-free procedure'' for foreign investors who have complained that bureaucratic red tape presents a huge obstacle to doing business in India. The government's pre-budget economic assessment, presented to Parliament last week, was bleak. In addition to the falling growth, it said the deficit rose to 6.1 percent of gross domestic product, the total value of goods and services produced by the economy, exceeding the target of 4.5 percent. A 6.35 percent inflation rate was reported Sunday, up from 5 percent during 1997-1998. The full impact of the nuclear sanctions was yet unclear, but they were already having a chilling effect. The rupee slid last week when Standard and Poor's financial rating agency revised its India rating outlook to negative from stable. A few days later, the World Bank postponed consideration of more than dlrs 800 million in development loans to India because of its nuclear tests, prompting a further slide in the rupee. The rupee opened at 41.74 to the U.S. dollar Monday; it was 39.73 at the beginning of May.

BC-Ethiopia-Eritrea
Ethiopian and Eritrean troops clash at border area
By ABEBE ANDUALEM Associated Press Writer
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (AP) _ Ethiopian and Eritrean troops have clashed in a disputed border area, and both sides suffered an undetermined number of casualties, a reliable source said Monday. The source, who could not be further identified, said the clash took place early Sunday near the village of Alitena in the foothills of the Asimba Mountains, about 600 kilometers (372 miles) north of Addis Ababa. A reporter for the Amharic language service of the Voice of America who was in the region said she heard artillery fire throughout the day Sunday. According to the source, the clash area is located 20 kilometers (12 miles) inside Ethiopian territory. Since its first public comment on the border dispute May 13, Ethiopia has repeatedly claimed that Eritreans have made incursions into Ethiopian territory. Eritrea denies the claims and has suggested international mediation. Ethiopia rejects direct negotiations until Eritrea withdraws and threatened to use force if it did not. U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs Susan Rice returned to Addis Ababa Sunday evening and will continue ``facilitating dialogue,'' a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman said Monday. Rice spent a week shuttling between Addis Ababa and the Eritrean capital, Asmara, after Ethiopia first accused Eritrea of border violations. A State Department team remained in the region, meeting with officials from both nations as well as from Djibouti, the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD) and the Organization of African Unity. The State Department issued a second travel advisory Friday warning American citizens to stay away from the border regions and has pulled U.S. government employees and Peace Corps volunteers away from border areas in Eritrea. In a speech Monday in Nairobi, Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, a former chairman of IGAD, expressed concern over the rising tension between the two countries and said he was already coordinating between current IGAD chairmain President Hassan Gouled Aptidon of Djibouti and other parties ``to settle this problem in a peaceful manner.'' Although no figures have been made public, military sources in Eritrea say at 200,000 Eritreans _ including regular army, veterans and youths doing cumpulsory military service _ have been mobilized since May 13. On Friday, staff at Asmara University were asked to contribute 10 percent of their monthly salaries to the mobilization effort. Eritrea has an estimated population of 3.67 million, compared to about 57 million in Ethiopia. Seven years ago, Eritrean and Ethiopian rebels forces united to overthrow Ethiopia's 17-year military regime in 1991. Two years later, Eritrea gained independence. Ethiopia claims that Eritrea is illegally occupying a 400-sq. km. (160-sq.-mile) area known as the Yigra triangle in northwestern Ethiopia as well as other areas in the northeast. Eritrea says that according to the Italian colonial boundaries that are still binding, the areas are Eritrean. In the past five years, Eritrea has had border disputes with Sudan and Djibouti as well as with Yemen over control of the Hanish Islands in the Red Sea. The International Tribunal in The Hague is expected to decide that dispute in July. (aa/js/sl)

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo
More deaths reported in Kosovo; hundreds flee
By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Heavy fighting in Serbia's explosive Kosovo province prompted reports Monday of more than a dozen new deaths and sent hundreds of people fleeing into Albania. Conflicting accounts of casualties in the blocked-off areas could not immediately be sorted out. But the bloodshed appears to be the worst since early March when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on militants and their families. A day after Serb authorities claimed to have killed several dozen militants in four villages in the Decani region of western Kosovo, ethnic Albanian officials said 33 Albanians had been killed over the weekend. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani while six were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died of their wounds in the fighting around Decani, 75 kilometers (45 miles) west of the regional capital Pristina, Serb sources said. The latest fierce fighting prompted about 1,000 Kosovo Albanians, mostly women, children and elderly, to leave the troubled region and cross over into Albania's Troboja region Sunday and Monday, Albanian authorities said. Interior Ministry spokesman Artan Bizhga said in the Albanian capital Tirana that the refugees, many of whom had walked for as many as 10 hours, were being accommodated in local homes and a school. Local authorities were providing free food and clothes. Authorities in Serbia, which along with Montenegro comprises all that remains of the Yugoslav federation, claim that thousands of Kosovo Albanians are staying in the province illegally. They are trying to block Kosovo's independence bid and are using the police and army to try to crush militants and maintain control over the province, where 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million is ethnic Albanian. More than 200 people have died in Kosovo clashes since the beginning of March. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, released the names of the six people it said were killed Sunday when Serb police stormed the village of Poklek, 25 kilometers (15 miles) west of Pristina. It said one had had his throat slit. According to the Albanians' account, Serb police burst into Poklek houses, pulled out villagers and told them to ``go to Albania and never return.'' Afterwards, Serb police allegedly set several homes ablaze after dousing them in gasoline. All phone lines remained disconnected Monday between Pristina and the hotspots of Decani, Klina and Djakovica, where fierce battles were reported Sunday. Yugoslavia's state-run daily Politika on Monday blamed ethnic Albanian ``terrorist groups'' for numerous deaths. It said that in their efforts to cross into Albania, they shelled several villages near Junik, ``a border town known for resisting militant enlistings, killing several of their countrymen, including children.'' Indonesian corruption probe to include Suharto businesses
Eds: RECASTS to ADD quotes, details throughout With BC-Indonesia By ALI KOTARUMALOS Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Authorities have launched an investigation into government corruption under ex-President Suharto, the attorney general said Monday. The broadly-based inquiry is expected to encompass business dealings by Suharto's family, which critics say used its connections to make billions of dollars from a wide range of industries during his three decades in power. However, the investigation's general focus is likely to disappoint many Indonesians who have been loudly calling for a fast probe to target the Suharto family's wealth specifically. ``The investigation is underway,'' Attorney General Sudjono Atmonegoro said at a news conference. ``This investigation is a process that will need time. It cannot be completed in just one or two days.'' Sudjono said the inquiry was the government response to calls for an investigation into the conduct of ``government officials.'' He did not specifically name Suharto. Critics say nepotism, corruption and cronyism that thrived under Suharto contributed in large part to Indonesia's worst economic crisis in decades. Suharto quit May 21 following riots over price increases and under pressure from student protesters who occupied Parliament. A leading opposition figure has called on Suharto to donate the bulk of his wealth back to the country. Amien Rais, a prominent Muslim leader, said that with the money Indonesia would not have to beg for assistance from international agencies to prop up the economy. Sudjono said the corruption inquiry would be carried out on the principle of ``presumption of innocence'' and would involve many government departments and outside agencies. As part of the probe, Sudjono said he had received guarantees from Suharto family members that they would not leave Indonesia. ``There have been guarantees from them that they will not leave our beloved country,'' he said. He said there were no plans to question Suharto, although the former president might be asked to check evidence from others, at a later stage. The head of the powerful military, Gen. Wiranto said recently he was opposed to a specific investigation into the Suharto family fortune, saying that it could only worsen national disunity. The military played a key role in Indonesia's recent political crisis. It quelled riots by putting thousands of soldiers and dozens of tanks on the street. Some claim it also was instrumental in persuading Suharto, himself a retired army general, to quit in favor of new President B.J. Habibie, a civilian and Suharto loyalist who has promised political and economic reforms.

Truth Body says Botha knew ANC activists were to be killed deal
Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with testimony, talks on a possible AP Photos GEO101-102 By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ A top official of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission on Monday indirectly blamed former President P.W. Botha for the killings of black activists during apartheid. Botha is on trial for ignoring a summons to appear before the Truth Commission, which is probing apartheid-era human rights abuses. But the trial _ the first ever of a former South African head of state _ has focused on Botha's role as chairman of the State Security Council, which coordinated a security crackdown on black liberation groups. The trial resumed Monday after being postponed for six weeks. Truth Commission executive secretary Paul van Zyl said minutes from State Security Council meetings contained words like ``eliminate'' and ``neutralize'' when referring to opponents of white rule. Botha headed the security council when he was head of state. ``It is quite clear from these documents, as we interpret it, the word eliminate means kill,'' van Zyl said. In showing why it wants to question Botha, the commission has presented the court in this southern coastal town with dozens of documents implicating Botha, who led South Africa from 1978-1989, in atrocities. Van Zyl said the Security Council had been briefed in 1979 about plans to launch overseas operations against members of the African National Congres, including sending bombs in the mail. Wearing a dark suit and foregoing a cane which he has normally used since undergoing a hip replacement last year, Botha sat impassively as he listened to the testimony. Botha, 82, had greeted a handful supporters as he entered the court, located near the village where he has retired. Talks have restarted on a possible deal to avoid continuation of the trial. The Truth Commission says it is still willing to try and drop the contempt charges against Botha if he appears at a special Truth Commission hearing. Botha has pleaded innocent to the charges. He says he has already given the commission 1,700 pages of written answers and says the panel only wants to humiliate him by forcing him to appear in person. He faces two years imprisonment and unspecified fines if convicted. (ph-aos)

Portugal sets up council to crack down on child labor

Describing child labor as ``a worrying fact,'' Employment Minister Eduardo Ferro Rodrigues said the council will include representatives from trade unions, employers, the government and civic institutions. Its chief task will be to monitor and recommend action. Stamping out child labor will require cultural and social changes, as well as cooperation between public entities, Ferro Rodrigues said. Most of the children work in the construction and textile industries in the north of the country, the confederation said. JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Indonesia's third largest airline, controlled by ex-President Suharto's youngest son, closed down Monday, crippled by the collapse of the rupiah, the government said. ``Because current conditions are so heavy, it is not possible for Sempati to continue its operations and activities,'' said Transportation Minister Giri Suseno Hardi Hardjono. Sempati's shareholders include Suharto's son Hutomo ``Tommy'' Mandala Putra as well as a military foundation. The government has already canceled many contracts with firms linked to the former first family, and on Monday announced it has launched an investigation of government corruption under his rule. Indonesia's attorney general said investigators have no plans to target the former leader, but will look into business dealings of his family. As part of the general investigation, Attorney General Sudjono Atmonegoro said he had received guarantees from Suharto's family members that they would not leave Indonesia.

BC-Thailand-Stray Dogs
Bangkok plans bounty for those bringing dogs for neutering
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Seeking to control the burgeoning population of stray dogs, Bangkok city officials have decided to pay residents 50 baht (dlrs 1.22) for each dog they bring in for neutering at public health centers. The policy was announced at a public hearing attended by 300 people on the question of how to control strays, Supong Limtanakul, an advisor to the city's governor, said Monday. The incentive would be paid for both people's pets and any strays they might bring in, he said. But the bounty would be paid only for female dogs of puppy-bearing age. Supong estimated that there are as many as 1 million stray dogs in the capital alone. He said the hearing was held because of complaints from joggers as well as foreigners who visited Buddhist temples, which traditionally shelter stray dogs. The foreigners' complaints could have a negative impact on tourism, he noted. He said some animal lovers at the hearing suggested the city government provide a budget to feed the strays, while others _ including relatives of dog-bite victims who had succumbed to rabies _ wanted to get the strays off the city's streets altogether. Last year about 80 people died of rabies, 10 of them in Bangkok, Supong said. ``Stray dogs is not the problem, the problem is people, people who have no responsibility,'' he said, noting that people abandon their canine pets at temples when they grow up, have too many puppies, or simply cease being cute. He also said the city is considering an idea to implant microchips in dogs which would contain their owners' names and other information. The scheme, to cost about 100 baht (dlrs 2.44) per dog, would help make owners more responsible because they could be traced, and also could be used to see whether a dog who bit someone had been vaccinated, he said.

BC-Israel-Settlers
Settlers launch campaign to turn public against pullback
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Jewish settlers mailed one million brochures to Israeli homes Monday in hopes of turning public opinion against a U.S. proposal that Israel withdraw from 13 percent of the West Bank. The campaign came as Israel's Cabinet again failed to reach a decision on the scope of the pullback. The United States reportedly wants an Israeli answer within the next few days. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu initially said he could hand over no more than 9 percent without compromising Israel's security, but media reports said Monday he was considering a larger pullback. The brochures sent out by the Jewish Settlers' Council warned that a 13 percent pullback would endanger Israel's water resources, its hold over Jerusalem and its control over holy sites as well as jeopardize the future of the 144 Jewish settlements. ``We can not surrender to American pressure!'' the brochure said in bold letters. Aharon Dombe, a settler spokesman, said the campaign cost 1.5 shekels (dlrs 405,000) and was paid for by supporters. Netanyahu last year committed to three troop pullbacks in the West Bank, but none have been carried because of disagreement with the Palestinians over the scope of each withdrawal. A majority of Israelis support the land-for-peace negotiations with the Palestinians, according to various surveys. ga-kl

TUNIS, Tunisia (AP) _ Tunisian coach Henri Kasperczak on Monday announced his squad for the World Cup, including four European-based players he hopes will give the team vital international experience. BC-Egypt-Libya,0350
Gadhafi to visit Egypt for talks on trade, investment
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi is making a nine-day visit to Egypt starting Tuesday that will focus on trade relations with Egypt and likely will touch on Libya's feud with the West over the 1988 bombing of an American airliner. Gadhafi's visit to Egypt, the second in two years, can be expected to upset the United States, which has sought to isolate Libya because of the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed 270 people. Banned from international flights under United Nations sanctions, Gadhafi is expected to travel by land over the Libyan-Egyptian border to the town of Saloum and then go on to Cairo. He will be arriving with an entourage including nine ministers and a team of businessmen. The team will discuss potential Libyan investments in Egypt, especially in the vast Toshka irrigation project in southern Egypt. The two countries are to sign seven trade, investment and manufacturing agreements, according to Egyptian news reports. The Libyans want to boost trade with Egypt, which now officially totals 492 million Egyptian pounds (dlrs 144 million) annually. Despite U.S. complaints, Egypt has sought to maintain good relations with its oil-rich neighbor. Gadhafi is likely to raise the Lockerbie issue in talks scheduled Tuesday with President Hosni Mubarak. Lockerbie will also be on his agenda with Arab League Secretary General Esmet Abdel-Meguid, who is to meet with British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook on June 14. Both the United States and England have sought to isolate Libya because of Gadhafi's failure to turn over for trial two Libyans charged with the Lockerbie bombing. Gadhafi says they cannot get a fair trial in either country and wants them tried in a neutral state. In an effort to force Libya to turn over the suspects, the U.N. Security Council imposed sanctions in March 1992 that ban international air travel, refuse arms sales to Libya and call for limiting diplomatic contacts with the country.

Wild gunfire greets victory by Milosevic foe
AP Photos Eds: UPDATES with newer vote count. By ALISON SMALE Associated Press Writer
PODGORICA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Wild gunfire erupted in downtown Monday as revelers celebrated the victory in Montenegro's parliamentary elections of the biggest challenger to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. With 94.2 percent of the vote counted, the Election Commission in the smaller of Yugoslavia's two republics said Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic's coalition had captured 49.5 percent of the ballots compared to 36 percent for Milosevic protege Momir Bulatovic. The Montenegrin separatist Liberal Alliance _ the only other party to clear the 3 percent vote threshold to get into parliament _ received 6.2 percent of the vote. Announcing those returns, commission chairman Stevan Damjanovic said votes from 40 polling stations, where about 26,000 voters were registered, were still not counted. He expected those results to be in by Monday evening but said voting would have to be repeated in two polling stations on Wednesday, delaying an absolutely final count until later in the week. BC-Sports-Tennis-Venus vs. Martina,
Williams-Hingis rivalry renewed at French Open AP Sports Writer
By ROB GLOSTER
PARIS (AP) _ Venus Williams slammed the serve at 185 kph (115 mph, but Ai Sugiyama held up her hand and watched the ball speed past. The umpire ordered the point replayed. Williams glared at her opponent with a look that seemed to scream, ``Are you ready NOW?'' Then the 17-year-old American responded with a 190 kph (118 mph) service winner. That may be the question for top-seeded Martina Hingis as she prepares to play Williams in the quarterfinals of the French Open on Tuesday, their fifth encounter already this year. The rivalry between Hingis and Williams is becoming one of the best in women's sports. Though it evokes hints of the Chris Evert-Martina Navratilova duels of the 1980s, it has the potential to become much more bitter off the court. Hingis becomes downright haughty when discussing Williams, whom she says has not yet earned the right to consider herself part of a great rivalry. ``Everybody else is trying to make rivalries against me,'' she said. ``Venus, she won Key Biscayne, but that's not a Grand Slam.'' Williams, seeded eighth at Roland Garros in just her fourth tournament on clay, responded diplomatically when told of Hingis' comments. ``I think that she's playing good tennis, and she has every right to say what she wants to,'' Williams said. Hingis holds a 5-2 record against Williams, including a 6-0, 6-4 win in the final of the U.S. Open last summer in their only previous Grand Slam meeting. They are 2-2 this year, with Williams winning on hard courts in Sydney and in the semifinals of the Lipton Championships in Key Biscayne. But Hingis won their only career encounter on clay, capturing the final of the Italian Open in three sets in mid-May. ``It was a good victory for me there to beat her in three sets in the final of a big tournament,'' Hingis said. ``I hope she will remember that, too.'' Hingis and Williams have eased through the first four rounds of the French Open. Hingis has lost just 14 games while averaging 56 minutes per victory. Williams has lost 13 games and averaged 58 minutes per match. Hingis said she has every reason to feel she has an edge over Williams heading into the match. ``Well, why shouldn't I?'' she asked. ``I'm No. 1, I've won four Grand Slams. I have the self-confidence.'' While Hingis is the master strategist, moving opponents around the court with precise groundstrokes until she has set up a winning shot, Williams relies on power and athleticism to overwhelm foes. Those contrasting styles bring back memories of Evert, the baseline strategist, and Navratilova, the powerful serve-and-volleyer. They enjoyed their on-court duels and an off-court friendship. But the Hingis-Williams matchup is not a friendly rivalry and, if Hingis is to be believed, not yet even a rivalry. All that could change on Tuesday.

THOUSANDS of pro-democracy activists held a protest on Sunday to mark the ninth anniversary of the June 4 Tiananmen crackdown, the first under Chinese rule. But on the mainland, police temporarily detained about 20 dissidents from the eastern Shandong province and also warned another 10 not to leave their homes ahead of the annual demonstration over the 1989 Tiananmen Square incident, a banned opposition party said. In Hong Kong, an estimated 3,000 demonstrators, carrying black and white banners, demanded the mainland government revise its verdict on the brutal military crackdown. The protesters marched from Victoria Park in Causeway Bay to the SAR Government Headquarters, but unlike previous years they did not pass the offices of the Xinhua News Agency. They chanted slogans calling for the release of all dissidents on the mainland and for democracy and human rights. The radical April Fifth Action Group carried a symbolic coffin with the slogan ``a political power that kills stinks for 10,000 years'', and put it outside the foreign ministry's Office of the Commissioner. The group carried banners and chanted slogans demanding the resignation of President Jiang Zemin and National People's Congress Chairman Li Peng, who they hold directly responsible for the massacre. A police spokesman said no arrests were made. The protesters later said they hoped their demonstration yesterday on Chinese soil could pave the way for more freedom to demonstrate on the mainland. Cheung Yiu-tong, a volunteer with the Hong Kong Alliance for the Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China, said: ``Now that we are under Chinese rule it is a lot more meaningful for Hong Kong people to fight for democracy in China.'' Other demonstrators were worried the Hong Kong government had plans to curb their ability to hold protests in the future. Alliance general secretary Albert Ho Chun-yan, a newly elected legislator, said he feared a new law would be passed during the next session of the Legislative Council on sedition and subversion to limit protests. Democratic Party vice-chairman Yeung Sum said the high turnout for the demonstration showed people still cared about fighting for democracy.

BC-India-Budget, 3rd Ld-Writethru,0680
New budget addresses economic woes
Eds: ADDS defense spending increased, taxes steady. No pickup. By ASHOK SHARMA Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India's finance minister, who promised firm action to deal with anti-nuclear sanctions that have battered an already weak economy, introduced a budget Monday that included more spending on infrastructure, defense and nuclear energy. Finance Minister Yashwant Sinha also offered reassurance to foreign businesses, whose investment he will need to jump-start India's economy. The Bharatiya Janata Party-led government's commitment to ``swadeshi,'' which the BJP defined as ``economic nationalism'' worried foreign investors. Sinha said ``swadeshi does not mean isolation, swadeshi means making India strong and self-reliant.'' Sinha said he believed the nuclear sanctions ``will not have any significant impact on our economic development,'' in part because he believed countries like the United States, Australia and Japan who cut loans and all but humanitarian aid after India's five nuclear tests last month would ``moderate'' their opposition in time. ``On our part, our policies have to be clearly directed and firm,'' he said. The new government, presenting its first budget, has promised to revive India's economic growth, which faltered to 5 percent in the fiscal year 1997-98, the lowest rate in the last five years. Sinha announced 611 billion rupees (dlrs 1.5 billion), a 35 percent increase, would be spent on what he called the key infrastructure areas of energy, transportation and communications. He also announced a hike of about 51 billion rupees (dlrs 1.2 billion), or about 14 percent, on defense. Military experts have said much of the defense budget, which has been declining in recent years, goes to maintaining conventional weapons. ``There can be no compromise in defense preparedness,'' Sinha said as lawmakers thumped their desks in appreciation. To tap the financial capacity of the millions of Indians living abroad, Sinha offered them educational, cultural and economic concessions. He did not give details. He also promised a ``hassle-free procedure'' for foreign investors who have complained that bureaucratic red tape presents a huge obstacle to doing business in India. In a significant move, Sinha said he will open the government-owned insurance sector to competition from private Indian companies. He did not say foreign insurance companies would be allowed in. The government said it would sell off its interest in Indian Airlines and several state-owned energy companies to raise funds. But individual and corporate taxes were to remain steady because, Sinha said, consistency in this area was needed to encourage Indians to pay. The previous government cut tax rates from 15 percent to 10 percent for those earning between 60,000 and 100,000 rupees (dlrs 1,540 to dlrs 2,560); from 30 to 20 for those earning between 100,000 and 150,000 rupees (dlrs 2,560 to dlrs 3,850); and from 40 to 30 for those earning more than 150,000 rupees (dlrs 3,850). Those earning less than 60,000 rupees (dlrs 1,540) pay no taxes. Sinha repeated the previous finance minister's argument that Indians would be more likely to pay their taxes if they were not burdensome. And, like the previous minister, he promised a crackdown on evaders. ``In a country of our size, it's a matter of great anxiety that the total number of taxpayers constitutes less than 1.25 percent of our population,'' he said. Sinha said he decided to hold firm on taxes despite a great temptation to raise them. The government's pre-budget economic assessment, presented to Parliament last week, was bleak. In addition to the falling growth, it said the deficit rose to 6.1 percent of gross domestic product, the total value of goods and services produced by the economy, exceeding the target of 4.5 percent. A 6.35 percent inflation rate was reported Sunday, up from 5 percent during 1997-1998.

THE property market has perked up, with transactions almost trebling just days after the government announced a package of measures to stabilise prices. Real-estate agents on Sunday said the lifting of anti-speculation measures and the pledge to boost liquidity for banks to assist homebuyers has rekindled buyer sentiment. ``After Mr Tung's announcement on Friday, total transactions have jumped two to three times higher than before,'' said Louis Chan, director of Centaline Property. But not everybody was happy _ more than 200 buyers of pre-sale flats marched in Central on Sunday to protest against measures they said were of no use to them. They marched from Statue Square to the SAR Government Headquarters waving banners and chanting slogans: ``Step down, Chief Executive'' and ``Chief Executive is in good shape but we are in poor shape''. Although transactions have risen, prices have not changed, Mr Chan said. Chi Cheung Property director Ivan Lo Chi-kai said the measures would stabilise the primary market and, as a result, the second-hand one as well. ``Tierra Verde and the remaining units of other new projects would benefit the most from these measures,'' he said. The measures, according to Mr Lo, would enable developers to establish a flexible sales policy. Buyers fear they might be left out if developers were given more flexibility and could opt not to rush in to sell their flats. Choi Ai Min, managing director of Hong Kong Property, said the measures marked the government's determination to manage the supply of residential flats in a flexible manner. In addition, prices of first-hand properties have already bottomed, so the prices in the second-hand market will stabilise shortly. Midland Realty managing director Cheung Kam-shing said the satisfactory results of the sale of Tierra Verde was good for market in the short term. He expected transactions in the first and second-hand market this month to be 20 and 30 per cent higher, respectively. ``Property in Tsing Yi, as affected by Tierra Verde, has obviously stabilised,'' Mr Cheung said. But he said investors should not be too optimistic as the government measures were short-term and intended only to stabilise the current market. Yesterday's demonstrators mostly claimed to have bought property last year as the market reached its peak. They said the measures unveiled on Friday came too late, claiming the prices of their units had plunged 30-40 per cent. A Mrs Wu, 70, burst into tears during the demonstration and wailed: ``I have lost all my savings.'' The unit she and her sons purchased last May was in May Wood Court (Kingswood Villa). ``When we bought the unit last year, it was worth $2.8 million but now the banks estimate it to be worth less than $2 million,'' her son said.

BC-Kenya-Wildlife Director
Dismissal of Kenya wildlife director blocked dlrs 400 million
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) _ David Western, fired by the government, returned to the helm of the Kenya Wildlife Service because donor countries withdrew critical financial support, a newspaper said Monday. A day after Western was fired on May 21, European donors canceled dlrs 400 million in aid earmarked for salaries and other crucial expenditures within the wildlife service, The East African, a respected weekly reported. Government and diplomatic offices were closed for a holiday, and could not be reached for comment. The cash-strapped, government-owned wildlife service has been working closely with organizations including the World Bank, coordinator of the Protected Areas Wildlife Service program, the European Union, and British, Dutch, German and U.S. development agencies. Sources, who were not identified, told the newspaper the decision to withhold funding was made soon after Western complained at a news conference was ousted because he resisted ministerial pressure to allow more mines in one park and to reallocate parts of other parks for private use. President Daniel arap Moi dismissed Western's allegations as ``cheap.'' Nonetheless, the government on Thursday extended Western's contract until the end of the year ``so that proper arrangements may be made for a takeover by (a new) director.'' The government has not explained why Western was dismissed nor why his contract was extended. On Friday, donors released dlrs 180 million to the wildlife service. Hit by a devastating slump in tourism due to political violence and floods, the wildlife service has been forced to make massive layoffs and huge spending cuts. Western has said he was pleased with his reinstatement, though it cuts short his tenure by a year. ``It will enable him to oversee the implementation of the ongoing restructuring exercise at KWS, and allow him to pursue funding options from both government and donors,'' the wildlife service said in a statement issued on Western's behalf. Western has held the post for more than four years. Western's predecessor, Richard Leakey, resigned twice within days in 1994, complaining of nepotism and corruption. He rejected a presidential order to resume his duties. (kjd)

In a noble move to help the elderly people and remove poverty from rural areas of the country, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina today launched the old age allowance programme. ``We are determined to remove all sorts of discrimination, exploitation, poverty and hunger from the society,'' she said before handing over the pass hooks of the allowance programme to the elderly people of Tungipara thana. The government has undertaken the humanitarian programme to help the aged but poor people of the country as per political commitment of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. Under the programme, 10 old distressed people from an ward that means 90 people from each union will receive Tk 100 each per month. Meanwhile, the government has enlisted some 4,03,110 people, including 50 per cent women, from 4,479 unions under 461 thanas of the country to bring them under the scheme. On the inaugural day of the countrywide programme, nearly 450 old people of Tungipara thana received their allowances. The Prime Minister handed over pass books, allowance of two months and conveyance Tk 20 to 60 old men of the area to inaugurate the noble programme. ``I pray for her so that she can help more poor like us .. .. I pray for her every success in her every effort,'' said Kasem Sikder, a 75-year old man after receiving the first installment of his life long allowance. Kasem, a father of three sons, came from nearby Bhagerkul village, said his sons give him foods, ``but that is not always enough for me''. ``I am very much happy as I have been able to take the chance to receive the money from the Prime Minister herself.. ..from now on I will buy an adequate amount of food for me,'' said a beaming Kasem wearing a blur lanced obstacles. Bijoy Krishna Mandal, aged about 80, came from Patgati village to receive the allowance. He said, ``I pray for the 'Bangamata' (mother of Bengal) so that she can serve thousands other poor people.'' Shashi Charan Mandal, seemed to be 80 years old, said he will spend the money for treatment of his eyes. ``I will buy medicine for my eyes as I have become almost blind,'' said the old man hailing from Chingari. ``May Allah save our Prime Minister as she can do more for our people,'' prayed the old man, a father of two sons and three daughters. Fulmala Biswas, a sixty-year old woman, also hailing from Patgati village, said she will buy cloths and medicine for herself by the money. ``For a long time I could not buy medicine for want of money although I have been suffering from various diseases,'' said Fulmala in a jubilant mood. ``Now I will consult a doctor and buy medicine.'' Another sexagenarian woman Devrani Roy said she had lost her only son in the Liberation War, but now there is none to look after her. ``I am just pulling on my life with the help of my neighbours,'' she said adding that the money will help her a lot. Earlier, addressing the gathering of the old men and women at the Thana complex premises, the Prime Minister said the government has taken up such a programme so that the neglected rural poor can be benefited directly. ``We are trying to help a little those poorest of the poor who feel neglected during the last days of their lives as they are considered burden of the society,'' she said. The money, even though a very little, will help them raise their status in the family and society, and make them feel that they are still important, Hasina said. ``This will have a positive impact on poverty alleviation programmes of the government,'' she said adding that the main target of the present government is to build up a poverty and hunger free nation by ensuring a better life for the downtrodden. Hasina said Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman was assassinated at a time when he started working for economic emancipation of the people. ``Now as the follower of the ideals of Bangabandhu I have started various programmes to ensure economic freedom of the people,'' she said. ``If we can bring back smile on face of the downtrodden, the soul of Bangabandhu will get peace.'' The old aged allowance programme was inaugurated on the death anniversary of the mother of Bangabandhu, Sayera Khatun. ``We have started this noble programme on the death anniversary of such a great lady who gave birth to the Father of the Nation,'' the Prime Minister said. She said Bangabandhu had fought throughout his life for establishing rights of the people and also sacrificed his life for the people of the country. ``Being the daughter of Bangabandhu, I'm also ready to sacrifice everything for the countrymen,'' the Prime Minister said seeking blessings from the people so that she can fight for the poor. Finance Minister SAMS Kibria, State Minister for Social Welfare Dr Mozammel Hossain, Gopalganj district Awami League general secretary Sheikh Abdullah, Social Welfare Secretary Nurul Abedin, DG of Social Welfare Directorate Meer Shahabuddin and Gopalganj DC Nasiruddin also spoke on the occasion. From the programme the Prime Minister went straight to her ancestral home and offered fateha at the Mazar of Bangabandhu and the Mazars of Bangabandhu's father Sheikh Lutfur Rahman and mother Sayera Khatun. PREMIER Zhu Rongji has ordered a more intensive war on corruption after nation-wide investigations into financial institutions uncovered far more irregularities than expected. In Guangdong alone, bad debts and non-performing loans were found to have increased substantiallly since early this year _ in spite of widespread awareness of the dangers posed by such irregularities in light of the regional financial crisis. Worse, more irregularities were found during the detailed scrutiny of the province's banks and other financial institutions. Similar discoveries have been made in other provinces, leading to the growing view that the mainland's true situation is worse than expected. Initial reports suggest that many state corporations based in the coastal regions have invested heavily in Southeast Asia. While known, the extent is only now coming to light. It is likely to lead to a thorough re-assessment of the impact of the regional crisis on the mainland. These discoveries have led Mr Zhu to order more intensive investigations and more severe punishments. It is understood that officials will be kicked out and barred from the civil service, no matter how minor their misdeeds, a mainland source said, quoting a recent speech by Mr Zhu that was recently circulated internally. Mr Zhu has also urged the media to give publicity to all such misdeeds in the crucial business sector. He also encouraged journalists to direct more energy and criticism to the war on graft and the crackdown on irregularities. Central investigators were asked to work closely with the media. ``We should mobilise all the forces in the society in the fight against these evils, especially those wrongdoings in the financial and banking sectors, which are crucial to a healthy and stable economic development,'' he said, pointing out that corruption, cronyism and irregularities are key reasons behind economic collapses in neighbouring countries. He said it was not enough to rely solely on law enforcement bodies. A Guangdong official, admitting more instances of serious irregularities have been uncovered, said officials in the whole province have become fidgety as a result.

Tories appoint right-wing anti-abortionist as health spokesman
LONDON (AP) _ Conservative Party leader William Hague on Monday appointed a right-wing legislator who opposes abortion as the party's spokesman on health. Ann Widdecombe, a staunch Roman Catholic who left the Anglican Church because she also opposes women priests, has risen to prominence as one of the Tories' most effective parliamentarians since the party lost power a year ago. Her appointment was part of a shakeup by Hague of the Tory spokesmen in parliament, a group known as the Shadow Cabinet. Another right-winger, Peter Lilley, who was Social Security secretary in the previous Conservative government, was named deputy leader of the party _ a post not filled under former prime minister John Major, who led the party to a devastating defeat. Miss Widdecombe, 50, was the only new appointee to the Shadow Cabinet. Her colleagues in the group include Michael Howard, the current foreign affairs spokesman, with whom she fell out when she was his deputy in the previous government. After the party's defeat, Miss Widdecombe effectively stymied Howard's bid for the Tory leadership by saying there was ``something of the night'' about him. There was no immediate sign Miss Widdecombe's strong views would affect her position as health spokesman. Abortion is effectively available on demand in Britain, and there is no significant public demand for less liberal laws ``This is the team that is going to hold to account the government that is increasingly breaking its promises to the country, and is going to generate ideas for the future,'' Hague said as he left Tory party headquarters. After a year in power, Labor Prime Minister Tony Blair holds record popularity ratings, while opinion polls indicate Conservative support stuck around 28 percent _ worse than the 30.6 percent than the party got in the May 1997 national election. HEALTH officials on Sunday gave the assurance that the intestinal disease which killed at least 17 newborn babies and young children in Taiwan was not likely to hit Hong Kong because of the clean drinking water and environment here. President of the Hong Kong Medical Association Dr Lo Wing-lok said there were no signs indicating the presence here of the killer virus _ entero-virus type 71. Director for Health Margaret Chan Fung Fu-chun promised her department would follow the situation closely. But no special working group would be set up at the moment, a spokeswoman for the Health Department confirmed last night. Dr Chan said symptoms of the virus were similar to most gastro-intestinal diseases, although type 71 could develop into a dangerous condition and be fatal in the worst case. ``A patient with the disease will develop fever and diarrhoea. ``If his heart is also infected, he will have shortness of breath and heart failure. ``If a patient (with a gastro-intestinal condition) has heart failure and shortness of breath or other serious complications, then we can tell that he is infected with the type,'' the health spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman said the virus was spread through food and close contact or touching of an infected person's faeces and body fluids. It is believed there were occasional cases here. Dr Lo said children and infants were more vulnerable to the virus than adults. He said the virus would not pose a great threat to adults with a strong immune system, but children under two years of age and who had no immunisation could be infected more easily, he said. The virus can infect the intestinal system and other organs, including the heart. But there was no evidence an outbreak would hit Hong Kong due to its clean drinking water and environment, Dr Lo said. To prevent young children from being infected, parents and nursery staff should be cautious about hygiene, he added. Meanwhile, the health spokeswoman said young children who caught any infectious disease should be suspended from school.

Passengers stranded as Air France strike begins France's biggest strike in 27 years, smaller airlines increasing flights
EDS: UPDATES with quote from SNPL pilot union, ADDS it is Air AP Photos PAR101-104 By CHRISTOPHER BURNS Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Thousands of frustrated passengers were stranded at airports across the country Monday, after Air France pilots began a strike that threatened to disrupt travel plans during the World Cup. Monitors at Paris' main airports offered a bleak sight for passengers: departure screens read ``canceled'' in bright red letters next to nearly all Air France flights nine days before the soccer championship begins. The jets of the official airline for the World Cup, many decorated with players representing the 32 teams, sat idle at terminals. Their 3,200 pilots sought to block wage cuts aimed at keeping the newly profitable state-owned airline out of the red. The walkout, Air France's biggest in 27 years, was a serious embarrassment to the leftist government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, and train workers were also threatening to strike later in the week. Frustrated passengers lined up at Air France ticket counters at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris, hoping to switch their tickets to other carriers. Nicolas Minvelle, hoping to leave on vacation to Senegal, said it wasn't fair the pilots were striking ahead of the World Cup, being played in 10 cities across France. ``They use an international event to bother everyone, it's too bad. That's not the image of France, it should be avoided. You can say they are not civic-minded,'' he said. Yelena Panteley, a Russian student from California, was on her way to see her mother in Saint Petersburg, hoping to catch an alternate flight. ``There is hope, but nothing's sure.'' Under normal circumstances, around 100,000 people would have used Air France on Monday. Air France assured that it would make good on its commitment to fly World Cup teams. But the airline expected to cancel 90 percent of long-haul flights for the coming week. About 25 percent of short- and medium-haul flights out of Paris' Charles de Gaulle airport are likely to fly as planned, the company has said, as are about 20 percent leaving from Orly airport, in south Paris. During the World Cup, fans will travel across France regularly since their teams will rotate between several venues. In addition, there are 9,000 journalists accredited to cover the event. Christian Paris, spokesman for the main union in the strike, the SNPL, admitted the consequences were ``disastrous.'' ``But when you're confronted by an attack you have no choice but to defend yourself. And that's what the pilots are doing as of today,'' he said in an interview on television channel France 2. In contrast to past conflicts when ground crews blocked airport runways, the pilots kept a low profile and simply didn't show up for work. Other airlines quietly went on with their flights and some increased flight quotas in some parts of the country to cope with demand. Transport Minister Jean-Claude Gayssot, speaking on French television, urged both sides to ``take up the path of discussion.'' Fearful that France's image could be tarnished when the soccer matches begin, one leftist lawmaker, Georges Sarre, denounced the pilots as ``the damned of the Earth.'' The SNPL union has called a 15-day renewable strike starting Monday. Three smaller unions called for a strike from Monday to Thursday. On Thursday, French industry will slow, with the CGT union calling for a strike which is expected to affect most public services, as well as the energy and construction sectors. (ip-cb)

Newspaper reports deportation center to be closed in two weeks
KUWAIT (AP) _ Kuwait has temporarily released hundreds of detainees from a controversial deportation center and is hoping to close the facility in two weeks, Al-Watan daily reported Monday. The Talha Deportation Center was set up after Kuwait was liberated in 1991 from a seven-month Iraqi occupation. But scores of inmates have since gone on hunger strikes or attempted suicide to protest detentions as long as five years. Kuwaiti Interior Minister Sheik Mohammad al-Khaled al-Sabah said that 250 people were freed on bail for six months to allow them to solve problems preventing them from leaving the country, Al-Watan reported. Talha's inmates are generally debtors or or so-called stateless Arabs that the government is seeking to deport. However, the debtors are expected to pay what they owe before being deported, and some of the others have nowhere to go. Interior and Justice Ministry officials have met with each of the center's inmates to ensure that their problems were solved and that they could leave the country, Sheik Mohammad told Al-Watan. Many of the stateless Arabs, which the government says number about 120,000, maintain they have lived in Kuwait for decades, but have been denied citizenship. The government argues most have other passports but have destroyed them seeking Kuwait citizenship. An estimated 600 people were reported detained in Talha last month. But after the releases, only 163 people are being held at Talba, Mohammad al-Zobi, a public prosecutor told Al-Watan. He said that they have been there for no more than one month. Al-Zobi said the debts of more than 60 inmates had been forgiven, and hundreds of others have already left the country. Human rights groups have criticized the detentions at the center, arguing that they are protracted and sometimes done without court order. Two years ago, the government promised to shut down the facility, which served as a school before the 1990 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. It did not deliver on the promise. de-tt-ggl
