ATHENS, Greece (AP) _ The government said Monday it will go ahead with the sale of Greece's fourth largest bank, bringing it onto a collision course with Socialist-controlled labor unions. Ionian Bank employees walked off their jobs on May 8 protesting plans by the Socialist government to sell the state-owned bank, part of a broad-ranging plan to streamline the economy in view of European monetary union. Workers ignored a court decision Wednesday declaring the strike illegal, forcing Premier Costas Simitis to hold an emergency Cabinet meeting to review government privatization plans. Efforts to unload Ionian have created one of the strongest trade union backlashes against the government. Simitis still faces problems with restructuring Olympic Airways, the debt-ridden national carrier. Protests are also expected over future plans to cut costs at the post office, public buses and the national railroad. ``We have unanimously agreed to proceed with the government's decision to privatize Ionian Bank,'' said National Economy Minister Yannos Papantoniou after the emergency Cabinet meeting. His statement tried to allay fears of a looming split in the governing socialist party, or PASOK, caused by the privatization plan. But the socialist-dominated Federation of Greek Bank Employee Unions, an umbrella union, vowed to strike indefinitely unless the government revokes the bank's sale. Ionian's management has asked a court to declare the federation's strike illegal. In an attempt to defuse the situation and calm tempers, Papantoniou invited workers and unionists for talks. He has already pledged that no jobs will be lost in the first few years after the sale. Simitis has been struggling to keep the party united following the death of its populist founder Andreas Papandreou two years ago. Large portions of the party's grass roots followers believe his free market policies contradict its socialist welfare-state ideology. ``It's a shame that a necessary policy began in a way which in the end undermines its importance and effectiveness,'' said European Commissioner Christos Papoutsis, a PASOK member, in an interview with the Athens daily Ta Nea. JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Facing increased pressure to clean up past misdeeds, Indonesia's new government announced a broad-based inquiry Monday into corruption under ex-President Suharto. However, it stopped short of meeting demands by student protesters and others who want the wealth of Suharto and his super-rich family specifically targeted. Critics say the Suhartos blatantly used their power and position to amass billions of dollars by dominating the now ailing economy. Thousands of students staged peaceful protests in several cities Monday calling for an end to both local and national graft. In Jakarta, about 50 students rallied outside the U.S. Embassy against what they said were American attempts to delay foreign loans to Indonesia. Flanked by soldiers, the protesters sat down at the gates and chanted slogans against U.S. intervention in the affairs of their economically-shattered country. They accused the U.S. of conspiring to stall the disbursement of aid tied to a dlrs 43 billion rescue package led by the International Monetary Fund. The loans were suspended amid political turmoil that led to the May 21 resignation of President Suharto. The IMF is expected to deliberate Monday on whether to resume aid. Meanwhile, a leading opposition figure has called on Suharto to donate the bulk of his wealth back to the country as it battles its worst economic crisis in decades. Amien Rais, a prominent Muslim leader, said that with Suharto's money Indonesia would not have to beg international agencies to prop up the economy. Rais said that if Suharto did that ``the Indonesian people could find it in their hearts to pardon him.'' Rais and others have called for an inquiry into Suharto's business empire and have also demanded that the former first family be barred from leaving the country. Attorney General Sudjono Atmonegoro said the corruption inquiry had been set up in response to public anger over the conduct of ``government officials.'' He did not specifically name Suharto. ``The investigation is underway,'' he said. ``This investigation is a process that will need time. It cannot be completed in just one or two days.'' Sudjono said the inquiry would be carried out on the principle of ``presumption of innocence'' and would involve many government departments and outside agencies. As part of the probe, Sudjono said he had received assurances from Suharto family members that they would not leave Indonesia. While there were no plans to question Suharto, the former president might be asked to comment on evidence from others, he said. The head of the powerful military, Gen. Wiranto, said recently he was opposed to an investigation into the Suharto family fortune because it could cause national disunity. The military played a key role in Indonesia's recent political crisis. It quelled riots by putting thousands of soldiers and dozens of tanks on the street. Some claim it also was instrumental in persuading Suharto, himself a retired army general, to quit in favor of new President B.J. Habibie, a civilian and Suharto loyalist who has promised political and economic reforms. Also on Monday Habibie appointed three former Suharto advisors to help steer the economy through its crisis. The economic crisis claimed another casualty Monday when Indonesia's third largest airline, controlled by Suharto's youngest son, closed down. The government said the carrier registered enormous losses because of a 70 percent drop in the value of the currency, the rupiah, since July 1997. Much of the costs borne by the airline were in dollars, but its revenue was mainly in rupiah. Sempati's shareholders include Suharto's son Hutomo ``Tommy'' Mandala Putra as well as a military foundation.

Monitors at Paris' main airports offered a bleak sight for passengers: departure screens read ``canceled'' in bright red letters next to nearly all Air France flights nine days before the soccer championship begins. The jets of the official airline for the World Cup, many decorated with players representing the 32 teams, sat idle at terminals. Their 3,200 pilots sought to block wage cuts aimed at keeping the newly profitable state-owned airline out of the red. The walkout, Air France's biggest in 27 years, was a serious embarrassment to the leftist government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, and train workers were also threatening to strike later in the week. Frustrated passengers lined up at Air France ticket counters at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris, hoping to switch their tickets to other carriers. Nicolas Minvelle, hoping to leave on vacation to Senegal, said it wasn't fair the pilots were striking ahead of the World Cup, being played in 10 cities across France. ``They use an international event to bother everyone, it's too bad. That's not the image of France, it should be avoided. You can say they are not civic-minded,'' he said. Yelena Panteley, a Russian student from California, was on her way to see her mother in Saint Petersburg, hoping to catch an alternate flight. ``There is hope, but nothing's sure.'' Under normal circumstances, around 100,000 people would have used Air France on Monday. Air France assured that it would make good on its commitment to fly World Cup teams. But the airline expected to cancel 90 percent of long-haul flights for the coming week. About 25 percent of short- and medium-haul flights out of Paris' Charles de Gaulle airport are likely to fly as planned, the company has said, as are about 20 percent leaving from Orly airport, in south Paris. During the World Cup, fans will travel across France regularly since their teams will rotate between several venues. In addition, there are 9,000 journalists accredited to cover the event. Christian Paris, spokesman for the main union in the strike, the SNPL, admitted the consequences were ``disastrous.'' ``But when you're confronted by an attack you have no choice but to defend yourself. And that's what the pilots are doing as of today,'' he said in an interview on television channel France 2. In contrast to past conflicts when ground crews blocked airport runways, the pilots kept a low profile and simply didn't show up for work. Other airlines quietly went on with their flights and some increased flight quotas in some parts of the country to cope with demand. Transport Minister Jean-Claude Gayssot, speaking on French television, urged both sides to ``take up the path of discussion.'' Fearful that France's image could be tarnished when the soccer matches begin, one leftist lawmaker, Georges Sarre, denounced the pilots as ``the damned of the Earth.'' The SNPL union has called a 15-day renewable strike starting Monday. Three smaller unions called for a strike from Monday to Thursday. On Thursday, French industry will slow, with the CGT union calling for a strike which is expected to affect most public services, as well as the energy and construction sectors. (ip-cb)

More deaths reported in Kosovo; hundreds flee
Eds: UPDATES with more reported deaths; background. By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Heavy fighting in Serbia's explosive Kosovo province prompted reports Monday of more than a dozen new deaths and sent hundreds of people fleeing into Albania. Conflicting accounts of casualties in the blocked-off areas could not immediately be sorted out. But the bloodshed appears to be the worst since early March when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on militants and their families. A day after Serb authorities claimed to have killed several dozen militants in four villages in the Decani region of western Kosovo, ethnic Albanian officials said 37 Albanians had been killed over the weekend. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani while 10 were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died in the fighting around Decani, 75 kilometers (45 miles) west of the regional capital Pristina, Serb sources said. The latest fierce fighting prompted about 1,000 Kosovo Albanians, mostly women, children and elderly, to leave the troubled region and cross over into Albania's Troboja region Sunday and Monday, Albanian authorities said. Interior Ministry spokesman Artan Bizhga said in the Albanian capital, Tirana, that the refugees, many of whom had walked for as many as 10 hours, were being accommodated in local homes and a school. Local authorities were providing free food and clothes. Authorities in Serbia, which with Montenegro comprises all that remains of the Yugoslav federation, claim that thousands of Kosovo Albanians are staying in the province illegally. They are trying to block Kosovo's independence bid and are using the police and army to try to crush militants and maintain control over the province, where 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million is ethnic Albanian. More than 200 people have died in Kosovo clashes since the beginning of March. An estimated 50 percent of the Serbian province is controlled by militant Albanians and many regions are blocked off, either by Serbs or Albanians. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, released the names of the 10 people it said were killed Sunday when Serb police stormed the village of Poklek, 25 kilometers (15 miles) west of Pristina. It said one had had his throat slit. According to the Albanians' account, Serb police burst into Poklek houses, pulled out villagers and told them to ``go to Albania and never return.'' Afterward, Serb police allegedly set 26 homes ablaze. All phone lines remained disconnected Monday between Pristina and the hot-spots of Decani, Klina and Djakovica, where fierce battles were reported Sunday. Yugoslavia's state-run daily Politika on Monday blamed ethnic Albanian ``terrorist groups'' for numerous deaths. It said that in their efforts to cross into Albania, they shelled several villages near Junik, ``a border town known for resisting militant enlistings, killing several of their countrymen, including children.'' BC-Pakistan-Iran-Nuclear,0464
Muslims worldwide ''happy'' Pakistan tested nuclear devices: Iran
AP Photos ISL101 By KATHY GANNON Associated Press Writer
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan (AP) _ Iran's Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi _ the first visitor to Islamic Pakistan since it exploded six nuclear devices _ said Monday that Muslims worldwide welcomed the nuclear tests. It is particularly so in the Middle East, where Muslims believe their traditional adversary, Israel, possesses the ability to make nuclear bombs, he said. ``Until now, they felt in ... the Middle East that only Israel had the capability ... now they feel confident,'' because a fellow-Islamic country also possesses the ability to make nuclear weapons, Kharrazi told reporters at a brief news conference upon his arrival in the Pakistani capital Islamabad. Kharrazi, however, dismissed suggestions that Iran was preparing to follow Pakistan down the nuclear road. ``We don't have any nuclear weapons program ... what we have is for peaceful purposes,'' and all Iran's nuclear facilities are open to international inspectors, he said. Last Thursday, after Pakistan tested five nuclear devices, Pakistan's Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif promised to safeguard the nuclear technology and vowed not to share it with any other country. Pakistan tested a sixth nuclear device on Saturday, one-upping rival neighbor India, which detonated five nuclear devices three weeks ago. Kharrazi said India left Pakistan with no choice of whether to test or not. ``As a matter of its national security and to create a balance in the region, Pakistan had no choice,'' he said. While in Pakistan, Kharrazi said he will try to cool tempers and ease tension in the Asian subcontinent. ``We understand the security concerns of Pakistan, but at the same time we think there should be more restraint and a relaxation of tensions,'' he said. Pakistan and India have traded a war of words since the first nuclear test by India on May 11. India has threatened to step up its military activity on its side of the troubled Kashmir border _ the flash point of two previous wars between the two nuclear powers. They fought a third war in 1971 over Bangladesh or what was then East Pakistan. In 1990, the specter of war surfaced and many people here feared a fourth _ possibly nuclear _ war between the uneasy neighbors. Pakistan accused India of preparing to attack its nuclear sites last week, scrambled its own air force and put its soldiers on alert. The latest accusation came from Pakistan's Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub who said his country had ``credible evidence'' that India was preparing a second site to test nuclear weapons. India denied the accusation.

World wool production estimated at lowest since World War II
LONDON (AP) _ Revised estimates released Monday showed world wool production falling for the eighth successive year to a post-World War II low. But the International Wool Textile Organization said prices remained weak because of Australia boosting supplies by selling from a stockpile and demand depressed by financial problems in Asia, particularly Japan. A report by the agency, which represents the wool industry in exporting and importing countries, also cited poor retail wool sales in Europe and ``deteriorating consumer and business confidence'' in China. It said the decline in production was due largely to farmers switching from sheep to products with better returns. The Brussels-based body's new estimate put global wool production in the 1997-98 (July-June) season at 1.429 million metric tons (clean basis), compared with 1.438 million tons previously forecast and 1996-97's clip of 1.474 million tons. In 1989-90, output hit a record 2.01 million tons. Since then, the agency's figures have shown declines every season _ particularly in the territories of the former Soviet Union and Australia. The 1997-98 production falls more than offset a record clip in China. The breakdown of the IWTO's latest 1997-98 global clip estimate -- in thousands of metric tons (clean basis), with 1996- 97 comparisons in parentheses -- included Australia 442 (457), New Zealand 201 (203), China 156 (149), former Soviet Union 83 (100), Uruguay 55 (60), Britain 40 (42), Argentina 37 (41), Turkey 36 (36), South Africa 34 (37), India 28 (28), Iran 23 (23), Pakistan 23 (23), Irish Republic 17 (17), Spain 16 (16), Morocco 14 (14), United States 13 (14), Brazil 11 (11), Mongolia 11 (11), Romania 11 (11) and France 10 (10). President Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed yesterday called for intensifying anti-smoking movement across the country comprising representatives from all sections of the society. ``It's very difficult to free the nation from the problems caused by smoking without an all-out effort of the government and the private sector and strong cooperation of the people,'' he said inaugurating a seminar at the Osmani Memorial Hall yesterday morning. Chaired by national Professor Nurul Islam, the founder President of ADHUNIK, the function was also addressed by Health and Family Welfare Minister Salahuddin Yusuf and Health Secretary Muhammad Ali. ``When the trend of smoking has declined in the developed countries following world-wide anti-smoking drive by the WHO and UNESCO, the tendency is gradually increasing in the developing countries,'' the President told the function. In Bangladesh, he said, the number of smokers were 2 crore in 1988 which seemed to be increased by this time. ``The habit mostly exists in the poor section of the people.'' President Shahabuddin said anti-smoking movement was not vigorous in the country before 1987. In this regard, ADHUNIK has played a pioneering role, he added. The President said various steps like announcement of smoking free zone, imposition of tax on tobacco and inclusion of anti-smoking issues in the text books have already been taken to discourage smoking, but expected success has not yet been achieved in this regard. ``It would be wise to prefer phase-wise pragmatic steps rather than closing the tobacco industry at a time to avert any economic disaster as thousands of people are involved in the industry,'' he said. He also suggested to discourage manufacturing and marketing of bidi and cigarettes, and intensify campaign about the adverse affects of smoking. ``The severity of smoking will be minimised if the anti-smoking movement can be turned into an active social movement,'' he said calling on the doctors, teachers, engineers, journalists, writers, poets, litterateurs and social workers to come up to supplement the effort. Health and Family Welfare Minister Salahuddin Ahmed sought cooperation of the people of all strata for a tobacco free society as it's not possible for the government alone to get the job done. ``Youths should be refrained from tobacco to make a tobacco-free society.'' In his welcome address, Prof Nurul Islam said some 10,000 people in the world are losing their lives everyday due to smoking. Quoting WHO statistics, he said there are 60 per cent male and 7-10 per cent female smokers in Bangladesh. But he assumed that the female smokers in our country is about 30 per cent. Prof Islam said of the smokers 80-90 per cent are from the poor section of the society while 23.3 per cent are school students. SINGAPORE (AP) _ Two Singapore branch officials of the Union Bank of Switzerland said Monday they have filed defamation suits against The Economist magazine for accusing them of poor risk management. That merger is awaiting U.S. regulatory approval. UBS branch chairman Lim Ho Kee and senior vice president James Loh told Dow Jones Newswires that they filed writs in a local court Monday. ``We absolutely refute all allegations made in The Economist article,'' Lim said. Bill Emmott, editor of The Economist, told Dow Jones Newswires in a telephone interview from London, ``The Economist stands by the article published in its issue dated May 30. If we receive a writ for defamation, we will contest it with all due vigor.'' In response to the magazine article, the UBS head office in Zurich had previously issued a statement saying that the Singapore branch ``is and always has been integrated into the independent centralized risk management processes for all credit and market risks. UBS Singapore was continuously respecting these procedures, especially the clear separation of duties.'' The statement said the UBS Singapore branch reported after-tax profits of 29 million Singapore dollars (dlrs 17.17 million) last year.

Gadhafi's trip is ``canceled for now,'' Omar Rashwan, Libya's coordinator for affairs with Egypt, told reporters in the western Egyptian town of Mersa Matrouh, where Gadhafi was to stop en route to Cairo. No explanation was given. However, the Libyan leader is known for changing plans without notice. It could also be that his visit was considered inconvenient at a time when Egypt is heavily involved in trying to organize an Arab summit on Mideast peace. No date for a new visit has been announced. An Egyptian presidential official, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed that Gadhafi will not arrive Tuesday and that the trip was ``postponed to an indefinite date.'' Gadhafi was to arrive with a high-level delegation including nine ministers and a team of businessmen to discuss boosting trade relations and investments. Gadhafi and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak were scheduled to meet Wednesday. Their talks were likely to touch on Libya's feud with the West over the 1988 bombing of an American airliner. Last year, Malaysia's food import bill totalled RM11.4 billion, with beef, fish, vegetables and fruits topping the list. After opening the Johor Baru South Area Farmers' Organisation today, Tengku Mahmud said State Governments had responded well to the call to allocate land for agricultural activities. He identified these states as Johor, Pahang, Perak, Terengganu, Negri Sembilan, Perlis, Kedah and Malacca. ``I am sure the results of the campaign (to boost food production) will be seen in 2000. He added State Governments should allocate land for agriculture projects on a lease basis rather than granting titles to avoid the land from being used for other commercial projects. Tengku Mahmud also said his ministry officials were continuing discussions on ways to boost agriculture output. He added the Ministry was also working out means to disburse the RM300 million recently injected by the Government into the fund for food, or 3F scheme. The sum was specially allocated for small farmers including Area Farmers' Organisations. He said the disbursement would prioritise cattle, poultry, fish and vegetable farming. Opening the annual general meeting earlier, Tengku Mahmud said the economic situation had provided an opportunity to revive the farmers' movement as the Government was giving the agriculture sector much emphasis. He said farmers and area farmers' organisations needed to strengthen their marketing network. ``Farmers must involve themselves in marketing their produce without middlemen. This way, they will get better prices while allowing consumers to pay less.'' Towards this aim, Tengku Mahmud said the Ministry had directed the Federal Agriculture Marketing Authority to increase the number of pasar tani or expand existing ones. ``We will ask State Governments to provide areas for pasar tani. SUPPLIES of wild American ginseng _ the precious root so popular in Hong Kong _ may be under threat, conservationists say. Over-production of the cultivated root, combined with the local economic downturn, has led to a fall in prices in Hong Kong. The World Wide Fund for Nature Hong Kong released a study into the dangers facing the precious health-giving plant. Author Chris Robbins claims there is a shortfall in the management of the ginseng trade, which may lead to depletion of the source. The report states that logging and the spread of suburban development could threaten the habitat of wild ginseng in America. Over-harvest adds to the danger. WWFHK spokeswoman Judy Mills said: ``A lot of people think of rhinos, tigers and bears when they think of endangered species used in traditional Chinese medicine _ but many rare plants are also used.'' Traditional Chinese medicine trader Chun Kwong-shing, who runs the Tai Wai Native Products Company, has been trading in Hong Kong for 30 years and has this year seen a decline in demand. The wholesale price per pound of wild American ginseng two years ago was US$500 (HK$3,900), while now it is only US$300. Lower prices have increased demand in spite of the hard times. The conservation group has suggested setting up a conservation trust fund through donations from the sale of American ginseng products, and conserving wild-ginseng habitats in North America. Hong Kong imports 2,500 tonnes of cultivated and 47 tonnes of wild American ginseng annually. North America is the major source of ginseng imported into Hong Kong. There is currently a ban on exports of wild ginseng from New York state and Canada where over-picking has led to scarcity. Ms Mills claims illegal shipments from these areas are further damaging supplies. But according to Cheung Chi-sun, endangered-species protection officer for the Agricultural and Fisheries Department, there is no significant increase in illegal imports. ``It is usually just individual travellers bringing back a few ounces of ginseng.'' Wild American ginseng grows predominantly in the northeastern US and Canada, while the cultivated version is found mostly in Wisconsin.

More deaths reported in Kosovo; hundreds flee
By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Heavy fighting in Serbia's explosive Kosovo province prompted reports Monday of more than a dozen new deaths and sent hundreds of people fleeing into Albania. Conflicting accounts of casualties in the blocked-off areas could not immediately be sorted out. But the bloodshed appears to be the worst since early March when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on militants and their families. A day after Serb authorities claimed to have killed several dozen militants in four villages in the Decani region of western Kosovo, ethnic Albanian officials said 37 Albanians had been killed over the weekend. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani, while 10 were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died in the fighting around Decani, 75 kilometers (45 miles) west of the regional capital Pristina, Serb sources said. The latest fierce fighting prompted about 1,000 Kosovo Albanians, mostly women, children and elderly, to leave the troubled region and cross over into Albania's Troboja region Sunday and Monday, Albanian authorities said. Interior Ministry spokesman Artan Bizhga said in the Albanian capital, Tirana, that the refugees, many of whom walked for as many as 10 hours, were being accommodated in local homes and a school. Local authorities were providing free food and clothes. Authorities in Serbia, which with Montenegro comprises all that remains of the Yugoslav federation, claim that thousands of Kosovo Albanians are staying in the province illegally. They are trying to block Kosovo's independence bid and are using the police and army to try to crush militants and maintain control over the province, where 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million is ethnic Albanian. More than 200 people have died in Kosovo clashes since the beginning of March. An estimated 50 percent of the Serbian province is controlled by militant Albanians and many regions are blocked off, either by Serbs or Albanians. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, released the names of the 10 people it said were killed Sunday when Serb police stormed the village of Poklek, 25 kilometers (15 miles) west of Pristina. It said one had had his throat slit. According to the Albanians' account, Serb police burst into Poklek houses, pulled out villagers and told them to ``go to Albania and never return.'' Afterward, Serb police allegedly set 26 homes ablaze. All phone lines remained disconnected Monday between Pristina and the hot-spots of Decani, Klina and Djakovica, where fierce battles were reported Sunday. Yugoslavia's state-run daily Politika on Monday blamed ethnic Albanian ``terrorist groups'' for numerous deaths. It said that in their efforts to cross into Albania, they shelled several villages near Junik, ``a border town known for resisting militant enlistings, killing several of their countrymen, including children.''

NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India on Monday rejected reports it was planning another nuclear test, following its call on all nuclear weapons states to start negotiations for a Nuclear Weapons Convention. Foreign Ministry spokesman K.C. Singh said Pakistani Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan's claims that India was surreptitiously preparing to conduct more tests next month was ``surprising'' _ and wrong. ``India has declared a moratorium on testing, and this has been reiterated by the prime minister himself,'' Singh said. His ministry reiterated India's long-standing call for international talks on reducing nuclear weapons in a statement Sunday. Despite Singh's firm statement that India's tests were over, the country's Atomic Energy Commission Chairman R. Chidambaram was quoted by local news agencies as telling fellow scientists at a forum in Bombay Monday that small tests might be carried out for research purposes _ but ``only if necessary.'' He did not elaborate. India escalated the long-standing Indo-Pakistan rivalry to the nuclear level with five tests May 11-13. In response, Pakistan claimed to have detonated six nuclear devices last week. Pakistan's Khan said he had credible information that India was ``already in the process of preparing a new test site ... to blast somewhere in the first or second week in July.'' Pakistan has not said whether it would test again. U.S. intelligence sources said they had detected no signs that either Pakistan or India was readying new tests. The international community has pressured India and Pakistan to sign a test ban treaty and the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Pakistan and India have fought three wars since they were carved from the same British colony 50 years ago. They are divided by religion _ Pakistan is officially Muslim and India is predominately Hindu _ and a simmering territorial dispute over the Himalayan region of Kashmir, which is divided between them and claimed by both countries. A top Iranian envoy arrived Monday in Pakistan and praised its government for its nuclear tests. ``From all over the world Muslims are happy that Pakistan has this capability,'' Iranian Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi told reporters. Kharrazi dismissed suggestions that Iran was preparing to follow Pakistan down the nuclear road. ``We don't have any nuclear weapons program . . . what we have is for peaceful purposes,'' and all Iran's nuclear facilities are open to international inspectors, he said. Violence broke out briefly Monday in Srinagar, capital of Indian-held Kashmir, after 100 people who oppose Indian rule distributed sweets in the streets _ a traditional way of celebrating _ and carried banners congratulating Pakistan on its nuclear tests. Some threw stones at police, who responded by beating protesters. Indian accuses Pakistan of arming and training several groups fighting either for Kashmir's independence or its union with Pakistan. Pakistan says it lends them only moral support.

The multi-million dollar Jamuna Multipurpose Bridge, renamed as the Bangabandhu Bridge, conceived in the late sixties will be opened for traffic from June 23 after a gala inaugural function. Work on the bridge, now going on in full swing, will come to an end by June 20, Deputy Project Manager Brig AHM Abdullah told The Independent yesterday at the project site. The bridge, which has been named after Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, is a prestigious project of the country, for which all the successive governments after the independence of Bangladesh contributed a lot. The bridge could have been completed by December last if the bridge authority had not taken up the construction of the dual gauge railway system at the northern side of the bridge along with the construction of the main bridge, a source said. The 12 metre radius curved bridge which looks like a crescent from its southern side, connects Kalihati of Bhuapur with Saydabad of Sirajganj linking the eastern part of the country with the west. The curve shape of the bridge, which was designed to protect drivers of vehicles from reflection of light, increased the length of the bridge by 31 metres. The multipurpose bridge, which is unique in the world by for its multipurpose use, including rail movement, gas and electricity transmission, and four-lane road, is learnt to be the 11th longest bridge in the world with its 4.8 kilometre long pathway and 18.5 metre deck width and 1200 metre radius of carvature of bridge. The life span of the bridge is estimated at 100 years, but engineers said that it may be much higher if it is maintained properly. Almost all the works has been completed except the setting up of the expansion joint (the joint needed to cope with the expansion of the bridge due to humid weather), parapet wall and barrier and construction of some structures for laying the railway track. The total estimated cost, including the escalated cost due to delay and price hike of materials used in the bridge, is Tk 3,742 crore including Tk 163 crore for the rehabilitation of the displaced people of the area. Of the total cost, the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the OECF, Japan, provided $200 million each the total amount of which in taka terms stood at 2400 crore. The rest of the amount was provided by the Bangladesh government. The other integrated constructions like rail, gas, 232 k.v electricity lines and telelinks required additional resources which would be provided by the respective departments, a bridge authority source said. The dual gauge railway system - broad gauge and metre gauge - will require more than Tk 100 crore. The eight components of the bridge such as the main bridge (contract-1) ,river training (contract-2), East and West approach roads (contract 3 and 4), rail approach for east and west (contract 5 and 6), the flood control embankment on east side (contract no 7) and flood control embankment on the western side (contract no 8) have been completed barring some finishing work. Apart from all these major works, the government has also carried out some small constructions for the protection of the bridge. Of the total cost for the bridge, about $300 million was used for river training to stop the shifting tendency of the river. A total of 2552 local workers and about 300 expatriates were employed during the peak period of the construction of the bridge, i.e from October 1995 to July 1996, according to the project authority source. A five kilometre cross dam on the west side has reduced the width of the river to almost half at 4.8 km, i.e the actual length of the bridge. The engineers said that the 4.8 km width of the river was sufficient to facilitate the flow of the total amount of water through the river. The first work of the bridge began in October, 1994. To begin the work the government had to spend an amount of Tk 400 crore which was obtained through the imposition of a surcharge on different services. The source said the total collection of surcharge was about Tk 560 crore. The surcharge was imposed during the Ershad regime. The bridge was conceived in 1966 and later Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman first initiated a dialogue with Japan for the construction of the bridge after independence. The donors agreed to provide resources during the BNP regime led by Begum Zia. The bridge was completed during the period of the present government. Three international contractors, Hyundai Construction and Samwan Corporation of South Korea and Hamban Ward Zevi of Netherlands executed the project. The design of the bridge was done by T.Y Lin of USA on behalf of Rendel Palmer Tritton and NEDECO and Bangladesh Consultant Ltd. The RPT also did consultancy work for Hardinge Bridge in 1912, which is still in operation. Sir Willium Hallcrow, Prize Water House, EPC and Rahman Rahman Haque have worked as managerial advisers to the government for the construction of the bridge. A panel of experts led by Professor of BUET Jamilur Reza Chowdhury also advised the government and donors. There was no major problems during the construction of the bridge. The only problems the contractors said they faced was that they had to be very tough to maintain the work schedule. The other problem was the numerous cracks that had developed in the hinges of the bridge, which were mended by injecting Epoxy Resin into the cracks so that water did not harm the iron rod of the bridge. The other problem was the presence of solid rock at the bottom of the river which gave the contractors a lot of trouble during the piling work. Project source said that all the work would be completed by June 20 and the bridge will be opened for a marathon race by freedom fighters prior to its formal opening. Meanwhile, a 20-member national committee headed by the Secretary of the Jamuna Bridge Authority, Abdul Muyeed Chowdhury has been formed to supervise the gala opening ceremony. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina will inaugurate the bridge. It is learnt the opposition leader General Ershad, will also be present at the function. There will be two meeting places during the inaugural ceremony at the two ends of the bridge. Sheikh Hasina will travel through the bridge by road from the Kalihati side and return from Sayedabad by train. The train service may not be commissioned before the construction of railway line upto Joydevpur. However the construction of railway line upto Joydevpur has been taken up.

------ KINSHASA, Congo (AP) _ Congo's President Laurent Kabila accused unnamed military officers of illegally smuggling gold, diamonds and rare wood from Congo's northeastern forests. Speaking to journalists on Sunday, Kabila promised that anyone caught unlawfully buying or selling the country's resources will be severely punished. ``Nobody is above the law,'' the president said. ``The era of institutionalized theft is over.'' Kabila made the statement several weeks after his minister of economy and petrol, Victor Mpoy, accused Ugandan government officials of illegally trafficking in Congo's natural resources. The accusations prompted cooler relations between Congo and Uganda, which strongly backed Kabila in his rebellion to oust the late dictator Mobutu Sese Seko. More than three decades of corrupt rule by Mobutu has left the economy in this central African country in a state of decay. ------ PRETORIA, South Africa (AP) _ Former Civil Co-Operation Bureau agent Ferdi Barnard was on Monday convicted of murdering anti-apartheid activist David Webster and attempting to murder Justice Minister Dullah Omar. Barnard worked for the now-defunct Civil Cooperation Bureau, an apartheid-era government unit that attacked anti-apartheid groups. Barnard was convicted in Pretoria High Court on 25 charges, including two murder charges, two of attempted murder and illegal possession of weapons and ammunition. He was acquitted on a further nine charges, including two attempted murder charges, because of a lack of evidence. Barnard would be returning to Pretoria maximum prison, where he was already serving a 10-year sentence. In court, Barnard for the first time admitted that he knew all along that the purpose for his monitoring Omar was to have him killed. College professor Webster was shot to death outside his Johannesburg house in 1989. In February, Barnard was sentenced to 10 years for the armed robbery of diamonds worth 10 million rand (dlrs 2 million). ----- NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) _ Three police officers were fired for fleeing when raiders broke into the jail they were guarding and freed 42 prisoners, a newspaper reported Monday. They were fired for cowardice, negligence and abandoning firearms while on duty, the Daily Nation reported, quoting unnamed sources. At least 30 armed men, some of them in camouflage uniforms, attacked Changamwe police station, near the Indian Ocean port of Mombasa, at dawn May 25. They stole three guns and killed a watchman at a shop next door. One of the stolen guns was recovered at Kaya Tsoba forest along with 22 rounds of ammunition during an ambush on Saturday evening, police said. No arrests were made. Last August, raiders struck Likoni police station just south of Mombasa, killing six policemen and making off with dozens of guns and thousands of rounds of ammunition at the beginning of a wave of attacks that claimed at least 88 lives and displaced 200,000 people. Opposition, human rights and religious leaders said the attacks were instigated by people close to President Daniel Arap Moi and targeted people on the Indian Ocean coast who came from other parts of the country known to support opponents of Moi. The attacks ended before the general election in December, but tension has remained high in areas where the raiders took cover, especially in caves in the forests around Mombasa. ------ ZANZIBAR, Tanzania (AP) _ Zanzibar's first international film festival will take place July 11-18 and will feature films made in Africa, Iran, India, Pakistan, the Gulf States and the island communities of the Indian Ocean. Yusouf Mohammed, a British volunteer working on the festival, says films will be shown in Zanzibar's famous Stone Town in the refurbished Old Fort, the House of Wonders, the Palace Museum and Victoria Garden. Organizers are also planning to set up a mobile screening unit to take the films to 26 villages on the islands of Zanzibar and Pemba so the estimated 300,000 Zanzibaris can also see the films. The embassies of France, Switzerland, Poland, Oman, India, Spain, Egypt and South Africa have volunteered financial support for the festival, whose cost organizers estimate at dlrs 200,000. ------ MASERU, Lesotho (AP) _ Seven workers of the Lesotho National Development Corporation died in a crash in the northern Leribe district when they were returning from a funeral, officials said Monday. A spokesman for the LNDC on Monday said six of the victims died instantly in the weekend crash and the seventh perished in a hospital. Two of six survivors are reported to be in critical condition. The accident happened in the Relebe district when the minibus in which they were travelling overturned and collided with another vehicle after a tire burst. ------ PRETORIA, South Africa (AP) _ South Africa on Monday announced a travel ban on members of the former Angolan rebel movement UNITA. Senior UNITA officials and their adult family members would be refused admission of transit through the country, Home Affairs Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi said in a statement. The sanctions were imposed in a United Nations resolution against UNITA for failing to finish complying with a 1994 peace accord. In compliance with the U.N. sanctions, South Africa would also refuse all applications by UNITA members or their families for visas, immigration permits or the extension of temporary residence permits. ------ MAPUTO, Mozambique (AP) _ The government says the country's inflation rate is dropping. The deputy minister of planning and finance, Luisa Diogo, put the inflation rate from January to April at 1.4 per cent, compared to 5.7 per cent in the same period of 1997. In 1997, Mozambique achieved a one-digit inflation for the first time since the introduction of a World Bank - International Monetary Fund-supervized adjustment program more than 10 years ago. Inflation was 54 percent in 1995, 16.3 percent in 1996 and 5.8 per cent in 1997. (aos)

HELSINKI, Finland (AP) _ Russian-Latvian relations can be restored to normal if the Baltic state adopts measures to improve the status of minorities, Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov said Monday. ``Our aim is not to break the camel's back and especially not the back of a state,'' Primakov told reporters. ``But the ball is in Latvia's court.'' Angered by alleged discriminations against Latvia's 700,000 Russian speakers, Moscow in April threatened sanctions against the Baltic state of 2.6 million. Finnish Foreign Minister Tarja Halonen urged Latvia to adopt measures proposed by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe for the treatment of minorities. ``Finland hopes Latvia, with the help of an efficient program, will further the integration of her Russian speaking population,'' she said. Halonen said that Latvia's possible future membership in the European Union would ``constitute the best and strongest guarantee for the future and position of the Russian speaking population.'' But, she added, that Finland ``as a member of a small language area, supports the strengthening of the position of the Latvian language.'' At the end of his three-day visit to Helsinki on Monday, Primakov flew to Switzerland. Earlier, he met with President Martti Ahtisaari and Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen. (mhh/ls)

Two Singapore conglomerates plan merger
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Hoping to capitalize on the bigger-is-better approach, government-linked conglomerates Singapore Technologies Industrial Corp. and Sembawang Corp. said Monday they would merge in order to compete more profitably in Asia. The new group, which will be named SembCorp Industries, will focus on infrastructure projects, marine engineering, information technology ventures and the leisure industry. The two conglomerates said the merger will create a company with the resources and financial strength to compete for larger projects in the increasingly competitive markets in Asia. It will have a market capitalization of 2.01 billion Singapore dollars (dlrs 1.19 billion), making it the 22nd largest company on the Stock Exchange of Singapore. The move must get shareholder, government and stock exchange approval before it can proceed. ``Individually, while both companies are profitable, there is a limit to their growth potential given their current size,'' said Wong Kok Siew, chairman of STIC and deputy chairman of Sembawang. ``In deciding to merge, both companies have significantly increased their chances of becoming a leading Asian corporate sooner rather than later.'' While the move was generally seen as positive, analysts said investors will withhold their support until they see what concrete steps the new group will take. ``If the management delivers what they say they will deliver, it will be good for the new company on a longer-term basis,'' said Ang Lay Pheng, head of research at Goldman Sachs Securities. ``The proof is in the pudding.'' Trading in shares in Singapore Technologies Industrial Corp. and Sembawang Corp. was suspended on the Stock Exchange of Singapore Monday pending the announcement. STIC closed Friday at 1.66 Singapore dollars (98 cents) a share, and Sembawang at 3.08 Singapore dollars (dlrs 1.82). Under the merger plan, 1,000 shares of STIC would be exchanged for 1,475.6 shares in the new group, and 1,000 Sembawang shares would be exchanged for 2,543.1 SembCorp Industries shares.

THE Digital Signature Act 1997 will come into immediate effect once the Government establishes the framework in two months' time. The Act, which is one of the six cyberlaws designed to facilitate electronic commerce (e-commerce), will enable businesses and the community to use electronic signatures instead of their handwritten counterparts in legal and business transactions. According to Energy, Telecommunications and Posts Minister Datuk Leo Moggie, the framework will define the various details to regulate the digital signature certification authorities (CAs). ``These include items like the level of expertise an organisation needs to have in the field of digital signatures before being registered as a licensed CA,'' he said. Moggie said towards that end, the Government has identified a transitional controller of digital signatures who will primarily license the CAs and monitor the activities of these authorities. ``There are things that need to be clearly spelt out so that people who think they have the expertise to be registered as CAs have to satisfy all the requirements. As it is a new thing, we need to be cautious. We will look at examples of how digital signatures function, especially in the United States and Europe, when drawing up the regulations,'' the Minister added. On when the transitional controller will be replaced by a permanent body, Moggie said it will depend on how the movement of the Multimedia Convergence issue materialises. ``This will be guided by the proposed Multimedia Convergence Act. It will be part and parcel of the function of the commission we are planning to have. Pending that, we need to have something else in place,'' he said. The Digital Signature Act defines digital signature as a transformation of a message using an asymmetric crypto system. Under such a system, only the combination between a person's initial message and the public key belonging to the person who signs can accurately decrypt the system. The CAs appointed to monitor and supervise the use of digital signatures must be licensed under the law. Those convicted of operating or submitting a certification authority without valid licences are liable to a fine of up to RM500,000 or 10 years jail, or both. In the case of a continuing offence, offenders are liable to a daily fine not exceeding RM5,000 for each day the offence continues. Moggie also mentioned that the Government is also in the process of drafting the Data Protection Bill which is targeted to be tabled in Parliament by the end of this year. The Act, when introduced later, is expected to give a boost to electronic transactions as it will ensure that all data including those of a personal nature are fully protected. Moggie said the right to privacy must be protected and the appropriate legal protection must be accorded to individuals. ``Legal provision will make it very difficult for other people to attempt to have access to personal data on the network knowing that there are penalties for the offence,'' he said. ``However, we're still not yet ready with what would need to be fully covered by the Act and also the deterrent level that needs to be imposed. We are still trying to draft and think through this and have it finalised by year-end in time for the Parliament session,'' he added. Moggie had earlier witnessed the signing of an agreement between Silicon Navigator Sdn Bhd and Internet Security Systems Inc (ISS) for the master distributorship and sequentially launched the latter's Internet security products and solutions locally. Under the agreement, Silicon Navigator will distribute ISS products and provide security consultancy services for Malaysia, Indonesia and Brunei. Silicon Navigator will tackle the local market through its value-added resellers, Extol Corp Sdn Bhd and Comwise Internetwork Sdn Bhd. ISS Southeast Asia's channel manager of the company's Asia Pacific division Raymond Cushman expressed interest in the Multimedia Super Corridor (MSC) project. ``We will investigate in the area of gaining MSC status,'' he said, after representing ISS at the signing ceremony. Silicon Navigator meanwhile was represented by its chief executive officer Kho Han Mien.

Reformist triumphs in Montenegro poll conducted,'' although media still biased.
Eds: AMs. Recasts and UPDATES, with OSCE saying election ''well AP Photos By ALISON SMALE Associated Press Writer
PODGORICA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ In a major electoral triumph, Montenegro's reformist president threw down a challenge to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic Monday that could dent or ultimately undo the strongman's rule. In true Balkan style, supporters of President Milo Djukanovic fired guns, waved flags and honked car horns as they showed their joy at an unexpectedly decisive win over Milosevic protege Momir Bulatovic in Sunday's parliamentary elections, With 94.2 percent of the vote counted for the 78-seat Montenegrin parliament, Djukanovic's coalition ''For a Better Life'' had secured 49.5 percent of ballots cast, the State Election Commission said. Bulatovic's Socialist People's Party had 36.07 percent, the Commission added. A jubilant Djukanovic, 36, told cheering supporters he hoped to build on the triumph and use it to spread democracy throughout Yugoslavia, which now consists of just Serbia and Montenegro. ``Montenegro has again shown that it has the wisdom, courage and resolve to resist those who decided to enslave Montenegro,'' he said. Although this mountainous republic has just 630,000 residents, it supplies the same number of deputies to the federal Yugoslav parliament as Serbia, with 10 million inhabitants. Djukanovic and his aides are determined to stack Montenegro's bloc with their supporters, and hope to team up with Serbian opposition deputies to vote Milosevic out. No political analyst in Yugoslavia can imagine Milosevic going quietly. Since rising to power in Serbia in 1987, the wily strongman has used a powerfully effective mix of nationalism, tight media control and autocratic methods to cement his hold on power. But Djukanovic and unrest in the Serbian province of Kosovo recently have weakened his grip. In Kosovo, ethnic Albanians fighting for independence appear to be gaining ground in ever more deadly battles with Serbian police. Djukanovic first threw down the gauntlet in the winter of 1996-7, coming out against Milosevic during massive protests against his rule. Last fall, the Montenegrin then narrowly beat Bulatovic _ his former best friend _ for the republic's presidency. Strongly backed by Washington and western Europe, Djukanovic took office last January. The strength of his triumph in Sunday's elections could hand him a majority in the 78-seat Montenegrin parliament. Besides Djukanovic's and Bulatovic's parties, only one other party _ the Montenegrin separatist Liberal Alliance _ passed the 3 percent vote threshold needed to get seats. Djukanovic aides suggested Monday that they would insist on Bulatovic being replaced as federal premier. Milosevic maneuvered his protege into that office two weeks ago after the previous premier refused to crack down on Djukanovic's pro-Western reforms. The big unknown Monday was Milosevic's reaction. Typically in such situations, he bides his time, allowing media or political aides to speak for him before acting. The state news agency Tanjug said that Bulatovic's party had accepted Sunday's results. Some 120 election monitors dispatched by the 54-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation concluded Sunday's ballot ``was generally well conducted,'' an OSCE statement said. ''I'm giving these elections a clean bill of health,'' said Javier Ruperez of Spain, heading the monitoring team. The statement urged all political parties to overcome the bitter divisions of the election campaign and ``work now at establishing a climate of dialogue and confidence.'' Media control has proven critical for all ruling parties since the old Yugoslavia, of six republics, began its bloody break-up in 1991. OSCE said Montenegrin state media were biased toward Djukanovic. But the transatlantic organization was even more critical of Serbian state media for its vicious attacks on the Montenegrin president during the campaign. (as/ds/gj)

Japan's governing coalition breaks up after four year alliance
Eds: UPDATES with quote from Hashimoto in 5th graf; EDITS to trim AP Photo TOK101 By CHESTER DAWSON Associated Press Writer
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's governing coalition officially broke up Monday ahead of parliamentary elections this summer, bringing an end to a four-year alliance between formerly bitter rivals. In a widely expected move, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto accepted the decision of the Social Democratic Party and New Party Sakigake to withdraw from the government. Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party has already assumed all Cabinet posts and enjoys a majority in the more powerful of Japan's two legislative chambers, so the coalition's demise was seen as unlikely to have much impact on the government. It ended an oddball marriage between the conservative Liberal Democratic Party and left-leaning Social Democrats, formerly Japan's socialist party. Previous to linking up in 1996, the two parties had been political enemies for most of the post-World War II era. ``I value our shared history of having been able to work together,'' Hashimoto told reporters after meeting with heads of the two former partner parties. Social Democrat head Takako Doi said her party decided to end its alliance with the LDP over disagreements with Hashimoto's party on key issues such as proposals for more stringent legislation on political ethics and the strengthening of U.S.-Japan defense ties. Masayoshi Takemura, chairman of New Party Sakigake, said ``Over the past year, the coalition was mainly driven at the LDP's pace and that left it in bad shape.'' The withdrawal was viewed by many as a tactical move before elections slated for sometime in July. Half of the seats in the upper house of parliament will be up for grabs. The pro-business Liberal Democratic Party has 261 seats in the powerful 500-member lower house. With 118 seats in the less powerful upper house, it still needs support from the 21-member Social Democratic Party and three-member Sakigake to gain a majority in the 252-member body. The Social Democrats and Sakigake party were expected to continue to vote with the LDP on a case-by-case basis. The Social Democrats have pledged to support Hashimoto's administration if opposition parties submit a no-confidence vote against the government. Hashimoto has indicated he will seek cooperation from the two parties on some issues. Still, he may need to court additional support from independent lawmakers and non-aligned parties such as a lay Buddhist political group which once had close ties to the LDP. In June of 1996, the LDP joined hands with the Social Democrats in an ``unholy alliance,'' producing Japan's first socialist prime minister in 46 years. While the two parties had long been rivals, they buried their enmity in a bid to keep from power a reformist coalition made up of political renegades from both parties. The LDP fell from power by this reformist coalition in July of 1993 after four decades as Japan's sole ruling party.

I AM saddened by C.L. Goh's advice to teachers not to ask presents from pupils and not to punish them or treat them differently when they cannot bring a gift on Teachers' Day (NST, May 26). Teachers do not need such advice which diminishes their dignity, least of all on an occasion society has set aside to acknowledge their special role and contribution. In spite of relatively low remuneration, lack of opportunities for advancement, the difficult circumstances brought about by the rapidly changing curricula, a new generation of students and parents who do not seem to have much regard for the teaching profession and the many frustrations within the education system itself, teachers valiantly struggle on. Teachers' Day brings a little consolation and encouragement. Goh's account of a colleague's dilemma reveals a typical lack of understanding of what is really going on in schools and the problems faced by teachers and headmasters. Although I do not know which school the particular child is in, I can understand how a problem such as the bunga hidup could have come about. Teachers and headmasters are faced with the problem of pupils trying to out-do each other in bringing presents for their teachers on Teachers' Day. To avoid the situation where the rich ones bring embarrassingly expensive gifts and the poorer ones try to buy presents they cannot afford, and situations where some form teachers are heaped with presents and the non-form teachers, though not less dedicated are neglected, some schools have standardised the gifts to a meaningful and relatively inexpensive bunga hidup (which can even come from the child's own garden) or perhaps to a simple card made by the child. An additional little note of appreciation from the parent would have also gone a long way to impart some needed joy to the teacher's heart. Teachers are not asking for presents, they are asking for understanding and trust. The source of the child's distress may have nothing to do with the fear of punishment or rejection by teachers but from the disapproval of his peers. Nonetheless, parents need to appreciate that teachers and schools have a tremendous impact on the shaping of the mind, character and values of their children. Russian markets lower despite U.S. support
Eds: UPDATES throughout with Fyodorov saying no ruble devaluation needed, but additional IMF funds would be welcome. TRIMS pvs. By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ The government has enough cash reserves to protect the ruble against devaluation, but additional help from the International Monetary Fund would help calm jittery investors, Russia's new tax chief said Monday. Boris Fyodorov, who was appointed by President Boris Yeltsin on Friday, said another dlrs 5 billion would be enough to reassure investors shaken by last week's wave of panic selling that caused the stock market to plummet. Despite U.S. promises to support new loans by international lenders, Russian markets sank further in early trading Monday. In a brief statement issued Sunday, President Bill Clinton expressed U.S. support for aid to Russia from such multinational institutions as the World Bank and the IMF. Nonetheless, by midday the stock market was down an additional 4.5 percent, although traders said there was little panic selling. ``We are seeing a manageable fall,'' said Robert Devane, head of fixed-income trading at Moscow's Troika-Dialog brokerage. ``We are not yet at a critical point like last week.'' Altogether the stock market is down 40 percent since April. The Central Bank has intervened to prop up the ruble and tripled a key interest rates to 150 percent to persuade investors to stay in Russia. The ruble was slightly weaker in trading early Monday. In a move to ease the crisis, IMF officials said Friday that they will recommend releasing a delayed payment of dlrs 700 million, the latest installment of an existing dlrs 10 billion loan. Before the crisis, Russia's economic prospects had been looking somewhat brighter, with the government having kept a lid on inflation and recording its first economic growth since the 1991 Soviet collapse. But the government has been unable to solve a years-long payments crisis, caused by its inability to collect taxes and therefore to pay wages to state workers. Many workers and pensioners have been unpaid for months. Fyodorov said in an earlier television interview that the country's 35 percent tax rate must be lowered but enforcement strengthened. ``The rate should be 20 percent, but then those who do not pay must in effect be put into prison,'' he told the NTV network. Russian leaders have said that the economic crisis was triggered by a combination of forces, including a sharp fall in world prices for gas and oil, the financial crisis in southeast Asia, and social unrest including a recent wave of coal miners' strikes. LONDON (AP) _ Brilliant West Indian batsman Brian Lara was fined 2,000 pounds (dlrs 3,260) by Warwickshire county cricket officials Monday for arriving too late to play a crucial league match on Sunday. The Warwickshire captain missed his team's four-wicket loss to Somerset at Taunton, blaming flight delays for his late return from a business trip to Trinidad. Lara arrived 20 minutes before the scheduled start of play but concerned officials had already replaced him in the starting 11 because of uncertainty over his whereabouts. Lara was summoned to appear before a disciplinary hearing at Edgbaston Monday, where he was ordered to pay the fine, a small proportion of the estimated 60,000 pounds (dlrs 98,000) he will earn playing for Warwickshire this season. Disciplinary committee spokesman Dennis Amiss said he heard a full account from Lara about his problems and accepted there were mitigating circumstances. Amiss also said Lara apologized to the committee and players. It is the second time this season that Lara has been delayed in the West Indies after missing his flight back to England.

BC-Russia-KGB Returns?
Yeltsin moves to strengthen government _ with help of former KGB agents
By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ When Boris Yeltsin was fighting communism, the KGB dogged his every step. But now that he wants to bring some order to his unruly government, he's turning to his former enemies for help. In the past week, Yeltsin has appointed three former spies to key jobs in his administration dealing with Russia's far-flung regions, where the Kremlin has suffered several recent setbacks. Yeltsin has not commented publicly on the appointments. But critics say the former KGB agents, trained in the repressive Soviet system, abhor civilian control over government and are generally anti-democratic and opposed to reforms. ``They seem to be out of their mind at the Kremlin,'' says Yevgenia Albats, a prominent Russian commentator who has followed the KGB and its successors' activities since Soviet times. First, Yeltsin appointed Vladimir Putin, 45, a former KGB intelligence officer posted to Germany during the 1970s, as his first deputy chief of staff in charge of relations with Russia's regions. Then he named Gen. Viktor Zorin, former deputy chief of the Federal Security Service _ the KGB's main successor agency _ head of the darkly named Department for Special Programs. Little is known about the department, although it is believed to be involved in regional issues. On Monday, Gen. Nikolai Patrushev, 46, another high-ranking Federal Security Service official, was appointed head of the presidential Main Control Directorate _ the department controlling how regional officials spend money from Moscow. Analyst Andrei Ryabov of the Carnegie Endowment for Peace said the appointments were made to tighten Yeltsin's control over the recently disobedient regions. Regional officials have been blamed for misspending the federal funds allocated to the regions _ thereby contributing to the chronic problem of unpaid wages and pensions that touched off recent strikes and protests. Despite strong opposition from the Kremlin, voters in the rich Krasnoyarsk region of Siberia last month elected as their governor Alexander Lebed, a former general and national security chief with presidential ambitions. In another embarrassment, a convicted embezzler was elected mayor in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia's third largest city. Election officials invalidated his victory after Yeltsin expressed concern about the balloting results. Ryabov, who studies Russia's domestic policy, said Yeltsin may also be trying to recruit officials with no ties to any of the powerful business clans vying for control over government. ``Yeltsin has obviously sought to find a counterbalance to the growing pressure of the powerful financial groups,'' he said in an interview. Ryabov cautioned against interpreting the appointments as a sign of growing clout for the former KGB, saying today's security officers are politically neutral bureaucrats. Albats, the journalist, disagreed, saying disdain for Yeltsin's free market reforms is widespread among the former KGB, and their loyalties doubtful. ``It's not that they are all bad guys, but they have been brought up in the system based on violence and lawlessness,'' Albats said. ``KGB people generally got a very good training, but their skills were intended for another system and hardly suitable for the democratic environment.'' The KGB was disbanded in 1991 shortly before the Soviet collapse and divided into several successor agencies. Many former spies have found their way into Russia's banking and business sector, while others entered politics. (vi/ls)

Polio is essentially a disease of infancy and childhood; the most vulnerable age is between six months to three years. There is no specific treatment for polio. Good nursing can minimise or even prevent crippling. Immunisation with oral drops of polio vaccine (OPV) is the sole effective means of preventing polio. Developed countries have used polio vaccine extensively since 1954 and have virtually eliminated the disease, but in developing countries polio still paralyses over 100,000 children each year. The environmental sources of infection are contaminated water, food and flies, with overcrowding and poor sanitation providing good opportunities for exposure to infection. All these are abundantly present in the slums of Dhaka City. Bangladesh has an Expanded Programme on Immunisation (EPI) through which polio vaccine is given to children aged under 5 years. Along with routine EPI, the government arranges the National Immunisation Day (NID) and immunises children aged 0-5 years against polio. The NIDs act as a boost factor in the strategy to eradicate polio from Bangladesh by the year 2000. A BRAC research team observed the latest NID on January 18, 1998 in TB Gate Jhil Par, Agar Khan Plot, Taltola, and Karail slums of Mohakhali area in Dhaka City. The knowledge and perception of the mothers and the matobbars (headmen, leaders) about polio and EPI were sketchy at best. The matobbars gave more accurate answers than the mothers but it was not markedly better. Few mothers could say why NID was held, where, or for what reason. Most slum-dwellers did not know children of what age or which childhood disease were the targets of the NID. The mothers said that polio vaccine was given in oral drops three times, but it was all right to give more drops. One mother said, ``If we get it free then we will give it to our children for as many times as possible.'' She had vaccinated her eldest child but did not remember the process or what it had included. She had heard that it might be good for children and thus sent her child to be vaccinated with a neighbour who knew more about these things. The only evidence of that vaccination was the BCG vaccination mark on the child. The Dhaka City Corporation organised the NIDs in urban Dhaka including the slums and it was assisted by non-governmental organisations (NGOs), and private voluntary organisations and individuals. The slum community was mobilised 1-3 days before the NID. Some mothers found out about the January 18 NID the previous day from messages broadcast from loudspeakers, some from broadcasts on radio and TV, but most heard about it from neighbours. Even the children had not heard anything. The mothers and matobbars said, ``We don't know whether miking was done because most of the time we are not home as we go to work. No one come to give us slips or registered our children.''Some interviewees said they had heard about the previous NID of December 1997 mainly from the public announcements made through loudspeakers in the vicinity of their slums. If the slum-dwellers thought their children should be taken to a vaccination centre then they usually mentioned the name of the centre held in the previous NID in December 1997, or they asked us where their children should be taken. Those living in Taltola Sweeper Colony slum said that they were going to take their children to the vaccination centre in the park the next day. The knowledge and perception about polio were not markedly improved after the NID session probably because other than giving oral drops to the children little exchange of information occurred. Although, after the NID all mothers interviewed correctly said that their children were vaccinated against polio, and that children over age 5 and fully immunised children should not receive this vaccine. But the slum mothers also added that the oral drops will protect their children from becoming crippled and blind and also from fever, small diseases, hand polio, cough and measles, and eradicate polio from Bangladesh. Most mothers walked to the centre and it took them 5-15 minutes to reach the vaccination spot, and they waited for 5 to 15 minutes for the children to be vaccinated. They did not face any difficulties in coming to the centre. The slum mothers opined that it was easier for them if immunisation was given directly in the slums. The knowledge and perception of the vaccinators varied. The vaccinators were NGO health educators, housewives, social workers, and school boys from the slums. The NGO health workers were more knowledgeable and they complained that they had not received ample registers, vaccination slips, posters or table cloths, but the social worker-housewives gave better service in terms of the number of oral drops given than the regular health educators. The NID Sessions The BRAC research team observed two NID vaccination centres in Karail and Taltola. Both the NID centres started after 10 am and closed by 2 pm. Although on our way to Taltola we saw one NID at 8:30 am already functioning. In Karail there were two vaccination centres near the central playground, one static arranged by an NGO called Unity Through Population Service, and another mobile centre arranged by university students belonging to the Rotary Club. The mobile team did not use an ice-pack and had the vials in an open bowl. In Taltola Sweeper Colony slum, the NID centre was arranged jointly by Rotary Club and Innerwheel Club. In Karail, vaccination centre was held in the club room of a certain political party, and it was made of tin roof, bamboo wall and mud floor. In Taltola the vaccination centre was a pandel set up by decorators hired by the organisers. Inside the pandal there were table, table cloth, several chairs, and a loudspeaker with recorder for announcements and songs about polio vaccination. The pandal was located in front of the park and next to a local bazaar and was quite dusty. In Taltola, a 15-year-old young girl had died one month after giving birth. Her dead body was kept near the pandal in which the vaccination centre was held. Until her Janaja prayer was held and her body taken away for burial no miking was done. But after that miking was constantly done till the end of the vaccination session. The vaccination centres displayed banners and posters with slogans such as, 'give your child OPV vaccination', Build a polio-free Bangladesh', the Moni' logo, and the names of the respective organisations. Vaccination was not given in an orderly manner with the parents and children standing in lines, but it was less chaotic in Taltola. The waiting area for the parents were not protected against the sun or rain, but there was space for some parents to wait inside the club room and the pandal. No supervisors came to the centre in Karail; but the current and ex-presidents of Innerwheel Club acted as a supervisor for the vaccination session and at the end of the session the national and international presidents of Rotary Club came to see how the session had done in Taltola. The vaccination sessions immunised 1,046 children under the age of five. There was no shortage of vaccines in the vaccination centres. Vaccine was kept in a vaccine carrier with ice pack. The vaccine vial was put on the ice pack in between the vaccine sessions in Karail but not in Taltola. The children were given 2-6 drops of OPV. Some children were given the oral drops at the back of the tongue. Registers were not maintained for the target children. According to the NGO health workers, in the 1995 NID parents were given slips and mothers came to vaccination centres with the slips. But this took more time and manpower and created disorder so the slip system was discontinued. A 25-day-old baby was given 3 drops of OPV in Taltola. Maternal antibodies circulate in children for the first six months and that is why the first dose of DPT is given at six weeks in the regular EPI schedule. Only BCG vaccination can be given at birth. A couple of children spat out the oral drops but they were not given the oral drops again. One child looked familiar to the vaccinators and they asked how many times he had taken the vaccine that day. He replied happily, Twice.' In Karail 30 vials out of the 40 taken, and in Taltola 19 out of the 25 vials taken were used but in Taltola all the vials were opened. Slum dwellers (young men and school boys) helping in the vaccination centres were asked to help identify the children who had been missed and they brought those children to be immunised. But according to the slum dwellers children outside the immediate slums were not present, ``Their mothers work so they will probably come in the afternoon. They won't come now.'' In Karail the vaccinators told the slum women that they would give the oral drops till 2:30 pm at least. But at 1:45 pm a local young political leader came and showed his displeasure, ``Why are you holding a vaccination centre in our club room without prior permission? You cannot do this. You have to leave.'' The vaccinators protested and tried to make him understand that the centre was for the good of the slum children and free of cost, but this only made the leader angrier. During this conversation two mothers waited with their children and requested that their children be vaccinated too. The vaccinators were upset and got frightened and told the mothers that their children would not be vaccinated but in the last moment they hurriedly vaccinated the children and quickly left Karail. The day before the NID there was some conflict in Taltola also about vaccinating only the children attending a school which was set up with the help of slum leaders affiliated to a certain political party. But the social workers convinced the leaders that all slum children should be vaccinated. In Taltola a woman came with a child half an hour after the centre was closed because she was told that the vaccinators would stay till 2-3 pm. Interestingly, not only slum children but those of middle income and upper income groups also came to be vaccinated in the centres located in the slums, but their numbers were few. A shortcoming of the NID was that it did not adequately publicise its mission. NIDs could not immunise all the targeted children, and only half the children who came to the NID sessions were given the oral drops properly. Furthermore, the interference of local political leaders hampered the delivery of this service aimed at our future generation. Current observations indicate that NIDs will probably be socially sustainable but the question of their being financially sustainable remains unanswered. The government successfully motivated NGOs, private organizations and university students to organise and participate in the NID campaign. The organisations targeted 1,300 and vaccinated 1,040 children, more than two-thirds of their target. Half of the children were vaccinated properly. There was some improvement in the knowledge and perception of the parents about immunisable diseases like polio just from one session of NID which the regular EPI in the last two decades were not able to do. The 1,046 slum children immunised in the NID live very near the EPI headquarters in Mohakhali, yet they had remained non-immunised despite having access to good transportation and finances. The NID sessions immunised socio-economically well-off children along with slum children and this was a success since the routine EPI had missed both the privileged and underprivileged group of children.
