In todays' medical scenario, asthma is turning out to be one of the most serious health problems plaguing almost all countries, both developed and under developed. According to the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in the US, asthma affects approximately 15 million Americans, four million of whom are under 18. In fact, over the last decade, there has been a 91 per cent increase in asthma-related deaths in the US alone. On global basis, at least 50 million people worldwide suffer from asthma and allergies. Studies conducted in different cities of India about the prevalence of asthma are quite horrifying. Case studies in Bangalore in India among 15,556 children revealed that instances of asthma rose from 9 per cent in 1979 to 24.5 per cent (almost one out of every four children) in 1994. ``Among adults it is now known that every tenth Indian sufers from asthma'', says Dr. Rajesh Chawla, senior consultant at Apollo Hospital and President of the Delhi Chest Forum. In Jaipur, a study among 4,000 people showed that 15 per cent of children in the age group 5 to 11 had asthma. In Delhi, the figure is about the same. The statistics revealed in the case of India, our closest neighbour and with enviromnental and economic condition of people almost similar, put us pondering that situation in our country might appear to be not very much different from India. Statistics available from the premier hospital for chest diseases in Dhaka revealed that asthma-related diseases and allergic infections registered a sharp rise from its previous figure of 5 per cent in early 1990s to about 15 per cent in recent times. The number of patients is on the upswing. Asthma is a chronic disease in which airflow in and out of the lungs may be blocked by muscle squeezing, swelling and excess mucus. Symptoms vary from person to person, but usually include coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness or producing a lot of mucus. Physicians don't know the basic cause of asthma or why one person gets asthma and another doesn't. They do know that heredity plays some role, meaning asthma often runs in families, especially in families who have a lot of allergies. It is known that asthma is not caused by emotional factors such as a troubled parent-child relationship, although emotions may affect pre-existing asthma. Though there are no nationwide studies, doctors confirm that the number of patients is on the upswing for reasons like an enormous increase in air pollution, usage of common drugs like aspirin and pain killer and an increasing list of allergens. Anyone can get asthma but it is most likely to occur in children by age 5 and in adults in their 30s. Even older people can develop asthma: about 10 per cent of new asthma cases are diagnosed in people who are 65 years or older. Certain factors increase in people's chances of developing asthma. For example, if one of the victim's parents has the disease, he is more likely to get it. People having allergic syndrome are more likely to develop asthma other than the heredity factor. (As a matter of fact, research data have revealed that at least 80 per cent of children and 50 per cent adults with asthma have allergies). The factors that cause this allergic syndrome still elude physicians. Studies have shown that the job of immune system cells is to identify foreign substances (such as viruses and bacteria). Normally this response protects us from dangerous diseases. Anybody having allergies would have a super-sensitive immune system which reacts to harmless substances like plant pollen, dust mites, or animal dander, saliva of animals with fir or feathers, cockroaches and their waste, stinging insects such as bees, wasps, hornets and red ants, foods such as eggs, milk, nuts and sea food, ingredients found in dyes, cosmetics, perfumes and latex. These substances are called allergens. And our immune system's ``overreaction'' is what causes our allergy symptoms. What causes asthma other than these allergens is still not known to experts even. Says an expert, ``The exact cause still eludes us''. But what is clear is the mechanics of asthma - a Greek word that simply means ``breathing hard''. It begins when the body's immune system becomes so sensitized to an allergen, mainly through heavy exposure in childhood, that it starts treating it as a threat. When the allergen enters the body the renegade immune system triggers the release of proteins called IgE antibodies in response to the allergen. These antibodies surge through the blood stream fastening themselves to cells which react by pouring out inflammatory chemicals. Confined to the nose at first, this reaction only leads to a runny nose. But when it extends down to the lungs, the result becomes lethal. The bronchioles (small airways) fill up with mucus leading to laboured breathing. As more airways get choked, the attack becomes severe. Leaving aside the family history in which case either of the parents carrying the disease leaves the offspring more prone to attack at certain stages of life, in most cases the allergens trigger the attack. Topping the list of villains mentioned earlier, air pollution these days poses the menacing threat. Says Dr. H. Paramesh, a paediatric pulmonologist and the Principal Investigator of the Bangalore Study, ``The risk in asthma is directly proportional to the number of automobiles, density of population and industrial growth.'' Ozone, diesel fumes and suspended particles all act as irritants to the air passages. Other new factors include, as already mentioned, drugs like aspirin and Brufen (mostly pain killer). ``The indiscriminate use of these drugs very often triggers asthma'', says Dr. Prem Sobti, President of the Asthma, Bronchitis and Cancer Lung Foundation of India. Doctors caution that anyone having anyone of the following symptoms for the past 12 months should seek the advice of a doctor to ascertain if he is heading for asthma attack: ) If you have had a sudden severe episode or recurrent episodes of coughing, wheezing (high-pitched whistling sounds when breathing out) or shortness of breath. ) If you have had cold that go to the chest or take more than l 0 days to get over. ) If you have had coughing, wheezing or shortness of breath in certain places or when exposed to certain things (e.g. animals, tobacco smokes or perfumes). ) If you have had used any medications that helped you breathe better. Today an entire generation is learning to cope out with the ailment. Doctors these days advise asthmatic people to carefully select exercise activities such as walking, light jogging, leisure biking and hiking rather than strenuous outdoor running sports. Swimming is often recommended for asthmatics because of its many positive factors: a warm, humid atmosphere, year-round availability, and the body's horizontal position which may help mobilise mucus from the bottom of the lungs. In fact, some Olympic swimmers have severe asthma. Other activities recommended include sports that involve short bursts of energy, such as baseball, football, wrestling, short distance track and field events, golfing, and gymnastics. Cold weather events such as cross-country skiing and ice hockey or long distance non-stop activities like basketball, field hockey or soccer are not recommended as they are likely to aggravate airways. However, childhood asthma differs from adult asthma in that infants and small children may not show the usual signs of asthma. Instead, asthma in children may appear as rapid respiration, noisy breathing, retraction and chest congestion. Parents can help the doctors better in recognising if their children are suffering from asthma. Parents may notice that their child has less stamina during active play time than his or her peers, or the child may try to limit physical activities to prevent coughing or wheezing. More subtle signs of asthma, such as chest tightness, may be overlooked or the child does not have the capability to identify them as asthma. Recurrent or constant coughing spells may be the only common observable symptom of asthma in young children. Though majority of the children who get asthma grow out of it in their teens, doctors feel that may be reversing with a lot of them retaining it through adulthood. An asthma-trigger control plan is an important part of controlling asthma. Most asthmatics, with inhalers or a peak flow meter, the most recent device with a plastic contraption at close reach, swap information and moral support. A peak flow meter is a device that measures how well air moves out of your lungs. During an asthma episode, the airways of the lungs begin to narrow slowly. The peak flow meter can be used to find out if there is narrowing of the airway hours - even days before you have any symptoms of asthma. By taking medicine early (before symptoms), one may be able to stop the episode quickly and avoid a serious asthma attack. In an effort to avoid serious asthma attack, families have got rid of their pets, done away with carpets that attract dust and even shifted residence to less polluted suburbs. Fortunately, these days the drug and the devices arsenal to deal with asthma are quite effective and easy to use. Only a few years ago arduous breathing meant frequent puffs of an inhaler. Today doctors have shifted the pattern of medication giving drugs only on emergency situation and in most cases pattern of treatment has been more proactive relying more on prevention. Bronchodilators are given to the asthmatics having only a tight feeling after running a flight of stairs. But an asthmatic who wheezes regularly needs a stronger drug support.Today steroid inhalers have become first line of drugs against asthma and in an inhaler form have little side effects. CFC-free ``Azmacort'' introduced in the market in the last part of 1997 after a series of clinical studies done by Dr. Jacques Caldwell, Medical Director of the Halifax Clinical Research Centre in Daytona, Florida, and Dr. Paul Chervinsky, President of the New England Research Centre in Darmouth, Massachusetts relieved asthmatics quite profoundly. Bringing further relief to the patients, researchers at the 1998 American Lung Association and the American Thoracic Society International Conference announced on April 28 this year, the results of the Azmacort built-in-spacer inhaler system using PET (Positron emission tomography) imaging technology - a device designed to enhance drug delivery and minimise local side effects. The NIH (National Institute of Health) in the US has recommended spacer use with inhaled corticosteroids to improve inhalation technique and reduce local side effects. So says Edward F. Haponik, Clinical Director of the Section on Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine and Professor of Internal Medicine, Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, North Carolina in a recently released (April 28, 1998) study conducted on patients, ``By showing patients that a spacer helps to get more medication to the lungs, rather than the mouth or stomach, patients may have a better understanding of the role of the spacer''. He further adds, ``Triamcinolone acetonide manufactured by Rhone Poulenc Rorer, under the brand name Azmacort, is an anti-inflammatory medication for the preventive management of asthma and the only inhaled bronchial steroid clinically tested and approved with a built-in-spacer.'' Doctors have cautioned that the increase in asthma attacks these days is linked to the fact that after a while, once the patient is a little better, the inhaler is put aside without completing the prescribed course. ``There is a feeling among patients that inhalers are bad and become a life-long addiction'', says Dr. Deepak Sehgal, a senior consultant pediatrician, at the Escorts Hospital in Delhi. With preventive drugs most asthma patients can start an exercise regimen. Doctors these days emphasise that with drugs most patients can pretty well lead normal lives. But the only thing that stands in the way is that the cost of medication is still quite prohibitive and seems to be a burden on poor and middle class families.

ARE government pensioners entitled to free medical treatment and medication? On the one hand we read that ``All government pensioners are eligible for free medical treatment ...'' (NST, May 21) as stated by the Honorary Secretary of the Malacca branch of the Malaysian Government Pensioners Association. He even quoted General Orders Chapter F and the procedure whereby one can claim reimbursement. Now the Health Minister says that ``Pensioners appealing for the continuation of free medication at Government hospitals have been told to submit a memorandum'' (NST, May 27). If the free treatment is already enshrined in the General Orders, then why the memorandum? Does this mean that the benefits have been withdrawn and we have to wait for the outcome of the memorandum? This contradicts the statement made by the Director of Hospital Kuala Lumpur, Dr Lim Kuan Joo, who assured all patients under its care that medication prescribed by its doctors ``will be honoured and filled accordingly'' (NST, May 26). Then there is the question of getting a letter from a doctor (to apply for reimbursement) stating the reason why he could not get the treatment or medication. A recent case of a pensioner seemed to show that there is still no co-ordination among the various departments. When the pensioner asked the doctor at HKL for a letter, the doctor said that he had no authority to give one. So where do we stand? We are honoured that the Health Minister ``regards pensioners very highly'' and that they do not ``face undue difficulties in terms of medical and health care'' (NST, May 27). But the situation is still the same, and most of us are still having difficulties. This is not something we can wait. Old and sick people have no time to wait.

Russian markets lower despite U.S. support staff by one-third.
Eds: UPDATES with new 10th graf, Kiriyenko orders Cabinet to cut By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ The government has enough cash reserves to protect the ruble against devaluation, but additional help from the International Monetary Fund would help calm jittery investors, Russia's new tax chief said Monday. Boris Fyodorov, who was appointed by President Boris Yeltsin on Friday, said another dlrs 5 billion would be enough to reassure investors shaken by last week's wave of panic selling that caused the stock market to plummet. Despite U.S. promises to support new loans by international lenders, Russian markets sank further in early trading Monday. In a brief statement issued Sunday, President Bill Clinton expressed U.S. support for aid to Russia from such multinational institutions as the World Bank and the IMF. Nonetheless, by midday the stock market was down an additional 4.5 percent, although traders said there was little panic selling. ``We are seeing a manageable fall,'' said Robert Devane, head of fixed-income trading at Moscow's Troika-Dialog brokerage. ``We are not yet at a critical point like last week.'' Altogether the stock market is down 40 percent since April. The Central Bank has intervened to prop up the ruble and tripled a key interest rates to 150 percent to persuade investors to stay in Russia. The ruble was slightly weaker in trading early Monday. In a move to ease the crisis, IMF officials said Friday that they will recommend releasing a delayed payment of dlrs 700 million, the latest installment of an existing dlrs 10 billion loan. Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko, moving to cut government spending, Monday ordered a 30 percent reduction in Cabinet personnel, the ITAR-Tass news agency said. Cabinet staffing will be cut from 1,450 people to 1,015, the report said. Before the crisis, Russia's economic prospects had been looking somewhat brighter, with the government having kept a lid on inflation and recording its first economic growth since the 1991 Soviet collapse. But the government has been unable to solve a years-long payments crisis, caused by its inability to collect taxes and therefore to pay wages to state workers. Many workers and pensioners have been unpaid for months. Fyodorov said in an earlier television interview that the country's 35 percent tax rate must be lowered but enforcement strengthened. ``The rate should be 20 percent, but then those who do not pay must in effect be put into prison,'' he told the NTV network. Russian leaders have said that the economic crisis was triggered by a combination of forces, including a sharp fall in world prices for gas and oil, the financial crisis in southeast Asia, and social unrest including a recent wave of coal miners' strikes. RENEWED interest among potential homebuyers after the lifting of anti-speculation measures could help Hong Kong's financial and property stocks when they resume trading on Monday, following a lacklustre show last week, analysts said. However, they added, the market still expected an uncertain week after the government's announcement of seven emergency measures to help revive the economy. These are aimed at reversing the massive slump in consumer spending, which the government blames for the contraction in the first quarter. The decision to relax anti-speculation rules introduced in 1994 was an attempt to stabilise the property sector and boost the economy, analysts said. ``The measures in the short term will ease the credit crunch and will stimulate consumption,'' Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa said. On Friday, Hong Kong stocks rose for the first time in six days, led by property shares, on the expectation that the government would ease the measures it imposed several years ago designed to curb speculation in Hong Kong's booming real estate market. The Hang Seng Index (HSI) gained 56.62 points, or 0.6 per cent, to 8,934.56, led by Sun Hung Kai Properties and Henderson Land Development. The index had fallen about 678.04 points or 7.1 per cent in the days before the announcement. However, gains were expected to be short-lived as, just after the market closed on Friday, the government reported that first quarter gross domestic product contracted by 2 per cent. Some analysts expect the economy to shrink as much as 3 per cent for the year. ``The reversing of the 1994 anti-speculation package in an attempt to stabilise prices is a potential disaster,'' said Christopher Tinker, regional head of economics and debt research at ING Barings. ``By pursuing this line, the government is clearly backing down on its housing policy, to the detriment of the man in the street.'' But the HSI is expected to respond favourably to the measures that include an extension of the pre-sale period of uncompleted flats from the current 15 months to 20 months and limiting flat sales to companies to the last 15 per cent of each batch.

The UN Security Council has rebuked Pakistan for defying the world in conducting another underground nuclear test on Saturday, amid growing fears that an arms race with neighbouring India could escalate out of control.Japan called an emergency session of the 15-members body on Saturday to present a resolution it had drafted with Sweden and Costa Rica to keep pressure on the two south Asian rivals, which between them have conducted 11 underground nuclear explosions in the past month. President Bill Clinton and UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan also condemned Pakistan, adding their voices to an international chorus of criticism and of appeals to the two nations to calm the tension created by their nuclear tests. Pakistan, in a robust defence of its actions, said its tests had achieved strategic stability in the region and told its people to tighten their belts to counter expected cuts in foreign aid. Security Council President, Njuguna Mahugu, of Kenya told reporters often the closed-door session, that the 15 members ``deeply deplored'' Pakistan's latest test--carried out only hours after the council had criticised Islamabad, for its first set of five nuclear tests conducted on Thursday. India conducted five tests on May 11 and 13, its first since it detonated one bomb in 1974. 'The council also called on the government of Pakistan to issue a public declaration announcing a moratorium on future tests and experimentation on delivery systems,'' Mahugu said. India announced a moratorium on future tests after completing its recent test programme. The council made its comments to the media rather than issuing a formal statement that carries the weight of international policy. But it is considering a resolution threatening further unspecified measures against both India and Pakistan. ``The council expressed its increased concern at the risk of a nuclear arms race escalating in south Asia and urged India and Pakistan to accede to the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), that was negotiated two years ago, `` Mahugu added. Japan's draft resolution 'encourages'' nations to stop supplying India and Pakistan with equipment and technology that could be used to develop nuclear weapons. Annan, in a separate statement, called Pakistan's action ``a further dangerous and senseless escalation of tension which could lead' to a nuclear arms race with incalculable consequences.'' He appealed to the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan to demonstrate leadership and reduce tensions between them, and repeated his offer to help mediate on the disputed region of Kashmir. President Clinton condemned Pakistan's new nuclear test and said, India and Pakistan were contributing to a 'self-defeating cycle of escalation '' 'These tasts can only serve to increase tensions in an already volatile region,'' he said in a written statement, 'both India and Pakistan need to renounce further nuclear and missile testing immediately and take decisive steps to reverse this dangerous arms race,'' he added. Clinton also signed documents setting in motion economic sanctions he-imposed against Pakistan that put in jeopardy billions of dollars in loans from multilateral lending institution. Sanctions have also been imposed against India.Japan, Islamabad's biggest aid and trade partner, has recalled its ambassador to Islamabad in protest, frozen new yen loans and suspended most fresh united loans--as it did to India after the Indian tests. Australia has suspended non-humanitarian aid. But Russia, China and most west European states have not followed suit, which means the same countries would likely block any punitive action in the United Nations. Pakistani leaders remained defiant in the face of international criticism. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said that government expenses-would be halved as part of austerity drive to offset the likely impact of sanctions.

Merger may save S. Africa's NP from going way of the dodo, NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES xfdws MERGER-MAY-SAVE-S.AFRICA sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 01, 1998 NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
IS the once all-powerful National Party about to disappear from the political scene. Are those dinosaurs who formerly led the cruel racial tyranny of apartheid about to leave, finally, the green benches of Parliament? It seems - on the face of it - possible. The party which used to be a byword for organisation, for knocking on doors and getting the vote out at election time is now a shadow of its former self. A series of local by-elections has seen the once great party humiliated by the cheeky liberals of the Democratic Party. In the Cape, in KwaZulu Natal, in Gauteng - especially in Gauteng, the commercial and industrial heartland of the country, NP local councillors have been ousted in favour of Democrats. Rosettenville in the south of Johannesburg, once the rock solid constituency of the fragrant Sheila Camerer, former junior Justice Minister, swung impressively to the DP. Most of the seats snatched by the DP have been in historically white areas, but in a mainly black squatter seat on the edge of Cape Town, the NP lost to the ANC - as well it might -but its vote dropped from 22 per cent to two per cent. In addition there has been a steady stream - and a swelling one - of defections from the National Party to the Democratic Party. There have been a swathe of councillors defecting in the Eastern Cape, where the NP has got into serious bother with its Coloured members. Former ministers have been knocking at the door of the DP leader Tony Leon and converts to liberalism now include such as Rina Venter, former Health Minister, and Tertius Delport, former Minister for Constitutional Development. But two weeks ago came a major blow to the new leader of the NP, Marthinus van Schalkwyk. For the first time one of his sitting MPs has defected. He is a Coloured former headmaster from the Eastern Cape, and the importance of his defection is that he must immediately lose his parliamentary seat. The new Constitution contains a rigorous anti-defection clause. If an MP is elected on one party's ticket he loses his seat if he loses the ticket. It is a powerful device for keeping petulant MPs in line. And not many people in their middle years - as MPs mostly are - can afford to lose the comfortable salary that goes with the job. Reaction from NP stalwarts to the party's troubles has varied. The rock- ribbed nationalists say pooh! We've had worse times. Remember the 1980s, when the Conservative Party was defeating NP candidates around the country? We recovered. The more nervous say the time has come to consider merging the opposition parties. One senior man - a former minister and a provincial leader - confided that defecting at a time like this is like rearranging the deck-chairs on the Titanic. What is needed now is a thorough reorganisation and realignment. The urge to merge is very strong. The National Party has always had a distinctly off-putting attitude to merger. It has always meant an alliance on NP terms, with it as the umbrella under which lesser parties could shelter. It is already too late for that. But even on kinder conditions, the Democratic Party would not have much to gain from a merger. It would be nice to be enriched by some of the prime city centre properties currently owned by the NP. But the price to pay in an indiscriminate acquisition of Nationalists and their principles might be hard for delicate liberal sensibilities. And in any case the Democratic Party does not truly need to merge now. There is no advantage in an electoral pact for except in local councils all national and provincial assemblies are elected on a proportional list system. But Leon is happy to say that his door is always open. The latest opinion poll figures are not reassuring to the NP. In 1994 the party gained 20 per cent of the votes nationwide. In an opinion poll last November that figure was down to 12 per cent. But last month it fell again to 10 per cent. By contrast the Democratic Party got 1.73 per cent in the general election. The November opinion poll gave them three per cent. By last month they were on five per cent. Things are not looking all that brilliant for the ruling ANC though. Much fuss has been made over statements from party leaders that it is looking to gain a two-thirds majority in next year's elections. This would enable it to rewrite the country's Constitution. It failed narrowly to do so in 1994 when it won nearly 63 per cent. According to November's poll that figure dropped to 58 per cent. By last month it fell to 54 per cent. And cynics point out that if it carries on at this rate, it would fall short of the 50 per cent it needs to form a government on its own.

French President Jacques Chirac called on Israel on Saturday to leave both occupied south Lebanon and Syria's Golan Heights, saying it must understand it cannot have security without Middle East peace.''Israel must withdraw from Lebanon in accordance with (U.N.) Resolution 425 and without any conditions. Syria has the right to see the Golan Heights returned,'' he said from the steps of the French ambassador's residence in Beirut.''In return, Israel, like all other states in the region, has the right to full and complete security.''The French leader then diverted from the printed text: ``But Israel must understand that her people will not know security if there is no peace. ``His call for an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon triggered loud applause from the 4,000 invited guests, including Lebanese political, military and religious leaders.Chirac, on his third visit to Beirut in just over two years, has been trying to boost France's role in Middle East peace making, and proposed earlier this month that an international conference be convened to resurrect the U.S.-brokered peace talks.In Arab countries France is seen as more even-handed than the United States, which is Israel's key ally and has failed to press Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu into advancing the peace process.In south Lebanon, Israeli troops are locked in a war of attrition with pro-Iranian Hizbollah guerrillas. Israel, after heavy losses last year, has offered to leave south Lebanon on condition the Beirut government gives security guarantees against cross-border guerrilla attacks on northern Israel.Lebanon and Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, have rejected the proposal on the ground that the 20-year-old U.N. resolution 425 calls for an immediate and unconditional withdrawal.Damascus, after seeing Israel reach separate peace treaties with Egypt and Jordan, opposes negotiations with Lebanon that ignore its demand for return of the Golan Heights. Netanyahu has vowed to keep the plateau, which Israel captured in 1967 and which dominates nearby areas of both Israel and Syria.Chirac said Paris was prepared to help guarantee border security: ``France is prepared to participate with others, if the parties concerned make a request, to guarantee your borders.''''I believe that once the Israelis have retreated as part of a global peace, the Lebanese army, along with the internal security forces, should be the sole upholders of the authority of the state in all your territory,'' he added.Chirac earlier discussed Middle East developments with Lebanon's top leaders, President Elias Hrawi, Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri and Parliament Speaker Nabih Berri.The French leader's 43-hour visit to Beirut, which ends on Sunday, has been rich in symbolism of the French legacy and hopes for the future. THE unusually high number of unsuccessful university applications in spite of the applicants' good results has raised several questions regarding Unit Pusat Universiti's selection and administrative process. There is, undoubtedly, a strong case for an overhaul of the process. It should be thinking hard on the reasons which led to the dismal failure of the process when it appeared to be working effectively in the past. As such, its proposed post-mortem on the process is a welcome move. Arguably, the department must also deal with the contentious issue of whether there had been any extraneous element that can be attributed to the shambles. The scenario where a successful applicant is instructed to register at a private college, a franchise holder of a university's franchise programme, is disturbing. Imagine the shock of both parents and applicants to receive an envelope and letter, bearing the name of a public university, instructing them to enrol at a private college where the fees are far higher compared with the university. Granted, miscommunication could be a reason for the confusion that arose. We are not hurling wild accusations. Such cases also point to the possibility of a university picking up more than the number of students it can accommodate for its matriculation programme with the ultimate aim of re-routing the excess to various franchise-holder colleges. If it had not recruited beyond the number it could accommodate, the students would be picked up by the institutions of their second, third and fourth choices. But the practice of accepting beyond the number of available places is, in effect, depriving the students of the chance to be enlisted by the other universities. Neither can they gain admission into Institut Teknologi Mara since under the UPU rules, ITM is prohibited from accepting students who have been admitted into other universities and their franchise programmes. That there is an element of commercial interest - the five universities with franchise programmes will obtain a certain percentage for every enrolment in the programmes - lends a disturbing dimension to the scenario. If an attempt to force the students into the programmes had transpired, we can only describe the action as unconscionable. The public has the right to question the morality of such an action. A situation where universities act as recruitment agents for their franchise holders should be avoided. Lest the relationship between the universities and franchise holders be deemed as incestuous. Education Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak had told students allocated places in these franchise programmes not to worry about the high fees since Mara would provide sponsorship for most of them. But the good minister misses the point if he treats the issue as merely a question of funding. The franchise programme is an excellent idea since it allows people to pursue their education at a higher level. But universities should not behave or be seen to behave in a manner which suggests they may be tinkering with the admission process to profit from the franchise programmes. Accepting students but only to have them re-routed to franchise holders is unwarranted. Neither should the franchise holders have access to the list of applications meant for UPU and the universities for the admission process into the public tertiary institutions. UPU must ensure its process is not open to such abuse.

CHINA Development Corp says it will buy a leasehold property in Honolulu, Hawaii, at a cost of US$68 million (HK$526 million) from US firms SHC-Realty and MKS Executive Partners. The 577,124 square-foot property, the Executive Centre, is a leasehold condominium project. The project comprises 511 residential and office, penthouse, town house, and commercial units, as well as 864 parking spaces.

The Palestinian cabinet called on Saturday international sanctions to be slapped on Israel to punish it for its hard line in the deadlocked Middle East peace process. 'We ask that the international community take economic and political measures against Israel to penalise the arrogant policy of its government,'' the cabinet said in a statement after its weekly meeting. The statement was issued as Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat was holding talks with leaders of the United Arab Emirates as part of a diplomatic push to gain support for an Arab summit on the deadlocked peace talks. 'European, American and Arab efforts to revive the process have led nowhere because of the Israeli government's policy, which does not respect international resolutions and accords signed with the Palestinians.'' The statement also lambasted Israel for its continued settlement polices, particularly in annexed east Jerusalem, saying they would 'lead to an explosion.'' Israel's decision in March last year to start work on a large new Jewish settlement in east Jerusalem, which the Jewish state occupied and annexed in 1967, led to the current impasse in peace negotiations. In a bid to break the deadlock, Washington is pushing Israel to hand over another 13 per cent of the West Bank to Palestinian rule, in tandem with Palestinian measures against terrorism, but Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said a troop withdrawal of that size would threaten Israel's security. 'The Israeli government has shown its true face by refusing the proposals of the Untied States, which is much closer to (Israel's) stance than ours,'' the Palestinian cabinet said. Netanyahu returned to Israel on Friday after his visit to China, and is due to hold a cabinet meeting on Monday to re-examine the US proposals. And in a continuing Palestinian push to garner support for an Arab summit designed to pressure Israel, Arafat was in Abu Dhabi for talks with UAE President Sheikh Zayed Ibn Sultan Al-Nahayan. Their discussions will cover 'the possibility of holding an urgent Arab summit to scrutinise the stalled peace process and efforts to tighten Arab ranks,'' the official Wam news agency said. The UAE on Wednesday renewed its call for the 'urgent'' convening of such a summit to try to break the 14-month deadlock, while Arafat warned of an new outbreak of violence in the occupied territories over Israel's hardline stance. 'A summit has become a national necessity to protect the right and the interests of our Arab nation,'' he said. Palestinian leaders believe the coming week will be decisive for the success of the eight-month-old US drive to unblock the peace process, saying Washington knows it cannot ask for more time without serious resistance form the Arab side. 'The Untied States knows perfectly well that the Palestinians and Arabs will not agree to continue any longer with the current situation of uncertainty,'' Arafat's spokesman Nabil Abu Rudeina told agency. The Palestinians hope the US initiative will end with Israel accepting US proposals for a partial pullback form the West Bank or, if Israel continues to resist, that Washington will make its proposals public and explain why they have not worked.

THE shortage of potable water and the resulting need to ration has been attributed to nature and is thought to be a short-term problem. Once the weather turns around, it is argued, we will have plenty of rain in the catchment areas and households will once again have abundant supply to use as they please. In many cases there may be more than enough water and it is justified to waste the resource because it is free and a gift from God and no government has the right to charge more than a nominal fee for its use. Some countries that promoted this ideology now find themselves with inadequate supply because of increased salinisation and alkalisation of water. While raw water is free, treated water is not. Raw water is generally not fit for consumption because if it is, we will not have a water crisis. We have a crisis because we are short of treated water. While the supply of raw water is driven by nature, that of treated water is not necessarily so. Otherwise countries like the Maldives and Dubai, which have low levels of rainfall would be out of treated water. The first thing to do to get out of the crisis is to distinguish between raw and treated water. We can have adequate supply of treated water even in an environment where there is very little rainfall provided we are able to manage water resources efficiently. The crisis is not due to nature but to the ``command and control'' type of water management we have inherited from the colonial days. We would not be facing a shortage if we had an efficient system of capturing, storing, treating and distributing water. As it is about 40 per cent of treated water is lost because the distribution pipes are old or leaking. We may even have problems locating these pipes because of the absence of maps. If this ``lost'' water was distributed to households we may not have such a severe crisis. However, to repair or replace the pipes requires money and the present water charges may be inadequate to cover the costs. Just like the modernisation of our electricity and telephone industries and transport system, we need to invest in the water treatment and distribution system to insure against a recurrence of the crisis. There may be some protests about raising water rates considering the current economic situation, but if you ask people who have been without water for 17 days how much they are willing to pay for treated water, they will tell you ``quite a lot''. Maybe we should base rates on people's ``willingness to pay''. Some Malaysians have been paying as much as RM20 for a day's supply of treated water during the crisis while others have been giving the Waterworks Department only RM21 for two-month supply. This is definitely inequitable. It is obvious that those not affected by the crisis are deriving a surplus - i.e. the difference between what people are ``willing to pay'' and what they are ``actually paying''. Therefore, it is time to negotiate a new social contract between the Government and people to ensure predictable and reliable supply of treated water based on rates or prices that reflect the scarcity of the resource. The contract will have to be consistent with the sustainable development of water resources. To sustain the development of water resources there must be enough money. Some will argue that the Government can rely on taxes but as the crisis amply shows, tax revenues are insufficient to meet this need. To treat and distribute water involves several costs. These include the purchase of capital goods, labour, materials and also environmental costs. These are all opportunity costs because the same resources can be used to build schools, universities, hospitals and a host of other things that can enhance the standard of living. There is therefore a need to recover the costs of developing water resources through pricing. Otherwise there will not be enough funds to maintain, renew and expand facilities for an expanding population. To ensure an adequate and reliable supply of treated water, it may be necessary to have a self-financing water resources development policy rather than rely on dwindling tax revenue. Efficient allocation will equate the price of a unit of water with the extra cost incurred in producing it. In the economist's jargon, marginal cost must be equated with marginal revenue. If marginal revenue is less than marginal cost then the Government will have to subsidise water supply and we may run into problems again if tax revenues fall below expectations. However, in a caring society this type of economic calculation may not be acceptable. The poor may not be perceived as able to pay as much as is needed to ensure predictable supply of treated water. To safeguard their needs, a ``lifeline'' rate can be introduced. What can be done is to estimate the minimum consumption of a family of five or six - the ``lifeline'' requirement. A low rate, even a subsidised one can be charged for this minimum essential. However, consumption beyond the lifeline requirement may be heavily taxed on a steep tariff structure. This way those who waste treated water or use it for non-essential purposes are heavily penalised and made to subsidise the consumption of the poor. This tariff structure can be designed to recover all the costs of developing water resources and at the same time generate sufficient revenue to promote sustainable development. Such a tariff structure will also provide incentives to conserve because it will become more and more expensive to waste treated water. Thus, there may not be a need to build more dams, reservoirs and treatment plants. This will not only preserve the environment from depletion and degradation but also save the taxpayers' money. Maybe it is time to think of treated water as a scarce commodity having attributes that are desired and valued and that are necessary to develop a healthy population. It is also time to discard the old view that treated water is free, cheap, in abundant supply and can be wasted. It is also time to manage it as a scarce commodity and to price it according to how much people are ``willing to pay''. A good time to evaluate the population's ``willingness to pay'' is when there is a crisis. In a number of countries where surveys have been done, the people's estimate of their own ``willingness to pay'' for treated water has been much higher than the politicians'. It is also time to get the community actively involved in planning and designing its treated water supply requirements to ensure that the crisis does not recur. (The writer is a professor at the Faculty of Business, Universiti Malaya)

BC-Zimbabwe-Ex-President on Trial
Former Zimbabwe president goes on trial on sex charges
HARARE, Zimbabwe (AP) _ Former President Canaan Sodindo Banana went on trial Monday on two charges of sodomy, three charges of attempted sodomy and six of indecent assault. Prosecutor Augustine Chigumira claimed Banana repeatedly lured soldiers, aides and security men to his quarters for sex, and had them punished if they rejected his overtures. Banana, 62, an ordained Methodist minister and ceremonial head of state from 1980-1988, pleaded not guilty. Wearing a green ``Mao'' suit he adopted in his heyday as a radical black liberation theologian, Banana arrived at the High Court in a chauffeur-driven purple Mercedes Benz limousine with his wife Janet. Carrying a walking stick painted with the Zimbabwean national colors of red, green, black and gold, Banana smiled for cameramen and took his place impassively in the dock. The case poses political embarrassment to his successor and associate, President Robert Mugabe. Before the scandal broke last year, Mugabe said gays are ``lower than pigs or dogs'' and should have ``no rights at all'' in Zimbabwe. The prosecution claims top political figures and military commanders covered up Banana's homosexual indiscretions. Vice President Simon Muzenda and Justice Minister Emmerson Mnangagwa are expected to testify. Defense attorney Chris Andersen asserted that any sexual intimacy took place with consent. But the prosecutor said the opposite occurred. He said one young guard, ordered to escort Banana on a tour of the grounds of the presidential residence, threw the president into the swimming pool to escape his advances. Eleven people will be alleging at the trial they were victims of Banana's advances, court officials said. (mh-aos)

Now that both India and Pakistan have emerged as nations with demonstrable nuclear capability, the task before the international community is to bring them back to the path of sanity. India's five tests and Pakistan's six in defiance of the universal call for exercising restraint have turned the region into a fertile ground for using the weapons of mass destruction, which can only mean incalculable misfortune for their impoverished people. So the reality is that the world will have to live with two more countries having the ability to mop up millions in a few minutes if they ever decide on doing so. That alone should suffice to remove all doubts that anyone might still have regarding the need for preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons. But when the cloud is already looming large on the horizon, the only way to avert a major disaster is to defuse tension. Both India and Pakistan should be persuaded to sign the CTBT which should help eliminate the possibility of a nuclear conflict and prevent further advancement of the two countries' weapons programmes That might sound like setting too modest and limited an objective; but as things stand now, it is difficult to see how else the threat of a nuclear conflagration can be dealt with. The Indian argument that the CTBT is discriminatory in the sense that it does not cut both ways has its point, since it can stop only horizontal expansion of the nuclear armoury, giving the countries already in possession of nuclear arms an undue advantage. If a nuclear-free world is what we are striving for, the rules should apply equally to all .Then come the punitive sanctions already imposed by the United States and Japan. These will, of course, hit the economies of India and Pakistan rather hard. And the poor people will have to bear the brunt of it all. True, the donor countries have few options, but ordinary people should not be made to pay a high price for the decisions made by their governments. The stirred up popular sentiments are by no means an indication that people have lost faith in peace, rather the celebrations in India and Pakistan following the nuclear tests only showed that plebeians, blinded by gut patriotism, were indeed not capable of judging everything critically.

A number of reports published in newspapers coming from various coastal districts of Bangladesh suggest that our fishermen living off the sea are experiencing a unique situation of elusive catches. The coastal waters appear to have been emptied of fish population.Many thousands of fishing boats and trawlers are returning empty from the sea after days spent on the waves. Trawlers fishing in deep sea waters are also complaining that catches are becoming alarmingly rare. Loss of living spells disaster for lakhs of idle fishermen.Coastal sea-beds and estuaries provide breeding grounds for much of the fish population of the Bay. According to reports, one of the major causes for the vanishing trend of mature fish catches is the irresponsible netting of fish fry for culture fishery all along the coast-line. Inadmissible types of nets are being used for rogue fishing, and fish fry is being caught by mosquito nets on a massive scale, irreparably impeding the growth of mature fish population. What is more regrettable is that the crude methods of catching fish fry for culture is wasteful to the extent of 80 per cent of the fry being spoilt in the process. The demand for fry could be easily met by adequate hatcheries that could ensure efficient and adequate supply for the culture fisheries, if properly set up in appropriate places. Appropriate management of the economy and environment of our coastal land and waters in the long belt from Teknaf to Dublar Char, that is capable of providing among other opportunities a valuable resources of extensive capture fishing, is a must for our sustainable development. Besides pollution from sea-lane traffic abuses, it is irresponsible depletion of immature fish stock and fry that poses a major threat to the coastal economy. The authorities ought to take special care to implement laws about breeding season bans on sea-fishing, to penalise harmful netting practices, and to ban commercial catching of fry altogether, in addition to stricter implementation of pollution controls along and off the coast.

Government survey shows most people worried about jobs
HONG KONG (AP) - Most Hong Kong people listed unemployment as one of their main concerns, a government survey said Monday. The survey also showed that only 44 percent of the 1,553 respondents said they were satifised with Hong Kong's present situtation, the lowest figure ever recorded since the government began conducting opinion polls in 1983. It said labor-related issues were the main preoccupation of 54 percent of the people interviewed over the telephone in the poll. Housing, which used to be the main concern, was mentioned by only 30 percent of the people in the latest survey. The poll, which was conducted last month, did not give any margin of error. On Friday, the government announced that the economy contracted by 2 percent in the first quarter, the first contraction in almost 13 years. Unemployment is at a 14-year high of 3.9 percent.

THE supermarket business remains a bright spot in an otherwise gloomy retail market. Sales continue to clock positive growth even as the economy shrinks. After all, there are essentials in life. Although the Hong Kong economy has registered negative growth _ the first time in 13 years _ neither of Hong Kong's two biggest supermarket chains, Park 'N Shop and Wellcome, are about to scrap plans to open more big stores this year. The basic cause of the first-quarter slump has been less consumer spending, which accounts for nearly 60 per cent of Hong Kong's gross domestic product. Despite the downturn, Park 'N Shop managing director Logan Taylor believes this is the time for investment in the future. The chain, he said, was opening five more ``Super Stores'' this year as part of an expansion program that would see the present chain of 173 stores expanding to 180. Rival Wellcome is similarly on a course of expansion. Marketing manager Lewis McMullen said the firm would open 10 more stores this year. Wellcome currently has 120 stores and employs 5,000. More staff would be needed for the expansion, he said. Economic gloom had no direct negative impact on business growth, he said. Indeed, he added, because the prices of the company's products were already very low, it was a good time for increasing market share. Also, the economic slump has brought massive cost reductions in terms of rents. Retail analyst Debbie Lau said both supermarkets were expanding to take advantage of low rents that have significantly reduced operating costs. The retail sector slump has meant rents plunging up to 30 per cent in prime locations. Yet rents continued to account for a huge chunk of Park 'N Shop operating cost, Mr Taylor said. Benefits of lower rents varied from place to place, he said. The super-store trend, Mr Taylor said, was to meet the demand for one-stop shopping. The range of products offered in a Super Store would range from daily grocery needs to wet-market features with seafood and freshwater fish. The new stores were long-term investments that promised solid returns, according to Miss Lau. The supermarket sector was more stable than other retail sectors. She noted that while other businesses were slumping, supermarkets had seen constant sales growth of 7 per cent to 8 per cent in recent years. ``We anticipate, for instance, that Wellcome supermarket will see a 7.6-per-cent sales growth in the next two years despite the downturn,'' Ms Lau said. And the Asian financial crisis has had only a minimal effect on the supermarket sector. ``After the regional turmoil, the supermarket sector is more competitive than other retail sectors, such as fashion,'' Mr Taylor said. ``The crisis had less of an effect on food retailers than other retailers, but it has changed the consumption habits of grocery buyers.'' Shoppers were now focusing more on basic commodities rather than on luxury or snack foods, Mr Taylor said. And the slowdown has meant people are dining out less. The Super Store approach was the way of the future for Park 'N Shop, as Mr Taylor saw it. By the end of this year, 25 per cent of sales revenue would be generated by Super Stores, he said. ``We will open one store in Lam Tin's Sceneway Plaza with a size of 30,000 square feet, a 35,000-sq-ft store in Festival Walk, Kowloon Tong, and a 30,000-sq-ft store in the former Wing On store basement in the Hopewell Centre.'' Opening a 25,000-sq-ft store would mean an investment of $15 million to $20 million, Mr Taylor said. And total investment for the current expansion plan would amount to about $75 million. Profit margins at super stores were lower than at at regular supermarkets, Mr Taylor added, because of the extensive range of products, but super stores produced bigger turnover and economies of scale. Park 'N Shop is also set to undergo an image overhaul with the arrival of a new company logo. The logo change cost several million dollars, Mr Taylor said, and it's expected to cover all branded lines within two years.

El Nino, the warm ocean current that triggers extreme changes in weather, is bringing about world-wide droughts that are a worry to farmers and the general consumer. Latest research reveals El Nino has been a regular feature of the past, occurring in periodic cycles. This particular El Nino is so turbulent probably for the global warming caused by the hole in the ozone layer. Since last year due to El Nino's influence a drought has been raging in Indonesia. Man-made fires to clear forests went out of hand with awesome conflagrations. Numerous precious flora and fauna have perished and are still perishing. Some, like Borneo's orangutans, survived the fire to die of starvation, lacking food because of the drought and the fire. Smoke hung in a haze for months over the region from Singapore to Borneo, forcing motor vehicles in even teeming metropolitan cities to use headlights to grope through low visibility. A similar disaster is befalling the region this year too. And now Mexico, which has not seen a rain cloud for months, is in the grip of a fire whose smoke is reaching out in a haze from Houston to Denver in the USA. The El Nino fallout in Mexico itself is of similar nature: for instance, millions of Monarch butterflies, who regularly migrate to Mexico in the winter, are in danger of being wiped out. In Bangladesh there is the likely onslaught of El Nino on the coming Aman crop. What is needed in all these countries is regional and global cooperation for timely weather forecasts alongside disaster management measures in accordance with the magnitude of the calamity.

BC-Sports-Tennis-Venus vs Martina,
Retransmitting Williams-Hingis rivalry renewed at French Open AP Sports Writer
By ROB GLOSTER
PARIS (AP) _ Venus Williams slammed the serve at 185 kph (115 mph, but Ai Sugiyama held up her hand and watched the ball speed past. The umpire ordered the point replayed. Williams glared at her opponent with a look that seemed to scream, ``Are you ready NOW?'' Then the 17-year-old American responded with a 190 kph (118 mph) service winner. That may be the question for top-seeded Martina Hingis as she prepares to play Williams in the quarterfinals of the French Open on Tuesday, their fifth encounter already this year. The rivalry between Hingis and Williams is becoming one of the best in women's sports. Though it evokes hints of the Chris Evert-Martina Navratilova duels of the 1980s, it has the potential to become much more bitter off the court. Hingis becomes downright haughty when discussing Williams, whom she says has not yet earned the right to consider herself part of a great rivalry. ``Everybody else is trying to make rivalries against me,'' she said. ``Venus, she won Key Biscayne, but that's not a Grand Slam.'' Williams, seeded eighth at Roland Garros in just her fourth tournament on clay, responded diplomatically when told of Hingis' comments. ``I think that she's playing good tennis, and she has every right to say what she wants to,'' Williams said. Hingis holds a 5-2 record against Williams, including a 6-0, 6-4 win in the final of the U.S. Open last summer in their only previous Grand Slam meeting. They are 2-2 this year, with Williams winning on hard courts in Sydney and in the semifinals of the Lipton Championships in Key Biscayne. But Hingis won their only career encounter on clay, capturing the final of the Italian Open in three sets in mid-May. ``It was a good victory for me there to beat her in three sets in the final of a big tournament,'' Hingis said. ``I hope she will remember that, too.'' Hingis and Williams have eased through the first four rounds of the French Open. Hingis has lost just 14 games while averaging 56 minutes per victory. Williams has lost 13 games and averaged 58 minutes per match. Hingis said she has every reason to feel she has an edge over Williams heading into the match. ``Well, why shouldn't I?'' she asked. ``I'm No. 1, I've won four Grand Slams. I have the self-confidence.'' While Hingis is the master strategist, moving opponents around the court with precise groundstrokes until she has set up a winning shot, Williams relies on power and athleticism to overwhelm foes. Those contrasting styles bring back memories of Evert, the baseline strategist, and Navratilova, the powerful serve-and-volleyer. They enjoyed their on-court duels and an off-court friendship. But the Hingis-Williams matchup is not a friendly rivalry and, if Hingis is to be believed, not yet even a rivalry. All that could change on Tuesday.

LAGOS, Nigeria (AP) _ In the wake of Nigeria's convincing 3-0 loss to Yugoslavia, many fans of the Super Eagles are clamoring for a goalkeeper purge. Radio talk shows and daily newspapers were filled Monday with condemnation for the performance of goalkeeper Abiodun Baruwa, who allowed in all three goals in the Friday match. Many fans called for the return of Peter Rufai, who plays for Spanish side Deportivo La Cornua, to the number one spot on Nigeria's World Cup-bound squad. Former national team captain Segun Odegbami said goalkeeping was merely part of a larger problem _ growing team apathy. ___ PARIS (AP) _ French midfielder Youri Djorkaeff says France's public recognition of the 1915 genocide of ethnic Armenians in Turkey inspired his spectacular goal in a 2-2 draw against Morocco last week. Djorkaeff, whose mother is Armenian, said he came on as substitute determined to score after hearing the news that lawmakers had passed a motion recognizing as ``genocide'' the deaths of 1.5 million Armenians. If the Senate also passes the motion, France would become the first major European country to recognize the genocide. The motion drew strong protests last week from Turkey. ``It was a great day for me because France acknowledged the genocide of Armenians,'' Djorkaeff said in an interview published Monday with sports daily L'Equipe. ``I thought of it as I went onto the pitch. I wanted to do something special, and that's how goals like that are scored.'' Djorkaeff, who plays for Italy's Inter Milan, equalized for France with less than 20 minutes to go, scoring a stunning overhead kick that gave the goalkeeper no chance. France then lost on penalties in the final match of the King Hassan II tournament. ___ BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Yugoslav Coach Slobodan Santrac on Monday dropped striker Anto Drobnjak and midfielder Albert Nadj from Yugoslavia's 22-man World Cup squad. Drobjak, of French champion's Lens, and Nadj, of Betis in Spain, will not travel to France, where Yugoslavia faces the United States, Germany and Iran in the preliminary rounds. Nadj reportedly had a row with Santrac before Yugoslavia's friendly warm-up with Nigeria last Friday which the Yugoslav team won 3-0. Nadj had allegedly refused to start the game on defense, rather than his usual position in the midfield. Santrac had a large choice of strikers and Drobnjak lost his place in competition with Predrag Mijatovic and Darko Kovacevic. The Yugoslav team up front includes forwards Predrag Mijatovic, Savo Milosevic, Darko Kovacevic, Perica Ognjenovic. ___ MILAN, Italy (AP) _ Oliver Bierhoff is aiming for Ronaldo yet again. Bierhoff held off the Brazilian star in the race for scoring champion in the just-concluded Serie A season and says he can do the same at the World Cup. ``I have always looked for a rival as a point of reference. Even as a boy,'' the German told Gazzetta dello Sport on Monday. ``It gave me the motivation to commit myself. Hopefully I can beat Ronaldo again _ at the World Cup and in the league.'' Bierhoff tallied 27 goals for third-place Udinese this season, while Ronaldo had 25 for runner-up Inter Milan. They'll be neighbors next year, though, with Bierhoff having transferred to AC Milan. ___ TUNIS, Tunisia (AP) _ Tunisian coach Henri Kasperczak Monday announced his squad for the World Cup, including four European-based players he hopes will give the team vital international experience. It will be the second time Tunisia has played in a World Cup, coming 20 years after its debut in Argentina. Many observers say the current squad is the most talented Tunisia has ever fielded. Kasperczak, from Poland, chose four players from European leagues: striker Adel Sellimi of Spanish second division team Jaen, the Freiburg (Germany) duo of Zoubeir Beya and Mahdi Ben Slimane, and France's Bastia goalkeeper Ali Bou Mnijel. Tunisia is in the same group as Romania, England and Colombia. ___ FRANKFURT, Germany (AP) _ On Germany's team of oldies, whose average age is over 30, one new face may have cracked the starting lineup. Defensive midfielder Jens Jeremies, the team's baby at 24, turned in an outstanding performance in the European champion's 3-1 victory over Colombia Saturday. ``Our best player was our youngster Jens,'' coach Berti Vogts said. ``The way he worked for (offensive midfielders) Andreas Moeller and Thomas Haessler, how he gave commands and stripped players of the ball _ that impressed me a lot.'' LAST week, I discussed the different factors that affect risk tolerance and profiled the characteristics of an aggressive investor. This time, we'll look at the three other investment personalities: dynamic, moderate and conservative, and how they approach investment risk. Dynamic Jason Won is a 32-year-old bachelor with a monthly income of $40,000 who lives with his parents in a 700 sq-ft flat in Tai Koo Shing. Jason is one of the lucky people who can live comfortably with his parents. But Jason is well aware of the need to save for his future. Because he is young, affluent and has virtually no financial responsibilities, he could probably be categorised as a dynamic investor who would select high-to-moderate risk investments with the potential for high return over the long term. This type of investors tends to favour a mix of investments that offers different risk levels and returns. They buy stocks in emerging markets such as South America and Southeast Asia, and stocks in developed markets such as the United States and Europe. They usually have invested in individual stocks and mutual funds and are knowledgeable about financial markets. Moderate David So is a 39-year-old restaurant general manager with a monthly income of $30,000. He has just paid off his mortgage on a 650 sq-ft apartment in Lam Tin, Kowloon, where he lives with his wife and their two children, aged 10 and five. To supplement his income, David occasionally works part-time as a taxi driver. Now nearing middle age. David is well aware of the need to save for retirement. As the family's sole breadwinner, he probably isn't keen on taking big risk. Thus, he could be categorised as a moderate investor who would adopt a middle-of-the-road strategy that will protect him but not make him wealthy. He categorises his investments into short term-high risk and long term-low risk. He accepts moderate changes in the value of his investments and takes calculated risk. People like David prefer a balanced mix of investments that includes blue-chip stocks, bonds and mutual funds. These investments generally provide a moderate return over the long term, and David likes the sense of security and stability his investments bring. Conservative James Chan is a 47-year-old supermarket manager with a monthly income of $35,000. He owns a 450 sq-flat in Tai Po, in the New Territories, which he bought more than 20 years ago. Recently widowed, James has three teenage children, aged 13, 14 and 16, to support. Because of his age, his moderate income and financial responsibilities for his children, James should adopt a conservative, or risk averse, approach to investing. His savings should be put into low-risk but safe investments. But James is by nature a risk taker and a gambler. He bets on horses and regularly visits casinos in Macau. When he invests, he buys highly speculative stocks such as little-known mainland industrial stocks and Indonesian mining and energy shares. James made money during the Hong Kong stock market bull run of 1993, but lately he has been hurt by the market downturn. It is people like James who especially need the discipline of a provident fund scheme. I hope he will select one that will provide solid management to help him save for his retirement because he'll probably need it. Now that we've looked at the four types of investment personalities, maybe you can decide your type. There is a Chinese saying: ``Know yourself and your enemy and you will win every battle.'' And knowing your investment personality will help you in your retirement plan. As with most things, you need to plan ahead to get ahead and achieve the results you want. In retirement planning, you need to ask yourself: ``How much do I need to retire comfortably?'' That depends on a lot of factors _ current salary, lifestyle, how many working years you have before retirement, assets, the rate of your investment return, your philosophy toward risk. We'll start talking about these next week.

BANGI, Sun. - The Government will continue the policy of intervention in market forces to help Bumiputera businessmen, Entrepreneur Development Minister Datuk Mustapa Mohamed said today. He said the policy of intervention by providing funds and awarding licences and contracts to Bumiputera entrepreneurs would be continued to ensure fair distribution of wealth. The policy was necessary as Bumiputeras were still handicapped in business and would be marginalised if left to market forces, he told reporters after launching the Kelab Wawasan Melayu Malaysia. Also present at the launch were pro-tem club president Datuk Shukor Raja Idris, deputy president Datin Faridah Mohd Said and about 200 members. Mustapa said in the 1960s and 1970s, such interventions were necessary as Malays were not able to compete with non-Malays due to low income and lack of a level playing field. In education, he said, similar interventions had caused Bumiputeras to be on par with other races, but the 30 per cent share equity for Bumiputeras in business had yet to be achieved. On business opportunities in the face of the negative growth of 1.8 per cent announced by by Bank Negara for the first quarter of this year, Mustapa said this was only short-term. He said the Government was consolidating the national economy and was confident it would recover in the long term. The long-term prospects for recovery were good and entrepreneurs should not be discouraged by the figures, added Mustapa. Shukor, who is group executive chairman of Warga Mantap Group, said the club, with an estimated membership of 3,000 nationwide, would act as a voice for entrepreneurs in small- and medium-sized businesses. He said the club would assist Malay entrepreneurs aged 18 and above deal with problems in their businesses brought about by the economic slowdown. A businessman based in Australia, Shukor said he decided to return home to invest in Malaysia and expressed confidence the economy would recover.

Nuclear one-upmanship: Spectre of a sub-continental Armageddon?, THE INDEPENDENT xfdws NUCLEAR-ONE-UPMANSHIP sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 01, 1998 THE INDEPENDENT ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. As part of the race for nuclear superiority in the sub-continent, Pakistan detonated a total of six nuclear devices on Thursday and Saturday - five on Thursday. BBC television showed pictures of excited people eating sweetmeat on the streets of Pakistani towns and villages and celebrating as Nawaz Sharif addressed the nation on Thursday saying: ``We have settled the account of the nuclear blasts by India. Today we have successfully carried out five tests.'' He went on to add that Pakistan had to carry out the nuclear tests because the world community had ``... not done anything effective to make India realise its mistake.'' Predictably enough Indian Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee said that these tests by Pakistan had vindicated' India's decision to test its nuclear devices. Immediately after Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's announcements, the Pakistani President announced a State of Emergency suspending the Pakistani Constitution. All these chain of events leading from the testing of Pakistan's missile Ghauri, India's nuclear tests, and now Pakistan's nuclear tests, with its declaration of emergency points definitely to a situation of belligerent confrontation between India and Pakistan. In fact Saturday's test by Pakistan came as an anti-climax, with Pakistan claiming all these to be part of a complete series comprising six detonations.Both Nawaz Sharif, on his election in February '97, and Atal Behari Vajpayee on becoming the Prime Minister of India in March, had stressed the importance of normalising relations between the two countries. In fact, when Sharif assumed Prime Ministership, it was seen that the voters were clearly in favour of better relations between the two countries and that they wanted to see India and Pakistan as trading partners rather than warring neighbours. In Pakistan 54% of the country's voters were below 40, and animosity towards India and memories of the partition are a matter of the history books to them in this age of liberalisation. However both Indian and Pakistani citizens were seen rejoicing after the tests, irrespective of age. The latest situation has raised concerns in the SAARC countries and the rest of Asia including China. President Jiang Zemin of China is supposed to have written to Nawaz Sharif to refrain from nuclear tests. Indian tests have been on a circumspect note, but now the news that the Pakistani missile Ghauri would be deployed with nuclear warheads makes that country a step ahead in the chessboard moves of belligerence. Can the two countries be now prevailed upon not to deploy these weapons? Bangladesh has forcefully stated its commitment to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, and its belief that the security of the region lies in its economic strength rather than military power, and now nuclear power. Bangladesh and the other SAARC countries now have the responsibilities to bring back India and Pakistan from the brink of war, whether conventional or nuclear, for the sake of real economic and social development in the region. The impending SAARC summit in Colombo-advanced by about ten days-may well serve as an important forum for a positive defusing of the situation. On the other hand if the efforts of the SAARC leaders cannot modify the stance taken by India and Pakistan, this will be a very dangerous situation spelling future complications in the region as well as for the alliance. In case of an actual war between India and Pakistan the physical well being of Bangladesh and the remaining SAARC nations will be, needless to say, greatly endangered. Reference is always made in international situations of this seriousness and urgency, to the need of the United States to exercise leadership in the world community, to assume its leadership role. For decades the Indian sub-continent had been on the back burner of America's external concerns. Now President Bill has turned the heat up, by his stern approach to sanctions against both India and Pakistan. The tense situation now because of the nuclear tests and that in Kashmir are now definitely seen as urgent problems, and a time for activism in South Asia. Clinton had also in the past referred to the Kashmir problem between the two countries in his UN speech in September 1993, when he said: ``Bloody ethnic, religious and civil wars raging from Angola to the Caucasus to Kashmir.'' However both Indians and Pakistanis have slated the US attitudes as being favourable to the opposing side. The attention of the largest and the militarily most dominant of the former imperial powers, naturally arouses the fears of some imperial residuum. In 1994, after the testing of India's missile Prithvi, Bill Clinton sent his diplomatic trouble-shooter, deputy secretary of state Strobe Talbot to broker deals that could begin to curb the nuclear arms race in the sub-continent. At that time neither the Pakistanis, nor the Indians bought Talbot's line completely. But both responded in a sufficiently positive manner for the American to say before leaving for the US from Islamabad: ``Much remains to be done on non-proliferation, but much was accomplished.'' Pakistan was then amenable to the US proposals on the non-proliferation conference and the non-deployment of the missiles. But while Islamabad seemed agreeable to a cap on production of missile material, it would not concede on-site inspections of its nuclear facilities. As for India, it did not respond immediately on the missile deployment issue, but Indian officials agreed in private to the non-proliferation talks. In only four years since April 1994, the situation has moved beyond the ambit of that bid of the US to defuse Indo-Pakistani nuclear tensions. In the case of India military decisions such as the present one of exploding nuclear devices is mainly in the hands of its political leadership. In Pakistan the military and the establishment has also an important say besides the politicians, and add to that the elements of it being the smaller country also wrestling with the contentious bone of Kashmir, and the US and the other developed countries may find it more difficult to convince Pakistan than India in turning back from the preparations and exercises of a nuclear confrontation. Analysts have also indicated an interesting angle inasmuch as the development of the nuclear bomb by Pakistan maybe the indications of a future Islamic' bomb which may present a threat to Israel. The UN, while deploring the tests by both India and Pakistan have offered personal mediation through Kofi Annan. Britain, the current chairman of G-8 has called an emergency meeting of the group, and included-significantly enough-China as a special guest in the deliberations on the nuclear scenario in the sub-continent. It is also time that both the remaining SAARC countries, possibly at the behest of Bangladesh, and the Non-Aligned Movement countries take emergency steps. The power of the military to assert need and acquire the requisite financial support is evident in a great measure in the legislative branches of both these countries. There, subject to minor symbolic changes, the military budget is voted automatically, and in recent years with annual increases. It is not even thought necessary that some military needs-intelligence operations, sophisticated nuclear weapons-be known to the legislative body as a whole and thus to the public at large. More important, perhaps, and particularly in the present case, is the reassuring manifestation of patriotism in supporting the armed forces. The authority of the military in establishing national military priorities has thus become complete. This is a circumstance that has to be conceded and considered in any approach towards a negotiated cessation of hostilities and the arms race. Furthermore the State of Emergency in Pakistan will preclude any overt domestic discussion and debate about this nuclear war preparations. Whether India will follow suit in like manner is yet to be seen. However Vajpayee has again reiterated his offer to hold talks with Sharif on all issues including nuclear arms and Kashmir. Above all this, on the domestic scene in both the countries, there were and there remain the insistent claims of the poor and the impoverished, in the cities and the villages. Whatever the external threats, there was and there is still the danger of an abrupt and violent challenge to domestic tranquillity if military needs continue to control the resources that, if used for basic income support, job creation, housing, education, health and social care, would ease the crisis within the countries. It has been said about the Soviet Union that it was impoverished precisely because it concentrated its resources on preparing for a war that would never be fought. If they had been used on public welfare, then the country may have shown the world the superiority of its socialist way of life. A couple of years back, Sherbaz Mazari commented on Zulfiquar Ali Bhutto: ``He was more anti-Indian than pro-poor.'' Now we have to see whether Sharif and Vajpayee are more anti-each other, or pro-poor in their respective countries.
