There is no doubt that English is a very important language. Just look at all the materials out there in English. Text books used in universities are mainly in English; the movies in the cinemas are in English; The Jakarta Post is in English. Of course a lot of materials have been translated. No movie in the cinema goes without a subtitle. This also applies for English TV programs. Best sellers have also been translated. But can we really rely on these translations? With no disrespect to the translators -- it happens to be something I also do from time to time -- there is an amount of information missing in the translated version or, at worst, the information is completely misleading, such as in the film subtitles. I watched Hook several years ago and in one of the scenes Robin William's character says, ``I have a problem with heights.'' The subtitle, however, reads, ``Saya memiliki masalah dengan berat badan.'' (I have a problem with weight). In Dead Poet's Society somebody saying, ``I'm not like you'' is translated as ``Saya tidak suka kamu'' (I don't like you). More examples can be seen on the TV as well. But the most ridiculous translation I've encountered so far is 'foto cangkir' (cup photo) for ``mug shot''. To avoid being misled with the information given by the translations, a good mastery of English is a must. And now that we are entering the era of globalization, English becomes more important. More people apparently try to learn English. If they do not have the time to take an English class, they might go out and buy English language study books. These books are helpful. You can learn English in the comfort of your own home whenever you have the time and are in the mood to do so. However, it is necessary to tread with caution when buying English language study books. Those books sold by sellers who get on and off buses or trains are to be avoided. It might be tempting to buy them because they are so ridiculously cheap but what is more important: the price of the book or the knowledge inside it? Buying English language study books from prestigious and well-known bookstores might be a better idea but that doesn't mean that you are safe. Prestigious bookstores do not necessarily sell prestigious books as well. On one of my frequent trips to the bookstore, a book called English Conversations caught my eye. The book was displayed in one of the well-known bookstores in Indonesia, so I thought it must be quite good. Out of pure curiosity, I flipped through the pages of the books just to get an idea of what the book was about. The book has two columns on one page. One column is for the ``English'' version of the conversation while the second column is in Indonesian. Allow me to enlighten you with some examples. It would be better if I gave you the Indonesian version first so that you don't get completely lost. One example reads: Jika kamu takut disuntik, minta obat saja. The English version reads ``If you afraid of injection [sic]. Ask for medicine, please.'' As you may have noticed the English is not really English. None the less, an English speaking person might still understand what is really meant. Now let's take a look at another example. The context of the conversation this time is about watching TV. One person wants to know what's on TV, so he asks Acaranya apa? In English --according to the author of this amazing book -- it is, ``What's the plan?'' This book really amazed me. First of all, I was surprised that somebody actually had the guts to write such a book. Second, there was a publisher who actually agreed to print the book. Finally, there was a bookstore manager who actually accepted the book to be displayed on the shelves. A piece of advice for those who are planning to learn a foreign language is to get professional help from a professional language institute. If you really don't have the time to attend a course then, by all means, buy a book. To help you pick out a book, bring a friend who speaks the foreign language to get her or his advice on the quality of the book. If no such friend is available, then avoid buying books from an obscure publisher. Stick with the well-known and credible publishers. This doesn't mean that you should not consider picking up any of these amazing books. If you want to get a cheap laugh then the book might be a good idea. I know I got a good laugh after reading just a couple of pages. Imagine what the whole book would do.

A group of 18 retired generals are demanding that the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) hold an extraordinary session no later than July to revoke decrees installing Soeharto as president and B.J. Habibie as vice president. The deadline was stipulated in a statement made available to the press yesterday and signed by the group's coordinator, former Commander of the Army's Strategic Reserves Lt. Gen. (ret.) Achmad Kemal Idris. The statement said they rejected the agreement reached between the House of Representative and the government that an extraordinary session be held in six months time. They argued in their statement that, apart from revoking the decrees, the Assembly should immediately elect a caretaker president or presidium. One of the signatories, Let. Gen. (ret.) Ali Sadikin, said Soeharto could not simply delegate his presidential mandate to his deputy. ``Such a sudden presidential succession cannot be held just like that. It must be held before an extraordinary session of the MPR,'' the former governor of Jakarta told The Jakarta Post yesterday. ``A presidential succession is not like the election of a village chief. An outgoing president must be held accountable for all the policies that he or she introduced,'' he said. Under intense pressure from mounting protests, Soeharto resigned May 21 and handed over power to Habibie. House Speaker Harmoko, after meeting with Habibie on Thursday, said they had agreed that an extraordinary session of the Assembly would be held at the end of the year or early next year to set the date for the polls. Harmoko also brushed aside suggestions that the extraordinary session would seek an accountability address from Soeharto. ``We, based on the spirit of total reform, declare our rejection of the said agreement (between the House leaders and Habibie),'' said the statement from the senior officers of the Armed Forces' 1945 generation. They closed their statement, which was signed by Kemal on Friday, by stating that ``the entire reform movement must be implemented peacefully and constitutionally''. Other signatories of the statement included former Army chiefs Gen. (ret.) Makmun Murod and Gen. (ret.) Rudini; former Air Force chief (ret.) Air Marshal Ashadi Tjahjadi; former Police chief Gen. (ret.) Awaloedin Djamin; former House/Assembly Speaker Lt. Gen. (ret.) M. Kharis Suhud; former Secretary for National Development Operations Lt. Gen. (ret.) Solichin G.P.; former Indonesian Ambassador to the United States Lt. Gen. (ret.) Hasnan Habib and former chief of the Army's special force (Kopasandha, now Kopassus) Lt. Gen. (ret.) Leo Lopulisa. A similar rejection of the agreement between House leaders and Habibie came from former economic minister Frans Seda. Frans simply said that waiting to hold the extraordinary session until the end of this year or even next year was simply ``too long''. But Frans did not specify a particular timeframe for the Assembly's extraordinary session. Speaking at a seminar on state ideology Pancasila here yesterday, Frans said the Assembly's extraordinary session would be a crucial point for the current transitional government to counter doubts on its ``legality''. He maintained that there was a question of legality surrounding the current government, which was not only eroding public trust but also international confidence, evident in the continued stalling of funds to be disbursed by the International Monetary Fund. ``The problem is that an international body will only give financial assistance to a government which is trustworthy,'' he said, adding that there should be no detachment in reforming the economic and political aspects of the nation. ``Fixing politics is part and parcel of remedying the country's economy,'' he said.

BC-China-Nuclear,0534
Foreign ministers of permanent Security Council to meet on South Asian arms race
By RENEE SCHOOF Associated Press Writer
BEIJING (AP) _ China will urge the world's powers to find a way to halt the nuclear arms race in South Asia when foreign ministers of the U.N. Security Council's permanent members meet this week in Geneva, a senior Foreign Ministry official said Monday. China fears the recent nuclear weapons tests by India and Pakistan will set off a chain reaction of other countries obtaining nuclear weapons and set back disarmament, the senior official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan will attend the meeting on Thursday with U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and the foreign ministers of Russia, France and Britain, the official said. Tang and Albright, speaking by telephone, jointly proposed holding the meeting, said Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao. China has no proposal for how to respond to the tests, said the senior official. ``That's why we're meeting. We have to work it out,'' he said. China does not want India, Pakistan or any other countries to become nuclear powers, he said. ``We should urge them with one voice and make them realize it's not in their interest,'' he said. China, taking a turn leading the meeting, also will propose talking about how to reduce tensions in South Asia, he said. China is worried a South Asian arms race will destabilize the world, the official said. China needs a stable international environment so that it can concentrate on its economic development, he said. Elaborating on previous statements by Beijing about the tests, he said China was ``infuriated'' when India said it needed nuclear tests because neighboring China is its top threat. ``We are not their enemy. It's not true,'' he said, adding the accusation was an insult. China had improved relations with India in recent years, the official said. He added the two countries have many similarities, including a history of colonialism and ``the same task to feed, clothe, house and educate our people.'' China conducted its last nuclear test in 1996 and declared a moratorium. It was one of the first countries to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. But even the treaty allows countries to resume testing if their ``supreme national security'' is threatened, the official said. ``I'm not saying China will do it. But we have to take into account this development. China is urging the world to do something,'' he said. The official denied China has helped Pakistan, its close ally, develop nuclear weapons. He confirmed that President Bill Clinton spoke with President Jiang Zemin by telephone before Pakistan conducted its tests. But he denied reports Jiang called on Pakistan to forego testing at the urging of Clinton. Jiang wrote to Pakistani Prime Minister Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif ``on his own absolutely 100 percent,'' he said. ``We don't like to be preached to. We don't preach to others what they should do. But we tell them how we feel. We have not minced words with our friend Pakistan.''

BC-India-Pakistan-Peace Prospects,0588
Tensions overwhelm peace moves With India-Pakistan
By HEMA SHUKLA Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ Escalating tension over nuclear weapons appears to have buried the already faltering peace process between traditional rival neighbors India and Pakistan. Only a year ago, citizens of both countries were applauding what they hoped to be the start of a new era in their long, stormy relationship. Then-Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral of India and his Pakistani counterpart Nawaz Sharif, meeting at a regional summit in the Maldives, agreed to open negotiations on a number of disputes. Now, with the 1998 edition of the seven-nation regional summit a month away, this time in Sri Lanka, the mood is different. Last month, India tested nuclear devices May 11-13. In response, Pakistan claimed to have detonated six nuclear devices last week. The negotiations Gujral and Sharif kicked off to such fanfare never got much beyond the stage of bureaucrats wrangling over the agenda. The centrist Gujral was replaced two months ago by Atal Bihari Vajpayee who, though considered a moderate, leads the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party known for Pakistan-bashing. ``Both countries have myopic leaders and fragile economies. They can't afford a war. There is no choice for India and Pakistan but to talk to each other,'' said Anand Kumar, political analyst and professor at New Delhi's Jawaharlal Nehru University. ``Dialogue should continue,'' said Dina Dayalan of the Indian chapter of the Pakistan-India Peoples' Forum for Peace and Democracy, a group of private citizens on both sides of the border who have tried to ease tensions by promoting contacts between ordinary people. Tariq Rahman, active in the Pakistani counterpart to Dayalan's group, said the tests set back efforts to build trust by creating a ``tremendous feeling of antagonism'' among ordinary people. He hopes that the ``belligerency'' would die down over time, enabling leaders of India and Pakistan to meet to discuss how to avoid using their new weapons of mass destruction. But in the short term, Rahman said, it is hard to envision such talks. The arms race has long drained both countries, among the poorest in the world. The United Nations Children's Fund estimated that between 1990 and 1996, India spent an average of 2 percent of its annual budget on education, and 14 percent on defense. Pakistan spent just 1 percent on education, and a whopping 31 percent on defense. Pakistan and India have fought three wars since they were carved from the same British colony 50 years ago. The chief bone of contention between officially Islamic Pakistan and predominately Hindu India is the Himalayan region of Kashmir, which is divided between them and claimed in its entirety by both countries. If Vajpayee and Sharif do hold one-on-one talks at next month's regional summit, the main topic is likely to be the region's new nuclear realities, pushing efforts to normalize relations into the background. Syed Ali Shah Geelani, who leads a coalition of parties that wants India-held Kashmir _ the country's only Muslim-majority state _ to break away from India, said the rivalry over Kashmir led to the nuclear arms race between India and Pakistan. ``The main root of this is Kashmir. They should open serious talks to resolve the Kashmiri issue,'' said Geelani, who wants Kashmir either to form an independent country or to join Pakistan.

Prosecutor reports progress in solving contract murders
MOSCOW (AP) _ The number of solved contract killings is on the rise, but Russia's most famous killing remains uncracked, Prosecutor General Yuri Skuratov said in an interview published Monday. Skuratov told the newspaper Novaya Gazeta that his office had solved 70 contract killings in 1996 and the number rose to 132 in 1997. ``I think we shall do a still better job this year,'' he said. Skuratov said that many top investigators had returned to the prosecutor general's office because of improved salaries and better working conditions. He said that his office was successful in solving the killing of investigative journalist Dmitry Kholodov, who died in October 1994 when a briefcase supposedly provided by an informant exploded in his hands. Three suspects in the case have been arrested. But the contract killing of TV host Vladislav Listyev, who was gunned down outside his Moscow home on March 1, 1995, remains unsolved. ``The Listyev case is very hard,'' Skuratov told the newspaper. ``In no case has the Prosecutor General's Office felt so much all-round pressure,'' he said. But, he said, regardless of pressure and the cost of the lengthy investigation, his office will take the investigation to its conclusion. (jai/ls)

IT is perhaps a misnomer to describe Malaysia's present economic state as an ``economic downturn'' for not all parties involved in the economy are facing a slump. For those that are export-oriented such as manufacturing- and plantation-based firms, the present period is as good as it gets. One good example of such a company is Polymate Holdings Berhad. Its main and most profitable subsidiary is Automative Battery Industries Sdn Bhd (ABI). Presently, ABI relies on the export market for 65 per cent of its turnover and it expects this figure to rise another 10 per cent in the near future. Furthermore, ABI's impending expansion programme to cater for strong overseas demand will make it one of the biggest battery manufacturers in Malaysia and this region. It was the idea of Ng Kim Weng, Polymate's group managing director and ABI's managing director, to ensure that the export market becomes ABI's mainstay. Ng had, from early on, realised that companies which rely heavily on domestic market might find their product demand eventually reaching a saturation point. However, he explained if the company is export-oriented, then the opportunities are limitless as the world becomes its marketplace. His foresight has since then paid handsome dividends as ABI's expansion plan is expected to increase the group's turnover by 15 to 20 per cent to reach RM80 million for its financial year ending Sept 30 this year. Ng recently took time to speak to Management Times. From the observation made during the interview, it was evident that he is a leader without airs and capable of understanding his people's viewpoints. The humble characteristics can perhaps be attributed to his vast experience in the sales line. Q: How would you describe your management style? A: I try to be extra careful when dealing with problems involving human relationship especially when it concerns employees, partners or customers. Therefore, I try to put myself in their shoes before making decisions concerning them. The other parties' feelings must always be taken into consideration. Furthermore, I personally try to and likewise expect my employees to get things done fast and well. In other words, I don't believe in procrastinating. This is important for day-to-day decisions, as we can't afford to delay decision making. Although planning is important, we can't be in the planning stage for too long. However, for long term decisions, I expect my employees to have proper planning. They should not act rashly and make on-the-spot decisions without having the correct information. Q: Should managers then rely solely on hard facts when formulating long- term plans? A: Actually, it should be a combination of intuitive feeling and hard facts. If you do long-term planning based solely on hard facts, it can turn out to be very misleading. This is because whatever happened before might not occur again. Alternatively, what has not happened in the past might happen this time around. As such, it's important that apart from relying on facts, we also have to place confidence on our observational skills. Q: In that case, what do you think of decision-making process based on intuition? A: Well, that basically involves experience. Generally, people who have undergone a similar situation previously would know what to expect and how to react. For example, they would know what decisions to take to counter problems created by the present economic downturn. This is true even if the problem is not exactly similar to a past problem. Just having that long experience in the industry would have prepared them to handle problems better. This is what separates the top level and middle level managers. Q: As such, in terms of weightage, how would you rank factors like experience, on-the-job training or formal studies in developing an efficient manager? A: I feel that observation is very important as from it, you would be able to envision the future requirements of the company. Meanwhile, on-the-job training is an on-going process that needs to be experienced on a continuous basis. However, employees without high academic qualification should not be seen as inferior. To me, what's more important is their character, how much initiative they exhibit. If they have a lot of initiative but are handicapped by the lack of high education. I am sure they will spend much time observing and learning, for example via on-the-job training, to overcome their limitation. Therefore, it's not surprising that they at times can perform better than their more educated colleagues. Q: Are you saying that even the top level managers don't need proper qualification? A: What I am saying is that academic qualification prepares managers to handle problems in the theoretical sense. So, if a problem occurs and graduate managers have been taught to deal with that particular problem in university, they will be able to overcome it. But, one should not forget that managers who rose from the rank and file too would be able to perform efficiently. They, in their journey up the corporate ladder, would have learned many things that would have helped hone their decision-making skills. Not surprisingly, at times, their solutions are considered superior to those from the textbooks. Q: You rose from rank and file. How has this, and your background in sales, prepared you for your present post? A: Basically, my sales experience has taught me to deal with people efficiently. I believe managers with sales background would have cultivated the necessary skills to deal with the needs of different sets of people. As such, this gives them a great advantage over, say an accountant who is purely analytical in functioning as a top level manager. Q: Are you then implying that top managers should have some sales background? A: No, that is not necessary. But let's say if you want to start a business and you have prior knowledge on sales, that will help you tremendously. This is because, it will help you sell your products better, but in the end, it still boils down to the character of the person. Q: Being export-oriented, what kind of priority do you place on research and development (RD) activities? A: Actually, we are one of the few companies in the industry which have invested a lot of money in RD activities. We know that to increase our export market share, we have to ensure our products meet international standards and have consistent quality. In the last year or so, we have invested more than half a million ringgit for RD activities. Q: Presently, retrenchment is a hot issue. How are you dealing with this? A: Well, for the time being, retrenchment is not something that is in our dictionary. But hypothetically speaking, if there is a need to exercise that option, we have to take into consideration the individual's performance and his/her length of service. Nevertheless, I don't subscribe to the ``last in first out'' idea. That is not fair to the productive employees who might be contributing more than the senior employees. Q: How do you view change management in the context of our present economic situation? A: To me, we have to transform according to the changes in the market. We cannot rest on our past laurels, as success is never a guaranteed attainment. Just because you were successful before does not mean that you will be successful later, especially if you don't change according to the dictates of the marketplace. The only way to be prepared for change is to get the proper exposure. For example, companies can send their employees overseas for exposure and also have them attend seminars regularly. Q: How do you accommodate young and ambitious employees in the organisation without creating animosity among the senior employees? A: I have on many occasions seen enthusiastic employees' ideas given during management meetings shot down by senior managers for no apparent reason. It's my opinion that we must not discourage eager employees like them as they are very capable in offering solid ideas. Therefore, it is important that the top management let everyone in the company know that they will support new ideas.

BC-Lithuania-Amber Room
Hunt begins for fabled czarist treasure
KLAIPEDA, Lithuania (AP) - German treasure hunters have begun combing a beach in Lithuania for the famed czarist Amber Room, allegedly buried there by Nazi forces, the Baltic News Service reported Monday. The beachcombers believe the cache includes panels from Czar Peter the Great's famed Amber Room, an ornate hall whose walls were made from the priceless, golden brown amber. It was a gift to Peter the Great from Prussian King Friedrich Wilhelm I, but the Nazis looted it from Leningrad in 1941. For the rest of World War II, the treasure was hidden in eastern Prussia, in the town of Kralovec. The search is focused in the dunes of the Neringa peninsula, a wind-swept sliver of land that runs parallel to Lithuania's Baltic Sea coast for more than 100 kilometers (60 miles). The German team is following leads by a former resident of the area who says he saw Nazi officers carrying boxes off a warship in 1944 and then bury them along the shore, BNS said. It did not name the resident or members of the German team. The fate of the Amber Room has long been a mystery and a source of speculation. The German government has said the panels were destroyed during the 1945 Soviet invasion of nearby Konigsberg now Kaliningrad, Russia. But Moscow has long insisted that the Nazis hid the treasure. The local office will kick off operations by providing customer support services to the company's distributors and partners here, said PeopleSoft Asia Pte Ltd's managing director Asean Robert Squires. According to Squires, PeopleSoft will also garner feedback from these partners in terms of additional requirements which are later channelled through the company's local outfit. ``The office will progressively grow to assist our partners in the execution of business,'' he told Computimes during a Press briefing in Subang Jaya last Thursday. Squires said PeopleSoft is continuing to invest in Asean despite the current economic downturn. ``The company is re-focusing on its core competencies and restructuring the business to be ready for the upturn of the economy when the time comes.'' He added that the time was right for the company to continue investing in the region. He said the company is confident that this is an effective and strategic decision for PeopleSoft and its distributors and partners. Commenting on the company's local distribution channel, Squires said PeopleSoft would maintain the existing structure, with no plans to either reduce or expand the network. The company's business this year, he said, is projected to grow but he declined to disclose any figures. ``It will be a slower one as compared to the company's growth in the last year,'' he said. At the same event, Squires also announced the official opening of a new office site in Singapore which serves as the company's business hub for Asean and the launch of PeopleSoft Version 7.5 enterprise application suite. The new suite, which offers the financials, distribution and manufacturing modules, will be available in the region next month while the human resources and payroll systems will be in the market in the fourth quarter of this year. YOUR magazine rightly suggests that the country's engine of growth -the construction sector - will and is gradually going to choke in the article entitled Spluttering Along In Fits And Starts (MB, March 16 issue). It also correctly points out that the onus of dragging the sector out of the quagmire will lie heavily on the shoulders of the three-year old Construction Industry Development Board or CIDB as it is more locally known. And boy what a task it has ahead of it! From the chart (Performance Of The Malaysian Construction Industry 1968-1998) which accompanied the article, it is perfectly clear that the local property/construction cycle is no different from that of any other country. We must, like them, go through a boom and bust period. We've had a veritable booming era for the last 10 years or so and will, for certain, go through a bust period. The question is, for how long or how short. And will it be a long but relatively painless, numbing affair or a short and excruciating period of contraction? The 12-member board was established on Dec 1, 1994 to co-ordinate the activities of the local construction industry and provide training and accreditation to local and foreign workers to ease the shortage of skilled workers in the construction sector. With the economic slowdown and the government's ongoing forced repatriation of many illegal workers, CIDB's role in enhancing the skills of both the locals and the legally employed foreign workers is all the more vital. Born at the height of the rocketing, booming real estate/construction development, CIDB will now have to cut its teeth and prove its mettle in a gradually deteriorating environment. The stormy winds of change is already being felt. Bank Negara Malaysia has dealt the first blow by labelling the real estate sector a non-productive sector; credit has been cut off and demand has plummeted. CIDB, to its credit, has already taken the first step in carrying out its ambitious targets. It has already set up, or is in the process of setting up, construction academies around the country with the primary aim of training the relatively unskilled workforce to meet the challenges of the millennium. It has also gone boldly to where no local consortia has ventured before ... it clinched several construction deals in Bosnia, Turkey and India and as your article states, it is also eyeing opportunities in Lebanon, Tunisia, etc. All this is fine and dandy when the construction sector was booming and the local pie was too small to be shared by so many fishes. The situation has changed now and it is for the worse. CIDB must now change track ... it must not act merely as the lynchpin for the big and rich construction companies by clinching lucrative overseas deals, but make a strong effort to assist the smaller fries in the local construction sector. With the local situation gradually deteriorating, many medium and smaller construction firms will find their very existence severely threatened. CIDB might well be their saviour in these difficult times. CIDB would do well to use this economic slowdown as a golden opportunity to push the smaller firms, who cannot yet compete on a global scale, into recognising the need for greater emphasis on innovation, and accelerate the restructuring of these firms from a labour-intensive dependency to one of high technology in line with the country's push towards information technology. For sure, it won't be an easy task but this is where the government has placed its trust in the CIDB. CIDB, therefore, will have to bring these small firms, kicking and screaming, into the era of a highly competitive domestic and foreign markets. It has the unenviable task of ensuring: that the local construction industry does not allow the stormy winds of change to go unheeded, that local construction businesses - whether Bumiputera companies or otherwise -respond proactively to the nation's changing circumstances, and that in order to back Malaysia's global ambitions, Malaysian construction firms must be determined to develop advanced strategies and technology, increase expenditure in research and development, skills training, education and infrastructure. With its zero growth forecast for the local industry, CIDB should see this period as the best opportunity to get its act going, to achieve all the aims and aspirations that led to its creation by the government and to be the catalyst in a soon-to-be moribund industry ... oh, what a challenge! Goh Kim Leong Cheras

Karachi Stock Market falls 128.76 to record low
KARACHI, Pakistan (AP) _ The Karachi Stock Market hit a record low on Monday falling 128.76 points to close at 911.44. ``There was massive liquidation by foreign investors and this put immense pressure on the market,'' said Hasan Davar, a trader with UBS Securities. The Karachi Stock Exchange opened Monday for the first time since Pakistan exploded five nuclear devices last Thursday and a sixth one on Saturday, bringing global condemnation and threats of economic sanctions. Within hours of the first five explosions, Pakistan's president declared a state of emergency and froze all foreign currency accounts to try to prevent a panic exodus of foreign capital from the country. Pakistan's foreign reserves stand at dlrs 1.2 billion, which is barely enough to pay for the next six weeks of imports, say financial analysts. Pakistan's Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz said last Friday that his government was preparing an economic recovery plan that would boost exports and reduce imports. Sharif announced across the board budget cuts of 25 percent in an attempt to reduce the impact of economic sanction. The stock market began to tumble immediately after India exploded the first of five nuclear devices three weeks ago. On May 8, the last trading day before India's May 11 explosion, the stock market closed at 1551. It has been on a downward slide since then.

IT IS NOT easy to establish a market base in Malaysia for a fledging Middle Eastern airline - especially when that airline does not even fly to Kuala Lumpur. Call it a daunting task, but that was the situation in 1991 when Emirates, the international airline of the United Arab Emirates, recognised Malaysia's potential and appointed a local company as its general sales agent (GSA). Says Emirates manager Malaysia Alban Lee, `There was much misconception and ignorance among the locals. In 1991, marketing Emirates in Malaysia was difficult. We were six years old. There was no flight out of Kuala Lumpur. If you wanted to fly with Emirates, you had to go to Singapore.' Another stumbling block was the common perception that Middle Eastern airlines are unreliable and offer scant frills. Fortunately, there was some consolation that many Westerners living in Malaysia already knew then of Emirates' growing reputation for fine service. `The primary aim at that time was to create awareness locally. The approach was to tell people that Emirates was an international, not a Middle Eastern, airline. The focus was on our services and product features. We were considered innovative for introducing inflight features such as a video system and a telephone for every seat, and fax machines,' says Lee. He adds that when people talked about the airline those days, it was either with envy or curiosity, depending on whether or not they were familiar with its service. He should know. Although he was appointed to head Emirates' Malaysian operations only in October 1996 when it began plying the Kuala Lumpur-Dubai route with three flights weekly, his ties with the airline extends further back. He was formerly with Emirates' GSA, Maple Travel (M) Sdn Bhd, and was its assistant general manager before joining the airline. Seven years on, the groundwork has proved to be solid. On April 1, the airline thickened its KL-Dubai route with a fourth frequency. By next year, Emirates would have added another flight. It plans to incre s frequency in the sector to daily flights in two years. The sector's passenger traffic has a healthy load factor of 82 per cent, and generated about RM20 million in income for the year ended March 31, 1998. This exceeded projections by 32 per cent. With Emirates taking delivery of two Boeing 777s and the first of 16 Airbus A330-200s by the end of the current financial year, passenger capacity will climb 20 per cent. The passenger traffic is forecast to grow by 25 per cent over the next financial year, indicating the airline's confidence that its yield will remain largely unaffected by Malaysia's economic slowdown. In fact, the ringgit's depreciation has made Malaysia a more attractive destination and has swollen demand for cargo space due to higher exports. However, as a scheduled airline, Emirates's priority is its passenger business. On the whole, Emirates' Malaysian operations contributed approximately 15 per cent of the airline's Pacific Rim revenue. Lee estimates that 80 per cent of Emirates' passengers in the KL-Dubai sector are holiday- makers. Business travellers are far fewer because trade between Malaysia and the Middle East is nominal. In the beginning, Emirates in Malaysia drew a sizeable chunk of its business from the expatriate community. Says Lee, `They responded very well because they were already familiar with what we had to offer. Typically, they had more exposure to Emirates in their home countries and needed less convincing. To put it arrogantly, they had been waiting for the product and now it's here. `It's more like a following. Most of these passengers fly to Dubai and proceed to popular Mediterranean destinations such as Turkey, Greece and Cyprus. For those who are sceptical or know little about us, we usually surprise by delivering more than expected. Eventually, people will learn to expect more from us. That will be the second phase. That is why we are always improving.' Emirates has a history of confounding the doubting Thomases. In his message in a corporate brochure, Emirates chairman Sheikh Ahmed Saeed Al Maktoum wrote, `The international regard in which Emirates is held today is very different from the tolerant scepticism which greeted its arrival on the aviation scene.' From an airline launched on October 25, 1985, with two leased aircraft and three routes, it has matured into the leading Middle Eastern airline with 44 destinations, the latest (to Malta) launched on March 30. Amsterdam is served as a cargo-only destination with Boeing 747 freighter leased from Atlas Air. It has gained attention in particular for its posh inflight amenities and its lengthening list of awards (151 at last count), mainly from trade and travel publications. Fleet expansion is a key component of the airline's growth programme. Emirates currently operates a fleet of 22 aircraft: nine Airbus A310-300s, six Airbus A300-600Rs, three Boeing 777-200As and four Boeing 777-200Bs. In November 1996, Emirates ordered 16 Airbus A330-200 aircraft, with options on a further seven, to replace its existing Airbus fleet. Emirates will begin receiving the A330-200s from January 1999, with deliveries to be completed in 2002. The new Airbus fleet will be powered by Rolls-Royce Trent engines as are the Boeing 777s. Emirates will be the only airline in the world with a fleet fully powered by Rolls-Royce engines. In August 1997, Sheikh Ahmed signed an agreement for two more Boeing 777-200 (long-range versions) on which Emirates has an option. The aircraft are expected to join the fleet during the last quarter of 1998. Like other carriers, Emirates also has to keep increasing its flights and destinations to strengthen business. An airline that aspires `to be a world-class, medium-sized airline by the year 2000' cannot afford to do less. `We are a young airline. We need to add frequencies to our destinations, including KL. We believe frequency sells,' says Lee. `We are also working to obtain more rights into new areas, but this can be difficult.' Fleet upgrading and award-winning service aside, Emirates still has quite a bit to aim for in Malaysia. Heading the agenda is making KL a mini-hub in the region. Explains Lee, `At the moment, at least 17 Emirates flights go through Singapore weekly. We hope to bring some of the flights to KL. Of course, the Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Sepang has to prove that it is as efficient and modern as it promises to be. If it can offer better handling, more airlines will come. Our goal is to fly more people into KL to take connecting flights to elsewhere in the region.' The other aspect to work on is to encourage more inbound traffic. According to Lee, most UAE nationals do not know much about Malaysia although it has many plus points such as the relatively lower costs and availability of halal food. He adds that all Emirates online stations have been directed to sell the Far East. In addition, Emirates in Dubai is working with Tourism Malaysia to promote Malaysia as a holiday spot. To gear up for imminent growth, the Malaysian operations will be increasing its staff, now comprising 15 people. The airline had planned to fly from KL to Jakarta but this has been put on hold due to Indonesia's economic crisis. There will eventually be flights from KL to Perth in Australia, as well. Says Lee, `We are committed. We are here to stay. Our Malaysia operations have proved to be profitable. We have as many frequencies as several other Far East destinations that came online earlier than did KL.'

Fontanelli wins 16th stage, Zuelle keeps overall lead

ASIAGO, Italy (AP) _ After a long breakaway from the main pack, Fabiano Fontanelli edged Paolo Bettini and Mario Scirea at the finish of the Tour of Italy's 16th stage Monday. That trio finished seven seconds ahead of a group of chasing riders and about 12 minutes ahead of the top contenders. But Fontanelli was in 77th place before the stage and not a threat to the favorites for the overall title. Alex Zuelle, who opened up a substantial overall lead with a dominating time-trial performance Sunday, retained the pink jersey heading into the toughest climbing stages. Fontanelli was timed in 5 hours, 53 minutes, 53 seconds over the 227 kilometers (140.5 miles) from Udine to Asiago, into the Dolomite mountains. (hjf)

ATTENTION to ergonomics makes Recaro seats different from other run-of-the-mill car seats. Jurgen Fritz, Recaro South East Asia Sdn Bhd managing director, says Recaro's design ensures a motorist sits properly with an emphasis on relieving the stress imposed on the spine and muslces. `Every Recaro seat offers correct ergonomics as well as comfort,' he says. Sitting ergonomically correctly requires the upholstery to be tailored to support the spine. Ergonomics, in fact, is the first cornerstone in the Recaro engineering design. The seat also needs cushioning properties to ease stress on the thighs. Seat height and tilt should be variable, giving the occupant complete control. Side bolsters on the seat cushion, lumbar support and backrest should be optimally-shaped for better support. Fritz says the basis of Recaro's unique construction principle is known as the closed back shell. `This provides the base for the ergonomically- shaped upholster. This is shaped in such a way that your weight is evenly distributed and your muscles remain relaxed,' he says. Its second cornerstone is safety. Recaro seats have a higher than normal backrest which provides optimum support for the entire back. Its fully- upholstered headrest is height and tilt adjustable, providing optimal damping of a head impact. Its back shell is entirely enclosed for improved protection from sliding luggage. The seat cushion is shaped with a strong cross member in the frame to prevent submarining in the event of a front collision, without which a person slides under the seat belt. Fritz says comfort is Recaro's third engineering cornerstone. `The design ensures reduced vibration, increased cushioning and optimum support,' he says. Throughout the world, Recaro seats are coveted for its upmarket appeal. `This is our fourth cornerstone - styling,' says Fritz. He says a good design always goes hand in hand with functionality. He says the Recaro design combines stylish elegance which blends well with the individual car's interior. `Our seats are predominantly made painstakingly by hand. This allows all aspects of the seat design to be meticulously prepared so that the completed seat fits together perfectly,' says Fritz.

ON THE cover of this issue of Malaysian Business is an Intel processor. Not just any old processor but the first Pentium II chip for mobile personal computers (PCs). Its introduction in April is particularly meaningful to Malaysia for two reasons: the launch was staged in Penang, and the processors roll off Intel's manufacturing lines in Kulim, Kedah. Another feather planted firmly in the cap of Intel Corporation's Malaysian operations. Intel Corporation is a company that excels by pursuing the future relentlessly, yet, its past is so rich it bears repeated mining. Its Malaysian history alone is interesting enough to fill a book. Actually, somebody has already authored such a tome. In 1991, Peggy Lim, a former Intel manager, came up with a 256-page hardcover entitled Steel: From Ashes Rebuilt to Manufacturing Excellence. The title refers to a fire that struck at the A1 assembly plant of Intel Technology Sdn Bhd - commonly known as Intel Malaysia - in Penang in the mid-70s. The company was just in its third year of operations on the island state. It was potentially an insurmountable setback. Then came the fightback. T-shirts bearing the slogan Intel Still Delivers were spotted all over Penang. Intel workers worked feverishly, some at nearby factories that had offered space, machinery and time slots. There must have been plenty of back-slapping and handshakes when the company shipped out crucial orders on time. The rest of Intel Malaysia's 25-year history may never reach such stirring heights, but it is still a colourful story of adversity, drive and achievement. It all began at the start of the 70s when Intel Corporation saw substance in the Penang leadership's vision to make the island an Asian Silicon Valley. When assembly operations began in 1972, several firsts were notched up. It was Intel's entry into Asia Pacific via its first offshore assembly plant, which cost RM4 million back then. Intel Malaysia was among Penang's high-tech pioneers, which explains why the company is invariably mentioned whenever government leaders speak about the state's progress and industrialisation. A few years later, Intel's senior management in Santa Clara, California, realised (but not without some persuasion) that the Penang operations could also handle the more complex job of testing microprocessors. That year, 1977, saw the opening of a second building at the Bayan Lepas site. Two decades on, the number of buildings swelled to 12, including several at Intel's test and assembly facility at the Kulim High-Tech Park. The Kulim operations are under another company, Intel Products (M) Sdn Bhd. The importance of Intel's Malaysian operations expanded accordingly. In July 1992, Intel Malaysia's then managing director P Y Lai sounded jubilant when he told reporters that Intel was transferring its entire microcontroller division in the United States to Penang. (Microcontrollers are programmed to control specific functions in products such as automobile engines, laser printers, disk drives and home appliances.) This was a huge step forward for Intel Malaysia, which was expected to rake in RM1 billion in annual turnover from the move. In Lai's words, it was `a milestone in the local electronics industry'. He, the first local MD of an Intel foreign unit, added, `This is probably the first time in Malaysia that a multinational is giving its offshore plant the total responsibility of handling the design, manufacturing and worldwide marketing of an important product.' And when Intel decided it was time to have a presence in China, who did it call? Intel Malaysia, according to an August 1992 news report. It quoted Lai as saying the headquarters directed the Malaysian subsidiary to negotiate with Chinese authorities on investing in the semi-conductor industry there. Today, Intel Malaysia and Intel Products' operations extend beyond testing and assembling Intel's most advanced microprocessors. The Penang plant has a packaging technology development lab and a design centre. In 1994, Intel transferred the sales and marketing of its Embedded Microcontroller Division to Penang. The Kulim plant, which opened in 1996, also churns out computer motherboards and networking/communications boards. In the mid-90s, Intel decided the time was right to have a sales and marketing presence in Malaysia. Malaysia had the highest consumption rate of PCs with Intel's Pentium processors. A representative office was opened in Kuala Lumpur in December 1995. These days, the sales and marketing operations are handled by Intel Electronics (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd, which is headed by a country manager. The company focuses on developing the domestic PC consumer market, promoting Intel's brand awareness, and working with the government and original equipment manufacturers or OEMs to help grow the Malaysian computer market. To be sure, Intel's Malaysian operations suffered other hiccups apart from the Penang plant blaze. In the early days, pilferage was an annoying and costly problem. That has since been remedied by tightening security so much that even Intel boss Craig Barrett is subjected to metal detector scans when he visits the plants. In August 1992, a 19-year-old contract worker was found dead in a liquid nitrogen filling station at the Penang facility. It was the first work- related fatality in Intel's history. This prompted Andrew Grove, the then Intel Corporation president, to issue on the same day a five-page memo addressed to all employees, detailing steps taken in the wake of the incident. Whatever measures instituted since must have worked well, for in 1995, the Human Resources Ministry gave Intel Malaysia a national award for occupational safety and health. Collecting awards seems to be part and parcel of Intel's Malaysian operations. In 1990, Intel Malaysia was named the first recipient of the Prime Minister's Quality Award. That year, it also added to its trophy cabinet a regional award for human resources development. The following year, it received The Intel Quality Award, an in-house honour, true, but prestigious nevertheless given the company's reputation for exacting standards. It has another accolade from the Human Resources Ministry, The Caring Employer Award, presented in 1993. Indeed, Intel Malaysia is clearly run on the principle that a happy employee is a productive employee. In 1991, for example, it became the first manufacturer in Penang to have its own bas kilang fleet by forking out several million ringgit to buy 230 air-conditioned coaches. The company takes care not to call its workers `operators'. According to a news article in April 1991, the term connotes a lower standing. Instead workers who handle highly automated machines are called technicians or computer programmers. Another mark in the plus column for Intel Malaysia is its vendor partnership programme, through which it helps develop its suppliers through a combination of nurturing, tutoring and prodding.

CALL IT A surreal moment. Intel Corporation president and chief operating officer Craig R Barrett had just finished a presentation in Penang on the chip-maker's global business strategy and was moving around at the front of the room, speaking to journalists and posing (a tad awkwardly) for pictures. Then, he stopped walking and unconsciously stood, all 1.88m of him, in front of a slide projector. Via a shaft of strong light, an image was emblazoned on his white shirt. It was the company's name in electric blue. There it was, so fortuitously symbolic, no public relations orchestration could have engineered it better - Barrett had Intel inside! Indeed, this is the man who will soon be at the wheel of one of the most influential forces of the global digital revolution. Come May 20, Intel's board of directors will elect Barrett, 58, as the company's fourth chief executive officer (CEO) in its 30-year history. This was announced shortly before he arrived in Penang on the night of April 1 as part of a busy swing through five Asia-Pacific countries in as many days. He gave the talk the morning after. Letting go of the CEO title is Andrew Grove, who has promoted `only the paranoid survive' to a management creed. As chairman, Grove will continue to work full-time, dwelling more on `broad strategic issues concerning the industry and Intel'. Intel's first two CEOs were the late Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore, now chairman emeritus. The duo, together with Grove, are widely seen as Intel's founding triumvirate. To an outsider, Grove's shoes seem impossibly large for Barrett to fill. After all, the former is an icon of commerce. He was Time Magazines' 1997 Man of the Year. A book, Forbes Great Minds of Business, says he is `widely regarded as the best corporate manager in America'. Most importantly, nobody disputes that the highly-respected Grove has helmed Intel (and the computer industry, to a certain extent) to a lofty position during his 11 years as CEO. Its sales ballooned from US$ 1.9 billion in 1987 to US$ 25.1 billion last year (see chart 1). Barrett too has an impressive record of his own, albeit one that is best appreciated by people familiar with the ins and outs of Intel. After getting his Bachelor of Science, Master of Science and PhD degrees in material science from Stanford University, he stayed on to teach. He was associate professor at Stanford when he left in 1974 to join Intel as technology development manager. He was named chief operating officer in 1993. Last May, he became Intel's fourth president. Barrett is consistently singled out as the person who has transformed Intel's manufacturing operations into a remarkably efficient and productive machine that is the key to Intel's dominance in the microprocessor market. But why not let the straight-talking Grove hand out the endorsement? When announcing the decision to make Barrett CEO, he credited Barrett as the architect of Intel's operations throughout the last decade. Analysts have given the thumbs up to the impending baton handover, pointing out that Intel now needs an experienced operational man as leader, someone who can slash costs in the face of falling prices of personal computers (PCs) and chips. Intel executives, Barrett included, are apt to insist that it will be business as usual despite the leadership change. At the same time, in an exclusive interview with Malaysian Business, Barrett reveals an acute awareness of the urgency for Intel to continue evolving as market conditions and the global economy shift. Excerpts: You are among several prominent personalities in the information technology (IT) industry who have visited this region recently. Do you feel that Intel is spoilt for choice when deciding on investments in the Asia-Pacific region? Not necessarily. The Asia Pacific is the fastest growing region for the PC industry and we intend to increase our presence in the region. We are always looking at investment opportunities but there are many factors to weigh. Malaysia is one of our choices because we've been here for 25 years. Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad was abroad when you came here last June and during this visit as well. If you had met him, what would you have discussed? Yes, I am keen to meet him. I would like to ask him about the progress of the Multimedia Super Corridor project. And for the simple reason that we have a 25-year history in Malaysia, we hope to gain some insight on long-term prospects and plans. We are also interested in his views on how we can contribute, educational initiatives regarding IT, electronic government ... There are many things we can talk about. A recurring message in your visits to the Asia-Pacific is that developing countries need to spend between three and 3.5 per cent of their gross domestic product (GDP) on IT to make their businesses more competitive globally. What exactly needs to be done and who should do it? This is an observation based on the fact that the IT spending in the United States is between three and 3.5 per cent of its GDP. The figure in developing countries is certainly lower and should be increased for competitiveness. If others are spending more and you are not, you will be left behind. It is a huge, complex effort. It should start with education and be carried over into government. Big business and small business must play a part too. The problem is some organisations are run by gray-haired people who look like me. They tend to resist such changes. This was the case in Europe until recently. The government can help by playing a leadership role. Big business has to be aggressive in adopting IT as a productivity tool. If a government leader or a company president uses IT, the rest will follow. Intel's mission these days is, in your words, `to create more new uses for PCs and find more new users for PCs', thus assuming a leadership role to expand the industry. There doesn't seem to be any parallel to this in other industries. Will there come a time when Intel will feel that it is taking on too much? As far as I can tell, there is no parallel to what we are doing in the IT industry. We are spending billions on our efforts. We have to. We are at the centre of the industry, not at its periphery. We already have almost a 90 per cent share of the market (for PC microprocessors). We can't go much bigger than that. We have to grow the pie. Take any IT industry survey and it will show a 15 to 18 per cent annual growth. This is a wonderful, unique industry. It is anti-inflationary. Not many industries can match such growth. It is a crazy industry, in a positive way, of course. Industry watchers are upbeat about your impending appointment as CEO because of your operational expertise. Although you have already been overseeing Intel's operations for several years, will there be big changes when you take over? There will not be any revolutions. For me, regaining a strong growth rate for Intel is most important. Historically, we were growing between 25 and 30 per cent a year. We want to be back at that level. (Intel's revenue grew by 20 per cent last year. Its revenue for the first quarter of 1998 is eight per cent lower than that of the previous quarter. This was attributed to the unexpectedly weaker demand for its PC chips.) I also want Intel to move aggressively into some new products and business areas, such as networking, electronic commerce, interactive entertainment and flash memory. You have often been described as competitive. But is that the same as paranoid? Or is there a need to be paranoid at all? Of course you have to be paranoid. One has to be paranoid in the IT industry. When you have a total turnover of your product line every 12 months, how can you afford not to be? If we are not paranoid, we stand to lose 90 per cent of our revenue. We like to compete very hard. Grove was quoted as saying that Noyce (Intel founding CEO) insisted that there was a technical solution to everything, while Grove believed in organisational or process solutions. Where do you stand? We have seen a transition in Intel's senior management from emphasising inventing to focusing on several equally important fronts. We progressed from a fundamentally technical venture to a combination of strong technology, products and marketing. Over the years, we have developed a wide-ranging approach to business with several degrees of expertise. We invest heavily in capital, research and development (RD) and marketing. Very few companies have big budgets for all three areas. Take Microsoft for instance. It spends a lot on RD and marketing but its capital cost is small; it costs next to nothing to manufacture software. (After elaborating on the different styles and strengths of Intel's previous three CEOs) Each CEO has shaped Intel in his own way. So how do you hope to shape Intel? Intel is increasingly becoming an international company. Today, less than 50 per cent of our products are sold in the US. We need to allocate resources to other countries to work with foreign companies and governments. We aim to have major market presence in these countries, not just by selling our products but also through other aspects such as brand recognition, awareness about IT and contributions to education and training. The other thing I would like to be remembered for is Intel expanding into new business areas and products.

BC-Sports-Golf-LPGA Rochester, 1st Ld-Writethru,0354
Rosie Jones wins Rochester International
By BEN DOBBIN Associated Press Writer
ROCHESTER, New York (AP) _ Rosie Jones reopened a four-stroke lead, then came back to the field with back-to-back bogeys before finally winning the rain-plagued Rochester International today. Jones barely matched par on the first nine Sunday _ at which point final-round play was halted after repeated rain delays _ but roared back with a 35-foot (10-meter) birdie putt on No. 10 and a 12-footer (4-meter) for birdie on No. 12. She dropped shots on No. 14 after getting tangled in the trees and No. 15, where she three-putted, then steadied down to complete an even-par round and finish at 9-under-par, or 279, at the par-72 Locust Hill course. It was her ninth victory, and 126th top-10 finish, in 16 years on tour. She took home dlrs 105,000 of dlrs 700,000 in prize money. Juli Inkster vaulted into second place with a 4-under 68, rubbing out an opening bogey on No. 14 with an 18-foot (5 1/2-meter) birdie putt on No. 16 and a 3-foot (1-meter) birdie putt on the next hole to finish at 7-under. ``I was so wired last night, I didn't sleep well at all,'' she said. Hollis Stacy, who had halved Jones' 4-stroke lead to two on Sunday, dropped to third place with a 70 to finish at 6-under. Stacy, 44, captured 17 tournaments between 1977 and 1985, including the Women's Open in 1977, 1978 and 1984. She has won just once since then, in 1991. One back were Meg Mallon, who closed with a 67, Moira Dunn and Sherri Steinhauer. The 38-year-old Jones, who won the Rochester International in 1991 and lost to Kathy Whitworth in a playoff in 1984, had opened up a 4-stroke lead over Steinhauer on Saturday with an 8-under 64. Swirling winds, flashes of lightning and heavy bouts of rain stopped play for a total of 5 1/2 hours Sunday, eventually leading to a postponement. Defending champion Penny Hammel slumped to 4-over, one ahead of South Korean rookie Se Ri Pak, who led the LPGA Championship from start to finish two weeks ago.

INTEL Corporation's top bosses love to use a photograph taken in Penang whenever they want to illustrate how much the Asia Pacific has progressed since the high-tech giant first ventured into the region. Chairman and chief executive officer (CEO) Andrew Grove used it last November when delivering the keynote address at the Asia-Pacific Information Technology Summit in San Francisco. More recently, Intel president and chief operating officer Craig R Barrett - who will take over as CEO later this month - found the picture just as handy for his April 2 presentation in Penang on the company's global business strategy. Taken circa 1971 when Grove was visiting the building site of Intel's pioneer plant in Bayan Lepas, the photograph shows a dark-haired and bespectacled version of him sporting a moustache and sideburns. He was standing barefoot in a muddy road with his pants rolled up to mid-calf level. What happened was Grove's car had gotten stuck in the mud. He recalled being helped by people herding water buffaloes nearby, but to no avail. In the end, he had to walk sans shoes to the site. Both men followed up on the first picture with a current one showing Intel's sprawling test and assembly complex at the Bayan Lepas Free Industrial Zone. `Things have changed a little bit since then,' Barrett understated. Intel, whose microprocessors power close to 90 per cent of the world's personal computers (PCs), has big plans to broaden its presence in the Asia-Pacific region. And Malaysia looks set to benefit, thanks primarily to the company's longstanding investment ties here. It is certainly a folly to ignore the region's rapid embrace of IT. International Data Corporation, an IT market research and consulting house, forecasts a compounded average growth rate of 12 per cent for IT spending in Asia Pacific for the period 1997 to 2002. Last year, the region's IT spending stood at US$ 50.3 billion (US$ 1 RM3.80) and can reach US$ 88.2 billion in the year 2002. In addition, the Internet explosion (Asia has the fastest growth), the soaring investment in IT infrastructure and the potential to become the world's PC development centre combine to bestow Asia Pacific with an irresistible pull. A breakdown of Intel's revenue pretty much indicates the same upward trend. In 1987, six per cent of its income came from Asia Pacific (excluding Japan). A decade later, the proportion has swelled to 19 per cent. Japan's contribution for both years was 10 per cent. Describing Asia Pacific as a hot area for PC consumption growth, Barrett says Intel is increasing its presence in the region not only through manufacturing and support, but also through sales and marketing. Of the company's total capital expenditure of US$ 4.5 billion last year, US$ 1 billion landed in Asia. On the 1998 projections, Barrett says the global investment should be about US$ 5 billion, with US$ 1.3 billion targeted for Asia Pacific. This year, he added, Intel would invest between US$ 400 million and US$ 500 million in Malaysia. The amount will be spent mainly on upgrading and expanding its test and assembly plants in Penang and Kulim, Kedah, and on an integrated warehouse at the Penang airport. Barrett reckons that among electronics players, his company is the number one investor in Malaysia in 1998. To date, Intel has spent US$ 1.2 billion on capital investment here. This has fuelled expansion of its Malaysian manufacturing operations over 25 years to now include a dozen industrial buildings in Penang and Kulim in which workers test and assemble microprocessors and a few other computer components. Research and development (RD) activities are focused on design and packaging technology. Some 7,000 workers are employed at the plants. Intel's sales and marketing operations in Malaysia started in 1995 when it opened a representative office. A current focus is to drum up business by promoting wider IT use among small and medium-scale industries. Another measure to increase sales is to aggressively reduce prices. It is only to be expected that Intel has signed up for a slot in the Multimedia Super Corridor (MSC) project. It was reported in February that Barrett had been named a member of the MSC's International Advisory Panel. He says, `We are still looking at options for being a part of the MSC, and what makes maximum sense with our partners in this area. We are definitely committed to having a presence there. Perhaps, it will be in the form of a stand-alone RD facility.' Intel's MSC-status company is registered as Intel Malaysia Design Centre MSC Sdn Bhd. Intel Technology Sdn Bhd's (also referred to as Intel Malaysia's) managing director Wong Siew Hai says the idea was to set up a development centre, only that it had not been decided what exactly would be developed. A full-time manager is working on the venture. Intel's push in Asia Pacific is not just about pouring in money. Barrett demonstrated this with frequent trips to the region that often include chats with government and industry leaders to propel Intel's `New Users, New Uses' drive. The aim is to encourage people to turn to IT and to nurture the creation of IT tools. More computers sold equates more Intel chips sold. Barrett's latest Asian tour was his third in less than a year. Between March 30 and April 3, his whistlestops also included South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand and Australia. `IT is the key to competitiveness in the future. That's not a terribly hard sell. If you come to a place like Malaysia, you don't have to talk very hard to the government to convince it that an IT infrastructure is very important, with the MSC and other IT projects the Malaysian government has underway,' says Barrett, adding that South Korea and the Philippines too have similar initiatives. `So every country is, in fact, looking for opportunities to create a strong infrastructure in IT. And I don't think they're necessarily competing. I think they're very complementary in many instances because one of the ways to create a strong local infrastructure is to have the capability for both hardware and software development in your country.' Despite these reassuring words, the competition for foreign IT investment remains a sweaty, high-stakes battle; the neighbours are equally eager to reap Intel's dollars and knowhow. It was recently reported that Thailand had persuaded Intel to provide technology to kickstart its Software Park. There have also been reports that South Korea was anticipating Intel to invest in a big way. Perhaps, the most telling development came in the Down Under leg of his last Asian tour. There, he met Prime Minister John Howard and senior ministers reportedly to work out a financial package that might get Intel to set up a wafer fabrication plant (or fab in industry jargon) in Australia. Such an investment is said to be worth up to A$6 billion (A$1 RM2.50). Some reports characterised the meeting as something of a hard bargaining session. `If you want to put a fab in Malaysia, you would probably get a 10-year tax holiday,' the Australian Financial Review quoted Barrett as saying. The question of Intel investing in a fab in Malaysia has come up before. Wong says it is a `totally different ball game'. He explains that fab operations have stringent and critical infrastructural needs, including water, gas and electricity. `With a few fabs set to operate in the Kulim Hi-Tech Park, hopefully it can be demonstrated that Malaysia has the capabilities to support such operations,' he adds. In arriving at its upbeat outlook on the Asia-Pacific region, Intel has not overlooked the Asian economic gloom. It is simply that the company is often guided by the philosophy of co-founder and chairman emeritus Gordon Moore. Barrett cites an oft-repeated Moore dictum: `You can never recover from a recession on the basis of the products you had when the recession started. You can only pull out of the recession on the basis of new products.' Says Barrett, `So if there is one message I would like to give the industries, governments and people of Southeast Asia during this crisis is that this is the time - probably the most important time - to invest and move forward.'

Hall to step down as Newcastle chairman
NEWCASTLE, England (AP) _ Newcastle United announced Monday Sir John Hall would step down as chairman, his caretaker stint complete following the controversial resignations two months ago of Freddy Shepherd and Douglas Hall. Sir John's departure follows last week's boardroom shake-up at parent company Newcastle United PLC when chairman Sir Terence Harrison and non-executive director John Mayo quit. In a statement, the company said it would ``consider the structure and complement of both the PLC and the football club boards immediately after'' new appointments were in place. Former chairman Shepherd and vice-chairman Douglas Hall quit in disgrace in the wake of well documented allegations that the pair made derogatory comments about the club's fans, Newcastle women, England skipper Alan Shearer and manager Kenny Dalglish. Sir John was subsequently recalled as chairman to stabilize the club but marked his return by defending his son and Shepherd for the contribution they had made to reviving Newcastle's fortunes. Those remarks sparked fears among fans that Shepherd and Douglas Hall would eventually return to the Newcastle boardroom. Sir John's decision to step down could heighten speculation the pair will soon be back on the board. (jp/scw)

Accused killer and drug trafficker Jose Luis Lopez, alias ``El Tamaulipeco,'' was handed over to Mexican authorities by U.S. authorities in the border city of Hidalgo, Coahuila, official news agency Notimex reported Sunday. Lopez is wanted by two Federal District judges on organized crime and murder charges. He is also wanted by judges in the Pacific Coast states of Michoacan and Oaxaca and by a city judge in Guadalajara involving murder and organized crime charges. In concordance with the Mexico-U.S. extradition treaty, Lopez's extradition is being handled by the Foreign Relations Secretariat, a federal agency, and not state or city departments. Lopez and two accused accomplices are required to make declarations before the two Federal District judges, Cruz Lilia Romero Ramirez and Patricia Gudino Rodriguez on murder, assault and battery and organized crime charges. The Mexico City Attorney General's Office (PGJDF) said the 42-year-old Lopez is originally from Nuevo Laredo, Tamps, the Mexican city directly opposite Laredo, Texas, on the Mexico-U.S. border. The PGJDF reported Lopez had served three years in a prison in Huntsville, Texas, for attempted murder of his wife. Lopez was handed over by Texas police at the city gate of Hidalgo, Coahuila, a border town that lies across the Rio Grande from Texas and which lies very close to Nuevo Laredo. Judicial police from Mexico City and Tamaulipas took him into immediate custody. Lopez currently is imprisoned in Mexico City's Northern Penitentiary.

Monitors at Paris' main airports offered a bleak sight for passengers: departure screens flashing ``annule'' and ``canceled'' in bright red letters next to nearly all Air France flights nine days before the soccer championship begins. The jets of the official airline for the World Cup, many decorated with players representing the 32 teams, sat idle at terminals. The walkout would be Air France's biggest in 27 years if it lasts the 15 days striking pilots have threatened, and was a serious embarrassment to the leftist government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin. Frustrated passengers lined up at Air France ticket counters at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris, hoping to switch their tickets to other carriers. Nicolas Minvelle, hoping to leave on vacation to Senegal, said it wasn't fair the pilots were striking ahead of the World Cup, being played in 10 cities across France. ``They use an international event to bother everyone, it's too bad. Yelena Panteley, a Russian student from California, was on her way to see her mother in Saint Petersburg, hoping to catch an alternate flight. ``There is hope, but nothing's sure.'' Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with stocks falling more than 10 By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russian stocks fell more than 10 percent Monday, despite new government efforts to sooth jittery investors and U.S. promises to support new loans by international lenders. The Russian Trading System closed down 10.2 percent, after Russian banks continued their frantic selling and western investors stayed away from trading. The market has fallen 44 percent since the beginning of May, and there are fears of further losses before calm is restored. The Central Bank has intervened to prop up the ruble and tripled a key interest rates to 150 percent to persuade investors to stay in Russia. In a brief statement issued Sunday, President Bill Clinton expressed U.S. support for aid to Russia from such multinational institutions as the World Bank and the IMF. On Monday, Russia's new tax chief stressed the government has enough cash reserves to protect the ruble against devaluation, but said additional help from the International Monetary Fund would help calm investors shaken by last week's wave of panic selling that caused the market to plummet. Boris Fyodorov, who was appointed by President Boris Yeltsin on Friday, said another dlrs 5 billion would be enough. Before the crisis, Russia's economic prospects had been looking somewhat brighter, with the government having kept a lid on inflation and recording its first economic growth since the 1991 Soviet collapse. But the government has been unable to solve a years-long payments crisis, caused by its inability to collect taxes and therefore to pay wages to state workers. Many workers and pensioners have been unpaid for months. Fyodorov said in an earlier television interview that the country's 35 percent tax rate must be lowered but enforcement strengthened. ``The rate should be 20 percent, but then those who do not pay must in effect be put into prison,'' he told the NTV network. Russian leaders have said that the economic crisis was triggered by a combination of forces, including a sharp fall in world prices for gas and oil, the financial crisis in southeast Asia, and social unrest including a recent wave of coal miners' strikes. In a move to ease the crisis, IMF officials said Friday that they will recommend releasing a delayed payment of dlrs 700 million, the latest installment of an existing dlrs 10 billion loan. Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko, moving to cut government spending, Monday ordered a 30 percent reduction in Cabinet personnel, the ITAR-Tass news agency said. Cabinet staffing will be cut from 1,450 people to 1,015, the report said. (pvs/ls)

BC-Sports-Golf-TPC of Europe
Westwood holds off Clarke by a stroke to win TPC of Europe
ALVESLOHE, Germany (AP) _ England's Lee Westwood Monday needed a 20-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole to end Darren Clarke's late charge and capture his second title of the year at the TPC of Europe. Westwood, the 25-year-old Ryder Cup player, fired a 66 and 23-under 265 to stave off Clarke's challenge by a shot after letting a four-stroke lead melt away at the dlrs 1.9 million tournament. Clarke charged by stringing together four birdies on his last five holes, before Westwood shook off his first bogey of the day on the 16th with the clutch putt. ``I finally closed the door, so it's the biggest birdie of the week,'' said Westwood. ``It's difficult when a player like Clarke is chasing you. He can birdie every hole.'' Clarke, of Northern Ireland, finished with a 4-under 68 and 266 while Masters champion Mark O'Meara was third at 269 and a final round 70. The American, playing his first European tournament since winning at Augusta, also chased Clarke but shot himself out of contention with a double bogey on the 11th hole. Westwood's title was his first in Europe this season, having earlier won on the other side of the Atlantic at the Freeport McDermott Classic held in New Orleans. Fighting a steady wind, Westwood's 6-under 66 came after he fired a course record Sunday with 61. ``It's the first time I've ever done that _ hopefully it's not the last,'' said Westwood of the two low rounds. Bernhard Langer finished with a 68 and 271, along with Ireland's Philip Walton. The German, a two-time winner of the tournament, also dropped out of contention with a double bogey on his second hole. ``You just want to stick your head in the sand _ I'm very happy with my round after that,'' said Langer, still searching for his first title this season. The scores, although low, were nothing compared to Sunday's third round when Westwood shattered the course record and O'Meara matched it. ``I'm surprised the scores weren't better. Maybe we used up all the birdies yesterday,'' said Walton, whose fourth-place finish came after he missed five straight cuts. (rk)
