BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Romania
Romania sets sights on semi-finals
SAFTICA, Romania (AP) _ Romania's soccer team hopes to make it into the semi-finals of this summer's World Cup in France, topping its performance of four years ago, when it fell in the quarter-finals. ``We might qualify for semi-finals if we play well,'' said Gheorghe Popescu, a key part of Romania's defense, who plays professionally for Turkey's champion Galatasaray. His teammate with Galatasaray, Gheorghe Hagi, known as ``the Maradona of the Carpathians,'' said Romania's most difficult game would be its first one, June 15 against Colombia. Although Romania beat Colombia in 1994 play, the first match is often the toughest psychologically. Dan Petrescu, a player for England's Chelsea, said Romania's tournament strategy will depend on whether the team beats Colombia. Romania plays in Group G, along with Colombia, England and Tunisia. Romania and England are considered the front-runners. Romania scored nine victories and one draw qualifying for the World Cup. The team achieved its best showing in the 1994 World Cup, beating Colombia and the United States in the first round, and even Argentina in a wild second-round match. Romania later fell to Sweden in the quarter-finals. The national team currently trains at their base of Saftica, 20 kilometers (12 miles) north of Bucharest. Coach Anghel Iordanescu is expected to announce the line-up for the World Cup soon. Romania will have two warm-up games, with Paraguay and Moldova, before leaving June 8 for France. (ma/cc/mh/scl)

MAIN board-listed Arus Murni Corporation Bhd (AMCB) is doing a volteface, both in terms of strategy and shareholders. Jettisoning finance, the company is pole-vaulting into property. Specifically, AMCB is selling its crown jewel, finance company Kewangan Bersatu Bhd (KBB), to Hong Leong Finance Bhd. The sale, of course, was in line with Bank Negara's drive to pare Malaysia's 39 finance companies down to eight. At the time of writing, details on price and mode of payment were not available. As of last month, Hong Leong Bank, Hong Leong Finance's parent company, was still conducting a due diligence audit on KBB. However, would AMCB prefer cash or something else? Probably cash, if its proposed property purchases get approved by the authorities and AMCB shareholders. In February, AMCB announced a series of acquisitions that would probably replace the lost income streams from KBB. These acquisitions will be paid in cash. Notably, AMCB will be buying a slew of Singaporean and Malaysian property companies from parties acting in concert with Singaporean property tycoon Eric Tan Eng Huat, also dubbed the Geylang King for his lucrative forays into the republic's property market. Torie International Pte Ltd (TIPL), which is controlled by Tan, will emerge as a substantial shareholder in AMCB. AMCB's controlling shareholder, Arus Murni Sdn Bhd - which is helmed by former Idris Hydraulic company secretary Mohd Faiz Abdullah - will sell 37.64 million AMCB shares and 9.41 million AMCB warrants. In toto, these constitute 22 per cent of total AMCB shares in issue and 16 per cent of warrants outstanding as at Feb 6, 1998. However, no mention was made of the quantum or mode of payment in the proposal. At the current price of 87.5 sen per AMCB share and 31 sen per warrant, the stake would cost TIPL RM35.9 million or about S$15 million - pretty cheap entree for Tan into the KLSE. Is AMCB getting a good deal? Overall, it seems the pre-tax profit would get a boost. For the half year ended June 30, 1997, AMCB suffered a group pre-tax loss of RM11.1 million on the back of interest income of RM116.98 million. Loss per share was 8.6 sen against earnings per share of 1.64 sen during the previous period. At the same time, cash reserves might be eroded and leveraging may rise. All in all, AMCB will fork out an aggregate cash consideration of RM117.4 million for the proposed Singapore acquisitions and RM289.7 million for the proposed Malaysian acquisitions. Properties were valued according to open market valuations as of different dates and using different methods by independent valuers. According to the proposal, the acquisitions are expected to be financed by the disposal of KBB, internal funds and bank borrowings. At the same time, net tangible asset per share of AMCB will decrease from RM1.79 to RM1.33. However, this is prior to the disposal of KBB. NTA post-KBB sale was not quantified because `the disposal consideration has not been determined at this juncture.' But, optimistically, earnings per share won't be diluted due to an increase in paid-up since no new shares are being issued. What was the rationale behind the proposed acquisitions? On one hand, the Singapore properties will enable AMCB to earn foreign exchange, a crucial consideration in the light of the ringgit's recent vagaries. The properties in Singapore comprise mainly completed residential and commercial units. Of course, points out a Singaporean observer, `The Singaporean property market hasn't been too healthy lately, so demand for the AMCB properties may not be that stunning.' The Malaysian properties comprise commercial, industrial, residential and recreational properties, located in mainly Johor Baru, with the balance in central Malacca and Ipoh. AMCB's Johor Baru jewel - the JB Waterfront City, a `self-contained metropolis to be built on a ``above-the- water'' concept on the Straits of Johor. Started in April 1997 and poised for completion by December 2000, assuming no hitches, this `Waterfront' will be Johor's new central business district. To safeguard its interests, AMCB will be getting a profit guarantee for the property companies. The vendors of the Malaysian property companies have guaranteed profit before tax of RM18 and RM21 million for the first and second calendar year respectively, starting from the completion date of the proposed restructuring. Likewise, the vendors of the Singapore property companies shall guarantee a profit before taxation for the first year of RM17 million and the second year of RM14 million. The guarantee ensures that the group's profit before taxation will not be less than RM35 million per annum for the two calendar years commencing from completion of restructuring. Discounting the profit guarantee, the Singaporean companies should be profitable based on their track record. Profit after tax and minority interests for the companies was S$13.72 million for the period from July 1, 1996 until Sept 30 1997 as compared to S$3.57 million for the period from July 1, 1995 till June 30, 1996.

BC-UN-Brazil-Drought
Brazil's food and crop situation critical, U.N. agency says
ROME (AP) _ Up to 10 million people in northeastern Brazil could go hungry this year because of one of the worst droughts in 15 years, a U.N. agency reported Monday. It said grain output will be half of normal and plantings of some crops have been cut up to 90 percent in some areas. The Rome-based Food and Agriculture Organization said up to 4.8 million people might starve. Half the land in the region, which has had no rain in six months, is a virtual desert, the FAO said, and the situation might worsen if the drought continues through December, as forecasts say. Grain production in the region is expected to reach just 4.5 tons, half the normal production, the FAO said. Plantings of rice and beans, staples of the local diet, have been cut sharply, in some locations by as much as 80 percent. Maize plantings are down 60 percent to 90 percent in some areas, and other crops, like coffee and sugar cane, are also severely affected. Although droughts are not unusual in the northeast, experts say El Nino has exacerbated the situation. (ar/cph)

LAST week share prices on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange closed broadly lower with movements confined within the support and resistance ranges on lack of fresh leads. The KLSE Composite Index staged several re-tests of its 544 support but gave way in the afternoon trades on May 29, this year. The relatively thin market volume reflected investors' current stand of sidelining their trading activities. On May 25 the KLSE CI opened on a weak note as investors felt there were no fresh incentives to enter the market. On the regional front, investors would like to see more stability before returning to the market. The KLSE CI closed 6.68 points lower to 570.55 level. Renewed weakness on the regional equities markets dampened market sentiment on the domestic front. It was also affected by news that the gross domestic product growth for the first quarter of this year was not very encouraging. Given the bearish influences on both the domestic and regional front, the KLSE CI drifted lower to 561.34 level on May 26, 1998, giving a loss of 9.21 points, or 1.61 per cent. The KLSE CI drifted even lower on May 27 on weakness of Japanese Yen. The wide fluctuations on the New York stock market was another contributing factor in dampening market sentiment on the local bourse. The KLSE CI closed 9.06 points, or 1.61 per cent, lower to 552.28 level. Overall market drifted lower on May 28 on continuing negative perception of the local and regional front. Economists and analysts were further concerned by the prospect of lower economic growth this year than forecasted earlier. The KLSE CI dropped another 7.54 points, or 1.37 per cent, to 544.74 level. The KLSE CI's technical rebound to 549.94 in the morning trades on May 29 soon fizzled out as sellers took the opportunity to liquidate. The overall market sentiment was still fragile when most stocks gave up their early morning gains. It closed at the week's lowest level at 538.24 level. Reflecting the continuing weak market sentiment, the KLSE CI fell 38.99 points, or 6.76 per cent, over the week to close at its lowest level at 538.24 points on May 29. The KLSE All Share EMAS Index dropped 8.41 points, or 5.80 per cent, to 136.51 level. The KLSE Industrial Index lost 69.23 points, or 6.27 per cent, to 1,035.40 level. The KLSE Second Board Index declined 4.69 points, or 4.04 per cent, to 111.47 level. Chartwise, the KLSE CI traced out five consecutive trading days' losses of 38.99 points, or 6.76 per cent. It had given up all its gains registered during the previous week's technical rebound to 596.09 level on May 21. Since then, it was almost a straight line decline. Following are the readings of some of its technical indicators:-Moving Averages: The KLSE CI continued to stay below all its 10-, 20-, 30-, 50-, 100- and 200-day moving averages. Momentum Index: Its short-term momentum index failed in its attempt on May 27 to overcome its resistance at the zero reference line. On Balance Volume: Its short-term OBV trend had since turned down below its 10-day exponential moving averages. Relative Strength Index: Its 14-RSI had since reversed from its recent peak at 46.01 level on May 21 to 31.77 level on May 29 OUTLOOK: Overall market had since weakened further on lack of fresh leads from both the domestic and regional front. Renewed weakness on the regional bourses coupled with the uncertainties of the regional currencies, particularly the Japanese Yen, dampened the market sentiment further. The KLSE CI fell below this column's envisaged support levels. It even breached the clustered support at 544 level before moving lower to close at 538.24 points on May 29. Following the KLSE CI's breakdown below the 544 support level, the KLSE CI has tentatively resumed its downside consolidation. A stay below the 544 level on June 1 shall confirm the resumption of its correction from 764.94 level. How far will this downside consolidation be? Trying to find an insight into the current downside consolidation, we have to revert to the KLSE CI's other phases of uptrend and downtrend to locate the likely symmetry waves. With that, we shall try to pin down the next set of symmetry wave in determining the current retracement support. The technical rebound from 470 level on Jan 12 to 764 level on Feb 11 gave a retracement gain of 294 points. This corresponded to the uptrend gain of 294 points, from 176 level in May 1986 to 470 level in August 1987. Thereafter, its price trend retraced from 470 level to 223 level in December 1987, giving a retracement loss of 247 points, or 84 per cent. Should the 84 per cent retracement (247 points) be the next set of symmetry wave, then the KLSE CI's current retracement will likely to find critical support at 517 level. Other Fibonacci-based ratio retracement from its recent movements placed its clustered support around 510 to 517 levels. Thus, the next downside critical support is at 511 to 517 levels while its immediate overhead resistance is now at 544 level.

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Gascoigne Out, 3rd Ld-Writethru
Hoddle says he dropped Gascoigne solely for lack of fitness Gascoigne; adds more Hoddle quotes; edits
Eds: ADDS bookmakers odds; bookmakers says team better without
LA MANGA, Spain (AP) _ England coach Glenn Hoddle said Monday he dropped controversial midfielder Paul Gascoigne from the final 22-man World Cup team solely because he wasn't fit. On Sunday, Hoddle stunned England by dropping the 31-year-old Gascoigne, rated by some as the best midfielder in English history. As well as Gascoigne, Hoddle also dropped five other players _ Tottenham goalkeeper Ian Walker, Manchester United's Phil Neville and Nicky Butt, Coventry's Dion Dublin and Everton's Andy Hinchcliffe _ to get down to the final 22-man team. But all attention Monday focused on Gascoigne, a highly skilled, creative player who has filled the tabloid press in recent years with reports of his fast-paced, hard-drinking life off the pitch. ``He (Gascoigne) was not selected on his fitness levels and his form over the last two or three months,'' said Hoddle, speaking at a news conference in this southeastern Spanish resort where England has been training. ``We have run out of time getting him to the (fitness) levels I needed,'' Hoddle added. ``I am as disappointed as Paul that he is not with us but I have had to make a very tough decision. It was a difficult one for me to call.'' Hoddle, looking composed in the face of a decision that could backfire, recounted that Gascoigne cried after he told him the news. ``We had a chat for two or three minutes that lasted no longer than that,'' Hoddle said. ``At the end of the day I think there were some tears in his eyes.'' ``He went into his room. I think some of his friends went into his room to console him. Paul acted as I would have expected him to react.'' Britain's biggest bookmakers Ladbrokes last week lengthened the odds on England winning the World Cup from 7-1 to 8-1 following poor play in three matches. The odds remained unchanged with Gascoigne's departure _ and could shorten. ``We believe the team is better off without Gascoigne,'' said Ladbrokes' spokesman Sean Boyce. ``We take the attitude this is a good thing.'' Gascoigne, a key figure when England reached the World Cup semifinals in 1990 in Italy, returned to England after the shock announcement and was reported staying with his estranged wife Sheryl. ``I can't believe this has happened. This is the worst thing that has ever happened to me,'' The Sun newspaper quoted Gascoigne as saying. The unexpected gamble by Hoddle, the No. 1 news item Monday across England, was surprisingly supported by more than 75 percent of callers to a popular London morning radio show. ``We've played him before when he's not been 100-percent fit, but that's been in a one-off situation, Hoddle said. ``This is different, this is going up against the best players in the world and he just wasn't ready for it.'' ``I needed to have 22 players who I knew could last 90 minutes, and Paul just didn't come into that category. The pace of the modern game means you have to have athletes, not just technically excellent players, but athletes as well. Gascoigne, who has played for Newcastle, Tottenham, Lazio, Glasgow Rangers and Middlesbrough, seems to have lost his dribbling and passing touch. He has also suffered numerous injuries and attracted the wrong kind of publicity off the field. Ankle and groin injuries sidelined him for much of last season and, although he played 90 minutes of England's 0-0 tie with Saudi Arabia and the 1-0 victory over Morocco on Wednesday, he managed only half of the game against Belgium and limped off with a leg injury. In those three matches he looked ineffective, a shadow of the creative player that made him a one-of-a-kind on previous English sides. Although Hoddle said he dropped Gascoigne over his lack of fitness, he kept the faith with Les Ferdinand and Darren Anderton, two Tottenham players who have been short on fitness and form this season. The move leaves England without a player with World Cup experience. The club failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup in the United States and reached the semifinals in 1990 in Italy. Trevor Steven, Gascoigne's former England teammate, criticized Hoddle's decision. ``There's still two and a half weeks before kick off. Paul has something that nobody else can offer the team and I would have just given him that time. ``As an England fan I would have loved to have seen him do well. But the decision has been made and I think our squad is poorer for the lack of Paul Gascoigne.'' (scw)

MALAYSIA, with its extensive oil and gas reserves, is home to three petrochemical centres. While Kerteh, Terengganu, is the acknowledged ethylene hub of the east coast, Pasir Gudang, Johor, is an alternative option for chemical and petrochemical investors. The Gebeng Industrial Estate in verdant Pahang has developed as a propylene centre and is attracting heavyweights in the global industry. With the economic downturn looming over the region, many companies are embarking on affirmative measures to ensure they not only stay afloat but thrive in rough weather. Likewise for petrochemical giant, BASF (M) Sdn Bhd. BASF is intent on staying focused and continuing to invest in the country. The company has investment interests in two of the three emerging petrochemical sites in the country. Its site in Pasir Gudang is a stand-alone manufacturing facility churning out plastics and specialty chemicals. Total investments at the site amount to RM200 million. The site at Bukit Jelutong, Shah Alam, is a tailor-made stand alone which concentrates on blending and mixing facilities and will house BASF's new headquarters. To date, BASF has poured in RM40 million in its polyurethene system blending facility and more investment ringgit is expected to flow in by the end of the decade. The company is looking at investing RM80 million before the year 2000 for the facility at Bukit Jelutong. The Gebeng site in Pahang is the company's integrated site and represents a joint-venture with Petronas, concentrated on producing acrylic acid. This facility involves the heftiest investment sum, running up a RM2.5 billion bill. The chemical market generally consists of two varieties: commodity and speciality. These can be further broken down into their smaller components. Commodity chemicals consist of petrochemicals, which holds the biggest market share at 40 per cent, inorganic chemicals (eight per cent), and textile chemicals (10 per cent). Specialty chemicals are broken down into performance chemicals (16 per cent of market share), pharmaceutical (16 per cent), agrochemicals (10 percent), and fine chemicals also known as pure chemicals (one per cent). Overall, commodity chemicals make up 60 per cent of the world's market and specialty chemicals make up the remaining 40 per cent. Both markets are still growing. However, the market for chemicals have not been sustaining growth other than pharmaceuticals and performance chemicals. The impact of these growing markets is significant; the bulk of BASF's manufactures are speciality chemicals. BASF's array of chemicals reads like an index list. The company classifies its products into four broad areas: health and nutrition, colourants and finishing products, chemicals, and plastics and fibre raw materials. BASF markets and sells nearly 850 products and more than 100 of those are produced locally. By end of last year, BASF Malaysia's sales turnover amounted to RM412 million. By the end of next year it is expected to be between RM700 million and RM800 million while by the year 2002, sales are estimated to hit RM1.3 billion to RM1.5 billion. Of the company's total sales, 30 per cent is sourced from local production and by the end of 1999, this will increase to 50 per cent. Juergen Knust, chairman of BASF Malaysia, says local production will further increase when the joint-venture with Petronas fully comes on stream. The business venture bodes well for BASF as worldwide demand for acrylic acid is growing at a rate of four per cent and the company is one of biggest producers in world. In Malaysia, says Knust, the big industries are the electrical and electronic industries and the related packaging industry, which is driven by the company's Styropor production, which has the largest turnover of production among all BASF's products. Up to 1997, the company imported 90 per cent of its raw materials. Since end of last year, this 90 per cent has been reduced to just below 50 per cent due to increased production capacities anticipated in the country. Knust cites both the electrical and electronic industries as BASF's strong markets. Other markets which the chemical giant has its fingers in include the automotive, textile and construction industries. Contrary to popular belief, Knust says the company still supplies to the construction industry as it is the only producer of Tamol, a super plasticiser used in the industry. About 70 per cent of BASF's clients in Malaysia are situated in the Klang Valley. Knust contends that, `Whilst there might be lesser volume of products needed in Malaysia, we are undertaking greater exports, especially to Asean where there is no major competitor producing this material.' Knust cites two major factors as to why BASF is doing well in the region. `We have our own production and 80 per cent of this goes into the export market to Asean and other countries. This market is doing well. Another reason is because we have enough customers who are export-oriented and that is why the company and the chemical industry can sail relatively unscathed.' On the current domestic market, there is no doubt that there is a slowdown, and Knust feels that any company needs the export activities to balance out. `You need this balancing act and a lot of effort to swing around your marketing endeavours to be even more export-oriented as compared with the past and I think we are into that mode.' And if the downturn continues, the export figure will see a further increase of another 10 per cent. There comes a note of caution, however, as both BASF and most in the industry did not expect the crisis to be so severe and not to last for so long. `Until now we have not changed our plans because overall we are doing very well. But as this situation carries on, let's say into mid- year, then we'll have to revise down some of our prospects. We are waiting and are being optimistic, but there will be lesser gowth if this downturn continues.' Sales turnover for Malaysia in the first quarter of this year increased 30 per cent and if it continues on the uptrend, the company's plans remain unchanged. New projects for the year will amount to RM150 million, and if everything goes to plan, BASF will release three new projects within the next three to six months. However, future investments will have to be revised should the economic slowdown continue into the year. `Looking back, we can only be glad that we planned the buildings so much ahead of time,' says Knust while reflecting on the increased costs nationwide. `There are certain effects (from the economic slowdown) as we supply both the automotive and construction industry. We are experiencing lesser sales in these industries,' he acknowledges. Delving into the subject of BASF's projects, Knust says that all the company's projects are for the long term and based on long term strategies. Everything is full steam ahead. This is possible, Knust feels, as the current economic situation aids in weeding out competition: `You get more and better suppliers.' He divulges that there will be more projects to be announced this year and in due course. The Bukit Jelutong plant is a medium-sized engagement and will produce polyurethene. The investment cost for this runs up a RM10 million price tag. By the end of the first quarter of 1999, Knust hopes to transfer BASF's headquarters to the site. The company's warehouse and domestic distribution centre will also be in place by then. The master batch production is slated to be running by mid-1999. Generally, a sense of commitment is prevalent in the air. Of BASF's investments, Knust says, `We have committed beforehand and we've invested beforehand. Of course, certain services may be cheaper now but we are here for the long term.'

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Romania,0265
Romania sets sights on semi-finals
SAFTICA, Romania (AP) _ Romania's soccer team hopes to make it into the semi-finals of this summer's World Cup in France, topping its performance of four years ago, when it fell in the quarterfinals. ``We might qualify for semifinals if we play well,'' said Gheorghe Popescu, a key part of Romania's defense, who plays for Turkey's champion Galatasaray. His teammate with Galatasaray, Gheorghe Hagi, known as ``the Maradona of the Carpathians,'' said Romania's most difficult game would be its first one, June 15 against Colombia. Although Romania beat Colombia in 1994 play, the first match is often the toughest psychologically. Dan Petrescu, a player for England's Chelsea, said Romania's tournament strategy will depend on whether the team beats Colombia. Romania plays in Group G, along with Colombia, England and Tunisia. Romania and England are considered the front-runners. Romania scored nine victories and one draw qualifying for the World Cup. The team achieved its best showing in the 1994 World Cup, beating Colombia and the United States in the first round, and even Argentina in a wild second-round match. Romania later fell to Sweden in the quarterfinals. The national team currently trains at their base of Saftica, 20 kilometers (12 miles) north of Bucharest. Coach Anghel Iordanescu is expected to announce the line-up for the World Cup soon. Romania will have two warm-up games, with Paraguay and Moldova, before leaving June 8 for France.

BC-Arabs-Summit, 1st Ld-Writethru
Precede CAIRO Abdullah in Jordan to resolve differences over Arab summit new quotes; changes byline
Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Saudi crown prince in Jordan; By JAMAL HALABY Associated Press Writer
AMMAN, Jordan (AP) _ Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah arrived in Jordan Monday for talks aimed at resolving differences between key Arab leaders on a proposed summit on the Middle East peace process. Abdullah came from Damascus where he met at least twice with Syrian President Hafez Assad to persuade him to accept an open agenda at the proposed summit, Arab diplomats said. Such a demand also has been made by Jordan and some Gulf nations. But all agree that the summit should forge a unified Arab position against Israel. Talaat Hamid, spokesman for the 22-member Arab League, said in Cairo that consultations are under way between Arab leaders over the time and place for the summit. He gave no other details. An Egyptian weekly newspaper reported that Morocco, Saudi Arabia and Egypt have offered to host the summit. The meeting was proposed by Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat who wants the Arabs to take a tougher stance toward Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since peace talks have reached a complete stalemate. Syria has taken this one step further, insisting that the summit should put the brakes on normalization of Arab ties with Israel, said the diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity. Jordan, Israel's closest Arab ally, apparently balks at that. Deputy Prime Minister Jawad Anani declined to comment on the hard-line Syrian position, saying ``they are free to say what they want.'' But, he added, the summit should ``evaluate the situation and (allow) each to express his opinion .. to agree and reach a consensus.'' A senior Jordanian government official said that Jordan ``prefers that no conditions be placed prior to convening the parley.'' The official spoke on condition of anonymity. Anani said the summit's agenda will figure high in talks during the two-day visit by the Saudi prince. Emphasizing the importance of his visit, Abdullah was received at the airport by King Hussein in a rare protocol gesture reserved only for heads of state. The two leaders are scheduled to meet privately. Abdullah is the first top Saudi official to visit Jordan since 1990 when relations strained over Amman's perceived tilt toward Iraq following its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Meanwhile, the issue of Iraq is causing problems for the summit too. Most Gulf states oppose inviting Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to the summit because of Gulf War rivalry. Syria says Iraq's presence is needed for a united stance against Israel. Several Arab countries also are unwilling to attend a summit while the United States still is mediating on the Palestinian issue. Once Washington announces its efforts have failed, Arafat would likely meet less resistance. Arafat began pushing for the summit after the United States failed to convince Netanyahu to accept a compromise of a further 13 percent troops pullback in the West Bank to restart talks. Arafat, who wanted 30 percent, has accepted. sn-ggl/jjh/vj

ALMOST every major information technology (IT) vendor is now targeting the small and medium-sized industries (SMIs) with a variety of offerings. Ask the people at IBM, Hewlett-Packard, Compaq, Digital and others, and they will talk about their plans and programmes to make headway in the SMI market. For them, this is where their growth, or a sizeable portion of their business, is going to come from this year. Yes, size does matter and in this case, it's the small that is expected to present the ``huge opportunity'' long sought by IT vendors. The vendors, after taking a good look at what they have, are packaging and re-packaging their products and services specially to meet the needs of the SMIs. Among the latest was Computer Associates which has packaged its enterprise management offering Unicenter TNG into so-called no-frills workgroup edition products. These are designed to be the entry point into the company's extensive offerings, and aimed at customers with less than 250 desktop clients. With the products broken up into modules, customers only buy what they need and cost is, of course, very much lower. Based on research carried out by the US-based Aberdeen Group, there is an untapped worldwide market of 1.5 million workgroup units, and this is probably what CA is going for with its workgroup edition products. The SMI market, according to market researcher IDC Malaysia, represents ``growth potential'' for IT vendors, especially when the region is experiencing an economic downturn. The percentage of IT usage in this sector is still considered low, as it was estimated that 90 per cent of the companies have yet to computerise or still require some form of computerisation. Most of those which have computerised have employed IT mainly to process data. IT is used to support operations, in areas such as accounting, human resource and inventory management, and purchasing. But IDC believes that IT usage is still remarkably low and these companies will still have to spend on technology to save on operational costs, and improve productivity in order to compete effectively. IDC Malaysia conducted a survey on the IT spending of local companies, dividing them into small, medium and large. It was interesting to note that 23.9 per cent of the small companies plan to increase their IT spending this year. Even more encouraging was that 26.5 per cent of the medium-sized companies which responded also want to spend more on IT. Under the current situation, large businesses are more likely to leverage on their existing IT infrastructure. Instead of replacing or increasing the IT equipment they have, they are more likely to maintain what they already have. Here, there's still an opportunity in the need for extended services and support. However, 34.6 per cent of the large companies that took part in the IDC survey informed that they intend to increase their IT spending this year. So, not everyone is going to hold back. Another trend noted in the survey was that 39.9 per cent of the small companies and 35.4 per cent of the medium-sized were still unsure whether to invest in IT. There is therefore a need to promote awareness among SMIs on how they can use technology to make their business more efficient. Here's an opportunity for them to raise their level of operations, and look into how local area networks (LANs), the Internet and intranets can help them. They should be more willing to invest, not just to survive but to plan ahead. No wonder most of the vendors are already looking eagerly at the SMIs. Here's a growing opportunity to present new technologies and products and services that could make a difference. In light of the emphasis on SMIs, the grant scheme announced recently by the Small and Medium Industries Development Corp (Smidec) to introduce a grant scheme to promote greater adoption of IT by SMIs is a move in the right direction. Under the programme, SMIs are able to obtain financial assistance in the purchase of manufacturing software. Smidec proposed to finance 50 per cent of the total cost of the manufacturing solutions purchased. Hopefully, the programme can be expanded so that more small and medium-sized companies can reap the benefits, and in the process become bigger.

Amway (Malaysia) Holdings Bhd is one of the top direct selling companies in the country. Based on its 1997 annual report, the company has fixed deposits of RM162.84 million, banker's acceptances of RM114.74 million and cash balances of RM4 million. It has a relatively clean balance sheet but its exposure to the US$ may be a cause of concern as the goods the company deals with are mostly imported. Despite its US$ exposure, some analysts are upbeat that the cash pile will not erode significantly. DETERMINING the cash surplus of a public listed company is not easy. Based on the best available published figures and feedback from research houses, we have attempted to compile a list of companies with favourable cash positions. However, in evaluating the strength of a company it must be remembered that there are several other factors to consider as well, such as their long- and short-term loans, the nature of business they are in and where they propose to eventually invest this cash. Below are some companies with at least RM150 million and above, based on latest published reports. Amway (Malaysia) Holdings Bhd is one of the top direct selling companies in the country. Based on its 1997 annual report, the company has fixed deposits of RM162.84 million, banker's acceptances of RM114.74 million and cash balances of RM4 million. It has a relatively clean balance sheet but its exposure to the US$ may be a cause of concern as the goods the company deals with are mostly imported. Despite its US$ exposure, some analysts are upbeat that the cash pile will not erode significantly. Datuk Keramat Holdings Bhd: Based on its 1997 annual report, the company has deposits, bank and cash balances totalling RM595 million, mostly generated from the sale of its stake in the then UMBC Bank to the Sime Darby Group. With short term borrowings of RM150 million, the company appears to have a net cash holding of about RM450 million. But much of it will be utilised to finance its acquisition of a Swiss bank. Golden Hope Plantations Bhd: After Kuala Lumpur Kepong Bhd, this PNB-linked plantation counter is perhaps the second most cash-rich company in that sector with about RM400 million in cash and short term deposits. With palm oil prices soaring with the depreciation of the ringgit, Golden Hope is expected to further enhance its cash position. The only setback is the exposure of its 61 per cent subsidiary Negara Properties to the real estate sector. With its healthy cash position, Golden Hope may be called upon to play the role of a white knight. Genting Group: Even after subsidary Resorts World bought a 20 per cent stake in Star Cruises Plc for about RM950 million, the group (which derives its main source of income from its gaming and resort operations at Genting Highlands, Pahang) still has a cash pile of RM2.5 billion left. With so much cash, analysts feel the group is finding it harder to make investment decisions. Among its investments in the past, only the power project in Genting Sanyen seems to have paid off so far. Even the Star Cruises investment is viewed with some sceptism as the cruise business in general is affected by an economic downturn. The group does not have any substantial liability at the moment but it remains to be seen if it can maintain a clean slate as the cruise business is capital intensive and Star Cruises is expected to add to its growing fleet in the next two years. Kuala Lumpur Kepong Bhd (KLK): As of last year, the company was sitting on a cash pile of RM400 million. This figure is expected to rise to more than RM500 million by next year due to the healthy prices of palm oil. The company is one of the solid plantation stocks with conservative investment plans. KLK is a 42 per cent associate of Batu Kawan Bhd, another plantation stock. The negative element is that Batu Kawan has a 30 per cent stake in stock broking firm Smith-Zain Securities and some exposure to property in mainland Penang. With the stock broking industry in the doldrums, some analysts wonder if some of KLK's cash surplus may be re-deployed elsewhere. However, analyst Liew Kok Wai of BNP PrimeEast Research does not think such a re-deployment will happen as Batu Kawan is conservative and Smith-Zain Securities is well run. Malaysian International Shipping Corporation (MISC): The country's premier shipping company had RM836.96 million in cash deposits and bank balances as of December 1997. A portion of this is expected to go into buying ships and tankers belonging to Konsortium Perkapalan Bhd (KPB) for cash. MISC has already entered into an agreement with KPB to purchase PNSL Ltd for US$ 55 million cash. Besides that MISC will also acquire a few more assets of KPB. After the acquisition, MISC's gearing will go up from 0.23 to 1.26. Based on the latest annual report, its long term liabilities are RM893.81 million. With the deal, MISC will have to assume all debts of KPB which is close to US$ 310 million. Perusahaan Otomobil Nasional Bhd (Proton): According to its 1997 annual report, cash and bank balances amount to RM1.46 billion. But short term borrowings come up to RM109 million and long term liabilities to RM357.47 million. For the current year Proton, like most other automobile companies, is expected to see a dip in earnings. Thus the surplus cash may come in handy. Also, Proton needs to spend about RM500 million in developing new models to replace its Iswara and Wira models. Star Publications (M) Bhd: It has a strong cash position - RM212 million in deposits and cash balances with virtually no borrowings. Like most publishing companies, the setback is the rising cost of newsprint due to the ringgit's depreciation. An anaylst says that it is yet to be seen how the company manages its cash and whether it makes a wise investment decision. So far, the company's recent purchase of its new headquarters building in Petaling Jaya has not been viewed favourably as some feel the company could have waited for property prices to come down further. Telekom Malaysia Bhd: Has cash and cash equivalent amounting to RM2.35 billion. But the premier telecommunications company in the country has total borrowings of RM6.4 billion. Of this, RM283 million is due within one year and another RM984 million due after one year but within the next five years. The hefty cash balance will come in handy for Telekom in its expansion plans as it gears for foreign competition next year. Sime UEP Properties Bhd: A subsidiary of the diversified conglomerate Sime Darby Bhd, it stands out among property stocks with a cash position of RM360 million and virtually no borrowings. It is also noted for its prudent and conservative management style. It has an ample, cheap yet well-located landbank with a book cost of less than RM2.00 psf. The only fear is that the parent, Sime Darby, has reported a loss for the first time in more than a decade due to its disastrous move into the banking sector. Though some analysts doubt that any cash from Sime UEP will be used to help out Sime Darby with its cash flow, the possibility still exists. Berjaya Sports Toto Bhd: This number forecast operator (NFO) has deposits worth RM213 million and cash and bank balances of RM66.52 million based on its 1997 annual report. This total of RM279.5 million is less than the other two NFO players mainly because of its track record of high dividend payments. It is these lucrative dividend payments that make some analysts rule out the possibility of BToto's cash reserves being channelled to other Berjaya companies. Magnum Corporation Bhd: Cash and bank balances of this company is estimated at about half a billion ringgit, giving it a cash per share of about 33 sen per share. The company had even more money in quoted investments: RM603.2 million as at Dec 31, 1996. The bulk of this - RM430.3 million - was invested in stocks on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange directly or through unit trusts. In its latest unaudited results for the year ended Dec 31, 1997, the group admitted that the currency and stock market turbulence in the region since last July had affected it. This has resulted in the group having to set aside RM425.82m as provision for diminution in value of this investment. In addition, there was a provision for a further RM94.137 million for unrealised loss in foreign exchange in respect of a foreign currency loan taken by a subsidiary. Analysts say the company has foreign borrowings of about US$200 million. Tanjong Plc: With about RM800 million in deposits and cash and bankbalances, Tanjong has been one of the first few cash-rich companies to announce what it plans to do with its money. It has proposed to buy a 47 per cent stake in independent power producer, Powertek Bhd, which will wipe out RM480 million from its cash reserves. If the deal goes through, it would trigger of a mandatory general offer (MGO) for the remaining shares. This could drain Tanjong's remaining cash and force it to take on borrowings, thereby breaking its debt-free status. Carlsberg Brewery Malaysia Bhd: This leading beer maker is not only well known for its alcoholic beverage but also for its clean balance sheet. A track record of keeping to its core business and rewarding its shareholders with high dividends and bonus issues lays to rest fears of Carlsberg using its cash reserves unwisely. For the year ended Dec 31, 1997, bank balances and deposits were at RM266.7 million. It is also a debt-free company. Hap Seng Consolidated Bhd is sitting pretty on a cash pile of RM256.6 million, made up of cash and bank balances and deposits with banks. Its strong cash flow and zero borrowings puts it in a good position to utilise its cash when opportunities present themselves. Analysts say the money could be used to expand Hap Seng's oil palm operations or its food and beverage business, which currently include a brewery in China and a 25 per cent stake in Carlsberg Brewery Malaysia Bhd. One worry is that controlling shareholder, Malaysian Mosaics Berhad has the ability, through its 50.11 per cent stake in Hap Seng, to tap into Hap Seng's cash via the injection of assets. Will it happen? Analysts say that judging by Hap Seng's track record, this is an unlikely prospect. Matsushita Electric Company (Malaysia) Berhad was sitting on a cash pile of RM178.5 million as at March 31, 1997, and it is likely this money will remain with the electrical manufacturer for some time to come. Reason: The conservative stance is traditional with Japanese companies which only use their money as and when they need it for expansion. Matsushita is also debt free. YTL Corporation Bhd: The YTL group has two listed cash rich entities, namely YTL Corp with RM3.63 billion and its 61-per cent subsidiary , YTL Power with RM2.59 billion. However YTL Corp has pledged the bulk of its cash reserves - RM2.14 billion - to a financial institution for a bank guarantee facility granted to one of its subsidiaries. YTL Corp also has cash balances of RM93 million but this is expected to be used to redeem bonds upon maturity. It also has term loans of RM707.12 million payable within one year and another RM905.86 million due after one year but within five years. YTL Power has close to RM2.55 billion in term loans, made up of bank loans (RM1.11 billion) and fixed rate bonds (RM1.43 billion). Most of these loans are repayable after more than a year. This is a positive note in light of the fact that being an IPP, it is assured of a fixed annual turnover of more than RM1.17 billion, by virtue of its power purchase agreement with Tenaga Nasional Bhd. Analysts believe that the YTL group as a whole has more than RM1 billion available for investments or capital expenditure. Selangor Properties Bhd is one of the few property companies said to have huge cash reserves. As at Oct 31, 1997, this company had cash and cash equivalents of over RM450 million and was debt free. This gives it a cash to share ratio of RM1.30. It has a steady stream of income from rentals from its commercial properties which are concentrated in the Damansara area. However, its cash pile might be reduced as the company is acquiring a piece of land for RM335.41 million cash payable over five years. Tan Chong Motor Holdings Bhd's net cash position is expected to reach more than RM200 million by the end of this year. Analysts say this is good for the company as it will put it in a strong position to weather the current downcycle in vehicle sales and capitalise on the eventual recovery of the motor industry. However, the bulk of this amount may go to finance the company's proposed share buy back scheme of 10 per cent of its share capital. However, analysts add that it is unlikely the company will buy back the shares all at once and, instead, may stagger the buy back process. Also, some of its cash may go toward a special dividend the company will be giving as part of its demerger exercise. Sapura Telecommunications Bhd's cash reserves were boosted after the disposal of stakes in Uniphone Sdn Bhd and Sapura Digital Sdn Bhd to Time RM452.66 million. About half this money however was used to retire loans. Although Sapura has yet to do anything with the balance of about RM264 million, analysts say that based on a recent increase in the company's interest income, the money is believed to be parked in banks and finance companies. However, at about the same time, Sapura has proposed to acquire stakes in companies belonging to parent, Sapura Holdings Sdn Bhd (SHSB). These transactions should reduce Sapura's cash reserves. As at Jan 31, 1997, Sapura's bank borrowings stood at RM266.22 million. Rothmans of Pall Mall Malaysia Bhd: Known for giving out one of the highest dividends, Rothmans has about RM560 in its bank and cash balances. This debt-free company also has bank guaranteed corporate bonds and loan stock of RM49.6 million at cost and Malaysian government securities of RM52.7 million at cost. Taking the latter's cash equivalents into account, Rothmans is sitting pretty on RM662.3 million. Analysts say that based on Rothman's track record, when its cash and bank balances reach between RM600 million and RM700 million, this would trigger off a special cash dividend. This means Rothman's will most probably be paying back its reserves to its shareholders. Gamuda Berhad: This construction giant has about RM253.5 million in deposits and RM12.7 million in cash and bank balances. However, according to the 1997 annual report, its bank borrowings, made up of term loans, overdrafts and banker's acceptances amount to RM10.5 million. The company also has issued long term bonds worth RM190 million which will expire in 2000 and 2001. The company's investments amount to RM60.8 million at cost and are mostly invested in investment management funds within Malaysia (RM10.3 million) and outside Malaysia (RM50.4 million). This would give it a total cash and cash equivalents of RM327 million but total long and short term borrowings of RM200.5 million. Analysts say that although the company has cash, much of it is tied up with its highway projects in the city. Petronas Gas Bhd: The 74.92 per cent subsidiary of Petronas sat on a cash pile of RM898.13 million as at March 31 last year. However, it has long term loans of RM2.31 billion including Yen-denominated bonds. The bright spark is that Petronas Gas has an assured earnings stream by processing gas generated from its parent to service the loans. Also it has already paid for the bulk of its capital expenditure to increase the gas processing facility in Terengganu. Trenergy (Malaysia) Bhd: The second board company is believed to have close to RM300 million following the sale of its US-based Hercules Offshore Corporation (HOC). When the company acquired HOC in 1996, nobody thought much of it. However, it sold HOC early this year when the US$ was at its peak against the ringgit and this translated into a hefty extraordinary gain for Trenergy. However, the bulk of the money is to be used to refurbish a vessel into a floating, production, storage and off-loading facility. The facility is to be leased to Petronas in a long term contract worth more than RM500 million. Some analysts feel another setback is that Trenergy is closely linked to the cash-strapped Renong Group. Daiman Development Berhad: This property-based company has fixed deposits and cash balances of RM144.5 million as of June last year. But analysts believe this cash pile may have increased to RM156 million as of December last year. However a portion of this - RM25.7 million - is pledged to banks to secure bank guarantees and a term loan of RM15.5 million. This still leaves it with over RM100 million in cash. Analysts who follow this counter say the company has a good track record in terms of cash management.

BC-South Africa-Botha Trial, 2nd-Ld-Writethru
Truth Body says Botha knew ANC activists were to be killed apartheid-era assassin may testify
Eds: (AMs) UPDATES with cross-examination and possibility that AP Photos GEO101-102 By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ A top official of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission on Monday indirectly blamed former President P.W. Botha for the killings of black activists during apartheid. Botha is on trial for ignoring a summons to appear before the Truth Commission, which is probing apartheid-era human rights abuses. But the trial _ the first ever of a former South African head of state _ has focused on Botha's role as chairman of the State Security Council, which coordinated a security crackdown on black liberation groups. Truth Commission executive secretary Paul van Zyl said minutes from State Security Council meetings contained words like ``eliminate'' and ``neutralize'' when referring to opponents of white rule. Botha headed the security council when he was head of state. ``It is quite clear from these documents, as we interpret it, the word eliminate means kill,'' van Zyl said shortly after Botha's trial resumed Monday after being postponed for six weeks. In showing why it wants to question Botha, the Truth Commission has presented the court in this southern coastal town with dozens of documents implicating Botha, who led South Africa from 1978-1989, in atrocities. Van Zyl said the Security Council had been briefed in 1979 about plans to launch overseas operations against members of the African National Congress, including sending bombs in the mail. Wearing a dark suit and foregoing a cane which he has normally used since a hip replacement last year, Botha impassively listened to the testimony. His lawyer, Lappe Laubscher, complained that van Zyl was diverting the case to uncovering Security Council deeds. ``Both of us are going to retire in George if you continue like this,'' Laubscher joked. Botha, 82, had greeted the supporters as he entered the court, located near his retirement home in the village of Wilderness. Prosecutor Bruce Morrison raised the possibility that Eugene de Kock, a former police colonel who headed a group of apartheid-era assassins, may testify. De Kock, currently serving a life prison term, carried out the 1988 bombing of an anti-apartheid group's offices. Former national police chief Johan van der Merwe has told the Truth Commission that Botha authorized the attack. Morrison said he wanted to ``consult'' with 4panel wants to humiliate him by forcing him to appear in person. He faces two years imprisonment and unspecified fines if convicted. (ph-aos)

IT'S FUNNY how sentiment on a stock can swing so wildly in a space of just six months. For most of last year, Singapore Telecom (SingTel) was under tremendous selling pressure. The reasons: the onslaught of competition in the mobile communications sector and its high share price relative to other regional telecom companies. Consequently, in the initial weeks after April 1, 1997, - the day SingTel lost its monopoly in the mobile phone and paging markets - its share price hit one record low after another. It sank to a depth of S$2.05 in September. Some S$19 billion in market capitalisation was wiped out. In the six months to September, SingTel underperformed the entire market by 17 per cent. But a twist of fortune came with the unlikeliest of events - the regional currency crisis. With its predictable earnings stream and huge cash pile, SingTel rose from the deep to emerge as `an island of stability in a sea of volatility'. Asian funds muscled their way onto SingTel's share register. By March 5, SingTel shares had regained all their losses and more. In the last six months, the share price gained S$1.21 to S$3.26 - outperforming the Stock Exchange of Singapore's All Shares Index by a staggering 55 per cent. Analysts are now singing a slightly different tune, swayed partly by SingTel's sterling 12 per cent growth in interim earnings. A number have since upgraded their calls: from sell to hold, from hold to buy or accumulate. According to The Estimate Directory, 60 per cent of analysts who track SingTel are now recommending a buy or a hold. This compares to below 50 per cent in November. Houses which have upgraded their calls include Credit Lyonnais, ING Barings, GK Goh, Tsang Ong and UBS. GK Goh's Alayne Wong says, `Under current market conditions, SingTel's defensive nature overrides its premium valuation.' She recommends SingTel as a core portfolio holding for the Singapore market. ING Barings' regional telecom analyst Gautam Kapoor argues that although SingTel is overvalued in some parameters, these parameters do not capture qualitative issues. For example, they do not take into consideration replacement costs, the management team and other local conditions. `At the end of the day, it depends on the market. SingTel is operating in an environment with more certainty. It's a safe stock with good earnings visibility,' he says. Analysts think that SingTel will continue to be a good place to park one's money until the financial storm in Southeast Asia blows over. However, most refrain from setting a price target for SingTel. So, fundamentally, compared with six months ago, what has changed about SingTel? For one thing, the financial crisis has jacked up interest rates. SingTel, with its cash hoard amounting to some S$4 billion, looks set to benefit in higher interest income. But operationally, there will be adverse impact, as SingTel readily admits. `Traditionally, there is a strong correlation between our earnings and the level of economic activity both in Singapore and the region,' says the group's investor relations manager Karena Tay. `The current regional turmoil is expected to impact on Singapore's economy, and telecommunications business will likewise be affected.' The writing could already be on the wall. Outgoing international telephone calls, which contribute 44 per cent to SingTel's group turnover, grew by a mere 2.3 per cent in volume terms in January this year. This pales in comparison to the double-digit year-on-year growth the business enjoyed throughout 1997. As for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar against the regional units and its depreciation against other major currencies in the West, they cut both ways. First, on the expenses side, SingTel will now have to fork out more to pay for traffic expenses, the fees it pays other telcos to complete international calls. These expenses - SingTel's largest cost component -are denominated in Special Drawing Rights (SDR) which are pegged to a basket of major currencies. On the other hand, income from its foreign associate Belgacom will now translate into 10 per cent more Singapore dollars. The plunge in regional currencies has also meant that SingTel's investments in Indonesia and the Philippines are worth a fraction of their earlier valuations. The investment cost in Globe Telecom, for instance, was S$155.7 million. At today's prices and exchange rates, the value is now down to a fifth at about S$31.6 million. In Indonesia, the group has invested S$28 million as at March 31 last year in its joint venture PT SingTel Bukaka. But on the bright side, SingTel's share of Globe Telecom's losses, too, will be very much less. The crisis could also present SingTel with opportunities to buy up regional assets at bargain prices. Overall, analysts think SingTel will weather the storm well. The consensus earning forecast for SingTel is still a healthy 13 per cent growth for the financial year ending March 31, 1998, and 11 per cent for 1999. Paribas Asia Equity's senior telecom analyst Neil Juggins is more bullish. He expects SingTel to post a 15.3 per cent surge in net profit to S$1.914 billion this year, followed by another 13.8 per cent next year to S$2.178 billion. SingTel shares, he says, will outperform the market in the next 12 months. Analysts anticipate earnings growth to come from local and international calls as well as value-added services. ING Barings' Gautam Kapoor sees increased profit in the cellular business as well, despite SingTel's loss of market share. This, he said, could be achieved with better cost control. Meanwhile, SingTel has smartened up a lot after its first taste of competition. It is more market-savvy now and its ads are being noticed. It is assiduously building up its brand name and gearing up for competition in the fixed-line and international calls businesses by 2000. It has stepped up efforts, and has been enjoying some success, in pulling second or third lines to homes. There is still room for growth as new demand will come from new homes and businesses and new multimedia services like Magix. Last year's line growth of 9.4 per cent is the highest SingTel has had for the last 15 years. And when full competition ensues, SingTel is set to be a tough contender. Today, SingTel is as competitive as, if not more than, any telco in the region. According to a study by the National University of Singapore, SingTel's rates are the cheapest in this part of the world, ahead of Australia's Telstra, HK Telecom and Japan's KDD. Beyond 2000, SingTel expects overseas investments to contribute about 10 per cent to its bottomline. A new earnings stream is also expected from its first satellite to be launched this year, ST-1. The satellite could potentially rake in revenues of S$42 million a year. But a word of caution before you rush in to buy more SingTel shares. Some analysts think SingTel is only good while the going is tough. And once the financial markets stabilise, the stock will lose its safe-haven status. At S$3.24 as at March 6 (price earnings: 26 times on expected 1999 earnings), it is one of the most expensive telecom stocks around. Merrill Lynch's Adam Quinton, who is advising his clients to reduce holdings of SingTel shares, says the group's cashflow and earnings growth are not compelling enough to sustain the current price. `SingTel is going to underperform the market in the long term.' For now, however, the fallout in the region, which could last well into 1999, should keep SingTel in the limelight. - Singapore Business

TELEKOM Malaysia Berhad is confident of turning the Mobikom cellular service into a profitable business with the proposed upgrading of infrastructure and injection of expertise. Its chairman Datuk Ali Hassan said with Telekom's years of experience in the telecommunications sector, it could turn Mobikom into one of its biggest revenue earners in future. Ali said Mobikom also stood to contribute a great deal to Telekom compared to other cellular services it operated because of Mobikom's large subscriber base of 300,000. Telekom also operates two other cellular services, the Atur 450 which has about 80,000 active subscribers and TM Touch which has 120,000 active subscribers. He said this when commenting on Telekom's takeover of mobile phone operator Mobikom Sdn Bhd for RM232.7 million on May 14. Ali was speaking to reporters after launching the northern region World Telecommunications Day celebrations at the Alor Star telecommunications tower on Saturday. Also present were Menteri Besar Tan Sri Sanusi Junid, Telekom chief operating officer for telephony Datuk Dr Rahim Daud, Kedah/Perlis chief business operations officer Sharoom Cha and State executive councillors. Earlier in his speech, Ali said to date Telekom had completed 92 of 200 proposed infrastructure projects in the State. This includes 84 fibre optic projects.

AS a sign of the difficult times, the advertising industry is usually one of the first to be hit as companies begin to slash marketing budgets in order to conserve cash flow. The ardent television viewer will have noticed that there are fewer commercials and that music videos have made a comeback to fill airtime in-between shows. In an increasingly competitive market, outdoor advertising firm Ganad Corporation Bhd remains optimistic it will be able to sustain itself during these lean times on its many long-term contracts (usually three to five years) sealed with multinational corporations. Some of its customers include Citibank, Toyota, Samsung and Marlboro. Assistant general manager Cheng Kee How said despite a consolidation in spending, Ganad would push for a bigger slice of the market, targeting about a third of new business. ``We are very aggressive and are discussing with some multinational corporations for new business. ``This will offset the industry slowdown and we will maintain our business,'' he said in an interview in Kuala Lumpur. Cheng said some of the multinational companies have contracts with Ganad's associate companies abroad. Ganad began regional expansion a few years ago into Myanmar, Cambodia, Thailand and China. Assessing the outdoor advertising segment, Cheng said it remained a small portion of the entire advertising industry and had seen a 20 per cent to 30 per cent reduction in spending. The other segments of the industry comprise television, radio, newspapers, magazines, rediffusion, video, cinema and point-of-sale. Newspapers command the largest slice of total advertising dollars at 60 per cent, or RM1.59 billion of a total RM2.61 billion last year. Nevertheless, Cheng said there had been a shift towards more outdoor advertising since television programming became more cluttered. With more new highways and expressways, prospects for the outdoor advertising segment are on the rise. He cited highways to the Kuala Lumpur International Airport as a good location to project the corporate image of multinational firms to visitors. ``Visitors will also have confidence in a country when they see the advertisements of big multinationals, and so outdoor advertising is serving its purpose in that way.'' With the Commonwealth Games in September, Ganad is doing its bit to promote the event. It is sponsoring some 70 billboard sites nationwide, worth a total of RM20,000 each. The campaign, which began six months ago, now sees some 50 billboards erected.

THE inclusion of independent market research in the Securities Commission's (SC's) requirement for listing exercises on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange in 1996 has proven to be a boon for Sofres Group, a French-based market researcher. Sofres FSA Malaysia (formerly Frank Small Associates) managing director Iain R Bell explains, `Companies now need to provide market research reports on the particular industry they are involved in, which include nature of industry, list of key players, market size, outlook and areas of growth for the industry for the next five years. This is where Sofres Malaysia has an advantage with the backing of the Sofres Group. The Malaysian operations have grown to become the largest Asia-Pacific office of the group, which has a total of 23 offices in 12 Asia-Pacific countries,' he enthuses. `Market research in Malaysia is undergoing a renaissance of sorts where an increasing number of local and multinational companies are looking to the industry as an important component of their business and marketing strategies,' he says. He continues that the demand for market research services is on the uptrend, both locally and globally, as businesses are increasingly aware that research has a positive effect on their bid to stay ahead. Knowledge of business markets, customer needs and identification of new opportunities are paramount to sustaining or expanding the business. Market research plays a critical role in the success of a company, as it assists organisations to fulfil their objectives by providing detailed, cost-effective and timely market information, along with quality interpretation, analysis and understanding that form the basis for the development of optimal strategic planning. In fact, this was the basis of the group's latest merger last November with United Kingdom-based Taylor Nelson AGB, resulting in the creation of the fourth largest market research company in the world, which recorded a turnover of US$ 450 million for FY December 1997. The merger involved Taylor Nelson acquiring STG119 million worth of shares in Sofres' holding company. Subsequently, it was listed on the London Stock Exchange and is managed by directors from both companies. The new entity, Taylor Nelson Sofres (TNS), has a network of over 4,000 professionals in 32 countries. The merger creates one of the widest product ranges in the industry, combining Sofres' and Taylor Nelson's combined strengths in continuous panels, databases and branded research products. Bell expands on the operations of Sofres Malaysia, `1996 was a good year with almost 70 per cent of our revenue coming from market research for listing exercises. But with the SC clamping down on new listings last year, the company has now ventured into other areas of growth.' The total number of companies supported by Sofres Malaysia for their listing exercise between 1996 and 1997 stands at 23, involving a wide range of industries. Apart from this, the company had done 19 independent market reports for various industries in 1996, while the number of independent market reports rose to 21 in 1997. He highlights that the local market research industry in 1997 was RM52 million and this is estimated to increase to RM60 million in 1998. Sofres Malaysia has recorded between a 15 per cent and 20 per cent revenue growth for the past five years, and is expected to peg a 18 per cent growth in revenue this year. Furthermore, 22 per cent of total revenue is derived from overseas clients. `Sofres Malaysia has a 31 per cent market share in the industry while Survey Research Malaysia (SRG Nielson) has a 45 per cent market share. The remaining market share is divided among other players in the industry. There are about 12 to 15 research companies in the country, some local while others are offices of regional companies,' he divulges. A further boost to the Malaysian operations comes in the form of being the only market research firm in Asia to achieve QCSI (Quality Control System for Interviewing) accredition. Bell elaborates, `Over 152,000 interviews were conducted in 1997 all on an ad-hoc basis. In the same period, more than 450 focus groups and 550 individual jobs were also conducted.' According to Sofres Malaysia associate director Supramaniam Letchumanan, the company comprises 120 staff and has five core divisions -consumer, business and property, services, media, and social and community. In addition, there are six specialist units - healthcare/personal care, telecommunications, food and beverage, automotive, financial, advertising testing/ tracking. `The consumer division (FMCG) forms 50.4 per cent of the total business done, followed by high tech/telecom/business to business research - 23 per cent, media - 9.4 per cent, corporate communication/human resource - 8.1 per cent, and automotive - 4.2 per cent. The rest of the divisions contribute a minimal amount,' he says. Currently, Sofres Malaysia is focusing on market sectors of real growth in terms of research and development which is in the areas of pharmaceuticals, automotives, telecommunications, information technology and healthcare. Bell emphasises that apart from providing research materials for overseas companies to enter the local market, the current trend is for more local companies to test the overseas markets. `In fact, the SC's requirement for companies to have market research done is a boon in more ways than one. Although most of our clients started the research for the purpose of listing, somewhere along the line, they realised that the research was useful for many other things,' he says. In the near future, the Malaysian operations will be introducing other products which are being marketed by the group. He cites the financial public relations research - which is a tool to improve share value, make it easier to raise capital in financial markets and develop more effective corporate communications - as an example. The financial public relations research product has been marketed in France and Europe successfully for the past five to six years, and will be launched in Malaysia within two months. `We are looking at a contribution of between 10 per cent and 15 per cent of the revenue from this product in France and expect similar contributions to the Malaysian operations once the product is introduced here. In the course of time, other products will also be introduced in Malaysia,' he adds.

CRABTREE Evelyn (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Kuala Lumpur Kepong Bhd, opened its flagship store at the Suria Kuala Lumpur City Centre on Friday. The store, which is the biggest in the Asia-Pacific region, sells toiletries and fine food. Crabtree Evelyn also has another outlet at the Starhill Centre which was opened last December. Asia-Pacific sales and marketing manager Frederic Puech, who was present at the opening, said that there were 62 outlets in the Asia-Pacific region and they are considering opening another in Penang. ``Penang is a possibility but for the moment we will concentrate on promoting our flagship store at the KLCC,'' said Puech. He did not want to reveal the total investment in Malaysia. On the products sold in the outlet, Puech said all of them are manufactured overseas. ``The soaps are made in Switzerland while the perfumes are from France. Toiletries are from Wales while some food products are from England.'' KLK bought over Crabtree Evelyn in July 1996.

DHAKA, Bangladesh (AP) _ Brojan Das, a Bangladesh national who swam across the English Channel six times, died Monday in the Indian city of Calcutta, his family said. He was 71. He was hospitalized in Calcutta with a heart ailment, his family members said, asking not to be identified by name. Das was the first Asian to cross the channel in 1958 and set a speed record in 1961. He is survived by his wife, a son and a daughter.

JARRAD, a 39-year-old computer programmer, was diagnosed with high blood pressure. He had sought medical help for headaches, tiredness and trouble sleeping. When his doctor asked about stress, Jarrad initially said that everything was find. But when the doctor probed further, about home and work, Jarrad admitted that his boss, Bill, was a real negative person. Bill only noticed the negative and never gave him any positive feedback. Jarrad never knew if his job was secure and he felt as though he never lived up to what Bill expected. Jarrad had thought about leaving his job many times but with the lack of hiring in his field he never felt it was possible. Jarrad's doctor prescribed blood pressure medication for the rest of his life. Dealing with a difficult boss on a day-to-day basis can have both physical and emotional consequences, including such diverse problems as hypertension, headaches, stomach aches, diarrhoea, insomnia, depression and nervousness. In addition, having problems at work often affect a person's home life, causing increased conflict within a marriage or with the children. As a psychiatrist I've treated many people who had a difficult boss. Job insecurity is more prevalent than several years ago which gives many employees the feeling that they have to put up with whatever an employer dishes out. As mental health professionals know, however, perception is everything. When you believe that you have to put up with mistreatment then you put up with it at whatever personal cost to yourself. When you believe that you can do something about a difficult situation then you generally tackle it in a positive way. There are many tactics you can use to deal with a difficult boss, besides blowing up or quitting. Here are five strategies: l Clarify your job expectations. Make sure that your work goals match what your boss wants from you. Many disagreements between an employer and employee stem from unclear expectations. Rather than blaming your boss for not being clear with what he or she wants, take the initiative to clarify goals to ensure you're on the right track. l Assume the best about your boss, unless you have clear reasons to the contrary. Bosses are people too. Most people in charge want to do a good job and want their employees to succeed. Sure, many supervisors or employers could do a better job or could benefit from more management training, but most of the supervisors I've met want what's best for their employees. When you expect the best, your attitude and work performance improves which goes a long way to improving your relationship with your boss. l When you feel your boss is upset with you check it out. Since employers and supervisors are in positions of authority their every action is interpreted by those who work for them. If an employee has `authority issues' from their past, he or she may misinterpret the boss' attitude or actions and be upset over a misunderstanding. I tell my patients that a negative look from a boss may mean nothing more than constipation on his part. You don't know unless you check it out! l If your boss throws tantrums, don't cower and don't provoke. Some bosses are emotional and belligerent by nature, some are that way because it gets them their way. If you cower and give in to them when they get upset, they will bully you as a matter of course. If you provoke them further when they're upset you may end up fired. The best way to deal with a bullying boss is to remain calm (even though you feel like screaming) and assert your point in a positive way. Many difficult bosses will have more respect for you if you stand up to them in a respectful way. If you stay calm when the boss is out of control he or she is likely to pull it together in order not to look like a fool. l Reinforce your boss when he or she is giving you the feedback you need to do your job. Too often employees see themselves in a powerless `one down' position with their boss. Employees can shape the boss' behaviour with positive reinforcement. For example, when the boss gives you good feedback tell him or her how much you need and appreciate it. If you notice your boss having a hard time with his or her boss, let them know that you appreciate their efforts and know things will work out. A kind word or a smile goes a long way to disarming a fuming boss. Using these simple strategies will give you some power in dealing with a difficult boss. Never forget that a work relationship goes two ways and that you have some responsibility for shaping the relationship. Now, if the boss is totally impossible and nothing works to turn the relationship around, look for another job. Working for a boss you hate over a long period of time will take years off your life. When you leave, however, (especially during this economy) plan you exit to a timetable that fits your needs, not the needs of your angry impulses. - UPS
