More deaths reported in Kosovo; thousands flee trims.
Eds: AMs. UPDATES with thousands marching in Kosovo; recasts and By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Refugees from Serbia's Kosovo province streamed into neighboring Albania on Monday to escape some of the worst fighting in months. Dozens of people were reported killed. Reports from Serb and Albanian sources often were contradictory and could not be independently verified. But with 39 people reported killed over the weekend, and fighting apparently continuing, the bloodshed seemed the worst since early March, when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on independence-minded militants and their families. A day after Serb authorities claimed to have killed several dozen militants in four villages in the Decani region of western Kosovo, ethnic Albanian officials said 37 Albanians had been killed over the weekend. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani while 10 were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died in the fighting around Decani, 75 kilometers (45 miles) west of the regional capital Pristina, Serb sources said. The latest fierce fighting prompted about 2,000 Kosovo Albanians, mostly women, children and elderly, to leave the troubled region and cross over into Albania's Troboja region Sunday and Monday, Albanian authorities said. They said more were arriving by the hour. Interior Ministry spokesman Artan Bizhga said in the Albanian capital, Tirana, that the refugees, many of whom had walked for as many as 10 hours, were being accommodated in local homes and a school. Local authorities were providing free food and clothes. In a statement, the Albanian government called on the United States and the European Community to intervene ``for ending the massacre in Kosovo.'' ``This is just the start of a war with tragical dimensions,'' the statement said. Authorities in Serbia, which with Montenegro comprises all that remains of the Yugoslav federation, are trying to block Kosovo's independence bid. They are using Serbian police and the Yugoslav army to try to crush militants and maintain control over the province, where 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million is ethnic Albanian. More than 200 people have died in Kosovo clashes since the beginning of March. An estimated 50 percent of the Serbian province is controlled by militant Albanians and many regions are blocked off, either by Serbs or Albanians. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, released the names of the 10 people it said were killed Sunday when Serb police stormed the village of Poklek, 25 kilometers (15 miles) west of Pristina. It said one had had his throat slit. According to the Albanians' account, Serb police burst into Poklek houses, pulled out villagers and told them to ``go to Albania and never return.'' Afterward, Serb police allegedly set 26 homes ablaze. All phone lines remained disconnected Monday between Pristina and the hot-spots of Decani, Klina and Djakovica, where fierce battles were reported Sunday. In Pristina, about 10,000 ethnic Albanians, including 2,000 children, marched to protest Serbian rule. Yugoslavia's state-run daily Politika on Monday accused ethnic Albanian ``terrorist groups'' of killing several of their countrymen while shelling several villages near the border with Albania whose residents do not support the militants. BC-Arabs-Summit, 1st Ld-Writethru,0526
Precede CAIRO Abdullah in Jordan to resolve differences over Arab summit byline
Eds: UPDATES with Saudi crown prince in Jordan; new quotes; changes By JAMAL HALABY Associated Press Writer
AMMAN, Jordan (AP) _ Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah arrived Monday in Jordan for talks aimed at resolving differences between key Arab leaders on a proposed summit on the Middle East peace process. Abdullah came from Damascus where he met at least twice with Syrian President Hafez Assad to persuade him to accept an open agenda at the proposed summit, Arab diplomats said. Such a demand also has been made by Jordan and some Gulf nations. But all agree that the summit should forge a unified Arab position against Israel. Talaat Hamid, spokesman for the 22-member Arab League, said in Cairo that consultations are under way between Arab leaders over the time and place for the summit. He gave no other details. An Egyptian weekly newspaper reported that Morocco, Saudi Arabia and Egypt have offered to host the summit. The meeting was proposed by Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, who wants the Arabs to take a tougher stance toward Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since peace talks have reached a deadlock. Arafat began pushing for the summit after the United States failed to convince Netanyahu to accept a compromise of a further 13 percent troops pullback in the West Bank to restart talks. Arafat, who wanted 30 percent, has accepted. Syria has insisted the summit should put the brakes on normalization of Arab ties with Israel, said the diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity. Jordan, Israel's closest Arab ally, apparently balks at that. Deputy Prime Minister Jawad Anani declined to comment on the hard-line Syrian position, saying ``they are free to say what they want,'' but the summit should ``evaluate the situation and (allow) each to express his opinion .. to agree and reach a consensus.'' A senior Jordanian government official said Jordan ``prefers that no conditions be placed prior to convening the parley.'' The official spoke on condition of anonymity. Anani said the summit's agenda will figure high in talks during the two-day visit by the Saudi prince. Emphasizing the importance of his visit, Abdullah was received at the airport by King Hussein in a rare protocol gesture reserved only for heads of state. The two leaders are scheduled to meet privately. Abdullah is the first top Saudi official to visit Jordan since 1990 when relations strained over Amman's perceived tilt toward Iraq following its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Meanwhile, the issue of Iraq is causing problems for the summit too. Most Gulf states oppose inviting Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to the summit because of Gulf War rivalry. Syria says Iraq's presence is needed for a united stance against Israel. Several Arab countries also are unwilling to attend a summit while the United States still is mediating on the Palestinian issue. Once Washington announces its efforts have failed, Arafat would likely meet less resistance.

BC-Iraq-Argentina
Argentina seeks contracts under Iraq's U.N. oil deal
BAGHDAD, Iraq (AP) _ Argentina is seeking contracts to sell Iraq food items under the U.N. approved oil-for-food deal, the official Iraqi News Agency reported Monday. It said a senior Iraqi foreign ministry official, Morcelo Avocadro, met with Iraq's Trade Minister Mohammed Mehdi Saleh on Monday to discuss ways of expanding bilateral trade. ``The possibility of Argentine companies getting contracts under the next phase of the oil-for-food deal was reviewed,'' INA said. The deal allows Iraq to sell a limited quantity of oil every six month to help it overcome shortages caused by U.N. economic sanctions imposed after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq can sell up to dlrs 5.2 billion worth oil in the latest phase beginning June 3, instead of dlrs 2 billion worth permitted in previous phases. Iraq plans to use dlrs 3 billion for buying food, medicines and other humanitarian goods from the oil revenue, up from dlrs 1.3 billion it used to spend every six months in the earlier phases of the deal. INA quoted Avocadro as saying that Argentina want contracts to supply Iraq with wheat, maize and cooking oil. Avocadro is the undersecretary for trade relations in his ministry. According to U.N. figures Argentina sold commodities worth dlrs 7 million to Iraq in the past 18 months. lb/vj

IF MELBOURNE holds the largest Greek community outside Greece, Perth has attracted the largest proportion of Asian settlers from the region. And if the rest of Australia seems increasingly mired in Asia's woes, could Western Australia also face a similar impact? Most Asians in Perth don't seem particularly perturbed about the impact from Asia's turmoil. In fact, much Asian investment still finds its way to Western Australia. Perhaps it's because of the Asian congeniality factor. But geographical proximity to Asia also counts for a lot. Still, there are the doubters. They say there is no state in Australia more exposed to the sick economies of Asia than Western Australia (WA). So, the popular argument goes, WA must itself be about to become a basket case. Don't you believe it. WA could still grow faster than the rest of the Australian economy in the coming financial year. Indeed, the Court government is budgeting on it. The official forecast for 1998-99 built into the recent budget is a whopping five per cent - almost two percentage points faster than the likely national growth rate, and not far short of WA's average growth for the past decade. On the Treasury's reckoning Asia will cost WA one percentage point of growth, ask the Canberra-based consultant Access Economics and it will tell you WA's forecast is a more conservative 3.5 per cent to four per cent. That's still a good half a percentage point above the likely national growth rate. WA's growth will depend on how quickly the main economies in Asia turn the corner. But if Asia's turnaround is reasonably rapid, the state can expect growth to be pushed along by strong investment in the resource sector. According to Ed Shann, director of Access Economics, there are resource projects worth A$14 billion in the pipeline, for which a decision on whether to proceed will be made in the next 12 months. The most important of these projects is the North-West Shelf LNG expansion, the cheapest version of which is worth A$6 billion, and the An Feng Kingstream steel plant which, with associated infrastructure, is worth A$2.5 billion. That's thanks to Asian investment, especially from Taiwan and, to a lesser extent, China and Malaysia, all of whom realise the importance of natural resources for fuelling their own economic growth. Obviously Shann isn't worried. `If they go ahead I don't think there's much to worry about,' he says. `There are some gold mines that have closed; there will clearly be something taken off the top of construction activity. But there will still be very high mining investment in WA.' The potential for strong investment was reaffirmed in the last Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey of business investment intentions, taken in the early months of this year. According to the ABS, business in WA is expected to lift investment by another whopping 18 per cent in 1998-1999. The state Treasury, taking a more conservative line and allowing for some delay in the North-West Shelf project, is looking for growth of about eight per cent. That should now be the envy of many Asian countries whose stripes have been lifted off their 'tiger' economies in the ongoing turmoil. But whatever the long-term effects of the native title law in Australia, on which the Howard government has taken a recalcitrant stance, there is no sign of it affecting the level of investment in the short term. Still, there are no guarantees that resource investment will keep going strongly in the case of the Asian meltdown. If either the North-West Shelf or the An Feng project were put on hold, the outlook for WA would change considerably. However, An Feng Kingstream director John Clark insists that work will begin in August. The plant, he says, will be at the bottom of the world cost curve. And he's not worried that Asian investment partners will pull out. The North-West Shelf partners seem almost as confident. While the project's Japanese customers have yet to commit to the extra gas sales, the project partners are confident of obtaining the letter of intent by the end of this year, in time to meet the project's original construction schedule. Helping the North-West Shelf partners - and other resource sector investors - make their sums work will be the depreciation of the Australian dollar. The Australian dollar has depreciated against the US dollar by about 11 per cent in the past six months and almost 19 per cent since the end of 1996. This has cushioned the Australian-dollar incomes of many Australian mining companies against the decline of USD-denominated commodity prices. At the same time, WA's mining and other commodity exporters have been able to weather the Asian downturn more easily than exporters of consumer goods and capital equipment. That is partly because commodities are sold on world markets. Lost sales in Asia can be replaced by sales (albeit at lower prices and with higher transport costs) in other world markets. When combined with the competitive dollar, the result is that all but marginal mines can keep producing. And highly efficient new projects, such as An Feng Kingstream, can still justify construction. `The iron ore industry is going great because it has had a rise in the USD contract prices,' Shann points out. `That's one area where there is going to be a continuing run of activity.' Nickel is likely to be another. `There's a large number of nickel projects around,' says Shann. `There are three under construction that will move into production this year. It's not clear if there are going to be any replacements, although there are a lot of projects which claim to be down in the bottom quarter of the cost curve. Maybe some of them do get up despite the fall in the nickel price.' But there is another important reason why the WA mining exports and investment should come through the Asian downturn reasonably intact. The point was made recently by the governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Ian Macfarlane. To some extent, Australia's food and mining commodity exports are inputs for Asian export industries. These industries will benefit from the big depreciation of Asia's currencies in the past 10 months. `We are probably better off in current circumstances than most suppliers because of the weight of commodities, foodstuffs and inputs into exports in our mix,' Macfarlane says. `After the transitional export finance problems are solved, we should expect to see strong growth in Asian exports as a result of their large increase in competitiveness.' Of course, WA will not get off scot-free. Not by a long shot. Take tourism. The tourist industry has taken a sizable hit. So has the rest of Australia. Takings by the West Australian accommodation industry in the December quarter were down in nominal terms on a year earlier, with the top-end four-star and five-star hotels suffering a 13 per cent fall in revenue. The Perth property market is also suffering from the financial pressures on Asian investors. The news recently that Boutique Asset Pty Ltd, a company connected with the powerful Indonesian Salim group, was pulling out of plans to develop a A$55m residential apartment tower in the Perth CBD (central business district) demonstrates the direct link between sections of the Perth property market and the prosperity of Asia. Still, neither Asian investors here nor West Australian officials are particularly worried. Looking ahead, the point to the Western Australia Treasury forecasts, which predict strong growth from consumer spending and a recovery in WA's housing investment. Access Economics' Ed Shann, however, warns that the commercial property market will remain fairly flat. `Basically they haven't been having much in terms of office construction,' he says. `So, unlike Sydney, where the property market is starting to kick in, that won't be a helping hand for Perth. Perth is still basically dependent on the resource sector.' So, as always in WA, it's back to the resource sector. But if the Treasury's economists are right, and the big projects go ahead as planned, the Western Australian economy could be one of the faster growing economies in Asia in 1998-1999. And the Australian state most exposed to the Asian crisis could come through with barely a bruising.

GATEWAY Inc, the direct marketer of personal computer (PC) products, has introduced its new entry level multimedia notebook called Solo 2500 which is powered by Intel's Pentium II processors. The notebook replaces the Solo 2300 model, and is targeted at the heart of the mainstream portable market with its emphasis on high performance and long battery life. Gateway's marketing director for mobile systems Rick Griencewic claimed that the Solo 2500 is the most aggressively priced thin-film transistor (TFT) and Pentium II-based all-in-one notebook available in the Malaysian market. ``While many of our competitors are struggling to ship their first Pentium II-based systems, Gateway is already cutting prices and is pleased to offer a third Pentium II product in its mobile line of PCs,'' he said. Griencewic said the Pentium II technology in mobile PCs delivers between 11 to 32 per cent better performance at the same thermal level of a 166 megahertz (MHz) multimedia extensions (MMX) technology. Gateway's Solo notebooks may be customised to custom-configure the central processing unit (CPU) speed, random access memory (RAM) amount, hard drive capacity, modem and network connectivity, operating system and applications software to meet individual requirements. ``The Solo notebooks can be upgraded or downgraded to meet individual requirements and budget,'' said Griencewic. Priced at RM8,498, the Solo 2500 is configured with a 200MHz Pentium processor with MMX technology, 32-megabyte (MB) SD random access memory (RAM), 12.2-inch TFT display, two-gigabyte (GB) hard disk, fibre distributed data (FDD), 56K PC card fax modem and lithium-ion battery. It includes a CD-ROM and floppy drive which eliminate the need to swap components. It also allows sharing of components such as docking stations, system memory, hard disk drives, power adapters and other common peripherals. Gateway said the Solo 2500 has added manageability features to lower the total cost of ownership through its common modularity strategy. For example, the LANDesk Client Management with Windows NT and SM basic input/output system (BIOS) allows a company's information systems department to manage company notebooks from remote sites. In addition, users can choose between a touchpad or stick-pointing device. This allows business users to standardise with one portable system and yet meet their personal preferences. Gateway's director of marketing for South Asia Niall O'Reilly said by introducing the Solo 2500 to the Malaysian market via the DirectPlus business model, Gateway has reaffirmed its commitment as the value leader in the local notebook market. The company's direct channel model strategy means that customers deal directly with the principal manufacturer and everything is built specifically to order, thus eliminating the middleman. It also enables Gateway to offer an attractive package which combines good pricing and the latest PC technologies available in the market.

IT SO RANKLED this writer in school all those years ago when a colleague, who shall remain anonymous, insisted on giving his mouthful-of-a-name in all its `triple-barelled glory'. Nothing really wrong with that except he was a fellow `Melayu' and to this far-from-wordly-wise teenager then, a Malay name had to conform to a simple convention. It was basically Abdul `this' bin Abdul `that' or Mohamad `this' bin Mohamad `that'. The snooty friend, instead, insisted on including a surname to his already unwieldy first and second names. `Its my family name,' he implored earnestly, almost on the verge of tears on being pressured by his hectoring interlocutors. Only now, having picked up the book The Merican Clan - A Story of Courage and Destiny which chronicles the achievements of seven generations of Mericans, the progeney of Kader Mydin Merican who first set foot in Penang from India in 1770, does one appreciate his stubborn insistence. Thanks to the pride attached in carrying the Merican family name with each succeeding generations, the task of tracing lineage can be undertaken with a great measure of certainty and accuracy. Forgive me, my friend? This writer's first ever inkling of the existence of a Merican was via the airwaves in the days when Radio 4 was called Rangkaian Biru. Every Sunday, one would look forward to the afternoon radio play and inevitably a Merican - Faridah Merican - would come on air as a principal character. Later on, news items would chronicle one achievement or other with yet another Merican, invariably bathed in academic or corporate glory. Names like Mahmood Merican, Malek Merican and Ahmad Merican all hit the headlines for achieving one notable success or another but little thought was given to the significance of that Merican family name. After all, one came from a culture where geneology and tracing one's family tree is limited to knowing the name of one's moyang and no further. However, the regularity with which this particular family name cropped up and the import of their achievements did raise a measure of envious curiosity. Now thanks to Datin Ragayah Eusoff, the blanket of ignorance is lifted. (She's married to Mahmood Merican, so that explains this particular labour of love!) Interestingly, Mahmood - the Datuk Dr Mahmood who was once chairman of Pantai Hospital - wasn't too keen on his wife's idea and mischievously suggested she write a book about Mericans who were already dearly departed! With great aplomb, Ragayah ignored his helpful suggestion. Why should the reader be interested in the Mericans in the first place? We should, if only because we take vicarious delight in sharing the success stories of others. In the case of the Mericans, the exploits of various clan members should by now confer on them the right to patent the formula for superachieving families - if the bunch of medical men and learned women as well as earnest entrepreneurs from their ranks have not already done so. Patriarch Kader Mydin Merican was a trader who became one of the richest men in the Penang of the 1830s. That he eminence grise in the Indian Muslim community was acknowledged by the British who appointed him Kapitan Keling. The fourth generation Merican produced the clan's first doctor, Ali Osman Merican. `Oss', as he was called, was in fact Penang's first Malay doctor. A sibling, Sheikh Basha, was an educator who was instrumental in establishing and heading Rida College, the forerunner of what is now the Institute Teknologi Mara (ITM). Thespian Faridah Merican is his daughter. The recipe for eminence cannot wholly be explained by way of geneology. Marina Yusoff, the country's second Malay woman lawyer who at one time landed an Umno Supreme Council seat, is a clan member. Her mother Mona was Dr Ali Merican's adopted daughter. The exploits of past and present Mericans have secured the clan an indelible page in the annals of Malaysian history. The author hints of more new pages to be written in her observation that there are 16 great-grandchildren of Dr Ali Merican making up the seventh generation Merican. That they are not yet making waves is no reason why one of their number should not start chronicling every mewling and chuckling emanating from every crib in all the Merican households. Failing which, there is always that famous family name one can latch on to in future undertakings of this nature.

THE highly-acclaimed television programme Sesame Street has now entered the realm of interactive technology. The Sesame Street Toddlers Deluxe comes bundled with three compact disks (CDs) and no prizes for guessing what they do. Those of you who grew up watching the Street programme will surely remember the days when you learnt to recite your ABCs, count your 123s and dance to the tune of Do-Re-Me together with the furry, memorable, cuddly creations from the late Jim Henson's workshop. But what makes this software package delightful is that it continues the Street's legacy of portraying the same zestful and eccentric ensemble of muppets. And doing what it does best, which is educating and entertaining young viewers, this package offers pre-school children the choice of a variety of learning activities ranging from recognising letters and numbers to rhyming and art work. Watch your kids get mesmerised by the eye-catching interface as Elmo (my personal favourite) guides them to learning the rudiments of knowledge. Along the way, introduce them to a ``star-studded'' cast of muppets like the nasal-voiced Grover and the ever-deliciously wicked Street inhabitant known as Oscar the Grouch, who, for some reason, has this inane attachment to his dumpster and develops insecurities whenever having to leave it. Then, there's the mismatched pair, Ernie and Bert, the misfit Cookie Monster and of course, the one-and-only Big Bird. Young viewers may not know this but parents who ardently follow the Street TV show, might recognise some similarities with the way the whole teaching processes here are being presented. While reviewing this software, I felt like I was watching the TV series all over again. And be prepared for some pretty witty scripts. Children (and parents alike) will be tickled pink to hear the usual banter, spiced with a dash of humour of course between Ernie and Bert as you pay these guys a visit. Or have your child rummage through Snuffleupagus' and Big Bird's homes to uncover the essential items that one is asked to look for. And if you simply want to take a break, how about listening to some songs? Interested? Want to know more? Well, Disk One unveils a series of activities covering areas like art and colouring using stickers and rubber stamps. Or how about creating slide shows from selected pictures? Here, children are exposed to verbal instructions and by following them, they can gradually pick up the basics of computer skills. After the ``getting-to-know-your-PC'' exercise, Disk Two then introduces toddlers to the alphabet, phonics and rhyming with the aim to helping children slowly develop their vocabulary skills. And surprise! surprise! There are even classic videos excerpts and songs from the TV show to add fun and variety. Feel like moving on? Well, there's Disk Three which progresses to the more difficult part of the learning process. There are lessons on numbers and games to play, in addition to songs to sing along to and storytelling. Help Count von Count find his bats in his castle and learn all about addition and subtraction. And parents, are you looking for comprehensive educational CDs that are worth your time and money? Why not give Sesame Street Toddlers Deluxe a try. And who knows, someday when that familiar Street tune is played, your child will sit back and say, ``Hey, that really brings back memories''.

AS non-programmable analogue joysticks go, I have never come across something as versatile as Rockfire's Bazooka Fighter. Though Bazooka is not the sort of name I would have given it, the features added to the joystick are by far some of the most innovative. To begin with, the joystick is designed to be a chameleon of sorts because it is capable of mimicking the functions or behaviour of more than one type of joystick design. Generally speaking, it looks like any other high-end and intermediately priced joystick, except that is has a curious-looking function on the left side of its solid-looking base marked Mode 1234. It is a slider switch which allows the gamer to determine how the Bazooka is supposed to behave. In mode 1, the Bazooka mimics the functions of the ThrustMaster FCS, from the four button fire control, to the viewfinder or hat switch, right down to its precision handling. The joystick throttle is disabled in order to avoid unwanted conflicts with an actual ThrustMaster's throttle control unit. Just add a rudder control unit to the Bazooka and ThrustMaster throttle, and the gamer should have a combination that is ready for almost any true-to-life flight simulator that requires high-precision handling. In mode 2, the Bazooka behaves like a CH Flightstick Pro. However, unlike the CH Flightstick, the throttle control for the Bazooka is not at the base but at the upper right side of the joystick grip. This would allow the gamer to fully dedicate his left hand (the Bazooka being a right-handed joystick) to keyboard commands. It is surprising that joystick makers had not come up with the idea sooner seeing how the need for the gamer's left hand to travel from joystick to keyboard can be ``fatal'' in most fast-paced and gruelling games, thus defeating the purpose of having throttle control on the joystick. Well, not only has that problem been solved, the Bazooka's throttle control is a special push-button analogue unit that is not only easily accessible but can also be ``auto-centred'', a feature necessary for ensuring efficiency in games like Descent and Descent II. No longer does a gamer have to worry about over-thrusting using that silly old slide or rotary switch. By moving the Mode 1234 switch to any position while holding down the throttle, the auto-centre feature would be enabled. And moving just the Mode switch would disable that feature. It is as simple as that. The only problem I faced with the throttle design was that it was not placed high enough, but this is not a problem that would be shared by most gamers unless they are adults with stubby hands and inflexible thumbs. I guess, for me, the cramps from having to bend my thumb a little more than what feels natural, would just take some getting use to. I just hope I do not get any bunions from it. In mode 3, the Bazooka behaves like an arcade joystick with two single fire and two turbo fire buttons capable of producing 15 signals per second, as well as throttle control. And in mode 4, the gamer will get four single fire buttons and a throttle control. Now, whilst the Bazooka is not about to replace sophisticated game pads in modes 3 and 4, it does have an advantage over them because of the throttle control. This feature would be most useful in arcade games that require two joysticks. To fully enable it, select the two joystick modes supported by the particular game and calibrate the joystick as instructed by the game manual concerned. Note, however, that the functioning of buttons C and D as well as the throttle control in modes 3 and 4 are dependent on the dual joystick mode. If at any point the joystick does not respond as it should under the various modes when playing through Windows 95, the user should see whether the particular mode corresponds to what has been set under the control panel of Windows 95. Personally, I had not encountered such problems when reviewing the Bazooka, but the control panel would have been the first place that I looked at had I encountered such a problem. Apart from all that, the Bazooka looks really chic and provides for a generally comfortable grip. Its wide handrest at the base of the grip allows for greater precision handling as well as alleviates wrist cramps. Of course, all this is relative to the user's general size, but as far as I can tell, my ``kill rates'' have generally gone up. So I guess this is one joystick I would be happy to have since it distributes stress to the whole of my arm instead of concentrating it on my wrist or elbow. I guess that is why the Bazooka marketers referred to it as ``ergonomic in design''. It has a wide and heavy base with no obtrusive slide controls for alignment error correction to mar its sleekness. Those alignment controls are placed underneath the base which not only makes the joystick look better but ensures that any accidental adjustments are avoided. What more, it comes with a 183-centimetre cable. Now, if only someone had thought of a better name than Bazooka!

Westwood holds off Clarke by a stroke to win TPC of Europe
EDS: ADDS details, prize money, quotes, byline, RECASTS in parts By ROY KAMMERER Associated Press Writer
ALVESLOHE, Germany (AP) _ England's Lee Westwood Monday sank a clutch birdie on his final hole to hold off Darren Clarke at the TPC of Europe and capture his second title of the year. Westwood, the 25-year-old Ryder Cup player, holed a 20-foot putt (7 meters) to capture the dlrs 1.9 million event by a shot after letting a four-stroke lead melt way. ``It's the biggest putt of the week, because I finally managed to close the door,'' said Westwood. Westwood, who fired a course record 61 Sunday, finished with a 66 and 23-under 265 to win his first tournament in Europe this season, having earlier won on the other side of the Atlantic at the Freeport McDermott Classic held in New Orleans. Clarke made a late charge by stringing four birdies together as the Northern Ireland player finished with a round of 68 and a 266 total. Masters champion Mark O'Meara, who also chased Clarke was third at 269 and a final round 70. He shot himself out of contention with a 11th hole double bogey. After taking what seemed to be a sure four-stroke lead into the 16th, Westwood appeared to be hit by nerves as Clarke's birdie run mounted. He missed an eight-foot putt on the 16th for his first bogey of the day, then struggled to play even on the 17th. ``It's difficult when a player like Clarke is chasing you. He can birdie every hole,'' said Westwood. But Clarke failed to position himself for another birdie on his approach shot on the par-5 17th, while Westwood launched a perfect shot down the center of the fairway on his final hole. ``That's a great drive,'' said Mark O'Meara, Westwood's playing partner, in his first European tournament since winning his green jacket in Augusta. Westwood said final two rounds of 61 and 66 were the best of his five-year career. ``It's the first time I've ever done that _ hopefully it's not the last,'' said Westwood. Bernhard Langer finished with a 68 and 271, along with Ireland's Philip Walton. The German, a two-time winner of the tournament, also knocked himself out of contention with a double bogey on his second hole. ``You just want to stick your head in the sand _ I'm very happy with my round after that,'' said Langer, still searching for his first title this season. The scores, although low, were nothing compared to Sunday's third round when Westwood shattered the course record by two strokes and O'Meara matched it. ``I'm surprised the scores weren't better. Maybe we used up all the birdies yesterday,'' said Walton, whose fourth-place finish came after he missed five straight cuts. Westwood took home dlrs 298,804 for his third career title on the European tour. (rk)

BC-Kazakstan-Germans
German minister says German-Russians returning home not burden
By BIRGIT BRAUER Associated Press Writer
ALMATY, Kazakstan (AP) _ Ethnic Germans returning home from the former Soviet Union are not placing a burden on Germany's pension system, the country's labor minister said Monday. Most of the returnees are young people taking jobs that most Germans would refused to accept, Norbert Bluem said following a three-day visit to Kazakstan. There has been heated debate in Germany about the ``Aussiedler'' from the former Soviet Union who are entitled to pensions because of their ethnic roots, even though the never contributed to the pension fund. ``The debate about Aussiedler causing financial problems for the German pension system is not only wrong, it it also stupid because it nurtures resentment,'' Bluem said. The German Labor Ministry says only 11 percent of ethnic German returning from the former Soviet Union are over 60 years of age, compared with 21 percent of Germany's total population. However, 33 percent of the returnees are children or teen-agers, compared with 19 percent of Germany's population. Germans went to Russia about 200 years ago at the invitation of the German-born Empress Catherine the Great who granted them land, religious freedom and other special privileges in return for helping to modernize the country. During World War II, Stalin ordered all ethnic Germans in the lower Volga region deported to Siberia and Central Asia as potential traitors. Thousands died in labor camps or coal mines. Germans started leaving the former Soviet Union during Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika reforms in the late 1980s. Since 1989, the number of Germans in Kazakstan has fallen by 75 percent, from around 1 million to 250,000 today. In recent years, Germany has tried to persuade ethnic Germans to stay where they are, because of its high unemployment rate and ballooning federal deficit. (str/ls)

IT is very rare to come across an organisation which can afford to start off with a completely automated system. Hotel chains may be able to start off with an integrated private automatic branch exchange (PABX) system which ensures that telephone calls are recorded, and printed rather than linked with the billing system, and where the cash register in the restaurant downstairs is also linked to the billing system. For most companies, however, growth is gradual and incremental. Generally, components stand alone and function individually. Then they are pulled into a functioning system. For example, if you are running a new company, you might plan on building an intranet in two years' time. At the moment you can't afford to invest in all the equipment, your staff aren't trained and you have not generated the amount of resources (paperwork, etc.) to make it worth such an investment in any case. Therefore, you might decide to buy a PC and some software which will help with specific jobs, such as accounting. This gives your staff time to become used to dealing with computers. When the time for building your intranet comes, you will probably have to invest in enhancing your machines but hopefully you will have kept staff accustomed to dealing with computers, accumulated enough resources to make using an intranet worthwhile and invested in enough equipment to keep development costs low. When investing in standalone equipment look to your future needs and consider investing in equipment with capabilities beyond your present requirements. For example, when buying a cash register for your new hotel, you might want to invest in a machine which generates information which is not used yet, such as an electronic cash register which is capable of integrating point of sale with invoicing and inventory packages. When automating a factory, you might choose to buy a robot which paints cars which is capable of linking to your inventory and production assessment systems but which for the first year is used only for painting with human operators assessing inventory and production schedules. The first year you will only use part of the machine's capabilities but when it comes to pulling together your equipment into a computer network, you will have the right tool in place. Be careful if you are investing in equipment where the technology is changing rapidly. If standards have not been developed you may find yourself investing in equipment which becomes obsolete before you are ready to proceed to systems integration. To avoid such problems, assess the current and future situation with vendors and consultants. As a general rule of thumb, many people recommend not to adopt technology which is less than two years old. When planning ahead, consider the facilities necessary to your future needs. For example, if you are installing a telephone system and investing in standalone computers, you might want to add in the infrastructure necessary for your planned local area network (LAN). When installing a PABX system you have to install wiring cables in the walls and ceilings to connect each telephone. Save future remodelling costs by installing network cable for your LAN on the same path at the same time. One of the costs of implementing information technology (IT) is acquiring trained users. Training can be expensive and keeping trained staff can be more difficult still in times of labour shortages. Paying trained staff premium wages will significantly reduce your training costs and keep your production level high. With evolving technology, training has become a vital success factor to the implementation of new systems and applications. Today it is no longer valid to put training off until the economic climate is more stable, nor is it cost-effective to send a large group of employees on general training sessions. Be prepared to have an ongoing training budget and use your training provision as a selling point in your marketing or recruitment. Consider the pros and cons of hiring staff straight out of technical college compared to hiring staff with experience but without the technological skills you need.

DO YOU WANT everyone in your office to share information instantly? Do you want to provide marketing and sales support, disseminate training materials and schedules quickly and cheaply? Do you dream about a system where collaboration means all members share and have immediate access to all necessary resources? If so, you need an office computer network. Computer networks allow you to banish resource hogging corporate documents that are now produced on paper like human resources guides, office and phone directories, parts and price information, newsletters, annual reports, maps, company facilities and product information literature. Computer networks allow you to store, manipulate and disseminate information quickly and cheaply. Local area networks A Local Area Network (LAN) is a computer network where computers are linked by a cable. Local area networks are often used by companies to allow members to share files and applications. In a network one set of computers asks another computer for files and services. The computer which asks for the files or services is called the client. The computer which provides the files or services is the server. The Network Operating System (NOS) ties a client to a server. Servers can provide, store and transfer files, access other servers, organise e-mail, printing queues etc. LANs allow everyone to share a printer and a file server, saving the company considerable investment costs. Adding an application server means everyone can share software packages. This means that you need not invest in expensive PCs as everyone can use cheaper 'dumb terminals' - computers without memories or processors which access the servers and keep documents stored there. With the appropriate software, LANs also support local e-mail between users and share modems among workstations. Sounds good? There is one big disadvantage: sharing applications can be expensive in terms of software licenses. When you use an application server, you can either buy a licence for each client, or you can invest in more software which regulates how many clients can use the package. Either way, when using branded products, licensing costs can rise very quickly. Enter the intranet This problem has been overcome by newer technology. Intranets are LANs which use Internet technology. Where a LAN is accessed through a file manager, an intranet is accessed through a browser. What does this mean? An intranet is based on the World Wide Web (WWW) model. The WWW categorises resources by URL, Universal Resource Locators, which are then referred to as links within a `web page'. When you click on a hyperlink, there is always an underlying URL that transports you to `another place' on the web containing various resources, eg, text, video, images etc. Your browser recognises what form information is stored in by the MIME (multipurpose Internet mail extensions) type and/or the file extension, and automatically does whatever is necessary to display the contents of the document. The technology used in browsers is extremely user friendly, just requiring users to `point and click' their way to resources. HTML (HyperText Markup Language), the `native' language of the WWW, is a simple programming language and there are many software packages offering shortcuts to web page design if users want to build extra resources. The web browser is, in effect, a `container' for a compound document. A compound document has several elements, which can include images, music, or even entire programs. The browser co-ordinates these elements to display the document. Another huge advantage is that the underlying structure of intranets (called a platform) is very flexible. Intranets rely on two formats which transmit data between linked computers. One is called Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and the other is Internet Protocol (IP). Working together they form the TCP/IP platform. This platform allows all different types of computers and computer networks to communicate with each other. Using TCP/IP it doesn't matter which network operating system anyone is using as web browsers are designed to read the data on all types of platforms. You can access information stored on a `Mac' as easily as information stored on a Unix machine. This means that you have no problem integrating inherited machines with newly acquired machines in your office. Redundancy costs are reduced significantly. How to set up an intranet If you don't already have a local area network, you need to set one up. This requires computers, wiring, a NOS, and a network interface card which connects the wiring to the NOS. To turn your LAN into an intranet you need to make sure that you have the appropriate software to display HTML files, TCP/IP communication and, if necessary, multimedia. In other words, you need a browser, assorted software and perhaps sound and video cards. You can choose to invest in software or download freeware from the internet. There are two different types of wiring which can be used to set up LANs. One uses coaxial cable which looks like the cable which goes to your TV antenna. The other uses twisted pair wiring which looks like fat telephone wires. The coaxial cable generally connects all the machines on the network on a single bus or line. This is generally called a bus.(Refer to Diagram 1.) The twisted pair wire uses a hub, a traffic intersection which directs traffic from one point to another in an intranet. This type of network is generally called a star. (Refer to Diagram 2.) Bus topologies used to be popular because they were cheaper to set up. In the last few years, star topologies have become more popular because their price has gone down and they are more flexible. Connecting intranets to make extranets A strategic use of intranets is to link your information network to that of your business partners. This is called an extranet. To do this you need a firewall to prevent unauthorised access. A client who wants to connect to the outside world has to go through the server to connect to the router, a traffic intersection which directs traffic from one point to another between an intranet and the outside world. When the server and router are configured to examine traffic before allowing requests and information to pass, then the client is deemed to go through a firewall. An extranet can be defined as a firewall to firewall connection between intranets. (Refer to Diagram 3.) In other words, requests from your sister company will be allowed through, but requests from strangers will not be allowed through. Development considerations When taking decisions concerning computer networks, consider the following points. First, decide which materials should be put online first and which materials can be added gradually. Everyone will have different priorities and it may take some time to come to a decision. Second, ensure that information is not altered without authorisation. You may consider asking each author or department to be responsible for their own set of resources. Third, once the system is online, consideration must be given to training users to develop new materials. Developing materials for LANs will mean product training for developers. If you choose to run an intranet you may choose to use authoring software which converts documents automatically to HTML format. You may also ask your technical department to make up various templates which can be used to put new information online while keeping the same look and feel as the existing system. Templates are a particularly useful device when putting regularly generated information online such as quarterly reports and so forth. Fourth, to ensure that the look and feel of the system remains the same even if the original developers leave, write a highly detailed style guide. Make sure that the style guide is adhered to so that users can access resources easily and quickly.

MARKET sentiment remained soft as evidenced by a persistent and slow downward push. The conclusion of the RHB-Sime Bank deal on April 23 was insufficient for the market to recover. However, it did allay earlier concerns on the funding aspect. RHB will purchase Sime Bank for RM368 million after disposing six subsidiaries. The Petronas-MISC-Konsortium deal was concluded on April 30. However, there were also corporate deals which failed to be concluded such as the reverse takeover of Ayamas. Concerns on the uncertainties of the overall market continues to be a nagging factor. MAS has yet to announce its restructuring as at May 4. Omega Securities has been suspended from trading until its minimum liquid funds is fulfilled. And there is a mixed feeling on the raising of the foreign equity stake to 61 per cent from 49 per cent for the telecommunications sector. However, the stake must be reduced back to 49 per cent within five years. Money supply M3 for March moderated to 13.7 per cent year on year. This slower money supply growth is worrisome as it suggests the economy is slowing. On the warrants market, an interesting development relating to extending their expiry dates has created excitement in a rather dull market. It started off with Apex-W, expiring on June 27 1998, being granted an extension of another year to June 27 1999 by the Securities Commission. This was followed by the proposal for TA-W to extend its maturity date from Nov 22, 1998 to May 22, 1999. The precedent for extending the warrant maturity date was set by UCB-T when it was given an extension from July 31, 1997 to Dec 17, 1997. In Apex-W case, it is restoring the duration of the warrant to the normal five years from the current four years. Similarly, TA-W of 4.5 years is seeking for an extension to five years. However, IOIPB-W and K HIN-W, both of four year duration, will expire on their maturity dates with no extension as they are due to expire in May. However, it is wrong to assume that all warrants of less than a five-year duration will automatically be extended. There may be speculation on an extra time period for warrants currently of less than a five-year duration. The bet is for the market to improve and hopefully, warrants will be exercised to pay off bond holders. Rating Agency Malaysia estimates some RM3 billion bond issues with warrants will mature in 1998. Warrants are sweeteners to attract subscribers to corporate bonds. The idea is for investors to exercise the warrants, ie converting to mother shares. With the cash raised, the corporation can pay off the bond holders. The drop in the share market has upset this idea as the warrant exercise prices are above that of the mother shares. It is cheaper to buy mother shares than to convert. A warrant is thus basically a bull market instrument. On the extension of the existing warrants to the five-year duration, the impact will be more on the warrant prices than on the mother shares. This will increase the time premium component of the warrant valuation. Based on the Blacksholes pricing model, adjusted to five years for those of less than 4.5 years, warrant prices improve. This would probably provide the opportunity for warrant holders to cut losses. On the technical side, the outlook has not changed as it continues to mark time. This must be sounding wordy by now as I continue to hold on to the bullish technical view. The slide in the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange Composite Index from the February high of 764.94 points has not negated the bullish view yet as the 470.43 point low of January has not been violated; the current probability suggests that it is unlikely to be breached. IN the last article, we examined background printing and the wrapping feature in Microsoft Word's Clip-Art pictures. Wrapping allows you to control the text-picture alignment which is important for the aesthetic appeal of the entire document. Today, we will examine this wrapping feature further. Once you have inserted the ClipArt picture, invoke Format -) Picture. Click on the Wrapping tab. You will see the options Square, Tight, Through, None and Top and Bottom. Below these, you will see another set of options labelled: Both sides, Left, Right and Largest side. These options help to fine tune the picture-text alignment and set the distance of the text from the edges of the picture. These options become active (i.e. can be used) only when you choose Square, Tight and Through. Let's suppose you want the text to flow in such a manner that the distance of the text from the left edge of the picture is greater than the distance of the text from the right edge. First, create some text and then insert a ClipArt picture in the middle of the text. Use Format -) Picture (Wrapping tab) to get wrapping options. Click on Square in the Wrapping Style options. Then, click on both sides in the Wrap to set off options. Choose `1''' in the spinner labelled left: this will create one inch of space between the picture's left border and the text. Similarly, use the spinner labelled right to alter the distance between the text and the right border of the picture. If you were to set the spinner at 0.3-inch, there will be 0.3-inch of space between the picture's right border and the text. You can get unusual but very appealing effects by using different settings for the right and left spinners. Sometimes, you can get a very elegant look by adding borders around the ClipArt Picture. Use the Format -) Picture command and click on the Colours and Lines tab. You will see three vertically stacked areas labelled: Fill, Line and Arrows. Almost the entire dialogue box is in subdued grey because a number of the features, such as arrows, are not applicable to ClipArt. Only the Fill (Colour) and Line (Colour) pulldown menus are active. The default settings on the Fill colour and Line colour menus are No Fill and No Line respectively. To add a blue border around the ClipArt picture, click on the menu arrowhead in Line. Choose Blue from the colour palette. This has the effect of drawing a blue border around your ClipArt picture. When you enter a particular colour in the pulldown menu, the rest of the features in the Line area become active because they become relevant options. These are Dashed, Style and Weight. Dashed allows you to choose a particular pattern for your border. Options include a series of little diamonds, dots, dashes and so on. If you were to choose Blue for Colour and the dots for Style, you will get a border of blue dots. The Style menu allows you to choose several types of patterns for the border. Options include thick double lines or a thick and a thin double line and so on. For instance, you can get a nice effect where the ClipArt picture appears to be nestled in a frame when you choose the last option in the Style pulldown menu, namely a thick line nestled within two thin lines. You can alter the thickness of the border by changing the settings on the Weight menu. A larger number causes a thicker line. Another trick that enhances the appearance of your ClipArt picture is the presence of the Fill colour. The colour menu in the Fill area allows you to add a colour of your choice to the space between the Clip Art picture and the border created by the Line menu. You need to choose the appropriate colour from the Fill (colour) menu. Once you have chosen a particular colour, the small checkbox titled semi- transparent will become active. When you click on this box, the colour in the fill area will take on a lighter, somewhat transparent hue. This hue goes very well with darker coloured lines for the borders. You can add a very classy look to your Clip-Art picture by using the special fill effects Fill (Colour) and patterned line effects in Line (Colour). The Fill (Colour) pulldown menu has an option labelled Fill effects. This allows you to choose a combination of various hues for the background; such as a lighter hue at the top which darkens progressively to the bottom. You can choose from several different effects. Similarly, the Line (Colour) pulldown menu has the option Patterned Lines. This allows you to choose from options such as bubbles, crosswires, brickwalls, and so on. The ClipArt feature offers numerous enhancement possibilities. By trying out different combinations of Special Fill Effects and Patterned Lines, it is possible to obtain outstanding results. You should experiment freely with various Colours, Styles and Weights in the Line options for the borders. Then, you should experiment with the different Fill colours and fill effects and examine your work with the semi-transparent feature. You must be careful that your choice of colours for the borders match well with the choice of colours for the lines. For example, dark blue borders with a light blue fill colour give a pleasant look while dark blue borders and a dark blue fill colour may cause your borders to become invisible. AMONG THE 27 states in Brazil, one stands out eminently. While the national exports grew at a rate of 18 per cent for 1996, the industries in Rio Grande Do Sol managed better at 26.2 per cent. The federation of industries (the Brazilian equivalent to the Federation of Malaysian Manufacturers) in most states of Brazil, with the exception of Sao Paulo, do not even have a building of their own. But in Rio Grande Do Sul, the federation of industries has a large headquarters with a state-of-the-arts convention centre which often attracts symphony orchestras from musically-inclined countries like Austria. Though many industries in Rio Grande Do Sul would prefer to attribute this success to their competitiveness, the key to this prosperity lies with Mercosur, the incipient customs union that stimulates trade between four countries. Though not as big as the European Union (EU), Mercosur is the most effective trade block in Latin America at present and its objectives almost similar to the European body. Besides Brazil, the other three members of Mercosur are Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. Chile and Bolivia stand at the fringes as associate members. With the formation of Mercosur in 1990, Rio Grande Do Sul found itself in a strategic position of being located at the hub of the customs union. Thus, the state became the gateway for the exchange of trade between Brazil, the biggest economic power in South America and its Mercosur partners. `When the idea of Mercosur was first mooted, everyone thought the state was doomed as it will have to compete with agriculture-dominated economies of Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. But while the argriculture sector of the state faced competition, the other sectors of the economy like manufacturing and heavy industries prospered,' says Florence Rosa, the director of international affairs for the state of Rio Grande Do Sul. Rosa says the formation of Mercosur enables industries in Brazil, especially from Rio Grande Do Sul, to market their products to more than 200 million people. The combined gross domestic product of the Mercosur countries is more than US$1.2 billion. The ultimate objective of Mercosur is to be a trade block encompassing all the countries in Latin America. The trade block also hopes to achieve a common external tariff among all countries in Latin America, thus it should be able to rival other trade blocks like the EU and the North America Free Trade Area (NAFTA). But this grand-design, targeted to crystallise within the next 10 years, has to cross several bridges first. First it has to remove the remaining internal tariff for certain products that are traded between the Mercosur members itself. Brazil, the dominant partner in Mercosur, has 27 products with tariff protection, Argentina 220 products, Uruguay and Paraguay 900 products each. The tariff is to give some form of protection for the manufacturers of these products. `We hope to remove all tariff barriers between Mercosur members by the year 2006. Then there will be an even more effective trade flow between Mercosur members,' says Rosa. There is also a common external tariff factor that has to be considered. Currently, the common external tariff among the Mercosur four countries averages 12 per cent. But this common external tariff has to be reduced further to ensure uniformity with other countries in Latin America, thus paving the way for the entry of more countries into Mercosur. Chile, for instance, has plans to cut its external tariff from 11 per cent to eight per cent this year. But Brazil and Argentina have plans to raise the external tariff of Mercosur countries from the present average of 12 per cent to 15 per cent. The proposed increase in external tariff means it will be a longer wait for Chile to be a full-fledged member of Mercosur. The addition of Chile into Mecosur means a lot as it will be a major step forward in the Latin America trade block becoming a reality. The move to raise external tariff is basically to add more revenue to the coffers of both countries, especially Brazil which is under severe pressure to reduce its public debt deficit and devalue its currency, the real. A devaluation will mean a nightmare for Argentina and the other two Mercosur members as these countries will depend a lot on exports to Brazil. A devaluation of the real will also further delay the removal of existing internal tariff structures between Mercosur countries. The formation of Mercosur also faces competition from the all-powerful United States which has set its sights on forming a Free-Trade Area of America (FTAA) by the year 2005. The FTAA will encompass 34 countries from the whole continent and be even bigger than the EU. US president Bill Clinton visited several Latin American countries last year with the hope of securing allies for the formation of FTAA, but his talks did not progress as expected. Brazil and a few other South American countries prefer to fully develop the Mercosur first, before even thinking of FTAA. 'We want to see Mercosur progress. Only then will Brazil be able to focus its attention on other trade blocks in the continent. Although there are disputes on tariff structures, Mercosur is here to stay,' exerts Rosa. Although Brazil is resisting the formation of FTAA, it does want to see a trade pact between all countries in the continent eventually. This is necessary if it wants to explore new markets for its massive economy. While the development of Mercosur faces challenges at the top of the administrative heirachy, on the ground, the trade integration between Mercosur countries is moving well. A new US$,36 million border crossing between Brazil and Argentina was opened early this year to cut waiting time for hauliers. Talks are also underway between Mercosur countries on strategic government procurement of goods and services, which amounts to about US$ 70 billion a year. The Mercosur countries have also agreed on cross-border transfer of pension rights. All the wealth in the exchange of trade between Mercosur countries has a tremendous effect on the industries in Rio Grande Do Sul. Out of the US$ 15.56 billion of trade flow between Brazil and its Mercosur partners, US$ 4 billion was attributed to industries in Rio Grande Do Sul. Dr Luciano Andre, the executive secretary to the Federation of Industries of Rio Grande Do Sul, says that more than 20,000 people from all over Brazil use their facilities every week. Goods to be exported to other Mercosur countries can only be done after obtaining certificates from the Federation of Industries of Rio Grande Do Sul. The federation issues a certificate after ascertaining that the goods meet the local content requirement. `Besides Mercosur, the state also thrives because of its excellent infrastructure and its proximity to Sao Paulo,' says Andre. Sao Paulo is regarded as the commercial capital of Brazil but it is already congested. `So many investors come here because the infrastructure facilities. For instance the state has one of the best roads in the country and it facilitates the movement of goods from one point to another with minimum logistics trouble,' says Andre. Rio Grande Do Sul's strategic position at the hub of Mercosur and its infrastructure has enabled the state to attract multinational companies, especially in the automobile sector, to set up investments in the state. Andre says among the companies due to start operations are General Motors, Ford and Goodyear Tyres manufactures. `The main objective of locating their operations in the state is to tap the market of Mercosul countries. For instance more than 30 truck bodies are exported to Mercosul countries per day,' he says.

WE continue our discussion on a type of random access memory chip, the dynamic RAM or DRAM chip. There are two types of DRAM - the single inline memory modules RAM (SIMM RAM) and dual inline memory modules RAM (DIMM RAM). The SIMM RAM for personal computers (PCs) before the 486 have 30-pin connectors while newer PCs have 72-pin SIMM RAMs. However, DIMM RAM comes with 168-pin connectors. Ever wonder why the SIMM must be installed in pairs while the DIMM comes single? Well, the answer is simple. For Pentium-based PCs, the motherboard supports the central processing unit (CPU) at 64 bits. A SIMM RAM transfers data at 32 bits. Therefore, to transfer data at 64 bit to match the CPU's bus width, you need two SIMM RAMs. So, each bank of RAM will consist of two slots for inserting SIMM RAM. What about DIMM RAM? Well, each DIMM RAM is able to transfer 64-bit data at one time. Therefore, its bank will consist of only a single DIMM RAM. From early last year, it gained wide usage. It is expected to be used mainly in Pentium and Pentium II-based PCs. The RAM chips come in either one of these two types: parity or non-parity. A parity RAM will check itself for errors using the ninth bit built in the chips. The extra one bit will be used for this purpose while the other eight bits will be used for operations. This ninth bit will be able to prevent corrupted data from being written onto secondary storage devices. However, parity RAM chips are more expensive than non-parity chips. Non- parity RAM chips do not have the extra one-bit chip thus making it cheaper but without the checksum operations. Most home PC motherboards are meant for non-parity chips. Bear in mind that non-parity systems will support both parity and non-parity RAM chips but not the opposite. Parity systems will only support parity chips and not non-parity chips. RAM that is able to fix error on data, such as error-correcting code (ECC) RAM is used for the new 440 LX chipset in Pentium II machines. The connector of a DRAM may be in chrome or gold. A gold-plated RAM is more expensive than the tin-plated connectors as it lasts longer and does not corrode easily. However, use RAMs that have the same type of metal as its connectors compared to the slot on the motherboard to avoid chemical corrosion between the two metals. You must also be careful to select a RAM that suits the voltage of your CPU as the voltage difference may burn the RAM chips on the board. Older CPUs use five volts while processors after the second generation of Pentium (Pentium 75 above) use 3.3 volts as core voltage. DIMM RAM uses only 3.3 volts. Refer to your PC's documentation for more details. To insert a RAM into its slot, you must follow these few steps. First, remember to ground yourself as memory chips are prone to electrostatic discharges. You can touch some metal objects to de-charge yourself. Insert the SIMM RAM into its slot at a 45-degree angle and make sure that the notch near the centre of the slot fixes nicely with the RAM, otherwise you may accidentally insert it in the opposite direction. Make sure the connectors are firmly in the slot. Hold the two ends of the RAM and lift it up. The RAM will hold firmly upwards with one click from each side of the tabs on the slot. That's it, you're ready to go. Switch on the computer and observe the RAM test. If there's an error or beeping, it means your RAM is not fixed properly in its slot or the RAM is damaged. Consult someone with computer technical knowledge if necessary to do it for you. In contrast to a RAM, the read-only memory (ROM) offers permanent data storage that is inalterable. ROM which has permanent data that can be altered but is rarely done is known as programmable read only memory or PROM. ROM that is often reprogrammed is known as erasable read only memory or EPROM. Simple, isn't it? The writer is in the Physics Department, Faculty of Physical and Applied Sciences, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia. E-mail feedback to rchee hijau.com.my.

LATE LAST year, Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux showed off its largest and latest high-tech water treatment plant in Vigneux-sur-Seine, 20km south of Paris. At its inauguration, French Environment Minister Dominique Voynet was impressed with the plant's ability to remove pollutants in water although, she said, it would be better if industries did not cause pollution in the first place. But we don't live in an ideal world: the pollution problem is unlikely to go away. And water suppliers need to continuously search for better ways to purify the water. Lyonnaise, which supplies drinking water to over 70 million people world-wide, focuses its research and development activities on new methods to purify drinking water and protect the environment, says Jack Moss, its international marketing director, water division. Its activities span the entire water cycle, from water resource management to wastewater treatment through a worldwide network of research and expertise centres. Daniel Villessot, deputy director of its technical and research division, says Lyonnaise spends over 300 million French francs a year on research and development. The bulk of the funds goes to Lyonnaise's International Water and Environmental Research Centre (CIRSEE) in Le Pecq, France, where about 300 scientists and technicians work on new processes to purify both raw and polluted water. CIRSEE designed the Cristal (Combination of Reactors Incorporating Separation and Adsorption of Liquids) process for the Vigneux-sur-Seine Membrane Ultrafiltration Plant which Lyonnaise claims is able to provide the highest quality of water possible now. The plant is the biggest in the world to use ultrafiltration membranes to treat drinking water. The Cristal process, according to Lyonnaise, improves the organoleptic quality of water and anticipates new types of pollution such as pesticides. It, thus, enables the plant to deal with accidental pollution which is frequent in surface water. The ultrafiltration membrane technique is said to eliminate unwanted flavours and tastes in water without the use of chemicals but preserves its natural mineral content. CIRSEE is also working on a wastewater reuse and recycling programme, because of limited fresh water resources and increasing demand for water. Bruno Levine, water reuse research engineer at CIRSEE, says recycled water can be used for non-potable purposes such as car wash, fountains, cleaning streets and flushing toilets. Other applications are in industries, for example in air-conditioners, and agriculture and landscape irrigation. Levine says recycled water can also be used to recharge ground water sources which can be affected by prolonged urban use. The recycling technology will lead to a 30 per cent reduction in water use, he says. Moss feels that ultimately, recycled water can be consumed by humans. But people are not psychologically prepared to consume recycled water. It will take a long time to convince them, he says. The Northumbrian Lyonnaise Technology and Research Centre in Newcastle, England, works on improving existing water distribution and wastewater collection systems. In Asia, Lyonnaise has set up the Asia-Pacific Technology and Research Network (Astran). Managed from Kuala Lumpur, the network has research centres in Macau, Sydney, Manila and Jakarta. Villessot says Astran will concentrate on water resources and problems specific to Asia. Lyonnaise's strong focus on RD, says Villessot, is to enable the company to maintain a competitive edge in the world market by providing added services at declining costs. Recognising the new global challenges, Compagnie de Suez and Lyonnaise des Eaux merged in April last year to form the Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux group. The merger, says Moss, is a `marriage of different capabilities.' Lyonnaise was in a capital-hungry cycle of business as the payback time of its Asian projects was over 10 years, he says. In the meantime, Suez, which had lost its industrial base but was cash rich and strong in electricity, was looking to refocus its activities. By coming together, the two companies could be in the forefront of private infrastructure services. Lyonnaise des Eaux, the water division of the group, is the world leader in the water sector, says Moss. The Fanco-Belgian group is refocusing on its three core business of energy, water and waste services and is planning to develop its operations outside the two countries. Last year, the group derived 30 per cent of its total revenue of 112.1 billion French francs from France, 44 per cent from Belgium and 26 per cent from the rest of the world. Its revenue from the Asia-Pacific region was three billion French francs. The energy sector contributed 64 billion French francs to the group's revenue in 1997, waste services 15 billion French francs and communications 2.4 billion French francs. Revenue from the water sector was 30 billion French francs in 1997, a seven per cent increase compared to 1996. This sector reported a profit of 1.4 billion French francs last year, an 11 per cent increase compared to 1996. With demand stabilising in Europe, the group's spotlight is shifting to the developing countries. It's positioning to seize the opportunities arising from deregulation of public monopolies and the growth of mega cities in these countries. The Asia-Pacific region contributes five per cent to the total revenue of the group. `It's a small amount but we plan to increase this to 15 per cent in five years,' says the group's Asia-Pacific president, Martin Negre. Lyonnaise plans to invest about US$1 billion in the next five years on several build-operate-transfer projects in the region. It already holds several water and wastewater concessions and projects in Macau, China, the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia, Vietnam, Thailand and Cambodia. Bruce W Bland, managing director of Lyonnaise (South East Asia) Sdn Bhd, says the company is prepared to invest over RM10 billion in Malaysia over the next two decades. It is eyeing several deals in Putrajaya, Cyberjaya and states which have yet to privatise their water supply. Bland says Lyonnaise and its local partners have invested over RM1 billion to supply bulk drinking water to 1.9 million people in Perak, Johor and Sabah. In Perak, Lyonnaise holds a 34.4 per cent stake in GSL Water Sdn Bhd, the concessionaire for supplying bulk drinking water to Taiping, Kerian, Larut and Matang districts. Its local partners are Gopeng Bhd (22.8 per cent), Wembley Industries Holding Bhd (20 per cent) and Sisma Water Technology Sdn Bhd (22.8 per cent). In Johor, Lyonnaise has a 25.5 per cent stake in Equiventures Sdn Bhd which supplies drinking water to the Johor Baru district. The local partners in the joint venture are Kembangan Dinamik Sdn Bhd (49 per cent) and Pilecon Engineering Bhd (25.5 per cent). Lyonnaise also owns Strategi Tegas Sdn Bhd, the operator of the Sungai Layang Water Treatment Plant and Sungai Johor Water Treatment Plant. In Sabah, Jetama Sdn Bhd holds the concession to supply water to the Kota Kinabalu area. It's a joint venture between Lyonnaise which holds a 35 per cent stake, the Sabah government (20 per cent), John Holland (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd (10 per cent) and Hume Industries Bhd (35 per cent). Privatisation doesn't necessarily lead to an increase in water prices, says Negre. In some countries with undeveloped infrastructure, he points out, people spend an enormous amount of time and energy to get their daily water supply. Often, he says, there is profiteering and the poor end up paying 10 to 20 times more to buy water. Lyonnaise, he says, is committed to supply water in a cheaper way for all to share. `There is no such thing as a free glass of water,' adds Bland. There are hidden costs in the water supplied by government agencies: the water is subsidised. By delegating the job to private companies, he says, governments can divert the money to meet other needs such as education, health and housing. Bland says governments also lack funds to improve existing networks. `By shifting the burden from the government to private companies, better services will be provided.' The efficiency gains will lead to a better water system at lower prices, he says. For example, Bland points out, three years after Equiventures took over operations, the quantity of water supplied in the Johor Baru district increased three times. Lyonnaise and its local partners in Equiventures invested RM800 million to have the automated, most technologically advanced water treatment plants in Malaysia, he says. Its computerised predictive and preventive maintenance programme has considerably reduced the number of plant breakdowns and cut total maintenance costs, he adds. In Macau, Negre says Lyonnaise and its partner, the New World Group, have successfully reduced non-revenue water from over 40 per cent to about 12 per cent after changing 70 per cent of the piping network. (Non-revenue water is water lost during the distribution process due to technical and non-technical factors such as leakage and theft). In Malaysia non-revenue water is between 40 and 45 per cent. Water is basic to life. Aware of the sensitivities involved in the business, Lyonnaise is painstaking in its choice of partners. `We go for genuine partnerships with the locals and have a responsible attitude to profits,' says Bland. And Lyonnaise takes a long-term view of investments, about 20 to 25 years, adds Moss. He says the payback time of its projects is over 10 years. Lyonnaise seeks to support the local community leadership, not usurp its powers, says Moss. `We advise, you decide.' Bland says Lyonnaise prefers the delegated management concept where the government retains ownership of assets and sets the price, quality and quantity of the drinking water.
