3Com Corp has announced the availability of its OfficeConnect Remote Dual Analogue router which is designed to enable access to information at the fastest speeds possible over analogue lines. According to 3Com's product line manager for entry-level systems PDD Andrew Moloney, the product is able to offer a near-integrated services digital network (ISDN) speed of 112 kilobits per second, which is equivalent to the power of two 56Kbps modems. He claimed the router also offers functionality over standard analogue lines but without the costs that are normally associated with maintaining a digital service. ``This product is ideal for small and mid-sized businesses because these outfits might not have the technical expertise to install complex products but need the advanced technology to keep them competitive in the current market,'' he added. Moloney said the new router is simple to install as users need only to connect their existing unit to their computer and existing phone lines. ``Once done, the hypertext markup language (HTML) Web-based tool takes the users through the configuration process. The system is usually up and running in under 30 minutes.'' With the new router, small organisations now have a high performance networking solution with competitive benefits that are typically found in large companies, according to Moloney. ``Organisations are now capable of implementing applications like electronic-mail (e-mail) while extending the local area network (LAN) to remote users,'' he said, adding that the router utilises already existing analogue phone lines to offer the benefits of high-speed information access. Another member of the OfficeConnect family is the Dual Speed Hub 8 which provides eight twisted-pair connections. With a built-in switch and Class II Fast Ethernet repeater, the product is designed specifically to cascade to other hubs and permit connection of up to four hubs in a series, Moloney said. Meanwhile, the OfficeConnect Switch 400 provides the flexibility in small-office switching. According to Moloney, users will be able to migrate effortlessly between 10 megabits per second and 100Mbps with the performance benefits of switching. Certified for domestic environments, the switch is designed to provide maximum throughput of 400Mbps and a direct connection to a server or end station or even to another hub or switch, he added. Now available in the market, the router is priced at US$745 (RM2,830). The hub costs US$755 while the switch is priced at US$755.

BC-Uganda-Rebels,0596
Ugandan government criticized for neglecting its own in favor of Sudanese rebels
AP Photos NAI101-103 By HENRY WASSWA Associated Press Writer
LIRA, Uganda (AP) _ Frightened nurses speak in low voices in the hospital where two soldiers groan in pain from wounds received when they stepped on a land mine. Sgt. Reuben Tugineyo and Cpl. Edward Adima were among 18 sent to protect the village of Oririm, 54 kilometers (30 miles) east of Lira two weeks ago when Lord's Resistance Army rebels penetrated deep into central Uganda. ``We followed the rebels ... they took off, leaving behind a land mine, which we stepped on,'' said Tuginyeo, 32. At the time, the army boasted that it had the rebels surrounded because they had ventured too far from their bases in southern Sudan. But by Friday, the rebels, operating in small units, had managed to elude government troops, and people expressed fears that the government of President Yoweri Museveni is on the losing end of the 11-year insurgency. ``They (the government) have already lost the war. The government is not effectively defending the people. They send a few soldiers to fight off the rebels,'' said Opio Moro, a Lira civic leader. ``For the war to end, there must be a mutual understanding between Uganda and Sudan.'' People in Lira and Oririm believe rebel penetration south and eastward from two northern districts has overstretched the army. They also believe Uganda's support for rebels in southern Sudan fighting the Islamic government in Khartoum has made it difficult to end the war with the LRA rebels. More than 10,000 people fleeing the rebel attacks have swarmed into Lira, 370 kilometers (230 miles) north of the Ugandan capital, Kampala. They are camped out in seven primary schools. ``People are panicking as they are not sure what will happen next. Soldiers are not permanent here. Only 18 were sent to defend our village,'' said Silvester Otiti Akeny, a teacher whose sister was killed in an attack during which he was briefly taken prisoner. Lira administrative officer Jacob Ettedu says the rebel tactic of avoiding major military and civilian centers to attack soft targets like remote villages at night has paid off. ``They move in very small groups. A whole government battalion is attracted by these small numbers. If they moved in groups of, say, 200, the army would finish them,'' he said. Another local official charges that Museveni's only brother, Gen. Salim Saleh, whom he named ``overseer'' of the Defense Ministry, spends more time helping Sudanese rebels than engaging the LRA. ``I asked Salim Saleh to come to our area and defend us,'' said Opio Moro. ``He told me he was going to Sudan. The army is engaged in Sudan and fighting wars in other countries.'' Others believe that the northern insurgency has gone on for so long because of the shift in Uganda's power base 12 years ago when Museveni, a southerner, ousted a government made up largely of northerners. The argument is that northerners may not be ready to accept a head of state from the south, and secretly sympathize with the LRA, whose goals, other than ousting Museveni, are vague. Around town, frustrated people blame the long war on the government's refusal to negotiate a peace settlement with LRA leader Joseph Kony. ``The war will never end here,'' said school principal John Etimu. ``Let the government talk with the rebels. Museveni's government supports rebels against Sudan, and in the process, neglects its people.''

Wanted: A society with a heart, MALAYSIAN BUSINESS xfdws WANTED-A-SOCIETY sked Emerging Markets Datafile May 16, 1998 MALAYSIAN BUSINESS ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. DESPITE Finance Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim's reiteration that layoffs should be kept to a minimum, `human bloodletting will be unavoidable' as MB writers predict (A Merger Wager, April 16 issue). In the same issue, a team member of Andersen Consulting cited casualty rates of between 30 per cent and 50 per cent in lost jobs, arising from bank mergers abroad. Then, on April 15, 1998, the president of the Malaysian Trade Union Congress reportedly announced that the number of retrenched workers stood at around 35,000 so far. The number of jobless in the foreseeable future seems to be headed upwards. Amid this gloomy scenario, there have been concerns that some still profitable companies may be taking advantage of the current situation to retrench their staff. Others cite mergers or acquisitions or plummeting demand as justifying the unkind cut. Still, others such as financially strapped companies may feel they have a watertight justification to cut their workforce. But there is a need for some lateral thinking in this layoff issue, specifically in tackling it. As people may be aware, the jobless disease can exact a big toll, both at the macro and micro levels. Rising unemployment can only mean reduced incomes, which in turn will backfire on businesses which removed them in the first place. But firms don't normally view things this way. They retrench mainly because they are short-term and desperate. Sometimes, they forget that they are in the business for the long haul. Retrenching staff can adversely affect the morale and productivity of the remaining staff, especially if their retrenched colleagues were to be given a raw deal. Those who are fortunate to remain in the payroll work under conditions of uncertainty until the economic recovery is in sight. Meanwhile, there are those who view the perceived excess staff like a gangrenous leg - to be quickly cut off, lest it endangers the bottomline of the companies. The business reengineering experts often think in terms of efficiency in justifying their recommendations to companies to remove staff from the payroll. The have no qualms as to what their recommendations could do to human lives who need food, drink, clothing and shelter as much as them. They will not understand the human trauma of being out of a job unless they experienced retrenchment themselves. The consultants and their converts often and primarily think in terms of ever-increasing improvements in corporate performance, recommending that companies should be lean and mean in a fiercely competitive world. This, they argue, is the stuff that business is made of, if they want to thrive in a dog-eat-dog world. Unfortunately, social considerations such as job security or job stability, a clean and healthy working environment, etc, are nowhere to be found among the higher rungs of their ladder of priorities. Perhaps, there is a need to rethink the whole business of being in business. Are we in business just for the sake of profits per se? Are we to think layoff at the first signs of trouble or weak demand. Let us not be quick to ape the American way of hiring when it's fine and firing when in decline. We need to fashion our own indigenous model -in good times, do not profligate but save wisely for the rainy days. That way, we will have the option of retaining jobs, instead of ruthlessly throwing people out of their jobs. We will then prove to be business owners or managers with a heart and a healthy social conscience, and our staff will surely love and remember us for it. This is the kind of loyalty and trust that staff are expecting their employers to display when the going gets tough, ie, employers remaining loyal to their staff at the time when their staff need them the most in keeping their jobs and earning a decent livelihood. Not only will staff love and remember them, they will also want to be loyal and give their best to their caring employers who stood by them. Still, the critical questions remain: how can jobs be saved in an economic and financial crisis? Can they be saved? If people are willing to put on their thinking caps, it is not difficult to arrive at a solution. Yes, we can save jobs - many jobs in fact, for the good of our country, families and individuals. There is no necessity to walk the path of least resistance and let go of our staff (those leaving voluntarily are exempted) so easily, unless of course there is a hidden agenda. Here, the various media can help by spreading the word that it is possible to save jobs, for example, by highlighting creative ways and means of preventing job destruction. One of the ways is for both the companies and unions to arrive at some amicable agreements to save jobs. Together, they can prevent the already flagging economy from becoming worse than it needs to be. Together, they have the capacity to restore job stability and job security before the job situation gets worse. For one thing, unions can initiate job-saving measures by laying meaningful concessions at the negotiating table with the employers. Concessions such as pay and benefit cuts can help to retain some staff under the payroll. The non-unionised employees can also follow the unions' example and accept lower remuneration and benefits to save jobs. Each senior staff or manager's pay cut has the potential of saving anything between two to four lower-paying jobs. Just think of the possibility of enlisting the support of more senior people in affected companies throughout the country to willingly accept pay and benefits cuts! Apart from wage cuts, companies should also do their part and explore innovative ways and means of reducing non-wage costs. In this regards, the involvement of staff in preventing their companies from declining or collapsing is crucial. The impact on our nation would be both positive and great if all parties concerned were to do just that. This, in turn, will help ease the needless trauma and anxiety arising from the possibility of losing one's job. Interestingly, there is a biblical example of how caring and concerned people helped those in need in a marvelous way. They truly sacrificed by selling their possessions and goods and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need. This story is recorded for us in the book known as Acts. Likewise, those who own or run businesses can make some sacrifices by, for example, selling some of the companies' assets to help avoid slashing jobs at the first sign of trouble. In bad times such as this, they could also consider trimming unnecessary non-wage costs, postponing non-critical capital expenditures, reducing wastage, implementing wage and benefit cuts and the like to prevent their profitability indicators from worsening, as well as to preserve the livelihood of their staff. For employees who see their pay cheques shrink, they should see their sacrifice as a way of helping their colleagues from being thrown out of jobs, which may otherwise cause much hardship to the unemployed and their dependents. For the more senior employees who suffer bigger paycuts in absolute terms, they need not fret but realise that they are contributing something worthwhile and meaningful in life. After all, how much does a senior staff need to live on? In a nutshell, all the above is part and parcel of what we, as a nation, should be striving to build - a society with a heart. Together, let us seize this opportunity to establish such a caring society.

Fontanelli wins 16th stage, Zuelle keeps overall lead
Eds: UPDATES with detail, official times, quotes.
ASIAGO, Italy (AP) _ After a long breakaway from the main pack, Fabiano Fontanelli edged Paolo Bettini and Mario Scirea at the finish of the Tour of Italy's 16th stage Monday. That trio of Italians finished seven seconds ahead of a group of chasing riders and nearly 12 minutes ahead of the top contenders. But Fontanelli was in 77th place before the stage and not a threat to the favorites for the overall title. Alex Zuelle, who opened up a substantial overall lead with a dominating time-trial performance Sunday, retained the pink jersey heading into the toughest climbing stages. Fontanelli was timed in 5 hours, 53 minutes, 53 seconds over the 227 kilometers (140.5 miles) from Udine to Asiago, into the Dolomite mountains. Zuelle was 29th on the day, 11:46 behind. Pavel Tonkov, the 1996 Giro d'Italia champion, finished 30th and remained second overall, 2:02 off the pace. ``I always believed I could do it today,'' Fontanelli said after his fourth career Giro stage triumph. ``I knew if I gave it a shot I could pull through with a win. There's no surprise. I've won stages before.'' Bettini had been the protagonist most of the day, breaking out in front along with Javier Ochoa of the Kelme team. Bettini repeatedly urged Ochoa to help do the work of providing a leading draft, but the Spaniard refused and Bettini eventually took off alone. He was joined at the front by Scirea and Fontanelli with about 10 kilometers (6 miles) remaining. ``I'm a little bitter. I don't know what the Kelme team was thinking,'' Bettini said. ``Fabiano I know very well. We were teammates last year so I know he's fast and could beat me.'' Tuesday's 17th stage takes the riders 217 kilometers (134.5 miles) from Asiago to Selva Val Gardena, including four tough mountain passes in the last 100 kilometers (60 miles). (hjf)

FANCY A dapper look, oozing with English charm and elegance? Then check out the Alfred Dunhill Spring/Summer 1998 collection, which draws on English style to fit the corporate businessman. The theme for this season's collection rests on slim and sleek tailoring with comfort as an underlying factor, while ties take on an English country garden theme. `English style is currently in vogue,' says Peter Tilley, Alfred Dunhill's international design and merchandise manager. `It's sartorial, reflecting the art of the tailor and the traditional English tailoring skills of London's Saville Row.' For those who are young at heart, the slim tailoring of Dunhill's designs emphasise cut and fit, belying a simple and understated elegance. Corresponding to today's expectations, clothes are comfortable; suits focus on lighter tones of grey and blue, and colours such as tan, naturals and pastels are used to soften jackets. Ties are filled with images of flowers, fruits and garden tools, swimming in vivid shades of orange, yellow, lime and deep red. The emphasis is on simple styling with soft, functional and lightweight material such as blends of wools and cotton to render the garments comfortable. The adventurous should find plenty of room to experiment with the many colours and prints that this collection offers. Tilley feels that the smartest and most conventional chap in the corporate workplace would just as easily and happily slip into something casual and dressed down on weekends and evenings. Dunhill's hacking jackets have a slim silhouette and come in varying shades and patterns. A majority of the jackets come in graphic checks in spicy mustards and browns or muted greens and greys to classic navy blues. Try throwing together a sophisticated look with a dark blue checked jacket with a bright blue shirt and grey pants. A shimmering grey tie tops off the look. The art of looking sophisticated with the many colours and designs to choose from lies in keeping the look balanced. Casual wear takes on both the sporty and the sophisticated touch. Weekend wear is a burst of colours ranging from bright hues of crimson to subdued shades of pastel blue. Try co-ordinating a powder blue blouson with navy blue corduroys and a blue and green checked cotton seersucker shirt. Sports jackets are also in again with a wider range of colours and patterns. Avid golfers will find that Dunhill has their love of the sport in mind in its golf wear collection. Golf shirts have wider armholes and are tailored slightly longer in the back to facilitate movement. Pants are made from Tencel and cotton, allowing for easier surface cleaning. For those who are still a mite baffled by two and three button jackets, here's a reminder: a three-button jacket tends to favour the slim, if your build is slightly on the tubbier side, go with the two-button jacket. The same rule of thumb applies to blazers; the six-button double-breasted blazer fits better on lean frames while the four- and two-button blazers are more suitable for tubbier frames. Also, if you prefer to follow the proper English way, only the middle button is done up in a three-button jacket.

THE RECARO name is renowned worldwide as a German product, and holds the position of undisputed leader in car seats the world over. The name draws covetous envy and inspires awe among the majority of motorists. Among drivers of luxury sedans, high-end sports coupes and `souped-up' racing or rally cars, Recaro is the seat of choice. Indeed, Recaro has become a cult brand in car seats worldwide, not only because of its snob value and aesthetic appeal, but also because of its ergonomic qualities. In the words of Recaro managing director Klaus Fricke, seats bearing the Recaro name are `more than just a technical extra'. He says Recaro seats offer added value, emphasising a certain zest which reflects a degree of hedonism for drivers with discerning tastes. Quietly - and with little fanfare - Recaro has come to Malaysia, and in the process, has made this country its regional base. For nearly a year now, Recaro seats have been made in Malaysia, and within the next few months, will be produced with 50 per cent local content. After overcoming initial teething technical problems, up to 80 per cent of Recaro seats made at its plant in Shah Alam now find their way back to Germany for the export market. This is on top of the 8,400 seats produced in 1997 which was delivered to Proton for the Putra. A little history. Recaro comes from the combination of the first two letters in Reutter and Carosserien. Two Reutter brothers, Wilhelm and Albert, had in 1906 set up the Wilhelm Reutter car and bicycle factory in Stuttgart, Germany. They gained a reputation for engineering excellence, producing non-production line vehicles in the Germany of the 1920s. After the Second World War, Reutter the company produced car bodies for Opel, BMW and Porsche, among others. When Porsche took over its operations fully in 1963, Reutter became Reutter Carosserien - shortened to become Recaro -producing seats for Porsche. In 1969, the brothers sold Recaro to a group made up of suppliers and competing firms, including seat manufacturer Keiper of Remscheid. The production base was also moved from Stuttgart to Kircheim. In Germany, the parent company is called the Keiper Recaro Group which has a total of nine factories all over the country. Recaro now supplies to 35 automobile manufacturers in 45 countries, and its seats are found in 50 different car brands worldwide. Its upmarket cachet is ensured by the fact that Recaro is the exclusive supplier of seats to Porshce. Speaking during the opening of the latest Recaro showroom in Shah Alam recently, Fricke said Recaro's international sales are expected to total around RM760 million this year. This is a 40 per cent increase from the RM540 million recorded last year. `Our goal is to increase production from the current 343,000 seats to 800,000 seats per year within the next five years. I truly believe Malaysia is part of this exciting strategy. Our growth here is based on mutual benefit,' he says. Recaro established a presence in Malaysia back in July 1997 with the setting up of Recaro South East Asia Sdn Bhd. It was set up with a local partner, Car Seat Malaysia Sdn Bhd which is in the process of acquiring an equity stake in the joint-venture. Malaysia has been chosen as its regional headquarters with the setting up of two production lines for the Recaro SR and N-Joy seats in Shah Alam at a cost of RM1 million. These production lines now employ 50 employees. Today, Recaro's investment in Malaysia has exceeded RM4 million, and this is expected to increase by another RM2 million with the planned production of a range of child seats. Last year, the Shah Alam plant produced 12,000 car seats valued at RM11.2 million for the local and export markets. Its local production is mainly geared to supplying seats for the Proton Putra and Proton Wira 1.8 rally car. Exports of Malaysian- made Recaro seats, meanwhile, go to Europe, Australia, Singapore, Hong Kong, Indonesia and Thailand. Recaro South East Asia managing director Jurgen Fritz says an increasing percentage of local components go into the manufacture of Recaro seats. `We consider Malaysia a good source of materials. We have chosen Malaysia as our regional headquarters because it offers our company positive prospects in terms of rich resources and world-class facilities. Furthermore, the government's open and liberal policies make Malaysia a viable and profitable location for foreign investors like Recaro,' he says. Looking after sales in the region is Malaysian Lau Man Chong, a 25-year veteran of the automotive industry who serves as Recaro South East Asia's regional sales manager. Lau says in the region, Recaro seats are exported to Singapore, Australia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Hong Kong. `The majority of our seats end up in the ``after-market'' segment where drivers take out their existing seats and replace them with Recaro seats,' he says. The current economic climate has not dampened Fritz's outlook on Recaro's prospects in Malaysia. He believes there are many challenges and opportunities still available in the region. `We have been in the business of making seats for over 90 years and during this time, there have been equally testing periods. We can weather this storm,' he says. Fritz says the current economic situation allows Recaro to be more competitive, thus enabling its export products to be more keenly priced. With increased local components, Recaro hopes to develop better pricing structures for both the local and export markets. `This strategy should increase demand, output and ultimately profit,' he says. He adds, `It is important to emphasise that Recaro established its operations in Malaysia as it sees the long-term growth for the Malaysian economy as excellent. While our exports to neighbouring countries are experiencing some current difficulties, these markets will recover, and Recaro will be in a good position to successfully exploit opportunities in these economies as they revive and rebuild,' he says.

BC-Zambia-Kaunda, 4th Ld-Writethru
Kaunda freed as state withdraws coup allegations lawyer, party officials
Eds: (AMs) UPDATES and recasts with background, comment from AP Photo LON101 By ANGUS SHAW Associated Press Writer
LUSAKA, Zambia (AP) _ Former President Kenneth Kaunda, freed from house arrest when coup-related charges against him were dropped Monday, immediately went to his opposition party headquarters to plan his next move. Kaunda, 74, walked out of the High Court in Lusaka after Attorney General Bonaventure Mutale said the state wouldn't prosecute Kaunda on charges he concealed prior knowledge of an Oct. 28, 1997, coup attempt. ``I feel great,'' said the nation's founding father, wearing a thick white beard he has grown since his arrest on Christmas day. Supporters waved two-finger victory salutes and cheered. Aides denied reports that Kaunda's retirement from politics was a condition of his release. ``There were no conditions. The state didn't have a case they could win,'' said Sakwiba Sikota, a lawyer for Kaunda. Kaunda drove through downtown Lusaka, waving his trademark white handkerchief, and met with supporters and colleagues at the headquarters of his United National Independence Party, the main opposition group. Kaunda said he was aware of pressure on him to hand over control of his party to younger leaders. ``I am going to listen to the people who have been discussing this, then I'll decide,'' Kaunda said. Party officials said Kaunda told them he wanted to convene a party convention to decide what to do next. The South African government welcomed Kaunda's release, saying in a statement that it ``creates an opportunity for all political parties to engage in a meaningful dialogue.'' Kaunda led Zambia to independence from Britain in 1964 and was president for 27 years until he was ousted by Frederick Chiluba in the first democratic elections in 1991. Last year's coup attempt against President Chiluba by junior military officers was quickly crushed by loyal troops. Many foreign countries had pressed Zambia to release Kaunda or give him a speedy trial. Also freed was Moyce Kaulungombe, Kaunda's bodyguard, who had faced the same charge as his boss. One state witnesses was to have testified that Kaunda predicted an ``explosion'' in Zambia days before the failed coup, said Wezi Kaunda, the politician's second son. Kaunda had spoken ``in the metaphorical, social sense. That was the best evidence they had,'' Wezi Kaunda said. Mwangala Zaloumis, an official of Kaunda's party, said Kaunda's arrest has increased his popularity. In January, Kaunda was transferred from a maximum security prison to house arrest. His release on Monday came on the first day of the trials of 81 suspects _ most of them soldiers _ who were arrested on suspicion of involvement in the coup attempt. Kaunda repeatedly declared his innocence. The charge against him carried a possible penalty of life imprisonment. Most of the other suspects are charged with treason and face the death sentence. BC-Russia-Mir, 3rd Ld-Writethru
Russians hopeful Mir computers will soon work again to conform.
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with computer working again, edits AP Photos MOSB101,103. By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ The central computer on board Mir was working again Monday night, after a three-day breakdown that threatened to postpone the Russian space station's last rendezvous with a U.S. shuttle. The Mir crew now hopes to reactivate the station's automatic steering system, said Valery Lyndin, a spokesman for Russian Mission Control. The shuttle can only dock with Mir when the steering system keeps it properly aligned. The space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to lift off Tuesday and dock with the station Friday to pick up astronaut Andrew Thomas, the seventh and last American to live on the Russian outpost. Lyndin said space officials have not yet determined why Mir's computer broke down on Saturday. Russian cosmonauts Talgat Musabayev and Nikolai Budarin replaced it with another unit, but the new unit failed on Sunday when they tried to switch it on. Ground controllers fully loaded the software into the computer Monday night, and the crew was able to get it working again within about 90 minutes. Reactivating the steering system can take an entire day. During a chat with ground controllers during the repair process, Musabayev said the situation on board ``isn't bad'' but added that he was concerned that it occurred on the eve of the shuttle's launch. ``I'm worried not for myself, but for the flight program,'' he said. Mir's computer repeatedly failed last year, prompting Russian space officials to send up a replacement on a shuttle ferry flight in January. That unit failed on Saturday after five months of trouble-free operation. The station's crew has replaced it with a back-up computer brought up by a Russian cargo ship. Mir's main computer operates the station's motion control system, and when it fails, the station's energy supply is threatened because it can't keep its solar panels in optimum alignment with the sun. Depending on how much energy was lost, it can take from one to three days to get the orientation system fully on-line. Fortunately, when the latest trouble occurred, the station was on the so-called solar orbit, which puts it in direct sunlight round the clock. As a result, the Mir's solar panels have remained in full sunlight. The crew also shut down some systems to save energy, and as a result Mir's batteries were full on Monday, making it easier for the crew to restore the orientation system, Lyndin said. (vi/mr/ls)

BC-Afghanistan-Quake, 4th Ld-Writethru,0629
Aid supplies begin to reach quake-stricken area in Afghanistan
Eds: Adds details from earthquake site throughout. No pickup AP Photos LON108-109 By PHIL GOODWIN Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ Some hobbled on makeshift crutches, a few carried stretchers and others broke into a run as helicopters carrying emergency aid landed Monday in remote northern Afghanistan, devastated by an earthquake that killed more than 3,000 people. On a small distant hillock, a woman cuddled her infant, a toddler sat nearby wailing. Crouched behind, her head buried in a bright orange shawl, a woman sobbed. The quake, which hit Saturday with a preliminary magnitude of 6.9, flattened entire villages, sliced mountains and triggered landslides. The estimates of the dead vary from 3,000 to 5,000 people. Thousands more are homeless and missing. The force of the quake literally sent houses roaring down mountainsides into the valleys below. There are estimates of up to 80 villages heavily damaged, and another dozen completely obliterated. Aftershocks lingered in the region Monday, sending frightened residents scrambling outdoors. Many people are refusing to return to homes still standing, said Sarah Russell, a United Nations spokesman in neighboring Pakistan. ``The aftershocks that continue to shudder through the region, sometimes only minutes apart, keep people from moving back into their houses and remind a population already traumatized . . . that another could easily strike,'' she said. In Chaujan, a village near the quake's epicenter, thousands of homes were flattened. People wandered through the rubble, dazed. In the middle of the devastation, a lone wooden door stood erect. The clumps of mud still clinging to it was the only reminder of the home that once stood there. The family of four that once lived there were dead. The International Red Cross and the United Nations scrambled to establish mobile medical units in Shari Basurkh, about 50 kilometers (30 miles), from Faisabad, the capital of northern Badakhshan province. Doctors Without Borders were operating a clinic there. Helicopters ferried the wounded, many with broken bones. Aid workers also distributed blankets, tents and plastic sheetings. Among the hardest hit areas was Rostaq, the site of a Feb. 4 earthquake that killed as many as 2,300 people and left another 8,000 homeless. When Saturday's quake hit, many in the area were still living in tents because they had lost their homes in the February quake. Aid workers at the site said people were traumatized, their eyes unfocused, their hands searching through the rubble. Many of the wounded loaded onto helicopters were old women and men and small children. Cargo aircraft from neighboring Pakistan, packed with emergency supplies, reached the region Monday. As relief workers reach the hardest hit areas, they have begun worrying about the risk of diseases like malaria, because of the rain, Russell said. Other health hazards include hemmhoragic fever and cholera, she said. The French Foreign Ministry also planned to send about 35 tons of humanitarian aid to nearby Dushanbe, Tajikistan, where it will be transported to the disaster area. Anti-Taliban soldiers who control this region say they have removed 1,650 bodies, but they said thousands more people are dead. The alliance spokesman Shamshul Haq Arianfar said eight villages simply disintegrated. Many of the homes in the area, already weakened by the February temblor, crumbled like dry dust in Saturday's violent shaking. The homes were made more vulnerable by the relentless rain that battered the region in recent days.

BC-UN-India-Pakistan,0301
Annan encouraged by response from prime ministers of India, Pakistan
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Following nuclear tests by India and Pakistan, Secretary-General Kofi Annan spoke by telephone with the prime ministers of the two countries over the weekend and was encouraged by their response, a U.N. spokesman said Monday. Spokesman Fred Eckhard gave few details of Annan's conversations with Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee and Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif except to say they were to ``encourage dialogue on peace and security issues including Kashmir.'' ``He was encouraged by their reactions and intends to continue to engage with them on these issues,'' Eckhard said. ``He was just encouraged by their openness with him and on that basis he is prepared to stay in touch with them.'' The United News of India reported that Vajpayee rejected any third party mediation between India and Pakistan to help resolve the Kashmir issue. Annan has offered to help the parties resume their high-level dialogue, which broke down last year over Kashmir, the Himalayan territory which is divided between them. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over Kashmir. The Security Council has issued statements deploring the South Asian nuclear tests and has called on both India and Pakistan to sign nuclear control treaties without conditions. India and Pakistan have resisted such treaties because they do not require the five permanent Security Council members _ the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China _ to dismantle their own nuclear arsenals. Foreign ministers of the five permanent members are to meet this week in Geneva to consider the next steps in trying to curb the nuclear arms race on the subcontinent.

LET ME confess: I am a failed business journalist as evidenced from the months of story-lessness, the unofficial media jargon for non-productivity. I stand now as a sucker for tales of those who can spin a report ala Fortune from stuff that baffle me: financial records, boardroom politics and shareholding value. That's why I ploughed through Bloomberg by Bloomberg, the czar of the financial information industry, with deep reverence. Michael Bloomberg needs no introduction. The founder of Bloomberg L P took an extraordinary 12 years to build a media empire that encompasses online and wire services, radio, television and the print media. He is hailed as Wall Street's best known generic name; utter Bloomberg and all these will come to mind - Bloomberg Financial Markets, a top provider of online financial information; Bloomberg News, a wire service providing news stories to leading newspapers worldwide; Bloomberg News Radio, a 24-hour nationally distributed news radio; Bloomberg Business News, a public television programme for the investment community and Bloomberg Television, a 24-hour direct satellite television network. But alas, I discovered that he had never been a journalist, so no tips to gather, no uplifting morale to pick up and no insight into the operations of a Bloomberg editorial room. This is no Ben Bradlee's (former managing editor of Washington Post) riveting insight into the workings of Washington Post. But plodding on grudgingly, I was rewarded with a powerful personality - hard-hitting candour with arrogance and humility surfacing at times, a patronising attitude at other times, but an unmistakable force of energy. Nothing in his early life indicates that he would one day be playing David to the Goliaths of the media industry. Armed with an engineering degree from John Hopkins University and a masters degree in business administration from Harvard University, he took up a friend's suggestion to apply for a job at Wall Street's Solomon Brothers Hutzler (now called Goldman, Sachs Co) as an equity trader. For someone who had queried 'Who are they? What would I be doing?', he loved the job, `reveled in it every minute of the day', and quickly rose up the ladder to become a Wall Street star and partner of the prestigious firm. As he said, he loved Wall Street not just for the money but the lifestyle it provided. He had humble beginnings. His father was a dairy accountant, and his mother, a home-maker. High-style Manhattan living enthralled him. He remembered gawking at a French restaurant's opulent decor, having a meal with more silverware per place setting than his family owned in total, cruising uptown in a black limo when the only other time he had been in such a car was at his father's funeral, and gasping at a US$ 50 tip someone had given for a two- dollar cab ride - an amount that would have covered his entire week's personal, social and food budget. He fittingly called this chapter of his early life, Capitalism, Here I Come. But the good life came to an end when he was 39. The firm's merger with Phibro Corporation resulted in the termination of several partners, including Bloomberg. After 15 years of 12-hour days and six-day weeks, he was told: `Here's US$ 10 million; time for you to leave.' His initial reaction: `US$ 10 million? America's a wonderful country.' Then, with the outgoing partners, he shot pool, smoked Cuban cigars, played poker and laughed uproariously. As he says, `I never look over my shoulder. Once finished: gone. Life continues.' All the same, he was worried his wife would be ashamed of his less visible status and he broke the news with a style that very few can afford: he presented her a sable jacket and champagne. His contention: a sable jacket seemed to say, 'No sweat. We can still eat. We're still players.' Yeah, I couldn't agree more. The end of the good life spells the beginning of an even better life! Any gutsy entrepreneur with money can enter the news business anytime. But starting something from scratch is far from easy. Bloomberg succeeded because he filled up a gap in the financial information industry (in his words, `making news with numbers' - combining text and analytics with computer-driven tours that let readers automatically see the calculations and graphs of what was written, and followed up with words to expand what the illustration showed) and built up his organisation's strength from there. As he says, `From the beginning, we tried to be different.' Much to his credit, he instinctively knew `unless our news was impartial, free of any outside influence, and not tied to some hidden agenda, then no amount of money or talent would assure us success as journalists'. He admits that one must learn what one doesn't know, and then, get access to the people who do know. He relies on professional journalists for Bloomberg's editorial policy and the management of the newspeople. His natural flair for the media industry and unshaken respect for editorial ethics explains why the Bloomberg News rivals Dow Jones and Reuters quickly. More than a piece of interesting reading, the book is certainly engaging and packed with information on how to start a lean, hungry company and keep it that way. The book is instructive of how he builds up his media empire, plays catch-up with the Goliaths of the industry, balances the dollar sign with the honour of the written word and his management style. But it's not purely a business perspective, he seems nostalgic in recalling his childhood days and family. And for those who yearn for words of wisdom from the czar, there's also terrific, albeit, patronising advice on how to increase and guard your investments. The one I love - and keep reminding my hubby and thus relieving us of the guilt of not being able to leave dollops of cash for our offspring - `children have no God-given right to an inheritance ... (what matters is) the best education and a grubstake to start them off.' Take it from Bloomberg - the emperor of the financial information industry knows what he is talking about.

WITH so many unit trust funds set up in the last few years, the country's first Bumiputera unit trust funds must surely be feeling the heat from new competitors. Amanah Saham Mara Bhd (ASMB) has not been taking it lying down. It plans to open up funds which have been exclusively Bumiputera for the last 30 years to all Malaysians. Says group managing director cum chief executive officer of ASMB, Datuk Kamaruddin Mohammed, `We have plans to re-launch the existing Tabung Kumpulan Modal Bumiputera (TKMB) funds and open them to all Malaysians.' Certainly this change is a milestone. `Yes, times are different now,' concurs Kamaruddin. If implemented, it would mean that non-Bumis will have more choices when it comes to ASMB's funds. Currently, only five funds out of 15 are open to non-Bumiputeras. They are ASM FPF, ASM Premier, ASPT (only for Tenaga Nasional Bhd staff), Dana Al-Aiman and ASM TP Balanced Fund. All TKMB funds are open to Bumiputera investors only. Kamaruddin started off in ASMB as a marketing executive in 1969, and is recognised today as one of the longest-serving chief executive officers in the unit trust industry in Malaysia. He has held a Securities Institute of Australia fellowship and gained work experience Down Under. Malaysian Business caught up with him to find out about what's in store for the funds, the unit trust industry, the economy and more. Excepts: How about a backgrounder on ASMB, the first Bumiputera unit trust fund in Malaysia? We were established in 1967. Our first Bumiputera unit trust scheme was set up the next year, even before Perbadanan Nasional Berhad (PNB) and Amanah Saham Nasional (ASN). Our first fund, the Tabung Kumpulan Modal Bumiputera 1 (TKMB1), now renamed Dana Al-Aiman, was first launched in 1968 and relaunched last year. Between 1968 and 1980, we launched 12 funds. But most of these - they were mainly TKMB funds - were very small, with an authorised size of 20 million units per fund only. They were small because the economy during that era was not as robust as the previous decade's. The initial investment required was only RM20-RM50. But over the years, the value per unit has grown tremendously - from RM1 to RM12. During that time, we gave out a lot of bonus issues and dividends. The original investors then cashed out and moved into other funds. Therefore, the 12 funds shrunk in terms of unit circulation. Now, they are worth about RM1-RM2 per unit. (ASMB was incorporated in 1967 and is wholly owned by Majlis Amanah Rakyat or MARA. ASMB, in turn, wholly owns ASM MARA Unit Trust Management Bhd, which was set up in 1993 to take over the management of trusts funds from ASMB. The 15 funds have a total approved size of 1.2 billion units. As of March 31, 1998, the number of units in circulation is 606.8 million). How have your funds performed as compared to three months and nine months ago? Compared to nine months ago, when the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index (KLCE) stood at 1,077.30 points (around June 30, 1997), our funds have dropped by 33 per cent - the stockmarket fell by 42 per cent during this time. However, since the stockmarket rebounded to around the 700-point range at the end of March 1998 from a low of about 470 points in January 1998, our funds have made a gain of 48 per cent over that three-month period. What is your investment strategy in view of the current slowdown? Our strategy is to liquidate positions in the stockmarket and invest more in money market instruments. What sectors do you favour? We favour sectors that are expected to be the engine of growth for the future, for example IPPs (independent power producers). We also like defensive stocks like food-based and consumer products, and plantations. We avoid construction, property, motor, banking and finance. However, as long-term investors, we will not avoid all other stocks. We have to keep our ears open, look at the balance sheet and study the company. Some companies are not up there but could perform. We like some Tier-1 banks and finance companies which are priced very attractively now. Who are your fund managers and what is their experience? Do you engage foreign expertise? ASM MARA has been managing the 15 funds since 1993. There are 10 fund managers in the team, including a general manager and myself. We do not have any foreign fund managers working for us. We have an investment panel and a syariah advisory panel comprising experts with vast experience in the field. Aminah Jaafar, general manager of ASM MARA, is a graduate of the Institute of Chartered Secretaries Administrators (UK) and has been with ASMB since 1970. Our five top management staff have clocked up more than 125 years in total service to the company. After almost 30 years in the unit trust industry, what is your opinion of the current state of affairs in Malaysia? The net asset value (NAV) of the local unit trust industry, including PNB, makes up only 8.9 per cent of the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange's (KLSE) market capitalisation. Excluding PNB, the NAV is around 1.7 per cent. Compare this to other countries - Thailand (16 per cent), India (25 per cent), Singapore (39.8 per cent), Australia and the United States (40 per cent), and Japan (48 per cent). This shows that there is tremendous potential for growth for the unit trust industry in this country. The sudden increase in unit trust management companies in the market within a short time in the past few years should bode well for the industry as it will help make the stockmarket more matured and less speculative. However, the concept of unit trust investment is still not very well known to the man in the street. How do you think we could further develop the industry? There should be stricter compliance rules to safeguard unit-holders. To increase professionalism, fund managers should be adequately trained to have a more global view. Ideally, they should be able to analyse stocks worldwide for investment opportunities rather than concentrate on local stocks only. The Federation of Malaysian Unit Trust Managers (FMUTM) could provide the necessary leadership and also oversee training programmes, say, for agents. Agents have to be trained to be more professional so that they deal with investors more as consultants rather than as salespersons. Fund managers should also be allowed to invest in more financial instruments, for example, the futures market. The regulatory body should also come up with guidelines to allow sales through the Internet. Is there a shortage of fund managers and if yes, how do we overcome the problem? Yes, there is. To overcome it, we need more foreign fund managers to train local fund managers via courses. It will also be helpful if undergraduates were exposed to the principles and practice of investment, especially in unit trusts. Universities should also hold courses relevant to fund managers. Why do you think investment in unit trusts has not caught on yet with the public? The Malaysian public is more used to the traditional modes of savings, for example fixed deposits and bonds. Many of them are not aware of the benefits/returns of investment in unit trusts as there has not been much publicity on unit trusts until recently. Also, there is an impression that Malaysian investors are more interested in short-term gains and fast returns. What is your advice for investors? Individual investors need to map out their monthly expenses and invest only the balance. They should diversify their investment portfolio. Those who have already invested should keep their investments and buy more to average out the cost. Now is the time to invest to get better capital appreciation in the middle to long term. Time has proven that if you keep your money in unit trusts, you will reap very good benefits. For example, if in 1968 you had RM20,000 in unit trusts, it would have grown to close to RM1 million 25 years later. Netherlands beats Spain 3-2 in overtime for World Cup title
UTRECHT, Netherlands (AP) _ Cheered on at home by a stadium filled with frenzied fans, the Netherlands defeated Spain 3-2 in sudden-death overtime Monday to win its third men's field hockey World Cup. Olympic champion Netherlands, twice winner of the World Cup in 1975 at Amsterdam and 1990 at Lahore, lifted the title following Teun de Nooijer's golden goal in the 13th minute of overtime. Spain took the lead in the 18th minute through a field goal by Javier Arnau. A penalty corner conversion by Victor Pujol increased Spain's lead before skipper Stephan Veen pulled one back for the Netherlands in the 58th minute. Penalty corner specialist Bram Lomans scooped the ball into the cage in the 61st minute to give the Dutch the equalizer and take the game into extra time. De Nooijer slammed a penalty corner rebound after goalkeeper Ramon Jufresa had blocked the shot from Lomans with two minutes of extra time remaining.

AT A time when most businesses are consolidating, Metal Reclamation Bhd is set to undertake a RM63 million expansion drive, a big portion of which will be financed with internally-generated funds and RM25 million with proceeds from its flotation exercise. The flotation exercise involves a public issue of 5.97 million ordinary shares of RM1 each at RM1.80 a share which will generate about RM30 million for the company. In an interview with Business Times, Metal Reclamation's managing director, Mr Lim Sheng Seaw, said apart from the funds generated in the flotation, the group will take up RM20 million in bank borrowings to finance its expansion plan. With this, he added, the group's bank borrowings will increase to RM80 million which although looks big actually comprises largely short-term loans for trade financing. Lim pointed out that the group's borrowings for working capital stand at only RM3 million compared with total credit facilities of RM102 million granted by its bankers. Thus, in actual fact, Metal Reclamation's debt ratio ``is very small'' and it is in the long-term interest of the group to partially finance its plans with proceeds from corporate exercises because for the group to grow it is not advisable to be tied down by huge long-term loans, he added. It is for this reason, Lim said, that the company is going for a listing as it will enable to have access to cash it needs to grow within the reclamation and sale of lead and lead alloys industry and to venture into other businesses that have synergies with the group's forte. ``The money that we raise from the listing exercise is for the business which in turn will provide us with more opportunities later,'' he added. Lim said he is confident Metal Reclamation will receive favourable response from investors when it is listed sometime in the first half of this year since its heavy investments show the company's strong commitment to its business. Furthermore, he pointed out, the investing public should take heart from Metal Reclamation's dominant position in the making of lead acid batteries for motor vehicles. There are four million scrap batteries in Malaysia every year and Metal Reclamation controls close to 90 per cent of this industry through its recycling operations. Commenting on the weak sales of new cars, Lim said Metal Reclamation will not be affected much as based on its projection at least 150,000 new cars will be on the road this year to join the existing four million cars already in use, providing the company with a ready and lucrative market. Even in the worst of times, he added, the company can look forward to get the lion's share of the minimum two million batteries a year used because car batteries last only two years. In any case, Lim contended, Metal Reclamation's earnings base is quite diversified with its batteries division contributing 30 per cent to group turnover followed by 20 per cent from its cable division which provides cable alloys used in the production of paper insulated and lead covered cables, with the rest coming from its pure lead and tin solders division. For the year ended December 31 1997, the group recorded a pre-tax profit of RM6.95 million on the back of RM203.88 million in turnover which Lim said is expected to grow at a rate of 5 per cent a year for the coming five years. However, central to Metal Reclamation's plans to strengthen its earnings base and its growth projection is whether it will be able to build its proposed plant at Pulau Indah in Klang. With the plant in operation, Lim said, Metal Reclamation will be able to further diversify its business base by moving into, for example, plastic recycling. The plant, which is expected to cost RM63 million, will not only increase Metal Reclamation's production capacity to 70,000 tonnes a year from the current 36,000 tonnes of pure lead and lead alloys, but will also be important in reducing usage of imported raw materials to 30 per cent from 60 per cent. It will also provide an opportunity to the group to once again participate in the international market as it did in the early 1990s when a quarter of the group's turnover was derived from the export market, Lim said. He added that the company will not have any trouble getting into the export market since its 99.97 per cent refined lead under the brand name ``MRISB-MALAYSIA'' is registered with the London Metal Exchange which enables the company to sell its products anywhere in the world with trading conducted in US dollars. Lim said this puts Metal Reclamation in an advantageous position as the weakened ringgit has not impaired its profits since trade, even in the country, is based on the US dollar and is only converted to the ringgit at the point of sale.

BC-Britain-Gazza and Spice
Spice Girls, Gazza sensations have Britain in a tizzy
LONDON (AP) _ It was all over the tabloids Monday, and the quality papers, too. Questions were asked in the House of Commons: Geri Spice is out. So's Gazza. Two idols fallen on a single weekend, touching on national obsessions with pop music, soccer and celebrity. Geri Halliwell, 25, was the eldest member of the Spice Girls, the inventor of ``girl power,'' the gorgeous pouting idol of millions of pre-adolescent girls. She quit after a series of fights with the other four members of the group _ and after earning a reported dlrs 20 million in the two years since ``Wannabe'' put them on top of the charts. ``What a shame,'' the Daily Star said in an editorial. ``The very power, energy and drive that made them a world pop phenomenon has now destroyed them.'' Paul Gascoigne, 31, was a sometimes brilliant soccer player who won the nation's heart with his tears when he was ejected from the 1990 World Cup. But the nation often had to think again: Gazza drunk, Gazza posing at a urinal on his wedding day, Gazza's wife Sheryl _ inevitably dubbed ``Shezza'' by the tabloids _ walking out of the marriage with a bruised face. ``His graceless existence has overwhelmed his footballing qualities,'' said an editorial in The Mirror, the second-largest-selling tabloid. England manager Glen Hoddle dropped Gascoigne from the World Cup squad because of his poor physicial condition. ``It's a great pity that Paul has not got himself fit. It's a pity he has so many injuries over the last months and the injuries kept coming,'' Hoddle said. Halliwell's announcement of her retirement and Gascoigne's dismissal were front-page naturals for the popular press. They even rated brief mentions on the front of the Financial Times. In the House of Commons, Labor lawmaker Gareth Thomas urged the government to encourage Geri ``to think again.'' ``Are you aware that local authority initiatives to encourage tourism in my area may well be undermined by the need to divert resources to fund trauma counseling for the younger members of my constituency?'' he said. But Tom Clarke, the minister for film and tourism, said the government wasn't inclined to intervene. Gazza isn't the government's problem either, but Conservative lawmaker Anne McIntosh managed to work his sad situation into a discussion of the ``social exclusion'' of Britain's down and out. ``I wonder if you would like to comment on the impact on the England football team of excluding Gazza from the squad?'' she said, drawing laughter from her colleagues. Sports Minister Tony Banks said he hoped Hoddle had made the right decision. ``I expect the English team to do even better now, even with the personal tragedy surrounding the football exclusion of that great character Gazza,'' Banks said. Big 5 should lead way to world free of N-arms, BUSINESS TIMES xfdws WORLD-FREE-OF-N-ARMS sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 01, 1998 BUSINESS TIMES ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. IN condemning the nuclear tests by Pakistan, which was responding to the tests conducted earlier by India, the world seems to have forgotten that the nuclear arms race actually began many years ago. If India, a poverty-stricken developing country, is rightly proud of its scientific and technical achievement in exploding five nuclear devices, then Pakistan should also be proud of its brilliant scientists and engineers in building and successfully exploding not just five, but an incredible six nuclear bombs in a matter of days. A nation can be economically poor but this does not necessarily mean that it is poor in scientific and technical talent. The myth created by those in developed countries that an economically poor nation remains poor because of the lack of scientific and engineering talent has been exploded with the explosion of nuclear devices by India and Pakistan. In fact, the myth was first exploded in 1964 when China, another big but poor country, exploded its first atomic bomb in 1964. From that time onwards, poor and developing countries have begun to realise that economic poverty did not necessarily mean poverty in scientific and engineering talent. A nation may be poor but it can also achieve certain things which the rich and developed countries are able to do. If anything else, the nuclear tests by Pakistan constitute the latest demonstration of how a poor and developing nation can take pride in its scientific and technical capabilities. It is blatant hypocrisy that the current five major nuclear powers, which have among them massive stockpiles of nuclear bombs and missile warheads which can obliterate the world several times over, can turn around and condemn India and Pakistan for going nuclear. If they do not want the other non-nuclear countries to go nuclear, they should have set an example a long time ago and completely destroyed their own nuclear stockpiles so that we can all live in a nuclear-free world. Instead, what really happened was that the Big Five nuclear powers engaged in an expensive nuclear arms race which threatened the world and introduced more destructive and dangerous weapons over the years. Technological one-upmanship was of such a magnitude that billions of dollars were spent and precious scientific and engineering resources wasted just to get a minor strategic edge over the adversary. There was even a chilling strategic concept known as MAD, which stood for Mutually Assured Destruction. The frightening thing was that MAD was not thought up by mad men but by seemingly respectable persons with good brains and intellect and who had received the right kind of education to qualify themselves to lead and manage advanced industrialised countries. To the advocates of MAD, tossing around with figures of millions of dead and injured people as a result of nuclear attacks became just a game. Killing in a potential nuclear war was of such a scale that it degenerated into a kind of intellectual exercise in the minds of the nuclear strategists. If a few hundred or even a few thousands are killed in an ordinary conflict, one can feel the pain and the tragedy of those who die, but in the more tragic circumstances of a nuclear conflict, the millions of those who are wiped out are nothing more than statistics because they are so many of them for us to feel the pain. The major nuclear powers have for years been arming themselves with huge stockpiles of bombs and nuclear warheads which reflected nothing more than the murderous desire for ``overkill.'' Why build a few thousand nuclear bombs when a few hundreds will be sufficient to destroy your adversary? There is no rationale for this desire for overkill and yet the major nuclear powers, with all their highly educated strategic planners, could not resist the temptation to build more and more nuclear weapons over the years that the nuclear arms build-up took on a life - and a momentum - of their own until the so-called Cold War came to an end with the break-up of the Soviet Union. However, even with the Cold War being over, the stockpiles of nuclear weapons still in the hands of the five major nuclear powers are enormous enough to destroy the world several times over. It looks like the major nuclear powers are still reluctant to abandon the ``overkill'' mentality. The tests by India and now Pakistan may have introduced a dangerous nuclear arms race in the sub-continent but the world itself is neither a more dangerous nor safer place now than it was before the nuclear tests by India and Pakistan. The culprits who started the dangerous nuclear arms race - the US, Russia, Britain, France and China - have not got rid of their own nuclear arsenals. Therefore, they have no moral right to stop other countries from conducting nuclear tests nor to build their own nuclear weapons. How can the existing nuclear powers condemn India and Pakistan for conducting nuclear tests and building their own nuclear weapons and missiles when they themselves have been doing the same thing for years and on a much bigger scale? The major nuclear powers have subjected the world - their own populations and the peoples of other countries as well - for the last five decades to the threat of a nuclear world war. This threat still exists because they have refused to discard their nuclear arsenals and yet they demand that other non-nuclear countries should not go nuclear. If the world is to be truly safe from the potential threat of nuclear destruction, then the first step should be taken by the existing nuclear powers themselves in completely destroying their own nuclear stockpiles. The only way to achieve a nuclear-free world is for the five major nuclear powers to first free themselves from nuclear arms.

MORE AND more chief financial officers (CFOs) are embracing the concept of total cost of ownership (TCO) for managing corporate asset costs, with determining the cost of information technology (IT) to your company being one of the most aggressive focuses. While you may not be responsible for calculating IT TCO for your entire organisation, chances are that someday soon someone will tap your budgets under a heading that reflects IT TCO. To get ready to manage relevant IT costs, a good starting point would be to develop a working knowledge of TCO for desktop and portable computers, and how to begin reducing PC-related costs immediately. It may surprise you to find out exactly how much PCs cost your organisation. I know when I was first introduced to the figures for my organisation, I was amazed, appalled and immediately suspicious of the source of these seemingly inflated figures. However, after seeing the strong relevance of these figures to the process of calculating PC TCO, I was able to accurately verify these costs on my own. Then, I was able to take action on reducing these costs for my regional headquarters operation here in Kuala Lumpur, and other Gateway operations in South Asia. More importantly, I've championed efforts toward staff training to help Gateway better assist customers in identifying TCO factors and issues to reduce customer costs. Here's how you can get started. Defining PC TCO In essence, PC TCO is all costs associated with the acquisition and operation of personal computers; from the initial purchase to training and support, including the cost of downtime to your organisation. A more complete list of PC TCO components looks like this: hardware - desktop and portable PCs and peripherals, software -productivity software, utilities and custom-developed applications, training - PC operation and software-specific instruction, management -utility costs of PCs at work, such as upgrades and enhancements, support - fixing hardware and software problems, and downtime - lost revenue and productivity due to system delays and failures. When looking into these elements as cost centres, managers can identify shortcomings, inefficiencies and waste associated with PCs, whether it is for a small workgroup, department or an entire organisation. Sometimes, these costs and potential savings can be difficult to identify at first, yet, they can ultimately be very dramatic. Hardware myths: Cheaper is not always better To begin with, one common misconception that I had, and many managers have, is that hardware is the principal cost associated with PC TCO. In fact, it is one of the smaller elemental costs, typically representing less than 20 per cent of PC TCO. Here's an example. Under hardware, one can take the original price of a PC, then add the cost of additional peripherals, ie, modems, printers, scanners, etc. Also included in the hardware cost is any fee associated with delivery, set-up, and configuration for the system and all peripherals. This is quite straight forward. However, what is not so clear is the connection between a specific hardware purchase - regardless of initial price - and the impact on other elemental costs such as management, support and downtime. This is where the serious TCO action often takes place. Management makes it happen Management describes the cost of leveraging PCs in the work environment. This encompasses general systems administration, such as alterations to hardware or software capabilities to suit changing requirements. This does not, however, include repairs, which fall under support. In some environments, management may also reflect the cost of network management and administration, but frankly, for workgroups and departmental managers, PC TCO is best calculated separately. The golden rule for reducing management costs for PCs is to buy systems that support current and foreseeable future requirements. Why? Today's cheaper PCs may be capable of handling your current requirements, but one modest software update can easily make that investment obsolete, requiring new systems. The result: no cost savings on management, with often a negative and lingering impact on support and downtime as you and your team come face to face with the ramifications of a short-sighted purchase. In today's market, here's how to avoid early PC obsolescence. Think in terms of purchasing fresh technology. Generally, it comes down to performance, capacity and manageability. Today's performance desktop PCs are based on Intel's Pentium II-class processors, where for obsolescence avoidance, I recommend systems running at 300 MHz or more with 64 MBs of RAM and 4 GBs of hard disk, such as Gateway's E-Series E-3110 300. The E-3110 comes with advanced manageability features built in, giving PC users and systems administrators the ability to diagnose and anticipate problems before they occur, which can save downtime and money. Similarly, for portable systems look at Pentium II processors with enough RAM and hard disk space to grow on. Support for office PCs Support includes all costs associated with fixing hardware and software problems. The good news is that PC hardware and software has become far more reliable since the dawn of the PC revolution. The bad news is that this enhanced reliability is most often only achieved by investing in high-quality, brand name systems to avoid faulty components and software compatibility issues. Here again, the golden rule for reducing support costs is to invest in quality systems from a vendor who you are confident will be around tomorrow. Vendors must be directly accountable to both requisitioning managers and users in providing solid warranties, and then stand behind their products with extended support programs. Support is a major cost centre because having a trained professional capable of fixing most PC problems arrive at your location costs money. But, as where there is smoke, there is fire, when there is support, there is downtime, and that can be most costly of all. Downtime equals lost revenue and productivity Downtime cost calculations can be somewhat tricky, but as you will see, it is one of the most significant issues regarding PC TCO. To make this calculation, you must first factor how much time management and staff spend interacting with the computer to conduct their jobs. Next, you figure the cost to your business when computers don't work, in the form of lost revenue or sales and lost productivity. It takes little imagination to consider a variety of circumstances where PC TCO of a given computer can multiply in hours or even minutes. Savvy managers quickly begin equating down computers as a steady stream of revenue seeping through cracks in the floor. You are very lucky if you are having trouble imagining such dire circumstances. But these circumstances do not have to be so dramatic. Intermittent failures or even slow performing systems sap productivity, often both materially and spiritually on the part of employees. My best advice on reducing downtime is two-fold. First, invest in quality, both in terms of hardware and software. Second, take advantage of vendor-provided internal or external support professionals and insist on fast, effective problem resolution. Software on the rise in TCO Software continues to grow as part of PC TCO, and in many cases, eclipses hardware and other cost elements. This is especially true in environments with a significant investment in customised applications software, such as resource planning, accounting and GroupWare. Reducing software TCO is best accomplished by rigorous software asset management and training. Studies have shown that an organisation's software costs can often be reduced by between 20 and 30 per cent or more through a more complete accounting and administration of software licenses. For example, computers most often come equipped with operating systems, but are regularly reigned into corporate software licensing agreements. Even more common are situations where purchased software goes uninstalled or forgotten, delivering no value to the organisation. Training is paramount The most important aspect of ensuring returns on software investments and other elements of PC TCO is training. Of course, some managers and staff insist that software training is unnecessary or a poor use of time. Here again, experience shows that time spent on training can significantly boost productivity on both standard and custom software applications. You have most likely heard someone look over your shoulder and say, `Wow, I didn't know that button could do that!,' or `That feature certainly would have been great to know about when...' Beyond productivity, software specific training also helps identify what not to do, and contributes to avoiding downtime. Standardisation leads to cost savings The fastest route to reducing PC TCO is through standardisation. Standardisation among hardware and software vendors and configurations leads to savings and significant efficiencies in all elements of PC TCO, especially in areas such as support, training and downtime. Identifying the appropriate model of desktop and portable computers that will satisfy current and future requirements is the first step. My company, Gateway, has implemented a global offering called Custom Integration Service (CIS) that focuses on helping companies identify specific requirements for desktop and portable computers and reducing PC TCO. CIS goes steps further by building each system's hardware and software configuration exactly to an individual customer's specifications, then delivering the system to the customer's door. Customers simply remove the box and plug in the new system to start productive work. PC TCO checklist Here's a checklist to help you begin to identify and reduce PC TCO: quality products serving current and future requirements, quality support to avoid problems and downtime, quality training pays off in productivity enhancements, asset management reduces redundancies, and standardisation improves all aspects of PC TCO. I look forward to answering any questions you have regarding managing PC TCO or other topics that I've covered in this column. Next time, I will be focusing on ways to manage repetitive stress problems associated with computer use. The writer is managing director of Gateway 2000 (South Asia). This is the second in a series of articles on managing IT. Views expressed are the writer's own.

BC-Air France-Strike, 5th Ld-Writethru
Anger, embarrassment as strike begins before World Cup TRIMS.
Eds: AMs; RECASTS and UPDATES throughout with new quotes, color. AP Photos PAR101-109 By CHRISTOPHER BURNS Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ In normal times, an Air France strike would merely cause havoc. But the walkout by the carrier's pilots Monday was worse: a deep embarrassment for a country preparing to host in just nine days the world's biggest sporting event, the World Cup. Despite pressure from leftist government ministers, most of the state-run carrier's 3,200 pilots stayed out of their cockpits to protest 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. They are threatening to stay out for two weeks or more. That's well into the World Cup, which begins June 10 and lasts a month. On just the first day Monday, 100,000 passengers were sent scrambling. And it could be only the beginning: French train workers were planning to strike at the end of the week. Desperate travelers lined ticket counters at Paris airports Monday, while the Air France planes they were supposed to take, many colorfully painted with soccer players for the championship, sat idle. Departure screens offered a bleak sight: they alternately flashed ``annule'' and ``canceled'' in bright red. Nicolas Minvelle, hoping to leave on vacation for Senegal, said it wasn't fair that the pilots were striking just before the World Cup, which is being played in 10 cities across France. ``They use an international event to bother everyone. It's too bad,'' he said at Charles de Gaulle Airport. The airports in Lyon and Marseille, France's second and third-largest cities, were virtually deserted. Rental car agencies did brisk business. Hassan Beloumi spent only a few minutes at the Marseille airport. The 63-year-old Tunisian was supposed to fly back to Tunis, but couldn't get any information. So he decided to stay in France. ``I'll go back to Tunis when the strike is over,'' he said. In any case, he added, ``I'll have a longer vacation.'' Mark Wall, an American living in Amsterdam, had to return from Lyon quickly for professional reasons. ``No problem,'' he said at the Lyon-Satolas airport. ``They gave me a ticket for tonight on a Sabena flight.'' At Paris' other main airport, Orly, Air France had arranged for Vince Narez and his wife to take a Northwest Airlines flight back to California. ``We're not very happy about it, but we want to get home,'' said Narez, of San Jose. Passengers ``are being taken hostage,'' the French passenger association ADUA said angrily. It called the walkout by the pilots, among the highest-paid in the world, ``a strike by the privileged of the skies.'' It said the strike was hurting France's image and offending taxpayers who paid billions of francs (dollars) to bail out the once-struggling airline. It called for anti-strike demonstrations in the airports. The walkout would be Air France's longest in 27 years if it lasts the projected two weeks. It was an embarrassing blow to the leftist government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin. The Communist transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, on Sunday made a final appeal for both sides to negotiate. But by late Monday, no new talks were planned. ``Negotiating teams are ready at Air France,'' said the carrier's director general, Henri Gourgeon. The airline said it would make good on its commitment to fly World Cup teams. But it canceled 90 percent of long-haul flights Monday, and most short- and medium-haul flights. Unlike past conflicts, when ground crews blocked runways and clashed with police, the pilots simply didn't show up for work. They are protesting plans to save dlrs 83 million through salary cuts while offering pilots shares in the airline. They also are angry about salary cuts for starting pilots. Christian Paris, spokesman for the main union, the SNPL, admitted the strike's consequences were ``disastrous.'' ``But when you're confronted by an attack you have no choice but to defend yourself,'' he told France 2 television. The union has called a 15-day renewable strike. Three smaller unions have called for a strike until Thursday. Also for Thursday, the CGT union is calling a strike affecting most public services, and the energy and construction sectors. In Paris, Michael Apstein of Boston didn't mind taking a later connecting flight to Montpellier on another airline, Air Liberte. ``It's nice to have a strike once in a while,'' he said, ``so you can go into Paris for lunch for four or five hours.'' Wooing foreign partners to survive, BUSINESS TIMES xfdws WOOING-FORIEGN-PARTNERS sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 01, 1998 BUSINESS TIMES ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC.
