IF BINARIANG Bhd, the young but aggressive telecommunications conglomerate, can sell a huge chunk of its shares to yet another foreign partner, there is no longer any justification to prevent other Malaysian companies from following in its footsteps. This is especially so when the foreign interest Binariang is selling its stake to is a company controlled by the Singapore Government. Some Malaysian parties - public and private - seem to have an aversion for all things Singaporean even though they are good. Binariang, a company seen by many as enjoying a special position in the country's corporate arena, has by its sale of shares to Singapore Telecoms, provided others with an equally strong justification to sell theirs to foreign parties in their desperate efforts to stay alive. Binariang, which counts among its prized possessions Maxis cellular and fixed line telephone services and Astro satellite pay television, is understood to have wooed the Singapore company to be its second foreign partner. Its first foreign partner is US West International, which holds 19.8 per cent of Binariang's shares. While Binariang, whose literal Malay translation means ``happy building'', declined to comment on the deal, it is understood that Singapore Telecoms may buy as much as 40 per cent of the company's existing paid-up capital. If the figure is correct, foreign shareholdings in Binariang will be only slightly lower than the 61 per cent maximum allowed. The Government recently raised the maximum for foreign equity in a telecommunications firm from 49 per cent to 61. The Singapore Telecoms deal is said to be worth RM1.4 billion. Several local companies have either sold substantial stakes to foreign firms, or announced plans to sell strategic blocks of their shares to foreign partners. With many local companies facing debt and cash flow problems as a result of the ringgit's depreciation and the sharp fall in the prices of shares, the alternative to insolvency is to sell shares and assets. The disposal of shares and assets to foreigners is fast becoming an imperative for local businessmen as credit dries up and interest rates remain prohibitive. Sales to local investors do not seem possible as they too face a credit squeeze. The use of many capital market instruments to finance share purchases is either officially curtailed or is commercially not feasible due to the shortage of funds and the high interest rates. As it now stands, only foreign investors are capable of buying shares and assets of local companies, and are willing to pay a much higher price than what is currently quoted on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange. With the exception of problems brought about by the sudden and sharp depreciation of the ringgit and the ensuing credit squeeze, many Malaysian companies remain viable. This is recognised by foreign long-term investors who are keen to take up strategic shareholdings as well as use Malaysian companies as vehicles for regional and international expansion. Unless the Government has a better and surer way of solving the problems of these companies, it should not discourage them from selling their shares and assets. It can help speed up approvals and encourage local companies to seek out strategic foreign partners instead of having these firms selling their shares and assets outright. Before the crisis, companies could wait for months for their applications to be approved without major problems to operations. Today, they need approvals more speedily as weeks or even days make a big difference. It is better to allow local businessmen, including Bumiputeras, to divest part of their holdings instead of forcing them to retain their shares and risk bankruptcy.

BC-Mexico-Obit-Mexico-Pedraza,0159
Hero of 1968 Olympics dies of hepatitis
MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Jose Pedraza, an army sergeant who thrilled Mexico with a late charge for a silver medal in walking at the 1968 Olympic games here, died Monday of hepatitis. He was 61. Pedraza was third as he entered University Stadium at the end of the 20-kilometer walk. The crowd thundered encouragement as he passed one Soviet competitor and came just short of passing the other by the finish line. Frustrated by his failure to overtake the winner despite the spectacular finish, he repeatedly hit himself in the head with his hands. ``This was an unforgettable moment in Mexican sports,'' said Guillermo Ochoa, presenter of the show ``Today'' on the nation's leading television network, Televisa. Pedraza continued in the military and held the rank of captain at the time of his death, according to military officials, who announced the death.

Israeli army jeep hits suspected Palestinian infiltrators
JERUSALEM (AP) _ An Israeli army jeep collided Monday with a car carrying six Palestinians who sneaked into Israel from the Gaza Strip, the army said. The Palestinians tried to escape in a waiting car with an Israeli license plate, the army said. When an Israeli army jeep tried to block the car, the two vehicles collided, the army said. Two soldiers and two of the Palestinians were slightly injured. The other four were arrested. In a separate incident, the Israeli army set up checkpoints Monday around the Palestinian village of El Khader in the West Bank after shots were fired toward two Israeli vehicles on a highway that passes the village. vb-hla

AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
MALAYSIAN Resources Corp Bhd (MRCB) sees the sale of a 15 per cent stake in Malakoff Bhd to UK-based National Power Plc (NPP) as necessary to maintain the group's overall financial strength. Chief operating officer Izzaddin Idris said on Saturday that MRCB is going through with the agreement as it is a ``good value deal'' which will see the group selling part of its stake at a premium price. The sale, together with the proposed disposal of MRCB's 51 per cent equity interest in Teknik Janakuasa Sdn Bhd, will result in MRCB deriving an extraordinary gain of RM480 million which will be used to pay off a substantial portion of its borrowings, which will be reduced to RM1.2 billion from the current RM1.6 billion. A huge portion of the borrowings arises from MRCB's US$250 million (US$1 RM3.89) bridging facility to finance the subscription of 34.7 million new shares and 14.9 million warrants in Rashid Hussain Bhd. Thus, Izzaddin said, the deal will effectively help reduce the group's debt ratio to 0.4 from the current 0.6 against shareholders' funds of RM2.86 billion. It is also expected to offset the translation loss of RM372.5 million (based on the assumption that the exchange rate is RM4 to US$1), as MRCB will have an extraordinary gain of RM480 million based on both the corporate exercises. However, he said, the sale should not be seen just as a dollar and cents deal, as MRCB stands to gain an important strategic partner which will open many doors to Malakoff in the international power market. NPP is a renowned international player with operations in Europe and India, and it has invited Malakoff to participate in some of their overseas projects, Izzaddin said. ``But due to the current economic environment, we would rather concentrate on the domestic market first,'' he added. Furthermore, MRCB sees NPP as a useful strategic partner in Malakoff's domestic market, especially where direct foreign investment is required. Izzaddin said this when asked to comment on the rationale for MRCB's disposal of a 15 per cent stake in Malakoff, which has been described as a ``cash cow''. Malakoff chalked up a quadruple increase in pre-tax profit for the half-year ended February 28 1998, to RM174.50 million from RM43.48 million. He also said MRCB's results for the half-year ended February 28 1998, which saw its pre-tax profit falling 65 per cent to RM51.94 million from RM147.93 million, did not come as a surprise considering the current situation.

HE IS Melbourne's most prolific CBD (central business district) property buyer. He is managing director of one of the country's fastest-growing listed companies. And he can sniff out a capital gain from 100 paces. But the high profile activities of lawyer Jason Yeap, a former Malaysian citizen, are in sharp contrast to the way he likes to do business. Despite a track record of savvy counter cyclical property plays which have put him in the limelight, the quiet Yeap and his stash of wealthy Asian investors firmly shun the attention. On a public front, however, he is willing to talk about his latest venture with the recent relaunch of listed company Phileo Australia. In less than two years he has increased assets from a mere A$2 million to more than A$60 million, and has managed to snare some of the city's prime redevelopment sites before most people even realised they were valuable. But it is Yeap's private client deals that keep the market ticking over and the market watchers fascinated. In the past five years he has spent more than A$200 million buying properties throughout Melbourne on behalf of overseas investors as an adviser and lawyer. At the moment, interests he represents control 15 Melbourne CBD office buildings, including seven along the prime Collins Street office strip. He also has another five or so, `I've never had to add them up before', on city fringes to make a current portfolio of 20 buildings. Making money from property involves a simple formula, Yeap says, despite multi-billion dollar losses by the big expert banks, institutions and developers during the last slump. `Basically, we look for undervalued assets in the best addresses,' he tells Malaysian Business. `Of course potential capital gain is our main driving force, either through value growth over a period of time or we improve the assets and the value increases from that improvement. `I like to pick the best address in a city and in Melbourne that's Collins Street. Our next best would be Queen Street and then Bourke,' he adds. Melbourne's landmark former stock exchange building is to be the next project off the starting blocks after last year receiving approval for a new office and residential tower at 357 Collins Street. The planned transformation of the derelict drab 1960s building includes 20,000 sq m of office space, a 130-room hotel and about 80 apartments. Yeap expects to launch the project within the next couple of months on behalf of its owner, a syndicate of Malaysian investors called Maxicity. But it is the public activities through Phileo that look set to make the next set of headlines. After re-listing in August 1996, the former Renak Holdings has leaped from acquisition to acquisition. It has amalgamated a portfolio of significant assets, including the huge General Motors Holden site in Melbourne's outer suburbs. The company plans to build one of the biggest industrial parks in Australia, with the 41 ha property eventually to house more than 200,000 sq m of buildings space. In an equally bold project, Phileo also snared the sought-after former Tram Depot in South Melbourne last year and virtually within hours had carved off a large slice of the site and on-sold it to developer Central Equity - at a profit, of course. On the bulk of the remaining South Melbourne site, the company intends to build one of the first major new office projects in the city since the market slump in the early 1990s. A seven ha residential parcel in Melbourne's suburban heartland of Box Hill is another of the group's new projects while a whole block on prime Port Melbourne is also earmarked for about 200 units. Phileo (a Greek word meaning friendship) is controlled by Malaysian-based Phileo Land and its investment, including an A$11 million injection last year, may prove to be a good hedge against uncertainty. Despite the ongoing roller coaster in the Asian markets, Yeap says the biggest hurdle of the meltdown has already been overcome - `fear of the unknown'. `What has happened is now already known. When the crises started we could see no end but now we know there are some deep problems in Indonesia, in Korea and Thailand. But because they are now known factors we can budget and manage from here onwards,' he says. `As a business person who looks forward, it should not be something that we are fearful of, it should be something that we must consider. Not something that we are so scared of that it paralyses us and we get nothing done.' Few, if any, Asian-based buyers will retreat or sell their assets because of financial pressure. `I'm not talking about the people who may buy a A$200,000 apartment, who could be hit hard - but I'm talking about those people who have spent A$15 million or A$20 million buying an asset in Collins Street.'

THE Malaysian Industry-Government Group for High Technology (Might) is currently undertaking an aerospace industry inventory exercise to identify the players in the local industry. Its chief executive, Dr Ahmed Tasir Lope Pihie, speaking to Business Times over the weekend, said the first draft of the inventory is expected to be ready in two months. The inventory exercise is among the 45 recommendations and implementation plans outlined by Might in the Blueprint for the Aerospace Industry in Malaysia. The blueprint, which will pilot the flight of the country's aerospace industry, outlines the key implementation programmes to be undertaken by the public and private sectors of the industry. The Government has identified the aerospace industry as a critical constituent of the country's future industrial base. The industry has been accorded a priority status in the Seventh Malaysia Plan (1996-2000). Both civil and military aircraft and equipment, satellites and space equipment, and related products and services fall within the ambit of the aerospace industry. It also includes aircraft maintenance, overhaul, repair and upgrading, manufacturing of aircraft, satellites, missiles and space vehicles, provision of infrastructure such as airports and launching pads for rockets, research and development activities and systems integration. Dr Ahmed Tasir said the agency is sourcing information from its own MIGHT Interest Group on Aviation and the International Trade and Industry Ministry, which has a cluster working group on aviation. Under the blueprint, the structure of the Malaysian aerospace industry will see the consolidation of the efforts of the key aerospace operators in Malaysia namely the Armed Forces, Malaysia Airlines and Malaysia Airports Bhd together with other general aviation companies. Engineering and manufacturing activities will be anchored in companies such as MAS Aerotechnologies, SME Group of Companies, RMAF Engineering and Phileo Aviation. ``We are not saying that there will be a physical consolidation of the companies in the aerospace industry, but we would like to see a consolidation in terms of efforts and resources,'' he said. Among the other programmes covered under the blueprint include: Manufacturing: Expanding parts and components manufacturing to enable the country to be a leader in upgrading and re-manufacturing activities. General aviation: To be a regional player in general aviation activities and a major player in the manufacture of light aircraft. Space: To be significantly involved in the utilisation of space for both commercial and strategic reasons. Systems: To be a major player in aerospace systems technology (including avionics); and Commercial aviation: Preferred transportation hub of and for the region. Among the projects to be undertaken are for technology acquisition, human resource development, space, composite procurement, vendor development, surveillance, defence and satellites. These programmes will, by the year 2015, enable Malaysia to have a cohesive and developed industrial base with aerospace capabilities, capability and competency at company and individual levels, a degree of technological independence, savings by obviating the need for foreign purchases, a sustainable national defence capability and enjoy the spin-off benefits useful in other industries. Might will also undertake a roadshow to explain the content of the blueprint to government agencies and the private sector companies. ``We have done one at Universiti Utara Malaysia, explaining the blueprint and the respective roles of the government agencies and the private sector in the scheme of things,'' he said.

HAVING established itself as the tea with the ummph, Boh Plantations Sdn Bhd intends to be the tea specialist in the market, for everyone ranging from six-star hotels to teh tarik stalls. Its executive director and general manager Caroline Russel says Boh's mission is to be a world-class Malaysian brand, competing against the best from anywhere in the world. According to Russel, while Malaysians have been drinking Boh Tea since the 1930s, it was only in the late 50s that a concerted effort was made to market the product domestically. In the 30s, most of the tea was exported in bulk to London. Russel hails from the family of John Archibald Russel, a tea producer and pioneer of highland tea cultivation, who established Boh Plantations in 1929. Boh Plantations has since stopped exporting its tea to London in bulk, and now, all the prime grades of tea produced by the company are sold in a branded form. Boh Plantations manages four estates: Boh; Fairlie and Sungei Palas Estates in Cameron Highlands; and a lowland estate - Bukit Cheeding - in Banting, Selangor. With a total planted area of 1,200 hectares, Boh Plantations produces 3.7 million kilogrammes of tea a year, or approximately five million cups of tea per day. As consumers become more sophisticated and discerning, Boh is moving towards a bolder and brighter corporate image. `In addition to increasing sophistication, the profile of the Malaysian market is becoming much younger with 44 per cent of the population being below the age of 19,' says Russel. `This presents a huge challenge to marketeers, especially those of long-established brands. Brands like Boh are in danger of being perceived as old-fashioned, boring and irrelevant to the youth market. A product that one's grandmother purchased may not fit in with a young person's self-image. We see the threat of younger consumers moving away from tea to soft drinks, as what is happening in the United States where Coke is a regular breakfast drink. We feel there is an urgent need to reposition tea as a healthy and great tasting refreshment, the choice even of a generation bombarded with MTV,' explains Russel. She adds, `So, it is also our mission to revitalise and rejuvenate the concept of tea here in Malaysia.' The launch of Boh's new corporate identity, according to her, is aimed at fulfilling both the objectives of establishing Boh as a world-class brand and as the beverage of choice for Malaysia's youthful market. `We recognise the need to contemporise the Boh brand, refresh and update its image while retaining its heritage and core values of quality and value. We want to re-emphasise the Cameron Highlands origin of Boh and the unique character of our teas, embodied in the phrase ``Boh ada ummph!''' The new identity will be reflected in all aspects of the brand - from new products to packaging to all marketing communication tools, from the Internet to advertising. `While the typography in the brand logo type is true to the original and remains strong, it has greater clarity and definition. The detailing lifts the profile of the brand, and it injects a sophistication and refinement that reinforces Boh as a brand synonymous with fine quality tea. At the same time, a more contemporary look has been achieved. `The diagonal graphics and the brown and orange colour schemes have always been, and will remain, strong, proprietary parts of Boh's packaging, instantly recognisable to the consumer. Brown is the colour of heritage and establishment, dependable and constant. Orange is in direct antithesis, reflecting zest, innovation and creativity. `Together, they reflect the qualities of earth and nourishment, soil and sunshine, two of the essential components in the production of fine quality tea leaves. This unique scheme will continue to form the visual identity of the packaging, and is the link by which the Boh brand is, and will continue to be, recognised,' details Russel. The new packaging for products like teabags, potbags, loose leaves and iced tea has been designed to revitalise Boh's identity. The colours have been enhanced, new ones introduced and graphics restyled. Product descriptions have been revised to reflect the long heritage and unique selling points of tea grown in Cameron Highlands. Boh's new identity is also expressed in the range of products that the company now markets. Each product is designed to cater to the needs of specific consumer groups, from the tea connoisseur, to the health enthusiast, to the stressed office worker, to the overseas tourist. Its product catalogue now includes the garden teas, Seri Songket flavoured teas, fruit and herbal infusions, specialty black teas, iced tea and three-in-one instant tea mix. The garden teas, targeted at the gift market and discerning tea drinker, is a range of Boh's own-grown, pure, unblended teas from a single tea garden. Tea can be likened to wine; its character and flavour are directly influenced by environmental conditions such as the climate and soil of the place in which it is grown. Similarly, the range of specialty black teas allow tea drinkers to experience selected unblended original teas from renowned tea-growing regions of the world. Recently, Boh also launched a range of instant iced tea mixes in Peach, Lemon Lime and Orchard Splash flavours, which are targeted directly at the youth market.

At Entertainment drops Poland's Canal Plus in cable TV enterprise
WARSAW, Poland (AP) _ The U.S.-based At Entertainment Inc. said Monday it had dropped plans to develop a digital pay-TV service in Poland with Canal Plus, and that it would develop one alone. The two companies had signed a letter of intent for the joint venture but could not agree on details before a May 31 deadline, said Przemyslaw Szmyt, a deputy president of At Entertainment. Szmyt declined to discuss details of the talks between the two companies. Canal Plus Poland, a subsidiary of Europe's largest cable TV company Canal Plus, declined to comment. At Entertainment plans to start its own digital TV service in September, Szmyt said. The Hartford, Connecticut-based company already runs the largest cable television network in Poland reaching 800,000 homes. It is to launch an additional cable TV network this week, Szmyt said. HARVARD: India evoked strong reactions from around the world with its nuclear tests. It received adverse press and evoked the anger of major powers and President Clinton imposed sanctions. India's neighbour, Pakistan, replied with its own nuclear tests evoking even stronger reactions. Its tests outnumbered its neighbour, which is also being subjected to sanctions. India is not being spared for setting off the ``nuclear arms'' race in Asia. But while India may have received considerable press, the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) sprang into action to present India's views. It took full page advertisments, including in the Financial Times of London. The advertisment was a public relations exercise and at the same time presented India's story and where it is heading in terms of the economy. The CII, in defending the Indian Government's nuclear tests, said they `` ... were carried out because of serious national security concerns, especially the nuclear environment in the region''. It added that `` ... the internationl focus must remain on Economic Opportunities and Economic Partnership''. In the advertisement entitled ``India: The High Growth Market Opportunity'', the CII listed out the agenda for growth, the business opportunities, economic vision and the government and private sector consensus on economic reform. The CII is not alone in adopting this strategy. Microsoft, taken to task by the US Government which has filed anti-trust lawsuits against the company, also ``told its story'' in a full page advertisment in the New York Times. Mr Bill Gates of Microsoft wrote an open letter to ``Customers, Partners and Shareholders'' telling his side of the story in the anti-trust lawsuits against his 23-year-old company. He explained, in his own words, that ``This is an industry built on innovation, competition and consumer choice - principles that America's anti-trust laws were designed to promote, and that have always been a cornerstone of Microsoft's business practices.'' Mobil outlined three steps for the US to take in dealing with Iran, namely, allow US companies to negotiate deals with Iran, contingent on the lifting of sanctions; allow US companies to swap oil with Iran; and grant a limited waiver to use Iranian equipment in the Caspian Sea. This ``advice'' came hot on the heels of Washington's announcement to waive sanctions against Petronas, France's Total and Russia's Gazprom for investments in Iran's oil sector. Under the Iran Libya Sanctions Act, the companies would have been penalised for investing in Iran. The three cases - CII, Microsoft and Mobil - all have one thing in common. They were fast off the starting blocks to present their side of the story. They did not wait for the media to pick up and tell their story for them. They chose to do it themselves, thus preventing any misrepresentation and misinterpretation. Telling one's own story as it is, is essential. The CII, Bill Gates and Mobil had compelling reasons to ``tell their side of the story'' and found it necessary to take full page advertisments. The media has its own bias and many feel that the media, both print and electronic, may not present the facts as they should be in their news stories. Developing countries, including Malaysia and its business community, need to learn from these companies to tell their own story. With the incresingly biased and opinionated news and feature stories, it is time concerted efforts are made to ``tell Malaysia's story''. While the government leadership, Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Minister continue to do their part, it is important for the private sector and the business community to play a greater part in this area. While small steps have been taken with the onset of the crisis, they are insufficient to have the required and intended impact. The continued presence in the popular press needs to be maintained. The Western media is a powerful tool, even if it does not report accurately all the time. It is a problem for small and helpless countries, companies and individuals in presenting their stories. Thus, the collective action of the CII can and should be emulated by organisations to present their side of the story and that of the countries in which they operate and have their base. The Malaysian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, for example, can together with other chambers of commerce and industry groups present the economic potential in the country. It is time the business community and entrepreneurs ``sell'' the potential to foreign investors and businesses. Malaysia's economic fundamentals remain unchanged despite the currency crisis. These need to be brought to the attention of the people who matter - decision makers, businessmen and fund managers. Who would be in a better position to speak to his counterparts, the foreign businessmen, if not his fellow businessmen and entrepreneurs with operations in Malaysia. Thus, as the CII has shown, the situation cannot be that hopeless. It takes courage to face the challenge, onslaught and condemnation from the world, including the most powerful economies. In the final analysis, it is the citizens, shareholders and owners who have to fight for their own country and company. If they do not, no one else will.

MEET Darryl Carlton. He's the chairman and chief executive officer (CEO) of Datek Sdn Bhd, the first Multimedia Super Corridor status firm to launch a Made-in-Malaysia software development tool, Batavia. Early in May, Datek achieved a coup of sorts when forty million viewers across the US and Canada got a virtual tour of its software development facility in Petaling Jaya. NBC, a major US television network featured Datek on its ``Technology Today'' show. Carlton, with 23 years in the computer industry, is unafraid to speak his mind on such issues as the use of local expertise and software piracy. Batavia, the first software development tool written in the Java programming language to come out of the Multimedia Super Corridor, was developed by a team made up largely of Malaysian software engineers. Carlton stresses, ``If I were in Silicon Valley I would still use the same expertise that I have now.'' And as for software piracy, he quipped, ``The American firms who are screaming the loudest about software piracy are the very ones who charge 50 per cent extra in Asia for their products, which are also very difficult to purchase here.'' The 42-year-old CEO, who is ``totally opposed to piracy'' also voiced his frustration over the inability to purchase software via the Net. He said that quite a few major corporations will not accept credit cards issued in Asia. Carlton who hails from Melbourne, did not learn about computers and software in the cloistered halls of well-known technical institutes but rather from being on-the-job. He in fact comes from a family where three generations have been in the newspaper business. It's not surprising then that he said, ``I worked for one year with the Melbourne Age when I was 17 years.'' In some ways, Carlton's link to the world of print continues, for he has written quite often for Computimes. These days, he writes less frequently due to growing business responsibilities. Datek's boss started working in the computer industry at the age of 18 as a trainee computer operator in 1975. ``The first computer I worked on was from GE,'' he said, adding that ``it had no keyboard, no screen, and used punched cards and punched tape.'' ``I started my first business in Australia in 1980 and that lasted two years,'' he said. In 1990, he began his second business that was operational until he moved to Malaysia in 1996 ``when I transferred all of the assets and intellectual property of that business to Datek''. He has personally invested RM10 million in the Malaysian company, proof of his belief in the nation's Information Technology (IT) commitment and he waxes enthusiastic about Malaysia's ``forward-looking'' stance. Carlton says, ``Compared with Australia, Malaysia has great vision.'' ``How many countries actually have a stated corporate strategy for the country?'' he queried. ``The fact that Malaysia has Vision 2020 is a dramatic improvement over those countries that don't have one. Most politicians in the world have a vision to win the next election and that's about it. ``Here you have a country with a government that actually has thought about the future.'' When relating why he chose Malaysia to base his company, he said, ``I can give you a host of business reasons as to why Malaysia is a really good place to operate but the reason I gave Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad was that the food is better here.'' In a more serious vein, Carlton added, ``The reason I came here was -this is a growth economy and the country is committed to IT and it's committed to moving away from manufacturing and tourism. ``The country's also committed to creating a sort of environment, where if you are a business person with ideas, you have a better than reasonable chance of being successful with those ideas.'' He added that that is all a business person seeks. ``No one really wants guarantees,'' he said, ``no one expects guarantees ... no one cares about handouts, what they want is the ability to do their best and this is what Malaysia provides.'' Prior to his coming to Malaysia, he said, ``I was doing business process engineering for very, very large corporations around the world and increasingly more and more of my business was coming from Asia. ``But everytime I did work in Asia and got on a plane to go home ... I was losing business.'' He continued, ``So I had to make a decision. In order to do business in Asia, I had to be in Asia. The next challenge of course, was well if I'm going to be in Asia - where and why?'' He downplayed the MSC as being the main inducement to set up business here. ``We decided to come here before the MSC took shape. We came here because the Government in Malaysia was already committed to technology.'' He said, Vision 2020 creates a very different climate. ``You have a climate in the main,'' Carlton said, ``where businesses are very forward-looking, in the main where the Government is very forward-looking and people are looking to the future and what it means.'' Commenting on current economic woes, he stressed that in Malaysia, the economy will get worse before it gets better. ``The economic problems here will drive out those companies which are basically badly-managed today and have been able to be successful because of the economy's general growth.'' As a result of the downturn, he said, the badly-run companies will not survive and ``therefore when the country does recover, it will recover in a dramatically better state, a higher quality state than it was previously in''. As a manufacturer of intellectual products, which Datek is, the depreciation of the ringgit provides cost advantages to the firm in the world market, said Carlton. The tightening labour market, he said frankly, boosted his ability to hire high quality staff and retain them at lower rates. From an investment point of view, he said, the tough economic situation improved many aspects of Datek's business. ``It provides us with the opportunity to basically be a `contrarian investor' ... we are dramatically increasing our investment. Now is the time to build products and export products ... not to hunker down in your shell and protect yourself.'' And this is precisely what Datek is doing. ``We are coming out with a couple of new products,'' says Carlton. ``We are re-engineering Batavia as a workstation product.'' ``The next version (of Batavia) which will come out in September will be the enterprise edition,'' said Carlton, adding that the enterprise edition will not be sold on the Net but directly and will be available from Datek's distributors. It will cost about US$10,000. ``What we expect from our website is to make fairly healthy sales (of the first Batavia version) and generate awareness of our products,'' he said. The firm will also introduce accounting software called `eXacct Financials' at the end of July. Touching briefly on the disadvantages of current economic problems, Carlton said as a result of this ``there is less liquidity in the market if you decide to go public''. And as for Asia's problems, he said in his forthright manner, the ``economies must and will survive''.

BC-Macedonia-Scandal
Seven people sentenced in pyramid scheme scandal
SKOPJE, Macedonia (AP) _ Seven people involved in last year's failed pyramid schemes, which cost thousands of Macedonians their savings, received sentences Monday ranging from fines to prison time. Some 23,000 Macedonians lost the equivalent of dlrs 65.8 million in late 1996 with the collapse of so-called pyramid schemes, which offer high interest rates and use new deposits to pay earlier investors. The biggest failure was of the Tat company, based in Bitolj, some 100 kilometers (62 miles) south of the capital, Skopje. Owner Sonja Nikolovska proclaimed her innocence and blamed the collapse on Macedonian companies that she claimed owed her an equivalent of dlrs 58 million. She was sentenced to eight years in prison. Four people who worked in government finance offices in Bitolj also received prison terms. Julijana Atanasova, head of the finance office, was sentenced to five years in prison. Employees Sogka Jancevska, Jonce Bocevski and Boris Mijalcev received sentences ranging from one year to three months. Siljan Micevski, the former mayor of Bitolj, received a one-year suspended sentence, while his wife, Violeta, was fined the equivalent of dlrs 882. All were accused of falsifying documents for Nikolovska and helped her avoid paying taxes. The scandal in Macedonia sparked fears of violence similar to that in neighboring Albania, where the failure of pyramid schemes led to armed insurrection last year. The Macedonian government has proposed a gradual compensation plan. (str/jg/scl)

THE call to buy Malaysian is not a call to buy inferior products, Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad said last night. ``World-class jeans are made in Malaysia. High-quality electronic components are manufactured in Malaysia. We can make cars and lorries in Malaysia that can be exported,'' he told a crowd of some 20,000 people at the ``Semarakkan Semangat Cinta Malaysia'' performance organised by the Malaysian Chinese Association in Kuala Lumpur. Dr Mahathir said Malaysian-made goods are ``different from before'' and the country has been making products for the world. Foreign goods, he said, are not necessarily better; in fact, he added, many foreign brands have Malaysian-made components. ``When we called for buying of Malaysian-made products, we are not urging the rakyat to buy inferior goods. We simply urge them to buy local products as this can help to strengthen the economy.'' He said buying local will help reduce the outflow of the ringgit while at the same time improve the local businesses. ``It is most critical to protect our currency, and this can be done by buying Malaysian-made products ... This gives strength for us to fight the present economic problems,'' he said. Dr Mahathir said Malaysians should support campaigns on buying locally- made goods. ``When we buy Malaysian-made products, it shows that we love the country and willing to sacrifice to defend the nation and its economy ... Malaysia belongs to all of us. If we don't, who else would love this nation?'' Dr Mahathir said the Government will do everything it can to defend the country and ensure it weathers the economic storm. He also called on the people to act rationally and sensibly in dealing with the problems facing them as a result of the region's financial crisis. ``In other multi-racial nations, there are problems and even racial riots due to the crisis. In Malaysia, we do not have this. No race in Malaysia is living in fear or feeling threatened. This is our advantage. We must value this,'' he added. The country's balanced economic development as well as the strong unity of its multi-racial population are the country's edge in overcoming the current downturn. Dr Mahathir said the country's racial harmony is intact because all the races in Malaysia are sensitive to one another's feelings.

BC-Germany-Obit-Huber
German dancer, film star, writer Lotti Huber dies at 85
BERLIN (AP) _ Lotti Huber, a pre-World War II cabaret dancer who escaped Nazi persecution and reclaimed fame in Germany in the 1980s with a film career, died Sunday at age 85. Huber died at a Berlin hospital after suffering a heart attack Friday, her friend and former stage partner Thomas Nowotny said. Huber's launch into cult status began at age 67 with the 1979 film ``Gigolo,'' in which she danced and appeared in a scene with film's lead, rock star David Bowie. She then netted lead roles in films during the 1980s by the openly homosexual German director Rosa von Praunheim, including ``Our Corpses are Alive,'' and ``Horror Vacui,'' in which Huber played a sect leader. She wrote a memoir entitled ``This Lemon Still Has a Lot of Juice.'' Born in 1912 in Kiel to a Jewish family, Huber became a cabaret dancer in Berlin. Because of her relationship with a German man, the Nazi government convicted her of ``racial disgrace'' in 1937 and imprisoned her in a concentration camp. An American organization secured her release a year later, and she emigrated to British-controlled Palestine and married a British colonel. After her stint as a cabaret dancer in Cairo, Egypt, the couple settled in Cyprus and ran a hotel together until their divorce in 1955. She returned to Germany in 1965. There was no immediate word on survivors or funeral arrangements. (im)

ANYONE who's been driving on our highways for any length of time will surely have stories to tell of lucky escapes from road accidents. Just the very thing happened when Malaysian Business test-drove the Ford Explorer 4-litre XLT sport utility vehicle (it's Yankee-speak for 4WD) recently. That life was spared and limb intact, was in no small measure due to the Explorer's rugged reliability. Overcome with grateful relief, a colleague who sat in the passenger seat chanted an involuntary `mantra': `Thank you XLT, I'm getting home safely.' (More about this `near-accident' later). The Ford Explorer XLT is an American import first launched locally in July last year. It comes with the reputation of being the `World's Best-selling' 4-by-4, and is credited with creating a huge growth in interest in the sports and recreational utility vehicle market in the United States. This trend has been transplanted to other markets in the United Kingdom, Australia, Thailand, Japan and South America. One would think anything stamped Uncle Sam would naturally be big and brash. This Explorer (there is a limited, upmarket model called the Explorer Limited) is big without being brash. Neither is it flashy. A pair of large `wraparound' headlamps split between a chromium-plated front grille gives it a commanding but understated presence. Its wheelbase measures well over 4.78 metres, making it longer than the Range Rover or many of its Japanese rivals. Yet it is lighter, having a kerb weight of just over 1,950 kg. A feature which sets the Explorer XLT apart from other 4WDs is Control Trac - a true on-demand 'smart' 4WD traction control system. Control Trac is operated by a simple three-position rotary knob on the dashboard and needs no secondary levers to clutter floor space or complicate driving routines. The Explorer XLT has deep windows that afford excellent all-round visibility. Rather than being hinged on to the rear door, the spare wheel is stored out of sight. The vehicle boasts stylish wheel arch flares and side sill skirts, tasteful chrome highlights and a classy exterior colour range. Sitting high above the traffic, yet avoiding the `tall boy' stance of many 4WD vehicles, the Ford Explorer has a commanding presence on the highway. Safety concerns are given top priority in the Explorer. All have dual front airbags, 4-wheel disc brakes with ABS, anti-submarining front seats, outboard seatbelt lockers, adjustable front seatbelt upper mountings, cargo tie-down hooks and limited-slip rear axle. The front sections of the Explorer XLT's separate chassis have controlled collapse rates engineered to help absorb frontal and offset front crash forces. Doors enclose side-impact protection beams and the body incorporates a cabin safety cage, part of which is a major composite cross car beam behind the instrument panel. The steering wheel frame is magnesium which has crash energy absorption and noise/vibration suppression qualities superior to the steel usually used. Internally, the dashboard controls not only look neat but they are also well-laid out and functional to boot. The Explorer XLT has a single stalk wiper and lamp controls to the left of the steering wheel - no confusing which controls what. On the minus side? The Autocruise control could do with a little refinement. Looking extremely functional, the thumb-activated pads require a degree of concentrated exertion (it feels hard to the touch) to operate. Climbing in requires some effort for those of us who are not physically too well-endowed; the Explorer XLT could do with side-steps. The seats are a little on the firm side, but this can easily be remedied by placing one of those therapeutic cushions easily available from auto accessory outlets. After all that, you are now ready to hear about that `near-accident' story. Friday afternoon on the Federal Highway and this driver had just collected the Explorer for the weekend testdrive. Most drivers are struggling to stay awake at the wheel with the airconditioning turned on full-blast. The bitumen on the road surface has a treacly appearance, having baked all day at an El Nino-induced 37 degrees Celsius. First protaganist: a woman driver in a shiny new compact car in the middle lane heading towards the city. For no apparent reason, she chugs along at just under 60kmph which riles protaganist 2 - a male driver of an articulated lorry minus the trailer. Pulling on to her rear, he clearly indicates his intentions: `Move aside, lady, and stop hogging the middle lane as if you were out on a Sunday drive!' `Miss Piggy' - that's a female road hog -doesn't get the hint. Exasperated, the driver tries to pass on the inside lane, where protaganist 3 - two men in a beat-up 1.3 litre saloon - is moving forward, fastest of the three! The lorry grazes the car on the left with its left front fender. The car's speed causes it to be shunted forward and once brakes are applied, is spun 90 degrees to the right while stuck to the front fender of the articulated lorry. The car's front fender grazes the left rear of `Miss Piggy's' compact which is propelled forward and spun 180 degrees. Pandemonium! The Explorer XLT was right behind the articulated lorry. Why didn't we become protaganist 4 - and another statistic of everyday road mayhem? Firstly, the Explorer's height affords a commanding `road ahead' view. Once the accident occurred, it bought sufficient time to hit the brakes. But had we not stopped in time, both front-seat occupants could have relied on the dual-airbags in the Explorer XLT to cushion an impact. COREL Corp has incorporated its latest word processor, Corel WordPerfect Suite 8, with Dragon System Inc's Dragon Naturally Speaking continuous speech-recognition software. The new bundle is called Corel WordPerfect Suite 8 with Dragon Naturally Speaking (CWS8/DNS). By leveraging on the reputation of Dragon Naturally Speaking as one of the industry's leading voice-recognition software, Corel hopes to add value to its existing word processing suite. While both software have been available separately in the local market for quite some time, this new bundle from Corel is still at its beta stage. ``The first final version of the CWS8/DNS will only be shipped and made locally available in the next couple of weeks,'' said Kany Chan, Corel's media relations manager for China and Southeast Asia, at a Press conference recently. CWS8/DNS runs on Windows 95 and NT platforms with a minimum of 133 megahertz (MHz) processor, 48 megabytes (MB) of random access memory (RAM), 110 megabytes (MB) of hard disk space, a 16-bit sound card and compact disk read-only-memory (CD-ROM) drive. According to Chan, the CWS8/DNS allows users to dictate up to 160 words per minute and encompasses a vocabulary of 230,000 words, customised abbreviations and jargon. But like all existing voice-recognition software, it requires ``training'' to the particular user's speech pattern, and is vulnerable to disruption from the environment's background sound. Although still unconfirmed, Corel said the price of this latest bundling effort will range as the local recommended retail price for the Corel WordPerfect Suite 8. CWS8/DNS is also expected to come packaged with a headset microphone to facilitate usage of the voice-recognition part of the word processor. At the same event, Corel also launched the Corel Print Office, an entry level desktop publishing application aimed at small office-home office (SOHO) users. The software encompasses three main components, which are: Corel Print Office, Corel Photo House and Corel Colleagues Contacts. Chan also gave a brief insight on Corel's development of Java-based products. ``There are three parts to Corel's Java strategy and they are the OpenJ Development Environment, jSuite and jBridge thin-client technology,'' she said. ``The OpenJ Development Environment is a professional software developers kit for Java applications, while jSuite is for end users who want to create lightweighted, Java business applications.'' Chan added that the jBridge thin-client technology is Corel's answer for users of 32-bit Windows applications who want to take advantage of Java virtual machines. As for the development of these Java-based products, she said Corel worked with Sun Microsystems in the initial stages of the development. ``These three Java applications from Corel should be available by the end of 1998,'' Chan said. The local distributor for Corel products is SiS Distribution (M) Sdn Bhd.

`FOR BETTER or for worse, till death do us part.' How many people actually keep to this marriage vow and stick together through thick and thin? At a time when our economy is faltering, let us all re-examine our matrimonial commitments to each other. This brings me to the subject of this issue's topic - the indispensable role of women in the success (or failure) of their husbands. The economic problems have taken its toll on many marriages, leading to divorce. Relationships have been highly strained and many families have fallen apart, primarily because people are not able to have the same life-style that they had in good times. I have a close friend who went through bad times recently. His business collapsed and the loan sharks were circling. Empathising with his plight, I introduced him to a job in another town. He brought his wife and his son along. However, things did not work out and the couple could not get along. My friend became unbearable to live with and his wife's impatience with his inability to overcome their financial woes took its toll on their marriage. I admire women who go through thick and thin and stand by their men. One such case is the wife of the Thai multi-millionaire turned sandwich vendor, Sirivat Voravetvuthikun (he appeared in our April issue) who was here recently to give support to our TTGG (The Tough Get Going) Fund. His wife, Vilailuck, earned a degree from Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, majoring in cost accounting. After getting married, she gave up her lucrative job to help her husband run his condominium project when it was not running smoothly. When the stock market crashed, her husband was down by one billion baht (RM100 million)! She stood by her husband when the business collapsed and he turned sandwich salesman. In fact, selling sandwiches was actually her idea! From the start of their sandwich venture, she would wake up every morning at 3.00 am and spend the next three hours preparing the sandwiches. When I asked her why she was prepared to stand by him all the way, this was what she said: `My husband is a good man. When he was rich, he was not one to squander his money. He doesn't smoke, doesn't drink and doesn't womanize. Many a time he wouldn't even spend on new clothes for himself. He would continue to invest whatever he earned into his business venture. He did his best for his family. I must now stand by my man when the chips are down.' Yes, it is easy to stick around when the going is good, but it is really during tough times that we need to stick together more, to give support in whatever way we can. Recently, I had the good fortune of meeting Datuk Maznah Hamid, who rose from being a farmer's daughter to become Malaysia's top Malay woman entrepreneur, managing director of the Securiforce group of companies and director of Perbadanan Usahawan Nasional Bhd (National Entrepreneur Corporation) which oversees 300 public listed companies. Maznah (she has since earned the nickname the Iron Lady of Malaysia) and her husband went through thick and thin on their way to be what they are today. This is what she says: `I would rather lose everything than to lose my husband and family.' Couples during these challenging times should emulate them. To all the women in our lives, I have this to say: `It is easy enough to be pleasant, `When life flows along like in a song.' `But the spouse worthwhile is the one who will smile, `When everything goes dead wrong!' Let's adopt the stance that in life there is no such thing as bad weather, only varying levels of good weather. A supportive spouse is important to guide the men through rain or shine. Women like Vilailuck and Maznah are shining beacons who point the way out of the gloom. This article is the second in a series contributed by Billi P S Lim in his effort to expedite the recovery of the Malaysian economy. He is the author of Dare to Fail which is available in English, Bahasa Malaysia and Chinese from major bookstores. Lim is also involved in a Malaysian economic recovery project called TTGG (The Tough Get Going) Fund, organised by MMM Networking Sdn Bhd and other Malaysian companies.

BC-Portugal-Arson Trial
Five get maximum jail terms for arson attack that killed 13
Eds: Meia Culpa is cq
PENAFIEL, Portugal (AP) _ A court Monday sentenced five men to the longest jail term allowed under Portuguese law for an arson attack on a nightclub last year that killed 13 people and injured 22. The court handed down the 25-year sentence to Jose Queiros for contracting three bouncers from the nearby city of Oporto and paying them 1 million escudos (dlrs 5,800) each to carry out the attack. The three-month trial heard how the three armed and hooded bouncers doused the Meia Culpa nightclub in gasoline and set it alight at 4 a.m. on April 16 last year. The men, in their early 20s, stopped the people inside from fleeing the fire, and shot one man in the back as he ran for a door. The bouncers, and the intermediary between them and Queiros, also received the maximum jail term. The motive was believed to be the competition for business in Amarante, 300 miles (480 kilometers) north of Lisbon where the recently opened Meia Culpa was rivaling Queiros's club called the Diamante Negro. Two men who stole the car used in the getaway were each jailed for one year. (bh/jt)

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 2nd Ld-Writethru,0595
More deaths reported in Kosovo; thousands flee
Eds: UPDATES with thousands marching in Kosovo. RECASTS, trims By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Refugees from Serbia's Kosovo province streamed into neighboring Albania on Monday to escape some of the worst fighting in months. Dozens of people were reported killed. Reports from Serb and Albanian sources often were contradictory and could not be independently verified. But with 39 people reported killed over the weekend, and fighting apparently continuing, the bloodshed seemed the worst since early March, when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on independence-minded militants and their families. A day after Serb authorities claimed to have killed several dozen militants in four villages in the Decani region of western Kosovo, ethnic Albanian officials said 37 Albanians had been killed over the weekend. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani while 10 were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died in the fighting around Decani, 75 kilometers (45 miles) west of the regional capital Pristina, Serb sources said. The latest fierce fighting prompted about 2,000 Kosovo Albanians, mostly women, children and elderly, to leave the troubled region and cross over into Albania's Troboja region Sunday and Monday, Albanian authorities said. They said more were arriving by the hour. Interior Ministry spokesman Artan Bizhga said in the Albanian capital, Tirana, that the refugees, many of whom walked for as many as 10 hours, were being accommodated in local homes and a school. Local authorities were providing free food and clothes. In a statement, the Albanian government called on the United States and the European Community to intervene ``for ending the massacre in Kosovo.'' ``This is just the start of a war with tragical dimensions,'' it said. LISBON, Portugal (AP) _ A consortium of Portuguese and Venezuelan companies Monday won their battle for control of private national television channel Televisao Independente, one of the country's four broadcasters. A court approved the takeover after TVI's creditors endorsed the consortium's proposed recovery plan for the debt-ridden channel. The consortium includes retail and industrial giant Sonae, media and entertainment group Lusomundo, both from Portugal, and Venezuela's Cisneros Group. The Cisneros Group, one of the largest corporations in Latin America, owns businesses in communications, entertainment and soft drinks, including Venevision, Venezuela's No. 1 TV station. The consortium's plan beat two other bids for control of TVI which was launched in 1993 by institutions and companies linked to the Roman Catholic Church as the country's second private channel. TVI has failed to secure an average weekly audience share of more than 15 percent since its launch, and creditors reportedly are owed 17 billion escudos (dlrs 93 million). SIC, the first private channel, launched in 1992, has attained an audience share of about 50 percent, eclipsing state broadcaster Radiotelevisao Portuguesa, created in 1956. The latest viewing figures, for the week May 18-24, gave SIC a 49.6 percent share, with 32.6 percent for RTP1, 11.3 percent for TVI, and 6.5 percent for RTP2. (bh/jt)

Police allow men, women to pray together at Jerusalem's Western Wall
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Breaking precedent, 300 men and women prayed together at Jerusalem's Western Wall _ despite violent protests by ultra-Orthodox Jews, who threw garbage at the worshippers over a police barrier. Sunday marked the first time that police allowed men and women to pray together at the wall, Judaism's holiest site. In the past, police upheld ultra-Orthodox practices, making sure men and women prayed in segregated areas. It was not immediately clear whether Sunday's action marked a lasting change in police policy. Worshippers from the more liberal Reform and Conservative streams of Judaism _ dominant among U.S. Jews _ made up the mixed service. In Israel, the Orthodox establishment has a monopoly over religious matters, including marriage and divorce.

Mir computer working again almost ready for testing.
Eds: UPDATES two new last grafs, service module for space station AP Photos MOSB101,103. By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ The central computer on board Mir was working again Monday night, after a three-day breakdown that threatened to postpone the Russian space station's last rendezvous with a U.S. shuttle. The Mir crew now hopes to reactivate the station's automatic steering system, said Valery Lyndin, a spokesman for Russian Mission Control. The shuttle can only dock with Mir when the steering system keeps it properly aligned. The space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to lift off Tuesday and dock with the station Friday to pick up astronaut Andrew Thomas, the seventh and last American to live on the Russian outpost. Lyndin said space officials have not yet determined why Mir's computer broke down on Saturday. Russian cosmonauts Talgat Musabayev and Nikolai Budarin replaced it with another unit, but the new unit failed on Sunday when they tried to switch it on. Ground controllers fully loaded the software into the computer Monday night, and the crew was able to get it working again within about 90 minutes. Reactivating the steering system can take an entire day. During a chat with ground controllers during the repair process, Musabayev said the situation on board ``isn't bad'' but added that he was concerned that it occurred on the eve of the shuttle's launch. ``I'm worried not for myself, but for the flight program,'' he said. Mir's computer repeatedly failed last year, prompting Russian space officials to send up a replacement on a shuttle ferry flight in January. That unit failed on Saturday after five months of trouble-free operation. The station's crew has replaced it with a back-up computer brought up by a Russian cargo ship. Mir's main computer operates the station's motion control system, and when it fails, the station's energy supply is threatened because it can't keep its solar panels in optimum alignment with the sun. Depending on how much energy was lost, it can take from one to three days to get the orientation system fully on-line. Fortunately, when the latest trouble occurred, the station was on the so-called solar orbit, which puts it in direct sunlight round the clock. As a result, the Mir's solar panels have remained in full sunlight. The crew also shut down some systems to save energy, and as a result Mir's batteries were full on Monday, making it easier for the crew to restore the orientation system, Lyndin said. Russia plans to bring down the 12-year-old Mir at the end of 1999 after the first parts of the international space station are in orbit. A Russian-manufactured propulsion system, is supposed to be launched in November. But Russia's contributions to the station have been delayed repeatedly because of financial problems. A service module for the station to be supplied by Russia is nearly ready for testing, the Interfax news agency reported. A satellite communications system and a computer will be installed in the module before it is sent to the Baikonur launch site in Kazakstan, where it will be launched in April of next year, the report said. TOUGH times are upon us. Industry sales are sluggish. Equity markets are down. The economic growth is grinding to a halt. Corporate performance is declining. What type of leadership is required to overcome these tough times? We often hear corporate leaders complain that things are out of their control. They cite the economic slowdown, which is an external factor, as an example. They say that they are no longer in charge and that they are driven by external circumstances. Companies cannot afford to retain such leaders who only know how to manage good times but are helpless during tough times. An extraordinary leadership is required to turn around this predicament. We need leadership that can help us transcend the difficulties and take us to the desired destination. I call this transcendental leadership. Extraordinary challenges require extraordinary leaders who can transcend what it is to what it can be. Scientist Albert Einstein said: ``No problem can be solved from the same consciousness that created it. We must learn to see the world anew.'' To transcend, we need to go beyond the limits of consciousness. To do this, we need transcendental leadership. Transcendental leadership is different from normal leadership. Normal leadership is based on defined human limits. The Advanced Oxford Dictionary defines ``transcend'' as going beyond normal limits. Transcendental leadership is about going beyond the defined limits of human knowledge, experience or reason to turn adversity into advantage. The key word here is ``defined''. Humans are often limited by the way or the degree they define things. Ordinary humans think, feel and act base on a mindset they are accustomed to. Defining existing problems and coming up with solutions within this paradigm won't overcome unusual crises. Transcendental leaders are those who can break limits by helping others redefine their possibilities. In this cyber age, we are beset by challenges that often go beyond the defined capabilities of normal leaders. Transcendental leaders use new levels of thinking, feeling and actions to overcome new challenges. Transcendental leaders know that the power to change comes from within them. They know they have access to limitless capacity, creativity and inner resources to change. The economic slowdown is an example of the emergence of unusual challenges that require transcendental leadership. Transcendental leaders enable people in an organisation to think what has not been thought before, to feel what has not been felt before and to act on what has not been done before, to achieve new desired levels of performance which have never been achieved before. To overcome the slowdown, organisations need transcendental leaders who can undertake 10 key transcendental roles to help their organisation bridge the chasm they are in today to where they want to be tomorrow. The accompanying diagram shows the 10 key transcendental roles. Thinking the unthinkable New inventions, discoveries and breakthroughs are achieved through thinking beyond normal conventions. If leadership was to be based on thinking the common, people today will not able to fly. For many centuries, men had dreamt of flying, but conventional thinking had always weighed men down. Conventional thinking had become the barrier to men's capability to fly, making them believe that the ``flying carpets'' of the Arabian Nights were only dreams and could never be a reality. It took unconventional thinking on the part of the Wright brothers to break free of those limitations. Isaac Newton, who is considered one of the greatest scientists of all time, was able to think beyond convention and thus discovered the laws of gravity. The story of young Newton sitting by an apple tree and asking, `` Why did the apple fall downward and not upward?'' is a good example of thinking the unthinkable. Mahatma Gandhi was in the realm of unthinkable during his time when he influenced his countrymen regarding his philosophy of non-violence and his commitment towards achieving independence for India. Martin Luther King was thinking the unthinkable for blacks in America in the '60s when he said: ``I have a dream that one day on the red hills of Georgia, the sons of former slaves and the sons of former slave owners will be able to sit down together at the table of brotherhood. ``I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the colour of their skin but the the content of their character.'' Political and industrial leaders must be brave enough to explore the realms of the unthinkable to turn around the Asian economies and corporate performance. They need a new way of thinking to come up with new solutions. There must be many ways a region, a nation, a community and an organisation can turn around the economies, besides just focusing on cost-cutting. We must begin by developing leadership that encourages thinking the unthinkable. Feeling the numbness Numbness is best understood when one is showered with so many gifts that one additional gift will not give more pleasure. Thus, the overabundance of gifts will reduce one's appreciation for them. Likewise, when one is injured in an accident, one more injury will not add additional pain. In good times leaders often become immune to their success. They forget that it is customers who pay their salaries and luxuries. It is the hard work of their people who laid the foundation of success, and that the continued success of their organisations will depend on their continuous improvement of their services and their organisation as a whole. The moment leaders become numb to their staff, customers, suppliers, competitors, government and stakeholders, it is the beginning of their downfall. Complacency is often the culprit that numbs the feelings of leaders towards changes around them. For example, many leaders in Asian corporate organisations are not confident as they are numbed by the message of gloom. Some have become complacent with the message of despair and are willing to accept their fate. In good times they are numbed by pleasure while in bad times they are numbed by their pain. In short, they become immune to the present conditions and do little to change conditions for the better. Transcendental leadership is about the ability to feel despite the numbness that is setting in all around us. They possess the power of aliveness and the ability to feel fully without being numbed by pleasures or pain. Transcendental leaders can change before things become a crisis, and they can capitalise on opportunities before they become opportunity costs. Doing the impossible At a recent business convention, I met John Coutis, a powerful and successful motivation speaker with extraordinary perseverance. Coutis is physically handicapped as he has no legs. He moves around with his hands . He speaks more eloquently and with more conviction than any other motivational speakers. The truth is that Coutis can do what most conscious minds think impossible. He is doing more things than an ordinary person. He scuba dives, swims, plays base ball, lifts weights, drives, speaks at conventions and does his own laundry. Coutis is a great motivational leader, providing inspiration to young people and business leaders around the world. Coutis' most valuable message is that he has an advantage, that he can see his handicap, whereas most people cannot see their ``handicaps''. He added that most people have a ``handicap'' in the way they think what is possible and what is impossible. Coutis' philosophy can be summarised as: ``There's no such word as can't.'' What resources Coutis lacks externally, he has been able to draw them from within him. His extraordinary belief, determination and positive disposition provides him enormous power to overcome challenges in his life. Great people have been able to achieve extraordinary feats because they dare to try what seems impossible. Roger Bannister was the first to break the four-minute mile barrier. Christopher Columbus did the seemingly impossible by setting sail on a route to East Asia by sailing due west across the Atlantic Ocean. His tenacity to find a westward route from Europe to the Orient led to his discovery of the Americas and created history. A 19th-century editor and essayist, Elbert Hubbard, said: ``The world is moving so fast these days that anyone who says it can't be done is generally interrupted by someone doing it.'' Political and corporate leaders will learn well if they heed this message. Touching the untouchables The original concept of ``untouchables'' came from Hinduism's hierarchical and hereditary caste system. The lowest group in this system was called ``untouchables''. However, the concept of untouchable that we would like to discuss here is different. The best way to illustrate this is that when watching a tragic love movie, we often notice that there are people who are emotionally overwhelmed and shed a bucket of tears. These people are touched by the drama as depicted in the movies. On the other, hand there are also people who are untouched by any of these tragic dramas, either outwardly or emotionally. One of the important roles of leaders is to touch these ``untouchables'' who are distant and impartial to what is going on. In organisations, we listen to managers who complain that there are staff who cannot be motivated no matter what they do to them. These managers say that these staff are a lost cause. While there is such a reality as an ``unmotivated person'', there is no such reality as an ``unmotivatable person''. Within each one of us lies huge motivation potential which is waiting to be unleashed. The unmotivated person is untouchable and is not moved by the normal calling of their work. The role of transcendental leaders is to change the unmotivated to become motivated. To do this, they need to liberate the motivation power within individuals and help them achieve great feats for themselves, for their families, for their organisations, for their nations and for the world. Transcendental leaders can touch the minds, hearts and souls of individuals to the extent that people are willing to commit their all to a worthy cause. These transcendental leaders know how to put the message in such a compelling and attractive manner that people are so touched by their noble cause and want to be a part of it. Victor S.L. Tan is the chief executive officer of KL Strategic Change Consulting Group. He holds a MBA degree from Ohio State University. His latest book is ``Changing Mindsets: Ensuring The Future Of Asian Organisations''. He will conduct a two-day workshop on ``Managing Tough Times'' on June 17 and 18.

Report: Pakistan feared Israeli attack hours before nuclear detonations
By DAFNA LINZER Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Pakistan feared an Israeli air strike on its nuclear installations hours before it detonated five nuclear devices last week, Israeli media reported Monday. State-run Israel television said Pakistan's foreign minister informed the United States about the plans last Thursday, hours before it carried out the tests. Pakistan believed that Israeli planes would operate out of bases in India, the report said. The United States told Pakistan that Israel was not planning any such attack, Israel's Channel Two Television said. Israel has relations with India but not Pakistan, the first Islamic nation to go nuclear. Shai Bazak, spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denied an attack was planned. ``These reports are totally baseless,'' he told Israel TV. Israel, an undeclared nuclear power, has warned that India and Pakistan's atomic tests could encourage Iran to follow suit. Israel destroyed an Iraqi nuclear facility in 1981. The Israeli Cabinet discussed the recent tests on the sub-continent on Monday, and Netanyahu's media adviser David Bar-Illan said in a statement that Monday's visit by Iran's foreign minister to Pakistan ``strengthens Israel and the international community's calls to make every effort in order to prevent Iran from gaining a nuclear capacity.'' ``The international community needs to act decisively in order to prevent Iranian capabilities,'' he said. According to Israeli officials, Iran is seeking technology to build a bomb and is close to having its own long-range delivery system capable of hitting Israel. In Islamabad, Pakistan, Iranian Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi said Monday that Muslims everywhere welcomed the nuclear tests, but dismissed suggestions that Iran was preparing to follow Pakistan down the nuclear road. dl-hla

More deaths reported in Kosovo; thousands flee employees seeing fighting. Trims. No pickup
Eds: UPDATES with U.N. spokesman confirming refugee exodus, U.N. By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Thousands of refugees from Serbia's Kosovo province streamed into neighboring Albania on Monday to escape some of the deadliest fighting in months. Dozens of people were reported killed. Albania appealed to the United States and European Union to intervene in what it said was a ``massacre'' in Kosovo. ``This is just the start of a war with tragic dimensions,'' the Albanian government said in a statement. Reports from Serb and Albanian sources often were contradictory and could not be independently verified. But with 39 people reported killed over the weekend, and fighting apparently continuing, the bloodshed appeared the worst since March, when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on militants among the ethnic Albanian majority in Serb-ruled Kosovo. In New York, U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard spoke of ``heavy and indiscriminate shelling'' of some Kosovo Albanian villages near the border to Albania. He said U.N. workers could see heavy mortars being fired into the villages. Serb authorities claimed Sunday to have killed dozens of militants in four villages in the Decani region of western Kosovo. Ethnic Albanian leaders put a firmer number on the toll among their people, saying 37 had died. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani while 10 were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died in the fighting around Decani, 75 kilometers (45 miles) west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina, Serb sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The latest fierce fighting forced about 2,000 Kosovo Albanians _ mostly women, children and the elderly _ across the border into Albania's Tropoja region on Sunday and Monday, Albania said. They said more were arriving by the hour. Local authorities were putting the refugees up in a school and in private homes and giving them food and clothes, Interior Ministry spokesman Artan Bizhga said in Albania's capital, Tirana. Authorities in Serbia are using Serbian police and the Yugoslav army to try to crush militants and maintain control over the province, where 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million is ethnic Albanian. The conflict has killed more than 200 people in Kosovo since the beginning of March. About half of the province is believed controlled by militant Albanians and many regions are blocked off, either by Serbs or Albanians. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, released the names of the 10 people it said were killed Sunday when Serb police stormed the village of Poklek, 25 kilometers (15 miles) west of Pristina. It said one had had his throat slit. According to the ethnic Albanians' account, Serb police burst into Poklek houses, pulled out villagers and told them to, ``Go to Albania and never return.'' Afterward, Serb police allegedly set 26 homes ablaze. All phone lines remained disconnected Monday between Pristina and Decani, Klina and Djakovica, where fierce battles were reported Sunday. In Pristina, about 10,000 ethnic Albanians, including 2,000 children, marched to protest Serbian rule. Yugoslavia's state-run daily Politika on Monday accused ethnic Albanian ``terrorist groups'' of killing several of their countrymen and of shelling border villages that are home to people opposed to the militants. Serbia is the dominant of two republics remaining in the Yugoslav federation.
