KUALA LUMPUR, Sun. - Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad reiterated his call to Malaysians to remain united and face the country's economic problems in a rational and sensitive manner. Dr Mahathir said these two qualities could help avoid possible misunderstanding and ill-feeling which were counter-productive to ongoing efforts to overcome the country's problems. He said various steps had already been taken by the Government to restore the economy and one of them was the ``Love Malaysia'', ``Buy Malaysia'' campaign such as the one organised by the MCA. Dr Mahathir said this at a large gathering of Malaysians at Dataran Merdeka tonight, including Bond girl Michelle Yeoh and other artistes. Also present were the Prime Minister's wife Datin Seri Dr Siti Hasmah Mohd Ali, MCA president Datuk Seri Dr Ling Liong Sik and his wife Datin Seri Ena Ling, deputy president Datuk Lim Ah Lek, MCA central committee members, the party's Wanita chief Datuk Teng Gaik Kwan and its Youth chief Datuk Chan Kong Choy. Dr Mahathir said: ``In some other multi-racial, multi-religious and multi-cultural countries, riots can be triggered by many factors. But we are fortunate because we are more rational and sensitive to each other's feelings and needs. ``This is one of our strengths. Of course, there are certain foreign Press which never fail to mention that there are racial undercurrents in the country. ``But tonight's gathering is a good example of how the various races in Malaysia get together to play their part in helping the economy. Some of the foreign reports seem to have been made by people who have closed their eyes, ears and minds. ``We can gather today without fear and tension. We must value this. I am very happy that tonight's event once again demonstrates the people's sensitive nature.'' He cited as an example of Malaysians' sensitivity the gesture by the organisers to stop the performance for a while to observe the isyak prayers at about 8.30pm. Dr Mahathir said the country was still committed to achieving developed nation status by 2020. ``We believe that we are able to develop the country to be on equal standing with other developed nations,'' he said. He added others might want to see the country impoverished so that they could then acquire the nation's assets. Hence, the attack on share prices in the belief that they could then buy these companies cheap. He said these people also wanted to take over local banks and industries. ``If we allow this, then we will be their slaves and cannot claim to be independent,'' he said.

Hezbollah threatens attacks, Israeli warns of harsh response
BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP) _ Hezbollah guerrillas have threatened retaliation for an Israeli missile strike that hit civilians in south Lebanon, while Israel warned of a tough response if shells fall in Israeli territory. The threats raised fears in Lebanon of a new round of cross-border fighting in which far more Lebanese die than Israelis. In Israel, newspapers reported Monday that residents of northern Israel spent the night in shelters in fear of a possible Hezbollah attack. ``The resistance ... cannot keep quiet in light of what has happened,'' Sheik Nabil Kaouk, Hezbollah commander in the south, told reporters Sunday night after weekend Israeli rocket attacks killed a Lebanese shepherd and wounded his brother and another man. In Israel, radio reports quoted the Israeli army's northern command as warning it will respond ``harshly'' if rockets fall on northern Israel. The Israeli army also suggested Monday that the harm to civilians was unintentional. ``Israel has no interest in attacking citizens,'' an army statement said, adding the targeted area ``is an open space and anyone in it is suspected of being a terrorist or protecting terrorists.'' Cross-border guerrilla rocket attacks triggered major fighting in 1996 in which at least 175 people, mostly Lebanese civilians, were killed. Since then, Hezbollah has targeted the occupied zone and occasionally Israeli positions along the international border for retaliation. On Sunday, Israeli troops fired a missile near a village in southern Lebanon, killing a Lebanese shepherd and wounding his brother, security officials said. On Saturday night, an Israeli rocket attack injured a guerrilla near another village. The Lebanese security officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, originally said two brothers were killed in the rocket attack Sunday. But they later said one of the brothers had only been wounded and was hospitalized. Both targets hit by Israel are in a guerrilla mountain stronghold on the edge of the Israeli-occupied border zone in the south. Hezbollah is leading the fight to oust some 1,500 Israeli troops and 2,500 Lebanese militia allies from the occupied zone. Israel or its allies have controlled the zone for over 20 years, maintaining the occupation is needed to guard against cross-border guerrilla raids.

I HAVE decided - for better or worse - to stay true to my Fiat. True, my trusty Fiat has overheated in the midst of the traffic crawl along Jalan Tun Razak in the middle of the day, with everybody gawking and no one stopping to help. It's true to say that my sentimental junk has a worse medical condition than me and has to meet its doctor (mechanic) more often than I have to see mine. And every time I bring it in for minor repairs, I might just have to forego the new clothes that I intended to buy that month. My 18-year-old junk is inclined to break down in the middle of the night along a road where there are no public phones and no passing vehicles for hours. And I dare not drive it into the Lake Club and park it outside for fear that I might be accused of depriving others with their Mercedes and BMWs of a parking spot. True that even if I started carpooling, others might still insist on taking the bus or even prefer to walk. And whenever I am driving my trusty Mirafiori 131 on the left lane, I get honked at for no reason whatsoever. My nephew Siji has never tired of reminding me that the car should be thrown into some disused mining pool but then I do not have to burn a hole in my pocket every month when the car loan sharks come to collect their monthly dues. In this economic hardship era, when the interest rates of all the car loans have gone up, I can smile and console myself that I would not be affected at all as my car belongs to me a hundred per cent. While others have to be careful with their spending, I would still be able to afford to gorge on cheesecakes and chocolates and give others a treat once in a while. Besides, my car would be the only one of its kind running on the road in a major traffic jam and might even be sought after in 20 years to come. And when cars are crawling along Jalan Tun Razak in the middle of the scorching afternoon and a brand new car decides to stall (which I have seen numerous times), I can hold my head up high (and if I could, I would even raise the two front wheels like they do with BMX bicycles!) and drive past in style. And all sensible drivers will say - see that trusty Fiat go! If I ever knock into or get knocked into by a brand new car, my first worry would not be ``What happened to my car?'' but the question would be more of ``How bad is his or her car?'' And when I go to any of the mechanics in town, they would fix the dent or restart it for me at the most minimal price or even for free, for fear that I might not be able to afford the bill. Now whenever the car decides to stall, I would curse it and threaten to throw it into the disused mining pool in Puchong but the silver lining here is that when it is repaired and on the road again, I will be a stronger person having gone through that phase. And if I ever decide to stop to buy those things that they sell at the roadside stalls along the highways, the sellers would not even think of charging me more than the usual price. They might even reduce it if I asked them. I know that my ``fiatty'' Fiat is at present out of fashion but then again, the fact remains that a child developing a hand at art would definitely start off by drawing MY car, and not some sporty sedan. And when senior journalists talk about the old times when they were driving only Peugeots and Fiats, I can join in and say ``Look, I am going down the same road as you people''. There will also come a day when I can talk of ``Those days when .....'' to the younger breed. While for many people Fiat stands for ``Fiat Is Always Trouble'', to me, MY Fiat stands for ``Fiat Is Always True''.

HYPERTEC Memory (M) Sdn Bhd, which specialises in personal computer (PC) memory, has announced the availability of the HyperRace MxPro 180, a processor upgrade designed to enhance central processing unit (CPU) performance by up to 360 per cent. According to the company, the HyperRace MxPro 180 is able to enhance CPU performance up to 360 per cent and is one of the most cost-effective MMX upgrade products, allowing users to run MMX-enabled software. Hypertec Memory said the product could be easily installed and it provides a simple alternative to buying a new Pentium MMX computer. ``The HyperRace MxPro 180 will bring an organisation or an individual's existing system up to today's expected performance standard for a fraction of the cost of a new Pentium PC,'' said Hypertec Malaysia's managing director Colin Lillywhite at the product launch held in conjunction with the opening of the local office. ``The local offices provide benefits for customers in this region by giving them reliable and fast delivery of our large, quality product range, including HyperRace processor upgrades and HyperRam memory products,'' he said. The company said the HyperRace MxPro 180 is suitable for users of Windows 95, Windows NT, games software and Internet applications. It is capable of increasing the software performance on a 75-megahertz (MHz) Pentium processor by 47 per cent for Windows 95, 41 per cent for Windows NT and by 368 per cent for multimedia and games programs. The HyperRace MxPro 180's socket-5 and socket-7 and basic input output system (BIOS) enhancement software ensures compatibility with existing systems. The product, said Hypertec Memory, meets the standards of XXCAL Inc, an American independent testing body that provides quality assurance and compatibility testing, and the Australian Electromagnetic Interference Standard (C-Tick). It also allows users to take full advantage of the increased internal CPU speed of 180MHz by including a large 64K internal write-back cache memory. The size of this cache memory reduces the number of external accesses which the CPU has to make. Hypertec Memory claimed this is significant as Pentium-class CPUs slow down between 50 and 66MHz when accessing the rest of the system. The HyperRace MxPro 180 is available at a retail price of RM599.

Often, there are bound to be some drivers coming from the USJ direction, defying the traffic lights and rules at the popular SS19 Subang Jaya traffic light junction, and making U-turns into SS18. This short cut is dangerous and can easily lead to a nasty accident. Although, there are two ``No Entry'' signs prominently placed on both sides of the entrance of a narrow and short sliproad from Jalan USL 3/1E, which directly links up with the nearby SS19 bridge into Subang Jaya, you can still see cars coming out from that sliproad. Again this is a short cut to get on the bridge and into Subang Jaya from USJ. It's also horrifying to see motorists making U-turns at the KFC exit. There is an urgent need for strict enforcement of the traffic laws by the relevant authorities. They should keep an eye on those who flout the traffic rules in SS19 so that the roads can be made safe for all motorists.

Report: Pakistan feared Israeli attack hours before nuclear detonations
By DAFNA LINZER Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Pakistan feared an Israeli air strike on its nuclear installations hours before it detonated five nuclear devices last week, Israeli media reported Monday. State-run Israel television said Pakistan's foreign minister informed the United States about Israel's plans last Thursday, hours before it carried out the tests. Pakistan believed that Israeli planes would operate out of bases in India, the report said. The United States told Pakistan that Israel was not planning any such attack, Israel's Channel Two Television said. Israel has relations with India but not Pakistan, the first Islamic nation to go nuclear. Shai Bazak, spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denied an attack was planned. ``These reports are totally baseless,'' he told Israel TV. Israel, an undeclared nuclear power, has warned that rival neighbors India and Pakistan's atomic tests could encourage nearby Iran to follow suit. Israel destroyed an Iraqi nuclear facility in 1981. The Israeli Cabinet discussed the recent tests on the Asian subcontinent on Monday. Netanyahu's media adviser David Bar-Illan said in a statement that Monday's visit by Iran's foreign minister to Pakistan ``strengthens Israel and the international community's calls to make every effort in order to prevent Iran from gaining a nuclear capacity.'' ``The international community needs to act decisively in order to prevent Iranian capabilities,'' he said. According to Israeli officials, Iran is seeking technology to build a bomb and is close to having its own long-range delivery system capable of hitting Israel. In Islamabad, Pakistan, Iranian Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi said Monday that Muslims everywhere welcomed the nuclear tests, but dismissed suggestions that Iran was preparing to follow Pakistan down the nuclear road.

Russian markets close in downward spiral analysis. CHANGES byline.
Eds: AMs. RECASTS with central bank comments on defending ruble, By JOHN IAMS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russian stocks plunged more than 10 percent Monday in a frenzy of selling by Russian banks and a cold shoulder from foreign investors wary of the market's turmoil. The Russian Trading System index closed 10.2 percent lower after late panic selling gripped the market and reassuring comments from government officials failed to calm jittery investors. Monday's close matched the 10-percent fall last Wednesday, when hectic selling caused the stock market to plummet and threatened a run on the national currency, the ruble. The market has fallen 44 percent since the beginning of May, making it the worst performing market in the world, and there are fears of further losses before calm is restored. The Central Bank has intervened to prop up the ruble and tripled a key interest rate to 150 percent to persuade investors to stay in Russia. A top bank official said Monday the interest rate would remain unchanged. ``At the present, there is no need (to change it),'' said Alexander Potyomkin, the bank's first deputy chairman. Potyomkin said the central bank will remain firm in its policy to defend the ruble. ``We will do our best to escape that kind of scenario,'' he told a news conference, referring to the possibility of devaluation. But investors are increasingly coming to believe that only an international aid package will be able to save Russian markets from a devaluation, that could lead to steep price hikes and social unrest. Boris Fyodorov, Russia's new tax chief, said Monday that government has enough cash reserves to protect the ruble, which closed relatively unchanged at 6.18 to the dollar Monday. But Fyodorov acknowledged an additional dlrs 5 billion from the International Monetary Fund would help stabilize the market. Russian leaders have said that the economic crisis was triggered by a combination of forces, including a sharp fall in world prices for gas and oil, the financial crisis in southeast Asia, and social unrest including a recent wave of coal miners' strikes. Deputy Prime Minister Viktor Khristenko said Monday that economic growth predicted for this year probably would not materialize, but was optimistic that the country could cope with the current crisis. ``If the government is able to quickly and effectively eliminate the consequences of the past week, the stability of the real sector of the economy will be preserved,'' he told a news conference. In a move to cut government spending, Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko Monday ordered a 30 percent reduction in Cabinet personnel, the ITAR-Tass news agency said. (pvs/jai/ls)

Denmark's coach presents his squad for the World Cup
By JAN M. OLSEN Associated Press Writer
COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) _ Denmark's coach Bo Johansson mixed veteran players and youthful talent in his 22-man World Cup squad Monday. Although Denmark, the 1992 European champions, played poorly in two recent World Cup warm-up games against Norway and Sweden, Johansson said there was ``nothing to be negative about.'' The side that will play in Group C against France, Saudi Arabia and South Africa, included three safe bets _ brothers Michael and Brian Laudrup, and veteran goalie Peter Schmeichel. Michael Laudrup is the only survivor of Denmark's 1986 World Cup side in Mexico. The 33-year-old will bid farewell to the national team after the World Cup. His younger brother, Brian, was on the team that upset mighty Germany to win the 1992 European Championship in Sweden. One of the world's top keepers, Schmeichel, has been suffering from a minor injury but Johansson was confident that the Manchester United's goalie would be fit in time for the World Cup. Schmeichel ``wasn't 100 percent in shape'' when Sweden beat Denmark 3-0 on May 28, Johansson said. As substitute goalies, Johansson picked Mogens Krogh of the Danish champion team Broendby, and sole newcomer Peter Kjaer of Silkeborg, another Danish team. The Danes have only qualified once before for a World Cup. Denmark surprisingly failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup in the United States and a defensive-minded team flopped in the 1996 European Championship in England. Johansson, a Swede, has 8 wins, 2 draws and 3 defeats since he became Denmark's coach in 1996. He selected experienced defenders like Marc Rieper, Jan Heintze, Thomas Helveg and Jes Hoegh on the team once known as ``Danish Dynamite.'' Striker Ebbe Sand, the Danish league's top scorer with 28 goals, was also selected. His first cap was against Norway on April 22 when Denmark lost 2-0. Other inexperienced players are defender Rene Henriksen who played his first match on the red-and-white team against Scotland in March, and forward Martin Joergensen who has played three times on the Danish side. Johansson who has opted for a 4-4-2 system, said he hadn't decided what system Denmark would play in France, adding he wanted to avoid ``the vulnerability of playing only one system.'' Before heading for France, Denmark plays a friendly against Cameroon on Friday in Copenhagen. The squad: Goalies _ Peter Schmeichel, Mogens Krogh, Peter Kjaer, Defenders _ Jes Hoegh, Marc Rieper, Jacob Laursen, Rene Henriksen, Soeren Colding, Jan Heintze, Michael Schjoenberg, Thomas Helveg, Midfielders _ Allan Nielsen, Per Frandsen, Morten Wieghorst, Stig Toefting, Bjarne Goldbaek, Michael Laudrup, Forwards _ Brian Laudrup, Miklos Molnar, Peter Moeller, Martin Joergensen, Ebbe Sand. THE fact that the Observer newspaper has decided to launch another attack on Malaysia hardly comes as a surprise. Indeed, the only thing surprising about the Observer's recent salvo was that it came so late; after all, the newspaper has been engaged in an all-out campaign against a host of Asian and Muslim countries for some time now. In this respect we need only to remind ourselves of the simple fact that the Observer was one of the newspapers in Britain which saw fit to condemn Muslims and the Muslim world in toto after the bombing of the FBI headquarters in Oklahoma in the United States some years ago. When the facts came to light and it was discovered that the bombing was the work of a group of white racial supremacists, the Observer, like the rest of the Western press, chose to keep quiet about its part in demonising the Muslims of the world. Such is the moral character of this newspaper which claims to be the ``defender of the truth''. Another self-appointed ``defender of the truth'' is Britain's Guardian newspaper, which has of late taken a keen interest in the affairs of Indonesia, Malaysia and the rest of Asean. As always, such ``concern'' comes at the point of a barbed pen which distorts the picture that it tries to draw in the process. The Guardian recently featured a report on the visit to Southeast Asia by Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown. The paper's reporter, who followed slavishly in the footsteps of the Chancellor, noted how Asians seemed to bow before the presence of this British politician as if he were some munificent white god that had descended from on high. But the magical charm of the Chancellor's tour was interrupted only when he set foot on Malaysian soil and was told that Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad was too busy to see him. The Guardian reporter dutifully recorded in a sarcastic tone that the Malaysian PM was not inclined to ``receive this representative of the Evil West''. (The thought that the PM may have had other more important things to do obviously did not occur to the reporter). However this sarcastic thrust was blunted by the Guardian's own incompetence. Having cast Dr Mahathir in an unfavourable light, it tried to juxtapose him against his more ``moderate'' deputy, ``Ibrahim Anwar'' (sic). Even a child in kindergarten would know by now that the Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia's real name is Anwar Ibrahim, and not vice-versa! The so-called ``defenders of truth'', such as the Guardian and Observer, would thus do well by serving as the guardians of grammar and spelling first. How should Malaysia and Malaysians react to this sort of verbiage disguised as reportage? Well, a modicum of intelligence and introspection would come in handy at this point. We need to consider the broader socio-economic and political context within which these attacks are taking place. The Observer, like many other newspapers in Britain, is in a state of crisis. The paper's circulation figures are unpredictable and in the end it is market sentiment which decides what comes on the news and what kind of news will sell. In a country where sensational news items such as the death of Princess Diana and UFOs sell better than stories about how the British government has allowed British companies like Sandlines to sell arms and rent mercenaries abroad, it is hardly surprising that sensational stories about the bizarre and exotic customs of the East tend to go down well with a jaded readership at home. This is reflected in the contents of some of the better newspapers in Britain as well. The Guardian, for example, has significantly cut its number of features from abroad. Once, the paper boasted of having a page devoted solely to African and Third World issues. Today, it features a page devoted to the affairs of the US instead. To make matters worse, papers such as the Guardian and Observer have begun to ``dumb down'' their coverage of foreign affairs to appeal to a broader spectrum of readers who seem to crave stories about tortures, killings, bizarre and outlandish rituals and exotic diets of foreigners. The lurid and sensational reporting that has come from papers such as these are thus merely part and parcel of a broader scenario, where the British press is slowly coming to terms with the painful reality that their halcyon days have long gone by. Resting on their laurels, they pine for the days when British newspapers were worthy of the name and conveniently overlook the fact that, today, even the pages of the Guardian and Observer are used to wrap fish and chips.

BC-France-Watering the Wine
Fine wine fraud; water, sugar, other additives may taint a Margaux
By CHRISTOPHE HUTTEAU Associated Press Writer
BORDEAUX, France (AP) _ A prestigious Bordeaux wine may not be all its label claims. Authorities have discovered water in the Chateau-Giscours, and even some sugar, milk and acid, and taken the case to court, judicial sources and the newspaper Le Monde reported Monday. An investigation shows that not only were water, milk and certain acids added to the wine -- a Margaux that is one of the most noted ``grand cru'' of the Medoc region. But there also was allegedly a mixing of vintages and inferior wines from elsewhere, the judicial sources said. Such trickery is tantamount to treachery in the wine business, strictly controlled to maintain the kind of quality that is synonymous with fine French wines. The judicial sources in Bordeaux, speaking on condition they not be named, said that several officials of the domain, one of the most imposing in the Medoc region, have been placed under investigation, a step short of being charged, for illicit practices. The judicial sources would not identify the suspects. Le Monde, which broke the story in a front-page article, identified those placed under investigation as wine expert Regis Froidefond and Jean-Marie Ferrandez who for four months headed the company marketing the wine. Dutch billionaire businessman Eric Albada-Jeigersma, who has bought part of the domain, was questioned in the investigation, Le Monde reported. The Bordeaux prosecutors office opened its investigation in 1995 after complaints by a government office that oversees competition and fraud complained. Acting on information from a former employee, the office discovered a mixture of vintages and inferior wines, the judicial sources said. Water and sugar were also allegedly added to some vats, the sources said. Le Monde reported that milk and certain acids were likewise detected. None of the additives makes the wine dangerous for the consumer, the sources said, but they could ruin the chateau, disparage the Margaux wines and there was speculation it could even shake up the rising Bordeaux wine prices. THE situation in regional stock markets may be still uncertain and all eyes remain focused on developments in Indonesia but on a global perspective investors and speculators should also be keeping a watchful eye on what's happening on Wall Street. One phenomenon that an investor should always remember when venturing into any stock market is that when almost everybody least expects something to happen, that very thing will take place. The Dow Jones average, which was reaching one high after another some weeks ago, was supposed to continue its record-breaking run and hit the sky by now. However, what has actually happened is that the Dow has pulled back in recent weeks and dropped by 70.25 points to 8,899.95 last Friday -something totally unexpected by optimistic forecasters earlier on. By all accounts, the Dow should continue to shoot up, given the fact that the US economy is doing well and the inflation and economic figures look good. Therefore, the Dow should continue to be good as well, or so goes the reasoning. In contrast to the US economy, the economic and financial situation in Japan, the world's second largest economic power, is really pathetic. The Japanese situation is such that whatever is being done to stimulate its economy and get it out of the financial mess, it is never enough and something more and much better is called for. Given such an unfortunate set of circumstances, it is no wonder that the Tokyo stock market - once even considered on the way to becoming mightier than Wall Street - has been humbled and seems to be going nowhere. Given a choice, it would be a safe assumption to advise investors that they should avoid Tokyo and go for stock markets which are holding up better. However, it has been often suggested that a seemingly sick stock market may provide potentially better opportunities for long-term gain than healthy ones which provide limited profit-making opportunities over the long run. The more sickly stock markets are probably selling at their historical lows and therefore an investor taking the long-term view can expect prices to rise much higher when the stock market moves out of its bottom and begins to take off. A sick market has the potential to get well and when it does become healthier, this will translate into higher prices and capital gains for the investor who is courageous enough to buy stocks when the market was ailing. If a stock market is already healthy with stock prices selling at their historical highs, there isn't much potential for profit for the investor who picks up prices at that high level. This is not to suggest that investors should only scout around for sick companies to buy their stocks because what is being suggested is that if they are global investors, they should not be deterred from going into sick stock markets just because they are unwell. A stock market may be sick but there are individual listed companies which are well managed with good assets and earnings but whose stock prices are pulled down together with that of the bad companies. What the investor should do is to seek out the good apples from the bad ones in an ailing stock market.

FOR decades, agriculture played a dominant role in the Malaysian economy. Rubber, palm oil, cocoa and timber products were the major primary commodities that contributed significantly to the growth of Gross Domestic Product, employment and export earnings. The agriculture sector as a whole contributed more than 50 per cent of export earnings during the 60s and 70s. Agricultural products are subjected to price fluctuations, and the inflexibility of demand and supply make it difficult to plan their development. They are also subjected to tariff and non-tariff barriers that curtail their developments. The huge drop in the international prices of these commodities in the 70s and 80s dealt a severe blow to the once striving agriculture-based Malaysian economy. This led to structural economic reforms in the 80s and beyond and a shift in the economy from dependence on the primary sector to the promotion of export-led manufacturing sector. Guided by the First Industrial Master Plan, 1986-1995 and the Second Industrial Master Plan, 1996-2005, heavy emphasis was given to boosting the manufacturing and services related sectors in Malaysia, with tremendous results. The manufacturing sector is now the engine of Malaysia's economic growth and contributes significantly to export earnings and employment, superseding the contribution of the agriculture sector. The contributions of the agriculture sector to GDP consequently declined to 18.7 per cent in 1990, 13.6 per cent in 1995 and is expected to further decline to 10.5 per cent in 2000. So is its contribution to employment and export earnings. Its contribution to export earning dropped from 26 per cent in 1990 to 18 per cent in 1995 and is expected to drop further to 22.2 per cent in 1990 and 13.1 per cent in 1995. The positive aspects of these declining contributions, however, have been the corresponding increases in agricultural value-added products, labour productivity and land-labour ratio. From a policy point of view, the structural change is a success as it has provided Malaysia the path to faster economic development and growth. More importantly, the change will lead to Malaysia being an industrialised country by the year 2020. The structural economic reforms enabled Malaysia to experience high economic growth of above eight per cent per year for almost a decade, among the most vibrant economies in Asia. Discriminatory policy treatment in favour of the vibrant manufacturing and property sectors at the expense of the agriculture sector, however, has its drawbacks. This is particularly clear during the current economic problem. The declining property market and the slowing down of manufacturing growth and exports brought about by the financial downturn have severely affected overall economic growth. The competitiveness of Malaysian exports is questionable, especially those with high import content of inputs. More surprising is the current account deficit in the balance of payments which, among others, can be attributed to our high bill of food imports, which was in the region of RM9 billion last year. The high bill of food imports, while acceptable in times of prosperous growth, is unacceptable during a slowdown. Questions have arisen as to our capability and capacity of producing our domestic food resources. With abundant land resources and thousands of plant species and a variety of animal husbandary available, the high food import only shows that less attention has been given to produce these food resources in a bigger way. Most alarming is that, not only human food but even animal and fish feed are mostly imported, thus contributing to the high import content of locally produced chicken and farm-bred fish. The current economic problem is in a way a blessing in disguise. The immediate response of both the Federal and State governments to revert to boosting agricultural production is most welcome. Indeed, there are ample opportunities for both the public and private sectors to venture into agricultural development in a big way to boost production, not only to provide food security but also to boost food processing and pharmaceutical manufacturing activities. The economic problem also revealed the need to provide equal treatment to the agriculture sector in our development process, alongside that given to the manufacturing sector. In addition to giving priority for approving land for large-scale agricultural production, some form of fiscal and financial incentives should be put in place. Agro-based research support should be strengthened to cover marketing aspects of agricultural produce such as processing, handling and quality control. Marketing channels should be strengthened through a more business-like public organisation. Infrastructure support, where necessary, should be provided. Efforts should also be made to identify the type of crops with high demand and output value. In addition to rice, fruits and vegetables, attention should be given to growing herbs, spices and ulam in a big way. These plants are not only available locally for large-scale production but also contain medicinal properties that can be used to produce traditional medicine and other pharmaceutical products. Fish production is another area with high economic potential, yet under- exploited. The Department of Fisheries forecast that by the year 2010, fish production will reach 900,000 metric tonnes from inshore fisheries, 600,000 mt from aquaculture and 430,000 mt from deep sea fisheries, with an estimated value of more than RM6 billion. There are vast opportunities for utilising mining ponds and lakes for inland aquaculture. There is also great potential for deep-sea fishing particularly in the South China Sea, which is still under-exploited. What is required is the provision of financial and non-financial incentives to attract private sector investment in the fishing industry. Now is the opportune time to give more attention to the agriculture sector. The current economic problem has taught us a lesson that discriminatory policy treatment in favour of a particular sector (manufacturing) at the expense of another sector (agriculture) does not guarantee sustainable development and growth. Agricultural and manufacturing production should therefore be given equal treatment in our development process. A thorough review of the National Agriculture Policy should be expedited to provide an updated policy in this endeavour. However, we must bear in mind two realities. Firstly, the current economic problem is temporary in nature and the Malaysian economy is expected to rebound in due time and secondly, we have to accept the fact that Malaysia is fast losing her comparative advantage in agricultural production. As such, the only rational justification for increasing domestic agricultural production is to be based on food security consideration rather than a temporary and short-term improvement in competitiveness due to current depreciation of the national currency. Another option is the liberalisation of agricultural trade, particularly of products where Malaysia has no potential comparative advantage.

BANK Negara says it constantly listens to suggestions from the market, but nevertheless prefers banks to stick to the stipulated plan to maintain credit growth at 15 per cent by the end of this year. The credit growth plan was introduced earlier as part of pre-emptive measures to protect soundness of the domestic banking system amid the regional financial crisis. The banking system's rapid moves to tighten credit extensions attracted criticisms from the market, with many complaining about difficulties in obtaining credit facilities to finance their businesses. ``We constantly receive views and comments and do so with an open mind. It is not the central bank's way to dismiss suggestions from the market outrightly,'' Bank Negara Governor Tan Sri Ahmad Mohd Don told newsmen at a briefing on Saturday. His deputy, Datuk Fong Weng Phak, estimated that about RM60 billion should still be available within the banking system in the next eight months, based on the present credit growth plan. The money is there, although potential borrowers must do a bit more to convince their respective bankers before they can have access to the funds, he said. While banks have been criticised for being overly cautious in extending credit facilities, several bankers contacted in recent weeks said they themselves are facing constraints to lend actively. Although the preliminary total pre-tax profit recorded by the domestic banking system stood at a high of RM7.9 billion for 1997, the actual profit is expected to be substantially lower as banking institutions have been required to provide higher provisions to build up loan loss reserves and strengthen their balance sheets. Briefing newsmen, Ahmad Don outlined immediate prospects for the Malaysian economy, one of the determining factors for recovery being that banks continue to lend within the credit plan figures. ``Many banks over-extended themselves during the economic boom period,'' said Bank Negara assistant governor Datuk Abdul Murad Khalid, who was also present at the briefing. Echoing Murad's sentiments was assistant governor Dr Zeti Akhtar Aziz who summarised all the pre-emptive measures instituted in the banking sector within the past year, saying they have brought positive results to shore up banks' fundamentals in facing the economic uncertainty. The Malaysian economy charted its first quarterly decline since the mid- 1980s when it contracted by 1.8 per cent in the first quarter of 1998 on an annual basis compared with a 6.9 per cent expansion in last year's fourth quarter. The banking sector felt impact of the regional financial crisis during the first quarter of this year as both deposits and loan activities recorded declines due to both supply and demand factors. The fall in domestic demand and slowing down of economic activity adversely affected the debt-servicing capability of debtors, resulting in some financial institutions facing a deterioration in their asset quality. ``The banking system is sound. It is under strain, but manageable,'' Ahmad Don said, adding that the central bank will maintain the present monetary policy and interest rates, as inflation figures are showing a rising trend. As at March 31 this year the level of non-performing loans of the banking system stood at 9.1 per cent. He also said that Bank Negara will continue with ways to strengthen the industry further, among others by actively encouraging merger of banks, insurance companies and discount houses.

SOFTWARE Dynamics Sdn Bhd, a company focusing on Cobol programming and solving Year 2000 (Y2K) problems, has announced a new service called the Y2K Factory to provide solutions for the millennium bug. Scheduled to be launched next month, Y2K Factory is aimed at sparing companies the trouble of recruiting extra personnel to deal with the Y2K problem, hence allowing them to concentrate on business more effectively. According to Software Dynamics' business development executive Amran Ariffin, the company uses two main software programs, the SoftFactory/2000 and HourGlass 2000, to address the problem. ``We are the local distributor for both software and these complement each other to provide a complete and comprehensive Y2K solution,'' he said. Besides providing the service, the company also sells SoftFactory/2000 and HourGlass 2000 packages to companies wanting to develop in-house Y2K solutions. SoftFactory/2000 is a toolset and methodology designed to enable information technology (IT) organisations rectify the Y2K problem with a set of intelligent rules specifically optimised for logic-based remedy. Available in three modules - Revolve/2000, SmartFind/2000 and Workbench/2000 - SoftFactory/2000 helps solve the impending Y2K date-change crisis affecting organisations with Cobol-based legacy systems. ``Even though SoftFactory/2000 is based on Cobol, it can also check Fortran, C++ and other basic text-written programs, except RPG,'' said Amran. Revolve/2000 is a tool designed to identify and categorise Y2K code in several languages and the package supports multiple Y2K-conversion methodologies. It also checks the date formats in the program. ``A lot of companies hesitate to buy the Y2K program because they think it is a waste of money to buy solutions solely for solving the Y2K problem,'' Amran said. ``But with Revolve/2000, users can still use it after the turn of the century for activities such as documentation and charting purposes.'' The second module, the SmartFind/2000, is a rule-based analysis tool for identifying lines of Cobol codes that require the remedy to become Y2K-compliant, and it is the core of the SoftFactory/2000 solution. It is optimised for Y2K conversions utilising logic-based ``windowing'' fixes to the century date-change problem. Software Dynamics said the rule-based detection methodology of SmartFind/2000 is considered to be the most effective compared to other methods which only identify date fields and requires no conversion and extensive manual intervention. The windowing solution identifies only dates which require fixing, such as those used in some calculations and comparisons, and leaves the two-digit dates in place, but adds logic to differentiate between centuries. The Workbench/2000 module, meanwhile, provides a complete personal computer (PC)-based testing environment for users' modified code. It gives a straightforward and accurate testing method for the Y2K program conversion. To complete the checking system, the company uses the HourGlass 2000 which the company claims is the only comprehensive date-simulation tool that lets users run specified programs, jobs or sessions, without affecting the others. It provides Y2K-compliance testing for in-house applications, third-party applications and utilities, running non-Y2K- compliant applications on the first day of year 2000, and rerunning old or future months or year-end jobs. However, the HourGlass 2000 is only available for the HP 3000 and 9000, and MVS systems. As the local distributor, Software Dynamics expects to generate RM2 million to RM3 million in sales by the end of this year. ``We believe Y2K Factory will contribute about 80 per cent of the sales while the rest is from pushing the boxes,'' Amran said. The Revolve/2000 module carries a price tag of US$52,500 (RM199,500) whereas cost of the SmartFind/2000 depends on the number of lines of codes used in the program and the Workbench/2000 is priced according to the number of seats.

The strong performance was attributable to a 34 per cent increase in net interest income and 83 per cent in non-interest income, while non-interest expense fell by 10 per cent. Given the encouraging profits recorded for the first quarter, the bank foresee its continuous commitment in the Malaysian banking industry by expanding its business strategy as the opportunity arises, its managing director Huibert Boumeester says. Announcing its quarterly results, ABN said that its total net non-performing loans (NPLs) remain at 0.7 per cent of total loans and advances, while general provisions stood at 1.7 per cent. The bank's total loan loss - covering the ratio of specific and general provision, and interest-in-suspense to total NPLs - stood high at 124 per cent. There was no new specific provision made in the period reviewed as adequate previsions were made in the previous quarter. As at March 31, the bank's risk weighted capital ratio stood at 14.2 per cent while total shareholders' funds grew by 10 per cent during the period under review from the previous RM148.6 million to RM163.7 million. ABN is a wholly-owned subsidiary of ABN AMRO NV and is one of the oldest foreign financial institutions in Malaysia. Its overseas associates, ABN AMRO Bank is one of the major banks involved in the Euro, the single currency in Europe that will be introduced on January 1 1999. The implementations of Euro will radically change the banking system in Europe, whereby banks will have fewer counterparts and will choose those which sell the best products. ``There will be intense competition between the biggest network banks while the smaller ones will either enter into alliances or come to banks such as ABN AMRO to do the processing for them,'' Boumeester said. He said the bank is preparing and investing considerable time and resources on smoothing the way for the introduction of the new currency. ``We hope by January 1 1999, we would be able to offer full banking services for the transition to the Euro as simple as possibele,'' he said. These will range from treasury and cash management facilities through trade and project finance, asset management and the full menu of capital market services.

THE fast pace of today's businesses and the Internet explosion are placing a heavy demand for information on networks. As a result, there is an urgent need for new applications and a centralised enterprise storage framework, according to EMC Computer Systems (South Asia) Pte Ltd's general manager Paul Rath. ``Enterprise storage means consolidated storage that is capable of supporting multiple operating systems and multiple mainframes, Unix and Windows NT servers on a single system,'' Rath said. ``The need for a shared, consolidated repository of business information has never been greater. The real value of enterprise storage is that it stores and retrieves data from all major computing platforms in both the mainframe and open systems environments,'' he added. Enterprise-wide connectivity is regarded as an important element of enterprise storage as it allows information system (IS) managers to consolidate packets of information into data centres for competitive advantage. As a result, IS managers are no longer just managing disparate technologies and data but information which now rests in a centralised location. To address this, EMC Corp, a worldwide provider of enterprise storage devices, is promoting the use of its architectures covering both hardware and software. For hardware, EMC offers Mosaic:2000, while Intelligent Storage Architecture (ISA) is used for the software. ISA is designed to create a computing environment driven by consolidated information from across the enterprise. Built on Mosaic:2000, the EMC hardware architecture is aimed at bringing together the best disk, memory and system software technologies. ``We don't manufacture storage disks, instead we formed alliances with popular database developers, hardware manufacturers and systems integrators to provide best-of-breed solutions,'' Rath told reporters in Kuala Lumpur. ``With EMC solutions, we give organisations a more timely access to information and this will lead to better business decisions. Moreover, a good enterprise storage must be able to provide connectivity, cascadable and information-centric solutions and this is what EMC products address,'' he added. On EMC business performance, EMC Computer Systems (Far East) Ltd's country manager Zulkifli Latiff said more than 1,000 units of EMC storage devices have been installed locally since the middle of last year. EMC claimed to be the world's largest supplier of enterprise storage devices with a 50 per cent share of the mainframe and the open systems markets.

MALAYSIAN Airline System Bhd (MAS) is planning to sell its used aircraft and borrow from a few foreign financial institutions to raise money for its capital investments totalling RM1.81 billion for the current year ending March 31 1999. MAS' treasury manager, Mr Low Chee Teng, said the group is negotiating with a few foreign parties for loans which MAS is hoping to secure and these to be guaranteed by export credit agencies in the respective institutions' countries. Out of the total investment, RM1.54 billion will be used to pay for four aircraft MAS will receive later this year and in 1999, including spare engine payments. ``Since the four aircraft are manufactured in the US and Britain, we are hoping that the export credit agencies of the countries can guarantee the debt acquired,'' Low said. Low, however, declined to name the financial institutions involved. Meanwhile, MAS chairman Tan Sri Tajudin Ramli once again successfully kept the group's much talked about restructuring plans under wraps. In a much eagerly anticipated briefing to the media and analysts last Saturday, Tajudin said details on the restructuring of the national carrier will be revealed this year. Declining to answer questions on the subject, the chairman who seems visibly upset, only said: ``We will come out with the details later.'' Meanwhile, the treasury manager said actual implementation of the restructuring exercise will take longer than a year. He said that MAS is still deliberating on the final structure of the plan. Tajudin also cleared the air over the exercise which he said is not an attempt to satisfy the business interests of specific groups of shareholders in MAS. In a statement signed by Tajudin himself, he said, that shareholders, regardless of the size of their investment, are valued partners in MAS. Hence, no party will be disenfranchised in any manner, Tajudin stressed. Earlier reports had said that Tajudin was planning to sell the company's aircraft to a new company, MAS Capital, which would then lease the aircraft back to MAS. It was also said that the proceeds from the transaction would be used by Tajudin to partly pay off his personal debts. Suffering from a RM225 million pre-tax loss in its last year ended March 31 1998, MAS has suspended flights to Madrid, Macau, Davao, Vientiane and Pusan. It has also deferred taking delivery of 14 aircraft. In addition, MAS has stopped extending the leases of its aircraft, cancelled any option aircraft, modified aircraft orders to save costs, and it has also offered to lease or sell its existing aircraft. Currently, 14 aircraft are being offered for lease or sale by MAS. Datuk Bashir Ahmad, the group's executive vice president, in briefing investment analysts at the same function, mentioned that MAS will now shift its growth emphasis to long-haul services, expecially to North America and Europe. This is as a result of the group's capacity reduction with the selling, leasing and the delivery deferment of aircraft. To concentrate on the long flight market, MAS will reduce the frequency of flights on the Orient road, to countries such as South Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan.

MATSUSHITA Electric Industrial Co Ltd (MEI) of Japan yesterday announced that it has established a new company in Malaysia to specifically handle treasury management of all its 20 subsidiaries in the country. The new company, 100 per cent-owned Panasonic Financial Centre (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd, would start operations on Monday. BC-India-Pakistan, 6th Ld-Writethru,0607
India denies it plans another nuclear test, urges nuclear talks
Eds: UPDATES with bomb blasts in Jammu city. No pickup. AP Photo DEL101-102 By HEMA SHUKLA Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ India on Monday rejected reports it was planning another nuclear test, following its call on all nuclear weapons states to start negotiations for a nuclear weapons accord. Foreign Ministry spokesman K.C. Singh said Pakistani Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan's claims that India was surreptitiously preparing to conduct more tests next month was ``surprising'' _ and wrong. ``India has declared a moratorium on testing, and this has been reiterated by the prime minister himself,'' Singh said. His ministry reiterated India's long-standing call for international talks on reducing nuclear weapons in a statement Sunday. Despite Singh's firm statement that India's tests were over, the country's Atomic Energy Commission Chairman R. Chidambaram was quoted by local news agencies as telling fellow scientists at a forum in Bombay on Monday that small tests might be carried out for research purposes _ but ``only if necessary.'' He did not elaborate. India escalated the longtime Indo-Pakistan rivalry to the nuclear level with five tests May 11-13. In response, Pakistan claimed to have detonated six nuclear devices last week. Khan said he had credible information that India was ``already in the process of preparing a new test site ... to blast somewhere in the first or second week in July.'' Pakistan has not said whether it would test again. U.S. intelligence sources said they had detected no signs that either Pakistan or India was readying new tests. The international community has pressured India and Pakistan to sign a test ban treaty and the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Pakistan and India have fought three wars since they were carved from the same British colony 50 years ago. They are divided by religion _ Pakistan is officially Muslim and India is predominately Hindu _ and a simmering territorial dispute over the Himalayan region of Kashmir, which is divided between them and claimed by both countries. A top Iranian envoy arrived Monday in Pakistan and praised its government for its nuclear tests. ``From all over the world, Muslims are happy that Pakistan has this capability,'' Iranian Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi told reporters. Kharrazi dismissed suggestions that Iran was preparing to follow Pakistan down the nuclear road. ``We don't have any nuclear weapons program . . . what we have is for peaceful purposes,'' and all Iran's nuclear facilities are open to international inspectors, he said. Violence broke out briefly Monday in Srinagar, capital of Indian-held Kashmir, after 100 people who oppose Indian rule distributed sweets in the streets _ a traditional way of celebrating _ and carried banners congratulating Pakistan on its nuclear tests. Some threw stones at police, who responded by beating protesters. In Jammu, the nearby winter capital, a small bomb went off in a crowded market, killing a small child and injuring nine others, police said. Mobs then burned down a dozen police jeeps and some private cars, injuring 10 policemen, officials said. The explosion occurred as campaigning during a local election concluded Monday. No one claimed responsibility for the blast. Indian accuses Pakistan of arming and training several groups fighting either for Kashmir's independence or its union with Pakistan. Pakistan says it lends them only moral support.

Sinn Fein stands up Prince Charles _ saving some British blushes plans in grafs 9-13, edits
Eds: UPDATES with Mowlam defending invitation, detailing government
BELFAST, Northern Ireland (AP) _ In a double-edged snub, leaders of the IRA-allied Sinn Fein party have turned down an invitation to a royal garden party because Prince Charles will be there. The announcement saved the host, Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary Mo Mowlam, from some awkward maneuvering, though she defended the invitation on Monday. Now, she won't have to worry about keeping the Sinn Fein leaders away from Charles _ whose much-loved great-uncle Lord Mountbatten was assassinated by the Irish Republican Army in 1979 _ when guests mingle Wednesday in the grounds of her Hillsborough Castle residence. Sinn Fein said that leaders Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness will boycott the party because Charles holds the ceremonial position of colonel-in-chief of the Parachute Regiment whose members were involved in the so-called Bloody Sunday killings in 1972. Thirteen Catholic marchers were shot dead in the British army's worst shooting in this province. After a long campaign by relatives of the victims, British Prime Minister Tony Blair this year authorized a new investigation into Bloody Sunday, which is being carried out by an international panel of judges. Leaders of pro-British Protestant parties accused Mowlam of blundering and insensitivity by inviting Sinn Fein to the party, being held to mark the 50th anniversary of the state-funded National Health Service in Northern Ireland. Before Sinn Fein said it wouldn't be going, Mowlam promised to make sure Charles didn't meet Adams and McGuinness, who hold two of the 18 Northern Ireland seats in the 659-member British House of Commons. Charles' office made no comment. ``I think we've indeed been fortunate that, for wrong and inexcusable reasons, Mr. Adams and Mr. McGuinness have declined the Charles invitation,'' Conservative lawmaker Andrew Mackay said in the House of Commons in London. Mowlam responded that Sinn Fein was a party to Northern Ireland's agreement on a new assembly, and that it was normal to invite all political parties to such events. ``We can't expect people to participate in the assembly together and then say we judge for ourselves different standards,'' Mowlam told the House of Commons. Mowlam told lawmakers that both the British and Irish Governments planned ``very soon'' to introduce bills establishing decommissioning schemes to encourage paramilitary groups to relinquish their weaponry, under the terms of Northern Ireland's April peace accord. ``There will then be no practical barrier to a start to decommissioning,'' Mowlam said. Mowlam said the British government will also bring in bills to set up Northern Ireland's new assembly and the planned ministerial council that will have members from both Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. Prime Minister Tony Blair is expected to fly to Northern Ireland to meet with the province's political leaders Tuesday in talks that will focus on the legislation. (mj-kg-rs)

British premier says violence in Northern Ireland predictable

MADRID, Spain (AP) _ British Prime Minister Tony Blair described the weekend's violence between Protestant marchers and Catholic protesters in Northern Ireland as ``not wholly surprising if regrettable,'' at the end of a flying visit to Madrid on Monday. Blair said that the violence, the worst since the Northern Irish peace agreement was reached on April 10, was instigated by people who ``belong to the past.'' ``The result of the referendum (in favor of the peace accord) showed that the overwhelming majority of people want to conduct debate by democratic and nonviolent means'' he added. The Labor Party prime minister made his comments during a joint press conference with his Spanish counterpart Jose Maria Aznar, of the center-right Popular Party. Blair was due in Dublin later Monday in this latest stage of a round-Europe tour to prepare for the Cardiff summit later this month that will wind up the British term in the rotating presidency of the European Union. The Spanish and British prime ministers also confirmed plans to hold annual bilateral summits. Blair said his ``excellent'' relationship with Aznar, despite their origins ``at opposite ends of the political spectrum,'' was due to the dwindling importance of the ideological divide between left and right as well as their relative youth. He stressed a meeting of minds ``on the principles of how we make our people more employable,'' underlining the need for competitiveness and adaptability of the workforce. (jt)

BC-Sports-Field Hockey-World Cup, 4th Ld-Writethru
Netherlands downs Spain 3-2 to take third World Cup
Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes. Will stand. AP Photos By MANDY MANN Associated Press Writer
UTRECHT, Netherlands (AP) _ Teun de Nooijer scored a golden goal two minutes from an imminent penalty shootout to secure the men's field hockey World Cup for Olympic champion Netherlands in sudden-death overtime Monday. Cheered by thousands of frenzied home fans, De Noojier's goal in the 13th minute of extra time helped the Netherlands beat Spain 3-2 to win the World Cup for the third time in the tournament's 27-year history. Spain, losing finalist in the inaugural 1971 World Cup, was again left holding the runner-up trophy on its second trip into the final. It was the second time in two years that Holland shattered the Spanish men's hopes of winning their first major title. The Netherlands beat Spain 3-1 in the title clash at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. Dutch coach Roelant Oltmans said he loved golden goals, even more so after winning the title with a rasping shot from De Nooijer. ``I love the golden goal. It's a great rule,'' he said after the victory. Spain showed its resolve to turn the tables this time by closely marking the Dutch raiders and surging into the lead against the run of play in the 18th minute through a flash strike by left winger Javier Arnau. The Spanish defense was under pressure from the Dutch raiders when a counter attack on the first Netherlands penalty corner saw Victor Pujol relay Juan Escarre's long pass to Arnau, who scored with a stinging angular shot past goalkeeper Ronald Jansen. Spain suffered a big blow in the 21st minute when its center-forward Escarre limped out of the field with a pulled hamstring, but its goalkeeper Jufresa played a brilliant game to thwart a series of raids on the citadel. Jufresa twice came between Dutch strikers and the Spain goal as he padded away stinging shots from Jeroen Delmee and Jaap Derk Buma. Marking the Netherlands' raiders exceptionally well, Spain seemed in control of the game when a penalty corner conversion by Victor Pujol increased the lead in the 54th minute by deflecting Arnau's shot past the bewildered goalkeeper. Dutch captain Stephan Veen brought his team back into the game with a 54th minute strike after dribbling into the scoring zone past two defenders on the right flank and shooting into the far corner of the goal. Going all out into the attack, Netherlands forced a series of penalty corners. But the Spanish defense held its ground until drag flick specialist Bram Lomans scooped the ball into the cage in the 61st minute to make the equalizer and take the game into extra time. De Nooijer slammed a penalty corner rebound into the goal to set of celebrations among the boisterous 15,000 capacity crowd after goalkeeper Jufresa had blocked the shot from Lomans with just two minutes of extra time remaining. Spanish coach Toni Forrelat said his players gave away easy penalty corners towards the end. ``The better team won but we had a chance to score our third goal, which would have finished the Netherlands,'' he said. ``It was great to try and beat the Dutch in Netherlands but we ran out of oxygen in extra time and were very tired. ``My team had not practiced strokes before or during the tournament so we were not playing for penalties.'' Roelants, the Dutch coach, said the goal from Veen was the turning point for Netherlands. ``I though it was all over when we went down 2-0,'' he said. ``The goal from Veen was very important and so was the crowd support which lifted us.'' MALAYSIA is pushing ahead with plans under a national blueprint launched late last year to develop its aerospace industry, despite the economic weather now. Nearly half a year after it announced the establishment of the Malaysian Aerospace Council, the Malaysian Industry-Government Group for High Technology (Might) last weekend disclosed to Business Times the proposed structure of the country's aerospace industry, as contained in the Blueprint for the Aerospace Industry in Malaysia. The setting up of the council was seen as a first step towards implementing the 45-point blueprint, which was launched by Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad last year, but little else of the document or the council has been reported since. Might said members to sit on the council, which Dr Mahathir will chair, are in the process of being identified. According to the blueprint, the council will be aided by the a National Aerospace Coordinating Body. The Department of Civil Aviation (DCA) will take on added tasks and will be known as the Malaysian Aviation Authority. The establishment of the council, the coordinating body and the authority as an integral part of the national aerospace industry structure comes under the Framework for Aerospace Industry in Malaysia, which is one of the 45 recommendations contained in the blueprint. ``The council will further the development of the aerospace industry by making key decisions in the areas of priorities and strategies,'' said the blueprint. Might will serve as the secretariat of the council to ensure a private sector-led consultative platform. It will also manage the National Aerospace Coordinating Body, which will act as a reference point for the various aerospace initiatives, activities and investments. The coordinating body will consolidate the current initiatives in the aerospace sector and further spearhead Malaysia's involvement in the industry. Its main functions will be to provide a reference point for the management of offset programmes, act as an intermediate for local and foreign interests in the aerospace industry, establish a detailed inventory of local aerospace players and regulate the key players. Under the proposed structure, five major groups of civil and military operators - Malaysia Airlines, Malaysia Airports Bhd, Defence/Security Forces, general aviation companies, and other companies - will play a major role in the industry. There will also be an aerospace intelligence unit ``parked'' under the National Aerospace Coordinating Body, which will monitor critical and strategic international developments in aerospace and aviation. At the same time, the blueprint said the proposed Malaysia Aviation Authority - modelled along the lines of the Civil Aviation Authority in the UK - will take over the role of the DCA. The Malaysia Aviation Authority will ensure adequate regulatory and strategic support for the development of the local aerospace industry. It would be an autonomous body, managed by a board comprising members from the industry and government. ``The Malaysia Aviation Authority will not only regulate but lead and support the changing demands of the aerospace industry instead of only fulfilling its traditional function of serving the aviation industry,'' the blueprint said. Might said Malaysia possesses the basic ingredients for achieving a competitive advantage in the aerospace industry but it needs to ``urgently restructure and enhance its competencies to excel in the aerospace industry.''

INDONESIAN President Habibie has been in office for slightly more than a week and he seems to have the situation under control. Aside from the small groups, opposition seeking reforms, poll date and other minor problems, life in Indonesia is back to normal. The fact that large numbers of Indonesians, led by ethnic Chinese have returned bear witness that life is slowly returning to normal. The long orderly queue to withdraw money from the biggest private bank is a contrast to the rioting mob prior to the stepping down of President Suharto. Habibie seems to have appeased the anger of the students and have gained the support of the armed forces. This will go a long way to help him get down to resolving the economic problems now facing Indonesia. Stability in Indonesia will also bring stability to its neighbours. The treasury announced early last week of the possibility of a surplus in its current account this year. Critics have come out to say that this has been achieved through the drastic cut back in the importation of goods and not through the more positive action of more exports. We feel that this is uncalled for, as the whole world knows that we are experiencing an economic slowdown. Common sense tells us that we should cut down on unnecessary import items, which are not productive. The Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange was traded easier for the full five days of trading last week. Although the local bourse did make an attempt to rally on Thursday and Friday, it was put down by concern in the weak ringgit and warning that our economy would move into recession if banks continue to be extra strict in their lending policy. Fears that the Hong Kong economy may slip into recession, the weak yen and high interest rates all added to the woes of a market that was already weak. The Dow falling to below its 9,000 point level is another factor that contributed to the overall weak market. BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open, 5th Ld-Writethru
Safin ends surprising run with loss to Pioline
Eds: UPDATES with Pioline defeating Safin; TRIMS. By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Marat Safin, the Russian qualifier who made a stunning run to the fourth round of the French Open, lost a tough five-setter Monday to Cedric Pioline of France, 7-5, 4-6, 6-7 (5-7), 6-4, 6-4. The crowd chanted wildly for Pioline throughout the match, but by the end, they were chanting as well for Safin, the world's 116th-ranked player who beat Agassi and defending champ Gustavo Kuerten here. At only 18, Safin is a decade younger than Pioline, who was a runner-up at last year's Wimbledon. Pioline will next meet Hicham Arazi of Morocco, who also advanced Monday. The American men may have bombed out at this year's French Open, but the women are doing just fine. With Venus Williams, Lindsay Davenport and Monica Seles all advancing Sunday, more U.S. women have reached the quarterfinals than in any French Open since 1986. They were almost joined by the other Williams sister, Serena. But she folded in the second set of a contentious match against Aranxta Sanchez Vicario after coming within two points of victory. ``I'm only 16, my first Roland Garros,'' Serena said after the match. ``Everything is a learning experience for me.'' That may be the one thing Sanchez Vicario agreed with. ``I taught her a lesson,'' the fourth-seeded Spaniard said angrily after the match. It was a lesson that featured glares across the net, an unusual dress change by the Spaniard, and a slam by Williams that nearly beheaded her opponent. Williams accused Sanchez Vicario of changing from a black outfit to a white one midway through the second set as a strategic move. Sanchez Vicario, for her part, was upset at Williams' attitude after a controversial point in the first set. ``I just think she doesn't have respect. She cannot go in with that attitude,'' said Sanchez Vicario. ``You know, I'm glad I beat her.'' So Serena will have to watch her sister in the quarters, and it should be one of the most intriguing matches of the tournament. Venus Williams will play top-seeded Martina Hingis, another match in a rivalry quickly becoming one of the best in women's sports. The older Williams advanced Sunday with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Henrieta Nagyova of Slovakia in which she slammed seven aces _ two at 116 mph. Hingis was a 6-1, 6-2 winner over Anna Smashnova of Israel in a match between former French Open junior champions. Venus Williams, the No. 8 seed, has lost just 13 games in her four matches at the French Open. Hingis has lost 14 games. Hingis holds a 5-2 record against Williams, but they are 2-2 this year. Sanchez Vicario will face Patty Schnyder in the quarterfinals. No. 2 Davenport and No. 6 Seles also advanced to the quarters. Davenport will face defending champion Iva Majoli, the 10th seed, who ousted No. 7 Conchita Martinez 7-6 (7-1), 6-7 (3-7), 6-3 in a match completed Monday. Majoli and Martinez were tied at a set apiece when darkness halted play Sunday night. Martinez jumped out to a quick 3-1 lead in the third set, then lost the last five games. Seles will face No. 3 Jana Novotna, who defeated No. 13 Anna Kournikova 7-6 (7-2), 3-6, 6-3 in another match halted Sunday night. The match was stopped with Novotna leading 4-2 in the final set. It took Novotna just 12 minutes to finish off the match Monday. Play was halted Sunday night at Novotna's request, which left Kournikova in tears because she had made the same request a game earlier, but was denied. According to international tennis rules, a match can be halted due to darkness only on an even-number game in a set. ``It was very difficult for me to play the match over two days,'' Kournikova said. ``It was a new experience for me.'' Seles, a three-time champion who never has lost before the quarterfinals in Paris, won 6-1, 6-4 over Chanda Rubin.

IPOH, Sun. - Cuepacs has received the green light from the Public Service Department to conduct a random survey on the New Remuneration System for civil servants to gauge its effectiveness and acceptance. The NRS, in its sixth year of implementation, has been the subject of many complaints from civil servants. Cuepacs secretary-general S. Siva Subramaniam said today: ``Questionnaires would be distributed to members of affiliated bodies in a month.'' He said the survey was expected to be completed in one month and its findings submitted to the PSD by the end of August. Siva Subramaniam said Cuepacs hoped the survey could help improve weaknesses in the NRS. ``We found the matrix system not properly implemented but we also have civil servants who approve of the system. That is why we need to conduct a survey on the NRS,'' he said after attending the opening of the Perak Cuepacs delegates' meeting. Under the NRS, every employee has to be assessed annually, first by his immediate superior and then by the head of his department on his performance and points are given for each aspect of the assessment. The NRS is designed to get the best out of government servants by rewarding them with salary increases based on performance. The performance of civil servants is then classified into one of four categories -unsatisfactory, satisfactory, very good and excellent performance. The unsatisfactory performer gets no salary increase for that year; the satisfactory performer, a salary increase on the same level; the very good performer, a salary increase of 1 1/2 increment and moved to the next level, and the excellent performer, a double increment and moved to the next level.

BC-Sports-Field Hockey-World Cup, 1st Ld-Writethru,0583
Netherlands downs Spain 3-2 to take third World Cup
Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes. Will stand. AP Photos By MANDY MANN Associated Press Writer
UTRECHT, Netherlands (AP) _ Teun de Nooijer scored a golden goal two minutes from an imminent penalty shootout to secure the men's field hockey World Cup for Olympic champion Netherlands in sudden-death overtime Monday. Cheered by thousands of frenzied home fans, De Noojier's goal in the 13th minute of extra time helped the Netherlands beat Spain 3-2 to win the World Cup for the third time in the tournament's 27-year history. Spain, losing finalist in the inaugural 1971 World Cup, was again left holding the runner-up trophy on its second trip to the final. It was the second time in two years that Holland shattered the Spanish men's hopes of winning their first major title. The Netherlands beat Spain 3-1 for the gold medal at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. Spain showed its resolve to turn the tables this time by closely marking the Dutch raiders and surging into the lead against the run of play in the 18th minute through a flash strike by left winger Javier Arnau. The Spanish defense was under pressure from the Dutch raiders when a counter attack on the first Netherlands penalty corner saw Victor Pujol relay Juan Escarre's long pass to Arnau, who scored with a stinging angular shot past goalkeeper Ronald Jansen. Spain suffered a big blow in the 21st minute when its center-forward Escarre limped out of the field with a pulled hamstring, but its goalkeeper Jufresa played a brilliant game to thwart a series of raids on the citadel. Jufresa twice came between Dutch strikers and the Spain goal as he padded away stinging shots from Jeroen Delmee and Jaap Derk Buma. Marking the Netherlands' raiders exceptionally well, Spain seemed in control of the game when a penalty corner conversion by Victor Pujol increased the lead in the 54th minute by deflecting Arnau's shot past the bewildered goalkeeper. Dutch captain Stephan Veen brought his team back into the game with a 54th minute strike after dribbling into the scoring zone past two defenders on the right flank and shooting into the far corner of the goal. Going all out into the attack, Netherlands forced a series of penalty corners. But the Spanish defense held its ground until drag flick specialist Bram Lomans scooped the ball into the cage in the 61st minute to make the equalizer and take the game into extra time. De Nooijer slammed a penalty corner rebound into the goal to set off celebrations among the boisterous 15,000 capacity crowd after goalkeeper Jufresa had blocked the shot from Lomans with just two minutes of extra time remaining. Spanish coach Toni Forrelat said his players gave away easy penalty corners towards the end. ``The better team won but we had a chance to score our third goal, which would have finished the Netherlands,'' he said. ``It was great to try and beat the Dutch in Netherlands but we ran out of oxygen in extra time and were very tired. ``My team had not practiced strokes before or during the tournament so we were not playing for penalties.'' Roelants, the Dutch coach, said the goal from Veen was the turning point for Netherlands. ``I though it was all over when we went down 2-0,'' he said. ``The goal from Veen was very important and so was the crowd support which lifted us.''
