BC-Air France-Strike, 6th Ld
Anger, embarrassment as strike begins before World Cup Quotes from Air France president
Eds: UPDATES with meeting between two sides planned for Tuesday; AP Photos PAR101-109 By CHRISTOPHER BURNS Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ In normal times, an Air France strike would merely cause havoc. But the walkout by the carrier's pilots Monday was worse: a deep embarrassment for a country preparing to host in just nine days the world's biggest sporting event, the World Cup. Despite pressure from leftist government ministers, most of the state-run carrier's 3,200 pilots stayed out of their cockpits to protest 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. They are threatening to stay out for two weeks or more. That's well into the World Cup, which begins June 10 and lasts a month. On just the first day Monday, 100,000 passengers were sent scrambling. And it could be only the beginning: French train workers were planning to strike at the end of the week. Desperate travelers lined ticket counters at Paris airports Monday, while the Air France planes they were supposed to take, many colorfully painted with soccer players for the championship, sat idle. Departure screens offered a bleak sight: they alternately flashed ``annule'' and ``canceled'' in bright red. After a day of strikes, Air France announced a meeting with the pilots' union on Tuesday afternoon -- the first since failed 11th hour talks last Thursday. ``Finally, it seems like a real wish for dialogue,'' said the spokesman for the pilots union, Christian Paris. ``I hope, I believe, these negotiations will bring us a solution to this conflict,'' Air France President Jean-Cyril Spinetta said on French television Monday night. But gave no hint the company was ready to withdraw a controversial plan to cut pilots' salaries in exchange for shares in Air France. An ``economic effort'' must be made by all ``if Air France wants to become one of the very big world airlines,'' Spinetta said. Nicolas Minvelle, 8th graf, 5th Ld (eg)

THE local stock market continued with its downward trend last week, a situation that is most likely to persist well into this week's trade, according to analysts. With no positive local and foreign developments that could spur the market, stocks were traded mostly lower throughout the week. As one analyst put it aptly: ``No matter where you turn, there were worries everywhere.'' Leading the worries is the anticipated low corporate earnings to be announced this week. Last Friday, national carrier Malaysian Airline System Bhd announced a pre-tax loss of RM225.38 million for the financial year ended March 31 1998. Then, there are the growing concerns over the country's state of economy. Malaysia's gross domestic product figure for the first quarter of this year is expected to be announced and already analysts have given their lower-than-expected forecasts. Adding to the weak sentiment last week was the statement made by Tun Daim Zainuddin that Malaysia must avoid stagflation - slow growth with high interest rates. Daim has said last Wednesday that if Malaysian banks continue to be unnecessarily strict in their lending, stagnant growth can be expected. On the foreign front, taking the cue from the sharp fall of the Dow Jones last Wednesday and coupled with continued concerns over the region's economies, share prices across the region fell hard. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index was the hardest hit as it nosedived 5.3 per cent or 498.78 points to below the psychological level at 8,983.43 on economic jitters. It was reported that Hong Kong chief executive Tung Chee-hwa said the territory might post negative growth as the economy was in a major adjustment. Besides worries that Hong Kong might go into recession, the sluggish Japan's economy and the yen depreciation against the US dollar contributed to the lethargic sentiment over the local bourse. The yen depreciation, said anaylsts could spark US investors to dump Japanese and other international stocks, which in turn would affect all Asian markets. Meanwhile, the political uncertainty surrounding Indonesia is far from over and this will further dampen sentiment across the region. Back at home, sellers, led by foreign funds swarmed the local bourse, selling down most blue-chip stocks such as Maybank, Telekom, Tenaga Nasional and Sime Darby. The week began last Monday with the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange Composite Index (KLCI) finishing 6.68 points lower to close at 570.55. The next day, it fell again by 9.27 points to 561.28. On Wednesday, as concerns on the economy grew, investors dumped heavyweight stocks, dragging the KLCI 9 points down to close at 552.28. Last Thursday saw a mild technical rebound in the early parts of the day but was later absorbed by profit-taking with the KLCI shedding 7.54 points to close at 544.74. Finally on Friday, selling pressure continued prompting the KLCI to close 6.5 points lower to 538.24. Overall, the KLCI lost about 38.99 points or 6.76 per cent from the previous Friday's closing of 577.23, while the Emas Index shed 8.41 points or 5.8 per cent to 136.51. In terms of volume turnover, last week saw a total of some 499.270 million shares traded valued at RM1.068 billion compared to 754.54 million shares worth RM1.550 billion the week before. Main board turnover was 445.993 million shares valued at RM993.515 million while second board saw a total of 44.195 million shares dealt valued at RM69.517 million. Off market turnover saw some 29.302 million shares done worth RM102.420 million compared to 74.759 million shares valued at RM161.183 million shares dealt the week before. Making its debut on the main board last week was Mieco Chipboard Bhd which was not spared from last week's bearish sentiment when it debuted at RM1.20 over its over price of RM1.50. The stock of the particleboard maker ended the day one sen lower at RM1.49 with about 1.2 million shares traded.

FORMER Selangor Menteri Besar Tan Sri Muhammad Muhammad Taib was acquitted yesterday on two charges of falsely declaring the money he took into Australia in December 1996 and failing to declare more than A$1.2 million (RM2.9 million) when he left the country. District Court Judge Eric Pratt freed Muhammad after the 12-man jury, which deliberated for almost five hours, returned a unanimous verdict of not guilty. Pratt said he would not entertain any reference on law by the prosecution when Crown Counsel Cate Holmes said she might make a reference later. ``You can do so before another judge,'' Pratt said, referring to his earlier ruling on mens rea (guilty mind) which the prosecution had to establish. When court was adjourned, Muhammad said ``syukur alhamdullilah'' (thank God), rushed out of the dock, hugged his wife Puan Sri Asbi Rohani Hasnan, his brothers and his counsel. More than 20 of his supporters in the public gallery above the court room, hurried down to meet him. There were sounds of relief and cries of joy when the head juror announced the verdict. With the acquittal, the money involved would be returned to Muhammad. Counsel Tim Robertson said the defence received a letter from the prosecution in the morning stating that the money would be released before the verdict since it was not tainted. Muhammad, 52, who resigned as Menteri Besar in April last year, was charged with two counts of falsely declaring the amount of money he was taking into Australia on Dec 16, 1996 and failing to declare more than A$1.2 million when he left the country on Dec 22, 1996. The charges were under the Australian Financial Transactions Report Act 1988. Under the Act, all transfer of any currency into or out of Australia in excess of A$5,000 (the limit was raised to A$10,000 last June) must be declared to the Australian Customs. Earlier, in his summing up, Pratt outlined the salient points in the defence and prosecution's evidence, and reminded the jury to return a unanimous verdict, one way or the other. (A unanimous verdict is required for federal offences such as those faced by Muhammad.) Muhammad, a Malaysian, should be judged in the light of his cultural background, the judge said, referring to Malaysians' preference to deal in cash. Pratt said there was no dispute that most of the elements of the charges were proved, but what was in dispute was Muhammad's intention. The judge said the jury should ascertain whether Muhammad had a guilty mind (mens rea) when he failed to declare the money. (The issue of mens rea was raised by the defence and Pratt had ruled that it had to be established before Muhammad could be guilty of the offences.) Pratt said it was rather unfair for the police not to show Muhammad the declaration form which he filled up on Dec 16, 1996. It would have been better if the form was shown to him during the interview so that he could explain himself, the judge said, adding that Muhammad was rather surprised when told that he had only declared A$9,793.

BC-UN-Kosovo,0423
Rugova calls for greater UN role, independence for Kosovo
By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ The leader of the self-declared government of the Kosovo Albanians sought U.N. support Monday for an international civilian administration for the troubled province as a first step toward independence from Serbia. Dr. Ibrahim Rugova met Monday with Secretary-General Kofi Annan, one day after the United Nations recorded a record number of people fleeing from Kosovo across the Albanian border to escape fighting which erupted in the Serb-ruled province over the weekend. U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard said 1,300 people arrived at the Albanian border town of Tropoja on Sunday, the largest number in a single day. Eckhard said an undetermined number of others were believed trapped by the fighting and unable to cross the border. ``The independence of Kosovo is the best solution,'' Rugova said after meeting Annan. Rugova said independence for Kosovo, which has a 90 percent majority Albanian population, would help stabilize the Balkans, ``even Serbia, although at this stage they think in a different way.'' Serbia rejects independence, considering Kosovo the cradle of Serb culture. The United States and other major countries also oppose independence but have called for self-rule for the Kosovo Albanians within Serbian borders. But Rugova suggested ``some kind of international civilian administration, or a protectorate, as an interim measure'' leading to full independence. In the meantime, he called for an end to Serb military and police operations against Albanian separatists who have been fighting for independence for the Albanian-majority region, which is now a province of Serbia. Serbia, together with Montenegro, forms Yugoslavia. Rugova met in Washington last week with President Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright to discuss the crisis in Kosovo. Rugova applauded U.S. mediation to promote a dialogue between the Kosovo Albanians and President Slobodan Milosevic. Milosevic revoked Kosovo's autonomy in 1989. ``In order for the negotiations to be successful, it is critical that police and military operations stop,'' Rugova said. ``Serb police and military actions have been continuing, resulting in many people killed.'' He said he asked Annan for ``more support for Kosovo'' and unspecified ``preventive measures'' to prevent further deterioration and ``massacres and massive ethnic cleansing.''

MALAYSIA is grateful to Britain for the assistance it has rendered to Malaysian students whose education has been affected by the shortage of funds following the country's economic problems. Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim expressed his appreciation to Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown during a breakfast meeting yesterday. Anwar, who is Finance Minister, said Malaysia appreciated the initiative taken by the British Government to look into the funding problems of its students so that they may continue their studies in the United Kingdom. It is learnt that the British Government, through its Foreign and Commonwealth Office, has set up a fund to assist needy Asian students unable to continue their studies in the UK because of the region's economic situation. The students requiring assistance are mainly from Indonesia, Korea, Thailand and Malaysia. The financing for the fund comes from the British Government, the British Council, several universities and private companies in Britain which have interests in the affected Asian countries. More details on the fund are expected to be announced next week. Later, speaking to Malaysian journalists at Malaysia Hall after addressing Malaysian students on the country's economic situation, Anwar, who was on a two-day working visit to London, expressed confidence that Malaysia could achieve a 2.5 per cent economic growth figure for this year. He said he would announce the country's economic growth figures for the first quarter of the year by next weekend. ``Although the first two months were really drastic and will reflect adversely on the growth, the March and April figures seem to be reassuring as there is more positive growth and lending by the commercial banks.'' Anwar also said Malaysia was prepared to liberalise its economic policy but at its own pace and not on the terms dictated by others. ``We should do it gradually and decide the pace and extent of liberalisation and ensure we have our indigenous capacity.'' He said although Malaysia did not have any major debts and, unlike some of its neighbours, could still survive the economic crisis without depending on the International Monetary Fund, it should learn from the experience of other countries where corruption existed. ``It is a big crisis which has hit all countries, including Russia. ``We must therefore resolve to be a united force to deal with the problem. ``We must resolve to fight corruption because it is a cancer that can destroy us.'' He urged the people to be prepared for change and accept reforms. ``We do not deny that there is a problem but our fundamentals are still strong. We need to learn from the experience of others. Our propensity to change for the better is necessary. ``I am confident that our economy will recover soon and we will come back even stronger because I believe in the resilience of the people. ``There is creative destruction and from the ashes of the past, we will build a new resilience for the future.'' Speaking to the students earlier, Anwar said there was no necessity for a shadow Cabinet in Malaysia as the Opposition was free to express their ideas. He said although ideas by the British Government are bandied about with the Opposition's shadow Cabinet over the media, it need not necessarily be emulated by Malaysia. ``The role of the Opposition in the West should not be considered ideal for us.'' Anwar agreed on the need for transparency through the media but cautioned against sensationalising issues which could cause tension among the people. On the prospects of more funding for students involved in research and development, he said the Government was committed to promoting RD and had allocated about RM400 million for the purpose through the Intensification of Research on Priority Areas Scheme. He said local universities such as Universiti Tenaga Nasional and Universiti Petronas had been asked to provide the necessary expertise and research centres.

KOTA BARU, Sun. - The Syariah Appeals Court today dismissed the appointment of Datuk Shukri Mohamed as prosecutor on behalf of the Kelantan Religious and Malay Customs Council (MAIK) in a libel case involving Pengkalan Chepa MP Mohd Amar Abdullah. The ruling was on the grounds the appointment had not been made according to procedure. The court, presided by three judges - Datuk Professor Mahmood Zuhdi Abdul Majid, former Lord President Tun Mohamed Salleh Abas and Datuk Nik Hashim Nik Abdul Rahman - ruled that Shukri's appointment could not be made under section 169(1) of the Kelantan Syariah Criminal Procedure Enactment as was done by Syariah deputy public prosecutor Abu Bakar Abdullah Kutty. Mahmood Zuhdi, who led the panel of judges, said this was because the provision in the section stated that a hearing before the Kadi High Court should be conducted by a prosecutor or a Syariah lawyer who had been given written permission by the prosecutor to do so. ``In this case, Shukri is not a Syariah lawyer.'' However, he said Abu Bakar could submit a fresh application to the Kadi High Court to appoint Shukri as the prosecutor. He also said that there was no need for the Kadi High Court to get approval from the State Government to do so. Section 170 states that written permission from the court is required for a lawyer to conduct prosecution on behalf of the State Government. The ruling was made following Mohd Amar's request, made through his lawyer, Takiyuddin Hassan for a revision on Shukri's appointment. Shukri had, on March 15, received sanction from Abu Bakar to act as prosecutor in the case. The sanction was made under Section 169 of the Kelantan Syariah Criminal Enactment Procedure. Takiyuddin, in his submission today, questioned the legality of the procedure in Shukri's appointment saying that Shukri's appointment to act as prosecutor in the case could not be made under Section 169. He also cited Section 167 which stated that the power to prosecute was only bestowed on the Syariah prosecutor. Mohd Amar, 34, who is Kelantan Pas Youth vice-chief, had pleaded not guilty in the Chief Kadi's Court in April last year with insulting MAIK over a Hari Raya Aidil Fitri sermon in his ceramah at Jalan Dusun Raja at 10.15pm on March 8, 1997. He is charged under section 121 of the MAIK Enactment 1994. If found guilty, he can be jailed three years or fined RM5,000, or both. He was alleged to have used the words kurang cerdik (not so intelligent) when referring to two or three MAIK officials in his speech at the ceramah.

TENAGA Nasional Bhd (Tenaga) says a more efficient generation of electricity that could lower tariffs is possible, but this will require existing power purchase agreements (PPAs) with the independent power producers (IPPs) to be ``undone''. Executive chairman Datuk Ahmad Tajuddin Ali said if a trading and settlement of electricity in a free market scheme is adopted, consumers will benefit from lower tariffs. But this scheme cannot be implemented if the PPAs are still in place. ``It would be unfair to Tenaga,'' Tajuddin said in an interview with Business Times. In an electricity trading and settlement market, the IPPs must inform the independent grid system operator of their plants' available capacity and their selling price daily. The independent grid system operator - which will manage the systems operations of the National Grid by the year 2000 - will then match the demand and supply of electricity at any one time and buy from the IPP which offers the cheapest price. The electricity will then be directed to Tenaga's National Load Despatch Centre at Bangsar, which will despatch it to the grid. Tajuddin said in this case, the PPAs become a stumbling block. Under the PPA, Tenaga will have to pay the IPPs an agreed amount for making their plants available to generate electricity for the use of the utility. Tenaga is spending more than RM2 billion to buy about 30 per cent of the electricity generated by the IPPs. The agreement also acts as a guarantee, whereby the IPPs can use the PPAs - which secure revenue to the companies - to source funds from financial institutions. Tenaga, however, does not envisioned the settlement and trading system to be in place for quite some time. It has enough supply and more than its required capacity. Currently, the installed capacity is closed to 12,000MW while maximum demand is 8,500 MW. The Government, too, is not ready for commitments on a settlement and trading of power as restructuring in the electricity is still on-going. ``I cannot make that commitment without being very sure,'' Energy, Telecommunications and Posts Minister Datuk Leo Moggie had said when asked about the idea of a power trading system. ``Once we make a public statement and if it is found not very practical or workable, we will get ourselves in a jam,'' the minister had added. A cautious approach to such a system is being taken. The Economic Planning Unit in the Prime Minister's Department is looking at its viability and customising it to the local electricity scenario. Penjanabebas, the association for IPPs, will hold a meeting soon to discuss the issue. Its honorary president, Encik Ahmad Jauhari Yahya, said a settlement and trading system will lower the entrance barrier and attract the best participant for the electricity generation industry. When asked on the impact of the settlement and trading system on the current PPA, he said ``we have been assured by the Government that existing agreement will be honoured''. Ahmad Jauhari said concerns will mainly be on industry restructuring and the reaction from the industry as the settlement and trading system will have to be viable to attract new investments. ``The settlement and trading system for power will result in a liberalised market if it is to be implemented. However, the market must be mature to accept such a system. The financial market must also be educated and accept that it a more competitive system,'' he said.

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - Developing countries should continue to pursue the agenda for further liberalisation in world trade, especially in manufacturing. ``Such a move would only be in the interests of developing countries, especially manufacturing into which these countries are now in a big way,'' Kuala Lumpur International Airport Berhad chairman Tan Sri Clifford Herbert said. Citing Malaysia, Herbert said, about 80 per cent of Malaysia's exports were manufactures-based and any denial of access to markets would have deleterious effects. ``Malaysia is today the 17th largest trading nation and it is in our interest to maintain an open trading system,'' Herbert, who was former Finance Ministry secretary general, said. He was speaking at the Harvard Project for Asian and International Relations conference titled ``Asia in Transition: Beyond the Miracle'' at the Putra World Trade Centre. Co-organised by Harvard University student organisation, Aiesec Universiti Putra Malaysia and the International Malaysia Forum, the conference entered its second day today. The conference aims to engage future leaders in discussions that demonstrate the complexity of international relations. Speaking on ``Economic Liberalisation: Problems and Prospects'', Herbert told the audience the recent Apec agreement in Vancouver, Canada to liberalise trade further in 15 major sectors was a positive development. ``Malaysia participated in these discussions and the fact that we could subscribe to this illustrates trade liberalisation is still very much on our agenda.'' ``Malaysia and like minded developing countries however must insist that liberalisation is not a one-way affair.'' Herbert attributed the long lasting growth in Asia to several factors which included; Increasing trade links with the rest of the world, with all these countries increasing their share of exports to the markets of the developed countries, particularly in manufacturing, and Flow of technology to these countries and high levels of foreign investment. ``Countries like Malaysia also benefited by the free flow of labour into these countries, sometimes at costs much lower than domestic labour.'' In the case of Malaysia, foreign labour now amounted to almost two million, out of a labour force of eight million. ``There is no doubt that liberalisation of markets in trade, investment, labour and capital contributed to the rapid development of these economies. ``Strong and purposeful leadership contributed to growth in a liberalised trading enviroment.'' These countries therefore, he added, had a strong commitment to maintaining open trading systems, free flow of capital, increasing globalisation and integration with world markets. ``In fact, if the economic crisis had not occurred, a higher level of liberalisation would have taken place.''

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - For good governance, those in power must have political legitimacy and be held accountable, Thammasat University professor of political science, Dr Likhit Dhiravegin said today. He said the writing of a charter would help reform the existing fledgling Thai democratic system, caught in the economic crisis. Dhiravegin said reform was inevitable to curb vote-buying, scramble for cabinet posts, corruption, interference in the civil service and abuse of the national budget. He said this presenting his paper, ``Good Governance in Asia : Political Reform and Democratic Development in Thailand'' at the Harvard Project for Asian and International Relations conference entitled ``Asia in Transition : Beyond the Miracle'' at the Putra World Trade Centre. Co-organised by the Harvard University student organisation, Aiesec Universiti Putra Malaysia and the International Malaysia Forum, the four-day conference is the first held in Malaysia since HPAIR's first conference in 1992. Undergraduates and post-graduates from the world's top universities including Harvard, Yale and Oxford are attending to exchange perspectives on critical international issues. A new charter would help rectify the defects of the present system on ascension to power and to institute a control mechanism. First, the ascension to power would be changed in such a way that more capable people with integrity would be recruited. Mechanisms of control through checks and balances would be devised to prevent the breaking of laws and the like. ``More importantly, the people must be given their rights and freedom and be able to participate in the political process,'' he said. To questions from the floor, Dhiravegin added that changes also meant the Prime Minister would be chosen by a vote count in the House of Representatives in lieu of the existing system where the party with the most seats in the House of Reprentatives would go around asking other parties to join as a coalition government. The process would afford more transparency. On the economic meltdown, he said it was not solely for lack of good governance but a coming together of several factors.

AMSTEEL Securities Sdn Bhd has been given written consent to continue trading by the Securities Commission (SC), on condition that it complies with the Minimum Liquid Fund (MLF) requirements of the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE) on or before June 5. Amsteel is one of 12 stockbroking companies with an MLF deficit reported by the KLSE on May 15. All firms on the list, except for Amsteel, have been placed under trading restrictions by the KLSE. Omega Securities Sdn Bhd has since been told to cease trading and the dealer's licence of MBf Northern Securities Sdn Bhd has been suspended. Labuan Securities's dealer's licence is also suspended. However, it does meet the MLF requirement. According to the SC, only Omega Securities has not received written consent to continue with its trading activities. The Commission, replying to a Business Times query, said it has given ``conditional consent'' to all the other companies (including Amsteel) to continue with their trading. ``The conditions of restricted trading of the KLSE apply to these companies,'' the SC said. To date, there has been no announcement that Amsteel is under trading restrictions. Meanwhile, according to a source, given the MLF deficit in Amsteel, the SC had issued a ``warning'' cum show-cause letter to the brokerage asking it to regularise its financial position or risk being ordered to halt trading or having its licence suspended. The company was also told to submit plans on how it intends to regularise its financial position, which it replied to. Following this, it received a letter of extension for three weeks from the SC. Since the extension, the source said, Amsteel has been reporting the necessary information to the SC. The source said the staff of Amsteel have been on their toes working to ensure that the company's financial position is up to the satisfaction of the SC. Daily operations of the stockbroking company have been under the SC's watch, the source said, adding that Amsteel has been in constant contact with the Commission. ``At the end of trading every day, the stockbroking firm has to report its financial status to the Commission, including its MLF position,'' said the source. Typically, brokerages hit with a MLF deficit must seek written consent from the SC to continue trading as stipulated under Section 20A of the Securities Industry Act 1983. What happens following the deficit is an issuance of a show-cause letter by the SC to the brokerage. The firm, in seeking written consent to continue trading, is required to disclose to the SC the steps it plans to undertake to regularise its financial position after which the stockbroking house will either get conditional consent or an order to stop trading altogether.

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - East Asian countries need to build up confidence and attract capital inflow in order to end the economic problems and put the region back on track. This was the view of scholars and corporate player attending the plenary session of the Harvard Project for Asian and International Relations Conference entitled ``Asia in Transition: Beyond the Miracle.'' ``Principally, one of the solutions to end the regional economic and financial problems is to ensure capital flow back to the region,'' said Arab-Malaysian Securities Sdn Bhd executive director Mustafa Mohd Noor. ``And this requires a stable currency market.'' ``If the capital flow resumes, the problems will subside. But if not, liquidity remains tight and it will be hard to suggest when the problems could be over,'' said Institute of Strategic and International Studies Malaysia deputy director-general Dr Zainal Aznam. Zainal added that tight monetary and fiscal policies, as well as high interest rates and postponement of mega developments, could also help end the regional problems. Crawford Jameson, a senior official at Morgan Stanley Singapore's investment and banking division, said building up confidence was a major task in view of the battering several East Asian countries took in the last few months. ``But we somehow need to come up with terms which can restore the loss of confidence in the region,'' said Jameson, who blamed the regional problems on corruption, inflated assets, weak market sentiments, ties between politics and business and ``white elephant projects'', among others. Mustafa said the Indonesian problem and the weakening of the yen were factors currently dictating the movement of the ringgit and other regional currencies. ``Currency volatility should delay resumption of capital flows to the region, and tight liquidity would retain pressure on interest rates and dampen economic activity.'' Denmark's coach presents his squad for the World Cup
By JAN M. OLSEN Associated Press Writer
COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) _ Denmark's coach Bo Johansson mixed veteran players and youthful talent in his 22-man World Cup squad announced Monday. Although Denmark, the 1992 European champions, played poorly in two recent World Cup warm-up games against Norway and Sweden, Johansson said there was ``nothing to be negative about.'' The side that will play in Group C against France, Saudi Arabia and South Africa, included three safe bets _ brothers Michael and Brian Laudrup, and veteran goalie Peter Schmeichel. Michael Laudrup is the only survivor of Denmark's 1986 World Cup side in Mexico. The 33-year-old will bid farewell to the national team after the World Cup. His younger brother, Brian, was on the team that upset mighty Germany to win the 1992 European Championship in Sweden. One of the world's top keepers, Schmeichel, has been suffering from a minor injury but Johansson was confident that the Manchester United's goalie would be fit in time for the World Cup. Schmeichel ``wasn't 100 percent in shape'' when Sweden beat Denmark 3-0 on May 28, Johansson said. As substitute goalies, Johansson picked Mogens Krogh of the Danish champion team Broendby, and sole newcomer Peter Kjaer of Silkeborg, another Danish team. The Danes have only qualified once before for a World Cup. Denmark surprisingly failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup in the United States and a defensive-minded team flopped in the 1996 European Championship in England. Johansson, a Swede, has 8 wins, 2 draws and 3 defeats since he became Denmark's coach in 1996. He selected experienced defenders like Marc Rieper, Jan Heintze, Thomas Helveg and Jes Hoegh on the team once known as ``Danish Dynamite.'' Striker Ebbe Sand, the Danish league's top scorer with 28 goals, was also selected. His first cap was against Norway on April 22 when Denmark lost 2-0. Other inexperienced players are defender Rene Henriksen who played his first match on the red-and-white team against Scotland in March, and forward Martin Joergensen who has played three times on the Danish side. Johansson who has opted for a 4-4-2 system, said he hadn't decided what system Denmark would play in France, adding he wanted to avoid ``the vulnerability of playing only one system.'' Before heading for France, Denmark plays a friendly against Cameroon on Friday in Copenhagen. The squad: Goalies _ Peter Schmeichel, Mogens Krogh, Peter Kjaer, Defenders _ Jes Hoegh, Marc Rieper, Jacob Laursen, Rene Henriksen, Soeren Colding, Jan Heintze, Michael Schjoenberg, Thomas Helveg, Midfielders _ Allan Nielsen, Per Frandsen, Morten Wieghorst, Stig Toefting, Bjarne Goldbaek, Michael Laudrup, Forwards _ Brian Laudrup, Miklos Molnar, Peter Moeller, Martin Joergensen, Ebbe Sand.

TIN mining used to be the in thing in the country. The wealthy were commonly referred to as tauke lombong; the title became even more apt if the rich person wore khaki shorts which were worn by the Mat Sallehs -Western bosses who run most of the mines in the country then. Malaysia's tin mining activities were at his height in the 1950s and the industry provided employment to the people. The country was then the world's largest tin producer and held the title for a long time. Even the secretariat of the Association of Tin Producing Countries (ATPC) was located in Malaysia due to the strengh of the industry. Tin, a non-renewable resource, however began to lose its shine when the world tin market crashed in the mid-1980s. It marked a turning point for the industry in the country. The world's largest tin producer became a net importer of the metal in the early 1990s. The low price of tin made mining activities unlucrative in Malaysia and land was used for more profitable sectors such as property and oil palm. The cheap price of tin, however, has helped one sector to prosper -the smelting industry. The two Malaysian smelters - Escoy Smelting Sdn Bhd and Malaysian Smelting Corp (MSC) - are now multi-million ringgit businesses. Foreign exchange revenue from export of tin in 1997 totalled RM479 million against RM533 million in 1996. However, the import of tin-in-concentrates were valued at RM452 million compared with RM486 million in 1996. As such, net export revenue in 1997 totalled RM27 million against RM47 million in 1996. Malaysia exported 31,785 tonnes of refined tin last year, down 2,557 tonnes from 34,342 tonnes in 1996. But even the smelting sector seems to be following the fate of the tin mining industry. Effective last April, Escoy Smelting had closed shop, making MSC the country's sole smelter of tin. Nonetheless, the Malaysian Chamber of Mines had expressed confidence that MSC can still assist the country remain as the centre of tin smelting in years to come. With MSC's smelting capacity of 40,000 tonnes a year, the chamber felt that the company should have no problems in maintaining the volume of refined tin metal exports which total some 30,000 tonnes a year. Tin's only avenue for maintaining its name in the country's list of revenue-earning industries is the Mineral Development Policy - a policy which allows the mining industry to diversify its sources and not limit itself to mining tin only. Unfortunately, the adoption of the Mineral Development Policy by states has been too slow for the industry's liking. Malaysian Chamber of Mines president Abdul Sukor Shahar had said although several roadshows had been conducted to explain the implementation and benefits of the policy, not much progress has been made. Except for Sarawak, which had incorporated several of the provisions into its State Mining Enactment, the other states have remained quiet. It is a sad that the new policy, which was intended to give a needed boost to the tin mining industry, invoked only lukewarm response from state governments. The MDC aims to generate mining investments and offer socio-economic developments to the states, especially those with mineral potential. The earlier the states realise these advantages, the faster the economic benefits to be reaped. The year will undoubtedly see more roadshows by relevant authorities and tin-related associations to convince state governments to adopt and implement the MDP. While the country's tin mining days are numbered, there is no reason why it should not continue to tap its remaining tin reserves. Granted that it is not viable to solely concentrate on tin mining, there is no harm in simultaneously mining both the metal and other minerals such as silica, ball clay, gold and marble stones. The diversification of mining activities may in the long term spur the sector to become a major revenue earner for the country once again. And perhaps this time there will be more tauke lombongs around.

KOTA BARU, Fri. - Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad said today the Government will continue to help big and small Bumiputera companies to enable them to compete with other races in the business sector. He said that it was the Government's responsibility to ensure that all races share the country's wealth. ``If we allow all the Bumiputera companies to collapse, we will be placed in a situation before the New Economic Policy was introduced, where the poor were generally the Malays,'' he added. He said, however, the Government would only assist Bumiputera companies which had the potential to succeed and that ``there is no favouritism''. Dr Mahathir said the Government's assistance to Bumiputeras was often interpreted by certain foreign quarters as helping ``government cronies'' as if they were favoured by the Government. ``Such allegations were made because they are envious of the achievements of the Malays. They actually want the Malays to remain the poorest race in the country. They have bad intentions and if possible, they want us to remain stupid. ``Even if a Malay businessman succeeds without Government's assistance, he will still be labelled a government crony,'' he added. He was addressing a large crowd at the launch of the Kelantan Multimedia, Telecommunications and Electronic Exposition (Emtek '98) at Sekolah Menengah Chabang Empat Pasir Mas/Tumpat. Dr Mahathir was accompanied by his wife Datin Seri Dr Siti Hasmah Mohd Ali. Others present included former Deputy Prime Minister Tun Abdul Ghafar Baba, MP for Gua Musang Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah, Entrepreneur Development Minister Datuk Mustapa Mohamed, Rural Development Minister Datuk Annuar Musa, Umno Youth chief Datuk Ahmad Zahid Hamidi, Johor Menteri Besar Datuk Abdul Ghani Othman and Umno Information chief Datuk Dr Yusof Nor. Dr Mahathir said since the NEP was introduced, thousands of jobs were created as well as scholarships given which enabled children in the rural areas to pursue their education which later enabled them to compete on equal footing with other races. He said these efforts helped the economy and created many millionaires and even billionaires. ``We should be proud of them. We don't question who they are because they are our representatives from among the Malays in the country. We want all the races to be equal. ``We do not want a situation where the poor are the Malays and the rich are from other races. This is a dangerous situation and can lead to chaos in the country,'' he added. Dr Mahathir also advised the people to familiarise themselves with information technology so that they could use IT to assist in the nation's progress. ``The use of IT is everywhere. It has created a borderless world. But there is now an attempt to colonise nations using IT instead of war planes or canons.'' He said an example of the power of IT was the transfer of millions of ringgit from one country to another with the touch of a button. ``We now have a borderless world. The world has become as if one country. People can move anywhere without restrictions and without respect for our borders. ``I do not know if this was done on purpose to control us but the fact is that they have succeeded in making us poor, and because of that, they are able to control our economy. They get richer and richer.'' Dr Mahathir said as the value of the ringgit depreciated, so would the people's purchasing power. When this happens, he said, the people could not buy imported products, such as milk, wheat and medicine, and as a consequence, the people would revolt and blame the Government. ``So, they are not only creating economic problems but political and social problems as well,'' he added. Citing Indonesia as an example, he said the country with more than 200 million people and experiencing a growth rate of seven per cent for several years was now made poor following the fall in the value of the rupiah. ``The people have forgotten the efforts of the Government to build the country over the past 30 years. At one stage, Indonesia was regarded as one of the economic tigers of Asia.'' However, he said, when the rupiah was attacked, it caused numerous problems, including high cost of essential items which have to be imported, the closure of 16 banks, the closure of 10,000 companies and the loss of jobs for 20 million people. Speaking to reporters later, Dr Mahathir said the development of the Multimedia Super Corridor would proceed despite the current economic situation. He said the economic problems in the region had also affected the finances of companies planning to invest in the MSC. For example, he said, companies in Japan have slowed down their investment abroad and this would affect the MSC. Asked if the economic problems could be overcome soon, Dr Mahathir said it could not be solved in the short term because ``we have lost the power to dictate the rise and fall of currency''.

AYAMAS Food Corp Bhd (AFCB) will jointly undertake with the Perlis State Government a large-scale broiler contract farming project. She said, a team of qualified veterinarians from Ayamas Food will give professional advice on the raising of chicks or broilers following strict quality control measures. ``We will also be supplying quality feed to the farm to ensure that the broilers achieve satisfactory growth during the 40 to 45-day cycle,'' she added. The farm, according to her, will be supplying around 50,000 birds per cycle. This will gradually increase to 300,000 birds per cycle in the long term. The MOU she pointed out, looks toward a long-term understanding and with time it is expected that more farmers will realise the lucrative returns of such a joint venture. In August last year, Ayamas signed an agreement with the Selangor Farmers Organisation (LPP Selangor) to undertake broiler contract farming for the supply of an estimated 5.4 million birds a year. At present the company's two processing plants in Bukit Mertajam and Port Klang process around 2.2 million birds per month. With the completion of the RM30 million upgrading exercise for the Port Klang plant by 1999, production is expected to increase by around 50 per cent. BANK Negara Malaysia (BNM) remains optimistic about the economy's outlook despite the negative growth for the first quarter, but three factors will be crucial in determining a better second-half performance. These are a higher export level, strong fundamentals in the banking system, and a stable ringgit. Its governor, Tan Sri Ahmad Mohd Don, elaborated on these factors at a press briefing last Saturday when asked for the bank's economic outlook for the second half of the year. He had just announced a negative 1.8 per cent growth in the gross domestic product (GDP), the country's first negative quarterly growth in over a decade. In terms of export, Malaysia recorded a large external trade surplus of RM8.8 billion during the first quarter due to a a sharper decline in imports in US dollar terms. The surplus for the corresponding period of last year was RM1.7 billion. Official statistics, however, show that on a quarter-to-quarter basis, the country's export has seen a sharp increase to RM69.8 billion in January-March 1998 from RM49 billion in January-March 1997. Ahmad Don said whether the country is able to increase its export level for the rest of the year is, therefore, paramount. ``But I must also say that other (countries) affected in the regional economic turmoil will also be trying their best to export themselves out of the problems,'' he added. Maintaining the fundamental strengths in the banking system is an ``all- important'' factor, the governor said. This is why the central bank has to ensure that financial institutions must continue to strive to achieve the 15 per cent loan growth target by year-end as stipulated in its credit plan, he added. Another important factor is the exchange rate of the ringgit. ``In the past few months, the ringgit has been relatively stable, although it remains vulnerable,'' Ahmad Don said. The ringgit has lost 33.5 per cent of its value against the US dollar since July last year. Last Friday, the ringgit ended at 3.89 against the greenback, compared with 2.52 at the end of June 1997. The local currency has also lost significantly against the values of other major currencies. Ahmad Don said the first quarter's contraction in GDP growth will have to be taken into account in making a forecast for the entire 1998. ``At some point in time, we may have to relook at these numbers,'' he added. The Government had announced last March a revised GDP growth figure of between 2 per cent and 3 per cent amid the weakened Malaysian and regional economies. The January-March negative growth was attributable to various factors. On the supply side, decline in output was most apparent in the construction, manufacturing and agriculture sectors, given the sluggish external demand especially from the Asian market. On the demand part, negative wealth effects due to asset deflation and the rising inflation rate led to more cautious consumer sentiment, which adversely affected private consumption. Output in the manufacturing sector declined 2.4 per cent on an annual basis compared with a 10.9 per cent growth in the last quarter of 1997. The decline was broad-based, affecting both the domestic as well as the export-oriented industries. For the construction sector, sharp slowdown in construction activity led to the sector recording a 10 per cent decline. This was due to a slowdown in implementation of the existing infrastructure and non-residential projects and also completion of projects associated with the forthcoming Commonwealth Games. Meanwhile, inflation rose significantly in the first quarter of 1998 with the higher import prices due to the weaker ringgit being passed down to domestic price levels, pushing the consumer price index up by 4.3 per cent (1994 100) against 2.7 per cent increase in the last quarter of 1997. At producer level, the producer price index (PPI, 1989 100) also rose significantly by 14.9 per cent reflecting the higher prices of both domestic and imported inputs. The overall position of the Federal Government remained in surplus. The current and overall accounts recorded larger surpluses of RM5.4 billion and RM4.2 billion respectively. The Government's total debt declined by 2.4 per cent from the level as at the end of 1997 to RM87.8 billion at the end of March this year, attributed to reductions in both the domestic and external debts.

WORLD Bank president James D. Wolfensohn began his Press conference by first apologising to the journalists present for the criticism he was about to make of the media for being too simplistic in its reporting of the Asian financial problem. The media, it seems, likes figures too much. The international bail-out efforts of Indonesia, South Korea and Thailand have been summarised in dollars and cents - US$45 billion here, US$50 billion there - and not much of anything else. Its pre-occupation with headline-grabbing figures, and the righteous calls for economic and political reforms, led to the media's inability to look into the social consequences of the financial trouble and the bail-outs. The millions who were suffering, for example, as a pre-requisite to participation in the International Monetary Fund programmes, were somehow lost in the debates on whether to extend loans to the troubled economies. Speaking at the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation forum Finance Ministers Meeting that ended in Kananaskis, Canada last week, Wolfensohn told of the millions in Indonesia who would fall into poverty, and whose lives would be greatly affected by food and medicine shortages. The number of those joining the ranks of the unemployed was also expected to balloon in the near future. In Thailand, he said, the poor state of the economy was breaking down the traditional support system resulting in the millions returning to their villages from the cities not receiving the help they would have had from their families. As a result, crime and child prostitution were now on the rise, he said. In South Korea, the fragile truce between the trade union, government and businesses needed for the implementation of the IMF programme was showing signs of cracks. That could lead to social chaos. While the economic woes in these countries were the root of the problems, they nevertheless could be alleviated if the international efforts to rescue them had spared some thought to people on the street. Debates on the pros and cons of giving the loans took the high ground, criticising governments for the way they do things and demanding reforms before help could be given, while in the lower rung of society, the people suffered. In Indonesia, for example, the IMF insistence that the food and fuel subsidies be removed, as they were economically unsustainable and unsound, resulted in rioting in the streets that saw about 500 people dead. Regardless of whatever romantic notions one might have on the uprising - that people took to the streets to rid the country of cronyism, nepotim, collusion or corruption - it was food and fuel that led to the burning and looting. A hungry mob, after all, is an angry mob. Wolfensohn was not alone in expressing his regret. The cool setting at the lodge in Kananaskis at the foot of the Canadian Rockies where this year's meeting was held could not escape the rioting and death in Indonesia. They served as constant reminders that, in the end, decisions in high places, no matter how noble, sometimes have their own peculiar spin on the masses. Apec Finance Ministers in their final statement recognised that any rescue effort has to have a heart. It must be tempered with the need to take care of the poor and needy who were already badly hit by any economic trouble, and would suffer more in any adjustment programme. Even the IMF agreed that some of its measures were harsh, said Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim who represented Malaysia at the meeting. Camdessus, he said, agreed that IMF would continue to be flexible with its programmes to make sure that the hardest hit would not be much worse off. It was not as if the IMF was extracting its pound of flesh from the Indonesians, it was just that no one foresaw how bad the effect of the measures, as they trickle down the system, would be on the people. They nevertheless served as sombre reminders that while bitter medicine might sometimes be called for, to quote Camdessus who was also at the meeting, the treatment must not be so harsh as to wreak havoc on the body. The medical anology had been used many times to justify the actions taken by the IMF. It is true that within its own field of competence such harsh measures were the only recourse. But care must be taken to make the medicine go down easier. Nevertheless, Anwar said the international community must assist the IMF, either through bilateral measures or through agencies like the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, whose functions were more suited for social programmes, while it was the IMF's job to help turn around economies. Anwar also took to task countries like the US, that wanted to see more being done in Indonesia before it could support the resumption of IMF loans, which had since been suspended, to the country. The Deputy Prime Minister, who became the unofficial spokesman for Indonesia at the meeting since the country was only represented by its ambassador to Canada, said he believed there was a genuine attempt by President B.J. Habibie to undertake economic and social reforms, and he should be given as much support as possible. The US should not expect immediate reform from Indonesia; it took the US more than 100 years to carry out similar reforms, he said. While the situation in Indonesia dominated the meeting, the general financial health of Apec member economies was also discussed at length, including trying to identify ways to minimise the possibility of the Asian financial downturn recurring. It was generally agreed that, currency speculators and manipulators notwithstanding, the slowdown was caused by the weak macroeconomic environment in the affected countries. Unsustainable policies coupled with poor governance and the dependence on foreign money made them vulnerable. The Kananaskis meeting agreed that increased surveillance of the macroeconomic conditions of countries be established, either through peer pressure, or a regional or global monitoring body. The ministers also agreed to continue looking at how best to deal with the influx of short-term capital flows. Though welcome, they had the tendency to disrupt economies as was seen in the days leading to the regional financial difficulty. The Finance Ministers also agreed to look at an initiative of the Apec financiers, made up of the private sector of member economies, for the development of domestic and regional bond markets as an alternative to raising funds for business and development. The over-dependence on short-term debts, where credit lines were easily recalled, had been the downfall of many business in the region. Long-term debts like bonds were less likely to be withdrawn and would be more consistent. Incidentally, there are two versions of how Kananaskis got its name. The first, rather appropriately, means a meeting place in the local Indian dialect. The other, the fable goes, the place is named after a Indian named Kananaskis. Apparently, while chopping wood he injured himself badly in the head and people thought he would not make it. But he miraculously recovered, and in honour of the magical recovery, they name the river and lake nearby after him. Perhaps the Canadians were thinking of the good vibes of the place, rather than its beautiful setting, in deciding to hold the meeting there. Some of the injuries to the troubled Asian economies seemed self-inflicted, but many believe that they would emerge stronger over time. For that no miracle will be necessary, only hard work.

Citing `new climate,' OAS president says Cuba could be readmitted ANA CAROLINA GRIFFIN
AP Photo CAR102 Associated Press Writer
CARACAS, Venezuela (AP) _ A ``new climate'' created by Pope John Paul II's visit earlier this year to Cuba is making it more likely that the communist-run island may rejoin the Organization of American States, the OAS secretary-general said Monday. ``It's clear for everyone that since the visit of John Paul II to the island a new climate has been created in which this issue can be addressed in a more constructive manner,'' Cesar Gaviria said in opening the OAS' 28th general assembly. If economic and political liberties and respect for human rights are broadened on the island, ``it will be possible to consider the return of Cuba to the Inter-American system,'' said Gaviria, the former president of Colombia. Mexico's foreign secretary, Rosario Green, suggested that a ``group of friends'' of Latin American nations be formed to help resolve the issue. Cuba was thrown out of the OAS in 1962 after strong pressure from the United States, which accused Castro of supporting leftist rebel groups in Latin America. While not mentioning the United States directly, Gaviria seemed to criticize the U.S. hard-line stance against Cuba. ``Many of us would like to see applied to this problem the type of diplomacy, negotiation and gradualism that have been effective in other regions,'' he said. U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, a fierce critic of Cuban President Fidel Castro, is scheduled to attend the OAS meeting Tuesday. Delegates cannot make a decision on the issue because Cuba has not requested readmission to the OAS. However, pressure could be built up for later addressing the issue officially. Castro has enjoyed a string of recent political victories, including the visit of Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien and the re-establishment of diplomatic ties with the Dominican Republic and Guatemala. The three-day OAS meeting also is expected to address subjects including poverty, drug trafficking, corrupt justice systems and consolidating democracy.

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - A lawyer, who brought an action against a legal firm for wrongful dismissal two year ago, was awarded RM135,000 in back wages and compensation by the Industrial Court. Industrial Court chairman Abu Hashim Abu Bakar, in ordering the Johor Baru-based legal firm of Gary Yuen Tan to pay Diana Ann Seah RM120,000 in backwages and RM15,000 as compensation for loss of employment, said to reinstate her would not be conducive to a healthy working environment for both the parties. In his judgment, handed down on May 20 and made available to the Press today, he said the firm had failed to hold a domestic inquiry before terminating the services of Diana. He said she was was not given the chance to redeem herself of the charges brought by the firm during the hearing stage on why she was dismissed. ``As a company, being a firm of advocates and solicitors at that, how could it have blundered on this basic duty of due enquiry?'' he asked. Diana had claimed she commenced her employment with the firm in April, 1995, with a salary of RM5,000 per month until she was terminated without any explanation on March 31, 1996. The firm had alleged at the hearing that among the reasons for it to dismiss Diana was that she had been dishonest, misrepresented the firm, was habitually late and gave wrong advice to clients.

BINARIANG Bhd, in a surprise move, is believed to have successfully wooed Singapore Telecom Ltd to be its second foreign equity partner. The deal - which was to be deliberated on by the Binariang board of directors yesterday evening - is said to be worth about RM1.4 billion. Officials at Binariang declined comment on the deal - which is expected to see SingTel taking up a 40 per cent stake in the telecommunications firm. As existing foreign partner US West International will still hold its 19.8 per cent stake in Binariang, this deal will be the first to see foreign equity in a local telecommunications firm exceed 50 per cent. This is however subject to there being no change to Binariang's paid-up capital. Should there be new issue of Binariang shares to SingTel, the overall foreign equity structure could be lower and the existing local majority shareholder - Tunku Burhanuddin's Trust Fund - may still remain the single largest shareholder. The Government recently raised the maximum for foreign equity in a telecommunciations firm to 61 per cent, up sharply from the previous cap of 49 per cent. However, the 61 per cent cap is subject to total foreign equity being scaled back to 49 per cent within a five-year period. Analysts said the deal could be good for Binariang as it represents much-needed cash infusion into the company - believed to have been facing cash-flow problems in terms of funding capital expansions. Despite a strong revenue base from its Maxis cellular subscriber base - which passed the 360,000 mark early this year - Binariang had to suspend its fixed-line expansion plans this year due to the property sector slowdown. This fixed line expansion represents a long-term growth strategy for Binariang and also for its sister company, Measat Broadcasting Sdn Bhd, which operates the cable television network Astro. With the fixed-line infrastructure - including fibre optic cable connections -Astro programmes can be pumped directly into subscribers' homes without need for the VSAT (very small aperture terminal) dish. The analyst said SingTel's involvement could further assist Binariang in expanding its subscriber base for Astro to Singapore and the rest of the region. Also, SingTel has a number of investments in foreign telecommunications firms abroad and the tie-up could see more optimum usage of Binariang's two communications satellites - Measat I and II.

JAKARTA (JP): Students in several cities, in a move resembling their colleagues' stand in Jakarta recently, are occupying local legislative councils to make their demands heard. While those in Jakarta took over the House of Representatives/People's Consultative Assembly building in order to press former president Soeharto to resign, those in Jambi have been occupying the provincial legislature and governor's office in their fight against rampant gambling. Students in Ujungpandang, the capital of South Sulawesi, are occupying the legislative council building to demand that Governor Z.B. Palaguna, whom they considered corrupt, to step down. Antara reported from Jambi, the capital of Jambi, that dozens of students of Sultan Thaha Saifuddin Institute for Islamic Studies have entered the fourth day of their occupation of the legislative building yesterday, while those from Jambi University camped out at the governor's office. On Saturday, they held free speech forums lashing out at authorities who have allowed various forms of gambling to flourish in the province of 2.4 million. The capital's population is 412,000. Both groups said separately that they would not budge until the authorities burned down all slot machines. Joeslin Nasution, a legislator of the United Development Party, joined the free speech forum staged by the IAIN students and pledged to bring the students' demand to the attention of the House. Provincial council chairman Chaeruddin was also supportive of the students' demand and said his office would pressure the military to get rid of all gambling machines. In Ujungpandang, hundreds of students from 42 universities occupying the provincial council building are demanding that Governor Palaguna be held accountable for what they described as rampant corruption, collusion and nepotism in the province. They said that they would not leave the building until the governor stood down. ``We also demand the auditing of local officials' wealth,'' said Muh Ichsan, chairman of the Association of Makassar Students . Maj. Gen. Suadi Marasabessy, chief of the Wirabuana Military Command overseeing Sulawesi, joined a free speech forum staged by students on Saturday but reminded them that the provincial council had no authority to sack the governor. Only the president has authority to sack a governor, he said. Kallo Bandaso, the provincial council's deputy chairman, said he would bring the students' demand to the provincial council and consult the governor about it. ``The students' demand will be channeled to the central government, although it is not the provincial council's stance,'' he said. Separately, Palaguna said that he would allow himself to be audited. He said that all local officials were also expected to volunteer to do the same if needed. In Surabaya, East Java, nine soldiers were punished for their ``disciplinary actions'' in handling student demonstrations. There were no details given about the violation but some student demonstrations in the province had been handled forcefully by the military. Maj. Gen. Djadja Suparman, chief of the Brawijaya Military Command overseeing East Java, said that the nine soldiers were serving detention sentences of two week. ``Soldiers should be strict in enforcing the law but on the other hand, strict actions will certainly be taken against those violating the law,'' he said yesterday after briefing 1,000 military and police officers in the city.

KUALA LUMPUR, Sun. - Singer Siti Nurhaliza, pop group BM Boys and Malaysia's own James Bond girl Michelle Yeoh called on Malaysians to stand united in facing the country's economic problems. They were among celebrities at the Semarakkan Semangat Cinta Malaysia concert organised by the MCA at Dataran Merdeka tonight. Organised as part of the MCA's Love Malaysia, Buy Malaysian Goods campaign, the concert was aimed at promoting unity and patriotism, as well as spurring Malaysians to help revitalise the country's economy by buying local goods. Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad, who was accompanied by his wife Datin Seri Dr Siti Hasmah Mohd Ali, was the guest of honour at the open-air concert. MCA president Datuk Seri Dr Ling Liong Sik said the campaign was enjoying ``encouraging'' support from Malaysians of all walks of life. ``With united support from the people, we will surely be able to meet the challenges posed by these economic problems.'' Present were the party's deputy president, Datuk Lim Ah Lek, Wanita MCA chief Datuk Teng Gaik Kwan and its Youth chief Datuk Chan Kong Choy, as well as other senior party officials.

PROFITABLE ENTERPRISE ... Not many people realise that dried squids which are considered delicacies by some, are produced mostly in Terengganu, mainly in Marang, Kuala Terengganu and Besut. Mohd Yusof Muda, 45, a dried squid producer and supplier in Kampung Air Tawar, Kuala Besut, said unlike fish which are caught only at certain times of the year, squids are available year round even during the wet seasons. His son-in-law, Fadzil Zabidi Zakaria (picture), helps him in the business. ``There's hardly a time where we cannot get squids and that is why I have sufficient supply to meet the customers' demands,'' Mohd Yusof said. During the peak season, he would process up to 300 kilogrammes of squids daily. That happens between January and October when fishermen will have abundant harvests of squids. Each kilogramme of squid normally costs between RM7 and RM8 while the dried ones cost RM40 per kg, he said. He said that to produce dried squids, one only had to cut and clean them before putting them to dry. ``However, to retain their natural flavour, the squids must be thoroughly washed with sea water before being dried,'' he added. Mohd Yusof, who has been in the business for 13 years, said during the rainy season, the squids would be processed in a smoke house where they were left to dry over a slow fire. He said besides selling the product in the district, he also supplied the dried squids to Penang, Malacca, Johor and Negri Sembilan.

KOTA BARU, Sun. - Umno members in Kelantan should build people's confidence in the party and Barisan Nasional if they are to wrest the State from Pas in the next general election. State Umno deputy liaison chief Datuk Annuar Musa said the party should be strong and united. ``People have the impression that Kelantan Umno is divided. We have to shed that image and this can be done if there is co-operation from all party leaders and members in Kelantan. ``We have to work as a team, failing which we will not get the support from the people,'' he told reporters after opening the Kelantan Umno Convention at Perdana Resort at Pantai Cahaya Bulan yesterday. Annuar, who is also Rural Development Minister, said Umno divisions in the State should enlighten the people on the benefits they would receive if the Barisan Nasional was returned to power. ``The Federal Government will be able to provide more (assistance) for the Kelantan people if Barisan Nasional is also in power in the State,'' he said. He said Pas, despite ruling Kelantan, could not do much to develop the State. ``The State Government requires Federal assistance and whenever faced with problems, the leaders seek the Federal Government's assistance,'' he added. He also expressed regret over the attitude of the State Government leaders for not telling the truth. ``They come to us (Federal Government) for assistance, but when they return (to Kelantan), they tell the people different things,'' he said.

JAKARTA (JP): New Minister of Education and Culture Juwono Sudarsono has said student organizations will no longer have to fall in line with the dictates of university rectors. ``Student organizations will be independent. They will no longer depend on rectors but on the higher learning institution's academic values,'' he said after the transfer of job ceremony from his predecessor Wiranto Arismunandar here last Thursday. He explained student organizations would be free of rectors' interference in their activities, including elections of leaders. But he advised students to ``be gentlemen'' and conduct fair, sportsmanlike elections, including if they ended up on the losing ticket. ``A student who loses an election should fairly recognize his rival's victory and should not establish a counter organization.'' He continued that students would be allowed to invite noted figures, including government critics, as campus speakers. ``But those invited to speak on campus should abide by all rulings prevailing there...,'' he said. ``There is no such thing as absolute freedom.'' Freedom comes with its own set of responsibilities, he added. ``When I was recently invited to deliver my speech at the University of Ohio in the United States, I also complied with the country's laws. I could not say: 'Clinton must be killed'. The freedom has its own limit.'' He said exceptions might be made for those invited to a limited forum attended by experts and intellectuals. ``This is a matter that is the same as the question of how to treat a photo of a naked body. Among physicians, it is a scientific photo, but to the public it is pornography.'' Juwono's progressive remarks are a marked departure from the stance of several of his predecessors, who rigidly defined the limits of student activism and barred political speeches from campuses. In the past, student organizations were even prevented from inviting political party representatives to address them on their campuses. Asked about democracy on campus, the minister said students should realize they should strike a balance between academic responsibilities and social activities. He said he would forge cooperation with rectors of private and state universities and institutes to reach a consensus on a code of ethics on campus. ``A consensus is needed so that academic activities should not be affected by social ones usually conducted outside of the campuses,'' he was quoted as saying by Antara news agency. ``If there is no consensus, the campus will certainly become an arena for political parties and groups of ideologies to compete, the way they did years ago.'' He cited the opinion of German sociologist Max Weber, who insisted that campus activities should be untainted by meddlings of political parties. Lessons could also be learned from campus turmoil of 30 years ago. ``During the 1960s, political parties entered campuses and student brawls became unavoidable. It was no longer a war of thought but a war of fists. Campus independence should be upheld and maintained.''

PORT DICKSON, Fri. - A trip back home for nine Indonesians ended in tragedy when the boat they were travelling in capsized 8.7 kilometres off Tanjong Tuan about 3am yesterday. Port Dickson acting district police chief, Deputy Superintendent Chee Cheng Wan said one of the victims was rescued about six hours later by a passing vessel while the marine police were informed later that another was rescued by another ship and sent to Dumai, Indonesia. He said a search and rescue operation involving two marine boats, including one from the Tampoi naval base was launched for the seven still missing. Chee said that police learnt from the rescued victim warded at the Port Dickson Hospital that there were nine people in the boat when it sank.

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - The Human Resources Development Council's re-training programme is meant strictly for workers retrenched or expected to be laid off by employers who have contributed to the fund, Human Resources Minister Datuk Lim Ah Lek said today. ``There is no move by the HRDC to expand the programme to those who have not joined the work force yet,'' he told a Press conference after he opened the MCA Youth 35th annual general assembly at the Tunku Abdul Rahman College. He said the council had set aside RM5 million for the re-training programme and those who had lost their jobs or were about to be retrenched could apply for re-training. ``These programmes would give the retrenched workers added value to their careers,'' he said, adding that it would be unfair to open it up to everyone. The Human Resource Development Fund was set up whereby participating companies, particularly manufacturers, contributed one per cent of their payroll to the fund. ``As trustee, our concern is to ensure that those affected by the economic problems would be given priority,'' said Lim. Lim also reiterated that the ministry would review the ``no levy collection'' for six months for the fund which took effect from March, this year. He said since the HRDF was set up, more than 1.7 million workers had been re-trained to upgrade their skills. ``We are also getting a lot of applications from training providers to take part in training programmes,'' he added. Lim said even the World Bank had acknowledged that the HRDF was an important component in helping to upgrade workers' skill and to help improve career prospects. He reiterated that the highly-disciplined workforce in the country had helped the country in facing the economic problems. ``Credit must also be given to the trade unions who prefer to settle disputes and problems through negotiations,'' he added. Unlike other countries facing the same problems, Lim said, there were no industrial disputes to disrupt the Government's move to tackle the economic downturn through various tough measures.

Norwegian Coach: ``Brazil not as good as FIFA ranking''
OSLO, Norway (AP) _ Brazil are a hot favorite to win their fifth World Cup title in France, but Norwegian Coach Egil ``Drillo'' Olsen said Monday there is a chance the defending champions would not make it to the second round. ``Brazil is not as good as the FIFA ranking suggests, and it is not unlikely that they will be beaten by two of the teams in Group A. But I don't think that will happen,'' Olsen said. Brazil tops FIFA's ranking, Norway is seventh. Brazil opens the World Cup against Scotland on June 10. In May 1997, Olsen's team stunned the soccer world by beating Brazil 4-2 in Oslo. Olsen's concern now is Norway's Group A opener against Morocco on June 10. ``Morocco is not going to be a push over. I was impressed when Morocco held France to a draw. However, England was a disappointment in their scoreless tie against Belgium,'' he said. (kk/ls)
