JAKARTA (JP): Soeharto's resignation from the presidency last month threw the door wide open for greater political expression, and also put back on the front burner a long-simmering debate over whether there should be religion-affiliated political parties. Last week, President B.J. Habibie said the government would allow establishment of just about any political parties, as long as their political platform was not tainted by SARA -- an Indonesian acronym for polarizing societal forces of differences in tribal affiliations, religion, race and societal groups. Some applauded Habibie's apparently magnanimous statement, but others were condemnatory. They said the President -- for many, indelibly tarred with the brush of the restrictive Soeharto regime -- was merely paving the way for him to use his own discretion in approving any new parties. Moslem scholars Amien Rais and Nurcholish Madjid, Catholic scholars Frans Seda and Y.B. Mangunwijaya and political scientist Ichlasul Amal are among those who have come out against religion-affiliated political parties due to the fear it could play up religious differences and ultimately tear national unity asunder. Others strongly beg to differ. Constitutional law expert Yusril Ihza Mahendra, politician Hartono Mardjono and ulema Ahmad Sumargono, Abdul Qadir Djaelani and Kholil Ridwan said Moslems -- the majority in Indonesia's 202 million population --should be allowed to establish an Islamic party. ``Islam, yes. Islamic party, yes. Don't repeat the mistakes of the old regime,'' said Sumargono when he addressed a gathering of around 2,000 at the Al Azhar Grand Mosque here yesterday. ``We welcome those who want to establish Catholic parties, Christian parties, Secular parties, or whatever, but don't prevent Moslems from forming an Islamic party because of fear that it would endanger the nation,'' Sumargono said. ``(The fear) is sign of an Islamophobia.'' He added: ``This line of thought is the remnant of Soeharto's regime formulated by (thinkers at) the CSIS (Centre for Strategic and International Studies). ``As long as we uphold the principles of fair play, equality and honesty, God willing, this nation will not disintegrate.'' Sumargono did not comment on the establishment Friday of the Syarikat Islam Party by members of the Syarikat Islam organization. In 1973, it had joined with several other Islamic parties to establish the United Development Party (PPP). Yusril, who also spoke at the gathering, supported the concept of an Islamic party but urged Moslems not to act hastily. ``Let us think calmly, let us prepare ourselves first. ``Just because people race to build political parties does not mean that we should go out there and do the same,'' he said. ``Don't be afraid of being left behind or losing the momentum, because we have the real (political) support, namely the Moslem majority, because people know what's right from wrong.'' He said a party that accommodated the aspirations of Moslems was a necessity, but Moslem leaders needed to first cooperate and form a committee to study and prepare further steps to be taken. He called for cooperation between young Moslem leaders with their seniors such as Jusuf Hasyim from Nahdlatul Ulama or Anwar Harjono from the Indonesian Council for Islamic Propagation. ``Let us reach a consensus that Moslems would only have one party, rather than divided into small parties which cannot even win a seat in the general elections.'' He spoke out against any efforts to limit the number of political parties, and said no matter how many were now established, a process of natural selection would weed out those which were worthy from the also-rans. ``Let the people be the judge whether those parties merit their support. Those which do not win people's trust will dissolve.'' Flag In Yogyakarta, Nurcholish Madjid and Mangunwijaya separately appealed against the forming of religious parties for fear they would cause unmanageable conflicts. ``I call on the government to issue as soon as possible a clear directive on the establishment of political parties,'' Nurcholish told reporters after speaking in a discussion at Gadjah Mada University. ``I am happy that Pak Amien Rais has disclaimed any intention of establishing an Islamic political party,'' he said. ``I hope Gus Dur (Abdurrahman Wahid, chairman of the 30 million-strong Nahdlatul Ulama Moslem organization) will say the same thing soon. ``I hope that even with such a huge following, Gus Dur would not establish a political party,'' he added. ``If people insist on establishing a party with a religion as its flag, I am afraid what ensues is disintegration,'' Mangunwijaya said in a separate discussion at Muhammadiyah headquarters. It was a view echoed by Frans Seda in a discussion in Jakarta Saturday: ``Religions may motivate our actions, may become the inspiration for us to select values, but they should not be the 'political flags'.'' He called on fellow Catholics to eschew forming a religion-based political party. ``If we felt we had to establish one, then it should not be based on religion,'' he was quoted by Antara as saying. ``That political party should be 'open' in nature and be based on nationalism and (state ideology) Pancasila.'' He endorsed a suggestion of fellow Catholic scholar Astrid S. Soesanto for the establishment of a party based on human rights. ``That particular party would be good, would be open and able to accommodate the aspirations of anyone regardless their background. ``We should establish a political party not because we want to take over the control of the country, but to dedicate ourselves for the nation.'' Rights Yusril reminded the public that it was the people's rights to assemble and establish their own political parties. But Abdurrahman instructed NU followers to wait for an edict on the matter from their leaders. ``Nahdlatul Ulama should maintain its khittah, and not turn into a political party,'' he said in a written address to a gathering of NU members in Surabaya, East Java, yesterday. Khittah is the official stance of Nahdlatul Ulama, which is a social-religious organization and thus barred from involvement in politics. In reality, however, individual members of Nahdlatul Ulama, including Abdurrahman, have been prominent movers and shakers in the political sphere. ``If NU members want to be involved in politics, please wait for a guidance from the executive board, which will be issued at the right time,'' Abdurrahman was quoted by Antara as saying. Democracy Prominent economist Faisal Basri noted in a gathering of students at the Bogor Agriculture Institute in Bogor, West Java, that the interest of particular groups only should not be behind the establishment of new parties. In a televised interview, he said people who set up parties should not do to sate a lust for power. ``The ultimate goal of politics should be social welfare.'' Political analysts J.B. Kristiadi of the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) and Indria Samego of the National Institute of Sciences told The Jakarta Post separately that people were racing to establish political parties to quench their thirst for real democracy after the floodgates of free speech had opened. THE move by the Construction Industry Development Board to provide free short-term courses to Sijil Pelajaran Malaysia students who failed to obtain a place in institutions of higher learning is commendable and timely. With thousands of SPM holders failing to get a place in local higher learning institutions, the courses come as a ray of hope for several hundred students interested in a career in building construction. Although CIDB can only offer its scholarships to fewer than 500 students, it is still an effort as it will have to spend about RM3,000 per trainee or about RM150,000 from its own funds. The objective of providing free courses is multi-pronged. The main intention is to attract SPM school-leavers who have an interest in building construction but do not have the qualification to pursue their ambition in higher learning institutions. The second objective is fulfilling its social obligation. By holding such courses, CIDB would be doing its part in attracting youths into a sector (building construction) which provides a lot of job opportunities rather than allowing them to loaf or be engaged in other unproductive activities. Thirdly, CIDB hopes the course could provide the foundation for these trainees to pursue higher professional courses related to building construction, including civil engineering. Finally, CIDB also hopes to build a register of skilled building construction workers. This will enable the board to become a reference centre or an employment agency for the construction sector which could supply skilled workers to contractors. CIDB chief excutive Datuk Abdul Rahman Abdullah said under the training programme, which is expected to be introduced early next year, selected students would be trained at six of the Akademi Binaan Malaysia (ABM) training centres located in Selangor, Perak, Johor, Terengganu, Sabah and Sarawak. Trainees would have to go through three to six months of basic building construction courses. They have a choice of 58 modules, including how to operate mobile cranes, brick laying and handling scaffolding. ``The students will be given certificates. With it, the trainees will have a better chance of securing jobs in the construction sector. It will also enable them to pursue higher education in related fields. ``If we do not offer this course, the students will have to seek jobs in the construction sector first and hope that their employers will send them for training at ABM later.'' At the moment, CIDB accepts employees in the construction industry for training at ABM. The training fee, ranging from RM2,000 to RM3,000, is paid by the employers. Those who complete the course are given competence certificates to acknowledge the level of professionalism in the respective fields. Although the facilities at the ABM training centres are still inadequate, they are more than sufficient to meet the requirements for basic training. In this respect, CIDB is also working closely with other skills training centres in the country such as the Terengganu Advance Training Institute in Kemaman and the Terengganu Skills Development Centre in Kuala Terengganu. ``We need all the help we can. We have to put on hold our plans to provide tower cranes or other expensive equipment at the ABM training centres at the moment due to the current economic situation. ``But this does not mean that we don't have any training equipment at the ABM training centres. In fact, our plan to co-operate with skills training centres is aimed at overcoming this problem in the short term. ``We also plan to provide twinning programmes with local and foreign higher learning institutions to ensure that our trainees get the best in skills training.'' On paper, the plans by the CIDB look realistic as it involves the development of manpower from the basic stage to the professional stage, as well as registration of manpower for the construction sector. However, to be successful, it has to receive the support of players in the the construction sector. They could at least share the cost of providing the training equipment and machines used by workers. The industry has to realise that what CIDB is doing is for the sake of the industry, especially in improving the professionalism and skills of manpower required in the construction sector. With more trained and skilled manpower, industries will no longer have to look abroad for good workers, reducing foreign exchange loss. The CIDB will have a registry of local workers that it can supply to contractors. Another training programme which deserves to be commended is the one endorsed by the Electricity and Gas Department, which involves the training of chargemen by industries. Under this programme, the State Economic Planning Unit shortlists the candidates for training and pays part of the allowances during the six-month training period. Industries which accept these trainees will provide on-the-job training and those who excel are given certificates endorsed by the department. In Terengganu, companies such as Perwaja Steel, Metro Pacific, Permint Plywood, The New Straits Times Press (M) Berhad, Gunawan Iron and Steel and the Marang Safari Resort, have participated in such training schemes and benefited from them. ``Those who received the certificates but declined the offer to work with their host companies can easily secure a job as chargeman in other companies as there are over 5,000 vacancies,'' said director-general of the department, Datuk Mohd Anas Mohd Nor.

KUALA LUMPUR, Sun. - The Anti-Corruption Agency's investigation of former Selangor Menteri Besar Tan Sri Muhammad Muhammad Taib is still on, ACA director-general Datuk Shafee Yahaya said today. He said the agency had completed the first part of its investigation which started the moment Muhammad was detained for failing to declare more than A$1.2 million (RM2.95 million) when he left Brisbane International Airport on Dec 26, 1996. ``The ACA has been investigating the matter since that day and this includes going through all his (Muhammad's) accounts and assets to ascertain the sources of his wealth. ``We have completed parts of it and have submitted the investigation papers to the Attorney-General's Chamber for a further directive before proceeding with further action. ``We are still investigating the second part of it and once it's completed, we will forward the papers to the A-G's Chamber.'' However, Shafee declined to comment on the recommendations made by the ACA to the A-G's Chamber on the matter so far. Although he also declined to elaborate on the two parts of the ACA investigations, it was reported early last year that the agency was investigating Muhammad and his two former aides following the discovery of large amounts of cash in Brisbane and Shah Alam. The ACA started the first investigation following a report lodged by Pas Youth secretary Mahfuz Omar with the Selangor ACA in Shah Alam on Dec 29. This came in the wake of an admission by Muhammad that the money which he failed to declare at the Brisbane airport while en route to New Zealand belonged to his three brothers - Datuk Raduan, Datuk Othman and Hassan. The second investigation was connected to the conversion of a 40ha forest area in Bukit Sungai Putih, Hulu Langat, involving Muhammad's former aides. It was reported that the land was gazetted as a forest reserve in 1972, but the State Executive Council took a decision in 1990 to degazette it. The land was originally part of the Bukit Sungai Putih forest reserve and had been earmarked for mixed development after a logging licence was given out to a company. It was reported that the ACA would call all parties involved in the decision-making to give their statements, including Muhammad. The others were State Forestry Department officers and State Executive Councillors, past and present. One of the two aides was said to be found with about RM1.5 million in his car when an ACA team went to his house in Shah Alam in December 1996. The ACA commenced investigation into this case following a report lodged at the ACA headquarters. The complainant was not named. Yesterday, Muhammad told Malaysian journalists in Brisbane that he had declared his assets to Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad and the ACA after he was detained in Australia. ``The ACA checked our accounts and scrutinised the records and it is up to them whether to take any action against me,'' he said, adding whatever he told the ACA was consistent with the evidence in court. The Brisbane District Court had on Friday, acquitted Muhammad on two charges of falsely declaring the money he took into Australia in December 1996 and failing to declare more than A$1.2 million when he left the country. The money was seized by the Australian police following his arrest and was released on Friday. During his trial, Muhammad told the court that he had used his wife's name, Puan Sri Asbi Rohani Hasnan, to purchase assets in Australia and New Zealand. This included a plot of land valued at A$460,000 and a A$460,000 bungalow at Sovereign Island, Gold Coast; a farm in Currajong valued at A$3.7 million, a NZ$500,000 house (RM1.05 million) and two plots of land valued at about NZ$4 million in New Zealand.

JAKARTA (JP): United Development Party (PPP) chairman Ismail Hasan Metareum said over the weekend that cabinet ministers, governors and Armed Forces (ABRI) leaders should no longer be recruited as members of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR). Addressing the opening of PPP's leadership meeting at the party's secretariat on Jl. Diponegoro in Central Jakarta, Ismail said the Assembly, along with the House of Representatives (DPR), should perform its duties purely as messengers of people's aspirations and remain free from government intervention. ``The Assembly should be a true representation of the people and the supreme power controller of the country,'' Ismail, who is better known as Buya, said Saturday. ``The ministers, Armed Forces commander and others of his rank, governors and all civil servants should not be MPR members,'' he asserted. Ismail was referring to PPP's proposal on a revision of the 1985 laws on the structure and position of the MPR and the DPR, on general elections and on political parties. In the past few years, almost all cabinet ministers and provincial governors have been members of the Assembly. The Assembly is comprised of 1,000 members. The House with its 500 legislators comprises half of the Assembly, the rest are appointed by the president. Ismail maintained that apart from the Armed Forces representatives, all members of the Assembly should be elected. ``The (new) law should at least delineate that all MPR members are directly elected by the people, except for, perhaps, the Armed Forces, who are appointed to the DPR with a number that can be negotiated,'' he said. Because Armed Forces members do not vote in elections, they are accorded 75 seats in the House. Electoral law Speaking on PPP's proposal for changes in the electoral law, Ismail said honest and fair should be added to the already existing four principles of general elections -- direct, general, free and confidential. He said election supervision should be held by an independent body consisting of neutral figures, while the government should act only as a facilitator. He also said that election day should be held on a holiday or declared a holiday. ``The government apparatus, both civil and military, from middle level down should not side with any poll contestants,'' he remarked. Speaking of revisions to the law on political parties, Ismail said there should be no restrictions on the ability to establish a political party or for the general public to be affiliated to any party of their choosing. ``People should also be free not to join any party. ``Civil servants should be free to join and not to join any political party. They should not need to obtain their superiors' permission if they want to become party members,'' he added. In the past, civil servants were required by the government to vote for the dominant Golkar. Speaking to journalists, Ismail said he was not troubled by the fact that several organizations which merged in 1973 to form the PPP were now breaking rank and establishing their own parties. ``PPP members are free to join and leave the party as they please,'' he said, referring to the Indonesian Syarikat Islam Party (PSII). Syarikat Islam announced Friday that it would go its own way in the political arena when its chairman Taufiq R. Tjokroaminoto said it was readopting its old name and forming its own political party. Another PPP element, the Tarbiyah Islamiyah Association (PERTI), has also indicated a plan to regain its glorious past as an independent party. Ismail, however, said that the PPP would remain a solid and unified party despite the withdrawal of several elements. ``PPP is not a federation of organizations, whose individual organizations can withdraw their membership just like that,'' he said, ``PPP will remain a merger of four political parties.'' As part of the national consensus, four Moslem political parties --Nahdlatul Ulama (NU), PSII, PERTI and the Indonesian Moslem Party (Parmusi) -- merged and formed the PPP in 1973. Ismail said the PPP would be unperturbed if Syarikat Islam later gained government approval to contest general elections. ``If that happens, then we will contest general elections together,'' he said.

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - The Health Ministry will intensify its campaign for more organ donation pledges from Malaysians while working out legal and ethical issues surrounding the process. Health Minister Datuk Chua Jui Meng said today lack of donors was hampering the development of an effective national organ transplantation programme, although the country had the capability to conduct such ``miracle'' operations. ``We have received more than 10,000 organ donation pledges from the public, of which more than 8,000 were made through the National Kidney Foundation and the rest with the Kuala Lumpur Hospital's Organ Transplantation Resource Centre. ``However, our cadaveric kidney donation rate is still low - less than 0.5 per million population in Malaysia,'' he said when opening the Malaysian Society of Transplantation's third annual meeting at the National Heart Institute. Comparatively, he said, the rate was about 40 per million population in countries such as Australia, Belgium, Spain and Portugal, and about 30 per million in the United States and United Kingdom. Chua said the Ministry's National Transplantation Co-ordination Committee during a meeting last March 5, had set up five sub-committees, to handle professional issues, public education, ethics and law, registration as well as planning and promotion. Chaired by Health director-general Tan Sri Dr Abu Bakar Suleiman and supported by professional groups, non-governmental organisations, universities, private hospitals and religious groups, the committee will next meet on June 18. Chua said the country had seen 663 local kidney transplants carried out from 1975 to the end of last year, 25 liver transplants performed since 1995 and three heart transplants as of April this year. ``Organ transplants have dramatically improved the quality of life for end-stage organ failure patients,'' he said, adding that they freed patients from tedious and expensive treatments such as dialysis, daily injections and intravenous feeding. However, he said the Government would strive to ensure donated organs do not become a commodity here as opposed to how organ transplants have become a commercial activity in certain countries. Chua said information of potential donors would eventually be forwarded to Kuala Lumpur Hospital to be compiled in a centralised database, to prevent the organ donation process from experiencing ``hiccups.'' On rumours that Viagra pills were available in Malaysia, Chua advised the public to be careful as the pills being sold locally were probably fake and could have harmful effects. He said the Pharmaceutical Services Division was compiling information about the drug, which is reported to address the problem of impotence but is not yet registered in Malaysia. He said if and when Viagra was to be registered, it would only be dispensed by prescription, enabling the physician to monitor the patient's condition as well as any other medication he might be taking.

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - Seven Malaysians, part of a 21-man crew onboard a Malaysian-registered ship, Petro Ranger, sailed home yesterday, about a month after the vessel was detained by Chinese authorities in connection with an alleged pirate attack in the South China Sea. The fuel tanker was held at the Haikou Port since it was intercepted by the Chinese maritime authorities on April 26. Following the vessel's release, the Malaysians and other crew members left the port in Hainan island for Singapore about 4pm. The Malaysians crew members were identified as Saravanan Subramanian, Mohamed Nazri Selamat, Abdul Kadir Soad, Sani Anak Ugie, Mohd Faizal Mohd Ghazali, Mohd Shizul Khan M. Razali and Mohd Samsuri Abdul Kadir. The other crew onboard the vessel were six Indonesians, four Bangladeshies, a Ghanaian, a Filipino, a Myanmar and the ship's captain, Kenneth Blyth, an Australian. Chinese authorities reported they had detained a gang of 12 Indonesians - believed to have boarded the vessel off the coast of China -in connection with the hijack of the ship to smuggle its cargo into the country. When contacted at his office in Beijing today, Malaysian Ambassador to China, Datuk Abdul Majid Ahmad Khan, said the ship and the crew set sail for Singapore yesterday. ``All the crew aboard the vessel, including the Malaysians, were released by the Chinese authorities,'' he said. The International Maritime Bureau had sought the assistance of the Malaysian Embassy after the bureau's officials and the ship's agent, Petroships of Singapore, were denied access to board the vessel. The crew members were also barred from leaving the vessel although they were allowed to post letters to their families, through the embassy. On April 16, the Petro Ranger disappeared during a voyage from Singapore to Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam after it was alleged to have come under pirate attack. It was transporting 11,000 tonnes of diesel and kerosene when the incident occurred. BC-Russia-Mir, 5th Ld-Writethru
Mir computer working again steering system.
Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with crew trying to reactivate AP Photos MOSB101,103. By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ The central computer on board Mir was working again Monday night, after a three-day breakdown that threatened to postpone the Russian space station's last rendezvous with a U.S. shuttle. That enabled the Mir crew to begin the long process of reactivating the station's automatic steering system, said Valery Lyndin, a spokesman for Russian Mission Control. The shuttle can only dock with Mir when the steering system keeps it properly aligned. The space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to lift off Tuesday and dock with the station Friday to pick up astronaut Andrew Thomas, the seventh and last American to live on the Russian outpost. Lyndin said space officials have not yet determined why Mir's computer broke down on Saturday. Russian cosmonauts Talgat Musabayev and Nikolai Budarin replaced it with another unit, but the new unit failed on Sunday when they tried to switch it on. Ground controllers fully loaded the software into the computer Monday night, and the crew was able to get it working again within about 90 minutes. Reactivating the steering system can take an entire day. During a chat with ground controllers during the repair process, Musabayev said the situation on board ``isn't bad'' but added that he was concerned that it occurred on the eve of the shuttle's launch. ``I'm worried not for myself, but for the flight program,'' he said. Mir's computer repeatedly failed last year, prompting Russian space officials to send up a replacement on a shuttle ferry flight in January. That unit failed on Saturday after five months of trouble-free operation. The station's crew has replaced it with a back-up computer brought up by a Russian cargo ship. Mir's main computer operates the station's motion control system, and when it fails, the station's energy supply is threatened because it can't keep its solar panels in optimum alignment with the sun. Depending on how much energy was lost, it can take from one to three days to get the orientation system fully on-line. Fortunately, when the latest trouble occurred, the station was on the so-called solar orbit, which puts it in direct sunlight round the clock. As a result, the Mir's solar panels have remained in full sunlight. The crew also shut down some systems to save energy, and as a result Mir's batteries were full on Monday, making it easier for the crew to restore the orientation system, Lyndin said. Russia plans to bring down the 12-year-old Mir at the end of 1999 after the first parts of the international space station are in orbit. A Russian-manufactured propulsion system, is supposed to be launched in November. But Russia's contributions to the station have been delayed repeatedly because of financial problems. A service module for the station to be supplied by Russia is nearly ready for testing, the Interfax news agency reported. A satellite communications system and a computer will be installed in the module before it is sent to the Baikonur launch site in Kazakstan, where it will be launched in April of next year, the report said. BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 5th Ld-Writethru
More deaths reported in Kosovo; thousands flee
Eds: UPDATES with scene in Tropoja, refugee quotes; trims By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Refugees from Serbia's Kosovo province streamed into neighboring Albania in unprecedented numbers on Monday amid reports of dozens of people killed and some trapped by the worst fighting in months. With 39 people reported killed over the weekend, and fighting apparently continuing, the bloodshed seemed the worst since early March, when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on independence-minded militants and their families. In New York, U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard spoke of ``heavy and indiscriminate shelling'' of some Kosovo Albanian villages near the border to Albania. He said U.N. workers could see heavy mortars being fired into the villages. Refugees talking to The Associated Press on the Albanian side of the border said one three-year old had died on the way and that they had heard second hand of infants inadvertently suffocated by parents who had covered their mouths and noses to stop them from crying and giving away their location to Serb forces. Ethnic Albanian officials said 37 Albanians had been killed over the weekend. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani while 10 were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died in the fighting around Decani, 75 kilometers (45 miles) west of the regional capital Pristina, Serb sources said. The latest fierce fighting prompted about 2,000 Kosovo Albanians to leave the troubled region and cross over into Albania's Tropoja (pronounced Tro-POH-yah) region Sunday and Monday, Albanian authorities said. They said more were arriving by the hour. In Tropoja, some of the hundreds of refugees in the town itself _ most of them old, young or women _ said they had walked for up to 20 hours to reach the Albanian town. They said Serb tanks were positioned inside Decani, and said some of the Serb forces besieging the town wore black uniforms. Tropoja, although some 5 kilometers (3 miles) inside Albanian territory, resembled a community under siege, with most of the men carrying rifles or other weapons. Some of them displayed the insignia of the Kosovo Liberation Army, the militant Kosovo organization spearheading the fight against Serbia. Andrew Harper, the representative of the main U.N. refugee agency, said he had purchased three tons of flour, rice and other basics on the local market to provide for the refugees, and more aid was expected from Tirana, the Albanian capital, on Tuesday. Still, some questioned if it would be enough. ``I am very worried about providing for all these people,'' said Isa Memia, the town leader. ``We have grave (supply) problems ourselves, but they are our kinsmen, and we will help them.'' Eckhard, the U.N. spokesman, called the refugee flow ``the largest such exodus to date.'' He said that 1,300 people fled to Tropoja town on Sunday alone and cited reports that some people were ``trapped and cannot cross the border.'' Refugees already in Tropoja said about 1,000 more were still on the Kosovo side of the border hills and were expected to cross Tuesday. In a statement, the Albanian government called on the United States and the European Union to intervene to end ``the massacre in Kosovo.'' Authorities in Serbia, which with Montenegro comprises all that remains of the Yugoslav federation, are trying to block Kosovo's independence bid. They are using Serbian police and the Yugoslav army to try to crush militants and maintain control over the province, where 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million is ethnic Albanian. More than 200 people have died in Kosovo clashes since the beginning of March. An estimated 50 percent of the Serbian province is controlled by militant Albanians and many regions are blocked off, either by Serbs or Albanians. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, released the names of the 10 people it said were killed Sunday when Serb police stormed the village of Poklek, 25 kilometers (15 miles) west of Pristina. It said one had had his throat slit. According to the Albanians' account, Serb police burst into Poklek houses, pulled out villagers and told them to ``go to Albania and never return.'' Afterward, Serb police allegedly set 26 homes ablaze. All phone lines remained disconnected Monday between Pristina and the hot-spots of Decani, Klina and Djakovica. In Pristina, about 10,000 ethnic Albanians, including 2,000 children, marched to protest Serbian rule. (pvs/md/gj)

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - The Selangor Waterworks Department today said it would further improve the water distribution process under the current rationing scheme to ensure supply reached everyone. ``We will try to do this by opening valves to higher areas first before opening those to the low-lying areas,'' said the department's deputy director V. Subramaniam during a Press conference at the department headquarters. As a result, he urged people who do not receive water through their pipes continuously to report the matter to the department so that it could rectify the situation. Subramaniam said although this would create a lot more work for his staff, who were already stretched to the limit, the move was necessary to ensure that everyone got their supply. Such adjustments have been successfully implemented for residents in Bukit Gasing and Puchong Jaya in Selangor, who are now getting water as scheduled. Besides valve manipulation, Subramaniam said repairing broken and leaking pipes could also help increase the efficiency of water supply. He said the department had managed to improve its response time to reports of damaged pipes. He said the public should not damage the department's installations or use more water than necessary because this might prevent areas on higher grounds from getting water. ``Unlike electricity, water takes time to travel when the valves are opened. Low lying areas will have to be satisfied first, including filling up all the pails and tanks, before it moves to higher ground.'' Subramaniam also said the levels at the Semenyih and Langat dams had dropped further as water had been released to maintain water production at the Sungai Semenyih, Sungai Langat, Cheras and Ampang intake treatment plants at 70 per cent. ``We will keep monitoring the situation and will inform the public of any decisions.'' Subramaniam said the department was still considering the steps to be taken under the contingency plan if the water levels at the dams fell to ``critical''. ``We are looking at other options besides just cutting down the rationing hours,'' he said. Meanwhile, Selangor State Information and Information Technology Committee chairman Datuk Sharif Jajang, said the forum to be held on June 3 would only create more confusion over the issue among the public. The seminar was organised by the Federation of Malaysian Consumers Associations on the water crisis Sharif, who is also the Industry and Investments Committee chairman, said the public already had adequate information on the facts of the water problem and as a result, need not attend the forum. ``This is especially so when the Selangor State Government, Selangor Waterworks Department and Puncak Niaga (M) Sdn Bhd are not attending the forum,'' he said at the same Press conference. He said the department would meet with Fomca on June 2 to discuss issues relating to the water problems and seek ways in which the organisation could help under present circumstances.

Reformist triumphs in Montenegro poll
Eds: UPDATES with near final results confirming Djukanovic victory. AP Photos By ALISON SMALE Associated Press Writer
PODGORICA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ In a major electoral triumph, Montenegro's reformist president threw down a challenge to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic Monday that could dent or ultimately undo the strongman's rule. In true Balkan style, supporters of President Milo Djukanovic fired guns, waved flags and honked car horns as they showed their joy at an unexpectedly decisive win over Milosevic protege Momir Bulatovic in Sunday's parliamentary elections, With 99.7 percent of the vote counted for the 78-seat Montenegrin parliament, Djukanovic's coalition ''For a Better Life'' had secured 49.5 percent of ballots cast, the State Election Commission said. Bulatovic's Socialist People's Party had 36.1 percent, the Commission added. A jubilant Djukanovic, 36, told cheering supporters he hoped to build on the triumph and use it to spread democracy throughout Yugoslavia, which now consists of just Serbia and Montenegro. ``Montenegro has again shown that it has the wisdom, courage and resolve to resist those who decided to enslave Montenegro,'' he said. Although this mountainous republic has just 630,000 residents, it supplies the same number of deputies to the federal Yugoslav parliament as Serbia, with 10 million inhabitants. Djukanovic and his aides are determined to stack Montenegro's bloc with their supporters, and hope to team up with Serbian opposition deputies to vote Milosevic out. No political analyst in Yugoslavia can imagine Milosevic going quietly. Since rising to power in Serbia in 1987, the wily strongman has used a powerfully effective mix of nationalism, tight media control and autocratic methods to cement his hold on power. But Djukanovic and unrest in the Serbian province of Kosovo recently have weakened his grip. In Kosovo, ethnic Albanians fighting for independence appear to be gaining ground in ever more deadly battles with Serbian police. Djukanovic first threw down the gauntlet in the winter of 1996-7, coming out against Milosevic during massive protests against his rule. Last fall, the Montenegrin then narrowly beat Bulatovic _ his former best friend _ for the republic's presidency. Strongly backed by Washington and western Europe, Djukanovic took office last January. The strength of his triumph in Sunday's elections could hand him a majority in the 78-seat Montenegrin parliament. Besides Djukanovic's and Bulatovic's parties, only one other party _ the Montenegrin separatist Liberal Alliance _ passed the 3 percent vote threshold needed to get seats. Djukanovic aides suggested Monday that they would insist on Bulatovic being replaced as federal premier. Milosevic maneuvered his protege into that office two weeks ago after the previous premier refused to crack down on Djukanovic's pro-Western reforms. The big unknown Monday was Milosevic's reaction. Typically in such situations, he bides his time, allowing media or political aides to speak for him before acting. The state news agency Tanjug said that Bulatovic's party had accepted Sunday's results. Some 120 election monitors dispatched by the 54-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation concluded Sunday's ballot ``was generally well conducted,'' an OSCE statement said. ''I'm giving these elections a clean bill of health,'' said Javier Ruperez of Spain, heading the monitoring team. The statement urged all political parties to overcome the bitter divisions of the election campaign and ``work now at establishing a climate of dialogue and confidence.'' Media control has proven critical for all ruling parties since the old Yugoslavia, of six republics, began its bloody break-up in 1991. OSCE said Montenegrin state media were biased toward Djukanovic. But the transatlantic organization was even more critical of Serbian state media for its vicious attacks on the Montenegrin president during the campaign. (pvs/str/jg/gj)

JOHOR BARU, Fri. - The Johor Welfare Department has launched an internal investigation into allegations that one of its senior officers in charge of an all-women's welfare home had sexually molested several inmates. State Welfare director Mohd Kodri Omar said today that at least two mentally-disabled inmates of the Rumah Taman Sinar Harapan in Jalan Datin Halimah had reported that they had been fondled and molested by the man in his office on several occasions. The officer has been temporarily seconded to the department's headquarters, pending the completion of the investigation. Kodri said the investigation into the allegations was headed by his deputy, Haron Mohd Isa, adding that a team would also question other inmates to ascertain if there were more allegations of sexual abuse. The New Straits Times has learnt that the allegations came to light after the two inmates had complained to a staff at the home, early this month. Recently, the home's Visitor's Board held a special meeting to discuss the allegations of sexual abuse. Rumah Taman Sinar Harapan was set up in the 1950s by the Federal Government. It has today more than 250 female inmates housed in about 20 dormitories. It houses physically and mentally-handicapped girls and women who have been abandoned by their families. It also houses normal babies, children and teenagers, including orphans, the children of illegal immigrants and divorced parents. The home also takes in children whose parents are serving prison sentences. Asked why a male warden was in charge of an all-female institution, Kodri said that there was no specific policy stating that the position had to be held by a woman. ``The idea is probably that the girls would benefit from having a father figure in their lives,'' he added. Kodri said that the department had not lodged a police report or sent the alleged victims for a medical examination because it had not completed its investigation of the case. He added, however, that the investigations should be completed soon. In a related development, State Unity, Women's Affairs and Social Welfare Commitee chairman Halimah Sadique has promised a thorough investigation into the allegations of sexual abuse and that there would be no cover-up. ``If the allegations are found to be true, the officer concerned will be brought to book,'' Halimah added.

THERE is no escaping them. Like a modern-day ``virus'', they are virtually everywhere. Shopping complexes, bus stops and taxi stands, inside LRT trains, along the highways and byways. They leap at you, envelop you and even if you don't pause for a second look, they insidiously wend their way into your mind. These are the posters - undoubtedly the most powerful tool of publicity, persuasion and propaganda in modern times, since Jules Cheret created the first four-colour posters in the late 19th century! Not meant to last, the posters have become one of the greatest signposts of the times with many of the more memorable images assuming iconic status. Some of the greatest original posters of all times are featured in The Power of the Poster exhibition at London's Victoria and Albert Museum in South Kensington, on until July 26. With a broad overview reflecting the social history of the last 120 years, the exhibition is neatly arranged under three categories - Pleasure and Leisure, Protest and Propaganda, and Commerce and Communication. The 300 posters on display are culled from the museum's own extensive collection of more than 10,000 original posters, and this exhibition is the most ambitious of its scale since 1931. The great appeal of posters is their effectiveness, their incredible outreach and mobility, and economy of production. They also reflect the changes in styles from Art Nouveau, Art Deco, Bauhaus and Russian Constructivism to the '60s psyche delia and Pop. The exhibition includes posters of Oskar Kokoschka, David Hockney, Richard Hamilton (This Is Tomorrow exhibition at the Whitechapel Art Gallery in 1965); Roy Lichtenstein (Crak! Now, Mes Petits ... Pour La France!, 1963), and Keith Haring. They are invaluable publicity for the latest plays, operas, concerts, even movies. Famous music posters include the album cover of punk rockers Sex Pistols' Never Mind the Bollocks by Jamie Reid and John Varnam (1977) and Martin Sharp's Mister Tambourine Man (1967). As propaganda, they have inspired revolutions, evoked nationalist fervour and boosted conscriptions. Savile Lumley's Daddy, What did YOU do in the Great War? is both an appeal to the conscience and national pride as well as a biting ridicule of the draft dodgers. Fougasse's Careless Talk Costs Lives brings home the importance of secrecy to overcome the enemy. Posters from the Bolshevik Revolution in the Soviet Union, American anti-war protests in Vietnam, the suffragette movement, ``ban the bomb'' campaign, the overthrow of Communism in Eastern Europe in 1989-90 have become key documents of some of the most tumultuous events of this century. Tomosz Sarnecki's High Noon 4 June 1989 election poster for Solidarity marks the political turning point in the former Eastern bloc enclave. There's also Ron Haeberie's photograph of the massacre with dead bodies strewn along a footpath with the terse captions: Q. And Babies? A. And Babies. Campaigns against VD and AIDS exhort machismo restraint or at least discreet precaution. The ubiquitous posters are also dominant in sports for mega-events such as the Olympics and the World Cup. One impressive work is that on mercurial former Manchester United striker Eric Cantona. Done with a twist when most Britons would be thinking of England wresting the World Cup, it says: ```66 was a great year for English football. Eric was born.'' Posters are at their most sophisticated in advertising. Some of the most provocative involve the Wonderbra and of course, Benetton's controversial and exploitative slew of confrontational realism. Besides Cheret, other big names in poster designs featured include the Beggarstaffs (Don Quixote, 1895), Frank Brangwyn, Cassandre (exponent of Art Deco), Ludwig Hohlwein, Tom Purvis, Graham Sutherland, and McKnight Kauffer. To mark the exhibition, a two-day conference, Posters: Persuasion and Subversion, will be held at the museum on June 12-13. For more information, visit the museum's website at http://www.vam.ac.uk The exhibition is open Tuesdays to Sundays from 10am to 5.45pm, and Mondays from noon to 5.45pm.

By STEPHANIE VAN DEN BERG
PARIS (AP) _ While rising Russian star Marat Safin played his fourth-round match on center court, he was being watched by a superstar _ Ronaldo, the Brazilian soccer sensation. What's more, Ronaldo was briefly joined by the teen queen of the French Open, Anna Kournikova, who lost earlier in the day. After a few games, Kournikova kissed Ronaldo on the cheek and left. It didn't take long for the crowd to notice the soccer star on the steps of the dignitaries box. They started chanting Ronaldo's name during the changeover. Though Safin had just lost the first set, he managed a big smile and a thumbs-up to Ronaldo. ``I'd never seen Ronaldo that close before.'' ___ GUGA: Last year's winner, Gustavo Kuerten, also looked in on Ronaldo at center court. The audience had some trouble spotting Guga under his new dreadlocks. Kuerten had said: ``If I win the tournament, I'll get dreadlocks.'' Even though he lost to Marat Safin in the second round, the idea had already taken hold. Guga followed up on his vow. He got his dreadlocks at the exclusive Jacques Dessanges salon at Roland Garros, where players can get free haircuts. ___ ANTI-WILLIAMS BANDWAGON: No. 10 women's seed Iva Majoli jumped on the anti-Williams bandwagon Monday when she was asked about the match between Arantxa Sanchez Vicario and Serena Williams. Sanchez Vicario won that match, and said afterward she was upset at Williams' attitude. Sanchez Vicario accused the 16-year-old Williams of not showing respect for her opponent. ``Serena and Venus have their own attitude,'' Majoli said of the Williams sisters. ``They're like, `Yeah, we're the best' ... I'm sure it's going to change in a year or two when they grow up.'' --- MASHED POTATOES: Hicham Arazi from Morocco beat Alberto Berasategui on Monday in a match in which most serves stayed under 150 kph (93 mph) for both players, unusually slow for the top men. When asked how his serve measures up, Arazi had some dietary tips for his questioners. ``I'm able to serve more than 150. I even reached 201 kph (125 mph) at one occasion. I've never been above 150? I can't believe it,'' he said. ``I'll need to eat more mashed potatoes tonight to catch up on muscles.'' (sab-jn)

LAST Wednesday's report that the Employees' Provident Fund might declare a lower dividend this year is not exactly good news to its over seven million members. Coming in the wake of last year's dividend of 6.7 per cent, the report, which cited Deputy Finance Minister Datuk Dr Affifuddin Omar as saying the EPF dividend payout this year might be affected by lower returns from its stock market investments adds more gloom to contributors who perceive their retirement nest-egg shrivelling. That gloom would be laced with pangs of frustration as members are painfully aware that savings in financial institutions yield much higher returns. Fixed deposits with finance companies for periods longer than a year earn more than 12 per cent per annum. Even commercial banks are providing interest as much as 10 per cent for one-month fixed deposits. Just as every cloud has a silver lining, EPF has provided that silver lining to its members to seek higher returns on their EPF savings but at their own risk. In 1996, the Fund introduced the Members Investment Savings Scheme that enables members to withdraw a portion of their savings to invest in approved unit trusts. As all EPF members know by now, savings with the Fund are trifurcated into three accounts. Account I, which is for retirement, captures 60 per cent of all savings. It is from this account that contributors can withdraw to invest in unit trusts. But members must have more than RM50,000 in Account I to be eligible to withdraw for investment. Even then, contributors can only take out 20 per cent of the amount, in multiples of RM1,000, that is in excess of RM50,000 in the account. Simply phrased, members must have at least RM55,000 in Account I to be eligible to withdraw the minimum of RM1,000 under the scheme. Which brings us to the logical question: how many among EPF contributors have RM100,000 or more in savings? The Fund, however, has never been keen to reveal any statistics. What we do have is a relatively old set of statistics on the savings profile of members as at the end of 1994. Those figures show about 33 per cent of 3.8 million active contributors had more than RM100,000 in savings with the EPF. At the other end of the scale more than 100,000 members have more than RM1 million in savings with the Fund. These statistics are not very significant to the primary aspect of this article, which is simply: how many EPF members have, so far, availed themselves of the the latest benefit provided by the Fund? Inquiries with three of the 30 approved unit trust managers reveal the response has been ``encouraging.'' Kuala Lumpur Mutual Fund Bhd, which manages 10 unit trusts, has so far attracted RM250 million from EPF members. OSK-UOB Bhd, which launched two unit trusts, has also secured funds from EPF members, though not in the scale of KL Mutual Fund which is the largest private unit trust managers in the country. Another fund manager, who declined to be named, expressed similiar views saying that it has attracted ``several millions'' from EPF members. These facts show that many members invest a portion of their savings in approved unit trusts. And a salient fact is that these members are willing to take the risk of transfering their savings in EPF to unit trusts in these difficult times. But they know that investing in unit trusts would yield higher returns than EPF could possibly declare. For instance, Permodalan Nasional Bhd, one of the approved fund managers in the EPF savings investment scheme, which manages the Amanah Saham Bumiputera has consistently declared dividends above 12 per cent. Even in the worst year, so far, in 1997, it gave 11.8 per cent. KL Mutual Fund, for another, has a distinguished record of providing an average of 10 per cent dividend on its income generating unit trusts over the last 30 years. Even late-comer, OSK-UOB is investing 72 per cent of the RM10 million it has so far attracted in fixed deposits that would yield 10 per cent or more in interest. Clearly then, EPF's savings investment scheme can increase the quantum of members' retirement nest-egg. But the amount they could invest in unit trusts, under current rules is relatively paltry. So the question is why should the Fund place a 20 per cent cap on the amount members could transfer to unit trusts. In drawing up this scheme, EPF realised that members who have substantial savings are mature enough to decide how their monies should be invested. The Fund has realised that despite its huge resources, it cannot give even the eight per cent dividend it once declared over four years in the early 90s. Since then the dividends has been 7.5 per cent (1995), 7.7 per cent (1996) and 6.7 per cent (1997). Surely then, EPF should allow members who have substantial savings in the fund to withdraw as much money as they can to substantiate their retirement nest-egg. Let them withdraw the total amount they have in excess of RM50,000 in Account I. The returns on investments in unit trusts will then truly be significant.

Judge Lim Yee Lan said there were material contradictions and inconsistencies in the evidence given by the victim and her mother. JAKARTA (JP): Journalists from the banned newsweeklies Tempo and DeTik have seized on rejuvenated freedoms of expression by announcing their intention of reestablishing the publications despite financial constraints. DeTik, published in tabloid format, may be back on newsstands within two weeks. Tempo magazine is expected to republish in a revised format in six months. Former general manager of DeTik Eros Djarot said the tabloid was set to be back in business within a fortnight even without a publication license. ``We had planned to (hit the streets) on Wednesday (June 3) but there are still legal matters to take care of,'' Eros told The Jakarta Post Saturday. Republishing without a license, Eros said, ``is a witness to our consistent stand to advocate the freedom of the press, that no power can tear us (DeTik) apart''. Eros said he hoped the plans could be realized around June 10. Goenawan Mohamad, the former chief editor of Tempo, conceded it would not be easy to start up the magazine again in the economic crisis. Goenawan, who was accompanied by secretary of Tempo's Alumni Foundation Putu Setia, the magazine's deputy chief editor Fikri Jufri and Zulkifli Lubis, said a special team had been established for handling the logistics of restarting publication. He said a group of friends had stated its willingness to finance the reestablishment of the magazine, which he pledged would be different from the host of newsweeklies on the market. ``Why republish the magazine if we do not offer anything new?'' Goenawan said. Fikri said this was an important consideration as several newsmagazines,taking up Tempo's logo and newswriting style, appeared shortly after its permit was revoked. He said the new edition of the magazine must woo readers with fresh draws. Freedom Goenawan, Fikri and Putu agreed in a meeting at the Tempo Cafe in East Jakarta yesterday that freedom of the media was imperative. ``Whether Tempo will be republished or not is unimportant, the important thing is that the government must now guarantee freedom of the press,'' Goenawan said. He urged the government to abolish a ministerial decree allowing revocation of publication permits. Tempo was closed down in June 1994, together with Editor and DeTik. Tempo was faulted for its critical report of the government's purchase of used ships from Germany, while the banning of the two other publications was attributed to ``administrative violations''. DeTik was owned by PT Detik Bangun Media Prestasi under the Yayasan Mulya foundation. In 1996, the now defunct Target tabloid, with a strikingly similar layout, was published and touted by many as DeTik's replacement after gaining a new license under a new company. Eros at the time denied that Target -- with majority shares owned by Agung Laksono, the director of the private AN-Teve television station and an executive of the ruling Golkar grouping -- was a substitute for DeTik. Agung is now state minister of youth affairs and sports.

LOCAL corporations, which had been complacent in managing their risks in the past, need to `urgently' enhance their financial risk management capabilities to protect themselves against volatile market conditions. Malaysian Monetary Exchange Bhd general manager Mohd Azwar Mahmud said in times of market turbulence, such as that experienced by the regional and local market recently, managing risk in passive and reactive ways could no longer be adequate for them. Mohd Azwar said corporations have to be more proactive and prudent in managing risk and one of the ways to do it is by using hedging activities in their operations. ``If they do not hedge, they will be caught by surprise should there be any sudden moves in the market. Eventually, if the moves are adverse it will be calculated in their bottom line (earnings). ``This was seen with the results of corporations which suffered unbelievable magnitude of losses due to the volatility in the market.'' Mohd Azwar said the financial market in this country would ``never ever'' be the same again. ``The rules of the game have changed and it is now about exposure to financial risk by choice and not by chance,'' he told reporters at the Corporate Treasurers' Colloquium in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. The event was jointly organised by MME and the Malaysian Association of Corporate Treasurers. Mohd Azwar added that unless these corporations changed their attitude and adapted to the changes in the market, it would destroy them. ``Even if the environment is stable and there is no compelling reason for them to manage their risk, they still need to be more proactive and prudent,'' he said. He pointed out that the application of derivative instruments in general requires a comprehensive training programme at all levels to ensure it is being managed professionally. The professionals must be willing to take more proactive role towards minimising risk exposures for the corporations, he added. He said MME in its efforts to promote the usage of derivative products as risk management tools, has been working together with financial institutions as well as corporations to set up their derivative desks. ``What we are doing now is getting local corporations to be more adventurous and aggressive by shifting and expanding their risk management capabilities,'' Mohd Azwar added.

Sarwo Edhi Wibowo, the late commander of the Army's special force RPKAD (now Kopassus). Susilo also reminded the public that before the poll could take place, the existing laws that govern a general election should first be amended as they recognize only three contestants. They are Golkar, the United Development Party and the Indonesian Democratic Party. ``Elections should be held as soon as possible but bear in mind whether six months would be enough time to change the laws, especially if there are new parties emerging,'' he said. Amien, who was accompanied to the gathering by economist Faisal Basri and Minister of Food, Drugs and Agriculture A.M. Saefuddin, said: ``The administration, even though it is a transitional one, still needs both domestic and international support in order to be able to carry out programs to cope with the crisis.'' ``It would not be fair to attribute all the economic problems to the post-Soeharto administration as many of the difficulties are a legacy of the previous government,'' he said, reported Antara. ``What would be fair, in order to set the economic wheels moving again in the shortest possible time, is giving an opportunity and support for economic-restoration programs,'' he said. This stance does not mean the campaign for better order in the political, legal and constitutional system should stop, he added. ``State policies, including in the economy, are, after all, the final results of an interaction of various interest groups, political forces, the business circle as well as the bureaucracy, which all operate in a certain legal-constitutional order,'' he said. Forgiveness In another part of his address, Amien called on Indonesians to ``forgive'' former president Soeharto, to give the latter peace of mind now that he has stepped down. On one condition: Soeharto should donate to the nation any of his wealth which might have been amassed illegally. ``Even though there were so many negative sides to his administration, it's undeniable that he has done the country a great service during his 32-year rule,'' Amien said in answer to a student's question. Amien had made the same call earlier this month while asserting that Soeharto's children, however, did not merit the same compassion and that they should face punishment should the court find them guilty of any crimes, including corruption, collusion and nepotism. Amien called on the former president to voluntarily donate his wealth -- and live on 5 percent of the total -- so the country no longer had to ``beg'' for assistance from donor agencies, such as the International Monetary Fund. A foreign media once estimated Soeharto's and his family's fortune worths US$40 billion. ``If he could do that, then Insya Allah (God willing), maybe the Indonesian people could find it in their hearts to pardon him,'' said Amien, who, on Saturday, called for a ban on the former president and his family from traveling abroad. Separately, a lesser-known politician, Zakiruddin Djamin of the National Unity Savior Institute, suggested yesterday that Habibie should personally approach Soeharto and urge him to donate his wealth to help the country rebuild its economy. ``Habibie should remind Soeharto of the promise he once made that he was willing to sacrifice his life, let alone his belongings, for the nation,'' Djamin said, reported Antara.

KUALA LUMPUR, Fri. - Universiti Malaya today refuted claims by its Academic Staff Association that the university's franchise programme for the matriculation of science students lacked transparency and that applicants had not been made aware of the programme. The university's public relations officer V.T. Ratnam, in dismissing claims of the programme's haphazard implementation, said all students had been informed in advance of the private institutions they would be placed with once all places at the university were filled. BC-Sports-Soccer-WC98-World Cup Growth,0809
PREVIEWING THE WORLD CUP As it grows, World Cup finds new markets, problems AP Sports Writer
RETRANSMITTING to all needing By LARRY SIDDONS
NEW YORK (AP) _ The force that rocks the world occurs for one month every four years _ and it gets bigger and bigger each time they put up the nets. When the World Cup is held for the 16th time this summer, more teams will play before more people and generate more money than ever before. Even grander things are up next _ a cup staged by two nations and earning billions of dollars in TV and sponsor fees. Its world championship puts soccer on an even higher stage than normal. By the time the title is decided in the new Stade de France outside Paris on July 12, a total audience of more than 17 billion is expected to have watched World Cup matches on TV, more than any other event by far. But there are fears that what one official calls ``the No. 1 passion event in sports'' may be getting too big and that fundamental changes are needed to protect its global stature. ``We are running out of countries capable of hosting the cup, and the more teams you add, the lower the common quality of the field,'' said Kier Radnadge, editor of World Soccer magazine. ``Probably the highest quality of the tournament was back in 1970.'' Seventy years ago, there was no World Cup. The title of soccer's best went to the winner of the Olympic tournament. But on May 26, 1928, a group of officials led by Jules Rimet of France agreed to stage a World Cup, and later awarded the first tournament to Uruguay, the reigning Olympic champ, for 1930. Of the 13 entries in that initial edition, only four came from outside the Western Hemisphere. A total of 435,000 fans watched the games, all but a couple played in a single stadium. There was no TV, of course, and organizers were pleasently surprised that they could pay all their bills. When defending-champion Brazil and Scotland kick off France '98 the evening of June 10, they will lead a field stretching from South Africa to South Korea. The 32 teams, double the number of just 20 years ago, will play in 10 stadiums, total capacity 1.81 million. Television networks around the world paid approximately dlrs 450 million dollars in rights fees to FIFA, soccer's world governing body. Organizers are confident of covering their dlrs 270 million budget from private funds. Two things spurred this growth _ TV and the emergence of sports as perhaps the single largest unifying force of late-20th century life. Starting with the first satellite transmissions of live matches in 1970, the World Cup became a truly worldwide event. ``It's always been that soccer was the most popular sport,'' said Jim Trecker, deputy secretary general of the U.S. Soccer Federation. ``But it was in the 1970s and '80s, through television, that the World Cup was universally disseminated and allowed all people to participate.'' ``Everything that's happened technically and socially in the last half-century has suited the game exactly,'' said Radnadge, who has covered the Cup from his London base since 1966. ``Sport has become one of the great movements of the 20th century.'' That universal audience _ not even moon landings, the Olympics, or even Princess Diana's funeral come close in sheer numbers _ has attracted commercial sponsors with wide-open checkbooks to the World Cup. ``It's just so big that you can't afford not to be involved in it,'' Radnadge said. So rich is FIFA that every four years it gives each of its 198 national members dlrs 1 million to help develop soccer in their country. ``To stretch the math a little, that's a 200 million-dollar giveaway,'' Trecker said. ``That's pretty good.'' And that number is set to explode. Next year, a new TV contract kicks in, worth a total of dlrs 2.5 billion for the World Cups in 2002 and 2006. FIFA will use a good deal of that money to promote grass-roots soccer programs and boost particiation and fan programs for women's soccer, a rapidly growing element of the sport. ``In terms of both the potential number of participants and the potential market, it makes perfect sense,'' Trecker said. But with growth and success have come increased demands and expectations. Radnadge said the list of countries that can realistically stage a World Cup now is down to a half dozen _ the United States, France, Germany, England, Italy and Spain. Trecker said it's time for FIFA to consider spending some of its money to ease the financial burden of local organziers, especially with talk about holding the tournament one day in South Africa or China. ``It think it might be wise to change the equation so those countries that are economically challenged can still play host,'' he said.

BC-Sports-Soccer-WC98-Bonuses,0681
PREVIEWING THE WORLD CUP World Cup mixes lure of the goal with that of cash
RETRANSMITTING to all needing By CIARAN GILES Associated Press Writer
For some soccer players, just reaching the World Cup is prize enough. For others, it is also the gateway to a lucrative feast. And where money lurks, controversy is bound to be close by. Over the decades, financial bonuses for World Cup performances have soared to such an extent that many national federations now prefer to remain tightlipped regarding the matter. Fearing a repeat of disputes with players that bonus negotiations triggered in previous tournaments, record four-time champion Brazil, backed by multinational sports product giant Nike, claims there will be none this time round for the big `R's _ Ronaldo, Romario, Rivaldo, Roberto Carlos _ or their teammates. But few believed them, especially after it was added that the bonuses wouldn't be revealed even if they did exist. Most suspect the South Americans' compensation will tally closely with that being promised to their Italian counterparts, for whom a a fourth championship would land a tidy sum of dlrs 278,000, nearly dlrs 80,000 more than squad members earned for winning the 1982 World Cup. But news reports say the Italian stars, including Roberto Baggio and Alessandro Del Piero, have been warned they won't get a single lira unless they reach the semifinals of the 32-team competition. Once there, however, each player stands to receive dlrs 55,500 each while even a place in the final would garner them dlrs 195,000. A little less demanding is host France, whose federation has reportedly set a quarterfinal threshold before unleashing the centimes. A place in the final eight would merit a dlrs 50,000 reward for each player and that figure will quadruple should they get to the final. Germany admits it is offering incentives from the start. Federation spokesman Michael Novak said each player would receive dlrs 270,000 for winning the title but also will get dlrs 25,000 just for getting beyond the first round. Neighboring Netherlands averted a repeat of the dispute that marred its run-up to the 1994 Cup by agreeing to a bonus package ``that satisfies both parties,'' according to team captain Frank de Boer. Reports said the KNVB originally offered a dlrs 70,000 bonus for winning the Cup _ less than what was agreed to for winning the European Championship in 1996 _ but eventually agreed to increase it to dlrs 100,000. Meanwhile, some teams are offering more for getting to the second round than others can for winning the trophy. Playing in its third World Cup, the United States, reportedly has pledged a whopping dlrs 250,000 to its players who have been with the team all the way through qualifying if the side manages to emerge from the three-game first round, in which it faces Germany, Yugoslavia and Iran. Some teams at the other end of the scale, however, are still squabbling over payments from the 1994 Cup. Just last month, FIFA was warning modest Cameroon that unless it paid former keeper Joseph Antoine Bell dlrs 74,000 owed him since 1994 it could be disqualified from the tournament in France. Bell caused a rumpus in the United States when he led a team revolt prior to its game against Brazil demanding Cameroon pay promised bonuses. Cameroon has pledged to resolve the matter. Neighboring Nigeria also found itself embroiled in a row the same month as players demanded their bonus be increased from dlrs 6,000 to 8,000 per game. Such disputes have led some to argue that team performances are too dependent on the dollar awards. ``Spain can't be world champions because we don't earn the most money. Brazilians earn much more,'' said cynical Spanish coach Javier Clemente. For him, eighth place would suffice for Spain, for which players would receive dlrs 73,000 each. The team's members have nonetheless been pledged a total of 280,000 dlrs each if they were to win the gold statuette.

PREVIEWING THE WORLD CUP World Cup 2006 a key factor in FIFA presidential vote
RETRANSMITTING to all needing By ERICA BULMAN Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ With eight years and two World Cups still to go, the host for the 2006 tournament is likely to be decided long before the decision is announced two years from now. In the fierce competition leading up to the FIFA presidential elections in Paris on June 8, the 2006 World Cup could figure prominently in the outcome. Both candidates have expressed support for different venues, with FIFA General Secretary Sepp Blatter speaking out for a World Cup in Africa and the UEFA President Lennart Johansson pushing for its return to Europe. Votes at the presidential elections could hinge on the issue. Though the African Football Confederation (CAF) officially supports Johansson, his backing from those nations appears to be disintegrating. Johansson's racial comments during a trip to South Africa in November combined with his support of a European World Cup final in 2006 have endangered key African votes, with several of its 51 nations having hinted they would support Blatter in the secret ballot among 198 members. Johansson saw his election campaign take another blow when CONCACAF announced in mid-May its decision to back Blatter. Liberian player George Weah, who plays for Italian club Internazionale of Milan and a former FIFA Player of the Year, also has announced he will endorse Blatter and try to convince African nations to do likewise. South Africa has from the beginning benefitted from the support of retiring FIFA President Joao Havelange. Havelange, who is stepping down after 24 years as head of FIFA, created a stir when he virtually promised South Africa the 2006 championship. Blatter has echoed Havelange's sentiments, indicating he would strongly support an African bid. Blatter said it was not right that he should promise the competition to Africa including South Africa, Morocco, Nigeria or Egypt. But he said if they had the necessary infrastructure, they should have it. ``I cannot promise anything but I said I would work for that,'' he said. ``We must do something for African football.'' Johansson even has angered at least one European vote, England, having openly endorsed Germany. It's a statement Blatter has tried to use against him. ``How can the Africans vote for someone who has already said he would give the World Cup to Germany?'' Blatter said. Once considered the front-runners of the chase to host the 2006 World Cup, Germany and England have split the European bid, only strenghtening the prospect of having it staged in South Africa. Both European countries already have hosted the World Cup, England in 1966, and Germany in 1974. Not to be overlook in the chase is Brazil, the four-time champion, which can also expect to receive strong support. Other competition may come from Australia which also has expressed interest in hosting the event. But clearly, staging one of the world's largest events in South Africa, backed by President Nelson Mandela, is an enticing prospect _ not only for FIFA but for the International Olympic Committee, which also loudly has applauded the nation's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games. Since the first World Cup in 1930, the finals have been staged in Europe nine times, in South America four times, North America three times and Asia (Japan-South Korea) will be organizing it for the first time in 2002. Africa and Oceania are the only regions to have never hosted the tournament. The decision on the host country for the 2006 World Cup will be made by the 24 members of FIFA's Executive Committee in June of 2000.

BC-Rwanda-Economy,0528
Rwanda says stability in danger unless it gets debt relief
By HRVOJE HRANJSKI Associated Press Writer
KIGALI, Rwanda (AP) _ Without international support, the Rwandan government will not be able to service a dlrs 1 billion debt and maintain economic and political stability, the finance minister said. In a speech prepared for an international meeting of donors in Stockholm, Sweden, on Tuesday and Wednesday, Finance Minister Donald Kaberuka appealed for dlrs 767 million in the next three years to sustain the cost of reforms. The World Bank has warned the national reconciliation and prevention of renewed ethnic violence will depend on success of the reforms. ``Crucially, the debt relief is itself ... restricting the ability of the government to undertake the critical social interventions required to bring about social reconciliation, reintegration and the necessary sustainable human development,'' Kaberuka said, according to a copy of his speech made available to The Associated Press on Monday. So far, donors have been satisfied with the government's record in restoring peace after a 1994 genocide, resettling more than 1 million refugees and stabilizing the economy. But economists say one of the key constrains lies in Rwanda's inability to service dlrs 1.2 billion in external debt and a high level of military spending at a time when the Tutsi-led army is fighting Hutu rebels. Rwanda has been paying dlrs 17 million each year to service the debt, most of it to multilateral creditors such as the International Development Association, the African Development Bank and the World Bank. The money was acquired by the former Hutu-led government responsible for the 1994 slaughter of 500,000 minority Tutsis. In July 1994, Tutsi rebels won power and started on an ambitious recovery plan to sell state-owned property, restructure civil service and reintegrate thousands of former Hutu soldiers and civil servants to win their confidence. But Kaberuka said the debt burden was too heavy too sustain and insufficient to clear Rwanda from its debt in a foreseeable future. In his speech, he appealed for a special case for Rwanda, under which the international donor community should write off dlrs 97.5 million in debt arrears and establish a Multilateral Debt Trust Fund to help finance the multilateral debt service until 2001. Under the proposal, the trust fund would be administered by the World Bank to ensure accountability and render reports to donors. If successful, the measures would help Rwanda qualify in three years for a debt relief. Such debt relief, under a World Bank-IMF program known as Highly Indebted Poor Countries' Initiative, has already been granted to Uganda and Mozambique, both credited with economic reforms. The amount of money used for servicing the debt would enable Rwanda to meet urgent social needs; support the victims of genocide and the cost of demobilization; and to finance the transition from crisis to sustainable economic growth, the World Bank said.
