PREVIEWING THE WORLD CUP Rimet's tournament returns, bringing back fading glory AP Special Correspondent
RETRANSMITTING to all needing By MORT ROSENBLUM
PARIS (AP) _ The 1998 World Cup brings France a last flourish of badly needed glory in the fading millennium, and the French are sparing no effort to wrap the games in grandeur. ``The World Cup must stamp our history,'' President Jacques Chirac said in January, inaugurating the new Stade de France near Paris with all the pomp of a Sun King opening Versailles Palace. For months now, officials have been spouting superlatives. This time, 32 teams compete instead of the 24 that have taken the field since 1982. With rebroadcasts, 37 billion people will watch at least some play, twice the audience of the Olympics Games. Over 33 days, 64 matches are scheduled in 10 stadiums from the soccer-mad little mining town of Lens in the north to the ancient Mediterranean port of Marseilles. A half billion dollars went into the Stade de France, an 80,000-seat concrete flying saucer hovering near Paris, where play will begin and end with elaborate fanfare. Another billion was raised from commercial sponsors, tickets and public funds for the French Organizing Committee (CFO) and facilities. Technicians laid 2.5 million kilometers (1.5 million miles) of fiber optic cable. But for most Frenchmen, the best part of the 16th World Cup is that it is theirs, a planetary platform to wave the blue, white and red Tricolor and a chance to throw the biggest dinner party ever. French football fans are praying for an unlikely victory for more than the usual reasons. A French journalist thought up the idea of a world federation in 1904. Two Frenchmen were behind the first Cup, in Uruguay in 1930, and a French striker scored the first goal. Michel Platini's goal in 1986 helped beat Brazil to put Les Bleus into the semifinals. But the French have never reached the final. A last game between, say, France and Brazil, would make their millennium. Even many who are fleeing for the duration are happy about the venue. As France melts into a European Union and Americanisms muscle into the culture, Paris will be the capital of the world. From the opening extravaganza to the final frenzy, the tournament promises to be distinctly French. Among the official suppliers is Yves Saint Laurent. There is an appointed purveyor of dairy products. ``We did have one problem at the stadium inauguration,'' allowed Pierre Parisot, director of the Stade de France. ``The hot dogs were terrible. Cold, all wrong.'' But, he added, spectators seemed pleased with the four posh Parisian caterers who served 11,000 meals. And patrons praised the wine cellar of the panoramic gourmet restaurant, run by Lenotre. Along the Champs Elysees, Frenchmen jostle with tourists to buy pins, T-shirts and blue-white-red soccer balls from an official World Cup stuff shop. Upon reflection, officials withdrew the official World Cup knife. Just about every item is emblazoned with the ubiquitous mascot: Footix, a cocky-looking little blue and red rooster with a goofy grin. Huge streetcorner posters push the slogan, ``It's not every day that we welcome the whole world.'' On one, a come-hither beauty in a slinky white sheath holds a tray at a lustrous Paris bistro. Perhaps to add an extra French touch, truck drivers and transport unions have threatened to strike during the tournament, choking off access to the stadiums. One popular booklet advises visitors how not to get cheated by merchants, hotelkeepers and taxi drivers. Another instructs locals to say ``moutchas gracias'' and its equivalent in a score of tongues. On television, talking heads give soccer new social and political dimensions. Sociologist Christian Bromberger told a colloquium he saw a ``footballization of society.'' He said, ``It is a profound game, a condensed source of all emotions: joy, anguish, revolt, injustice.'' Many fear it is also a source of violence, and police have made complex plans to contain hooligans or rowdy fans who do not make it into stadiums. For a while, tourism officials urged Britons to come without tickets and watch matches on outdoor screens. Someone thought about that again and changed the message: Stay home. Tickets are already a sore point. After the European Union and other countries roasted France for keeping the lion's share of the tickets for Frenchmen, organizers scraped up 110,000 tickets for foreigners to order by phone. The April day they went on sale, however, 20 million calls swamped the 90 operators, and it took two weeks before the tickets could be sold to the lucky few who managed to get through. In London, the Daily Mirror reported that an elderly Englishman destroyed finger ligaments by repeated dialling. Of 2.5 million tickets, two-thirds were allotted to Frenchmen, and another 12 percent to the organizing committee and commercial affiliates. Tour operators got another 8 percent. Tickets to early matches went on sale in France in 1996, and were sold out a year ago. In December, a lottery among Frenchmen determined who could buy tickets for the nine deciding matches. For instance, real estate executive Pierre Macchi and a friend each applied for four tickets to the finals. Both wound up with two seats. ``You can imagine,'' he said, ``we were ecstatic.'' He paid dlrs 600 per ticket and could have sold the two extras for three times that. Instead, he gave them to an equally ecstatic friend for merely twice the face value, which reduced his cost to zero. Tickets or not, fans are swarming to France which, with annual arrivals of 67 million, is already the world's most visited country. By May, 360,000 hotel rooms were booked, mostly in Paris. The show starts June 9 with a Festival of Football, a citywide splash of color and sound climaxing at the Place de la Concorde, a sweep of dramatic stone and space at the heart of Paris. Details are guarded with the zeal of a state secret. Four parades will start at classic monuments, with music and costumes of dozens of cultures blending with a French accent. In the nation of Liberty, Equality and Fraternity, the festival's theme is Excitement, Universality, and Sharing. There are some rubs. None of the 12 official sponsors, and only four of the eight suppliers, are French. The games' official restaurant is McDonalds. Soccer-hating Frenchmen have formed a tongue-in-cheek association called, ``The Cup Is Full,'' to plan alternative activities in June and July. If popular, the group represents a clear minority. Starting June 10, first-round matches will be played in nine provincial cities chosen for their football traditions, their ample stadiums, and their accessibility. Each has tried to outdo the other to remain in visitors' memories. The largest stadium outside Paris is the wide open 60,000-seat Velodrome in Marseilles. But the most passionate may be in Lens, just outside of Lille at the top of France. The 47,000-seat stadium can hold 1 1-2 times the city's population. And early in May, when Lens won the French league title, most townsfolk were there at 3 a.m. when the team returned home.

PREVIEWING THE WORLD CUP Two-time World Cup runner-up aims again for top spot
RETRANSMITTING to all needing By MIKE CORDER Associated Press Writer
AMSTERDAM, Netherlands (AP) _ Another major soccer tournament. Another talent-packed Dutch soccer side. Another near miss? From trusty Ajax goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar to star strikers Dennis Bergkamp and Patrick Kluivert, the Netherlands _ World Cup runnerup in 1974 and 1978 _ has the quality to take the title. The question _ as always _ is whether they also have the temperament to play as a team rather than 11 talented individuals. Ajax Amsterdam's Danish coach, Morten Olsen, recently said that the Dutch do not have the character to take soccer's most prestigious title. That was evident at the last major soccer tournament, Euro 96, when players in the fancied Dutch squad reportedly split along black-white lines and midfielder Edgar Davids was sent home for publicly criticizing coach Guus Hiddink. This time around, Hiddink is attempting to shield his 22-man squad from the pressures of the tournament, while giving them a chance to let off steam during the long campaign. Hiddink has commandeered a hotel in the mountains above Monte Carlo as the Dutch base this summer. ``Players will have privacy, but will also be able to get out and meet people. We want to avoid them getting bored,'' he said. After nearly two years on the international sidelines as punishment for the Euro 96 bust up, Davids' form has been so good with Italian giant Juventus that he now is a near certainty to play. Davids is likely to share the midfield with old Ajax teammates Clarence Seedorf, now with Real Madrid, and Ronald de Boer. The hard-working Juventus star is seen as an ideal defensive foil for De Boer and Seedorf, who both tend to push forward looking to create or score goals. In Ajax's Van der Sar, the Dutch have one of the world's most reliable goalkeepers. The bean-pole Amsterdammer has conceded just 20 goals in 33 league matches this season. The Dutch also boast the world's most expensive defender, Jaap Stam, the PSV Eindhoven center back who will play for Manchester United next season. Off the field, Hiddink has assembled an impressive bench of assistant coaches with a wealth of major tournament experience. Ex-internationals Johan Neeskens, Ronald Koeman and Frank Rijkaard are key members of the Dutch party. Rijkaard's appointment was seen as an effort to boost the morale of young players like Seedorf, Kluivert and Davids who share Rijkaard's Surinamese roots. In his last year with Ajax, Rijkaard acted as a seasoned mentor for the young guns. His calm head and experience could be crucial for the Dutch who always carry a huge weight of expectation from their fanatical orange-clad fans. Not only do the supporters expect their team to win, they expect them to win in style, playing the kind of attacking ``total football'' that took the Dutch to two World Cup finals in the 1970s.

HIS name has been stepped on, dragged through the mud, and smeared in just about every way - mostly by children. But he is not some unfortunate victim of malicious mouthing - he is in fact, Thomas J. Bata, whose name adorns every school-going child's shoes. At 83, Bata, who opened the newest retail outlet at KLCC in Kuala Lumpur on Saturday, is a sprightly, browned version of Santa Claus, snowy hair and all. Conspicuously absent are the elves, dancing at his fingertips. ``Yes, I wore Bata shoes as a child,'' he says, answering a million-dollar question. And now? ``Now I mostly wear Bata shoes. But I also wear other shoes because that is the only way to make a comparison,'' he says triumphantly, neatly sidestepping what could have been an awkward question. ``And,'' he says warming up, ``sometimes I wear a different shoe on each foot!'' Bata was born into a shoe-making family. Twelve generations ago, an ancestral member of the Bata clan decided that farm prices were too low, and that shoes were a better business. In 1894, Thomas' father, Tomas, converted that hand-operated business to a machine-manufactured one, and the Bata shoe empire was born. ``See, I have even developed a shoemaker's thumb,'' he says, waving a thumb that curves sharply backwards, usually acquired by cobblers who cut leather by hand. Born in Prague, Czechoslovakia, just before the First World War, Bata's childhood was filled with sporting activities like horseback riding, skiing in the winter and swimming in the summer. His early schooling took place in England and Switzerland, and his degrees (including a Doctor of Sciences) were obtained in Czechoslovakia. At the age of 24, he emigrated to Canada, where he has lived for the past 59 years. His English, though flawless, is still heavily-inflected with an Eastern European accent. And he is still as active as ever. Hours after stepping off a plane from Oslo, Norway, he entered the interview room, leaning heavily on a cane. One could have been forgiven for assuming that this was a sign of age. But no, the cane was because he ``skied stupidly'' and is at the tail-end of recovery from a broken leg. As the only child, was the pressure on him to take over the business? ``I never really wanted to get out of it,'' he says, again circumventing the real question. But would his father have been disappointed if he hadn't shown any interest? ``Perhaps. But if I had wanted to become a doctor, for example, I don't think he would have stopped me. And if I had become a good doctor, he would even have been pleased.'' However, there seems to have been no danger of a lack of interest. At age 16, the younger Bata got directly involved when, on his own drawing-board, he tried to improve the models the company was then producing. He remained as involved in designing until the age of 60, which means that those still in school in 1975 may have worn shoes created by the man himself. Bata shoes first made their appearance in Malaya in 1930, when a retail outlet was opened in Capitol Street, Singapore. Through many periods of corporate restructuring and growth, Bata Malaysia, which manufactures and retails, was established. To date, school shoes remain the best-selling item. Due to its ubiquitous quality here, and its seeming absence in some Western countries, many have mistaken Bata for a local brand. But although Bata may not retail under its own name in these places, the company supplies some models to other retailers, such as Marks and Spencers. In fact, in Indonesia, Thailand and Chile, Bata also makes shoes for Adidas, Nike and New Balance. However, there is no likelihood that the Bata brand-name will be phased out. Transcending the boundaries of icon, it has become an institution. My wordprocessing programme which underlines Prada with a disapproving red line, has no such trouble with Bata. In the words of Thomas J. Bata: ``We do not aspire to be in a super luxury class. Our ambition is to serve a wider range of the population with first-class, progressive products at a reasonable price.'' Bata Bites: Bata Shoe Organisation Ltd is named after its Czechoslovakian founder Tomas Bata. The company's headquarters are in Toronto, Canada. The first Bata outlet in Malaysia was opened in Jalan Pudu, Kuala Lumpur. Bata has two factories in Malaysia, one in Klang, the other in Seremban. In 1997, Bata Malaysia exported 2.5 million pairs of shoes to Europe and North America. Italy alone bought nearly 500,000 pairs. In the same year, 11.5 million pairs, largely school shoes, were sold in Malaysia. Twenty-five per cent of total annual sales come from Asia. There are 250 Bata stores in the country. Besides Selangor and the Federal Territory, which have 60 stores, the state with the largest number of stores is Johor, with 30. Sabah has the least number of outlets, at 13. The latest Bata outlet which is 2,700 square metres big, opened at KLCC in Kuala Lumpur on Saturday. This year, Bata Malaysia will open more big outlets in: Miri, Kuantan, Johor Baru, Ipoh, Malacca, Kuala Terengganu, Kota Kinabalu and Penang. Bata Malaysia also runs Athlete's World, which carries a variety of athletic products.

R. GUNA could go on and on about Remington Steel - not the TV sleuth, but his favourite typewriter. His Remington is about 45 years old, of semi-standard issue, weighs slightly over three kilogrammes and is silent. Guna also has a Remington Rand, a portable, in his shop. Both Remingtons can fetch up to RM1,000 each. Guna loves old typewriters which others would dismiss as junk. The Remington and Royal typewriters were both popular in the 1950s, he says. The American-made Royal is distinguished by its letters on cardboard, placed on the transparent keytops. It is neat and smaller in size, and was popular in the past with planters who bought them for their wives to type those lengthy letters home. Look around the shop and one can find names like Imperial (British-made), Roneo (UK), Hermes (Swiss) and Olivetti (Italy). The shop is a mass of old keyboards, spare parts and gadgets haphazardly heaped along dusty shelves. Guna inherited the business in 1977 after the death of his father. As he was the only one interested in carrying on the business, he quit his job as a costing and store clerk at McAlister's in Jalan Kidd and, with the help of his father's friend Khoo Swee Yong, started repairing and reconditioning typewriters. His father had started the shop in 1951, servicing typewriters for plantations, banks, Government departments and hospitals. For instance, said Guna, ``we have been making office calls at United Plantations since 1957. It was then known as Bernam Oil Plantations.'' From servicing of typewriters, customers later asked him to repair those which had broken down. A repair job could take two months and cost from RM300 to RM600 inclusive of spare parts, he said. ``Many people opt to repair these `antiques' because they trust these machines more than modern ones,'' he said. Guna has lovingly restored, polished and fine-tuned machines left by customers who never returned for them. Restoration work is time-consuming and has to be done on a trial-and-error basis. He said a typewriter between 30 and 40 years old can be sold for between RM800 and RM1,000 to collectors and writers. Some banks, for instance, still keep their old typewriters for sentimental reasons. Added Guna: ``One can ascertain a typewriter's quality by the impression of the typewritten characters. ``The old ones also tend to be rust-free since they are made of steel. The type of ribbons used also differs,'' he said.

AFTER operating for 90 years, the Escoy Smelting Sdn Bhd tin ore smelting factory in Penang closed down at the end of March. The 7.7ha plant in Jalan Datuk Keramat shut down its furnaces and will spend the next two months clearing up. It will open a plant in Phuket, South Thailand, to take advantage of the cheaper labour there. Escoy managing director Datuk Nazir Ariff said the decision to move to Phuket was made a few years ago. Among the reasons were that the Penang plant was located right in the city centre, and also the fact that there was a shortage of tin ore resulting in very little smelting being carried out. Nazir said the services of the 500 workers had been terminated. The company, he said, has yet to decide on development plans for the former smelting site. Escoy, whose parent company is Amalgamated Metal Corporation Private Ltd, London, was formerly known as Datuk Keramat Smelting and prior to that as Eastern Smelting when it was established in 1908. This international tin smelting concern began as Seng Kee Tin Smelting Works in 1897, and its founder was Lee Chin Ho, the first Chinese smelter to adopt the use of European reveberatory furnaces. Tin was transferred from the company's mines at Gopeng, Perak, and also from the mines of South Thailand and smelted into ingots for re-export. In 1907, the company was floated as Eastern Smelting, a limited liability company with a capital of $500,000, attracting North Malaya's largest tin magnates to its board, including the renowned Khaw family. Chin Ho lived in a building built in 1908 which later came to be known as Birch House, while his relatives and workers lived in the surrounding row of houses in Chin Ho Square. It is believed that the house was named after Sir Ernest Woodford Birch who was the British Resident of Perak from 1904 until he retired in 1911. Birch was the eldest son of J.W.W. Birch, the Straits Settlement colonial secretary and British Resident of Perak who was assassinated in Pasir Salak in November 1875. Chin Ho gave up his stake in the firm in 1910 but continued to live at Birch House until it was taken over as the company offices in the 1930s. It was given a modern facade after the war. JAKARTA (JP): Councilors and a contractor urged the city administration Saturday to stop the rampant collusion, corruption, cronyism and nepotism in the awarding of its development projects. They argued that the time had come for the administration to promote clean governance in line with the growing spirit of political and economic reforms. Amarullah Asbah, head of the City Council's Commission C for financial affairs, said the administration had for years been notorious for red-tape that spurred a high-cost economy. ``It's public knowledge that many projects are awarded without fair bidding,'' he said. ``People wanting to participate in a bid have to deal with countless (people at) desks to succeed.'' The administration should move fast to end the corrupt practices to improve its image, said Amarullah from the Golkar faction. Lukman F. Mokoginta, head of the Indonesian Democratic Party (PDI) faction, said many projects were awarded to certain companies by way of engineered bidding. ``Projects are awarded through collusion, cronyism and nepotism involving officials,'' he said. Such practices are rampant not only in the city administration, but also at other government institutions, said the member of Commission D for development affairs. Lukman said the engineering of bids involved officials from the highest to lowest levels. ``The project manager, head and members of the bidding committee, head of the office or even the typist could be involved in collusion,'' he said. He said contractors could obtain information about proposed projects long before they were tendered. ``A project plan should be kept confidential until it is offered for bid. But some contractors get drafts from corrupt officials even before the administration reveals its yearly budget in April,'' he said. A contractor who spoke on condition of anonymity told The Jakarta Post that it was easy for someone to get a project at the administration if they had a friend or relative within the bureaucracy. ``It is common for officials, like the project manager or head of a department, to disclose a project planned for the next fiscal year to contractors they know well. ``It is common for contractors who have become part of the inner circle to be awarded a project well before it is made public. In this case bidding is a mere formality,'' said the source, who admitted that he had been granted several projects through such a process. The formal bidding is attended by 11 bidders who already know who will be awarded the project. The one who is awarded the contract then cooperates with the 10 who lost out. ``We call them bidding associates. They'll lend you their documents to be used in the contrived bid. It is customary to pay dues of between 2 percent and 5 percent of the project value to be shared by the 10 companies. ``Remember that as a picked contractor, you have to pay 'thank you' fees to the officials. Usually we allocate 20 percent of the project value for them,'' he said. He said bidding associates, who usually gather in a particular corner in the administration complex every day, were long-time partners of city bureaucrats. ``They (bidding associates) know full-well that they will always get lots of money as long as there are corrupt officials.'' Amarullah said the corrupt practices had badly tarnished the city administration's image. ``The administration must get rid of these bidding associates,'' he noted. According to Lukman, the council has tried to put a stop the collusion and corruption for years but the call has fallen on deaf bureaucrats' ears.

NOTHING is more invigorating than being greeted by colourful annuals and other garden shrubs and creepers when you step out first thing in the morning. We complain about the warmth and dryness outside, but this time of year - hot, dry periods - brings out the best in summer flowering plants. Plan your planting; select species to suit your needs. As I often say, planting garden annuals and herbaceous perennials is not particularly difficult and involves only digging the soil to a reasonable depth, bringing in organic material to upgrade its organic status and moisture retention, as well as coarse sand for all-important soil aeration and drainage, to ensure healthy plant growth. Here are some of the colourful annuals you can try your hand at. They are not difficult to raise from packet seeds; an average of 20 or 30 seedlings are easily obtainable from one small packet of seeds costing about RM2.50. Annual seedlings planted in a small polybag will cost between RM1 and RM2 each, depending on variety and species. Balsams This colourful annual flower is easy to grow and will reward you with lovely blooms in about eight weeks. The plant flowers right up to two or three weeks before it dies. Balsams love the sun and are not choosy about soil type, provided there is good drainage, organic matter and moisture. It can tolerate a certain amount of shade. Yates' Superb Double Mixture seeds, readily available in the country, have all the finest colours and lovely blooms; an example is the camellia. The plant will grow up to 45cm high. It will do best in raised beds prepared beforehand with a liberal dressing of well-rotted organic manure or compost; this will provide moisture retention and fertility. Balsams are very vigorous growers and respond well if soil is well-prepared and mulched. The mulch can be, simply, dried grass clippings. Lawn clippings should not be discarded, as they can be useful mulching or compost material that will eventually be returned to the soil. Balsam seeds are fairly large (half the size of the green pea) and can be sown directly into the soil (or polybag or pots - one seed will be enough); sow seeds 3-4mm deep. Seedlings should be spaced 30cm between rows and 25cm between plants. This should give the actively-growing seedlings lots of room to develop into healthy plants, with maximum flowering capacity. The plants should be well-watered twice a day; A layer of organic mulch will help keep surface roots cool and moist. Flowering should begin six or seven weeks from sowing. In Malaysia, balsam has always been a popular flower, especially in school gardens, because it is so easy to grow and has bright colours, ranging from white to pink to wine. Portulaca Portulaca is another dazzling, colourful annual. Once it matures, it will flower continuously; flowering is rather short-lived, but there is prolific bud formation. This helps keep up flower production, especially during the four or five hours of the morning before the sun becomes too hot. Flowering portulaca looks like a carpet of colours - white, pink, red, orange, lilac and other intermediates. Portulaca is a low-growing succulent annual (or perennial), boasting lovely rose-like blooms. It is known in Malaysia as the Japanese Rose. How this name came about is a mystery, because it is neither Japanese nor a rose! Portulaca was originally found in Brazil, but it soon spread to all warm parts of the world. It is an extremely hardy plant. It is herbaceous, and is ideal for rock gardens and low borders. Leaves are greatly modified into rod-like structures. The original portulaca is very common in rural areas, where it is found growing in sandy soil, particularly along the coast. This species is more of a perennial than an annual. It bears light purple flowers and blooms during the first half of the day, after which all its flowers fade; by morning of the next day, though, flowers burst forth again. New portulaca varieties have now appeared. These are more colourful than the original purple. In all types, flowering is more profuse in the late mornings, before it gets too hot. Because the plants have endless flowering stems (the plant grows in rosette form) and have flowering buds in abundance, flowering seems to be continuous. As the short-lived flowers fade, new ones open to take their place. Portulaca is extremely hardy, even in very harsh conditions. It is common knowledge that to encourage it to flower well, do not pamper the plant and do not overwater. Over-watering or pampering with nutrients will lead to a lush growth of foliage at the expense of flowering. Portulaca thrives in sandy soils and enjoys the sun - the hotter the better. The plant is propagated by stem cuttings, as well as by seeds. Seeds are very fine and contained in cup-shaped structures. Plants creep along the ground, protecting their roots; they are excellent in smothering weeds. Plants should be watered in dry weather, but do not overwater - they prefer rather dry conditions. The plant has single- and double-flowered varieties. Sunnybank double mixed is the most widely-planted, and boasts a range of bright colours. New varieties you can grow are the Yates' Sunnybank mixed; this contains both doubles and singles in a wide range of brilliant colour. Yates' Dazzle Doubles is a fine double-flowered strain of dazzling colour; this grows to only 8-10cm high and is lovely in hanging baskets, window boxes, borders and sunny rock gardens. Single mixed is another showy plant with gorgeous colours. It grows exceedingly well in hot, dry periods. Portulaca blooms secrete honey and are insect-pollinated; there are always bees and small insects hovering around the bright blooms. Most species of portulaca have mucilaginous, often acidic (malic acid) stems and foliage. Portulaca oleracea is edible and is a pot herb. Salvia This is another garden annual popular in subtropical and warm climates. This brilliant bedding plant was once believed to have medicinal properties and it derived its name from the Latin word salveo - to heal. Salvia splendens from Brazil can grow up to 30-45cm high in the tropics. Modern cultivations tend to be more compact. `Blaze of Fire' is a variant of the splendens - the vivid red bracts that hold the scarlet flowers are borne closely on long spikes, and are spectacular in full bloom. Other forms exist - white and mauve, to deep purple. These are much sought-after for landscaped gardens. Another, the blue salvia (Salvia farinacea), is another that can be a centre of attraction amid reds. Salvia farinacea is the mealy sage from Texas, with a flower like lavender's, of deep violet with white wooly bracts and stems. This can grow to 60 cm high and is ideal for cuttings for vases. It has oval, aromatic leaves, and is excellent in open beds.

BC-UN-Iraq,0507
Butler headed for Baghdad this month for more weapons talks
By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Under pressure to speed up U.N. weapons inspections in Iraq, the chief U.N. inspector will travel to Baghdad this month in a renewed effort to account for all the banned weapons Iraq reportedly held before the 1991 Persian Gulf War. U.N. sources said Richard Butler will hold talks June 13-14 with Iraq's deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz. Butler hopes to be carrying a strong message from the Security Council that Iraq must disclose more information about its weapons programs if it expects to have crippling economic sanctions lifted. But officials of the U.N. Special Commission, which performs the inspections, admit privately they have lost ground in the political battle to convince all 15 council members that serious gaps remain between what Iraq is known to have held before the 1991 Gulf war and what it claims to have destroyed. The council imposed sanctions on Iraq in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. After a U.S.-led coalition drove the Iraqis from Kuwait, the council decided to maintain sanctions until the inspectors certify Iraq is free of all long-range missiles and chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. Iraq claims it has destroyed all illegal weaponry and that the United States and Britain are manipulating the commission to keep sanctions indefinitely. Russia, France and China are urging the commission to accelerate its accounting of Iraqi weapons so that sanctions can be ended. Butler, an Australian, will attempt to shore up support when he briefs the council Wednesday. U.N. officials say Butler will present aerial photographs and other evidence to substantiate his claims that Iraq has failed to account for significant portions of its illegal arsenal. To narrow the gap, Butler and his staff met last week at U.N. headquarters with an Iraqi delegation which included Foreign Minister Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf and Lt. Gen. Amer al-Saadi, a senior adviser to Saddam. ``Basically, the Iraqis gave us the same kind of explanations they've given in the last year,'' said a U.N. source on condition of anonymity. ``They claim to have provided all the documents to the commission. The commission has different ideas.'' U.N. and Iraqi experts have been excavating sites near Baghdad where the Iraqis say they destroyed missile warheads capable of carrying chemical and biological agents. The source said that operation brought the two sides ``close to a full accounting'' on missile warheads. As a result, he said, the commission may be able to end its missile inspections in October. But the source said progress in accounting for Iraq's chemical and biological weapons programs has been slower. For example, he said, Baghdad has offered production records for 1988 and 1989 for the deadly nerve agent VX. But the commission suspects Iraq was able to produce several tons of VX in 1990.

JAKARTA (JP): A forensic expert has determined that a police intelligence officer, reportedly stoned to death by students during a demonstration at Juanda University campus in Bogor last month, died of a heart attack. Dadang Rusmana's death on May 9 was due to a coronary. ``We did not find any bruises on the back of his head. We found only minor bruises in his nose and on his lips,'' Yuli told The Jakarta Post. Police have maintained Dadang died from a head injury sustained after a rock was thrown at him by students. Yuli said the injuries she found might be consistent with the 43-year-old falling facefirst onto the ground. Dadang was comatose when he was admitted to the hospital at 4:03 p.m. on the day of the incident, she said. ``He died about seven minutes later.'' Yuli said she examined Dadang's body at 7 p.m. National Police spokesman Brig. Gen. Dadang had tried to intervene to rescue a military intelligence officer, Capt. Ali, from a student mobbing, when he was hit by a rock thrown by protesters, police have maintained. Ali remained hospitalized. Students have insisted they attacked Ali because he entered the university's mosque without removing his shoes outside. They claim Dadang's body was not at the scene when they were dispersed by hundreds of police and military officers who entered the campus. Lawyer Esther of the Jakarta Legal Aid Institute said there was a significant time difference between when the officers dispersed the students and when the police announced they found Dadang dying at the scene. She did not rule the possibility the police put Dadang's body at the scene after the students fled. The university students and lecturers visited the National Commission on Human Rights on Monday, complaining that police tortured 12 students believed to be connected to the incident. Lawyer Apong Herlina of the institute, who represented the students, said students were forced to confess they beat Dadang to death. Nine of the students were released after being detained for three days, while the other three were named as suspects in the death of Dadang, she said. Apong said one of the suspects, identified as Emon, was paralyzed due to the torture inflicted during his time in custody of the Bogor police precinct. APHIDS, or plant lice, are small, soft-bodied insects that feed on plants by sucking out their fluids, or sap. They are about the size of a small grain of rice. They range in colour from pale green to red. They have a white woolly coating. Often named for the type of plants they destroy, aphids survive by sucking out the plant juices of soft and fleshy new growth. This damages the plant's ability to process food. You will usually find aphids among ornamental or fruit trees by checking newly-formed leaves and buds. Distorted young leaves with a grayish cast are sure signs of the pest's presence. Aphids also excrete a sticky coating onto leaves. These insects are easy to detect; turn over a damaged leaf and you are sure to find a cluster of the culprits. How they feed Aphids feed by sucking out plant sap with their piercing mouth parts; they use slim, needle-sharp stylets in their beaks, with which they pierce stems, leaves, buds, roots and fruit. In badly-ravaged plants, aphids may cause leaves to curl or may stunt a plant's growth. This will hinder its production of flower or fruit. Eventually, the plant may die. Aphids also introduce fungi, bacteria and even viral diseases, that can be as damaging as the aphids themselves. Aphids expel, from the end of their abdomen, a rather sticky, sweet substance called ``honeydew'', a favourite food of some species of ants. These ants move the aphids to productive plants, thus helping spread the pests. Control The first step to controlling aphids is inspecting new growth for any tell-tale signs. You can wash off the slow-moving pests with a slow jet of water from the garden hose. For more serious infestations, use suitable insecticides available at garden centres. Check the label carefully. Other ways to fight aphids: Destroy them by hand - Rub an infected leaf between thumb and forefinger. Be careful not to damage leaves. Wash them away - Mix insecticide with soap and use it to rinse away the aphid population. Mala-thion will do the job. Sometimes, insecticidal soap can be used to good effect - otherwise, mix your own. White oil - Abarol or albolenium are formulated to destroy soft-bodied sucking insects. Follow instructions; exceeding the recommended dosage can cause foliage burn. Ladybirds are beneficial insects which feed on aphids. Ladybirds and lacewings are natural enemies of aphids; in Nature, they and other beneficial insects feed on aphids and their grubs. Controlling ants is another way of putting an end to the menace, because the ants spread aphids to healthy plants. Ants are said to rub the bellies of the smaller insects, causing them to excrete the ``honeydew'' the ants feed on. Spray plants with an insecticide against ants. Systemic insecticides Use systemic insecticides to control these sucking pests more effectively. These are most commonly used to fight aphids. Plants absorb these chemicals into their systems. They do not harm plants, but when the aphids suck up the sap, they quickly die. Where sucking insects are concerned, ordinary contact insecticides that control biting insects are useless because the pests do not eat plant tissue, they suck only the sap through their hollow needle-like mouths. Rogor or Dime-thoate is a suitable systemic. Whichever insecticide you choose, follow directions closely for safe and effective use. Then wash your hands and face with lots of water.

Russia slashes price for oil company it couldn't sell
MOSCOW (AP) _ The Russian government lowered the price for the Rosneft state oil company to dlrs 1.6 billion on Monday, after failing to sell it last week for dlrs 2.1 billion. The government wants to sell 75 percent of Rosneft, both to raise much-needed cash and to show that its privatization program is working. Several oil companies indicated interest in Rosneft, Russia's fifth largest oil company. But Russia's young stock market has crashed since the sale was planned last fall and the price of oil has also plummeted on world markets. The sale was seen as a major test for President Boris Yeltsin's new Cabinet, which has said it would carry out further privatizations without bestowing any special favors on the country's politically powerful commercial banks. The sale was suspended last Tuesday when the government received no bids. In announcing the new price of 9.8 billion rubles (dlrs 1.6 billion), Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko did not say how long the bidding process would remain open this time. (ls)

The event was officiated by Energy, Telecommunications and Posts Minister Datuk Leo Moggie. Also present was Lester Technology's group chief executive Jerry T. Wu. According to Lester Technology, business opportunities for encryption technology products would be boosted by the explosive growth of the electronic commerce market in the Southeast Asian region and also around the globe. The company says the public key infrastructure (PKI)-driven worldwide market is expected to be worth an estimated US$200 billion (RM760 billion) by the year 2000. By that year, the potential market for certification authorisation in Malaysia with national root status will be about RM194 million. Lester Technology had in December last year introduced the LTG CA suite which is an encryption technology product for complete Internet, intranet and extranet security. The suite provides public key and private key encryption needed for identification, authorisation and authentication of electronic transactions. Information encrypted with a particular public key can only be decrypted with its corresponding private key. The LTG CA suite supports 128-bit symmetric algorithm and 1024/2048 Public Key algorithm. According to Wu, there are about 50 players worldwide which are dealing in encryption technology products, but Lester Technology could be among the few to offer a comprehensive product range that includes both enterprise certification authorisation (ECA) and secure electronic transactions (SET) certification authorisation to fully meet the security needs of the various users of the Internet. He added that the company is currently conducting several pilots with one local ISP and a few other organisations, which he termed as ``potential certification authorisation'' bodies. On another development, Wu said Lester Technology will submit its application for the Multimedia Super Corridor (MSC) status in a few weeks' time.

I FIRST made Professor Yuan T. Lee's acquaintance through his five-page curriculum vitae. A notable scientist whose highest achievement has been winning the 1986 Nobel prize for chemistry, Lee's accomplishments consist of a seemingly endless list of fellowships and awards, honorary appointments, academic positions and lectureships. Sixty-one-year-old Lee has recently opened a new chapter in his life. After living in the United States for 32 years, four years ago he gave up American citizenship and returned to his homeland, Taiwan, and became president of Taipeh's prestigious Academia Sinica. ``I thought I would be too old if I didn't come home,'' he says, laughing. Lee left for the US to pursue a doctrate in chemistry in 1962, and then dedicated his life to research. His purpose in returning to the Far East was a noble one; he hoped to raise the standard of research and improve the education system in Taiwan and Southeast Asia. ``If you work hard, you can conduct world-class research in Southeast Asia,'' he says. ``I decided if I do not raise the standard of chemistry research to the highest level in the world, my returning to Taiwan won't mean very much.'' After six months as Academia Sinica president, Lee took up a new challenge, heading the Council for Educational Reform; he has spent two years working to improve education in Taiwan. ``I believe people can be educated to change things for the better,'' he says. ``But I can't do very much alone, and I hope to persuade established scientists and academicians to get involved.'' Talking to Lee is like talking to a walking encyclopaedia. The scope of his knowledge is vast, not limited to chemistry or science. And he is a man of many concerns, especially in the humanities, economics, social sciences and education. He recently spoke at a seminar in Kuala Lumpur entitled ``Asian financial shocks, high-technology and economic growth''. ``I'm not an expert on the economy or monetary system, but I'm concerned about the future of Southeast Asia - what we are doing and where we're heading,'' says Lee. ``Whenever I'm asked to do something, it is a challenge. I may not know very much, but I learn. Life is a long learning process,'' he adds. Lee was born in 1936 in Hsinchu, Taiwan, to an artist father and schoolteacher mother. He had a colourful and fun-filled elementary and secondary education in Hsinchu, where he was actively involved in sports and music. The turning point in his life came when he was 16. ``I fell ill and was in hospital for a month. I was thinking to myself what the meaning of life is and who I would become.'' An avid reader, Lee found the biography of Madame Curie fascinating. It was Curie's dedication to science and her selflessness and idealism that influenced him to study science. ``For the first time, it hit me that you can achieve something when you have ideals,'' says Lee. ``Madame Curie was a very idealistic person who believed knowledge belongs to all humankind.'' Aside from his ambition to become a scientist, Lee's other wish was to change tradition and transform society. ``China was so poor and there was much political unrest after the war. I wasn't happy about the situation in society. I believe there's a need to reform and change, and that we should work hard to transform society.'' After completing his first and second degrees in chemistry in Taiwan, he won a scholarship to pursue his doctorate at the Univesity of California at Berkeley. It was a very different but interesting experience for Lee and wife Bernice Wu. ``We came from closely-knit extended families. But in America, we were uprooted and isolated; we knew nobody,'' says Lee. ``Then I found I had all the time in the world for science.'' For the first four years, Lee was totally immersed in science and forgot educational and social reformation. As there were few Chinese students in America at the time, Lee put in his best to prove that Chinese could do as well as Americans. He developed an interest in crossed molecualr beams, studying reaction dynamics. Upon receiving his Ph.D in 1965, he stayed to conduct more experiments and research as a post-doctoral fellow, under Professor Dudley Herschbach at Harvard. Lee accepted a position as assistant professor in the chemistry department of the University of Chicago in October 1968, and began his illustrious academic career. From 1974 to 1991, Lee was professor of chemistry there and at the University of California, Berkeley. He became an American citizen in 1974. His three children were born in the United States. In 1986, Lee won the Nobel prize for chemistry with his mentor Herschbach and colleague John Polanyi, for the development of chemical reaction dynamics. But he confesses he never worked to win the prize. ``I just wanted to be a good scientist and contribute to society,'' he says. ``I was interested in solving problems and doing things no one is able to. I do not believe anything is impossible. ``This is something young people do not understand. They look at us and think we sacrifice so much time and energy. But I enjoy my work immensely. To me it is much more fun than going out and playing baseball. When you carry out a successful experiment when no one in the world knew it would work, it is really very exciting.'' Lee is one of five Chinese Nobel laureates in history and the only one born in Taiwan and who has won in chemistry (the others won for physics). Winning the Nobel prize has changed his life. ``A Nobel laureate is expected to be spokesperson for his field. I was asked by the university, by the state of California, by the US, and even by the government and people of Taiwan and China.'' Lee travelled around the world helping scientists in countries as far-flung as Italy, France and Japan; he spoke at numerous conferences and conventions. ``I became very busy and was spending less time in the laboratory,'' he says. ``On one hand I wanted to do more science, but on the other I wanted to help people. My loyalty was even questioned by the White House because I was helping the Taiwanese government. Suddenly, I thought: `Jeez, things are getting so complicated!''' Lee then decided he should zero in on something, thus his plan to leave America and return to Taiwan to promote scientific research and education. His decision was welcomed by many Asian intellectuals, scientists and academicians. ``When you work hard, it doesn't matter where you are as long as you're contributing,'' he says. ``It wouldn't make much of a difference if I serve in the United States, as there are other great scientists. But by returning home, my presence will make a difference in Taiwan.''

JAPANESE share prices closed 0.8 per cent lower yesterday with market sentiment hit by Pakistan's nuclear tests and the yen's fall against the dollar, brokers said. The Nikkei stock average of 225 selected issues on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dropped 125.77 points to close at 15,670.78, while the broader Topix index of all first section issues edged down 2.24 points to 1,221.49. Turnover on the major board totalled an estimated 320 million shares, up from Thursday's 270.2 million shares. Share prices lost direction after an early round of dealer-led activity ran out of steam, with investors sidelined ahead of the weekend, brokers said. Earlier, the yen's sharp fall past 139 against the dollar pressured the market, together with uncertainty over the Asian economic and political situation following Pakistan's nuclear tests, they said. But share prices closed above a low of 15,604.70 thanks to ``buying support by public sector pension funds which bought into high-weighting issues in banks and other sector leaders'', one broker said. The release of poor employment data, which showed the nation's unemployment rate soared to a record high of 4.1 per cent, had a limited impact on share prices, brokers said. Slowing selling by foreign investors also helped share prices move off their lows, with some foreign investors beginning to buy into selected blue-chip issues with good earnings fundamentals, they said. But share prices failed to move into positive territory due to a lack of follow-through buying, with a wait-and-see mood spreading in the afternoon session ahead of the weekend, they said.

SHARE prices closed up slightly on Wall Street on Thursday, but gains were limited because traders were nervous about the continuing troubles in Asia. The Dow Jones index of 30 blue chips rose 33.63 points (0.38 per cent) to 8,970.20 on bargain-hunting. Share prices rose and fell throughout the day. The market closed down 27 points on Wednesday, after sliding 175 points one day previously because of unease over Asia's economic woes and its consequences for US companies. Then on Thursday, the US government revised upward its estimate on US economic growth for the first quarter from an annualised 4.2 per cent to 4.8 per cent as strong consumer and business spending was offset by a weak trade sector due to the Asian financial problem. But growth is expected even as export sales to Asia shrink, analysts said. Exports have also been reduced since the dollar is at its highest level against the yen in eight years, making Japanese goods relatively less expensive, said John Lonski, the principal economist for the Wall Street rating firm Moody's. On the bond market, the average yield of the US Treasury Department's benchmark 30-year bonds remained stable at 5.832 per cent down from 5.837 per cent. Among the gainers, Boeing rose 3/8 to 46-13/13 despite announcing Wednesday that its business would be hurt by Asia's economic woes. Banking issues rose, with Citicorp up 1-1/16 to 150 and NationsBank was up 13/16 at 76. Chrysler rose up 2-3/16 to 56-15/16 after the annual meeting of Daimler-Benz shareholders. JAKARTA (JP): A predicted dengue fever outbreak peak, which was expected to happen in May or June, will unlikely be realized as number of sufferers has sharply decreased, an official said yesterday. The City Health Office's public relations department head, Maryani, said the number of dengue fever patients in the city as of May 31 reached only 1,700, a sharp drop compared to 6,600 as of the end of April. She said the total number of the dengue patients throughout the city so far this year was 10,700, with 83 deaths. The fall in the number of people infected is due mainly to city residents' aggressive activities to eradicate the habitats of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, the carriers of the dengue virus. ``It is also due to the end of the rainy season, when there is less flooding, which helps spread the mosquitoes' breeding,'' she told The Jakarta Post. The dengue fever outbreak reached its highest level in April, when hospitals and health centers were swamped with patients. To help prevent the spread of dengue, the city administration launched a mass movement in April to fight the disease. Maryani said that even though the peak of the outbreak was believed not to materialize, people should remain on alert. ``We hope people won't stop the mosquitoes' habitat eradication program,'' she said. Based on the Post's observations yesterday, hospitals were no longer as full with dengue fever patients as in April, when many had to be treated in hospital corridors due to limited availability of rooms. ``We treated about 20 to 25 dengue patients a day in April. But now there are only about five people a day at most,'' said Bambang D., a doctor at Cipto Mangunkusumo General Hospital, Central Jakarta. An employee at state Fatmawati Hospital, South Jakarta, said the situation was back to normal, so the dengue fever alert post at the hospital was removed last week. ``The post was established to anticipate a steadily rising number of patients at the hospital. Now, however, we consider the post is no longer needed,'' said the employee, who asked not to be named. A similar situation was also seen at St. Carolus Hospital, Central Jakarta. Nurse Citra D. said that in April, the number of new dengue fever patients reached dozens per day but ``it's about two or three a day now.''

THIS gargantuan film (we're talking about the hype surrounding it, not its merit!) can be summed up in two words: physical tragedy. It has special effects that are nothing less than stunning and, ermmm, nothing else much. The story revolves around Godzilla making its way to New York, leaving the usual, if uninspired, trail of destruction. Supporting this computer-generated imagery (CGI) Godzilla are Matthew Broderick in the lead as nuclear scientist Dr Nick Tatopoulos; Jean Reno as French spy Philippe Roche; Hank Azaria as a cameraman named Animal and Maria Pitillo as the pitiful Audrey - pitiful because she is forced upon an unsuspecting audience. None of these cardboard cutouts adds any originality to their performances. However - strangely - it must be confessed that Azaria has more screen presence than Broderick. And Godzilla in turn, has more than all of them put together. Safe to say, throughout this feeding tube of a movie, the only pondering viewers are apt to do is to ask why Godzilla chose New York. And even then, this could be easily attributed to the re-awakening of some long dormant and ancient instinct, probably memories of the prehistoric supercontinent, Pangaea, or something like that. Then again, it could also be the attraction of the trendy lifestyle in the city that never sleeps and its superb skyline. One can never be sure about these things nowadays! Anyway, for an audience weaned on Steven Spielberg's Jurassic Park and its sequel, The Lost World, or the CGI-laden box-office bomb Dragonheart, there's nothing new or groundbreaking in Godzilla in terms of special effects, except maybe for the creature, which even then looks like a cross between the artist H.R. Giger's Alien and a scowling T-Rex (Jurassic Park). Godzilla is basically a pastiche of other blockbusters - Godzie downtown is like Mrs T-Rex in San Diego looking for her little one in The Lost World; Godzie underwater is like the swimming aliens in Alien Resurrection; Godzie being target practised upon is like King Kong, and, of course, landmarks going down is similar to what happened in Independence Day (ID4). Surprisingly, the first teasing glimpses of the gigantic CGI creature's tail and feet as it runs swerving behind one building or another seem so unreal and do not mesh with the surrounding. Only in the darkened scenes (underground tunnels, underwater or during nighttime) does the mighty CGI Godzilla look believable. One thing that really needs saying is the mannerism of the towering beast, which is very real, especially when its suspicions are aroused as the humans try and bait it for the second time. The single most memorable scene has to be when the creature dives into the sea to escape its pesky tormentors, only to face armed submarines. Also striking are the scenes depicting Godzilla's flammable breath, if that's what it is, in two incidences. As for scale, this Godzilla is sometimes dwarfed by the tall buildings in New York. It does not often come across the way the hulking Godzilla of yore did in those kitschy Japanese shows that we used to see on television long ago. It must be said that for a nation that has been tracking the beast, the US sure is ill-prepared to grapple with the situation when Godzilla comes a-calling. And where is the camcorder brigade that is always in every nook and cranny capturing everything on video for posterity Stateside? The only first glimpse of Godzilla that the New Yorkers see on their tellys are bad visuals taken by Animal. For those looking for a huge dose of destruction in the exact same vein as dished out in ID4 in 1996, it'll be good to hear that New York's landmarks are destroyed willy nilly. For dessert, there is the squadron of helicopters swarming in on Godzilla, only to be outsmarted and crunched by the beast during the first round of their encounter. Unlike ID4 (made by the same director-producer team of Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin), this film's weakness is that it does not have memorable characters with whom audiences can emotionally lock onto. Godzilla's cutesy characters spewing effortlessly-digestable inanities pale in comparison to ID4's screen magnet Will Smith. If the serious anti-nuclear message at the core of the movie does not come across, the blame must squarely fall on the filmmakers who have sacrificed substance (in the screenplay) for cheesy lines. It is sad that the film leaves no room for its characters to ponder on the folly of their ways although it is firmly established that Godzilla is the mutated result of the undersea nuclear testing conducted by the French. Everyone in the film takes Godzilla to be the bad guy who must be destroyed. The creature eats fish, for Godssake - he does not go around chomping people. Well... except for a few misplaced stomps here and there. While we're at it, the soundtrack is not memorable at all and neither is the creature's vocal performance. Verdict: This is a morally-unsound movie - a true-blue denizen of the 90s would be appalled when the actors on screen applaud as Godzilla collapses at the end. Folks, this year's event movie just got dumber.

HENGELO, Netherlands (AP) _ Ethiopian Haile Gebrselassie bettered the men's 10,000 meter world record by five seconds Monday, finishing in 26 minutes 22.77 seconds at the Adriaan Paulen Memorial track meet. He shattered the nine-month old mark of 26:27.85 set by Kenyan Paul Tergat in Brussels on August 27 last year. Gebrselassie ran the last ten laps of the track with only lapped runners for company after the last of the five Ethiopian pacemakers he'd brought along dropped back. The Ethiopian clocked a half-way split time of 13:11.53 over the first five kilometers. Gerbrselassie made the most of a sunny and almost windless early evening here, and encouragement from lapped compatriot Habte Jifar, who chased him round the final circuit. Earlier in the meet, African male athletes scored three season-best times over the middle distances. Kenyan Wilson Boit Kipketer set a 3,000-meters time of 7:36.05, besting Moroccan Brahim Lahlafi in a close finish. And there was a Kenyan 1-2-3 in the 3000 meters steeplechase as Bernard Barmassai came home in 8:11.57, ahead of Julius Chelule and Patrick Sang. Barmassai's time sliced 8.29 seconds off American Mark Croghan's previous best time of this season. And it was the turn of Moroccan Hicham El Guerrouj to lead the world this year in the 1,500 meters, winning in 3:31.19, some way ahead of Frenchman Nadir Bosch and Julius Achon of Uganda. The second world record attempt of the day proved a flop as Australian Emma George failed to better her own record mark of 4.59 meters in the women's pole vault. In fact, George couldn't clear the bar at all. She failed three times at 4.30, the height she came in on. And the same height won her American rival Stecey Dragila the competition. (sc)

JAKARTA (JP): A Korean and an Indonesian were killed when their car collided with a truck in Cawang, East Jakarta, early Saturday, hospital sources said. Another three Koreans, identified only as Soon, Rhe and Lee, were critically injured and were treated at the Indonesian Christian University (UKI) hospital at Cawang. The dead were identified as Lee Euw Sam, 36 and the car driver, Saiman Basri, 43. Lee died on the scene and Saiman in the hospital. According to Duyeh Supandi, the personnel manager of PT Klapa Nunggal at Cileungsi in Bogor, West Java, where all the victims worked, the five were on their way to the metal factory from Hotel Indonesia in Central Jakarta when the accident happened. ``They had to reach the factory early in the morning and start work before other employees did,'' he said. Duyeh said that all the Koreans arrived in Indonesia several days ago. The bodies of Lee and Saiman were sent to Cipto Mangunkusumo General Hospital for postmortems. Saiman's wife, Sukarti, said that she received a call from the factory at about 9 a.m. on Saturday, telling her that her husband was in critical condition at UKI hospital. Sukarti went there but missed her husband's body, which had already been moved to Cipto Mangunkusumo. She could not hold back tears when visiting Saiman's body accompanied by her relatives. ``We will bury him at Ratu Jaya in Depok,'' she said. Saiman is survived by five children, aged between seven and 19. Sukarti, a resident of Sukma Jaya district in Depok, West Java, said that her husband had worked for the factory for four years. ``I hope that the factory will help us support the family. I have no idea how to pay the children's school fees,'' she said.

MALAYSIAN Airline System Bhd recorded a group pre-tax loss of RM225.36 million for the year ended March 31, 1998, from a pre-tax profit of RM349.56 million previously. At the company level, pre-tax loss stood at RM226.25 million against a pre-tax profit of RM328.23 million previously. After providing for taxation of RM31.27 million, the group's after-tax loss was RM256.64 million while group loss per share was 33.7 sen from a group earnings per share of 43.8 sen last year. Group turnover grew 8.7 per cent to RM7.051 billion and investment and other income dropped by one per cent to RM102.69 million. Group cashflow per share improved by 76 sen or 52.1 per cent from RM1.46 to RM2.22. MAS said in a statement performance was affected by the decline in traffic demand, escalation of costs and foreign exchange losses, particularly in the second half due to the economic situation in the region and the weak ringgit. The group suffered a translation loss of RM3.487 billion compared to a translation gain of RM164.2 million last year, on revaluation of long-term foreign monetary assets and liabilities. However, as the borrowings were mainly to finance the acquisition of aircraft, the costs of which were denominated in the US dollar, the appreciation in aircraft book value was approximately RM4.8 billion at RM3.64 to US$1. The statement said as only translation loss for long-term foreign assets and liabilities were amortised, an exchange loss of RM620.9 million was booked in. During the year, the group also incurred an exchange loss of RM97.5 million on operating transactions, provided RM165.2 million for doubtful debts and RM48.6 million for its Year 2000 Compliance programme. The statement said in the year under review, the group entered into sale and leaseback arrangement for 11 aircraft and seven spare engines and sold an Airbus A300B. These transactions resulted in a total gain of RM620 million. A gain of RM136.9 million was also derived from divestment of aircraft engine repair and overhaul business unit to an associated company. During the year under review, MAS took delivery of six B777-200, three B747-400, one B737-400 aircraft and deferred the deliveries of three B747- 400 aircraft. The statement also said that MAS' capacity, inclusive of freighter operation, expanded 4.3 per cent to 6,411.3 million tonne-kilometres while traffic grew at a rate of 4.9 per cent to 3,887.7 million tonne-kilometres. Overall load factor improved by 0.3 percentage points to 60.6 per cent while passenger load declined 1.7 percentage points to 67.9 per cent. The airline's outlook for the current financial year was that demand for air travel would remain weak. It said the economic problems in the Asian region would affect intra-Asian travel while outbound traffic from Malaysia and domestic travel would drop further if the economic situation did not improve. However, the statement added, the undervalued ringgit, the 16th Commonwealth Games in September and some other major international events should encourage inbound traffic into Malaysia and also enhance awareness of the country for future travel. Expected keen competition will continue to exert pressure on yield. Costs are expected to remain high.

Riot victims find it hard to rebuild business, JAKARTA POST xfdws RIOT-VICTIMS-FIND-IT sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 01, 1998 JAKARTA POST ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
JAKARTA (JP): The sky over the city is blue once again. There is no more gray smoke rising from burning shops, houses and offices as was the case during the recent riots. But grief still hangs in the air. It is as black as the gutted remains of buildings, silent witnesses to the looting and burning of more than 5,000 shops and malls. Most of the property belonged to Indonesians of Chinese descent. Hendrawan is one of the many victims who lost his source of income within a matter of hours. His shop in Pasar Minggu, South Jakarta, where he sold spare parts for cars, was set ablaze by looters on May 14. Sifting through what remains of his shop, he collects blackened spare parts and uses both hands to dust off the ashes. ``I want to start my business again but I don't know whether it's possible,'' Hendrawan, who returned from his hometown in Purwokerto, Central Java, last week, said. Before he started selling spare parts in Pasar Minggu six years ago, Hendrawan ran a car repair shop from his house. He decided to turn it into another business with the hope of making a better living. He bought a 20-square-meter shop worth Rp 65 million after obtaining a 10-year loan with his house as collateral. ``I still have to figure out how to pay my loan for the next four years, or the bank will confiscate my home,'' the 41-year-old father of four said. At the moment, he is preparing the necessary documents, such as those from the district office and the fire department, to persuade the bank not to confiscate his home. He had no insurance for loss or damage of the shop and stock. ``I need more time before I can continue paying my loan.'' Getting another loan is out of the question. ``See for yourself, how can I convince a bank to give me a loan now? Maybe I will try to persuade my relatives to give me a loan to restart my business, but, under the present conditions, it won't be easy.'' In the meantime, Hendrawan must find a way to put food on the table for his wife, who does not work, and their children. ``With no business to run, I don't know how long I can go on living like this.'' Indonesia's ethnic Chinese, who account for 5 percent of the 200 million people here but are said to dominate the economic sector, are often the scapegoats for public anger. During the recent riots, many stayed in their homes as they had no place to go. The wealthy ones managed to flee to other countries, some holed up in the Thousand Islands and at Soekarno-Hatta International Airport, while others stayed with relatives or friends in a place they considered safer. Now that the situation is cooling down, some have already returned to the city -- only to find debris instead of the houses, offices, or stores they left behind. Lina Herlina, 45, another Indonesian of Chinese descent who ran a grocery store at Pasar Minggu market, has no plans to continue her business. Starring at her gutted store, she could identify nothing but a blackened iron chair and shelves. ``I don't think I will start my business again, I don't have money to start again, this is all I had,'' Lina, who managed to get out of her store when the mobs started looting the market, said. ``My priority now is how to survive the situation.'' Only two months ago she paid up the three-year rent for the shop. Now her family must depend solely on her husband's small salary as a bookkeeper at a pharmacy. ``I was trying to start my own business to earn extra money for raising my children. ``And I still don't understand why they burned down my shop,'' Lina said, adding that she had a good relationship with other shop owners and customers living near the market. Maintaining a good relationship with neighbors is a must, especially if you belong to the minority. But during the recent riots this rule did not apply, primarily because there were allegations that those who started the incidents were people from outside the area. Unity Several eyewitnesses saw the same people inciting the riots, according to Rosita Sofjan Noer, businesswoman and deputy chair of the Coordinating Body for National Unity (Bakom-PKB). They saw those people unlock stores and shops with special ``cutters'' before provoking the mobs to loot and burn. She believed the looting was well-organized and urged the Armed Forces to thoroughly investigate the case. ``The Armed Forces has to start determining who was behind these riots.'' Bakom is a forum of public figures from various ethnic groups established in 1977 to promote national unity. They members include tycoon Liem Sioe Liong, alias Soedono Salim, and his son Anthony Salim, hotelier Sukamdani Sahid Gitosardjono, banker Usman Admadjaja, scholar Juwono Sudarsono, researcher Harbrinderjit Singh Dilon, scholar Bachtiar Aly, and businessman K. Sindhunatha. Rosita said the recent tragedy reflected a decline in society's sense of unity and nationalism. The looting and burning of stores, shops and malls belonging to those of Chinese descent revealed the social jealousy of certain groups. Like many people, the rioters believed the inaccurate stereotype that all Chinese are rich. The fact that many of those rich people prefer to live exclusively and do not want to mix with the indigenous people adds to their animosity. Rosita said Bakom had assigned 80 people to gather data about the number of victims and the material loses. ``The data is expected to enable related ministries to determine the necessary steps to help the victims.'' No less important is the government's efforts to protect all citizens, regardless of their ethnic background, to create a feeling of safety and certainty, she said. ``It's important to give them a feeling of certainty and safety before they rebuild their businesses,'' Rosita said. Chinatown President B.J. Habibie last week toured Jakarta's Chinatown in Glodok, West Jakarta, and the shopping centers in Klender, East Jakarta, and Cempaka Putih, Central Jakarta, all of which were damaged in the riots. He promised that the government would help traders in all possible ways. He also convinced traders of Chinese descent of the government's intent to provide equal treatment for all. His words have yet to become reality, but many have great expectations of him. Amir Tjipta, one of the traders, has started cleaning up his gutted store in the Glodok electronics market. ``I've started cleaning up my store because now I feel secure after the President himself paid us a visit,'' he said. Glodok was the worst-hit area during the recent riots. Over 3,800 kiosks and a 150-room hotel were burned and looted in the neighborhood. About 65 people died in fires in a number of Glodok shopping malls, while 45 others were seriously injured. Amir wishes he could soon restart his business. ``Being a trader is the only thing I know but now, with my shop gone, I have to start all over again. And I really hope that the President will not forget his promise to help us,'' said the man, who has three children and a wife to support. He expects the President to help traders get bank loans. ``I put all my money into my store and I don't have enough savings to start again,'' Amir said. If he fails to get a loan, he would be forced to wind up his operations completely. ``Maybe I will try to get money to renovate the store and then sell it. But, in the current situation, I know it's not easy,'' said Amir. The city administration has promised to speed up the processing of permits for renovations to buildings destroyed during last week's rioting. The West Jakarta mayoralty even said that victims of the riots could rebuild without a permit. In South Jakarta, they are allowed to do so, on the condition that the design of the new building is the same as the old one.

Musa: Asia's dynamic growth lulled people into complacency, NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES xfdws ASIA'S-DYNAMIC-GROWTH sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 01, 1998 NEW STRAITS TIMES-MANAGEMENT TIMES ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
KUALA LUMPUR, Sun. - Before facing the current economic problems, Asia's dynamic economic growth, dubbed the Asian Miracle, provided its citizens with a success which lulled them to complacency. ``It is common knowledge the manner Asians were shopping at shopping centres of the world ... Paris, Milan, London, New York,'' former Deputy Prime Minister Tan Sri Musa Hitam said. ``They were shopping like their counterparts who came from far more developed economies with little concern for being frugal. We didn't know how to manage monies ourselves ...'' he said. ``Currently, many of us, are reeling from this trouble. Indonesia, Korea Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore ... all of us are feeling it,'' Musa, who is chairman of Lion Land Berhad, said. He said this when closing the four-day Harvard Project for Asian and International Relations conference at the Putra World Trade Centre today. Musa said the theme for this year's conference was apt as it enabled the participants to understand the issues at hand. ``If this (the conference) was organised several years ago ... the theme would have been different. ``Our (the nations') dynamism brought streams of people from the international community who came and viewed us with awe. ``We had people who had nothing but good things to say about us ... the Asian way.'' But success breeds arrogance, corruption, decadence and failures. ``We became too rich too fast ... suffering from success which bred failures.'' The cultural shock from that failure was traumatic. However, countries in the region had reacted with an acceptance of responsiblity for the problem and taken remedial action immediately. ``There are some countries that indulge in the denial syndrome ... yet are forced to take remedial action grudgingly. ``There are those who deal with the problem with cool acceptance of the reality of the situation, adopting a no-nonsense approach towards remedial action and getting on with the job at hand to put their act together.'' Musa said one aspect not mentioned much in the wake of the downturn, and which could be regarded as positive, was the human rights issue. ``Being an international activist in the cause, in the present social, economic scenario, the human rights cause seems to be the winner here,'' Musa, who heads the Malaysian delegation to the 54th session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, said.
