THE American columnist and political philosopher Walter Lippmann once remarked that, in politics, there can be no concluding chapter because there is always more future out in front than recorded history behind. At no point is there a pause when all problems, upheavals and conflicts are solved and every good idea finds its proper place. In Asia, with the overthrow of Suharto and the detonation of the Indian H-bomb we have just had another jolting reminder of the truth of this observation. At the same time, barely noticed, in Latin America there is another event afoot that reaffirms the other side of political life, the often successful quest for a more orderly, self-disciplined and far-sighted world, that certainly India and Pakistan could benefit from in their own fraught relationship over Kashmir and Indonesia likewise with its continued occupation of East Timor. Very soon one of the world's last remaining inter-state conflicts, between Peru and Ecuador, will be laid to rest with the signing of an historic peace agreement. For many decades Latin America has received more than its fair share of disapprobation because of its declining relative economic standing after the high hopes of the early years of the century when its growth was spectacular, its penchant for dictatorship over democracy and its leanings towards the worst income distribution of the world's five continents. Much of the critique was accurate - and part remains apposite even now, despite widespread economic reforms, when one observes the medieval attitudes towards the poorer classes and much of the continent seemingly intent on diluting the benefits of its return to democracy that marked the 1970s and 80s and the onset of a Latin renaissance. Today there seems to be a vogue for an era of ``democratic Caesars'' -elected politicians who ask their legislatures to re-write the constitution so they can stand for a second or even a third term, or for voting for president, as in Bolivia last year, a former harsh military dictator or, as looks increasingly likely in Venezuela, a colonel who all but carried out a coup in 1992. But there was always another side of Latin America that put it in the forefront of civilisation - its belief in international law, the avoidance of war and the supremacy of diplomacy and negotiation. It has always been a contradiction, too rarely perceived by outsiders, that while Latin America may seem to have a life-long fascination with the caudillo/general, its paucity of international conflict makes it this century's most peaceful continent, a state of being that is reflected not least in the relatively low percentage of national income that Latin America spends on military hardware. (Which makes it all the more contemptible that the Clinton Administration, as a favour to the US arms industry, tried to stoke up Latin American arms spending by reversing President Jimmy Carter's ban on the sale of advanced warplanes to the continent). The Latin American ``gift'' to the world community of this notion of law before war was fashioned by a distinctive group of scholars active in the years leading up to World War II, including Ricardo Alfaro of Panama, Antonio de Bustamente of Cuba, Epitacio Pessoa of Brazil, Francisco Urrutia of Colombia and most important, the Chilean, Alejandro Alvarez. It was Alvarez who led the effort to show how the basis of international law as it developed after World War 1 was fundamentally wrong, with its stress on the independence of states. His emphasis was on the ``Interdependence of states''. ``This is'', he wrote, ``the foundation of their reciprocal relations, and mutual assistance is the condition for their peaceful co-existence and their mutual and moral development''. Although World War II appeared to suffocate this thinking it did in fact survive to play an important part in the post-war order, not just in the proclamations of international law societies but in the way that states went about formulating their ideas of their own relations and the rules that ought to govern them. This historic peace agreement points up the relevance of these political ideas. Ecuador and Peru have been arguing about a piece of (oil-rich) Amazon forest since Spanish colonial times - which puts India's and Pakistan's quarrel or Indonesia's and East Timor's or, come to that, Israel's and the Palestinians' into perspective. In 1995 the two countries briefly went to war which animated Argentina, Brazil, Chile and the US, working together to broker a series of peace negotiations. Ecuador has now given up its claim, but Peru, embracing Alvarez's principles, will give Ecuador permanent access to the Amazon - a permeable border in effect. Latin America now wants to make money, not war. If Asia and Africa, not to mention Greece, Turkey and ex-Yugoslavia in Europe, could learn from Latin America about the superiority of law over war not only would there be more peace, there would be more prosperity - and the world will have taken a great step away from Lippmann's sophisticated pessimism towards Alvarez's more considered optimism.

PAKISTAN has ignored world opinion not to take the same path that India travelled two weeks ago in testing nuclear its capability. At 5-5 in one month alone, the score is tied and honour has perhaps been satisfied. Has the detonation of nuclear devices been worth it in a tit-for-tat grudge match? Pakistanis themselves will have to weigh the answer against the larger risk of economic and social repercussions, and decide if pride alone will suffice to sustain a population of 140 million. The bite of an immediate shutdown of external humanitarian and development aid will be felt long after the euphoria fades. Pakistan's only consolation may be that its erstwhile neighbour is dealing with the same fallout. Not too long ago, there was a glimmer of hope that India and Pakistan were finally meeting on common ground to resolve an enmity that has stretched over 50 years. The nuclear tests need not mean an end of this, but could become yet another area in which they work towards a lasting understanding that is beneficial to both countries. And it could begin with them signing the 1996 Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. India's earlier assurance that it would conduct a strategic review of its nuclear programme must be met with a similarly unequivocal undertaking by Pakistan. Indeed, both must further declare a moratorium against taking that next step which would result in nuclear weapons being designed and built. Regional stability depends on this, as does the protection of humanity from the disastrous outcome of playing with nuclear warheads. With the latest episode, the global community can no longer afford to dither over tough decisions. The five major nuclear powers especially have to show greater seriousness in implementing nuclear arms disarmament conventions. The US, Britain, Russia, China and France can hardly preach when they have practised all that they now seek to ban. It is time to disband the club. For so long as this is not done, there will always be some ambitious country or other trying to make a point, just for the sake of doing so. Pakistan and its leaders can expect to feel the same stinging denouncement by world leaders that accompanied India's venture into what is considered forbidden territory. As it is, the response has been predictable and instantaneous - the US imposing sanctions, Japan withdrawing aid, Australia cutting military ties and dropping official visits, and Germany stopping talks on economic development. Pakistan, now in a state of emergency, has battened down the hatches and is looking to wait out the storm of disapproval. The nuclear arms race does the world no good at all. There are more productive ways in which mankind can utilise resources for its own progress, to leave a constructive rather than destructive legacy. More is to be gained from investing in peace than preparing for the eventuality of war. After two World Wars and numerous armed conflicts, no further proof is needed that war is a wanton waste of the earth's most precious resource -life. If national leaders refuse to see this, then the potential victims of aggression must claim their rights through national democratic processes. Economic, social and health arguments will prevail over military insecurities and political posturing. Long after the dust settles on test sites, it will be ordinary citizens who will continue to carry the burden of the nuclear arms race.

Mexico's constitution gives the government the right to temporarily seize companies vital to the nation's economy or security. Aaron Dychter, undersecretary of transportation, said at a news conference that the government was not taking sides in the dispute, but was protecting the public interest in taking over an airline that carries about 30,000 passengers a day. ``We cannot allow, or think about, putting in risk the national economy,'' he said. The government had been prepared to use replacement workers and non-union flight attendants to maintain as much of its schedule as possible. Union members decided it would be ``the lesser evil'' to return to work, the union's secretary-general, Alejandra Barrales Magdaleno, told the Televisa television network. Although close to agreement on wage issues, the union and airline are fighting over benefits and working conditions. Flight attendants want a pension plan, better health benefits and guarantees on flight staffing. Aeromexico wants to increase shifts by two hours and reduce the time between shifts. Labor problems weren't evident at Mexico City's airport Monday morning. No pickets were in sight and television monitors listed Aeromexico's flights as ``on time.'' Jose Luis Nieves, traveling on Aeromexico to Acapulco for a business convention, said he was relieved to hear that flight attendants were still on the job. ``I hope that there aren't any last-minute surprises,'' he said.

LOS ANGELES (AP) _ Hideo Nomo's career with the Los Angeles Dodgers came to an abrupt halt on Monday when the team removed the Japanese right-hander from the roster. Nomo has lost four straight decisions, and he has allowed 18 earned runs in his last 26 2-3 innings. Claire said Nomura called him Saturday night and asked for a meeting. ``Hideo had expressed the thought that it would be best to make a move,'' Claire said at a Dodger Stadium news conference. ``This was the best move to accommodate that request.'' Nomo is signed through the end of the season and is earning dlrs 2.7 million this year _ his fourth with the Dodgers. He is not eligible to become a free agent. ``Maybe a chance of scenery would be beneficial for Hideo,'' said Nomura, who cited recent trade rumors, causing his client to want to pitch somewhere else. ``Just a change in the environment.''

BC-Sports-Soccer-World Cup-Netherlands-Paraguay,0664
Netherlands puts on powerful attacking show to crush Paraguay
AP Photos By MIKE CORDER Associated Press Writer
EINDHOVEN, Netherlands (AP) _ The Netherlands put on a powerful display of attacking soccer to crush Paraguay 5-1 in a clash of two World Cup bound sides in the Philips Stadium here Monday. After being criticized by coach Guus Hiddink for squandering chances in last week's lackluster 0-0 draw with Cameroon, the Dutch struck the target almost at will Monday. ``After the Cameroon game, we needed a result like this,'' Hiddink said. ``It was important for us and for the supporters.'' But Hiddink said his team needed to keep its concentration in defense even when attacking. ``We gave away too many chances today,'' he said. Marc Overmars scored twice and set up another goal before being substituted to a standing ovation in the 71st minute. Paraguay took a surprise lead in just the second minute when Jorge Campos chested down a headed pass from Jose Cardozo and immediately volleyed the ball low to Edwin van der Sar's right. Van der Sar, appearing to think the ball was going wide, made no effort to save it and watched helplessly as the shot hit the back of the net. The Netherlands gradually clawed its way back into the game as Arsenal's Overmars repeatedly beat defenders down the left flank. In the 8th minute, Patrick Kluivert tipped an Overmars cross just over the bar and five minutes later Overmars headed on a pass to Ronald de Boer who controlled the ball on is chest and volleyed just over the bar in a near repeat of Paraguay's opening goal. It was Overmars, the Netherlands' most dangerous player, who scored the equalizer, shooting low into the corner of Paraguayan goalkeeper Jose Luis Chilavert's net after a deft pass from Kluivert in the 26th minute. Kluivert and Overmars combined again in the 29th minute to give the Netherlands a 2-1 lead. Kluivert's powerful drive was well saved by Chilavert but Overmars was on hand to tap in the rebound. And it was the same pair who teamed up two minutes later to give the Netherlands a 3-1 lead. Overmars beat two defenders and took the ball to the touch line before squaring it to Kluivert who shot home from close range. The Netherlands continued its trademark fluent attacking soccer after the break. Substitute Boudewijn Zenden set up the fourth Dutch goal, crossing in the 58th minute for captain Frank de Boer to head in. Paraguay should have pulled a goal back in the 67th minute when Miguel Benitez found himself with only replacement goalkeeper Ed de Goey to beat, but put his shot wide. Zenden came close to scoring a spectacular goal in the 72nd minute. He picked up the ball on his own halfway line and beat tackle after tackle before unleashing a powerful shot that beat the goalkeeper but crashed off the inside of the post and rebounded to safety. Jimmy Hasselbaink made it 5-1 in the 83rd minute, calmly sliding in a pass from Kluivert. The Netherlands takes on Belgium, South Korea and Mexico in World Cup qualifying Group E while Paraguay has a tough task in Group D where it meets Spain, Bulgaria and Nigeria. The Dutch take on Nigeria Friday in their last warm-up match before leaving for France. BC-Spain-Equatorial Guinea-Sedition Trial
Fifteen condemned to death for sedition in Equatorial Guinea
MADRID, Spain (AP) _ A military court sentenced 15 people to death for sedition in Equatorial Guinea on Monday at the end of a mass trial of more than 100 people, according to Spanish news reports. The sentences were revealed in Madrid by representatives of the opposition to President Teodoro Obiang who also reported that the remaining defendants had received jail sentences of between six and 24 years, Spanish national radio said. The charges stemmed from an attack in January on a military barracks on the Guinean island of Bioko _ the home of most of the ethnic Bubi minority in this tiny central west African country. Many of the condemned belong to the Bioko Autonomy Movement, an outlawed political group that strongly opposes Obiang. ``The sentences are outrageous'' a spokesman for the group said on Spanish radio, claiming that confessions had been forced out of accused with torture. ``This can only bring instability to Equatorial Guinea'' he said. The human rights group Amnesty International, along with several European countries and the United States, has long accused Obiang's government of human rights violations. Obiang seized power in this oil-rich country wedged between Cameroon and Gabon in 1979 by overthrowing his uncle Francisco Macias Nguema. Some 500 people, mostly Bubi, were arrested in the military crackdown that followed the January attack, which left four soldiers and one civilian dead. Amnesty claimed four of the detained died in custody and sent two observers to the mass trial in Malabo _ the capital of this former Spanish colony of about 400,000 inhabitants. Calls to Amnesty on Monday went unanswered. Spanish journalists covering the trial were asked to leave the country last Friday after they reported that some of the accused had been tortured. A precise figure for the number of those tried could not be obtained. Monday's sentences prompted Spanish Foreign Minister Abel Matutes to send a letter to his Guinean counterpart calling on Obiang to pardon the lives of the 15 condemned to death, national radio said. The Spanish Socialist Party issued a statement describing the trial as ``full of irregularities.'' The trial was of particular interest in Madrid because four Spaniards of Guinean origin were among the defendants. They were absolved of all charges, the radio reported. (jt)

BC-Colombia-New Force,0476
Independent woman a new force in Colombian politics
AP Photos NY198 By JARED KOTLER Associated Press Writer
BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) _ Although she lost her bid to become Colombia's first female president, Noemi Sanin jolted the two-party system that has dominated the nation's politics for more than a century. Hers was the first independent candidacy to seriously challenge the Liberal and Conservative parties' power monopoly, giving Sanin unprecedented influence over the country's political future. The No. 1 question today in Colombia is ``What will Sanin do?'' A former Conservative and foreign minister, Sanin placed third in Sunday's first round behind Liberal Horacio Serpa and Conservative Andres Pastrana. Now, Serpa and Pastrana, each of whom got 35 percent of the vote, will be courting the 2.8 million voters, or 27 percent of the electorate, that backed the upstart Sanin. ``They are drooling over Noemi's votes,'' said Andres Franco, a Javeriana University political analyst. In speeches Sunday, both Serpa and Pastrana made thinly disguised overtures to Sanin voters, who analysts say will go mainly to Pastrana. Sanin, one of 15 children from a middle-class family, has refused to endorse either man. ``It would be wrong for me to tell the millions of Colombians who voted for me whom they should vote for in the second round, because their very nature is independent,'' Sanin said after recognizing defeat Sunday. But even refusing the role of kingmaker, Sanin may wield tremendous power for someone who just lost an election. At minimum, analysts say, she has toppled gender barriers and tapped into social changes that may threaten the two-party system in this violence-wracked country, where politicians must grapple with a 34-year-old leftist insurgency, drug traffickers and rampant corruption. ``Noemi Sanin has demonstrated that soon a woman will become president,'' said Pastrana. Chief campaign advisor Miguel Silva said Sanin's media-based campaign resonated among a booming urban population that clamors for change and refuses to take instructions from party machines. Indeed, Sanin won the vote in Bogota and the country's next-largest cities, Cali and Medellin. She attracted far fewer votes in the rural heartland, which holds about two-thirds of the vote and where the party machines are strongest. ``In the small towns, you still need a party. You need a political organization,'' said Silva. Previous attempts to breathe fresh air into the two-party structure have been squashed or fizzled out. But even if she is up against history, Sanin is determined to make her mark. ``We will become the political conscience of the nation, demanding a fight against corruption, economic recovery and the search for peace,'' Sanin said Sunday.

BC-Yugo-Kosovo, 5th Ld-Writethru,0626
Thousands of refugees flee fighting in Kosovo; dozens reported dead,0620
RETRANSMITTING to fix slug Eds: UPDATES throughout with details. EDITS to tighten. By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Thousands of refugees from Serbia's Kosovo province streamed into neighboring Albania on Monday to escape some of the deadliest fighting in months. Dozens of people were reported killed. Albania appealed to the United States and European Union to intervene in what it said was a ``massacre'' in Kosovo. ``This is just the start of a war with tragic dimensions,'' the Albanian government said in a statement. With 39 people reported killed over the weekend and fighting apparently continuing, the bloodshed appeared the worst since March, when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on militants among the ethnic Albanian majority in Serb-ruled Kosovo. In New York, U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard spoke of ``heavy and indiscriminate shelling'' of villages near the border with Albania. He said U.N. workers could see heavy mortars being fired into the villages. Refugees said a 3-year-old child died en route to Albania. Ethnic Albanian officials said 37 Albanians were killed over the weekend. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani while 10 were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died in the fighting around Decani, 45 miles west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina, Serb sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The fierce fighting forced about 2,000 Kosovo Albanians _ mostly women, children and the elderly _ across the border into Albania's Tropoja (pronounced Tro-POH-yah) region on Sunday and Monday, Albania said. They said more were arriving by the hour. In Tropoja, some refugees said they had walked for up to 20 hours to reach the Albanian town. They said Serb tanks were positioned inside Decani, and that Serb forces were besieging the town. Tropoja, although some three miles inside Albanian territory, resembled a community under siege, with most of the men carrying rifles or other weapons. Some men displayed the insignia of the Kosovo Liberation Army, the militant Kosovo organization spearheading the fight against Serbia. Andrew Harper, a U.N. aid worker, said he purchased three tons of flour, rice and other basics on the local market to provide for the refugees, and more aid was expected from Tirana, the Albanian capital, on Tuesday. ``I am very worried about providing for all these people,'' said Isa Memia, the town leader. ``We have grave (supply) problems ourselves, but they are our kinsmen, and we will help them.'' Authorities in Serbia are using Serbian police and the Yugoslav army to try to crush militants and maintain control over the province, where 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million is ethnic Albanian. The conflict has killed more than 200 people in Kosovo since the beginning of March. About half of the province is believed controlled by militant Albanians and many regions are blocked off, either by Serbs or Albanians. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, released the names of the 10 people it said were killed Sunday when Serb police stormed the village of Poklek, 15 miles west of Pristina. It said one had had his throat slit. According to the ethnic Albanians' account, Serb police burst into Poklek houses, pulled out villagers and told them to, ``Go to Albania and never return.'' Afterward, Serb police allegedly set 26 homes ablaze. Serbia is the dominant of two republics remaining in the Yugoslav federation.

Sore back knocks Woods from Kemper AP Golf Writer
By RON SIRAK
NEW YORK (AP) _ With the U.S. Open just two weeks away, Tiger Woods withdrew Monday from the Kemper Open with a sore back and flew to Las Vegas for treatment. ``His physical therapist advised him that with the U.S. Open coming up he could aggravate the condition by playing this week and suggested he come to Las Vegas for treatment,'' said Bev Norwood, a spokesman for Woods with International Management Group. Las Vegas is also where Woods' coach, Butch Harmon, is based. Woods played last week at the Memorial Tournament in Dublin, Ohio, finishing 51st. He flew home to Orlando, Florid on Sunday night. ``This is a precautionary measure to ensure that he is ready and able to play in the U.S. Open,'' Norwood said. Ben Bundred, Kemper Open tournament chairman, said Woods felt his back stiffen on the flight from Ohio to Orlando. He said the pain worsened when Woods hit balls in Orlando on Monday morning. ``He thought nothing of it, went to bed, and this morning when he went to work out, it hurt worse,'' Bundred said. Bundred added that Woods recently had an MRI on his back and that his therapist, Keith Kleven, suggested Woods fly to Las Vegas for treatment of what could be a ``potential chronic problem.'' Woods has played in 39 PGA Tour events since turning pro in 1996, and this was the first time he withdrew because of injury. He pulled out of the 1995 U.S. Open as a amateur after one round because of a sore wrist. He also withdrew from the Buick Challenge in 1996 because of exhaustion. ``Tiger has had back pains on and off but his parents have always assumed they were growing pains,'' Norwood said. ``But the therapist he has been working with for six months said there was some irregularities in his lower back.'' Woods, 22, has already won seven tournaments, including the 1997 Masters, and nearly dlrs 4 million in less that two years on the PGA Tour. Tall and lanky, his enormously hard swing clearly puts strain on his back. The treatment will consist of stretching, back stabilization, heat and ice, his spokesman said. He said it was not immediately clear how the injury would affect Woods' practice routine for the U.S. Open. The U.S. Open will be played June 18-21 at the Olympic Club in San Francisco, a course Woods knows well from his college career at Stanford.

New Dutch Antilles government sworn in
By NORMAN SERPHOS Associated Press Writer
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao (AP) _ After a five-month political deadlock, a prime minister was sworn in Monday to head a new government in the Netherlands Antilles. Suzy Camelia-Romer, 38, is the youngest-ever prime minister of the territory's five Caribbean islands: St. Maarten, St. Eustatius, Saba, Bonaire and Curacao. Together, the islands are an autonomous member of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. Six political parties united to form the new government after Jan. 30 elections failed to produce a clear winner. The center-right Antillean Restructuring Party won four of 22 parliamentary seats in the elections, more than any other party but not enough to govern. It was left out of the new coalition. Camelia-Romer, a former justice minister, pledged to erase a dlrs 70 million budget deficit and increase spending for the Dutch Antilles Coast Guard, which is charged with stopping drug smugglers from South America. She and six Cabinet members were sworn in Monday by Gov. Jaime Saleh in Willemstad. The coalition government includes the Curacao-based Popular Crusade Labor Party, which won three seats, the National Party of the People, with two seats, and the May 30 Workers Liberation Party, also with two seats. It also includes the St. Maarten Democratic Party, with two seats, the Bonaire Democratic Party with one seat and the Windward Islands People's Movement from Saba with one seat. Amid grim days, Couples finds his game AP Golf Writer
By RON SIRAK
DUBLIN, Ohio (AP) _ There must be times when Fred Couples looks at Ernie Els, Tiger Woods, David Duval and Justin Leonard and thinks back to those days when he was considered the best golfer in the world. In the first five years of this decade _ 1990-94 _ Couples finished in the top three 25 times in only 99 starts, with eight victories, including the 1992 Masters. Then it seemed like nothing could go right. From 1995 through '97, Couples had only two top-three finishes in 48 tournaments and won just once. At times during that stretch it seemed as if life was conspiring against Couples. A series a personal tragedies made his chronic back pain seem almost an afterthought. Soon after his Masters victory he went through a very public and very expensive divorce with his wife of 11 years, Deborah. ``I go to sleep thinking about it and I wake up thinking about it,'' Couples, an affable and private person, admitted before the 1993 Masters. The next year, his mother Violet died of cancer. And last year, on Thanksgiving Day, his father Tom died after eight years of treatment for leukemia. In between, there was an engagement that didn't work out and then last year his girlfriend, Thais Bren, was diagnosed with breast cancer. Through it all _ or because of it all _ Couples emerged as a man more at peace with himself, and perhaps has emerged as a better golfer that he was even back then when he was the No. 1 ranked player in the world. ``It's given me a kind of peace,'' Couples said. ``I feel comfortable with my father. He had a long life and I realize how lucky I am to be doing what I'm doing. And I have the best girl in the world.'' His golf this year has been as impressive as it was in 1991-92 when he was twice voted the PGA Tour player of the year by his fellow players. In 11 tournaments in 1998, Couples has finished first twice, second twice _ including the Masters _ and third once. In his last five tournaments he has finished second, third, second, 18th and first, playing 17 of 20 rounds under par. ``I think I'm very capable of playing at 38, 39, 40 as well as I did when I was 32,'' Couples, 38, said after winning the Memorial Tournament over the weekend. Clearly, Couples is pleased with what he has achieved this year, but just as clearly he wants to roll up numbers as good _ or better _ than those he once achieved. ``I've had a great month, two months, but two months does not create a whole year of good golf,'' Couples said at Muirfield Village, where he shot four consecutive rounds in the 60s and hit 32 of 36 greens in the weekend rounds. ``I just had one great year,'' Couples said perhaps too modestly about his early success. ``And people keep trying to get me back to that year, and it's not easy to do.'' But Couples seems capable of doing it. If not for two bad swings _ one at the Masters and one at the Byron Nelson _ Couples would be on the verge of a monster year. But it was a hopeful sign that he was able to put those recent failures behind him and protect a lead in the final round at the Memorial. His back problems seem under control and he has reduced his playing and travel schedule in an effort to prolong his career by reducing the wear and tear on his back. And clearly he has many goals he still wants to achieve. Only Greg Norman and Tom Kite have won more than the dlrs 10.4 million Couples has earned. And another major championship or two would enhance his standing among the best players of his era. ``Great players have great records,'' Couples said. ``I consider myself right underneath them, which is fine.''

Belfour: Wings lucky to be up 3-1 AP Sports Writer
By DENNE H. FREEMAN
DALLAS (AP) _ Ed Belfour is a tough man to convince. He thinks the Detroit Red Wings should be thankful for their 3-to-1 edge over Dallas in the Western Conference finals. ``The last two games we've dominated but they've had a lot of luck,'' the Dallas goalie said. ``A lot of our shots have hit goal posts, cross bars, shafts of Chris Osgood's stick. That's just luck.'' The defending champion Red Wings can clinch the best-of-7 Western Conference series with the Stars on Wednesday night in Reunion Arena. While Belfour believes Detroit is surviving on luck, some of the blame for back-to-back losses falls directly on the feisty and defiant Dallas goaltender. Belfour, signed as a free agent last July to provide the big playoff victories that Andy Moog couldn't produce, was involved in two plays in Detroit that led to critical goals for the Red Wings. In Game 3, Belfour ventured into the corner to play the puck and fell after he hit Martin Lapointe. Not drawing a penalty, Belfour scrambled back into the crease just as Lapointe took a pass and shot the puck between Belfour's legs. It stopped a Dallas comeback in an eventual 5-3 Detroit win. On Sunday with Dallas trailing 1-0, Belfour slashed Lapointe and the Red Wings scored on the ensuing power play. ``I shouldn't have taken that penalty,'' Belfour said. ``That was a bad penalty to take at that part of the game with Detroit already leading.'' Center Mike Modano, who has scored only one goal against Detroit, is worried about the Stars getting bad bounces and starting slowly. ``The last two games have been tough-luck games,'' said Modano, who hit a post on one of his shots. ``You can pinpoint little things that aren't going our way.'' But he admitted the Stars need to get off to a quick start Wednesday. ``We keep painting ourselves in the corner at the start of the game,'' he said. ``We have to come out and control the game early. We have two days to regroup. We know what we have to do.'' The Stars may have to do it with fewer skaters without defenseman Richard Matvichuk, who was knocked out of Game 4 with a shoulder injury, and defenseman Shawn Chambers who is out with an injured knee.

Elway says he'll play another year AP Sports Writer
By AARON J. LOPEZ
DENVER (AP) _ John Elway is coming back. The quarterback ended four months of speculation on Monday when he announced he would return for a 16th season with the Broncos. ``The bottom line is I wasn't ready to quit competing,'' Elway said. ``I've got a lot of years to live in retirement and the last thing I want to do is pass up the opportunity to play one more year of football.'' The suspense began in January after Elway led Denver to its first Super Bowl championship in five tries. The victory left him with the choice of ending his career at the top or returning to defend the title with several personal milestones within reach. Elway, who will turn 38 on June 28, needs 1,311 passing yards to join Dan Marino as the only National Football League quarterback to reach 50,000. He also is 22 touchdowns from 300 and 87 completions from 4,000. Team owner Pat Bowlen was delighted by the announcement. ``I've got to keep pinching myself here because I've been waiting and hoping for this announcement for a long time,'' Bowlen said. In 15 seasons, Elway guided his team to more victories (138) than any other quarterback in NFL history. He is the only player ever to pass for 3,000 yards and rush for 200 yards in seven straight seasons (1985-91). Famous for improbable late-game comebacks, he had rallied his team to 44 game-saving drives in his career _ more than any quarterback ever. He was selected to eight Pro Bowls and was the NFL's Most Valuable Player in 1987. He affixed his name to 54 Broncos' regular-season or postseason records. But one goal consistently eluded him. He suffered three increasingly ugly Super Bowl losses and, at 37, had begun to wonder if he would get another opportunity. It came on Jan. 25 in San Diego against the defending champion Green Bay Packers. Despite mediocre statistics, Elway set the tone by scrambling and diving into two defenders for a first down to set up a Denver touchdown late in the third quarter. In the closing minutes, Elway accounted for his 45th game-saving drive, completing a 23-yard pass to Howard Griffith to help set up Terrell Davis' go-ahead scoring run in the 31-24 victory. ``I know that I've been labeled as the guy who's never been on the winning Super Bowl team,'' a jubilant Elway said then. ``Boy, am I glad to get rid of that.'' Elway had minor surgery on his throwing shoulder in February, six months after rupturing a biceps tendon in his shoulder in a preseason game that was first feared to be career-threatening. To some, that operation was a tipoff Elway was coming back, although he maintained as recently as Friday that he had not made up his mind.

BC-Sports-Basketball-NBA Finals,0581
Play it again: Jazz and Bulls in finals AP Basketball Writer
By CHRIS SHERIDAN
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) _ The teams are the same, the MVPs are different and the home-court advantage doesn't belong to the Bulls anymore. Chicago and Utah begin their rematch in the National Basketball Association Finals at the Delta Center on Wednesday night, with Michael Jordan going after his sixth ring and Karl Malone and John Stockton looking for their first. The Jazz will be coming off 10 days of rest since sweeping the Los Angeles Lakers in the Western Conference finals. It is the longest layoff in NBA playoff history. ``They're waiting, they're hungry and they feel the pain from when we beat them last year,'' Jud Buechler said after Chicago defeated the Indiana Pacers 88-83 Sunday night in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals. ``We may be a little tired, but our hearts are not tired,'' Jordan said. Therein may lie the key, the one intangible on which this series may turn. No one has ever doubted the heart and unstoppable will of Jordan. And then there's Karl Malone. He, too, plays with much heart. But he is not Jordan. During last year's finals, one significant storyline was the MVP debate. Malone beat Jordan in the MVP vote and almost seemed surprised that he would be expected to back up the honor. It was the sort of pressure Jordan routinely thrives on. Malone didn't. In Game 1, he missed two free throws with 9.2 seconds left that could have given Utah a three-point lead. Jordan then hit a jumper at the buzzer for the one-point win. Malone sheepishly admitted afterward that Jordan is a better player. In Game 5, Malone had as many baskets (one) as air balls in the fourth quarter, then selfishly refused to commit his sixth foul when the Jazz needed to stop the clock with less than 10 seconds left. Scottie Pippen dribbled around Malone, fed Luc Longley for a dunk and the Bulls went ahead 3-2 in the series. In Game 6, Malone shot 8-for-15 from the line as the Bulls clinched the championship, 90-86. This year, Malone won't have to justify any awards. But he'll still be going for the championship that has eluded him through an otherwise magnificent 13-year career. That goal will be at odds with the Bulls' quest to add to their jewelry collection before they go their separate ways. Coach Phil Jackson has been calling these playoffs the ``Last Dance,'' with the expectation the Bulls will be broken up at after the season despite chairman Jerry Reinsdorf's stated inclination to offer everyone one-year contracts if the team wins a championship. It's another similarity to last year's finals, when Jackson was using his off days to interview for coaching jobs. Even so, the felling of an impending breakup has been stronger this spring. Practically the entire team will be free agents this summer. Scottie Pippen has wanted a megacontract for years, and his dissatisfaction with Bulls management appears irreparable. Jordan has mulled retiring, and the All-Star game and every Bulls road trip was treated like a farewell tour before he backed off his earlier stance that he would refuse to play for any coach but Jackson. Utah and Chicago finished the regular season with 62-20 records. The Jazz have the home-court advantage because they swept the two-game season series.

His movie ``Space Jam,'' sharing the big screen with Bugs Bunny and other Warner Bros.' animated pals, brought in dlrs 230 million at the box office and dlrs 209 million in video sales, the report said. Average NBA salaries have risen from the low six-figures in 1983-84, the season before Jordan's debut, to above dlrs 2.6 million this season. Even Jordan's agent, David Falk, is cashing in. Falk's agency recently was sold for about dlrs 100 million, and Fortune estimated half of that represents the ``Jordan Effect.'' At the end of the day, Jordan is mystified by it all, Fortune said. ``I never really envisioned myself having any kind of major impact on people,'' Jordan told the magazine. ``Even now, when I see kids wearing my shoes, it's kind of wild. Jazz are rested and ready for champs AP Sports Writer
By BOB BAUM
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) _ Well rested and way past ready, the Utah Jazz finally went through a practice on Monday knowing who their opponent will be in the National Basketball Association Finals. Now the Jazz realize that if there was ever a time they were poised to dethrone the Chicago Bulls, it is this year. While the Bulls were sweating through a seven-game Eastern Conference finals series with Indiana, the Jazz were resting, waiting, waiting and waiting. Now they've got a weary Chicago team coming into a series where Utah, not the Bulls, has the home-court advantage in one of the loudest buildings in the NBA. ``In the back of all our minds, it's got to be _ this is the year,'' Utah's Greg Foster said. ``We've played great. A year ago, Utah was in uncharted territory against Chicago, but still played the Bulls tough before losing in six games. This year, the Jazz say, they know what to expect. ``We know that every ball counts for something _ every loose ball, every rebound,'' Antoine Carr said. ``You've got to get all the little things done. If you get all the little things done, everything else will take care of itself.'' But don't try to convince the Jazz that they are the favorites. Not against the Bulls, not against Michael Jordan. ``They're the championship team,'' coach Jerry Sloan said. ``They're the guys who know how to win, and have won, championship games. Until you beat them, they're still the champions.'' Karl Malone said he heard Chicago's Jud Buechler say the Bulls were underdogs. ``Yeah, right,'' Malone said. ``Maybe if we were a younger team, they would have gotten us on that, but we're not going to listen to it.'' Foster said he's trying not to notice how many people are picking Utah to end the Jordan dynasty. ``That just puts unneeded pressure on us,'' Foster said. ``I still feel that we're in a situation where we have everything to gain and nothing to lose. They're the team that if the Jazz win, it's `Oh man, what happened to the Bulls?' I still think we're the rabbit going after the hunter, as Charles Barkley would say.'' Last year's loss to the Bulls is no added motivation, Jeff Hornacek said. ``We're not the type of team that worries about revenge,'' he said. ``As Jerry would say, that's playing in the past. Our goal is to try to win the championship this year and really forget about last year.'' By the time Game 1 tips off on Wednesday night, the Jazz will have been idle for 10 days since they completed their four-game sweep of the Los Angeles Lakers in the Western Conference finals. It's the second-longest layoff in NBA history. Only the Lakers' 12-day respite between the conference finals and NBA Finals in 1982 was longer.

Capitals can wrap up first-ever trip to finals AP Sports Writer
By JOSEPH WHITE
WASHINGTON (AP) _ The Washington Capitals, the oldest National Hockey League team never to reach the Stanley Cup finals, are tantalizingly close to getting there. On Monday, for the first time in the franchise's 24-year history, the Caps donned skates and pads in their practice facility's locker room and sent pucks flying off the boards in the month of June. With a 3-1 series lead over the Buffalo Sabres, a victory Tuesday night is all that's needed to smother the memories of years of mediocre seasons and first-round playoff flops. ``I've never got this far,'' said seven-year center Joe Juneau, who scored the winning goal in Saturday's 2-0 Game 4 victory in Buffalo. ``It's a great feeling to have a chance to be in the show. We all know what's waiting for us, and I don't think anybody's going to relax yet.'' The Capitals are to the point where the one-game-at-a-time cliche has become intertwined with the team's unprecedented success. The locker room clipboard that had 16 sheets on it at the start of the playoffs has been stripped down to sheet No. 5 _ as in five games to go to win the Stanley Cup _ and coach Ron Wilson said he doesn't mind his players thinking ahead to the glory of playing in the finals. ``I think it's good to look at that because it motivates you to get the job done,'' Wilson said. ``We've put ourselves in a very good position with three games to win one. We'd obviously like to get it done at home.'' By no means are the Capitals writing off the Sabres. After all, if goaltender Dominik Hasek can beat the United States, Canada and Russia in consecutive games to win an Olympic gold medal with the Czech Republic, then he certainly can lead the Sabres back from a 3-1 deficit. ``Their confidence is probably shaken a little bit,'' Wilson said. ``But I don't think anybody outside of their locker room feels they can come back, so that takes away some of the pressure. They're a young team. They're going to play with desperation because they realize that if they lose another game, they're finished. We have to match their desperation with a sense of urgency. The Caps have been in this position twice already in the playoffs, putting away Boston in six games and Ottawa in five after taking 3-1 leads. Those were liberating victories because of Washington's history of blowing 3-1 leads _ it's happened three times in the last 11 years _ and Buffalo coach Lindy Ruff and his players are hoping to revive the hex one more time. ``We've got them right where we want them,'' forward Dixon Ward said. ``We set them up perfectly for this situation. Everything is going as planned. Now all we have to do is win three in a row.''

Report: Australia to become worst greenhouse gas emitter
CANBERRA, Australia (AP) _ Australia will be the world's worst per capita greenhouse gases polluter within 12 years, a report released Monday found. Australia was one of only three developed countries which won approval at the international conference on global warming in Kyoto, Japan, last December to increase greenhouse gas emissions by 2010. The outcome was hailed by the federal government as a major victory for Australian industry, but an analysis of the Kyoto agreement by the liberal think-tank the Australia Institute said the victory may be at huge environmental cost. The institute's report says Australia's per capita emissions from energy consumption and industrial uses will rise from 21 (metric) tons per head to 26 tons in 2010, making Australia easily the world's biggest greenhouse gas polluter. Institute Executive Director Clive Hamilton said Australia had tricked the rest of the world into giving it special treatment and had seriously jeopardized attempts to involve developing nations in future climate change agreements. ``If they had been aware of the facts, other nations would not have agreed to Australia's demand for an increase in emissions but would have required us to cut our emissions by more than other countries,'' Hamilton said.

Travelers Group takes 25 percent stake in top Japanese brokerage
Eds: UPDATES throughout and tightens By CHESTER DAWSON Associated Press Writer
TOKYO (AP) _ Travelers Group Inc. is buying a quarter of Nikko Securities Co., the third-largest Japanese brokerage house, expanding its worldwide presence and placing a dlrs 1.6 billion bet on Japan's financial future. The American financial behemoth joins a growing number of foreign firms, including securities rival Merrill Lynch and Co., that are strengthening their position here. With the Japanese government loosening regulations and scandals tarnishing the image of domestic brokers, foreign firms are gaining unprecedented opportunities in one of the world's biggest financial markets. Monday's deal comes less than a month after Travelers unveiled an dlrs 82 billion merger with Citicorp to create the world's largest financial services company. The partnership with Nikko will enhance the global businesses of both companies. ``Our creating a partnership with Nikko will allow us to be more productive not only in this marketplace but all around the world,'' Sanford Weill, chairman and chief executive officer of Travelers Group, said at a press conference in Tokyo. New York-based Travelers will become Nikko's biggest shareholder, taking over from top Japanese lender Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. Nikko will buy a smaller stake in Travelers Group to solidify the broad-based tie-up. The deal is one of the most aggressive moves to date by an American financial firm in Japan amidst a major effort to liberalize the Japanese financial industry by 2001. The reforms, dubbed the ``Big Bang,'' are expected to open up a pool of personal financial assets worth an estimated dlrs 9 trillion. A number of other big names on Wall Street have also expanded in Japan. In February, Merrill Lynch and Co. hired 2,100 former employees of the failed Yamaichi Securities Co. to staff 33 retail outlets nationwide. Fidelity Investments Co. has announced similar plans. The foreign firms hope to generate big business by persuading Japanese consumers to shift the bulk of their assets from low-yielding savings accounts and by winning support from the public because of the financial problems and other scandals plaguing domestic companies. As part of their strategic alliance, Travelers and Nikko plan to link their worldwide securities sales and trading businesses. They will also set up a jointly-owned Tokyo-based securities company with working capital of more than 140 billion yen (dlrs 1 billion). The Japanese venture, to be called Nikko Salomon Smith Barney Ltd., will incorporate the investment banking, consumer product and research operations of Nikko Securities, one of Japan's ``Big Three'' brokers. Masashi Kaneko, president of Nikko Securities, said that he does not expect the tie-up will trigger a drastic job cuts or branch closures in the immediate future. The venture will be headed by Yuji Shirakawa, currently president of Nikko Research Center. Toshiharu Kojima, chief executive of Salomon Smith Barney in Japan, will become co-chief executive of the venture, along with a Nikko Securities official. Investors reacted positively to the news. Nikko Securities shares rose 11 percent in Tokyo to close at 482 yen (dlrs 3.46). Travelers shares rose dlrs 1.75, or 3 percent, to close at dlrs 63 on the New York Stock Exchange. Separately, the Tokyo Stock Exchange launched an investigation Monday over possible insider trading involving Nikko shares after the price of its stock jumped Friday, an exchange official said. Nikko shares closed at 436 yen (dlrs 3.16) Friday, up 4.8 percent from Thursday's close. At one point during trading Friday, the shares rose as much as 10 percent. A total of 8.59 million Nikko shares were traded, about 5.9 times the amount traded on Thursday. Both Travelers and Nikko denied any involvement in insider trading.

A total of 8.59 million Nikko shares were traded, about 5.9 times the amount traded on Thursday. Both Travelers and Nikko denied any involvement in insider trading.

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 5th Ld-Writethru,0627
Thousands of refugees flee fighting in Kosovo; dozens reported dead,0620
RETRANSMITTING to fix slug Eds: UPDATES throughout with details. EDITS to tighten. By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Thousands of refugees from Serbia's Kosovo province streamed into neighboring Albania on Monday to escape some of the deadliest fighting in months. Dozens of people were reported killed. Albania appealed to the United States and European Union to intervene in what it said was a ``massacre'' in Kosovo. ``This is just the start of a war with tragic dimensions,'' the Albanian government said in a statement. With 39 people reported killed over the weekend and fighting apparently continuing, the bloodshed appeared the worst since March, when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on militants among the ethnic Albanian majority in Serb-ruled Kosovo. In New York, U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard spoke of ``heavy and indiscriminate shelling'' of villages near the border with Albania. He said U.N. workers could see heavy mortars being fired into the villages. Refugees said a 3-year-old child died en route to Albania. Ethnic Albanian officials said 37 Albanians were killed over the weekend. Twenty-seven died in clashes in Decani while 10 were killed when Serb police stormed a village elsewhere, they said. Two Serb policemen also died in the fighting around Decani, 45 miles west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina, Serb sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The fierce fighting forced about 2,000 Kosovo Albanians _ mostly women, children and the elderly _ across the border into Albania's Tropoja (pronounced Tro-POH-yah) region on Sunday and Monday, Albania said. They said more were arriving by the hour. In Tropoja, some refugees said they had walked for up to 20 hours to reach the Albanian town. They said Serb tanks were positioned inside Decani, and that Serb forces were besieging the town. Tropoja, although some three miles inside Albanian territory, resembled a community under siege, with most of the men carrying rifles or other weapons. Some men displayed the insignia of the Kosovo Liberation Army, the militant Kosovo organization spearheading the fight against Serbia. Andrew Harper, a U.N. aid worker, said he purchased three tons of flour, rice and other basics on the local market to provide for the refugees, and more aid was expected from Tirana, the Albanian capital, on Tuesday. ``I am very worried about providing for all these people,'' said Isa Memia, the town leader. ``We have grave (supply) problems ourselves, but they are our kinsmen, and we will help them.'' Authorities in Serbia are using Serbian police and the Yugoslav army to try to crush militants and maintain control over the province, where 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million is ethnic Albanian. The conflict has killed more than 200 people in Kosovo since the beginning of March. About half of the province is believed controlled by militant Albanians and many regions are blocked off, either by Serbs or Albanians. The Kosovo Information Center, close to the ethnic Albanian leadership, released the names of the 10 people it said were killed Sunday when Serb police stormed the village of Poklek, 15 miles west of Pristina. It said one had had his throat slit. According to the ethnic Albanians' account, Serb police burst into Poklek houses, pulled out villagers and told them to, ``Go to Albania and never return.'' Afterward, Serb police allegedly set 26 homes ablaze. Serbia is the dominant of two republics remaining in the Yugoslav federation.

EDITORS:
The AP World Service operates on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) and begins each 24-hour cycle at 0000 GMT. Listed below are key elements of the news service transmitted on all circuits, unless otherwise noted: 0000 GMT Opener, Advisory USING THE AP WIRE, Advisory AP News Digest AP Sports Digest By 0100 GMT AP Top Financial News 0300 GMT AP Asian News Digest, Advisory (Asia only) By 0500 GMT U.S. seasonal sports roundup 0700 GMT AP News Digest (0600 GMT summer time) AP Asian News Digest (Asia only) By 1000 GMT Asia Business Briefs (Asia, Europe, Mideast, southern Africa) 1100 GMT AP News Digest (1000 GMT summer time) 1200 GMT AP News Summary AP Asian News Digest, UPDATE (Asia only) 1300 GMT AP Sports Digest (1200 summer time) AP Top Financial News 1400 GMT AP Europe, Advisory (Europe only) 1430 GMT Africa Briefs (except Asia) 1500 GMT AP World Graphics, Advisory Middle East Business Briefs By 1600 GMT Global Weather 1800 GMT AP News Digest (1700 GMT summer time) AP World Graphics, Advisory 2100 GMT US-Canada-Business Briefs 2200 GMT Pronouncers, Advisory _ pronunciations of names, places in the news 2300 GMT AP World Graphics, Advisory 2330 GMT Latin America Briefs (Europe, Americas) ---- Other fixtures: Feature stories, slugged FEA, are listed at the bottom of each AP News Digest. Three packages on the 0000 GMT digests emphasize specific subjects: _ business on Tuesdays; _ science on Thursdays; _ arts and entertainment on Sundays. ``Editorial Roundup,'' excerpts of editorials from newspapers around the world. Thursdays around 1600 GMT. ``AP Weekly News Calendar,'' a list of significant news events expected in the upcoming week. Sent early in the GMT cycle each Friday and updated late in the cycle with U.S. events and again Mondays. ``AP Weekly Sports Calendar,'' a list of sports events expected in the coming week. Early in the Friday cycle. ``Today in History,'' a list of historic events for each day, transmitted early each weekday about one week in advance. ``US-Top Ten'' in Friday early (GMT) cycle _ the top popular songs in America each week. Theme slugs are used to identify some stories: SCI - science (discoveries, innovations); CYBER - computer technology; MED - medicine/health (discoveries, innovations); ARTS - arts/entertainment; TRAV - travel enterprise; FEA - general features; ANALYSIS - analytical backgrounders. Sports - used on all sports stories. Category codes are used on all stories to enable computerized sorting: ``i'' on general news or feature copy; ``f'' on financial stories or fixtures: and ``s'' on sports stories.

BC-AP Top Financial News,0780
EDITORS:
A summary of financial and business news from The Associated Press at 0000. Stories carry ``f'' or ``i'' category codes and move on this circuit in expanded form: NEW YORK (AP) _ Blue-chip stocks edged higher Monday, but technology shares took another drubbing as the delay of the new Intel chip compounded worries about the impact of a weak Asian economy on computer industry profits. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 22.42 points _ or 0.25 percent _ to 8,922.37 after retreating from an 81-point advance to within 20 points of 9,000. Broader indexes fell, with the technology-laden Nasdaq composite plunging nearly 2 percent as the recent exodus from big computer-related names picked up steam. (US-CLOSING STOCKS) NEW YORK (AP) _ American Home Products Corp., a leading drug and health care products concern, is buying biotechnology giant Monsanto Co. for stock valued at about dlrs 33 billion. The deal announced Monday would create a life sciences behemoth with dlrs 23 billion in annual sales, more financial muscle for research and marketing and ambitions for getting products out faster in a fiercely competitive market. American Home Products makes the pain reliever Advil, Chap Stick lip balm and Robitussin cough syrup as well as a range of prescription drugs and medical devices. Monsanto makes ingredients for agricultural products, pharmaceuticals and foods including the Lasso and Roundup herbicides and the Nutrasweet sugar substitute. (US-MONSANTO-AMERICAN HOME) MOSCOW (AP) _ Russian stocks plunged more than 10 percent Monday in a frenzy of selling by Russian banks and a cold shoulder from foreign investors wary of the market's turmoil. The Russian Trading System index closed 10.2 percent lower after late panic selling gripped the market and reassuring comments from government officials failed to calm jittery investors. Monday's close matched the 10-percent fall last Wednesday, when hectic selling caused the stock market to plummet and threatened a run on the national currency, the ruble. The market has fallen 44 percent since the beginning of May, making it the worst performing market in the world, and there are fears of further losses before calm is restored. (RUSSIA-ECONOMY) PARIS (AP) _ In normal times, an Air France strike would merely cause havoc. But the walkout by the carrier's pilots Monday was worse: a deep embarrassment for a country preparing to host in just nine days the world's biggest sporting event, the World Cup. Despite pressure from leftist government ministers, most of the state-run carrier's 3,200 pilots stayed out of their cockpits to protest 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. They are threatening to stay out for two weeks or more. That's well into the World Cup, which begins June 10 and lasts a month. On just the first day Monday, 100,000 passengers were sent scrambling. And it could be only the beginning: French train workers were planning to strike at the end of the week. (AIR FRANCE-STRIKE) KARACHI, Pakistan (AP) _ The Karachi Stock Market hit a record low on Monday falling 128.76 points to close at 911.44. ``There was massive liquidation by foreign investors and this put immense pressure on the market,'' said Hasan Davar, a trader with UBS Securities. The Karachi Stock Exchange opened Monday for the first time since Pakistan exploded five nuclear devices last Thursday and a sixth one on Saturday, bringing global condemnation and threats of economic sanctions. Within hours of the first five explosions, Pakistan's president declared a state of emergency and froze all foreign currency accounts to try to prevent a panic exodus of foreign capital from the country. Pakistan's foreign reserves stand at dlrs 1.2 billion, which is barely enough to pay for the next six weeks of imports, say financial analysts. (PAKISTAN-STOCK MARKET) JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israel on Monday decided to retain ownership of 51 percent of the national air carrier El Al, despite recommendations the unprofitable company be sold off. A statement from the ministerial committee overseeing Israel's privatization plans quoted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as saying the decision ``will protect our national interests.'' Israel radio said national security and emergency situations were key factors in the decision to retain a majority share of the airline. The decision ensures that El Al flights will continue to be grounded during the Jewish Sabbath _ from Friday sundown to Saturday sundown. The Sabbath groundings have been cited as a factor in the company's losses. (ISRAEL-EL AL)
(PROFILE (WS SL:BC-AP Top Financial News; CT:f; (REG:EURO;) (REG:BRIT;) (REG:SCAN;) (REG:MEST;) (REG:AFRI;) (REG:INDI;) (REG:ENGL;) (REG:ASIA;) (LANG:ENGLISH;)) )

BC-AP News Summary,0612
A summary of late news from The Associated Press. Some items have moved on this circuit in expanded form with ``i'' or ``f'' category codes: PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Thousands of refugees from Serbia's Kosovo province streamed into neighboring Albania on Monday to escape some of the deadliest fighting in months. Dozens of people were reported killed. Albania appealed to the United States and European Union to intervene. Reports from Serb and Albanian sources often were contradictory and could not be independently verified. But with 39 people reported killed over the weekend, and fighting apparently continuing, the bloodshed appeared the worst since March, when Serbian police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on militants among the ethnic Albanian majority in Serb-ruled Kosovo. The latest fighting forced about 2,000 Kosovo Albanians _ mostly women, children and the elderly _ across the border into Albania's Tropoja region on Sunday and Monday, Albania said. (YUGOSLAVIA-KOSOVO) TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ Iran will not build an atomic bomb despite nuclear tests by Pakistan and India that have forced ``a new security situation'' on the nearby Asian subcontinent, the defense minister said in comments published Monday. India tested five nuclear devices last month, which were followed by six explosions by neighbor and rival Pakistan. Iran denies repeated U.S. and Israeli allegations that it is close to building an atom bomb, saying its nuclear program is peaceful. (IRAN-NUCLEAR) JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Facing increased pressure to clean up past misdeeds, Indonesia's new government announced a broad-based inquiry Monday into corruption under ex-President Suharto. However, it stopped short of meeting demands by student protesters and others who want the wealth of Suharto and his super-rich family specifically targeted. Critics say the Suhartos blatantly used their power and position to amass billions of dollars by dominating the now ailing economy. Thousands of students staged peaceful protests in several cities Monday calling for an end to both local and national graft. (INDONESIA) FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ Some hobbled on makeshift crutches, a few carried stretchers and others broke into a run as helicopters carrying emergency aid landed Monday in remote northern Afghanistan, devastated by an earthquake that killed more than 3,000 people. On a small distant hillock, a woman cuddled her infant, a toddler sat nearby wailing. Crouched behind, her head buried in a bright orange shawl, a woman sobbed. The quake, which hit Saturday with a preliminary magnitude of 6.9, flattened entire villages, sliced mountains and triggered landslides. The estimates of the dead vary from 3,000 to 5,000 people. Thousands more were homeless and missing. Aftershocks lingered in the region Monday, sending frightened residents scrambling outdoors. (AFGHANISTAN-QUAKE) AMMAN, Jordan (AP) _ Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah arrived Monday in Jordan for talks aimed at resolving differences between key Arab leaders on a proposed summit on the Middle East peace process. Abdullah came from Damascus where he met at least twice with Syrian President Hafez Assad to persuade him to accept an open agenda at the proposed summit, Arab diplomats said. Such a demand also has been made by Jordan and some Gulf nations. But all agree that the summit should forge a unified Arab position against Israel. Talaat Hamid, spokesman for the 22-member Arab League, said in Cairo that consultations were under way between Arab leaders over the time and place for the summit. (ARABS-SUMMIT)
(PROFILE (WS SL:BC-AP News Summary; CT:i; (REG:EURO;) (REG:BRIT;) (REG:SCAN;) (REG:MEST;) (REG:AFRI;) (REG:INDI;) (REG:ENGL;) (REG:ASIA;) (LANG:ENGLISH;)) )

BC-People and Places,0840
People and places in the news meteorite sale, Geri Halliwell and Paul Gascoigne, and a noisy sign. Some items may also have moved as separates.
Eds: Contains items on Hitler and potato chips, Jerry Seinfeld,
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ An advertising agency apologized for using Adolf Hitler's image to sell potato chips in Thailand, and was talking with the chip-maker Monday over whether to pull the ads. The TV commercial for ``X'' potato chips shows Hitler giving a Nazi salute and a shot of a swastika transformed into the ``X'' product logo. Posters for the chips suggest that eating the snacks would transform even Hitler himself into a fun-loving, likable character. ``The commercial ... is designed to communicate that the world would be a better place if happiness ruled. It was never intended to offend and the agency apologizes to anyone who finds it insensitive,'' the international ad agency, Leo Burnett Bangkok, said in a statement Sunday, after Israeli diplomats complained. Talks were under way Monday between the agency and the Thai client, Food Processing Co. ___ SYDNEY, Australia (AP) _ The array of snacks Jerry Seinfeld reportedly requires backstage is idiosyncratic enough to inspire an episode of the popular U.S. television show ``Seinfeld.'' The superstar comedian is scheduled to do eight live shows in Australia this month, but only if he gets certain foods, according to The Daily Telegraph. The paper quotes an unnamed promoter as saying Seinfeld's ``essential backstage items'' include: 18 small bottles of water on ice (any brand except Evian is fine), one bag of Rold Gold pretzels, one vegetable tray for four people, one small jar of mayonnaise, and a small amount of pasta salad _ hold the mayonnaise. ``By superstar standards, it's not that demanding a list,'' the promoter told the Telegraph. ___ SAN FRANCISCO (AP) _ Mark Lenney now owns a little piece of Mars. The engineer from Santa Clara, California, shelled out dlrs 700 for a Mars rock at an auction on Sunday that included dinosaur bones, rare gems, minerals and several meteorites. ``It was reasonably priced,'' said Lenney, who added that the mystery of the universe propelled him to his first auction ``to be in touch with the wonder of it all.'' Lenney also picked up a dlrs 450 slice of meteorite created at the dawn of our solar system and a dlrs 325 rock from a 1969 meteor shower that contains dozens of amino acids, the building blocks of proteins. The biggest seller at the auction was a 995-pound (450-kilo) boulder that was part of a vast meteorite shower that fell on the edge of the Kalahari Desert thousands of years ago. It sold for a whopping dlrs 101,500. Not to be outdone by more experienced collectors, 9-year-old Caleb Kauffman of San Francisco won the bidding for a sample of Sikholite-Alin meteorite, an iron specimen that fell on Siberia in 1947. ___ LONDON (AP) _ It was all over the tabloids Monday, and the quality papers, too. Questions were asked in the House of Commons: Geri Spice is out. So's Gazza. Geri Halliwell, 25, was the eldest member of the Spice Girls, the inventor of ``girl power,'' the gorgeous pouting idol of millions of pre-adolescent girls. She quit after a series of fights with the other four members of the group _ and after earning a reported dlrs 20 million in two years. Paul Gascoigne, 31, was a sometimes brilliant soccer player who won the nation's heart with his tears when he was ejected from the 1990 World Cup. But the nation often had to think again: Gazza drunk, Gazza posing at a urinal on his wedding day, Gazza's wife walking out of the marriage with a bruised face. England manager Glen Hoddle dropped Gascoigne from the World Cup squad because of his poor physicial condition. In the House of Commons, Labor lawmaker Gareth Thomas urged the government to encourage Geri ``to think again.'' BC-Britain-Prosecution Agency
Britain's state prosecution agency faces major shake-up, government says
LONDON (AP) _ The government has said it will back proposals for a shake-up of Britain's public prosecution organization _ which would include the introduction of American-style district attorneys _ in an effort to stop so many serious cases being dropped before they get to court. A damming report on the 12-year-old Crown Prosecution Service issued Monday said it was too bureaucratic and centralized to do its job, with lawyers spending too much time on paperwork and not enough fighting cases. ``Our assessment of the CPS is that it has the potential to become a lively, successful and esteemed part of the criminal justice system, but that, sadly, none of these adjectives applied to the service as a whole at present,'' the report, written by former judge Sir Iain Glidewell, said. Glidewell said that prosecutors failed to pursue one in eight cases, and that about a quarter of people charged with more serious offenses had their prosecutions dropped. In contrast, only 1 in 100 motoring offenses was dropped by the CPS, the report said. The service's critics, including police officers, say that has happened because the service's lawyers prefer to pursue easy-to-win cases and engage in plea-bargaining in more serious cases to avoid the expense of going to court. The report made 75 recommendations, including the establishing of 42 new Chief Crown Prosecutors, one for each police force area in England and Wales, which British newspapers reported Tuesday would be modeled on the U.S. system of district attorneys. Scotland has its own state prosecuting service. ``The Government accepts the thrust of the report's proposals for reordering CPS priorities to focus more on the core business of prosecuting, greater separation of management from legal work, greater autonomy for the areas, and better prospects for the staff,'' Attorney General John Morris told the House of Commons on Monday. Brazil, Mexico.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) _ A Puerto Rican separatist group responsible for bombings in the 1970s and 1980s on Monday promised to fight to prevent the sale of the public telephone utility to GTE Corp. and other investors. ``The sale of the Puerto Rico Telephone Company is nothing more than a declaration of war,'' the People's Boricua Army said in a letter sent to the Associated Press. ``Now they will know what war is.' Gov. Pedro Rossello announced a dlrs 1.9 billion deal last week to sell part of the telephone company to investors and give GTE control over management. The sale must be approved by the Puerto Rican legislature. The guerrilla group is also known as the Macheteros, or ``cane-cutters.'' Founded in 1978, it claimed responsibility for several bombings and other attacks on U.S. government installations through the early 1980s. ___ SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic (AP) _ A bomb exploded outside the headquarters of the Dominican Republic's main anti-drug agency early Monday, leaving a bucket-sized crater in the pavement but causing no injuries. Explosives experts took samples from the site Monday morning in Santo Domingo, but nobody was immediately arrested. The blast came days after a visit to Santo Domingo by Barry McCaffrey, U.S. drug policy adviser to President Bill Clinton. The explosion also followed cocaine seizures totaling 1,980 pounds (900 kilos). The cocaine was believed to have come from the Cali Cartel in Colombia. ___ PANAMA CITY, Panama (AP) _ A major drug trafficking suspect who was the focus of a political scandal in Panama has been extradited to Florida, officials said Monday. In a radio interview, Interior Minister Raul Montenegro said Castrillon Henao, a Colombian, was flown to Florida on Sunday, where he was also wanted on money laundering charges. Local newspapers reported that Jose Castrillon Henao had contributed to the 1994 campaign of President Ernesto Perez Balladares. The president denied knowledge and vowed to tighten rules on campaign financing and against money laundering. Police arrested Castrillon Henao in April 1996, accusing him of being head of the Cali drug cartel's operations in Panama. ___ RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil (AP) _ Brazilian drug stores saw brisk sales of Viagra on Monday, the first day the anti-impotency drug was legally sold in the country. Pharmacies that had not yet received the drug reported waiting lists with as many of 40 names. Several others had opened telephone hot lines for home delivery of the drug. By early afternoon, Gilberto Silvany, a Rio pharmacist, reported his store had already sold out 80 percent of its stock. ``I think we'd probably sell more but a lot of people are too embarrassed to ask for a drug that affects them down there,'' Silvany said. Although Monday marks the first day that Viagra was sold legally in Brazil, it has been available for some time on the black market for as much dlrs 22 a pill. In the drug stores, the drug sells for about dlrs 48 for a box of four pills. ___ MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Mexicans continue to hold a generally favorable image of President Ernesto Zedillo, despite skepticism about the success of key policies, according to a poll published Monday by the daily Reforma. Asked the rate the president on a scale of one to 10, those polled gave Zedillo an average rating of 6.4, down from 6.5 in March and 6.7 in December, but higher than the ratings in his first two years after taking office in December 1994. The poll found that 54 percent approved of Zedillo's performance, down from 59 percent in September 1997, while 39 percent disapproved, up from 32 percent in September. However those polled overwhelmingly said the government had achieved little success in halting corruption, solving the rebellion in Chiapas, improving the economy, attacking pollution or fighting drug trafficking. Reforma said its polling unit surveyed 1,190 adults across Mexico in late May. It gave a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent. ___ MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Bandits blocked the road from Acapulco to Zihuatanejo and robbed passengers aboard a luxury tourist bus of more than dlrs 2,200, newspapers reported Monday. The daily Reforma reported that one of the passengers, Isolina Sanchez, was shot in the thigh during the incident and was being treated at a hospital. Federal Highway Police told Reforma that the incident occurred at 3:30 a.m. Saturday on the outskirts of Acapulco. Six heavily armed men blocked the highway and forced the driver to leave the road. Passengers were then robbed of their belongings.

BC-Japan-Explosion
Explosion destroys three buses near Tokyo airport, no injuries
TOKYO (AP) _ A pre-dawn explosion Tuesday at a bus depot just outside Tokyo destroyed three buses, two of which were used for shuttling passengers to Tokyo's main international airport, a police spokesman said. Atsushi Henmi of the Chiba Prefectural, or State, Police, said the explosion occurred in the bus depot at the Matsudo office of Keisei Electric Railway's motor vehicle department at around 3:30 a.m. (1830 GMT Monday). The explosion set two limousine buses and one regular passenger bus in the depot on fire, destroying them, Henmi said. There were five bus company employees on night at the time of the explosion, but none was hurt, Henmi said. Police suspect anti-airport radicals may have been involved in the explosion as fragments of lead cables and batteries were found near the explosion site. The airport at Narita, 65 kilometers (40 miles), east of Tokyo, opened in 1978 with a single runway. Left-wing activists, opposed to the expansion of the airport, claim that the government has planned to use the airport for military purposes. In April, a pre-dawn explosion damaged the home of an official at the airport, while in February the ultra-leftist Revolutionary Workers Association claimed responsibility for three homemade rockets fired into a cargo plane area at Narita airport. One airport worker was injured in that attack, which came as athletes and other officials were arriving at the airport for the Winter Olympic Games in Nagano. (km)
