BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open,0771
Can Venus and Hingis be the next Chris and Martina?
By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Could there be, finally, a rivalry to match Evert vs. Navratilova? Surely that's what the tennis world hopes. Not so fast, says Martina Hingis. She isn't ready to call Venus Williams a true rival yet. ``Everybody else is trying to make rivalries against me,'' she says. ``Venus, she won Key Biscayne, but that's not a Grand Slam.'' ``I'm No. 1, I've won four Grand Slams. I have the self-confidence.'' True. But Williams is playing so well at this year's French Open that their match Tuesday is the most anticipated of the tournament. Hingis and Williams will meet in the quarterfinals, but many see it as worthy of the final. Williams, seeded eighth at Roland Garros in just her fourth event on clay, responded diplomatically to Hingis' comments. ``I think that she's playing good tennis, and she has every right to say what she wants to,'' Williams said. Hingis holds a 5-2 record against Williams, including a 6-0, 6-4 win in the final of the U.S. Open last summer in their only previous Grand Slam meeting. They are 2-2 this year. But Hingis won their only career encounter on clay, the final of the Italian Open in May. ``It was a good victory for me there,'' Hingis said. ``I hope she will remember that, too.'' Statistically speaking, the two have had an almost identical run through the early rounds here. Hingis has lost just 14 games while averaging 56 minutes per victory. Williams has lost 13 games and averaged 58 minutes per match. But stylistically speaking, they are totally different. Hingis has a masterful touch, moving opponents around the court with precise groundstrokes. Williams is pure power. Power is what Marat Safin has, in spades. The 18-year-old qualifier stormed his way through the first three rounds, but lost in the fourth Monday, in five tough sets. The French fans chanted wildly for his opponent, Frenchman Cedric Pioline. ``Allez Cedric!'' they yelled. But as the match wore on, there were growing chants of ``Ma-RAT! Ma-RAT!'' It was in tribute to the remarkable run by the young Russian playing his first Grand Slam event. He began the tournament ranked 116th, but won't be there much longer. ``I think I can beat good players now,'' he said after Pioline ended his run, 7-5, 4-6, 6-7 (5-7), 6-4, 6-4. Safin's tournament started with three qualifying matches just to get into the main draw. Next up was Andre Agassi. With the American star hot on a comeback, Safin wasn't given a chance. But he thwarted the comeback, and then ousted defending champion Gustavo Kuerten, ranked eighth in the world, in another five-setter. In the third round, Safin, by now the story of the tournament, had a slightly easier time _ a four-setter over Daniel Vacek of the Czech Republic. That set up the match with Pioline. The 28-year-old Frenchman is erratic, but brilliant on occasion. He's reached the finals of Wimbledon and the U.S. Open, both times losing to Pete Sampras. Pioline has a reputation for choking at the end of matches. He's reached 12 finals but has only two singles titles. Safin knew nothing of that. ``Nobody told me,'' he said. It didn't matter. This time, Safin unraveled. Pioline broke serve three times, including once in the fifth set. That was enough. Safin said he wasn't thrown by the 16,000 or so fans at Roland Garros shouting for Pioline. However, the presence of soccer star Ronaldo in the VIP box was another matter. Asked if he'd been distracted by the Brazilian, in town for the World Cup, Safin thought for a moment, then announced: ``Yes.'' ``I'd never seen Ronaldo so close up before,'' he explained. Then again, maybe it was the presence next to Ronaldo of Anna Kournikova, the blonde Russian teenager who also lost Monday. ``She's so beautiful, unbelievable,'' Safin said. Whatever the reason, Safin said he'd learned a lesson on center court. ``You have to be a little bit clever on the important points,'' he said. ``You can't lose your serve when you are 5-3 up.'' Olga Morozova, the former Russian champion, played with Safin's mother, Rauza. She said Safin was the new great hope for Russian tennis. ``It's really quite unbelievable, what he did here,'' she said. Safin himself was more down to earth. What makes him happy is that he broke into the top 100 this week.

BC-UN-Kosovo,0532
Rugova calls for greater UN role, independence for Kosovo
Eds: RECAPS previous By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ With violence escalating in Kosovo, the head of the self-declared government of the Kosovo Albanians is calling for an international civilian administration for the Serb-ruled province as a first step toward independence. ``The independence of Kosovo is the best solution,'' Ibrahim Rugova told reporters Monday after meeting Secretary-General Kofi Annan. He said he asked Annan for ``more support for Kosovo'' and unspecified ``preventive measures'' to prevent further deterioration and ``massacres and massive ethnic cleansing.'' Rugova said independence for Kosovo, which has a 90 percent majority Albanian population, would help stabilize ``even Serbia, although at this stage they think in a different way.'' Serbia rejects independence and considers Kosovo the cradle of Serb culture. The United States and other major countries also oppose independence but have called for self-rule for the Kosovo Albanians within Serbian borders. But Rugova said an independent Kosovo could guarantee the safety of Serbs living within its borders. Pending independence, he suggested creation of ``some kind of international civilian administration, or a protectorate, as an interim measure.'' He also called for an end to Serb military and police operations against Albanian separatists who have been fighting for independence for the Albanian-majority region, which is now a province of Serbia. Serbia, together with Montenegro, forms Yugoslavia. Rugova arrived in New York after a visit to Washington in which he conferred with President Bill Clinton and U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright. His visit coincided with a sharp escalation of violence in the troubled province. Thousands of refugees streamed Monday into neighboring Albania to escape some of the deadliest fighting in months. Dozens of people were reported killed. Albania appealed to the United States and European Union to intervene in what it said was a ``massacre'' in Kosovo. ``This is just the start of a war with tragic dimensions,'' the Albanian government said in a statement. The bloodshed appeared the worst since March, when Serb police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on militants among the ethnic Albanian majority. On Monday, U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard said 1,300 people arrived Sunday at the Albanian border town of Tropoja, the largest number in a single day. Eckhard said an undetermined number of others were believed trapped by the fighting and unable to cross the border. During the press conference, Rugova applauded U.S. mediation to promote a dialogue between the Kosovo Albanians and President Slobodan Milosevic. Milosevic revoked Kosovo's autonomy in 1989. ``In order for the negotiations to be successful, it is critical that police and military operations stop,'' Rugova said. ``Serb police and military actions have been continuing, resulting in many people killed.''

BC-Sports-Baseball-Dodgers-Nomo,0557
Nomo's career with Dodgers over AP Sports Writer
Eds: RECAPS previous By JOHN NADEL
LOS ANGELES (AP) _ ``Nomomania'' came to a shocking, abrupt end in Los Angeles. Hideo Nomo, who brought thousands of Japanese fans to major league baseball after joining the Dodgers in 1995, was cut loose by the team Monday. The Dodgers designated Nomo for assignment, removing him from the team's 40-man roster immediately. They have 10 days to either trade or assign the 29-year-old right-hander, or seven days to place him on unconditional release waivers. The decision marked another major move since the Fox Group purchased the Dodgers from the O'Malley family 2 1/2 months ago. Catcher Mike Piazza and third baseman Todd Zeile were traded to the Florida Marlins on May 15 for outfielders Gary Sheffield and Jim Eisenreich, third baseman Bobby Bonilla, catcher Charles Johnson and a minor league pitcher. And last week, the Dodgers were reportedly close to acquiring left-hander Randy Johnson from Seattle. Nomo's name was mentioned prominently, and agent Don Nomura said at a Dodger Stadium news conference Monday those rumors caused his client to want to leave Los Angeles. Nomo's popularity among Asian fans was similar to the kind of fan support _ ``Fernandomania'' _ received in the Mexican community after the emergence of left-hander Fernando Valenzuela, who pitched for the Dodgers from 1980-90. Nomura met with Dodgers general manager Fred Claire on Sunday and requested a move be made. A day earlier, Nomo was booed during a 7-3 loss to Cincinnati in which he allowed seven hits and six runs in 3 2-3 innings. Afterward, manager Bill Russell said, ``Today was the fastball, it just wasn't there. We're told that he's healthy, but he's not the same.'' Nomo, who underwent arthroscopic surgery on his pitching elbow last fall, was just 2-7 with a 5.05 ERA, although he struck out 73 in 67 2-3 innings and pitched two complete games. He lost his last four decisions, allowing 18 earned runs in 26 2-3 innings. ``Hideo had expressed the thought that it would be best to make a move,'' Claire said. ``We'll be talking to many teams, perhaps all teams. There is a time frame. That being said, there is also a great demand for pitching. Hideo is an outstanding pitcher.'' Nomo said little at the news conference. But, through an interpreter, he said it was true he ``definitely needed a change of scenery, a change of environment.'' ``I'm truly grateful for everything the Dodgers did provide me, with an opportunity to fulfill a dream,'' he said. Nomo is signed through the end of the season and is earning dlrs 2.7 million this year _ his fourth in the major leagues. Nomo was the 1995 NL Rookie of the Year, and recorded 500 strikeouts faster than any other pitcher in major league history, accomplishing the feat in 444 2-3 innings. He was 13-6 with a 2.54 ERA and 236 strikeouts in 1995; 16-11 with a 3.19 ERA and 234 strikeouts in 1996, and 14-12 with a 4.25 ERA and 233 strikeouts last year. When asked if Monday's move meant Nomo's career with the Dodgers was definitely finished, Claire said, ``That is safe to say. It's not a move you can turn back from.''

TOKYO (AP) _ The U.S. dollar was higher in early trading Tuesday from its levels late in Tokyo on Monday, though off record highs reached overnight in New York. Tokyo stock prices rose moderately. The dollar bought 139.42 yen in early trading, up 0.30 yen from late Monday in Tokyo. The Yomiuri newspaper, quoting unnamed international sources, said the deputies of the Group of Seven major nations may hold a meeting to stem the yen's slide. Japan's Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga, meanwhile, expressed renewed concern about the current level of the yen against the dollar. ``In any case, I have strong concern about an excessively weak yen, and we will take appropriate and decisive action against it,'' Matsunaga said at a regular news conference. On the stock market, sentiment improved slightly after Monday's announcement that Nikko Securities Co., a major Japanese brokerage, and Travelers Group of the United States were planning an equity tie-up. The benchmark 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 125.82 points, or 0.82 percent, to 15,446.85 in the first 30 minutes of trading. On Monday, the index had lost 349.75 points, or 2.23 percent. ``The market welcomed Nikko's alliance, as it will likely trigger more Japanese financial institutions' tie-ups with foreign institutions,'' said Masaru Arai, general manager of the stock division at Ryoko Securities. Deepening worries over the state of Japan's economy had triggered Monday's fall. BC-Air France-Strike,0656
Talks set Tuesday, but can pilots be enticed to return to skies?
EDS: RECAPS previous AP Photos PAR101,105,108. By ELAINE GANLEY Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Air France, the official World Cup carrier, moved into its second day of a strike Tuesday, setting talks to find common ground with angry pilots and save face ahead of the soccer championships next week. The strike caused chaos for almost 100,000 passengers on its first day Monday, worries for fans and teams attending the month-long World Cup starting June 10 and embarrassment for all. The state-run carrier's main pilots' union called the 15-day action to protest against 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. Most of the 3,200 Air France pilots did not work Monday. Departure screens at airports around the nation flashed the bad news: ``annule'' and ``canceled'' next to list upon list of flights. Air France planes, many decorated with giant paintings of soccer players representing the 32 competing teams, sat idle. Air France predicted a slight improvement in traffic Tuesday with 15 percent of long-haul flights taking off, compared to 10 percent Monday, and up to 35 percent of short- and medium-haul flights scheduled. ``I think that all the French without exception, and naturally the pilots ... hope the (World Cup) will be a great fete, a great fete for world soccer and a great fete for France,'' said the airline's president, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, in a television interview Monday night. ``And I don't see who would take responsibility to wreck this great fete by a strike which can't be understood.'' Air France is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France, and the company has said if the strike continues it will probably use outside carriers to enable it to meet its obligations. Spinetta appeared to be counting in part on World Cup ardor to convince pilots to return to the cockpit in talks set for 3:30 p.m (1330 GMT) Tuesday -- the first since failed 11th hour talks last Thursday. But he gave no hint that Air France, which almost went bankrupt in 1993, was ready to withdraw its controversial plan to cut pilots' salaries in exchange for shares in Air France. Pilots also want Air France to do away with salary cuts for starting pilots, a system in force for the past year. Nicolas Minvelle, waiting at Charles de Gaulle Airport for a flight to Senegal, said it wasn't fair the pilots were striking just before the World Cup. ``They use an international event to bother everyone. It's too bad,'' he said. The airports in Lyon and Marseille, France's second and third-largest cities, were virtually deserted. Rental car agencies did brisk business. The U.S. Soccer Federation, heading to France on Thursday, said it is sending the U.S. team on an American Airlines flight to Paris that connects to an Air France flight to Lyon. As a backup, the Americans have rented buses for all their travel plans in France. ``After the draw, everyone was scared,'' federation president Alan Rothenberg said Monday. ``We've gone out and spent to set up our own system ... to take care of ourselves.'' Passengers ``are being taken hostage,'' the French passenger association ADUA said in a statement. BRISBANE, Australia (AP) _ A new poll released Tuesday predicted Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party will split the conservative vote in Queensland's June 13 election, lifting the opposition Labor Party to power. If Labor ousts conservative Premier Rob Borbidge's government, it will be a bad omen for the nationwide chances of Prime Minister John Howard and his conservatives in the federal election expected later this year. Whether or not Hanson's party, famous for its anti-gun control, anti-Asian immigration, and anti-Aboriginal welfare policies wins any seats itself, it would have made a major impact on Australia's political landscape. Labor and Borbidge's conservatives currently hold 44 seats each in the state's 89-seat Parliament; Borbidge has governed only because a single conservative independent member of Parliament has voted with his side. The Newspoll survey in The Australian newspaper shows support for the governing conservative coalition in big-city Brisbane seats dropped from 42 percent to 25 percent while Labor had soared from 49 to 54 percent. The Newspoll showed support for Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party had tripled to 15 percent in the past six months statewide, and almost doubled to 7 percent nationally in the past two weeks. In Queensland rural areas, support for the governing conservatives had slumped from 54 percent to 41 percent. Newspoll said the margin of error on various questions ranged from 3 to 4.4 percent, depending on the number of respondents. CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Much of the Arab world greeted with concern nuclear tests by India and Pakistan but blamed the arms race on the West for turning a blind eye to Israel's secretive nuclear arsenal. India's five tests May 11-13 escalated the long-standing Indo-Pakistan rivalry to the nuclear level. Pakistan reponded with what it said were six detonations of its own; five on Friday and one on Saturday. Pakistan and India have fought three wars since they were carved from the same British colony 50 years ago. They are divided by religion _ Pakistan is officially Muslim and India is predominately Hindu _ and a simmering territorial dispute over the Himalayan region of Kashmir, which is divided between them and claimed by both countries. The world ``must seriously encourage'' India and Pakistan to quickly sign a non-aggression treaty to prevent regional instability, the OIC, a 55-nation group that includes Arab as well as other countries such as Iran and Indonesia, said in a statement. But the Arabs were quick to point out that Israel, located in the center of a hostile Arab world, has most likely possessed nuclear bombs for decades without facing any punishment from the rest of the world. Iranian Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi defended Pakistan's tests, saying India left Pakistan no choice. At a news conference during a visit to Pakistan on Monday, Kharrazi also said Muslims in the Middle East long had worried about Israel's nuclear capability and could now feel confident that a fellow Islamic nation possessed similar abilities. ``As a matter of its national security and to create a balance in the region,'' Pakistan had to respond with its own nuclear tests, he said. The leader of a radical Palestinian guerrilla group also boasted that the Muslims now have an Islamic bomb to counter Israel. ``Pakistan's possession of nuclear power is to be considered an asset to the Arab and Muslim nations,'' Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the spiritual leader of Hamas movement, said. But if other Arab nations felt any pride in that fact, they didn't show it. Kuwait, which has good relations with Pakistan and India, said it expresses its ``extreme regret and worry about this arms race ... and its dangerous consequences on the security and stability of the area.'' The Saudi Arabian government issued a statement Monday claiming ``double standards by the international community through excluding Israel from nuclear inspections have encouraged the nuclear arms race. The United States imposed harsh sanctions on Libya, Iraq and Iran _ and now on India and Pakistan _ for trying to acquire weapons of mass destruction. Similar statements were made earlier by the United Arab Emirates and Lebanon. Egypt, the Arab world's stalwart, criticized neither Pakistan nor its traditional ally India. But Foreign Minister Amr Moussa said their explosions have proved that an international treaty banning nuclear tests ``has gone with the wind.'' Israel is believed to have 100 nuclear warheads. Successive Israeli governments have refused to either confirm that or allow the International Atomic Energy Agency, the U.N. nuclear watchdog, to inspect its facilities. Israel has warned that the Indian and Pakistani tests could encourage Iran to follow suit. But Kharrazi said his government has no intention of developing a bomb and that its nuclear program is for peaceful purposes.

Aid trickles into quake-stricken Afghanistan
Eds: RECAPS previous AP Photo ISL102 By PHIL GOODWIN Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ Aid organizations struggled to deliver emergency supplies and treat injured survivors of an earthquake in a remote region of northern Afghanistan that killed at least 3,000 people and left thousands more homeless. Landslides cut off roads to the hardest-hit areas, where 16 villages were destroyed, blocking aid trucks, Martin Griffiths, U.N. deputy emergency relief coordinator, said Monday in New York. ``This is a scenario from hell,'' Griffiths said. ``It's a region which is extremely inaccessible.'' As aftershocks rumbled through the region Monday, frightened residents scrambled out of the few homes still standing and refused to go back inside. The quake, which hit Saturday with a preliminary magnitude of 6.9, flattened entire villages, cracked mountains and unleashed landslides across this rugged, remote region of struggling farmers. Estimates of the dead ranged from 3,000 to 5,000. Thousands more were missing or homeless. About 45,000 of the area's 70,000 people have no shelter, Griffiths said. The quake sent houses tumbling down mountainsides into the valleys below. Up to 80 villages were estimated to be heavily damaged, and another dozen obliterated. In Chaujan, a village near the quake's epicenter, the scene was horrific. Thousands of homes were gone. People wandered, dazed, through the rubble. In the middle of the devastation, a lone wooden door stood erect, clumps of mud on it the only reminder of the home that once stood. The family of four who lived there was dead. Tending to the injured was a priority Monday. The International Red Cross and the United Nations set up mobile medical units in Shari Basurkh, 50 kilometers (30 miles) from Faisabad, the capital of northern Badakhshan province. Doctors Without Borders were operating a clinic there. Helicopters ferried the wounded, many of them with broken bones, most of them small children and the elderly. Aid workers distributed blankets, tents and plastic sheeting. Among the hardest-hit areas was Rostaq, the site of a Feb. 4 earthquake that killed as many as 2,300 people and left another 8,000 homeless. Many residents were living in tents even before the quake, having lost their homes in the February quake. The region is in the control of an alliance fighting the Taliban religious army, which holds the Afghan capital, Kabul. Anti-Taliban soldiers say they have recovered 1,650 bodies, but added that thousands more were dead. Aid workers said people were traumatized, their eyes unfocused, their hands automatically searching through the rubble. With poor sanitation and recent rains, the risks of malaria, cholera and hemorrhagic fever were rising as each day passed. Many homes simply crumbled into dust in Saturday's violent shaking, after being cracked by the February quake and pounded by recent, relentless rains. Cargo aircraft from neighboring Pakistan, packed with emergency supplies, reached Faisabad on Monday. A U.N. disaster coordination team was flying in Monday to help manage the aid operation. France was sending about 35 tons of aid to Dushanbe, Tajikistan, to be transported to the disaster area. Japan, the European Union, and the Netherlands were also sending assistance. ``The key here is to respond very, very quickly,'' Griffiths said. ``The key thing we learned from the last time is to get air transport in quickly.''

Australian woman swims from Mexico to Cuba
AP Photos By JOSE LUIS MAGANA Associated Press Writer
HAVANA (AP) _ Australian Susie Maroney became the first person to swim from Mexico to Cuba, completing the estimated 197-kilometer (122-mile) crossing in less than 39 hours. Maroney, 23, touched Cuban soil at 5:03 a.m. on Monday, walking onto the beach at Las Tumbas in eastern Cuba. She said Monday afternoon that she was still feeling a bit weak. ``I'm just really relieved that it's all over,'' she told The Associated Press in Havana. Maroney said she crossed the Yucatan Channel in 38 hours and 25 minutes, swimming in a shark-proof cage towed by her support team. She suffered jelly fish stings and bruised wrists from hitting the cage, but otherwise was in good shape. Last year Maroney became the first woman to swim from Cuba to Florida when she completed 190 kilometers (118 miles) in a record 24 hours and 34 minutes. The crossing from Mexico's Isle Mujeres, near Cancun, to Cuba was more difficult, she said. The water was very choppy, Maroney said. She swallowed a lot of sea water and suffered from seasickness, she said. ``It was definitely the hardest swim,'' she said. Though she said there were moments when she feared she wouldn't finish, Maroney's spirits were boosted by the sight of dolphins and turtles and the goal of becoming the first person to make the crossing. ``You do it for yourself personally,'' she said. ``It's just the best feeling when you touch the sand and you realize you've swam the furthest.'' Australian media reported that if the 197-kilometer (122-mile) distance is verified, Maroney will be able to claim the record for the longest distance ever swum at sea: In 1976, American marathon swimmer Walter Poenisch swam 196 kilometers (121.5 miles) wearing flippers in the Straits of Florida. Maroney has been swimming long distance since she was 14, and has crossed the English Channel twice. She set the women's record for longest distance covered in 24 hours without the aid of ocean currents _ 58.5 miles (94 kilometers) _ set in a swimming pool in Brisbane, Australia on July 2-3, 1993.

BC-UN-Child Labor,0504
Child marchers breathe new life into old U.N. agency
By ALEXANDER G. HIGGINS Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ An exuberant group of children who have been rescued from mines, sweatshops and servitude around the world descended on Geneva Tuesday to breathe new life into an old U.N. agency. The children will be among the first speakers at the annual meeting of the 174-nation International Labor Organization, which is considering a new world convention aimed at abolishing the most extreme forms of child labor. The children, including a 15-year-old boy from Bangladesh who lost a leg in a coal mine accident and an 11-year-old former domestic servant from Nepal, are culminating a six-month campaign. ``Go, go, global march,'' shouted the children Saturday as they led more than 1,000 demonstrators through the streets of Geneva. The campaign, sponsored by the ILO, the U.N. Children's Fund, Scouts and other organizations, began last January in the Philippines and has included marches in 62 countries in Asia, Africa, North and South America and Europe. Child labor tops the agenda of the annual two-week ILO meeting, which brings together representatives of government, labor and management. The ILO draws up and monitors conventions on a wide range of labor issues. The campaign against child labor was a boost for the ILO, showing that the oldest U.N. agency stemming from the 1919 creation of the former League of Nations is still needed to stop labor abuses around the world. The ILO has been singled out by the United States in its campaign to reform the world organization. Some U.S. Republicans have accused the ILO of being irrelevant. Another visitor expected at the meeting was newly freed Indonesian labor leader Muchtar Pakpahan, who was imprisoned from 1996 until last week on charges relating to civil unrest and alleged subversion. Other speakers were to include U.N. human rights chief Mary Robinson and Venezuelan President Rafael Caldera. The meeting will work on a declaration committing countries to work toward collective bargaining and the elimination of forced labor. The new child labor convention would call for criminal penalties, specify preventative measures and rehabilitation of child victims, according to the organization. The labor organization also has called for new international legal standards on child labor that would halt slavery and slavery-like practices, forced labor and debt bondage. The standards also would prevent children being used in prostitution and pornography or any activity likely to jeopardize their health or morals. ILO surveys have found that a quarter of all children ages 5-14 are economically active, with many of them doing hazardous jobs. ``Children are employed simply because they are cheaper and more compliant than adults,'' said Neal Kearney, general secretary of the Brussels-based International Textile, Garment and Leather Workers Federation.

LONDON (AP) _ Contracts to build a 5.4 billion pound (dlrs 8.9 billion) high-speed rail link from London to the Channel Tunnel are expected to be signed Tuesday, the Financial Times has reported. The newspaper predicted Tuesday that Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott would tell the House of Commons on Wednesday that his search for new backers to rescue the troubled 68-mile (110-kilometer) link has been successful. A spokeswoman for Prescott's Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions would not confirm the Financial Times report. ``The Deputy Prime Minister said he wanted to make an announcement as soon as possible after the (Parliament) recess,'' said the spokeswoman, speaking on customary condition of anonymity. ``But I am not in a position to confirm any particular date at this stage.'' London and Continental Railways Ltd., which won the contract to build the link in February 1996, said in January that it was 1.2 billion pounds (dlrs 1.9 billion) short. The government refused to provide the funds and said that unless the money could be raised, the state would take over the project. The government has already committed 1.8 billion pounds (dlrs 2.8 billion) to the link, which would carry trains at 300 kph (186 mph) through southeast England and is due for completion in 2003. Currently, passengers who ride the Channel Tunnel trains from Paris to London whiz at high speed through France, only to slow down after they cross under the sea and amble along British commuter tracks. Under the reported deal, London Continental Railways would receive financial backing from rail infrastructure group Railtrack. The Financial Times said the company would build the link in stages, with Railtrack agreeing to buy the first phase _ from the tunnel to Ebbsfleet in north Kent _ at a price reflecting construction costs. Railtrack would take an option over the later, more expensive sections of the line into central London, the newspaper said. (er)

BC-Palestinians-Watchmen,0563
Palestinian security firm patrols east Jerusalem
By IMAD MUSA Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ On their first night on the job, a team of Palestinian security guards dressed in matching black jackets bearing the company emblem _ the Dome of the Rock Mosque _ hit the streets of east Jerusalem in search of trouble. With crime on the upswing and no Palestinian police allowed in the eastern sector of Jerusalem, a group of Arab residents decided to take security into their own hands and turn a profit. Abdul Razzaq Ghazzawi, co-owner of the newly founded Jerusalem Security Services, and a former Israeli police officer said his company could fill the niche. ``We will protect the property here,'' he said. In March, professional thieves broke into a bank by drilling holes through three neighboring stores. And recently, robbers managed to walk out of a building in the area's busiest street with a giant safe. The Israeli police, who have jurisdiction in the area are investigating the crimes, but they maintain a small presence in east Jerusalem and often do not receive the full cooperation of Palestinians, distrustful of the Israelis who took over the area in the 1967 Mideast war. Israel annexed east Jerusalem shortly after the war, but the Palestinians want it as the capital of a future state. Palestinian leaders have for years been calling for a civilian Palestinian police force. Peace accords with Israel allowed Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority to operate in all Palestinian cities, but prevented it from working in Jerusalem and left the city's status open for future negotiations. The security company received verbal approval from Israeli authorities to go ahead ``as long as it does not break the law or establish relations with the Palestinian Authority,'' the company's lawyer, Jawad Bulous, said. That agreement is fine with the owners. ``We will not get involved in politics. Already some of our customers are afraid that the Israelis will close us down, and we do not want that to happen,'' Ghazzawi said. In the past, Israel has tried to prevent Palestinian security forces connected to the Authority government from operating in Jerusalem. Shmuel Ben Ruby, a spokesman for the Jerusalem police said he was checking into the company's approvals. The 25 young men of the security firm are armed with batons, flashlights, stun guns and small mace canisters and only work at night. Firearms were not provided however, ``to avoid any legal wrangling with the Israeli police.'' On Monday, four guards rode on scooters past store fronts, while others patrolled the unlit streets and winding stone alley ways on foot. They received no formal training, but Ghazzawi said he gave them two directives: Protect the stores and do not get involved in police work. The Palestinian Chamber of Commerce has already given the company its blessing and sent out letters to over 1000 business in east Jerusalem touting the new company's services. Ali Tazziz, who chairs the chamber said it was Israel's disregard of the traditionally Palestinian side of the city which led to the need for the company. ``The west side gets all the attention, protection and services,'' Tazziz said. ``We were forced to do this because of their neglect,'' he said.

Dollar higher, stocks bounce back moderately in Tokyo
Eds: UPDATES with midday currency, stock and bond prices
TOKYO (AP) _ The U.S. dollar was higher in morning trading Tuesday amid continuing pessimism about Japan's economy, though it retreated from seven-year highs reached overnight in New York. Tokyo stocks rose. The dollar bought 139.53 yen in early trading, up 0.41 yen from late Monday in Tokyo. In New York overnight, the dollar settled at 139.70 yen, its highest level since June 24, 1991. The dollar has gained steadily in recent weeks against the yen as sluggish consumer spending and the write-off of some 76 trillion yen (dlrs 550 billion) in bad loans by the nation's banks cloud the outlook for Japan's economy. But the dollar ceded some of its gains in early Tokyo trading amid a rising chorus of concern for the weakening yen by Japanese finance officials. Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga told reporters Tuesday the yen is too weak and Japan will take decisive action to defend it. The same day, Haruhiko Kuroda, head of the ministry's international finance bureau, said the pace of the Japanese currency's decline is too fast. ``In any case, I have strong concern about an excessively weak yen, and we will take appropriate and decisive action against it,'' Matsunaga said at a regular news conference. On the stock market, sentiment improved slightly after Monday's announcement that Nikko Securities Co., a major Japanese brokerage, and Travelers Group of the United States were planning an equity tie-up. The benchmark 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 120.58 points, or 0.79 percent, to 15,441.61 at the close of the morning session. On Monday, the index had lost 349.75 points, or 2.23 percent. ``The market welcomed Nikko's alliance, as it will likely trigger more Japanese financial institutions' tie-ups with foreign institutions,'' said Masaru Arai, general manager of the stock division at Ryoko Securities. Deepening worries over the state of Japan's economy had triggered Monday's fall. The broader Tokyo Stock Price Index of all issues listed on the first section was up 9.33 points, or 0.78 percent, to 1,206.03. The TOPIX fell 24.79 points, or 2.03 percent on Monday. Meanwhile, the yield on the benchmark No. 182 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 1.130 percent from Monday's record low finish of 1.155 percent, driving its price up to 112.59 yen from 112.41 yen.

BC-FEA-France-Micromotoring,0652
Forget gas guzzlers: kids, countryfolk drive lean and license-free
By CHRISTOPHER BURNS Associated Press Writer
LES HERBIERS, France (AP) _ For landlocked countryfolk without driver's licenses and chic Parisian teen-agers evading parental chauffeuring, a tiny contraption has been a boon. At first sight, it's cute as a bug and not much bigger. The two-seat Microcar has to be to stay under the weight and speed limits of a ``voiturette,'' or ``quadricycle.'' Owners don't seem to mind that it's like riding atop a lawnmower. They like the legal loophole: you don't need a driver's license. Never mind that Americans are embracing gas guzzlers thanks to rock-bottom prices at the pump. Europe's ``micro'' and larger ``mini'' car markets are benefiting from gasoline prices that can top dlrs 1.10 a liter (dlrs 4 a gallon). Microcar and eight other ``micro'' producers in France and Italy expect to sell 25,000 units this year, up from about 16,000 last year. At the assembly plant in this village outside Nantes in western France, lines of red, blue, gray and green Microcars hang from a yellow overhead conveyor belt that cranks out about 30 a day. A well-heeled subsidiary of the pleasure boating giant Jeanneau _ bought out in 1995 by another yachting giant, Beneteau _ Microcar glues together a featherweight body from nine pieces of reinforced polyester, using parts from regular automakers. The cars are limited to 350 kilograms (770 pounds). The Yamaha diesel engine powers the car up to 43.5 kph (27 mph) and uses 3.5 liters of gasoline per 100 kilometers (gets about 68 miles per gallon). The micros aren't much cheaper than some of their slightly larger competitors _ the minis like the Rover 100, Renault Twingo and Fiat Cinquecento. Microcar's sticker price starts at about 50,000 francs (dlrs 8,300). But the edge is, you don't need a license. Anyone 16 and over can drive them. ``I'm 16, and it's changed my life,'' says Emmanuelle Bousquet, whose family lives in the upscale western Paris suburb of Boulogne. ``I don't have to depend on taxis, buses, the subway, my parents.'' With Mom and Dad's help, she's added electric windows and leather upholstery to her trendy gray voiturette _ options Microcar offers to attract the Gucci crowd. Outside Orleans in the Loire Valley, Jacqueline Bourgeot has been driving micros since 1984. As an epileptic, she can't get a license. ``I'm independent with this car. I'm not forced to wait for my husband,'' said Bourgeot, 49, a nurse who works nights. She doesn't deny her Microcar is a bit loud, ``but it makes less noise than my Aixam and my Erade'' _ earlier versions of other makes. Microcar also makes a quiet electric version that looks like a small beach buggy, and some hybrid models use electric and diesel motors. So far, European officials don't see micros as a road hazard. They're already banned from freeways because they have to stay under 45 kph (28 mph). But it's anyone's guess how many owners may have lost their licenses because of drunk driving or other offenses, and no accident statistics are available. Up to now, there's been no clamor to do away with the legal loophole in France, Italy, Spain and a handful of other countries. But Britain and the Netherlands are among those that require licenses, and the European Union is studying how to standardize regulations on licenses and safety. The micros are part of the smaller-is-beautiful trend in Europe's car market. Analysts expect Europe's overall subcompact auto sales to rise more than 9 percent in 1998. Of course, Emmanuelle dreams of her 18th birthday, when she hopes to get a Volkswagen Golf. In the meantime, her parents can at least be happy she's riding on four wheels. ``A scooter is too dangerous for Paris,'' she says.

BC-FEA-US-Pantyhose Panacea,0719
There may be help for harried hosiery users
AP Photo NY342 By LISA CORNWELL Associated Press Writer
AKRON, Ohio (AP) _ Suzanne Nesbit knows pantyhose problems. Snags, runs, rips and tears _ always at the most inconvenient times _ are always followed by the traditional quick fix with smelly nail polish. ``And when you do use nail polish ... it sticks to your leg and you end up tearing off layers of skin when you try to take the hose off,'' Nesbit said. But Nesbit, a 36-year-old pharmacist who says she often snags her hose on desk corners and other equipment at Akron General Hospital, has found a new product that may be a boon to long-suffering women. RunFree Instant Hosiery Repair is an odor-free, colorless liquid that comes in a small tube and is applied with a brush like nail polish. It was created by Robert Horning and Deborah Vollmer who are betting that women are looking for better ways to patch their stockings and cut down on their hosiery costs. Industry experts believe it may be the first run-repair product of its kind. Horning and Ms. Vollmer, both of Akron, were on a date at a restaurant when she discovered she had a run in her stocking. She borrowed some nail polish from a woman in the ladies room. ``When I returned to the table, I told Bob I hoped the nail polish odor wasn't too strong, and he wanted to know why I was putting on nail polish in the middle of dinner,'' she said. Horning said he couldn't believe there wasn't a product to repair runs in women's hosiery. ``I guess, being a guy, I just never had thought about it,'' Horning said. They began brainstorming and decided they would give it a try. After consulting with chemists and physicists and testing more than 400 compounds, RunFree was developed in 1994. The next few years were spent working on packaging and marketing, and in November 1997, RunFree went on the market, retailing for dlrs 4.95 a bottle. A bottle will fix more than 60 runs and 100 snags. The clear liquid has only slight scent for second or two when first applied, then is odor-free. It can't be seen on hose the way nail polish can, and doesn't become hard. It also seems to withstand washings. Ann Coburn, 65, likes it so much she ordered 15 tubes to give out as party favors. ``It's nice to have something you can use for quick repairs, especially since you inevitably get runs and tears when you are running late or on your way to something important,'' she said. Susan Stromberg, manager of the Capezio Dance Theater Shop in the Cleveland suburb of Lyndhurst, has sold about 30 bottles and is on her second order. ``I've sent samples to our stores in New York, Dallas and Boston and it seems to be selling well if you bring it to customers' attention,'' she said. ``We sell products for adult ballroom and ballet dancers and for children in dance classes, and those stockings and tights can be really expensive to replace, with some costing as much as dlrs 23.'' Ms. Stromberg says her customers like RunFree because it can be used before runs even start to reinforce toes and panty. ``RunFree will outlive your pantyhose,'' she said. ``The threads will eventually wear thin in other parts of the stockings before the area with the run or snag treated with RunFree gives out.'' Sid Smith, president and chief executive officer of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, said women have tried a wide range of techniques to extend the life of their stockings _ even putting hosiery in the freezer with the hope that it will help prevent runs. But Smith knew of no other product aimed specifically at patching runs. He said he hasn't taken a look at RunFree yet. He did have an answer for the age-old question: Why can't manufacturers make pantyhose that won't run? ``Women would like pantyhose that don't run, but they also want sheerness,'' said Smith. ``The strength of hosiery is directly related to the size of the yarn, and the heavier yarn you use, the less sheerness you are going to have.'' Smith said there is nothing on the horizon to suggest a no-run, sheer pantyhose will be available in the near future. And that, say the makers of RunFree, is what they are counting on.

BC-FEA-US-Amusement Park Prices,0662
Up, up and away _ adult fees for U.S. amusement parks on the rise AP Business Writer
AP Photo NY450 By MIKE SCHNEIDER
ORLANDO, Florida (AP) _ When Disneyland opened its gates in 1955, it cost dlrs 1 to get in. Four decades later, the California landmark and amusement parks around the United States are charging prices that on popular vacation days in the past could have bought admission for the whole neighborhood. Nowhere is the steep rise in prices more pronounced than in Orlando, the theme park capital of the world. In the past month, the area's three major parks _ Disney, Seagram's Universal Studios Florida and Anheuser-Busch's Sea World _ have each raised the price of admission for an adult by more than dlrs 2, to dlrs 44.52, including tax. The fees leave some visitors as breathless as a roller-coaster ride. ``I was quite surprised. It was very expensive,'' said Pippa Timmins, a British tourist visiting Orlando with her husband and three children. During their two-week vacation, the family from Peterborough, England, visited Magic Kingdom, Disney-MGM Studios and Sea World. The scenario is the same nationwide. Knott's Berry Farm outside Los Angeles has raised its adult ticket price dlrs 1 to dlrs 36. Paramount's Kings Dominion near Richmond, Virginia, and Cedar Point in Sandusky, Ohio, raised adult ticket prices dlrs 2 to dlrs 32. Over the past decade, some parks have increased admission fees by as much as 75 percent. In 1989, a ticket to Sea World cost dlrs 25, Walt Disney World charged dlrs 30.50 and a visitor could get into both Kings Dominion and Cedar Point for dlrs 20, according to the trade publication Amusement Business. The higher prices haven't hurt business. A record 167.2 million people passed through the 50 most-frequented amusement parks in North America last year, Amusement Business said. Most theme parks raise their prices every two years or so, said Donna Ross, executive vice president of the Florida Attractions Association. Theme park owners and managers say they aren't to blame _ increases come from the higher minimum wage and the public's desire for something new. Both Knott's Berry Farm and Cedar Point, for example, are launching new tower rides which drop patrons into a controlled free-fall from several hundred feet in the air. Each costs several million dollars to build and customers pick up the tab. In central Florida, Disney has added a new theme park, Animal Kingdom; Universal added a multimillion-dollar Twister ride based on the film; and Sea World added Journey to Atlantis, a roller coaster-water flume ride. ``It's a continued investment in our business,'' said Tom Schroeder, a Universal spokesman. ``We're in the business of creating fresh, innovative attractions and to do that requires money. We need to get a return on our investments.'' Cypress Gardens in Winter Haven, Florida, raised its adult admission by dlrs 1 to dlrs 31 because of the increase in the minimum wage, co-owner Sharon Creedon said. ``We don't live in a vacuum. Your costs keep growing,'' she said. ``If all those costs remained stagnant, we could have our prices remain stagnant.'' There are discounts that couldn't be found a decade ago, too. Both Sea World and Universal have ``second-day free'' offers and there are off-season discounts for state residents. Tourists in Orlando can even get tickets as low as dlrs 17.50 if they listen to a 90-minute pitch from a salesman trying to sell them a vacation home first. Despite the costly tickets, the parks are going to have to charge a lot more money before they scare the Timmins family away. Mrs. Timmins and her husband, Peter, spent dlrs 5,000 on a two-week tourist package that included airfare, hotel, a rental car and theme parks admission. ``When they start charging dlrs 100, that's when we'll think twice,'' Timmins said.

Thai inflation expected to fall by year's end, deputy premier says
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Thailand's soaring inflation rate is likely to fall in the second half of the year and will be below IMF targets by year's end, a deputy prime minister predicted. Supachai Patichpakdi, who is also commerce minister, said in an interview late Monday on the ITV television station that declining inflation would allow high interest rates to fall as well. ``That will benefit the entire economic system,'' Supachai said, without giving any estimated figures. High interest rates are crippling Thai businesses struggling to survive the current recession, which the government said last week will be far deeper and probably longer than previously expected. The International Monetary Fund has demanded that Thailand keep inflation at an average of 10.5 percent for the year as a condition of receiving a dlrs 17.2 billion economic bailout package. The economy has begun to stabilize under the administration of Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, but new declines in the currency and stock market this week on fears of a deeper recession underscored how far the country still has to go. The Commerce Ministry released data Monday that showed Thai consumer prices rose 10.2 percent year-on-year in May, the worst inflation in more than three years. It was the fifth consecutive month this year that the index has risen. Inflation has worsened steadily since July 1997, when Thailand abandoned its fixed-exchange rate system under attacks by currency speculators and triggered a chain reaction of crises across Asia.

BC-Malaysia-Drought
Severe water rationing for parts of Kuala Lumpur
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (AP) _ Residents in large parts of the Malaysian capital may get water only once every three days as a severe draught forces authorities to consider drastic rationing, a newspaper said Tuesday. Rationing water may be the only way of stretching reserves that have fallen sharply in the absence of rain, the Star newspaper said quoting the Selangor Waterworks Department. One major reservoir near Kuala Lumpur has only enough water to supply city residents for another 10 days, the newspaper warned. ``The dam level now is only 1.26 meters (4.1 feet) above the critical level of 204.2 meters (673.8 feet),'' V. Subramaniam of the department said. Below the critical level it is difficult to pump water. The dam that normally supplies 477 million liters a day to the city was able to pump out only 191 million liters on Monday, the daily said. Three other dams that provide water to the city were also depleted and pumping out far less water than usual. Nearly two million or one-third of the population of Klang Valley, as Kuala Lumpur and its suburbs are known, have been on water rationing for three months. Residents have to wait with pails, plastic containers, urns and even bottles for water trucks to arrive. The worst drought in decades is being blamed for the water shortage in the city that depends mainly on rain-fed reservoirs. But experts also say that indiscriminate logging has affected the traditional rainfall in the area.

TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga expressed ``strong concern'' on Tuesday about the current level of the yen against the U.S. dollar and warned Japan will take appropriate action to stem its currency's fall. Matsunaga declined to comment on what he sees as an appropriate exchange rate for the American currency and the yen. ``But in any case, I have strong concern about an excessively weak yen, and we will take appropriate and decisive action against it,'' Matsunaga told a regular news conference.
